I wanted to read The Cuckoo's Calling solely because it was J.K. Rowling. I am a ridiculous fan of her work, her life story, ‚Äãand the Harry Potter series, on which, unlike most lucky readers, I did not get my hands until very recently (on book #5 now and going strong). This book is an entirely different genre and it's indeed easier to imagine an ex-military ex-cop ex-PI turned male author - perhaps by the name of Robert Galbraith - dreamed this up than the heart-warming fantasy fiction writer we know and love as Ms. Rowling.But alas, Rowling has many tales to spin, and I have to say, I loved this tale too. I generally go into books by the author and not by the book description, so I knew very little about the book. Had I read that it was about a super model who allegedly commits suicide and a grieving brother hires a PI to investigate it as a possible murder, I would have moved right on. I don't do murder mysteries, that's my mother-in-law's world. But I loved it.SPOILER ALERT - One burning question that I have if you've already read the book is this: Why did John Bristow hire the detective if the truth was as it was? Why would he benefit from the truth, or was he hoping for a different outcome, was he framing another or just pushing his luck for fun? And what clue was the initial giveaway for Strike?As for the characters: I liked Cormoran Strike alright. He's your typical ex-military PI, with a terrible war injury and a complex and self-destructive love life, and of course, he's a damn good detective to boot. Together with Robin, his "temp" secretary, they make such a fun match as they follow lead after lead to solving the mystery. The book takes you into the lives of the rich and famous: Guy Some, the gay fashion designer, Ciara Porter, the other supermodel, the Bristow family: a rich spoiled family with dark secrets and terrible relations toward one another, the boyfriend - drug-addict, spoiled, hungry for real love, too famous to care, too unstable to be likable, and more.The one theme that struck me is how assumptions can turn into reality when terrible things happen to those who are full of self-destructive habits. How easy is it so conclude that "Sure he killed himself. You could see it coming! He was depressed, an alcoholic and often talked of suicide. It all makes sense!" And yet, not every soul caught in the cycle of self-destruction is interested in ending his or her own life, and not all such deaths are "accidents" waiting to happen.While I have no real interest in the lives of rich and famous, I was drawn to the book because I am curious about the many facets of the author's skills. This is not exactly a "PG" or family friendly book. There is much cursing, much foul language, and sexual content that is hard to image from the author of Harry Potter, and that's not easy to do. This speaks to the versatile skills of the writer, and how she can truly put herself in the shoes of characters from all walks of life, and speak their language, express their pains and desires, and take us into their world. She is a master storytelling, and it shows in every unfolding of The Cuckoo's Calling. While I am not in a hurry to do so, I'll probably pick up the next in the series of Cormoran Strike, but first, I really do need to finish the Harry Potter series, or risk being the absolute last person on earth to do so!

For the author in you waiting to get out but held back by excuses, procrastination and most of all, fear, this book is for you. Presland takes you through the emotional management and tactical processes necessary to write your non-fiction book. There are exercises, actions at the end of each section and inspiration. The book's structure encourages you to apply the knowledge with a sense of urgency, and not to put off writing your book for all the excuses that hold back most of us writers. Also, there are some great suggestions I am going to use particularly around layout, chapter structure and self-publishing. All in all, a great resource for writers!

I received the Logitech Illuminated Living-Room Wireless Keyboard K830 for the purpose of driving a 2009 Mac Mini, which I use as an HTPC connected to my television.  In this regard, this keyboard performs well.  The integrated mouse pad and keyboard make it easy to drive web-based  video on-demand services from across the room (mainly for those that do not support Chromecast yet).  The only negative I had with it is that I could not get bluetooth connectivity to work with my Mac Mini.  I was able to get the keyboard working with bluetooth to a Macbook Pro just fine, so either my Mac Mini had an issue or it was too old/not running the proper OS to connect with the keyboard.  I used the included Unifying receiver to attach with my Mac Mini and connected that way and have had no issue with connectivity.

Our baby is now 12 pounds and it although he fits in this car seat and it is safe for him, it's easier to take him out of the car while he's in his infant car seat. The cover is also removable and it‚Äôs washing machine safe, so it‚Äôs easy to clean.With no complaints and only positive experiences with it, I give this beautiful  Black Maxi-Cosi Vello 65 Convertible Car Seat 5 stars.

This review contains SPOILERS. You've been warned! :)This book moved me so much: old age, loss, regrets, pain, terminal illness, loneliness, suicide, women in a "man's workplace", and a vile teenager (I could have done without David but I guess we need all the characters!). I liked Queenie Hennessy but I can't say that I loved her. I wanted to. The story starts in a hospice and it ends there. The mystery of Harold Fry was new to me as I had not read the other book, "The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry", Rachel Joyce's earlier book. I can't say that I'm drawn to reading it either.The writing is beautiful, I love how the author writes out the waltz scenes and the stunning way she describes Queenie's sea garden. I could almost see Queenie working there. The story is told from the perspective of Queenie and the timeline moves from the present time at the hospice to the past, all the way back to Queenie's childhood and then to the more recent past when she worked at the Brewery and fell in love with Harold Fry but did absolutely nothing about it. But that is not half as annoying as the vile teenage son of Harold Fry, David, a good-for-nothing teenager that Queenie is happy to let walk all over her. I just could not get onboard with the dynamics between David, Harold and Queenie. I  like to think my character is strong and has choices and exercises them, but Queenie just kept acting dumb and dumber, and I could not feel sympathy for her.One of the themes this author explores is one we may just know something about: how hard it is to tell the truth after the first lie and then the second one and then a mountain of lies, because you just couldn't bring yourself to tell the truth after that first one. Such is the dilemma of Queenie toward Harold.I listened to this book on audio, borrowed from the library, and it was a wonderfully entertaining listen, but I was impatient. I listened at 1.25x or 1.5x the speed. I wanted to keep moving forward. What secret had she kept for 20 years? And in the end, not only did I guess the secret (no, that never happens to me!!!), I also didn't find it to be intriguing enough. Argh. I do feel bad for Queenie and this was a stunningly written book, but my dislike of David was too much. If he was supposed to be the villain, at least then I knew I was supposed to dislike him, but there is no way I had any sympathy for that vile teenager.The best passages in the book are the dances, the drives with Harold Fry, the sea garden and the scenes at the hospice. They are bittersweet and lovely and full of joy.My favorite twist was learning that Queenie had imagined the help she was getting with her letters. But it made sense. It was better that way. Did Harold Fry find out about the secret after all? Could he read her shorthand? Was there anything else to give it away? I don't know. I never will. I am however glad to have read the book.

Disclaimer: I received a free copy of Bob Pritchett's book, Start Next Now, and here is my honest product review.From the description: "This fast-paced book provides you with an actual plan to start achieving your goal before you even finish reading." So it's a quick read, motivational to light a fire under you and to get you going, to make you feel responsible for your life and your dreams, and to give you pointers here and there about the next steps in your education, career, or business, but the term "an actual plan" is an exaggeration.It's a quick read, maybe 40 minutes and the author is a savvy businessman who knows a lot about running a business, starting from scratch and not attaching value to the usual stuff that misdirects those of us in search of something more than just a job and a salary. He has some extremely good points: About questioning the value of further education, an MBA, or a big name school, about setting yourself apart whether in an interview or in an office conversation and about staying motivated and giving up watching TV or doing stuff that wastes your time, and those are all very good pointers.The main problem is that there are no step-by-step how-to on figuring out your passion or starting a business or getting a raise other than the cursory details and the book is so short, it just doesn't have the capacity to go into any level of detail as it's tackling way too many subjects at once.A lot of the concepts, while I agree 100%, are the same old motivational and inspirational words and phrases you hear from any successful business person. I had hoped for some originality, but I did not come away with any.The main issue I see here is me: I am not the ideal target reader for this book, as I felt I knew a lot of what was in here. If you are completely new to the idea of making a change in your life, getting unstuck, pursuing your goals, listening to your heart, doing the right thing without asking for permission, etc. and don't need to go into any depth on any given topic, if you need a quick boost and inspiration to get started down the right path or at least, start moving away from the wrong thing, it can be a good read. this may very well serve as a great resource.

I gifted this L'Oreal Paris Age Perfect Hydra-Nutrition to my mom. She had insisted that she knew exactly what she wanted. She's in her early 60s and has beautiful skin, but the wrinkles have appeared and so I got it for her. She hasn't stopped talking about it. She loves this cream so much, and I also went ahead and bought one for myself.While my mom hasn't been the fanatic I am about her skin, she is still seeing nice benefits from the cream especially for the price. For me, I have used $60 or even $90 face creams that promise you the world, and only take your money. I've also used cheap skincare and sworn it off, but I do trust L'Oreal and other brands that have been around for decades and have done tons of scientific research on their formula and are providing these wonderful creams at decent prices.I use the cream after I take off all my makeup and tone my face. I use it over my face and neck. I also use it on airplanes because it is super hydrating on dry airplanes, and recovery for your skin is essential if you fly a lot. I haven't used it during the day - it's thicker than I would like for a daily moisturizer and no SPF, but I'm sure you could if you are staying indoors all day.Fantastic skincare that I plan to continue using for the foreseeable future. Thank you L'Oreal!

Friendly warning: My review may contain spoilers so beware if you haven't read the book and are sensitive to such things.I read After You before its prequel, Me before You, and while I wish I had read them in the right order, I gained an interesting perspective reading them in reverse. This was the third book in the last month that I have read by Jojo Moyes, and it's my least favorite and I still loved it. The Girl You Left Behind is my true favorite and After You my second favorite, even though I was so fed up with Lily, the spoiled little brat, but alas, annoying characters are part of a great story.I was far more attuned to the audio version and the reader's voice in After You that it took me a few hours into the book to warm up to this female version of Louisa Clarke, but warm up I did, and I stayed up late, laying on the carpet, stretching my limbs and listening to the final hours of the story of Louisa Clarke and Will Trainer.  It was truly a lovely story, even if you had to tolerate way too much of Patrick (aka, running man! yikes!) and too little of the love story between Louisa and Will - it really didn't come into play until the latter part of the book, and it ended almost before it started.Jojo Moyes grapples with some complex themes, the biggest one the choice of self-assisted suicides for those terminally ill and suffering, and whether this is something their families and loved ones and the right 'authorities' should allow or deny. I learned quite a bit about the limited life of quadriplegics and admired Louisa's determination to help Will find a thread of hope in the living side. And yet I couldn't help but see Will's side of life in this way versus life the way he had known it, and despite the love that had grown in his heart, he couldn't bear the thought of living this way. Dying looked more appealing than living in his condition, and that made this book a terribly sad story to read.I wasn't crazy about the break in the choice of narrators especially since NONE of them included Will. One chapter was by Trina the sister, another by Nathan the medical care provider and another by Mrs. Trainer and yet another by Mr. Trainer, but mainly we saw the world through third-person limited view of Louisa Clark, but this did afford you the 360 view into the tragic lives of those affected by such awful twists in fate.Overall, I LOVE love LOVE this author. Jojo Moyes is funny, smart, both heart-wrenching and heart-warming, and draws up characters and circumstances and lives so real that you feel you are there with them, watching them go through their conflict and triumphs, and being as real as your own breathing! Plus I'm now into my modern English female novelists phase, so I'll be reading more of her work.What would you do if you were a 35-year old most successful, admirable, adventurous, physical, wealthy and life-hungry person and an accident took all that away from you, leaving you at the mercy and burden of others to take care of you, to see to your every need and to go through hell with you. What if you knew that not only you won't be getting better, but you will actually be getting worse, with frequent bouts of pneumonia and various infections, and a very good chance of some bacteria or virus taking over at anytime and declaring you finished. Just like that. Maybe a part of you might choose a dignified way of dying, on your terms, on your chosen day and hour, with all who love you surrounding you.This is a book that shows us to respect the choice and decisions of those who are most affected by their own affliction, and to honor the choice of life or death, whatever their wish may be, even if our own selfish desires would rather see the suffering person among the living. It's a vastly complex and yet simple theme and Jojo Moyes does a brilliant job of exploring it to its very core.

I do a lot of yoga and my yoga teacher out in Hawaii swears by the Smelly Washer brand. I'm brand new to this. I got two kinds, one is a regular one and another is this Towel Cleaner version.It is in powder form and it is pretty strong. The label warns that if you put new clothes, the colors will fade. I threw all my yoga towels and other regular towels in but I missed a brown top in there too. It wasn't new and it did not fade one bit. In fact, none of my towels, even the pink one, suffered from any loss of color.The bad sweat smell is gone now, and your towels smell of absolutely nothing. :) It's great for the bad smell to be gone but I wish there was some kind of scent to give to the freshly cleaned laundry. Anyway, that was not the #1 priority and the stuff works. I'm partial to liquid detergents but we used the powder and the results are satisfactory.I would not use this powder with a regular load of laundry. It's targeted for towels only.

My review does contain plot spoilers so read at your own risk. :)"It was never about the painting, Sophie."An amusing fact is that I kept wondering about what happened between Heir Kommandant and Sophie. How is it possible that the author didn't reveal that critical scene? How was I left to guess what happened there? So I was searching the web with the phrase: "Did Heir Kommandant sleep with Sophie?" and I found Chapter 9, which contains this critical quote, a chapter that somehow my audio book completely skipped over!!!! Now everything in this dark world makes a lot more sense, and Sophie's story is even more bleak, as if that were possible.I Loved this story so much. This was my 2nd read by Jojo Moyes nd I'm already reading a third and fourth book by her. Her writing style is a symphony to my ears, part Jane-Austen (without censoring the sex, thankfully!) and part modern-day British female novelist with a most capable skill of describing detail. Jojo Moyes is particularly effective in describing love and loss and the journey of the heart and mind as it comes to the realization of one's terrible fate. If you love complex characters put in impossible situations, you will love this war-time love story which tracks the history of a painting that is central to the plot. I enjoy both story and plot in my novels and I suppose it's in my DNA that as a woman, I would enjoy a story of heartbreak, grief, love, loss and Jojo Moyes delivers on every aspect.Many reviewers have said how much they loved the complex war-time story of Sophie and her beloved Edouard over the present-time modern story of Liv and Paul, and frankly, I think that's just easy to do. War-time love stories grip you. It is so hard for us to imagine a world stripped of everything normal, of beauty and humanity and peace, a world filled with terror and fear and atrocity, and to throw a love story in the midst of that makes it impossible to match with any modern day drama. Yet, I feel that it was truly a well-done fantastic novel.I do admit that when we switched over from Sophie's impossible situation in 1917 over to a bar or restaurant in 2006, I was throw off, and I didn't want to care about Liv and her stupid drama, her loss, her grief, and her propensity for a little alcohol. I just didn't care until I did, and then it was impossible to let it go. There are a few more flashbacks from present time over to Sophie's circumstances, and then the rest of the holes are filled with old surviving relatives, hidden letters and other forms of proof uncovered during the trial.Yes, Paul and Liv did not have the same impact as Sophie and her Edouard but why should they? They are in a different age and circumstance. The story has to flow and it did. The loose ends were attended to, the questions answered and you were left feeling so much compassion for characters that you had never met in real life. You know you will cry reading this book, right?The themes were all over the place: Love, loss, sacrifice, uncertainty, fear, terror, hope, despair, anger, rage, helplessness, victimhood, desire, judgment, kindness, beauty, art, humanity and fate.Thank you, Jojo Moyes, for an experience I will not forget. Your characters are etched in my memory, and hard as it was to read and imagine the war time story of Sophie, I am so very glad for it.

Cute short little read even for adults. A friend of mine posted the best quote from the book."He said, "You become!". It takes a long time. That's why it doesn't happen often to people who break easily or have sharp edges or who have to be carefully kept. Generally, by the time you are Real, most of your hair has been loved off, and your eyes drop out and you get loose in the joints and very shabby. but these things don't matter at all, because once you are Real, you can't be ugly, except to people who don't understand."And that is why I picked up this beautiful little read, my first by Margery Williams, and finished it in 20 minutes. It was a break from the heavy-duty stuff I read, and a message I needed to hear. A message that is relevant to so much of life and what we are experiencing, for me it's the path to creating a business and staying humble on the Ashtanga journey, and for you, it may be something else, but it is entirely applicable to an aspect of your life.All the same, I am reserving my 5-stars for books I love-adore-inhale so this is a 4-star.

It's not a low quality kind that you would normally get for this price, and I appreciate the attention to detail that went into creating the jars.

As an adult reader of these books, I started the Harry Potter series well over a year ago, and devoured the first 3 books of the 7 and then got side tracked to other books. A few months ago, I decided to go back and finish them when they became available on the Kindle Unlimited Store, and with that long a break, I couldn't just start where I left off, so I re-read all of them. It was a wonderful treat. And I just now finished Book 4.You can immediately notice the darker, deeper, more complex, more grim and perhaps adult-like tone of the books. We are now in the 4th year of Harry's schooling and he meets again with the dark lord and his grotesque plans throw even darker shadows over Harry and Hogwarts.The plot of evil thickens, the friendship bonds between Harry, Ron and Hermione strengthen, even as he spends much of the book on his own, sorting through his own challenges, and Rowling gives you so much more to reflect on. The themes of shame and guilt around identity, the true test of friendship, the acts of selflessness and compassion, the temptations of winning vs. doing the right thing, the power of trust, the test of strength, the resistance to fight your enemies when they tease your friends, and the show of courage even and especially when you are scared out of your mind.My favorites in this book: How Hermione and Harry collaborated, Mad-Eye Moody's protective ways, Hagrid and Madame Maxime's relations, the French kids from Beaubaxton's and the concept of foreign schools even in the Wizarding world, Ron's jealousy and denial, the Weasley twins and their adventures, and the reappearance of Sirius Black.What I love so much about JK Rowling is how REAL she makes it all. How she draws parallels from Hogwarts and magic and the Wizarding world into the regular world, carrying themes of abuse among teens, jealous, compassion, love, worry, anxiety, stress over studies, the desire to win and to impress and to hide your emotions for fear of being laughed at and so much more, it's as if the only difference is that you can do magic in that world but not in the regular world, and yet, you have all the other issues to deal with. Because if magic solved everything, I suppose, then what would the  point of the book or the story? She's beyond brilliant and I can't wait to get into Book 5.

Disclaimer: I received a free Best French Press from X-Chef  and here is my honest product review.As the non-coffee drinker, I didn't have immediate use for a French Press but then as a fanatic of loose-leaf fine tea and forever making different types of tea and never having enough tea pots, the French Press came in very handy.If you want to use it for tea, then never use it for coffee. The coffee smell never goes entirely away and it will affect the aroma of tea. Make it exclusively for tea.This is a large French Press. We made two 16-oz tea mugs and there was still a little room left to fill. If you're making Oolong tea, make sure to drain all of the tea during each steeping so that the wet leaves are not soaking in luke warm water as you are enjoying the first round.It's a beautiful sturdy and nice French Press. It is well-made, and I love it already. I would not put it in the dish washer, and not mix it for multiple uses of tea and coffee if you drink both.

This is my first essential oil diffuser. I usually just burn incense or rarely use candles for smells and scents, but since I've been getting into essential oils lately, I wanted to test out a diffuser. After reading a bunch of reviews, I settled on this mainly because of the dual function of diffuser and the soothing lights.During the day, I've been using it in my office. In the evenings, I put it in my bedroom and we've been running it all night.The diffuser has two settings for the lights and I usually have it on the dimmed version. I don't believe there is a way to just have the diffuser and not the lights and why would you? The lights change color, I've seen about a half dozen beautiful colors. Each one stays on a few seconds and then it slowly morphs into another color. Very relaxing.For the diffuser part, I fill the water from the tap up to the Max Line marked clearly on the diffuser and then add 4-5 drops of essential oils, put the cover on, and then I plug it in. Make sure you put the diffuser on a flat surface, it does better on a flat wood or metal surface than on cloth or fabric surfaces.The diffuser comes on at intervals. It is not a constant diffuser. Every 10 seconds or so, it comes on for about 8-12 seconds, then a 10-12 second break, then it goes again, and as it comes on, there is a little humming sound that it makes, very low but my husband was noticing it the first night. Update on this a week later: My husband can't seem to sleep to the sound of the oil diffuser coming on, so after much "discussion", we are now leaving the oil diffuser part OFF but leaving the light ON - apparently that doesn't bother him. So keep this in mind in case you are a super light sleeper. It doesn't bother me so I'm keeping the 5 stars.It's really relaxing to watch the diffuser with the lights changing and the steam coming off the top and the smell filling up the room. I plan to use it for a very long time!

Disclaimer: I received a complimentary The Best Leather Care Treatment from Leather Nova and here's my honest request.Disclaimer: I received a complimentary Leather Conditioner & Restorer from Leather Nova and here's my honest request.I used this primarily on my leather chairs and my husband's black leather piano stool. The leather chairs are brown thick leather and needed some professional cleaning, and the piano stool is a black leather stool with the buttons.I got this  Leather Nova's Leather Cleaner along with Leather Conditioner & Restorer along. Here's how I used it.First, I made sure the furniture isn't dusty - if it were, I'd have used a dry rag to just dust it off. Then I applied the Leather Conditioner & Restorer into a clean microfiber towel (not directly at the furniture) and applied to the chair in circular motions. You have to be careful not to get your nails on the leather so to avoid scratching your own furniture. Those don't come off easily. And I did this twice, and applied it completely to the whole leather sofa. After it had finished drying - 2-3 hours - I then applied the Leather Conditioner & Restorer to the little sponge pad which came with it and this gave it a clean shiny look. I love it. I'm very impressed.Now there was another reason I was interested in leather cleaners. There is a patch of an area on the leather sofa which is particularly worn out - it has a sticky feeling - I've tried everything to get it off without lucky. I swear it is so much smoother and softer after applying the leather cleaning and I plan to do this regularly (once a month) so I can keep restoring that section back to the original. I have high hopes. Love this product, and it has done much better than my previous leather cleaners! Just keep in mind that you may want to get both this and the Leather Conditioner & Restorer to use them together.

I like Gaiam brand in general, but this top is just okay. It's got nice sleeves and a decent material but the back is frumpy and doesn't relax as well in your lower back, so I'm not terribly impressed with the design, but the material is good. It's one of those borrowed designs with imperfect execution, at least on my body.Also, they sent out a Medium instead of a Small, which is making this more of a loose top. I got the grey, you'd be better off with the black, as tops in black looks so much more sophisticated.

Hubby and I are on weight watchers, and very proud of ourselves, but one thing we desperately needed to use on a very frequent basis was a kitchen scale. I've been reading reviews of a bunch of different brands and this one looked and felt like the right one so I snatched it up.It is extremely light, but that's not a bad thing. And extremely sensitive too which can be a good thing in a scale. We are usually weighing out all of our foods and what I was looking for was a scale that obviously gives me the accurate measures but also can be reset and turned off relatively quickly. You still have to press the buttons and hold them down a couple of seconds before the LED light goes off.Other than that, so far it's doing its job. I'm afraid I don't have 6 months worth of use to report yet, but I'm giving it a 5 star for now and coming back to update if there should be any changes!

I was not familiar with the super popular Dr. Bronner's brand, and I came across this through a problem with ahem, smell. Let me explain. I do this crazy yoga called Ashtanga and it's usually a 2 hour sweaty (emphasize the word SWEATY) practice in a room with others. As there's not too many people in my household, we do not do laundry every day and I've struggled with the idea of letting my wet sweaty clothes sit in the hamper until the next wash day. Sometimes it's okay but over time, a lot of my tops developed this disgusting odor because they had gone sour. Another regular wash didn't work so I needed a strong heavy-duty brand of soap to do the job. This stuff was the highest recommended item from my yoga community so we got it, and today we ran a super long load on a 1/4 cup of Dr. Bronner's Fair Trader & Organic Castille Liquid Soap, and the clothes smell wonderful. I love the smell of Tea Tree and the absence of the other smell.As this is a multi purpose soap, I use it also for regular hand washing and other tasks, and it is serving us brilliantly. Really happy with this brand, and I've got the lavender version waiting to be tested, although I think the Tea Tree was a much better deal.So YES to fixing your sour clothes with Dr. Bronner's! So relieved.

Imagine if you could go back and redo the big incidents of your life, the ones that led to accidents or tragedies or big irreversible mistakes of your life, and if you could just relive them, and yes relive your entire life too if you took the option, and you could make a smarter, better, more well-informed decision. How different the course of your life would be? How different your outcomes, the people in your life, and the places you end up in.Well, Life after Life is a repetition of this very concept for the incredible LIVES of one Ursula Todd. I never liked Groundhog Day, and much as I like Bill Murray, I found the movie rather annoying. Oh not again! was my sentiment for seeing the same scene over and over, and yet I could appreciate the concept if not the particular events and settings and people. If you could turn back time, what would you do differently? It's not just an interesting concept, it is a massively complex one and it only works if you can do a great job with the execution of it, and Kate Atkinson does it remarkably well. She imagines all the horrible things that could have happened to Ursula, and in some lives, they befall her earlier than in other lives, all marked by the somber words: Darkness fell.Atkinson is rich in her prose, elaborate in her descriptions, and remarkable in creating bonding with the reader - you and me. I had never heard of it until I found this book in the audio selection of Overdrive from the library, and I'm thrilled. She's a phenomenal novelist, with more than a little of Jane Austen in her. The settings of 20th century, the wars, England, Germany, and an upper class British family and the writing style all give me flashbacks to Jane Austen, with a 100 years of period gap.I like Ursula so much and feel for her. I like reading stories where I like the protagonist. I'm finding myself cheering her on and hoping she'll escape this particular tragedy in this life so she can get past this stage and we can move on. I like too that Atkinson is not telling you much at all. You have to pay attention and piece the story and the lives together. You have to know what happened in the past life and what led us to come to this life now. And as someone who is just terrible with novels - or movies - that do weird stuff with timelines, I think I'm following quite well, and so no doubt no other reader will have trouble with it.Since she is writing about the 20th century, Atkinson has no trouble finding powerful themes for her novel: two world wars, Germany, England, bombings in London, women issues, famine, and more interesting topics of adultery, affairs, exploring one's own path in a society and a time that judges your every move, and society does include one's own flesh and blood: one's family. I loved the characters of Ursula, Todd, Izzy, Hugh, and Crichton.In the end, I can't help but feel sorry and nostalgic for Ursula, as if I'm missing the new versions of her life recurring until all eternity. When does it end, the chance to live again? In Groundhog Day, it was after you learned the lesson and could properly move on to tomorrow, but with Ursula? Oh you must really just ready this novel, it's so very good.

These Gaiam yoga socks could be a real 5 star IF they were not so big. I wear US Shoe size 7.5 and they are a little too big, so they slip off and move around when you try to do some yoga in them but they are very cute, lively color and shades of purple and pink, and a nice stretchy material. I wore them just to walk around the house in them on the hardwood floors and it felt better than walking barefeet. Some support!I don't think you can get a full yoga practice in them, so if you are looking for that level of practical use, I wouldn't recommend them.

I've been using this monitor for the past few weeks and I find it a solid addition to the Samsung lineup.  My primary monitor has a 16:10 ratio (the great Samsung U2412M), and this one has a 16:9 which is a bit more of a widescreen look.  There are only two connection options, a VGA cable and HDMI (but there are no speakers so you can't use that HDMI connection for any audio).  No USB ports or anything extra like that...just the 2 video inputs and a power plug.Really the only drawback for me is the lack of any up/down adjustments: once the monitor is on the stand then that is the height it will be, so getting it to the proper level with other monitors will require the other monitors to adjust up and down.  A minor annoyance, but I am able to work around it.

Disclaimer: I received a free Thunder Chalkboard Stick-on Labels and White Color Liquid Chalk Pen and here's my honest review.I have never used a product like this so I was excited. You get several sheets of stickers, different shapes, and the black is very nice with a polished look about it. And then you get a single pen to use along.First downer I had was that the sticky labels was stuck a little too hard onto the paper. It took me a lot of work to get it completely out, and I lost a couple. I don't know why this was the case.The second downer is the pen, it is not nearly as bright and white against the black background as you'd like to see. I can understand that if I had been using it for a while but it is totally fresh!!! I wonder if it will run out way before I run out of stickers.They do wash off easier and you can reuse them and reapply them but the less-than-sharp-clear pen makes it hard to give this more than a 3 star.

Disclaimer: I received this non-slip eco-friendly AVIVA yoga mat free in exchange for an honest review.I am so grateful to AVIVA for making such great beautiful products. I love their yoga blocks and I really wanted to LOVE this yoga mat too. It is a great double sided mat that you can use for mild yoga, Kundalini, or gentle yoga. I have it spread out on my yoga studio floor and I use it to push up onto handstands and for knee support. the surface area is very soft cushy material with some patterns along the mat for focus and concentration. It's also perfect for meditation! I also love the colors: orange on one side and navy on the other.Because it's so soft and cushy, it folds up really nice for travel in a luggage too.Unfortunately, for the type of yoga I do, which is sweaty hard-core Ashtanga yoga, it doesn't work well. When you sweat, the mat doesn't absorb the sweat and so it becomes quite slippery. My go-to mat is a Manduka and if you are used to practicing on that, this won't give you the support and stickiness factor that you absolutely need to do your practice. So take sweat and the type of your yoga into account, but if you want just to have a spare yoga mat around, it's a great and beautiful mat.

Disclaimer: I was given a free 6-pack in exchange for a fair and honest review.The socks arrived in some kind of bubble wrapped box, which was very strange, as socks are the last item to be considered "Fragile!" but whatever. It was a protective packaging. You get 6 pairs and I initially thought that these are for me - I'm a woman! - but they seemed very big so my husband took them. We washed them before he wore them, so regarding the other review, I can't say how they smelled. I didn't smell them! They seem to be decent socks, - nothing special about them. They fit him as expected, and they feel nice and comfortable, but again, everything is just average about them, so I'm giving them a 3-star. I hope this helps.

.. beyond a shadow of a doubt, too scary for children and some adults. I didn't know what Coraline was about except that there was a little girl, a world behind the wall and well, Neil Gaiman. My 6th book by Neil Gaiman was yet another success. I listened to this read by the author himself and it was delicious. Nobody can tell a story as well as Neil. He is exquisite. He has an imagination like no other, and you can hear his invisible signature in all of his works. As you can tell, I adore Neil Gaiman and this book is a solid 5 stars. I can't say that I *loved* it - I never say that about Neil's work. I just enjoy them immensely. I can't help not listening onceFor the over-sensitive, just be forewarned. I'm not speaking to the plot as much but there may be some references that may be considered a spoiler in your book.As to the story, it's short and not-so-so-sweet ;)! It started off great, and Coraline's life was perfectly boring and normal until she went through the door in the parlor. And then the parallel worlds started to collide into one another. The Other parents. The Other neighbors. The other life. You know, one of my favorite phrases in this book was when Coraline says to the Other neighbor, "I don't want what I want. Nobody does! What's the fun of getting everything that we want?" I love that truth - I don't want what I want. We want what we have, I suppose, and we are reminded of it so much more fiercely when we lose it, which is the great theme of this book when Coraline is separated from her real parents and her real life, the boring and normal one that she was trying to get away from, and such is the sweet irony of life.As much as I enjoyed the book, something about it made me shudder. It was creepy and scary and bizarre and weird, and it was extremely well done but something. Maybe it's Gaiman's fascination with rodents, all the business with mice and rats. Maybe it was the button eyes. Yeah that one was creepy. Maybe it was the souls in the closet. I don't know. Maybe it was the unknowns of the world he had created. I think it was missing context - more context as to what this world was. More telling from the author and less guessing from the reader. Yes, that's it. I wanted more of that but hey, maybe I didn't. Do we really want what we want? Coraline doesn't think so, so who am I to argue? Hey, just read it. It's only 200+ pages and it's Neil Gaiman. Such a genius!!!

I love Lara bars in general, but this - the BLUEBERRY MUFFIN - is the ONLY Lara bar that I crave. I can eat the other flavors, and they're good compared to other bars, but this one is out of this world. I have been ordering them by the box. And I am not at all a bar-kinda-girl, but I have to tell you, if you like the chocolate/blueberry taste, and want the healthy nutritious compact meal that this LaraBar is, you have arrived home.I wanted to wait and do my review after the honeymoon wore off to make sure it's not a passing fancy, but it's been over 6 months and I'm still loving the LaraBar as much as ever before.

Disclaimer: I received a free Lumo Lift to use and below is my honest review on the product.Being in front of a computer most of the day, I found myself falling into a pattern of slouching down into my seat.  That, coupled with the fact that I "look down" at my hand held devices which put my neck at an awkward angle, definitely contributed to various tingling and pain in my arms, back and neck.Thankfully, the Zumo Lift is just what I needed to become mindful of my posture. It was very easy to pair with my smartphone (via Bluetooth) and after a couple of minutes figuring the device out I was able to put it to use.  The device will "buzz" if it finds itself out of alignment with the preset "good posture position", and after the first couple of days of using it I found that I was more cognizant of my posture because I knew I was wearing the device.  Even the times when I wasn't wearing the device I was paying attention to how I was carrying myself so it definitely makes you more aware of how you are sitting and standing. I've only been using it a week, but I will be using it for the foreseeable future until my desired posture is "locked in"!

Disclaimer: I received a free Harcas Knife Sharpener and here's my review. In fact, my dad also used it and contributed to my review below as he does most of the cooking and food preparation. :)-The hand can hold this sharpener very conveniently so the grip is great.- The abrasion material underneath will not let it slid on the counter when sharpening a knife.- The height of the sharpening blades are located high enough not to scratch the counter while sharpening.- The ceramic rods hones the knife until its razor is sharp so be careful!- Interesting to know that Harcas Sharpener also sharpens the blunt knives.This is a great essential tool to have in the kitchen if you use your knives regularly. Sharp knives are safer to use than blunt knives, a counter-intuitive concept that I didn't know until I learned it. So sharpen those knives before using them!

My SimpleHuman trashcan is probably about 7 years old by now. I have since purchased one for my parents and one for my in-laws. I heard my brother also uses this trashcan. This is a must-have for any nice usable functional kitchen, hands down! Here's why we LOVE our Simplehuman trashcan.Trashcans, to be perfectly honest, were never on my shopping list, much less on a list of item that I would research and spend so much money on, but after using disgusting old smelly cheap trashcan for years, I decided ENOUGH. My kitchen deserves a nice looking and more importantly, functional trashcan that looks as good as the rest of my appliances.I love simplehuman because:1. The stainless steel clean look with black. Stylish and clean.2. Keeps odors in. I can't impress upon you how important this function is especially when the trashcan is out in the kitchen and not in some closet.3. Holds a lot of trash. It's nice not to have to empty the trash so frequently without the consequences of smell and stink!4. Functional for years.5. Easy to change bags, insert new ones, and clean the inside black plastic trashcan which comes out and can be hosed down and washed if need be.Best and most functional item for any decent kitchen. Simplehuman has delivered a great product here. We are grateful!

Disclaimer: I received a complimentary Bago Travel bag and here's my honest review.This is a small backpack that gets folded into a nice zippable bag that you can then throw into your suitcase and take with you for use at destination. The material is great - it's a nice quality of nylon with a nice pattern on the black and the dark muted colors are easy to match with anything. That's the color I received and like it. They also have bright colors you can choose from.This is perfect for a daypack on travel. I see myself using it on occasion when a day's hike may be involved. It is something I would only wear when I am dressed very casually. It's a very sportish bag and I wouldn't wear it if I were dressed nicer for the day. Maybe I'm funny that way but I do try to match the bag to my attire :)!You can adjust the strap and use the side pockets for small bottles of water. The bag itself is smaller than I had thought also, without any cushion so I would not put my laptop in there without some cushion and padding on it. It's meant to be for small quick errands when you are away to give you room for extra storage. It's also rain proof and so no worry on getting things wet.It is a simple design for a simple function and it is well made. I would recommend it if you want to pack an extra bag on your next travels.

Love these bolsters. They are firm, so if you are looking for something softer, Manduka has some great softer cushions but these bolsters are firm, and I don't believe the cover unzips - I saw that someone was trying to wash the cover, I don't recommend that. It's a very tight fit around the bolster and I would not want to put it back on. It's not exactly like a pillow case over a pillow.The print, the design, the feel of the fabric and the colors are LOVELY. Hugger Mugger is exclusive and you simply want to HUG these bolster! :)Best use for this bolster: Put a block on one far end of your mat, put the top of the bolster on the block so it lays at an angle, then put your lower back to the end of the bolster and lay flat on the raised edge, relaxing your arms on each side. It's a beautiful way to unwind after yoga!!!Plus they are gorgeous pieces of furniture to have around your yoga space or studio.

I LOVE this soft, cushy, light yet supportive, sweet-touch-to-the-skin round yoga bolster. I use it during Savasana mainly under my knees to raise them and spread them and let my hips relax further. I also lay long side of it to open my back very gently before  more hard-core back bends. I can't tell you how much I love Manduka, and while the bolster is a luxury and not necessary for my yoga practice, it is a nice treat!!

This is my favorite tweezer in the world. I had the first one for about a year before I left it in Las Vegas by accident during a recent trip. It was a no-brainer than I had to get back on Amazon and order a second one which arrived yesterday and this one has a pretty clear case. (I don't recall the first one shipping with a case.) And I'm back in business now. :) Both times, I got chosen the pink color. I like how they don't let you choose and they just sendSeriously though, Tweezerman is gentle, effective, doesn't leave marks on your skin, it is a most brilliant useful tiny tool that I will be using daily.

All it took for me to pick up ‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation‚Äù was the presence of Swamp Thing on the cover. DC Comics knew exactly what they were doing and I fell for it. I‚Äôm a sucker for anything that features Bernie Wrightson and Len Wein‚Äôs mossy creature. Unfortunately, he didn‚Äôt figure into the story as much as I would‚Äôve hoped. That‚Äôs not to say the book wasn‚Äôt compelling.With the Justice League missing and the villains in control, Phantom Stranger must destroy evil itself! But to stop the Crime Syndicate, Deadman must take control of Aquaman‚Äôs body!The official synopsis provided by DC is really just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to ‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation.‚Äù There‚Äôs so much more here than just what they describe. The Phantom Stranger must save his guardian angel, partner with the Spectre to do battle against the Sin Eater and his evil minions, and face his day of judgment against a council made up of his most dangerous enemies.He does all of this while battling his own will to rebel against his Maker and take things into his own hands. The fact that so much of the book deals with spiritual battles within ourselves is part of what kept me interested in ‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation.‚Äù Granted, there are a lot of religious ideologies mixed together here. Although much of it is based in Christianity and the teachings of the Bible, other world religions end up being blended in and create a hodge podge of New Age mumbo jumbo in the end.The concept of the Phantom Stranger being Judas Iscariot atoning for his betrayal of Jesus Christ intrigued me immediately. His is a story about the road to redemption and his constant struggle to keep the faith and blindly follow the Will of God wherever it takes him. J.M. DeMatteis, Len Wein, and Dan Didio do a good job combining forces to keep readers engaged through this collection of issues 12 through 22 of the Trinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger and Trinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Future‚Äôs End #1.One problem I had with ‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation‚Äù is the way the different issues skip ahead in the story, leaving out major events talked about but never witnessed on the page. It felt like most of the action took place in other issues of different comic book titles. That‚Äôs one of the problems of having a combined universe. Things happen to characters in another issue of another series that affects the book you‚Äôre invested in. There‚Äôs too much interweaving of storylines between the different character titles. The only way you could keep up with it all is if you won the lottery and had a few hundred dollars a month and 24 hours a day to dedicate to comic book reading.‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation‚Äù is rated ‚ÄúT‚Äù for Teens. There‚Äôs the usual comic book violence, some mild language, and partial nudity. I don‚Äôt know which artist or artists it is, but someone has an obsession with naked bodies of all types. Whether it‚Äôs lost souls or our superheroes being stripped (literally) of their costumes and powers, you better believe they‚Äôre three-quarters naked.I do have my problems with the religious aspects of ‚ÄúTrinity of Sin: The Phantom Stranger Volume 3: The Crack in Creation‚Äù being all jumbled together. However, if you treat the book as a work of fiction influenced by the Bible and other religions, it‚Äôs an entertaining read that blends together love, loss, regret, and redemption with a healthy dose of action and adventure. The inclusion of John Constantine, Swamp Thing, the Spectre, and Superman is an added bonus.

Mill Creek Entertainment gives children of the 1980s and their offspring a double dose of sci-fi fun with the ‚ÄúKrull / Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù Combo DVD release. ‚ÄúKrull‚Äù recently had its Blu-ray debut. ‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù hasn‚Äôt seen the light of day since hitting DVD back in 2001. The two movies put together in one package is a great way for genre fans to pick them up.I recently reviewed the ‚ÄúKrull‚Äù Blu-ray when it was released through Mill Creek Entertainment. If you‚Äôre interested, you can read my review right here. In a nutshell, it‚Äôs an epic hero‚Äôs journey that mixes together ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù and ‚ÄúLord of the Rings.‚Äù However, modern audiences might find its pacing a bit slow in places.‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù is a blend of a couple different influences on science fiction flicks of the 1980s. Imagine if a reluctant hero-for-hire in the vein of Han Solo traveled to a planet where the inhabitants live in a society that resembled the dystopian world of ‚ÄúThe Road Warrior.‚Äù It comes complete with scavengers, mutants, and a makeshift city whose citizens enjoy watching people fight for their lives in a deadly maze. It all sounds a little familiar, eh? It also sounds like a lot of fun!In the year 2136, Wolff (Peter Strauss), a wily salvage pilot and intergalactic bounty hunter, answers a distress signal on Terra Eleven. Agreeing to pick up three women who've been shipwrecked, he lands on the planet only to discover they've been kidnapped. Following their trail, Wolff soon encounters Niki (Molly Ringwald), a spunky orphan who agrees to guide him across the Forbidden Zone, a vast wasteland populated by plague-infested mutants. After many battles, Wolff and Niki finally reach the lair of Overdog (Michael Ironside), the planet's half-man / half-machine ruler. Discovering the women are held captive in Overdog's slave pens, Wolff's rescue mission finally begins.‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù was originally released during the 3-D craze of the early 1980s. ‚ÄúJaws 3-D,‚Äù ‚ÄúFriday the 13th, Part 3-D, and ‚ÄúAmityville 3-D‚Äù are other movies which are more identifiable from this era. The film is presented in 2-D on DVD, but you can definitely tell where the 3-D would‚Äôve played a part at times.The cast of ‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù was made up of some familiar 1980s faces. Peter Strauss is known for his many roles in television shows and movies. Ernie Hudson is best known for his character Winston Zeddemore in ‚ÄúGhostbusters‚Äù and ‚ÄúGhostbusters II.‚Äù When the movie came out in 1983, Molly Ringwald‚Äôs only major parts were in ‚ÄúDiff‚Äôrent Strokes‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Facts of Life.‚Äù She comes off as an annoying tag-along here until the end of the film, where she makes an attempt at redeeming herself by facing down her fear and working hard to stay alive. Michael Ironside fully embraced his role as the cyborg tyrant Overdog.Both ‚ÄúKrull‚Äù and ‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù are rated PG. ‚ÄúKrull‚Äù features mild violence and gore, and frightening / intense sequences. ‚ÄúSpacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù includes mild violence and gore, profanity, and frightening / intense scenes. One of the bat creatures in the film is shown topless, but it‚Äôs not known whether the monster is male or female. There‚Äôs definitely nothing sexy about the scene.‚ÄúKrull / Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù Sci-Fi Double Feature is a bare-bones release. There aren‚Äôt any special features to be found. Most fans of the films won‚Äôt even care. It‚Äôs the first time either one has been available in over 10 years.Newer viewers might find the ‚ÄúKrull / Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone‚Äù Sci-Fi Double Feature a bit heavy on the cheese and slow in stride. The special effects are all practical as well. It‚Äôs nice to see all the hard work the crew put into the visual look of the film. If you love the original ‚ÄúStar Wars,‚Äù then you‚Äôll no doubt enjoy these two offerings from Mill Creek Entertainment. Watch them through the eyes of a 10 year old in 1983 and everything will be fine.

You say you haven‚Äôt had enough of Edward and Bella? You need more of Jacob Black‚Äôs pecs in your life? You prefer glittering fangless vampires to the nasty, messy, and unattractive ones found in ‚Äú30 Days of Night?‚Äù Summit Entertainment heard your cries and fulfills yours deepest wishes with ‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga Extended Editions.‚Äù‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga Extended Editions‚Äù includes ‚ÄúTwilight,‚Äù ‚ÄúNew Moon,‚Äù and ‚ÄúEclipse.‚Äù Don‚Äôt ask me why they didn‚Äôt throw in ‚ÄúBreaking Dawn‚Äù Parts 1 and 2. Part 1 already has an extended edition and would‚Äôve been rather painless for the studio to include. Why didn‚Äôt they just piece together an extended version of Part 2 and make this release a fan‚Äôs ultimate dream package? We‚Äôll probably never know.‚ÄúTwilight‚Äù features 4 extra minutes of romance and drama. ‚ÄúNew Moon‚Äù is extended from 130 minutes to 137 minutes. ‚ÄúEclipse‚Äù is bumped up from 124 minutes to 129 minutes. Basically, you‚Äôre buying all 3 movies again for 16 minutes of added footage. If you‚Äôre one of the legions of enthusiasts who adore this franchise, it‚Äôll be worth every penny.‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga Extended Editions‚Äù come together in one regular sized Blu-ray amaray case. It‚Äôs pretty darn nice when it comes to storage. The new packaging sure beats the heck out of the bulky ‚ÄúTwilight Forever‚Äù behemoth. There‚Äôs only one problem: it doesn‚Äôt include either of the ‚ÄúBreaking Dawn‚Äù movies or the special features! If you‚Äôre a completist, you have to find space on your shelf for both sets.Let me jump up on my soap box for a minute now. Although ‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga‚Äù does send some negative messages to girls out there, it also has some good ones I enjoyed seeing as well. Bella is weak and way too obsessed with a guy to the point that she will do anything for him. It makes her sort of pathetic. However, I did appreciate the fact that Edward and Bella kept from having pre-marital sex in a day when not much thought is put into giving yourself away to anybody who comes along. Even though it‚Äôs not part of the set, I liked the fact that Bella wouldn‚Äôt kill her baby in ‚ÄúBreaking Dawn,‚Äù which directly or indirectly (if you ask Director Bill Condon) promoted pro-life.If you can settle for just the first three movies with no special features in one handy set and already have the ‚ÄúBreaking Dawn‚Äù Blu-rays, ‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga Extended Editions‚Äù will satisfy you. I‚Äôm one of the ten guys on the planet Earth that actually like this series and I was a bit annoyed when I received it not to see all the movies included. Some folks might feel like they‚Äôre being taken advantage of after buying the movies multiple times by now.I gave the movies 3 stars because the set is missing the extended editions of "Breaking Dawn" Parts 1 and 2.I gave the movies 3 stars because the set is missing the extended editions of "Breaking Dawn" Parts 1 and 2.

I remember seeing ‚ÄúSupernova‚Äù back in 2000 when it originally came out on DVD. Like most people, I thought it looked great at the time, but really didn‚Äôt have much else going for it. My opinion hasn‚Äôt really changed since re-visiting it after the movie‚Äôs recent Blu-ray upgrade by Scream Factory. The special effects and design are still the highlight of a sci-fi film that suffers from simply maintaining the status genre quo and offering nothing new.The medical ship Nightingale 229 travels through deep space in the early 22nd century taking on search and rescue missions it‚Äôs assigned to. Its six-member crew includes a Captain and Pilot (Robert Forster), a co-pilot (James Spader), a medical officer (Angela Bassett, a medical technician (Luo Diamond Phillips), a search and rescue paramedic (Robin Tunney), and a computer technician (Wilson Cruz). When their vessel, the Nightingale 229, answers an emergency distress signal from a comet mining operation in a distant galaxy, the crew soon finds itself in danger from the mysterious young man they rescue, the alien artifact he's smuggled aboard, and the gravitational pull of a giant star about to supernova. The resulting explosion will be the most massive explosion in the universe.What was originally planned as a low-budget study of human relationships amongst the stars quickly mutated into a rather lackluster action yarn about picking up a stray and his alien artifact. Of course we all know the object can‚Äôt be good and the whole situation goes south very quickly in a matter of 90 minutes. It‚Äôs evident by the way the movie progresses in a very choppy and rushed pace that there was more to the story than what we get here. There were 15 minutes of deleted scenes for the movie included, so I can only imagine there has to be even more footage lying in a box somewhere out there.The cast would be considered an ensemble these days since most of the actors have gone on to do bigger and better things since ‚ÄúSupernova.‚Äù James Spader, Lou Diamond Phillips, Robert Forster, and Angela Bassett were already established stars at the time of this movie‚Äôs release. Peter Facinelli went on to play the patriarch of the Cullen vampire clan, Carlisle, in ‚ÄúThe Twilight Saga.‚Äù Robin Tunney worked on ‚ÄúPrison Break‚Äù and continues as a member of the cast of ‚ÄúThe Mentalist.‚Äù Here they just walk around angry with grim looks on their faces.‚ÄúSupernova‚Äù is rated R for sci-fi action violence and sensuality / nudity. There are at least two topless shots of Robin Tunney and a rather explicit love scene. Director Walter Hill (operating under the pseudonym Thomas Lee) was definitely fascinated with the human body. He stalls on one shot of Peter Facinelli‚Äôs backend for what seems like an eternity. Angela Bassett gets her opportunity to bare all, albeit in the shadows, as well. There‚Äôs an acceptable amount of gore as Facinelli‚Äôs character continuously gets beat upon. However, even this aspect of the film seems uneven. Sometimes we get to see the carnage, while at others it‚Äôs edited out nice and neat.Although there really isn‚Äôt much going on here in a spiritual sense, one line of dialogue that James Spader utters stood out to me. When the crew is coming to grips with the chain of events Peter Facinelli‚Äôs character has unraveled, he makes a bold statement. Spader proclaims, ‚ÄúWhat if they didn't crucify Christ, but they did!" He uses such an extreme example to explain that it doesn‚Äôt matter what could‚Äôve been. What‚Äôs more important is dealing with what is. Angela Bassett‚Äôs character also dramatically makes a comparison between aliens and God when she says, ‚ÄúWhoever they are, they're as smart as God and a lot less nice.‚Äù I don‚Äôt think so.Scream Factory‚Äôs Blu-ray debut of ‚ÄúSupernova‚Äù is presented in 1080p Widescreen (2.36:1) with DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1. Special features include a ‚ÄúMaking of ‚ÄôSupernova‚Äô‚Äù feature, deleted scenes, an alternate ending, and theatrical trailer.‚ÄúSupernova‚Äù isn‚Äôt completely void of any entertainment value. It just lacks the endeavor to be anything more than a slick sci-fi action yarn. It will remind you of the awkward era of filmmaking when studios were transitioning from working with real models and sets and moving into the arena of CGI effects. If you‚Äôve ran out of other alien encounter movies, this will tide you over until something new and bolder comes along.

Although its roots lie in the legend of Bloody Mary, the ‚ÄúCandyman‚Äù franchise built a mythos all its own in the span of three movies. Actor Tony Todd would argue that the entire series revolves around a tragic story of unrequited love and the vengeance rained down upon those who dare disturb the tortured soul of the title character. I would absolutely agree with him, especially after ‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh‚Äù expands on the backstory of our antagonist.Candyman moves on to New Orleans and starts his horrific murders once more. This time, his intended victim is a school teacher. Her father was killed by Candyman, and brother wrongly accused of the murders.Instead of the usual horror film retread we get when it comes to sequels, ‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh‚Äù actually expands on the history of the character by visually telling his tale onscreen. It pounds home the tragedy surrounding Candyman and brings more of a sense of humanity to the ‚Äúvillain‚Äù of the story.Tony Todd brings Candyman to life and makes you both feel sorry for and fear his character. He brings an air of refinement to what could have been just another slasher icon. Veronica Cartwright plays a widowed southern belle who has a secret of her own to keep. Even in 1995, she was already a veteran of the horror genre because of roles in ‚ÄúAlien,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Birds,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Witches of Eastwick,‚Äù ‚ÄúInvasion of the Body Snatchers,‚Äù and more.I‚Äôm fascinated by writer and atheist Clive Barker‚Äôs attraction to Christian religion and Catholic imagery as showcased once again in ‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh.‚Äù This time it‚Äôs exemplified through the events of Mardis Gras in New Orleans and the religious meanings behind the celebration. I also found it interesting that one of the main focuses of the lynch mob was a middle-aged lady carrying her Bible and encouraging the torture of Candyman.‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh‚Äù is rated R for violence and gore, and for some sexuality and language. There‚Äôs the expected amount of blood and onscreen butchering you would expect from a horror movie. A couple are shown having sex in public on two occasions. They‚Äôre nude and shown from the side, but no actual privates are shown.Special features for Scream Factory‚Äôs Blu-ray release of ‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh‚Äù includes audio commentary by Director Bill Condon, ‚ÄúThe Candyman Legacy with Tony Todd‚Äù featurette, ‚ÄúDown Memory Lane with Veronica Cartwright‚Äù featurette, and a theatrical trailer.‚ÄúCandyman: Farewell to the Flesh‚Äù rises above what could have been just another pedestrian follow-up to a slasher flick. Instead of simply lining up new faceless victims for the killer to take out with his hook hand for no reason, our dreadful anti-hero is given substance and motivation for his actions. An air of mystery and a dark family secret add another level of elegance to the movie.

I love ‚ÄúStar Trek.‚Äù I wish I could watch an episode of the original series, ‚ÄúThe Next Generation,‚Äù or ‚ÄúEnterprise‚Äù every single day of my life. However, my wife hates the entire franchise. I‚Äôm forced to catch a movie or episode any time she‚Äôs at least a thousand feet from the house and can‚Äôt hear the theme music or the voices of the actors.CBS Blu-ray makes it easy on folks looking for the brighter spots by putting out the most important and popular two-part episodes of ‚ÄúStar Trek: The Next Generation‚Äù flawlessly seamed together into feature length films. They remind me of the key adventures I need to re-visit on a regular basis. In celebration of the release of the seventh and final season, we get the series‚Äô epic swan song ‚ÄúAll Good Things.‚ÄùPast, present and future collide for Captain Picard (Patrick Stewart) as he finds himself bouncing around through three different time periods -- the Farpoint mission, the present, and the future in which many changes have affected the Enterprise-D crew. Meanwhile, the mischievous Q (John de Lancie) is back for his last time trying to help Picard figure out the meaning of a spatial anomaly... or is he only making things worse?One section of the combined episode is reminiscent of ‚ÄúStar Trek III: The Search for Spock.‚Äù The aged crew must come together and follow their former Captain on an unauthorized mission to save the entire universe. It also gives everyone a chance to see what the crew is up to and will look like as they grow older. Of course, things can change if the timeline is screwed with.The only part of ‚ÄúStar Trek: The Next Generation ‚Äì All Good Things‚Äù I had an issue with is its nods to evolution. Q takes Picard to the area where France will be billions of years in the past and shows him a puddle of primordial ooze we‚Äôll form from. Any Creationist is going to have an issue with this sequence.Special features for ‚ÄúStar Trek: The Next Generation ‚Äì All Good Things‚Äù include audio commentary by Michael D. Moore and Brannon Braga, ‚ÄúThe Unknown Possibilities of Existence: Making ‚ÄòAll Good Things‚Äô‚Äù featurette, episodic promos (Parts 1 and 2), and deleted scenes.‚ÄúStar Trek: The Next Generation ‚Äì All Good Things‚Äù ends the series with a cataclysmic danger to humanity which trumps anything the crew has ever faced. It brings the series full circle through picking up with the trial which began in the first episode of the show, ‚ÄúEncounter at Farpoint.‚Äù Q became such an iconic figure it only seems fitting that the series ends with a universal threat brought on by the godlike being and his judicial court.

‚ÄúTusk‚Äù is one of those films the saying ‚ÄúThere are things you can‚Äôt unsee‚Äù was created about. Kevin Smith‚Äôs latest horror film is like the car wreck you can‚Äôt keep from looking at. Unfortunately, the horrific images in front of you stay in your psyche well after the credits roll.When podcaster Wallace Bryton (Justin Long) goes missing in the backwoods of Manitoba while interviewing a mysterious seafarer named Howard Howe (Michael Parks), his best friend Teddy (Haley Joel Osment) and girlfriend Allison (Genesis Rodriguez) team with an ex-cop to look for him.‚ÄúTusk‚Äù is a great contemporary horror movie that engages the viewer through connections you make with Justin Long‚Äôs character. Even though he‚Äôs shameful, you can‚Äôt help but feel sorry for him. ‚ÄúTusk‚Äù also leaves you contemplating how awful it would be to live your life out as a monster no one can stand to look at.The cast of ‚ÄúTusk‚Äù all perform their parts well. They deliver their lines and portray their characters with all the sincerity you could muster for an irreverent Kevin Smith vehicle. Just like all his other movies, there‚Äôs a lot of dialogue between the scenes of terror and zaniness to wade through.‚ÄúTusk‚Äù is rated R for some disturbing violence / gore, language and sexual content. There are no sex scenes or nudity, but plenty of innuendos just like you would expect from a Kevin Smith film. Severed body parts are seen throughout. Take my word for it when I tell you what you see here truly can‚Äôt be unseen.I don't condone much of what Kevin Smith is known for and definitely don't share his same stances on many issues. However, he is an admirable filmmaker who takes real life experiences and characters you can identify with and relate to and puts them onscreen for you to enjoy and ponder.Special Features for "Tusk" include deleted scenes, audio commentary with Writer / Director Kevin Smith, ‚Äú20 Years to 'Tusk'‚Äù featurette, ‚ÄúThe Making of 'Tusk'‚Äù featurettes, and Smodcast #259: The Walrus and The Carpenter.I wouldn‚Äôt go as far as saying ‚ÄúTusk‚Äù is a perfect movie. There will be moments where you wonder why certain stretches of dialogue are being uttered or what the point of a scene was. You‚Äôll ask yourself the question, ‚ÄúWas Smith trying to stretch the story out to make it a full length film?‚Äù Overall, if you like unsettling creature features with a good amount of build-up, you‚Äôll enjoy ‚ÄúTusk.‚Äù

Marvel might be riding high now as a member of the Disney family, but twenty years ago it was literally taking any deal it could get from Tinseltown to make some money off the different properties they owned. Low-budget versions of ‚ÄúCaptain America,‚Äù ‚ÄúFantastic Four,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Punisher‚Äù are perfect examples of where the comic book publishing giant was heading at the time. Even George Lucas‚Äôs bigger attempt at bringing ‚ÄúHoward the Duck‚Äù to life was a miserable failure.With all the hype surrounding the upcoming release of Scott Derrickson‚Äôs ‚ÄúDoctor Strange,‚Äù it only made sense that Full Moon Features would take advantage of all the chatter and excitement by releasing its own version of the tale on Blu-ray. For those who might not know, Marvel gave rights to Full Moon Features in the early 1990s to adapt the mystical magician‚Äôs adventures into a live-action movie. When time ran out and the property went back to Marvel, Charles Band decided to move forward with his rendering altered enough to keep from crossing any lines of copyright infringement.Doctor Mordrid (Jeffrey Combs) is a powerful sorcerer who has sworn to keep Earth safe from the powers of darkness throughout the universe. His arch-enemy Kabal (Brian Thompson) arrives with plans to destroy the world. The two clash in an epic battle of good and evil that includes destructive mystical abilities and re-animated prehistoric creatures.You can tell as soon as the opening credits roll on ‚ÄúDoctor Mordrid: Master of the Unknown‚Äù Directors / Producers Charles Band and his father Albert were quite passionate about bringing one of their favorite superheroes to life, even if he was under a new name with a re-tooled storyline and origin. Obviously, the movie was made on a budget that limited some of what could be done. It still looks great and the entire cast is fully invested in their individual roles.The Blu-ray upgrade for ‚ÄúDoctor Mordrid: Master of the Unknown‚Äù provides a clean picture to enjoy all the practical effects and stop-motion work the Full Moon crew put into the production. It‚Äôs a true pleasure to see actual physical sets and props onscreen versus CGI landscapes and the likes. The 5.1 surround sound transports Richard Band‚Äôs musical score and all the blasts of magic to every corner of your home theater.Special features for ‚ÄúDoctor Mordrid: Master of the Unknown‚Äù include audio commentary with Jeffrey Combs and Charles Band. An original Videozone featurette is found as well. William Shatner talks with Jeffrey Combs, Barbara Crampton, and Stuart Gordon for a rare round-table discussion. It also contains uncut behind-the-scenes footage from the Full Moon Vault.‚ÄúDoctor Mordrid: Master of the Unknown‚Äù is unrated but should hold an R for all intents and purposes. There‚Äôs only one scene of nudity, which was really unnecessary and could‚Äôve been cut or edited to open the picture up to even younger viewers. There was some violence and language as well, but nothing that would‚Äôve caused it to be rated anything more than PG-13.1992‚Äôs ‚ÄúDoctor Mordrid: Master of the Unknown‚Äù still stands up well today even though elements of it might seem aged. It‚Äôs a reminder of where comic book properties stood in the grand scheme of Hollywood at that time. Fans of Full Moon, Marvel, and comic books will deem it necessary to grab a copy of this to complete their collections of rare home entertainment.

For someone who claims to be an atheist, Clive Barker sure does delve into the afterlife and spiritual realm a whole lot. From ‚ÄúNightbreed‚Äù to ‚ÄúHellraiser,‚Äù the author / director seems to have an obsession with what‚Äôs to come once we shuffle off this mortal coil. Scream Factory‚Äôs release of ‚ÄúLord of Illusions: Collector‚Äôs Edition‚Äù reminds horror fans of his passionate and dark dwellings on the realm of the dead. This new version assembles the Director‚Äôs Cut and the theatrical one with new and old special features for its debut on Blu-ray.Private Detective Harry D‚ÄôAmour (Scott Bakula) is caught up investigating the deaths of several reformed cult members. As he digs deeper for one of the victims‚Äô widows (Famke Janssen), he is exposed to the dangerous worlds of illusions and magic. D‚ÄôAmour soon learns that illusions are trickery, but magic is very real and very deadly.The 1080p High-Definition Widescreen (1.78:1) transfer for the Director‚Äôs Cut gives home viewers the perfect visual experience. The practical and special effects for ‚ÄúLord of Illusions‚Äù are still impressive, even if their limitations are more evident because of a clearer picture. Knowing that all the gruesome carnage seen onscreen was achieved without the use of CGI is a breath of realistic fresh air.Both the Director‚Äôs Cut and theatrical version of ‚ÄúLord of Illusions‚Äù give viewers the option to switch between DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 and DTS-HD Master Audio 2.0. Either way, the musical score, dialogue, and audio effects will plunge you into the woeful recesses of Clive Barker‚Äôs mind. It‚Äôs left up to you what level you want to descend to.‚ÄúLord of Illusions: Collector‚Äôs Edition‚Äù comes with plenty of extra material thanks to Scream Factory‚Äôs loving attention. Clive Barker provides commentary for his Director‚Äôs Cut. ‚ÄúA Gathering of Magic‚Äù featurette gives us a glimpse into the making of the film. A new interview with Storyboard Artist Martin Mercer is found. Original Behind-the-Scenes footage, deleted scenes, and a photo gallery are included as well.The Director‚Äôs Cut is unrated and with good reason. There‚Äôs loads of violence and gore, nudity, language, sexuality, and adult situations. Not only are we exposed to female nudity, we get full frontal male nudity as well. Some of it is shrouded in shadows, but still visible.‚ÄúLord of Illusions: Collector‚Äôs Edition‚Äù reminds us all of what a great blend of noir and horror Clive Barker‚Äôs film is. It does an excellent job of showing us what can happen if we become obsessed with attaining power and forbidden knowledge through the occult. Even though he might not fully believe in it, Barker teaches us that playing with magic and supernatural forces can only do harm. You might not want to own it, but it‚Äôs worth a watch just for its interesting take on the subject matter.

Scream Factory follows up its release of the original horror classic with the sequel ‚ÄúPumpkinhead II: Blood Wings.‚Äù While not quite as satisfying as its predecessor, you can‚Äôt help but have a level of respect for screenwriters Ivan and Constantine Chachornia for trying to change things up a bit when it comes to the storyline of the film. We get the same premise, but with a little detective work and two intertwining motivations for the title creature to go on its killing spree to mix it up. The acting is a bit cheesy, but what can be expected from a movie made in the mid-1990s that obviously would feel more at home in the 1980s.A group of teen troublemakers resurrect the spirit of vengeance known as Pumpkinhead (Mark McCracken). Trapped inside the monster is the tormented soul of a young boy named Tommy (J.P. Manoux). First, pieces of the bodies of the gang who murdered him begin to pile up. After that, the creature‚Äôs focus changes to the high schoolers who mortally wounded his caretaker. Pumpkinhead will stop at nothing until those who have wronged him are served bloody justice.‚ÄúPumpkinhead II: Blood Wings‚Äù is presented in 1080p High-Definition Widescreen (1.85:1). Its video upgrade provides a clearer picture while not sacrificing its original film flavor. Made up of all practical special effects, the clarity doesn‚Äôt showcase CGI limitations the way it does with newer movies. There‚Äôs nothing quite as satisfying as looking at the TV and knowing what you‚Äôre seeing is actually tangible and not an X that an actor is staring at on a green screen. However, the creature‚Äôs point-of-view vision is rather dated and comes across as a bit hokey.Given a 2.0 DTS-HD Master Audio Stereo upgrade, ‚ÄúPumpkinhead II: Blood Wings‚Äù isn‚Äôt quite as fulfilling in the sound department as a 5.1 surround mix would be. It still gets the job done, blending together the musical score, sound effects, dialogue, and ear-piercing screams of the fiend‚Äôs many victims. The shrills of the tormented and growl of Pumpkinhead will still leave you looking over your shoulders and nervously twitching.‚ÄúPumpkinhead II: Blood Wings‚Äù is rated R for horror violence, sexuality, nudity, and language.
