When it comes up to furniture it bumps gently and then redirects it‚Äôs path. Amazingly, it appears to sense walls and will turn before bumping. One night my husband and I watched the robot moving along the floor avoiding walls but then it got stuck under a chair for about ten minutes. It was rather hilarious.Now, what I have trouble with concerning the robot: it likes to eat the fringes on our area rugs. It will suction up the fringe and then twirl around because it can‚Äôt let go. And phone charging cords are not safe. I find myself ‚Äúbabysitting‚Äù it so it doesn‚Äôt put the wrong things in its mouth, which defeats the purpose of a robot vacuum. Also, the robot is supposed to return to its docking station when the power becomes low. Mine has yet to find the station. I‚Äôve found it dead in the back bathroom, my bedroom, and the living room; everywhere but the docking station that is set up in the kitchen.Is it effective? Like I said, it does a better job at upkeep than thorough cleaning. Sometimes it appears selective in what it picks up and will leave larger bits of dust on the floor.Most important question that my kids had: Will the cat ride on it? Heck, no, the poor animal looked terrified and bolted out of the room.I give it a 3.5 because it eats parts of my rugs and can‚Äôt find the docking station. Perhaps Bissell‚Äôs next venture will iron out some of these bugs.

A light and refreshing moisturizer based on the blend of minerals found in the Dead Sea desert and it's water, AHAVA gel cream feels so lovely on the skin. There is no tacky or greasy feeling after application as it absorbs quickly and the fragrance is very subtle.The box contains a printout of the minerals found in this moisturizer and where they came from. And apparantly the healing properties of the Dead Sea are famous. I did notice my skin did not experience any irritation or breakouts. And after a week of use I realized the last vestiges of summer dry skin had faded.The price is a bit high for someone on a budget but only a dab twice daily is needed for full use so the 1.7 ounces goes a long way.

While the topic of rape is painful and inspires feelings of anger, it is also complex; it is an important issue that should never be swept under the rug. Although our attitudes and social mores have changed over the last few hundred years, our progress is not yet complete. We have evolved from the era when a father decides who his submissive and dutiful daughter marries to "No means no". But, the issues of slut shaming and "boys will be boys" have not been eradicated and a woman in a short skirt is still "asking for it". It's infuriating to realize that, whether we know it or not, people are still taking sides.What We Saw is a novel that takes the idea for it's story from an incident that recently happened in a small town and puts it into context for the reader. The author gives the main players names. The setting is still a small town that supports it's high school sports teams and the accused are members of the state championship-bound basketball team. What the reader takes from this story is that because people, with all their flaws and fallibilities, are involved, the topic of rape is still not straightforward.Kate Weston wakes up the morning after a big party with a huge hangover. Her best friend, Ben, had driven her home early because she was too drunk. On Monday, she realizes a girl named Stacy is not in geology. People are talking about her. Then Kate sees a photo on the Internet of the half-dressed and apparently unconscious Stacy tossed over the shoulder of one of the star basketball players. Kate finds there are more pictures and supposedly a video that everyone is whispering about. When four of the star players are arrested for rape, Kate's school and the town practically explodes with anger. Fingers are pointed at Stacy because she had been drinking and she was known to sleep around. People are furious, even indignant, that this "incident" threatens their team's chance to go to State.As Kate's relationship with Ben blossoms into more than friendship she finds herself torn. Ben, an all-around good kid, wants to distance himself from the turmoil and focus on a scholarship to escape the suffocation of their small town. Kate wants to know what really happened. How can it be Stacy's fault if she was unconscious? Kate was just as drunk as Stacy; it could have happened to her. Would she too be to blame for her actions? As her friends and family take different sides from one another, Kate applies a principle she learned in geology: seismic shifts may be small and unnoticeable, but they are still earth shattering.I cannot say I loved this book; it's impossible to love a story about such an issue. I can say that I cared enough for the characters to feel their intense pain but also recognize why some of them felt the way they did. For good or bad, I understand the reasons why Ben wanted to steer clear of the fallout. But, I also applaud Kate for doing what she had to do despite her clear understanding of what the consequences would be. And that's what made this book so painful: the collateral damage is just as devastating as the rape. No one is spared.This is an important discussion and the author has done a commendable job in exploring society's attitudes towards women and the subject of rape. I highly recommend it for every teenager.

Silent Scream started out interesting enough with a murder, nothing too gruesome, but it draws you in because the victim recognizes her murderer. Then, the narrative moves on to introduce the reader to DI Kim Stone, a most irritating detective; she‚Äôs arrogant, rude, and damaged. She reacts to her gut feeling. She rides a Kawasaki. She grew up in the foster care system. If it weren‚Äôt for the fact that this character is an irredeemable bully, I would go so far as to her to say she reminds me exactly of DI Helen Grace of the MJ Arlidge series.This is one of the few books that I almost did not finish. Multiple times. After putting up with Stone‚Äôs negative disposition and her completely lackluster co-workers for a few chapters (Which one was Stace? Is Kev the one with the angry girlfriend?) I was ready to chuck the book. Especially if her partner DC Whathisname kept calling her ‚ÄúGuv‚Äù. I found the dialogue to be clich√© and trite. The ‚Äúparagraphs‚Äù barely had two sentences; the narrative was mostly a sentence at a time. It did make for faster skimming like I ended up doing.The only thing that kept me interested was the mystery. There‚Äôs a second murder. Then the skeleton of a young girl is found at an archeological dig next to a burned-down home for wayward teens. At that point I was able to overlook Stone‚Äôs behaviour and focus on the story, but then she would be a jerk to a co-worker or a witness or some total stranger and I would consider tossing the book‚Ä¶again. And the book is chock full of face-palm-plant moments to keep the reader entertained. My favorite was during Stone‚Äôs interview with the first victim‚Äôs co-worker; the victim is dead barely more than 12 hours and the co-worker is blatantly flirting with Stone? That is a WTH moment for sure. Also, whenever the police dug up another body, the murderer‚Äôs inner dialogue was practically drooling with nostalgic glee while he relived that victim‚Äôs last few moments.After Stone completely alienates half the characters in the book the author tries to build sympathy for her by placing blame on the death of her brother, her incarcerated and psychotic mother, and the years Stone spent as a nobody in the foster care system. The only outlet for her damaged heart is in rebuilding a motorcycle. She has a rare few moments when she shows a sense of humor. That‚Äôs all well and good, but Stone is still a jerk.When the killer is finally revealed, it‚Äôs a weird twist is a canyon-size stretch that might shock some readers but it‚Äôs nothing new or unusual. I really wanted this to be a good book and I did keep reading in case it got better. But it all comes down to the immature dialogue, one-dimensional and/or unmemorable characters, and a completely unlikeable main character. There are plenty of books out there with anti-heroines, but they at least have some quality about them that makes the reader actually appreciate or enjoy the person‚Äôs character. Case in point: DI Helen Grace.Judging from the hundreds of 5 star reviews I can see the author has some fans and I‚Äôm glad for the debut writer but I won‚Äôt be picking up her next book.

Strongly spiritual and beautifully written, Miserere is an emotionally fulfilling and phenomenally creative story. It is world building and character driving fantasy writing at it‚Äôs finest. Because it takes the tenants of our major world religions and uses them for the foundations of Miserere‚Äôs Woerld religions does not mean it is a Christian book. Nor does the fact one of the main characters is a young teen make it a YA novel. Miserere is intense and creative and the characters are fiercely compelling. And its debut author has produced a most memorable experience.This was such a joyful change from the usual fantasy novels on the market. The author has taken only a bare few of the usual tropes and poetically and spiritually blended them into a fantastical new world with memorable and soulful characters.  I cannot rave enough about this book.Please, read it. You will not regret it.

A drawback to modern urban fantasy novels is the author mistaking sarcasm with just plain smartass. In the first few pages of Pale Queen Rising we meet Claire, the top assassin for the Winter Queen, as she threatens and interrogates a victim. Her inner voice and snarky dialogue comes across as immature and, from an assassin point of view, completely unintimidating. Just those first few pages almost made me chuck the book into the DNF bin. But, I held on. It was a good move on my part.Despite the weak beginning and after starting on the wrong foot, the book improves exponentially. Either I grew accustomed to Claire, the main character, or the narrative improved. A mortal raised in the Winter Kingdom by Queen Mab, Claire is trying to discover who is syphoning off the "Dream" that fuels the citizens of Winter and the Summer kingdoms. A byproduct of happy mortal thoughts, Dream is equally and tentatively shared by the two, but the unknown third party is endangering their treaty.The world building is solid as the author already established it in his earlier trilogy, The Immortal Circus. The magic of the fae, the demons, the witches, and the mortals who learn from them is, well, magical. The beasts are fantastic. And I absolutely love the demon Eli. Claire, while not touchy-feely, is compelling. Between her anger, her sense of loss concerning her real mother, her compulsion for killing, and her love of good bourbon and a hot bath, I did grow to like her.While I have not read the trilogy that precedes this new series I understand it is not truly necessary. I quickly read some the synopses of those books to see if it would affect my experience. There are characters that dwell in both trilogies. And despite the cliffhanger ending of Pale Queen Rising that does stem from the Circus Trilogy, I do not feel compelled to read it. One thing I did notice is that in most of the reviews concerning the final book of The Immortal Circus the readers were angered by the ending. Some were furious. They felt too many questions were left unanswered. This must be the "rest of the story" the readers were begging for.So, despite the rocky beginning, I know I will continue this series.

Bought a pair of 30 X 30 pants for my son as that is the size he usually wears. The Dickies however run much larger than expected and the result is a look that my kids call "Bucket Pants". The waist is so large you look like you're wearing a bucket. The thighs are wide and the length is comically too long. I even double-checked the tag to make sure they are the right size--they are.I am returning them.

The first time I used The Falsies mascara I noticed how thick it was. Usually I apply 2 coats and I did so with this product. The result is a very thickly coated, spidery set of lashes that I had to separate with a lash comb. The wand is loose and wiggly so it would brush against the bridge of my nose and leave a thick black smudge when I had to work on my left eye with my right hand. It was a bit much for what I usually wear to work.The second time I used the mascara I applied only 1 coat. The look is still rich and dramatic but not as spidery yet I still had to separate the lashes. The wand brush is shallow and doesn't evenly touch or separate the lashes and may be the reason the mascara is so thick when applied. Because the appearance is not very subtle, I would recommend this for an evening out or a party. It's too flamboyant for work.The price is affordable but the look is not for an everyday/office/work use. It does work if you want to add some dramatic flair to your appearance.

When it comes to testing dog food products I have the perfect hound for doing just that. And this time Millie had a friend, Trapper, visiting for the week so they both got to try the Nutro Company dog food. Not sure what they were thinking except that they gobbled it down and then both looked at me expecting a second serving. Both dogs are medium size so the kibble bits are perfect for them. The chicken, rice and oatmeal combo sounds like a good meal for any dog with digestion problems. I liked the organic ingredients with extra vitamins; it makes for a nice wholesome meal without the added corn syrup that is bad for dogs.The problem I would have with continuing to provide this dog food is the price. A medium size dog like Millie would require the 30 pound bag. But at $49.99 a pop, the cost is out of my budget range. I would love to use this product regularly but, again, the price. Sorry Millie.

I had a couple of people in my family test drive these headphones; my son tried them when playing with his computer games and my husband used them to listen to music. They both agree that these headphones are phenomenal when it comes to sound. They both love the pillow soft ear pads. Not only are they extremely comfortable but they effectively blocked out any ambient noise.The gamer thoroughly enjoyed the surround sound. He said it was the best pair of headphones he has ever tried. Unfortunately the microphone was not very effective when it came to communicating with other players; his voice came across as too quiet. The specs show that these headphones are not built for gaming anyway. The amount of power is overkill for just gaming.The music lover could not stop raving about the clear crisp sound. The balanced sound is the best he has ever heard with any pair of headphones. He now has these squirrelled away in his basement studio for use when recording bands. They make for an awesome playback tool for editing and mixing. The specs show these were built for and are perfect for listening to music.Not sure what the microphone is for when it comes to listening to music and it's not powerful enough for gaming. But, these headphones are a definite 5 star from my guys.Highly recommended.

The first book of The Great Library series, Ink and Bone, establishes an alternative reality where a significant wonder of the ancient world, The Royal Library of Alexandria, was not destroyed and burned to the ground. The world did not lose the massive and invaluable collections of cultural writings. The library still exists in the year 2025 and is the center of political power. However, instead of encouraging the masses to engage in critical thinking or writing, the Library regulates what the people are allowed to read. Books are forbidden. New ideas are forbidden. There are no paper books, only a device called the Codex is available for approved books or any news updates. Hence, there is a booming black market in paper books. But anyone caught dealing or buying or owning unapproved material faces the death penalty.Ink and Bone follows the young Jess from his family roots in the black market to the great Library itself as a candidate for the honor of Library scholar. It's a ruthless process that thousands apply for, and whereas a handful might be accepted, in the end only six candidates will become scholars. This is a provocative idea that could make for a stimulating new YA series. But, despite a chase scene in the beginning, Ink and Bone starts out dry and kind of flavorless. While a few of the characters are interesting, none are that compelling to me. And, many of the details taken as fact in the story just don't make sense.How does a Library once built as a center of knowledge that encouraged new ideas and debate become an authoritarian political power that forbids such undertakings? That part is never explained. The Library hoards any ancient hand-written material and books so the people are forced to read only what is broadcasted on their government-controlled Codexes. Guttenberg's idea for a printing press was regarded as seditious and therefore did not become reality. So, what did people read in the centuries before the Internet Codexes? I can't wrap my head around that one.Also, since the greatest honor in society is to become a Library scholar the reader would expect grueling testing and classwork that establishes who become the final six. That is part of the program but what truly decides who gets to stay is a roll of the dice. That's right, their teacher rolls a pair of dice and the unlucky are sent home.  What????There are other parts that bugged me like hints that parts of the world are at war and the first time the reader learns this is when the English Jess meets a candidate from Wales. The tension between the two is vaguely explained by some comment that they are at war. Aaaaannnnddd...? Later there is more exposition but very little other than the English-Welsh war. And don't get me started on the automatons and the Translation Center; they appear to be plot devices tossed in as needed.It's not a terrible book, it has its interesting moments and towards the end it's pretty good, but it's flawed and I felt disengaged. So I won't be checking out the next book in the series.

I love the graphic design on the exterior and my Kindle fits snugly into it so I feel it's safe. But, the graphics are more faded than the photo implies and the case doesn't stay shut. I wanted something without a magnet, so if this had an elastic band to keep it closed it would be better.The material feels sturdy and is light which is helpful because the Fire is a bit heavy. The cost, however, is too steep for what you get. I would price it more in the $9.99 range.

During the Civil War, Andersonville Prison in Confederate Georgia was notorious for it‚Äôs horrific and inhumane conditions. In a four-month period the prison population ballooned from just over 7,000 prisoners to an unbelievable 31,000 Union soldiers. Short on food rations, water, medicine and housing, prisoners died by the thousands of malnutrition and disease. Just the facts alone concerning Andersonville make for an unimaginable horror story. Author Edward Erdelac has taken these barbaric prison conditions and added his own angle: there is something darker and more arcane than just humans controlling Andersonville.While most prisoners would try to escape the prison camp, Barclay Lourdes, a black slave with a mysterious past, steals into Andersonville. Barclay originates from New Orleans but wears Yankee blue and some of the prisoners notice he is more educated than most black slaves. Many of the white prisoners cannot even read, but Barclay can. He is a man with a mission and it takes awhile for the reader to discover the true reason. While Barclay struggles to survive the white prejudice against slaves he must also deal with the suspicions that the other blacks feel towards him. There are some interesting, and bizarre, characters that add some good momentum to the plot.It‚Äôs a great idea for a story and Erdelac‚Äôs book is terrific. Just his descriptions of the inhumane conditions were horror enough for me but his dark arts twist makes the story even more so. The author incorporates actual events and people from the real Andersonville giving the book some historical flavor.There are times the book meanders or the flashbacks are confusing, but it all comes together in the end. Some of the writing comes across as unpolished, but the strength of the story significantly carries it. I highly enjoyed it and recommend it to horror book fans.No worries, the story is zombie and vampire-free.[This review is based on an advanced copy received from the publisher via NetGalley.]

Having never read any of Rae Carson's works before but knowing they were all high fantasy YA novels I had no idea what to expect from her latest book, Walk On Earth A Stranger. Set during the nineteenth century American gold rush period it could have read like historical fiction but for one element: the main character, Leah Westfall, is blessed with the ability to divine gold. Not just pan or mine the precious metal, Leah, also known as Lee, can sense even minute particles of gold hidden in the earth or streams. She is even overcome with her "witchy" feeling concerning gold when she is near jewelry or gilded objects. Her talent could make her family extraordinarily rich. But, her parents have always taught her, and lived by, a strong sense of morality and principle. They live simply. Any gold she finds on another person's property is not theirs. And, just like the bag of gold dust hidden under the kitchen floorboards, the Westfall family has kept Lee's talent a secret from everyone; even her best friend, Jefferson.Then one day, Lee's world is shattered and she is forced to flee. Only days earlier, Jefferson had asked Lee to run away from their home in Georgia to California with him. Scared but determined, Lee decides to her only choice is to escape her home and find Jefferson. But, back then, women couldn't, and didn't, travel alone; not only was their safety at stake, but women were regarded as the property of men. So, Lee cuts off her hair, dresses as a young boy and hits the trail west.At this point the book focuses on Lee's voyage and the unbelievable hardships the pioneers faced just to get to the other side of the continent. What now takes us only a few days drive time took the pioneers months to travel. And the daily blood, sweat and tears they experienced would result in a mere twelve to twenty miles of trail by nightfall. Hired by a wagon train made up of families, bachelors, and immigrants, Lee continues to hide her identity and her talent. But her story is more than the miles traveled; it is also made of many rites of passages for Lee. She turns out to be a very remarkable and courageous young woman with strong opinions concerning race and women's rights.Carson's story is compelling as her characters are likeable or understandable and the writing is strong. I felt for the characters when, whether for safety or practical reasons, they were forced to make some hard and very painful decisions while on the road. The descriptions of their days of hunger, thirst, exhaustion, and heat, or their moments of fear were palpable. I even cried while reading a few of the scenes. I also felt joy with the travelers when they would experience moments of music around the nightly campfire, friendship, or just find clean water. And I love how the author would symbolically sprinkle references to gold throughout the story: Lee's eyes, Jefferson's dog's name, buttons on a shirt, the color of a desert sunset. Even Lee's last name, Westfall, has meaning.It's an outstanding book and a great beginning for a trilogy. It will be interesting to see what the author has in store for these characters in the next book.Highly recommended.

In author Christopher Farnsworth‚Äôs world, if a vampire can take a blood oath to protect the president of the United States, then, by God, the Fountain of Youth is not just a legend, it‚Äôs the premise for yet another entertaining book. The Eternal World, a standalone book, is a story of greed and revenge, altruism and love, and for good or bad, how the world could be forever changed by the fountain‚Äôs existence.Five hundred years ago, a young conquistador, wounded in battle, is running through the jungle of the New World. As he lies dying in a cave near a pool of blue water, he feels the cool touch of a beautiful angel. Abrupt fast-forward to present day: a serial killer is hunting his next prey and finds himself the victim. Then, Dr. David Robinton, a man who dedicates his life to his lab and his research, finds himself being dumped by his girlfriend. So when he receives an offer from playboy and pharmaceutical giant, Simon Oliver, to join his company with multiple perks and an unlimited budget to research an anti-aging drug, the driven David cannot refuse.But Simon Oliver is more than the womanizer and drunkard the paparazzi love to catch on film, he is a man with a very old secret and an ancient enemy. The beautiful Shako has been tracking Simon for many years and she is out for revenge. Her first scene in the book proves she is more than capable when it comes to dealing with murderous scum and it is possible she could easily destroy Simon‚Äôs world.While David is driven to perfect a compound that will cure the body-ravaging effects of disease and old age, it appears that Simon also wants to save the world. But is he truly a compassionate billionaire or is he just a greedy megalomaniac? It doesn‚Äôt take much to put two and two together in this book. There are a few twists that are pretty good. There are some flashbacks that fill in the blanks, including a rather large expository segment concerning Simon and Shako. Some people call it an ‚Äúinfo dump‚Äù, but, whatever, the book is still entertaining. However, the droll sense of humor that is found in the Nathaniel Cade series is sorely missing in The Eternal World. I miss that cantankerous old vampire.No matter how much the readers need to suspend their disbelief, they will find this book to be a fast-paced and exciting read. I know I‚Äôll recommend it to a few of my reading buddies. And, I know I‚Äôll read Farnsworth‚Äôs next novel, vampire or not.

This computer was my introduction to the searing pit of malaise known as Windows 8.I've used Windows 7 for the past six years. Windows 7 is a pretty decent operating system. Windows 8, as you probably know, is a seething horror-show of apps, blinking tiles, little slideshows, the phases of the moon, I mean WHAT IS THIS??? When I turn on my computer, I want to see my desktop. What I don't want to see are all these "apps" that I didn't install, stuff for managing my investment portfolio or reading the news and the weather and recipes and all these little pictures of people I don't know, pictures of food that I didn't make, just staring back at me. Taylor Swift's face should not appear, unbidden, on my laptop. It's that simple. It's like what you would expect to find at msn.com, only they've brought msn.com straight to my desktop. Noooooo!!!!I should mention that my previous laptop is also a Dell, specifically, the Studio XPS 16, which I got about six years ago. It's worked well over the years and with various upgrades (memory, HDD), it's been a good computer.Now, if you use any computer for six years, your fingers just automatically go where they need to go. And you might expect a slightly different keyboard layout on a different brand of computer. But it turns out Dell thinks that even existing Dell users should have to relearn the the locations of various keys. Like the "home," "end," "delete," page up, and page down buttons. All in different places. WHY DO THEY DO THIS? It's like when you go to the grocery store you've been shopping at for years, and one day they've switched all the aisles around so the paper towels are where the cereal used to be and beer is where the paper towels used to be, and you have to wander the store for 20 minutes just to find a bottle of ketchup.And what's up with the function keys? I can't just hit F5 anymore to reload a web page. Now I have to press the Fn key while pressing F5. Otherwise I end up PAUSING THE MUSIC I WAS LISTENING TO. Good god, people, WHY WHY WHY???Oh, speaking of keys, the keyboard feels a little flimsy. Again, this is in comparison to my previous Dell laptop, which had a keyboard that felt solid when I typed. I guess I'm a pretty forceful typist, but I don't think it should feel like my fingers tapping away might actually break the keyboard, but that's how it feels sometimes. Like the plastic plate around the keys might snap into pieces just through normal typing.It didn't help that the keyboard plate was actually semi-detached from the body of the computer when I first opened it. It felt REALLY flimsy then as it rattled up and down with every keystroke, until I realized the problem and snapped two of the keyboard tabs back into the frame. Nice quality control, Dell.Another issue is with the touchpad. Sometimes I have to tap the thing like six times to get a click to register, and I promise you by the sixth time, a "tap" has become something rather more emphatic. Especially when you click a link and sit there waiting for it to load and then you realize the click didn't register and you've just been sitting there doing nothing. Maybe there are certain areas on the pad which don't register a regular "left" click. I don't know. There's no way to know. Maybe I'm just used to my previous Dell's touchpad. As it is, though, the touchpad is a dreadful combination of being much MORE sensitive to light movements (although this can be adjusted), and ultra-UNresponsive when it comes to taps (which as far as I can tell, cannot be adjusted).Initial setup seemed to take ages. I was particularly alarmed when the system prompted me to sign into my Microsoft account (or create one!) as part of the setup process. Good god, can you imagine? The wireless adaptor immediately found my WiFi, so that was nice. All the better for my computer to start sending my personal info back to the mothership, I suppose.As I learned six years ago, Dell computers come loaded with all kinds of bloatware, junkware, hellware and all-around yuckware, and this one is no exception. This, coupled with the bizarre array of "apps" that came pre-installed, immediately led me to undertake a clean install of Windows 8.1. This was pretty easy using the Windows Installation Media Creation Tool, which I downloaded from the Microsoft site and followed the instructions. Unfortunately, neither the wireless nor the wired ethernet network adaptors were functioning afterward, which meant there was no way to get online, which meant no way for the computer to download drivers so as to fix itself, in an infinite loop of loathing. I tried reinstalling again with the same results.So that was that. I then decided to install Ubuntu. Which was extremely easy to do and I was sailing along just fine thinking to myself "HAHA Windows 8.1, you lose!" Until that night when I wanted to watch "Sons of Anarchy" on Netflix. Whereupon I found that there is no way in Ubuntu to adjust screen contrast. Brightness yes, contrast no. Which meant that all video was either too dark, or completely washed out. So it was back to Windows 8.1 again.A quick aside here: WHAT WAS SO WRONG WITH WINDOWS 7 THAT YOU HAD TO GO AND CHANGE IT???By the way, if you do reinstall Windows, you'll notice that nowhere on the computer will you find the license key. Used to be they'd put it on a sticker on the bottom of the laptop. Invariably upside-down, so that instead of simply tilting the laptop up away from you and looking at the sticker underneath, you had to pick the whole thing up and hold it upside down.Well now the sticker doesn't exist, because the license key is hard-coded into the bios chip (in encrypted form), so you don't ever have to enter this license key again. The bios automatically knows that your Windows installation is valid because it's physically paired with your specific machine. So there you go.(If you do reinstall windows, be sure to save the Firefox installer onto a USB drive first so that you don't have to open Internet Explorer even once to get online. Not even to download Firefox.)Well this time, the wireless adaptor STILL didn't work, but miraculously, the wired ethernet adaptor DID work, so all I had to do was plug it directly into my cable modem and let Windows download the correct drivers, and before long I was connected to WiFi and ready to go.Now, there is a way to disable the hellish Windows 8 "app screen" so that you go straight to the desktop by default, but I'm too exhausted to describe how to do it. You can Google it, though. It was pretty easy. You'll of course have to manually delete certain of the more hideous apps, like Internet Explorer (just no), and Mail (hello, gmail.com), and Microsoft's vile media player and completely unnecessary pdf reader and bunch of other silly absurd stuff. But with a little bit of time and effort you can get things more or less under control.I don't know, guys. It's a nice computer. The fan is pretty quiet, and it stays pretty cool, so it doesn't scorch my lap and turn my wrists into a pair of braised sausages like my old Dell did. Battery life seems pretty good. The built-in Bluetooth is nice. The screen is nice and wide.Oh, and guess what? They're currently rolling out Windows 10 (free upgrade), which means I probably get to do all this over again in a few weeks. Which I fully intend to do, because there's no way it could be worse than Windows 8. #famouslastwords

Always on the lookout for new earrings to add to my rather large collection, I was pleased to find these lovely silver Celtic knots earrings. These drop style earrings are the perfect size; not too ostentatious but definitely noticeable. They are sturdy, but light on the earlobes and so very lovely.The price is affordable for everyone.

This is the perfect skirt for work or just kicking around on the weekend. At 5'4" and 115 pounds, the small size fits me perfectly. The hem sits about an inch or two above my knees but the elastic waistband can be folded over to make for a shorter skirt if desired.I love the diagonally curved scallop seams; it is not only an eye-pleasing detail, it gives the cotton/spandex fabric more flexibility and movement. So far I have worn the skirt while gardening, doing housework, and at a barbecue; it's that versatile.The price is fair for the value of what you receive. Highly recommended.

The beginning of this novel sets the tone perfectly: as a man is confessing to a brutal rape and murder of a young women he is envisioning himself attacking the female detective sitting in front of him. What the reader quickly learns is that the man is a famous crime fiction writer with early onset Alzheimer‚Äôs and the murder is a scene from his first novel. Only fifty years old, Jerry Gray, writing under the name Henry Cutter, is rapidly deteriorating, losing his memory, and his life, to the insidious disease he calls ‚ÄúCaptain A‚Äù. But, while Jerry‚Äôs family and friends refuse to believe his confused ramblings, the reader sees reason to believe that what he is saying is quite possibly true.This creates an unusual conundrum, and a fantastic plot device, that will constantly keep the reader on its toes. Is Jerry telling the truth or did his life as a fictional storyteller, a ‚Äúmake up artist‚Äù, leave him to believe he actually did commit those crimes? As he always told aspiring writers, ‚Äúwrite what you know‚Äù. Did the actions of Jerry Gray make him the popular writer Henry Cutter because he not only wrote what he knew; he wrote what he did?While the narrative is told in a third person present tense, there are expository chapters in the form of Jerry‚Äôs journal; a first person past tense detailing his descent into ‚ÄúBat**** County‚Äù.  He refuses to call it a diary, it is a journal and it is for the future Jerry so when reaches that point of no return he will have a chronicle to remind him how he got there and what he lost along the way. It‚Äôs pretty powerful and the events he writes about are incredibly sad. But, as the present day story unfolds, Jerry‚Äôs life becomes more harrowing because he keeps escaping from his nursing home. And when he is finally found many miles away and with no memory of what took place, the police are finding the bodies of murdered women.The pacing is fast and the twists build up, especially as the book comes to a close. There are some reveals that sharp readers might guess, or suspect, before the end. Otherwise it is a well-written and deeply disturbing book; fortunately there are moments of subtle dark humor to alleviate the shocks. I was glued to the pages and finished it in a day because I wanted to know how it ended.The good news: the author has a treasure trove of other mystery novels that I am definitely going to have to read now.Highly recommended.
Three words: German dungeon pornIt doesn't get any better than that.

Let me start by saying this book is awesome. I love the premise, love the female main character, and because the backstory of Wolf by Wolf includes an intercontinental motorcycle race, it truly speeds along to the end. As a YA alternative history novel with a sci-fi departure from reality, it asks the reader to suspend their disbelief, and trust me, the way the author presents it, it's not hard to do.In the Author's Note she tries to examine the "What if?" facet of life with this book. What if Hitler and Emperor Hirohito had won the war? What if those two dictators took over the Eurasian continent and northern Africa? And what if the egregious medical experiments performed in the concentration camps left a young girl with the power to "skinshift" and change her appearance at will? That is the basis of Wolf by Wolf.After Yael, a young Jewish survivor of the medical experiments escapes a death camp she joins the resistance. Years later, her ability to skinshift gives the resistance a perfect opportunity to bring down the Nazi Regime. She must impersonate Adele Wolfe, the only female to win the annual Axis Tour, a grueling motorcycle race from Berlin to Tokyo, in the upcoming competition. Hitler will be in Tokyo for the finish and last year he honored Adele Wolfe during the Emperor's Ball. If she wins this race, Yael will have a chance to be close enough to Hitler to change history.Most of the book centers on the race with flashbacks to Yael's childhood and her years with the Resistance. The reader learns the personal meaning behind the five wolf tattoos on her arm. She is an intense, focused young woman with one goal: revenge. She is able to think on her feet, can handle any gun, carries a knife in her boot and is a trained fighter. Her skinshifting is a powerful tool. To sum up, the girl is badass.The race is not as straightforward as Yael assumed. Many of the racers play dirty and a huge monkey wrench is tossed into the story when two of the racers are close to the real Adele Wolfe. There is a lot of tension and some huge twists in the story. During the heart pounding racing scenes I actually felt myself grow tenser as the racers sped closer to the finish line. Every setback, every close call is nerve-racking. But despite moments of self-doubt, Yael's determination is unfailing and she is a fighter, a most powerful character.The author's writing style is expressive especially when conveying Yael's inner thoughts. The wolf tattoos have significant meaning to Yael and she counts them, wolf by wolf, in her moments of despair, when she needs reason to continue her mission. So many elements of this story are wonderful choices: using a victim of Nazi medical experimentation as a weapon against the Nazi's is my favorite. The end of the book could almost, but not quite, make it a standalone with some unanswered questions for the reader to draw their own conclusion. But, no, this is the first of two books and I am thrilled to say that I will pre-order the next one as soon as I can and will breathlessly wait for it.Highly recommended. Highly.

I cannot rave enough about LED bulbs. My plan is to replace every incandescent bulb in my house with an LED. Initially the price will be high, but the savings in electric bills will be worth it. It costs pennies to power these things.They are expected to last up to 22 years and that is an immense draw for me. These 100 watt bulbs are exceptionally bright but are not hot to the touch.Note: these bulbs are not for use with dimmer switches.

When a trio of pirates ambushes a yacht in the South China Sea they discover the cargo is more than the fortune in sapphires they were hired to steal. There is an incredible find on that yacht, something worth killing for. Only one man returns to shore and texts the ‚Äújugmaker‚Äù, his employer Angela, that he has the stones but doesn‚Äôt tell her what else was on the boat. Then he disappears. Angela receives a deadly threat: Return what you stole and I will return the sapphires. With her back against the wall, Angela contacts someone she hasn‚Äôt seen for five years, someone who thought she was dead: Jack, a criminal with extraordinary skills, a Ghostman. And Angela, his mentor, taught him everything he knows.To tell any more of the book would ruin all the surprises and twists that make it an entertaining and exciting read. The author is obviously having a great time with his characters and the setting, the island of Macau. After hearing the author, Roger Hobbs, speaks the other night about the second book in his Ghostman series it was apparent that he loves what he does and intends to keep writing. He has the basics of the third book lined up and is very excited. His exuberance comes across in Vanishing Games.The relationship between Jack and Angela goes way back and they have what appears to be more than just a non-romantic student/teacher connection. It‚Äôs an interesting collaborative partnership and I think the author does a good job of keeping it genuine. Unlike the first book, Ghostman, which had a team working together on a job, Vanishing Games is just the two of them. And it works well.But what really amused me about this book is that is almost reads like a textbook on how to be a master criminal. The reader will learn the best way to scuttle a boat, destroy the facial features of a severed head, make a silencer out of a plastic pop bottle, the workings of a ‚ÄúKansas City Shuffle‚Äù, and how to break into a hotel room using a program off the internet to bypass the card key system. And that is only naming a few of the tricks someone can learn from this book.It‚Äôs a fun read with a fast and furious ending. This book does not disappoint. Recommended for those who love thrillers or want to pick up some extra tips on how to become a Ghostman.

I'm 5' 3" tall at 116 pounds with a long waist. This skirt fit perfectly! It's waistband rests just below the belly button with the hem a few inches above my knees. I chose the heather-gray skirt with the plaid fabric. The fabric has a lovely pattern and feels well-woven, the pleats are sturdy, the fit is comfortable and I love the belt line button decoration. I don't wear a belt with it because it would not go well with and/or obstruct the button decoration.When I bought this, the skirt cost $18 and I feel it was well worth it.

Many authors will borrow a few ideas or elements from other books and tell their tale with a different flair or meaning or perspective. Others will sometimes borrow too heavily and while they may try to make the story their own, it does not work and the reader is constantly comparing one book to the other.That's how I felt when I read author Melissa Gray's debut YA fantasy novel, The Girl at Midnight. Too much of Gray's book is directly borrowed from Laini Taylor's awesome and beautifully written novel, Daughter of Smoke and Bone. I'm willing to overlook similarities and enjoy another author's different take on a story, but I was so distracted by the unequivocal likenesses of the two books that it detracted from the reading experience. And, Gray doesn't have the writing chops that Taylor has.The first chapter was a great beginning. A Seer, The Ala, from the ancient race of bird-like Avicen people adopts a young human runaway. While the Avicen live underground in present time New York, the little runaway, unfortunately named Echo, lives in the New York public library where she reads constantly. The Avicen have begrudgingly allowed Echo into their world and she grows into a sassy, sometimes annoyingly too sarcastic, teenager who is an expert at pickpocketing and stealing. She's tight friends with Ivy and has just started a romance with Rowan, both Avicen.Then the author introduces the Drakharin people, centuries-old enemies of the Avicen. Unlike the Avicen who sport feather-like hair, the Drakharin have dragon scales. Why they hate each other is never covered in this first book of the trilogy but their Dragon Prince, Caius, is tired of the war. He wants peace as he mourns the death of his secret Avicen lover. His one-dimensionally evil twin sister craves war and victims for her to personally torture.Separately, both Caius and the The Ala believe peace can be attained if the ancient, and mythical, firebird is found. It's power can end the war. The Ala sends, of all people, Echo to find it. Meanwhile, Caius and his best friend, Dorian, are on their own quest for the firebird. Of course they will cross paths. If you have read Daughter of Smoke and Bone, you will, by this time, recognize the similarities: Avicen=Chimaera, Drakharin=Angels. They are at war, they hate each other, they should never intermix, but sometimes souls will fall in love with the wrong kind.The relationship between Caius and Echo is predictable and uneventful. Of course it includes a love triangle. But, it is the relationship between Dorian and another Avicen that really captures the spirit of how people so diverse can fall for one another: it is tentative and shy and awkward and...normal. I fell in love with those two.Now, the ending: a feeble Deus ex Machina comes swooping in to save the day, of course. But, what it is and how it is discovered made me laugh out loud and shake my head. Really? Really?I really wanted to like this book. And I really wish I could give this debut author a big thumbs up but there were too many similarities to DOSAB. Echo could be unbelievably annoying. And the ending was...really?Anyway, I'm sure Gray will develop a fan base and grow as a writer, but her debut novel just didn't grab me.

The Perky-Pet wild bird feeder, with it's sturdy construction, squirrel baffle and four compartment seed dividers, should be the best feeder I've ever owned. And at $70+ a pop, it had better be the best bird feeder in my backyard. So, what's the problem?The birds completely ignore it.I have five feeding stations in my yard and two weeks after hanging the Perky-Pet I noticed it was still full.  I let the other feeders go empty so that the birds would try out the Perky Pet. Usually my yard is so populated with birds it sounds like walking into an aviary; constant bird chatter and songs. Now, it was empty. There was the lone finch that tried the thistle from the Perky-Pet every now and then but the birds were feeding elsewhere and my yard was silent.So, I re-hung my $10 cylinder feeders and my $35 Squirrel Buster feeders and the birds came back. They still ignore the Perky Pet.I don't know what the problem is but the feeder is built to last, it holds up to five pounds of seed, and can serve up to 10 birds at a time. So, I hate to give it a low rating but the birds' opinion does count. If they don't like it or use it, it is not a good feeder for my yard. Perhaps it will do well with other yards but, in mine, the birds have spoken.3 stars for construction. One star for effectiveness.Addendum: I was comparing my bird feeders to the Perky Pet and noticed the Perky Pet feeder holes are much smaller. That would explain why only a finch might show interest. The other birds' heads are too large. So, I changed my rating to 2 stars.Addendum as of May 10, 2015: I don't know what happened but some more birds are starting to take notice of the Perky-Pet. It's not just the finches either. So, I raised my rating to a 3 star because the product shouldn't be rated low because my birds were acting snobby.

Eleven years ago, after reading a review in our local paper, I picked up a novel by then-debut author Craig Johnson called The Cold Dish. And I was hooked. His characters were vivid and human and likeable. The humor was cheeky, yet cleverly worded. There were elements of Indian mysticism and Greek philosophy. With the Wyoming terrain playing a volatile supporting character to the fallible human cast, The Cold Dish was one of the best books I had ever read from a debut author. Still is.Now ten books, 1 novella, and a collection of short stories neatly tucked under his cowboy belt, Johnson proudly, and rightly so, presents Dry Bones. With Sheriff Walt Longmire, the renaissance man of Wyoming lawmen, at the helm and his deliciously salty undersheriff Victoria "Vic" Moretti as his wingman, the fictitious Absaroka County is faced with a mystery that kind of began 65 million years ago. When the bones of probably largest and most intact T. Rex skeleton is discovered on Danny Lone Elk's ranch it is cause for celebration. Until, that is, the body of Danny Lone Elk is discovered face down in a pond of carnivorous snapping turtles. The imagery is not lost on the reader as Lone Elk's family, the Cheyenne tribe, the High Plains Dinosaur Museum, and the federal government all lay a claim to the dinosaur nicknamed "Jen".Walt's tiny town of 2483 citizens is immediately overrun with bureaucrats, media, and the FBI--that's the government agency FBI, not the Longmire sobriquet for big Indians. Henry Standing Bear, the sage Indian who has had Walt's back since elementary school, helps Walt navigate through the politically and culturally delicate dance with the Cheyenne tribe. Characters from past books like Agent In Charge McGroder, a man who owes Walt his life, and two agents, nicknamed the Bobs, assist with the federal investigation. Making Walt's job even more difficult is the supremely pompous acting deputy attorney, Skip Trost. And, on top of all of this mayhem, Walt's daughter is flying in from Philadelphia with his first grandchild, Lola, whose namesake is Henry's Baltic-blue 1959 Thunderbird convertible.Thankfully, now that deputies Saizarbitoria and the appropriately named Double Tough are back, as is former-Sheriff Lucian Connelly who stubbornly refuses to die, Walt has his entire team on board. Even Dog, his ever present canine sounding board is there to help. Saizarbitoria is able to update Walt on the multiple equipment requirements of an infant granddaughter. Lucian is willing to shoot anyone, anyone, just give him a chance. And Double Tough (I missed that guy), after losing his eye in an earlier book is back from medical leave sporting an eye patch and a fake eye. I laughed out loud at Vic's reaction when no one had the nerve to tell DT his new eye was the wrong color: "I can't believe you a******* were going to let him wander around looking like a ****ed-up husky because you two were afraid of hurting his delicate feelings..." I love that woman.But then tragedy hits Walt and it's a heartbreaker. And while Walt feels that it is personally aimed at him from someone in his past he has to deal with the human fallout and that's just not something he is good at. He's a man who keeps his feelings to himself and bumbles when handling the feelings of others. Boy howdy does this poor man seriously fumble around. It painfully reminds the reader that despite his strong and stoic nature, deep down, Walt is still a frail human. We also get to see a bit of Walt's childhood, something he rarely looks back upon. To add to Walt's unhappy distress, the prophetic visions of his ghosts are starting to come true.With his ability to build a strong story, his intelligent and clever word play, that cheeky sense of humor, and the most remarkable and endearing cast of characters; Johnson remains one of my favorite writers. I look forward to, and faithfully pre-order, all his new books. And, if he ever visits your town for a book signing, do go meet him. He is a most personable and accommodating speaker; he truly loves talking to his readers. His signings here started in a tiny little bookstore and as his audience grew exponentially he had to move to a larger venue.Yep, this book is highly highly highly highly recommended.

Confession time: I bought the Faceless Knight for myself. I have been building one of those ubiquitous 3-D fairyland dioramas that you find on Pinterest in my backyard. I already have a couple of knights with horses (originally presents for my nephew but I kept them) and my son gave me a dragon for Christmas.They all look awesome in their mossy rock and succulent plant environment. The dragon is terrifying in his former-birdhouse-now-prison lockup. They just needed a Faceless Knight to add another mystical element to the story. Because the Faceless Knight reminded me of a the Ring Wraith from the movie, "Lord of the Rings", I had to order him.In the picture, it appears the knight is in a defensive stance. I didn't realize he is meant to be astride a horse. No matter, I'll just order an equally freaky horse for him, but for now he stands astride the mossy hilltop next to the dragon cage. Surrounded by lava rock and quartz, this guy is right at home.Now, I need a wizard.

The Marvel Avengers Crunch Beach Towel is colorful, large, and whimsically decorated with muscled good guys, but the fabric is about as thin as a tissue. While it is advertised as a beach towel that can also be used as a bath towel, do not be fooled by this double agent. It's about as absorbant as a cloth napkin. For $22 most buyers would expect a little more absorbency in a towel but I fear most of the profit goes towards the Marvel trademark and upkeep for Stan Lee's mustache.But you know, the kids don't care. It's got the Hulk and Iron Man! Unless the fabric is burlap and scratchy they don't notice, or care about, it's quality. It's the Avengers, for heaven's sake! Even I was running around wearing it like Thor's cape.Despite the price and fabric quality, it's perfect for laying around on the beach or the poolside, showing off to your playmates, LARP, ComiCon, superhero accessorizing, or just hanging in the bathroom so your adult friends can say, "Oh my God, where did you get such a cool towel?"4 stars. Would get 5 if it had included Black Widow.

Ruins of War by debut author John A. Connell is, I always hate saying this, a book that I really wanted to like. Setting the story post-WWII war-torn Germany with former enemy American army detectives investigating a series of gruesome murders sounded riveting. It's a brilliant idea for a detective series. But, in the end, the execution, dialogue, and some of the painfully one-dimensional characters sabotage what could be an impressive debut.Barely seven months after Germany surrendered, the country is in chaos. Neighborhoods are destroyed, families separated, children orphaned and the threat of a long, cold, and hungry winter has descended upon the once proud country. To make matters worse, the presence of the American army antagonizes a major part of the population. There is no mutual trust or respect. Criminal Investigator Mason Collins, an American police officer with a less than stellar reputation, is the lead detective in a gruesome killing. A body was found wired to a pole, it's abdomen flayed open, the arms and legs missing. What complicates this murder is the possibility the victim was German and the bureaucrats running the Criminal Investigation Division feel the Germans should handle this case. They are unwilling to supply the necessary time and manpower for a German "problem".Mason Collins feels differently, especially after a second body is discovered in the same condition. This becomes a point of contention between Collins and his unbelievably one-dimensional commanding officer. No matter how much progress or effort Collins makes in the case, the CO inevitably tells Collins it's not enough. His negative responses are inevitable and predictable. It gets old real fast. And I was stunned by his reaction near the end of the book when the killer kidnaps yet another victim. It's a race against time and he chooses to send his men on a different raid?When Collins meets an American journalist, Laura, their mutual attraction to one another would be an entertaining diversion from the horror that pervades the story if it weren't for one thing: their flirty banter is laughable. And not in a good way. The dialogue in the book is not the best but it really flattens when these two converse. It reminded me of an old B-movie. In fact, the whole book reads like a movie script and when I found out that the author is in the movie business I wasn't surprised.The serial killer has left mutilated bodies throughout Munich in bizarre displays that reminded me of the TV series "Hannibal" and the reader finds out he is a creature filled with self-loathing and anger. His cruelty is appalling but I laughed out loud when he reminded himself what he does for a living. The reader will figure out who he is and what drives him to do such barbaric acts rather early on in the book.The author's strongest writing comes from his commentary concerning post-war Germany. It's powerful and paints a vivid picture that leaves the reader sympathetic towards the citizens of the former Nazi regime. The hostility between the two former enemy countries is palpable, and understandable, from both sides. There are some good suspenseful scenes but if the story had been written more tightly the twists would have been more shocking and less predictable. And the author missed a perfect opportunity to better hide the killer's identity from the reader. He was on the right track.This is the first book in the Mason Collins detective series but I don't think I will continue to follow it. There is some strong writing in parts of this book, but it didn't satisfy me.

Hands down, this is the worst and most expensive mop I have ever owned.I was so excited to receive it in the mail. It was easy to put together, the instructions concerning it's use were simple and easy to follow, and it even came with it's own special cleaner. It's sleek and light and the cord is extra long.Then, I plugged it in...the noise it made was almost louder than my neighbor's Harley. The scrubbing wheels are vacuum-powered as opposed to motorized which would make them stronger and more effective but I was too enamoured to care. But then the wheels got stuck multiple times and I had to either turn the machine on and then off for them to restart, or I had to reach down and use my hands to get them moving again. Touching the wet and dirty wheels was gross and my infatuation with my new mop began to wane.You need to squeeze a lever on the handle to get the cleaning water to squirt out onto the floor. Then you start mopping. The wheels do not distribute the water evenly so you have to make multiple back and forth motions, squeezing all the while so as to distribute the cleaning water. If there is a spill or some dirt on the floor you need to hold the cleaner on top of it while the wheels scrub at it. Repeat the motion if it doesn't work the first time. Usually you will need to repeat it again and again. Like a mop, only louder.After you have dowsed the floor, you kick a toe switch to vacuum up the water. Repeat again and again because the vacuum may be effective at vacuuming up dust but it does diddley when it comes to water. Then, when the darn thing stops working because there is some unbeknownst filter that clogs after using. Then you take the stupid thing apart while dumping dirty water all over the place. After much swearing and washing of the filter you can repeat your back and forth motions...like a mop. Except then the handle disconnects from the body of the vacuum (3 times!) leaving you to use even more salty language than previously.To be fair, I tried this thing twice on ceramic tile and hardwood floors just to make sure it was not user error that made this the most expensive and crappiest mop I have ever owned. When I turned the beast off the sound of silence is almost deafening. My hand was tired from squeezing the lever to distribute water, I was exhausted, and my arm and shoulder joints hated me for pushing the thing back and forth and back and forth ad nauseum. Like a mop but heavier, louder and less effective. And it took me triple the amount of time to clean than when I used a simple, timeless mop.Why anyone would pay $240 for this POC when they can buy a mop for under $10 is beyond me. This thing is going straight to the junk closet in my house where it can collect dust. Millennia from now when anthropologists dig it out, they too will be baffled by it's uselessness and will ask the same question: why would anyone buy this thing?

When we think of angels, we think of beautiful and heavenly creatures created by God. We hear the beautiful music we know they make while they fly about with their gossamer wings. They are inspirational, divine, and a gift from Heaven.But, what if they weren't. What if they came down from Heaven and conquered the human race, turned them into slaves, destroyed their way of life? Those aren't creatures of God, those are the angels in Susan Ee's new book, World After, the second part of her Angelfall Trilogy. While they remain gorgeous winged creatures of power, their intentions are evil. And their actions are despicable.The second book picks up immediately after the end of the first. After the scorpion angels attacked Penryn, Raffe thought she had died and flew away with his transplanted demon wings, leaving her and his sword behind. However, the venom only temporarily injured Penryn and when she comes to life people view her as the living dead. It doesn't help that her mother is clinically mad and her sister is horribly disfigured by the angels' experiments. They escape with the resistance army that has effectively pissed off the angels by blowing up their aerie.Even though Raffe is not physically present during the first half of this book, the author has used a clever writing device to keep him in the story...and Penryn's thoughts. No question that the girl is in love with the angel she saved. She misses the gorgeous angel with what she describes as a "corny sense of humor". But, what are Raffe's feelings towards her? She's kickasss tough, has some mad karate moves and is deadly with Raffe's sword. What's the problem? Well, it's complicated.While Raffe is gone, Penryn is able to focus more on her mom and sister, Paige. Mom may be crazy, but there are times she is crazy like a fox. Paige is a sad story. Her body is a horror show, disfigured with Frankenstein-like stitching, her teeth filed to deadly points, Paige is revolting to the other humans. But, like their mom, she also has some tricks up her sleeve and I found myself gob-smacked by her by the end of the book. I like this family.  No, I love this family.Now, I'm still having some WTH moments with the angels' choice of party wear. Zoot suits? Flapper dresses? Is there some hidden meaning that I am not catching? But, the moment passes and I am still enchanted by the whole story.Then the book gets dark. Really, really dark. Just when you thought the angels could not be crueler or more sadistic, they prove you wrong. They crank it up to 11 on the evil meter. There are some insanely cringe-worthy moments in this book. And it's not only the angels that make you recoil in disgust. When beaten and starved and caged, the humans are pushed to their limits of their humanity.I have already pre-ordered the next book.Addendum: I read this while I was supposed to be studying for my test tomorrow. It's that good.

I've never used pore strips before because it sounded gross pulling black heads out and seeing the debri on a piece of tape. But, after using the Biore Deep Cleansing Strips I can understand the draw. After using for the first time my skin felt so soft and smooth and looked so clean. I was really impressed.The instructions are easy to follow: clean your face, thoroughly moisten your nose and cheeks, then apply. After 15 minutes they feel like papier-m‚ch√©, almost bullet proof even. Slowly peel away. Rinse any remaining charcoal and viola! Clean, smooth skin with reddening or irritation. It's that simple. The price is affordable and when I run out of my sample box I am going to buy more.Gross to look at, but highly recommended.

After reading Joe Abercrombie's first YA novel, Half a King, a strong beginning to his "Shattered Seas" trilogy, I recognized a writer who not only appreciates but revels in the virtue of a flawed character. My impressions were substantiated when I read his "First Law" trilogy. Abercrombie can bring to life characters that are insufferable and deceitful and should be unlikeable but, strangely enough, the reader devours them.He can also write mean fight scene.In his first journey into YA, Abercrombie introduced us to the world of the Shattered Seas and it's contentious countries ruled by the cruel High King. The young Yarvi, a political victim of palace subterfuge within his own country of Gettland is forced to take a journey as prince-turned-king-turned-slave-turned-hero. It is an odyssey of self-discovery that ends with his rightful position as Father Yarvi, right hand and Minister to the new king of Gettland.Half the World takes place shortly after the end of that superb first novel. While Father Yarvi is still a driving force to the story, this book mostly focuses on Brand and Thorn, two teenagers training to be warriors in the King's army. A horrific accident during a training exercise lands Thorn in prison; her death sentence, if carried out, is equally horrific. When Brand speaks up for her, he unwittingly changes their lives and launches their own odyssey.Father Yarvi must travel half the world looking for allies to fight against the High King. His crew includes Brand and Thorn, as well as his former shipmate Rulf from Half a King. The journey is brutal but it bonds the shipmates like a family, and is full of surprises. Thorn trains daily as a fighter with the cunning, foul-smelling, unpredictable, and completely entertaining Skifr, a highly skilled warrior herself who is not afraid to pick her nose in public. During their year of travel, Brand, a boy from the slums who dreamed of becoming a warrior quickly grows into a young man who prefers the way of Mother Peace and chooses to see the light in everything. Thorn, however, becomes a strutting fighter, a daughter of Father War, who revels in the battle. And Yarvi, constantly referred to as a man of "deep-cunning", who is bound to forsake the ways of Father War and must follow the ways of Mother Peace is definitely a bastard son of both. His strategies from the beginning to the end show a man of deep cunning who will sacrifice others to achieve his goals.As Half a King was recognizable as a YA novel with it's short chapters and shorter story, Abercrombie-Light to be sure, Half the World is more evolved and complex. While Thorn was angry and cocky, almost repelling at times, she had moments that defined her as more than just a fighter. She is also pretty good at spitting and hucking snot rockets. Brand may have seemed rather Mary-Sue-ish to some, but his loyalty to friends and family, and his unwavering integrity, especially in the end, made him a true warrior in my eyes. And, unlike the first book, I was able to recognize that this medieval world is definitely a futuristic remnant of what was once a world ruled by "elves" with their "magic" lights and tall buildings and factories.Abercrombie's books are some of the grittiest, and smelliest, fantasy novels but he thankfully also maintains a sense of humor throughout that helps alleviate what would otherwise be a bleak story. While he can write some of the best fight scenes, he is also able to expose the absolute horror of war: bloody and unfair and cruel and sickening. His major characters are never black and white, many are quite prickly, but they are enjoyable and memorable.I cannot wait for the next book.Highly recommended for fantasy nuts, YA enthusiasts, and Joe Abercrombie disciples.

I recently had the privilege of hearing fantasy writer Brandon Sanderson speak and he said if you take a deck of cards, fifty two elements we all know and recognize, and shuffle it you will always come up with a new creation. Always. No matter the combination of face cards, numbers and suits, you will have created something entirely new. Bearing that in mind, when I started reading Red Queen by debut author Victoria Aveyard I recognized elements of Divergent, Hunger Games, Graceling, even a dash of Harry Potter but it was still, to me, a new creation that I thoroughly enjoyed.In a fantastical world where humans are divided not by the color of their skin but by the color of their blood, those with Red blood are considered the commoners and workers and soldiers who live to serve the Silver-blooded elite. The Silvers are each blessed with a specific superhuman ability: telekinesis, speed, fire making, water nymph, mindreading, or strength, just to name a few. In this dystopian world, in the country of Norta, at war with Lakeland for the past century, the red-blooded Mare lives in the impoverished rural city of The Stilts where electricity is rationed and her only future is conscription into the army. When Mare's childhood friend, Kilhorn, loses his apprenticeship and must join the army, Mare takes drastic steps to save him.Her desperation fortuitously lands her in the palace as a servant,  herself safe from conscription. However, an extraordinary turn of events exposes an unknown power in Mare. The palace nobility quickly covers up the possibility that a Red could have the power of a Silver and Mare is betrothed to the king's second son. She is then forced to live a life of lies and political subterfuge. As her palace teacher explains to her "Anyone can betray anyone". Complicating her already imperiled life is the growing Red rebellion that threatens the Silvers' elite status and her ever-changing feelings towards not one, but both the king's sons.So, all the elements are familiar, easily recognizable and present but they do not detract from the pleasure of reading Red Queen. Yes, there are inconsistencies that have made other readers firmly plant their face in their palms. There are times I forget their world is advanced enough for video cameras and nuclear radiation when the palace women wear long silk gowns. The Silvers have their powers but will resort to using guns to fight the Reds. The Reds have been sent to the frontlines to fight the Lakelanders in the trenches for decades when it seems the war could be easily finished if the Silvers stepped in and used their powers.The story, while not fresh, is still interesting and the characters quite likable. The writing is not dumbed down or condescending. And there are enough twists to keep the reader on their toes. Some I was able to guess, others did surprise me. And the final battle scene is plausibly well written with enough tension to keep me up last night.  When the story ends, there is no huge cliffhanger to annoy the reader so the components will compel the reader to want to read the second novel.So, enjoy this deck of cards because the Red Queen has not been played yet.

I bought these for my son's girlfriend (a Gustav Klimt fan), 5' 6' and 160 pounds with impossibly long legs, and they fit perfectly. They are comfortable, well made, and gorgeous. The colors are bright, the fabric is sturdy, and they look great on her. And the price cannot be beat!! I looked at other leggings with "The Kiss" and found many reviewers to be uphappy with the fit or the fact that the leggings tear too easily. These are perfect.Highly recommended for "The Kiss" fans or those looking for something to kick up the wardrobe a notch.

While I have never read anything by Richard Price, AKA Harry Brandt for this book, his reputation certainly precedes him and this latest novel, The Whites, has definitely made me a fan wanting to read more of his work. Although this police procedural could be a quick read for the story alone, I took my time enjoying his writing style, the essence of his characters, and his way of building a plot brick by captivating brick. It is one of the best books of this genre I have read in a long time.In the 90's, Billy Graves and a tight crew of young cops new to the Anti-Crime unit, self-christened themselves the Wild Geese. They were neighborhood regulars who tolerated the non-violents but gave hard chase, even over rooftops, to their "prey". Each earned their Gold Shield but over the years all the WG have since retired, except Billy. Some moved on to jobs vastly different from their rough riding days: one now the owner of a funeral home, another a superintendent for rundown apartment buildings, one even became a multimillionaire through hard work and good investments. Billy, however, due to the fallout of a tragic shooting, has remained on the dead end night shift.Through the years, each of the WG has born the burden of what they called a White: a heinous murderer that walked free. Each of the WG has kept in contact with the remaining loved ones, swearing that one day their White would be convicted. Then, one night Billy recognizes a murder victim as one the Whites. Not shedding tears, he notifies the WG. Then, another White shows up dead. While this should be cause for celebration, Billy starts to recognize a pattern. As well as telling Billy's story, there is also a second ongoing narrative concerning another detective who accidently bumps into what he would regard as his own personal White.While this story has many characters, both minor and major players, this story is Billy's. His wife has major mood swings, his young boys are busy, and amusing, little hellions, and his father with advanced dementia that waxes and wanes live with them. A dedicated cop and family man, he also considers all the members of the WG to be family as well.Other than the colorful dialogue and writing, the appeal of this story is that no character is written as black and white. Their merits as well as their flaws are laid bare. Billy's love for his wife, his pride in his father's accomplishments before his brain started to deteriorate, even his adoration for his boisterous kids are apparent, as well as his fierce loyalty to his WG. But what really impressed me was how the other detective was written; while angry and vengeful, that detective is also shown as a family man. The WG are wonderfully more than two-dimensional. The reader cares for the characters.It's a well-written police procedural with compelling characters and a brilliant narrative. Some readers state that the beginning is slow and they are correct. The writer is building his story on the backs of a cast of many. The criminals are even referred to as "actors" and "players" by the detectives.Highly highly recommended.

Note that this is my first chain saw and the ease with which I was able to set it up and use it speaks volumes. Unlike the gas-powered saws that are able to travel without a power source, this electric saw is perfect for garden and property maintenance. It's lightweight, ergonomically balanced, and has just enough safety features to protect the user without being over-controlling. It starts with the push of a lever and press of a button--no yanking a starter cord. When you release the on button, the blade stops instantly. And I liked the cord lock so that you do not lose power by accidentally detaching the saw from an extension cord. Very safe.We have used it for firewood and for dismantling the old Christmas tree. With the little tree, it was more likely to catch on the branches and kick back. It cut through the firewood like carving butter and with zero kick back.Pay attention to the tightening feature or the chain will come off mid-use like it did for me. That is user-error only but it's a good thing to bear in mind. The self-sharpening feature is very easy to use. The manual that comes with the saw has simple, easy to follow directions. It comes with a plastic blade cover.It's a perfect tool for property maintenance and the price is comparable to the quality of the tool. I was very impressed with what it did for my needs. Highly recommended.

Sturdy, well-designed and with a price tag that will not break your budget, this Retrospec bike pump is one of the better floor pumps on the market. Too large for travel, the Retrospec is perfect for home base. With the three adaptors it can be used for bike tires or basketballs or even water toys. The hose is longer than most floor pumps and makes it that much easier to use. The barrel and the handles are steel with a comfortable padding covering the handles. I really like the 160 psi gauge: it is set on the barrel facing up at the user and comes with a moving setting indicator for your desired pressure.There is a clip to hold the tubing up off the ground. And it is attractively designed.Highly recommended.

I cannot say enough about how practical and useful the LED lighbulbs are. They cost a pretty penny to buy, but over the next TWO DECADES you will have a bulb that not only lasts but is unbelievably cheap to use. Pennies, in fact. Our house is slowly replacing each regular Edison-bulb as it dies with an LED. It is a no-brainer. Go with the LED!

My son is a GoPro nut and so this Reach, GoPro-approved, is just perfect. It has a 14-40" extension that makes the pole a nice compact, backpack size when fully collapsed. It extends with three interlocking pieces that can be secured at any length along the pole. The camera mount at the distal end is screw-in for better security. The lanyard at the handle unscrews so the end can be connected to a tripod mount making for an even longer pole for filming from a greater height.The pole is quite sturdy but it also makes for a heavier pole which can be uncomfortable if used for long periods of time. The extension mechanism is not smooth and needs an oiling or waxing to fix that. Some GoPro-friendly poles have a clip on the handle for the remote you get with the newer cameras, this does not. Also, at $55 this pole might not be affordable for some GoPro users.My son loves it. It should survive the ski slopes and the long board hills. Highly recommended.

The Wolf Winter, by Swedish author Cecilia Ekback, opens in the year 1717 with two young girls, immigrants from Finland, discovering the body of a local villager. His carcass is torn apart as though attacked by wolves but their mother, Maija, recognizes the work of something more frightening than a wolf: a human. In their tiny mountain village, occupied by no more than a dozen families, the fact that one of them is capable of murder is a chilling discovery. As the townspeople are willing to blame the death on wolves, Maija is determined to discover the true nature of the man's death.For those who voraciously devour murder mysteries, this book is different from the crime novels that are solved by the end of the week. Wolf Winter begins in the early fall and does not resolve until spring.
