The intrusion of the church, the villagers' distrust of the indigenous Lapps, and a deadly, snowstorm plagued winter, obstruct Maija's commitment to find the murderer. Left on her own with her two young girls, Frederika and Doratea, Maija is forced to brave, and survive, as an outsider in this hostile environment. Her struggle was so absorbing it made this reader forget about the murder and focus on her day-to-day struggle against the frigid weather and alienation from fear-driven villagers.While beautifully written, Wolf Winter does have parts of the book that feel as if it's meandering. Most passages are short, some with seemingly inconsequential events like Maija darning socks or Frederika taking her little sister to school. As the winter intensifies, the book grows more mystical with religious, and arcane, symbolism. Frederika's part in the story expands as she begins to interact with the Lapp tribe that the villagers distrust. She also begins to discover more about herself as a young woman, an element of this story that some readers found to be inconsistent with her age. Taking into consideration the century in which this story takes place and how people lived shorter lives and consequently had to grow up faster, some of Frederika's actions make sense.Wolf Winter is a fascinating and beautifully written debut novel. The women are written as strong and independent survivors of their environment. And when the story finished, I found myself thinking about them for days. While initially annoyed at how slowly the story advanced, with the murder mystery seemingly part of the background, I recognized in the end that it was all a complex part of the big picture. There is more to this story than just the murder as it turns out humans are much more predatory and beastly than any wolf.

My husband runs a small recording studio, which, among other projects, often is requested to record full bands in a single room - for that "live" feel and sound.  According to him, anyone who has ever attempted such a recording knows full well how much the snare drum resonates when another instrument plays in its proximity.  This is often mitigated in an ad-hoc fashion, such as duct tape, jellies, or a cloth over the snare drum.  While these methods are moderately effective, they tend to alter the sound of the snare to a point that one must "fix it in the mix".  Along comes the Puresound Snare Wire.  While he is quite the traditionalist when it comes to new fangled gadgets, he tells me this one seemed quite promising.  The quick mount/release required a bit of attention to the instructions, which are fortunately made clear via written and photographic instructions on the packaging.  A few simple steps and it's on the drum.  The strands are slightly heavier than most snare wires, which gave him concern as to how it would resonate when the drum is struck.  The strands tensioned quite nicely, with room for simple adjustment per one's taste.  With a bit of experimenting, he was able to get a very clear, sharp report form the snare, which came through nicely in a top/bottom mic set up.  When tested with a loud guitar, bass guitar, and live vocals in the recording room, the strand proved most useful.  The usual resonant noise associated with a snare in the same room as those instruments was far less prevalent than with any snare wire he'd used before.  He didn't have to over tighten the wires, or ad jellies or tape to the head to eliminate "snare buzz".  The result was a snare that had ample punch while not disrupting the other instruments playing along live in the room.  This not only saved effort, it saved time.  He was able to dial in a great full band sound with a drum that, while present in the mix, did not interfere with the other frequencies in the room.  All in all, for a price that is commensurate with many quality snare wires, this is a great set of wires for live and recording settings.  The wires are sturdy, resonate properly, and allow for a great mix with less effort to the engineer.  Just for shivers and giggles (his words) he might get another set for a piccolo snare.  Give them a try - he thinks you'll like `em!

I had such high hopes for this movie.  I was probably more excited about the release of this movie than any other movie I can think of in recent years. I was almost counting down the days until its release.With that said, upon completion of the movie (which I almost walked out on), I was very disappointed, to say the least.  This movie just misfires on all cylinders. Carrey and Daniels overacted throughout the entire movie.  What made Dumb and Dumber great, was the subtleness and intelligence of their stupidity.  In this movie, it's just straight up stupid, slapstick, failed attempts at humor.I would give it 1.5 stars, but I have to give it 1 since amazon's rating system doesn't allow for half stars.  Awful movie, and terribly disappointing.

Scott Abel pulls no punches.  He tells you exactly what you need to do and what NOT to do, to be able to build muscle, if you happen to have poor genetics for muscle building.  This book was unlike anything I ever read before on the topic.  GREAT value at only a buck!  I would recommend this to ANYONE who has trouble building mass.

I like this coffee a lot.  The price is right, and it tastes pretty good and seems like good quality beans.  We had been using Dunkin Donuts and Folgers in our office, and the feedback from our agents has been extremely positive for this Don Pablo coffee.

These cables work great.  Haven't had a problem with any of the 3 pack yet. The only issue that I have, is that these cables are REALLY short. I mean, the shortest cable I've ever seen.  Unless you are charging your phone or iPod literally 6 inches away from you, don't bother with these.I can only use these on my laptop while I'm using it.  The cord is even too short to have in my car.Update: I removed 1 star, because 2 of the 3 cables have completely crapped out.  1 cable is still functional, after a few months.

I drank almost an entire box of this tea, and I'm just not feeling the calming properties of it.  I wanted something to help reduce stress, promote restful sleep, and to quiet my mind a little of anxiety arises. This doesn't seem like the tea for those things.  The tea tastes OK, sort of like chamomile, even though chamomile isn't in the tea.I guess I'm looking for something with a little more relaxation kick.  This doesn't pack it for me.

I've never drank coffee that made me feel worse.  I don't know what the deal with this stuff is. It makes me so dehydrated, that I feel like I have full blown diabetes or something.  I couldn't place it the first week or so I was drinking the coffee.  I thought it was a new grass fed protein powder I was using.  But I stopped using that, and my dehydration woes continued.  I need to drink like 3/4 of a gallon of water to offset the excessive thirst associated with this coffee.I haven't seen anyone else mention this, so I would hate to think that it's just me, but I am pretty aware of my body.  My dehydration is directly related to this coffee consumption.  It's so drastic, that I can't help but write a negative review.  The coffee tastes and smells good, but man, the thirst is unlike anything I have ever experienced.  No joke, I can drink 12 beers and not feel this dehydrated.

Coconut Water is expensive, probably because it costs so much to ship, due to the weight.  I really gave up on drinking it, because of the cost.  But, I came across this Coco Hydro in my local health food store.  I figured, what the hey, it's cheap enough, at about 75 cents per serving.I was pleasantly surprised.  The first time I ever drank it was when I was hungover. And it provided me with INSTANT relief.  It's very hydrating.  Which of course, is the main reason anyone wants to drink coconut water in the first place.The taste is OK.  It doesn't taste like fresh coconut water, but it tastes like some of ones you would find in a can or something.  The taste isn't super important to me.  It tastes good enough for me.  My main thing is the hydration and electrolytes, which this has.  I will definitely be buying this again.

I read the label in the store and Puroast sold me.  The increased antioxidants, 70% lower acid, organic, state of the art brewing process, etc.  I was sold!However, it wasn't until I got home and tasted the coffee, that I had a change of heart.  This coffee, while it may have 70% lower acid, tastes absolutely horrendous.  It might be the worst tasting coffee I've ever had, outside of a drip machine in an Econo Lodge.  It is almost undrinkable if you like your coffee black.  If you mask it with sugar and cream and flavorings, it STILL tastes bad!I have no idea how this company decided to go to market with a coffee product that tasted so terrible.On top of it, this coffee hurts my stomach WORSE than normal coffee!  So I don't know if I buy into the 70% less acid claim.  Regular coffee really doesn't bother my stomach at all, but I figured 70% less acid would be healthy for your gut, so I bought it.  Well, coffee finally upsets my stomach.  I feel like I am drinking PURE acid, not 70% less.This was a disastrous purchase, and I highly recommend everyone look elsewhere for a low acid coffee.

This bar is absolutely terrible in every way, shape and form.  The only benefit is the bar isn't that bad, chemical-wise.  Most high protein bars have chemicals in them, but this doesn't have TOO many, which is the only plus.The cons:1. One of the worst tasting bars I have ever eaten. It's so bad, that I ended up throwing out 9 that were left in my box of 12.2. Awful texture.  It's bone dry, rock hard, chewy and rubbery at the same time.3. It melts SO easily.  If your bar is in your pocket and it's more than 70 degrees out, it's going to begin to melt.  I haven't seen that many bars that melt this easily.4. They don't digest well.  They sit like a rock in my stomach.Avoid these awful bars.

This product has worked for me.  But I still get a Roach every 2-3 days.  I used to get one about every 2 days. So the time has been shaved off ever so slightly using this 6-pack, but my problem hasn't been fixed by any means.  It's definitely worked SOMEWHAT, but it's not a cure-all like some of the reviews on here would indicate.  I've been using them about a month, and have probably had to kill 8-10 roaches in that time.  It reduced my roach activity by maybe 25%.

I am a big fan of Gary Null and a big fan of his Green Stuff.  However, a few years ago, after the whole Vitamin D fiasco, he changed suppliers, and more than DOUBLED the price on this product.  It used to retail for $39.99, and often you would find it in the Vitamin Shoppe for $29.99 on sale every other month.For $30, it was a great value.  For $74.99, it's now the highest priced Green Powder product on the market.  Do your research - there isn't a single product on the market that's as expensive as this one is.  I can't fathom why Gary would do this.I'm sure he still gets sales off this product, but they have to only be a fraction of what his sales were with the previous Green Stuff.I don't buy it anymore, sadly.  I can't justify paying $74.99 for a bottle of this stuff, when I can get a competitors product for $40 or less.

I have read such a ridiculous number of sales and "self-help" books, it's staggering.  It has to be in the hundreds.  I have had minimal results at best from reading those 100+ books, in the area of financial abundance.  I have had a lot of results in other area.... relationships, spirituality, social, family, but money?  Minimal at best.I always loved Bob Proctor from The Secret.  He has such an authoritative, confident way of speaking. I decided to give this book a try.I have to say, this book is THE best book I ever read in regards to fulfilling the kind of life you desire.  Nothing else I have read even holds a candle to it.  I would say, "Think and Grow Rich", but that book is so old with so many outdated references, that I had trouble relating.  It had great stuff, don't get me wrong, but "You Were Born Rich" is better.  Bob Proctor has such a clear, concise way of describing the universal laws and the steps required to get what you want in life.Bob Proctor's "Bible" is "Think and Grow Rich".  He has read it every single day for 50 years.  I have a feeling this book is going to become my "Bible".

This honestly might be the best bottled Green Tea I've ever consumed.  I saw it for sale in a local retail store, and decided to give it a shot.  WOW.  It's not very gingery. It's more sweet, with vanilla and lemon undertones.  Sounds weird, I know.  I thought it would be too, but it's incredible.  The price online here for this case is outrageous.  Much better finding it and buying it locally.

There is no other way to say it -- these bars are absolutely disgusting.  They are sweeter than pure sugar, yet taste terrible.  They are so sweet that they hurt my teeth.  They digest terribly on top of it.  At least the bar has a nice label and design. But the bar itself?  The company needs to go back to the drawing board on this one.  Awful.

This is about on par with Zevia, in my opinion. It's OK at best. Has a weird aftertaste like every other stevia drink I've ever had. Let's face it, folks. Stevia isn't the answer. You can try to mask it 100 ways. It's still stevia. It tasted weird. I would rather see a xylitol based soda. At least that tastes pretty similar to sugar. This root beer is just OK for me.2.5 stars.

This may be one of the worst tasting natural bars I have ever consumed.  The ingredient list looked good, the label was nice, the company seems like they have a good mission, but wow, this bar is terrible.  There really isn't much else you can say about this bar.  It's sweeter than plain table sugar, first off.  I have no idea how they could possibly make something taste this sweet, but they did.  It's literally sweeter than straight sugar packets.  Secondly, because it's so sweet and sticky, it hurts my teeth.  Lastly, they don't digest well.  They sat like a rock in my stomach.  Not indicative of a healthy bar, when it's not easily digested.They need to go back to the drawing board on this one.

Jeffrey Gitomer is extremely cocky.  I feel like you'll either like him, or you'll hate him.  His writing style and his bragging throughout the book was a gigantic turnoff for me.  I couldn't stop thinking how much I wanted to punch him, the further along the book I read.With that said, the actual sales content of this book is lacking.  It's really more about mindset, organization, confidence, branding yourself, and such.  I have read far greater sales books.  Zig Ziglar, Brian Tracy, Tom Hopkins, Jim Rohn, and such, they're the ones you want to go to for actual sales content.  I have seen a few reviewers mention this, and I will as well, this is more like "How to train your mind for Sales Success" than an actual sales book.I wasn't a fan of this book.  I know it has a great rep and is a mega popular sales book, but it just didn't do it for me.  A book that I keep going back to time and time again is "Question Based Selling", and of course, anything by Brian Tracy or Tom Hopkins.

I actually like this book better than the updated version, Diet Recovery 2.  This book emphasizes cleaner eating. I tried the "eat anything you want" approach in Diet Recovery 2 and felt AWFUL.This book is about more salt, sugar and saturated fat, but eating whole foods and drinking less fluid (especially water).This book is just what the doctor ordered for me.  I firmly believe in the dangers of "8 glasses of water" per day, when someone has a low metabolism.  I have experienced it first hand. I drink a 16 ounce bottle of water, and within 60-90 seconds, I feel freezing cold.  It's been happening to me for 10 years, but I never put 2 and 2 together, because water is "healthy", right?Another thing I noticed, is that the higher my calorie intake was, the more "normal" I started to feel.  Instead of needing a winter coat when it was 55 degrees out. But, like I said before, eating wholesome nutritious foods the key for me.  Eating ice cream sandwiches, pretzels, McDonald's and all of the other junk that Matt Stone suggests in Diet Recovery 2 didn't work. However, eating whole foods worked like a charm.

I saw these at a local health food store and was excited.  I figured it was more of a matcha green tea in a sachet, since it didn't need heated water.  Opened the pouch and it was normal leaf tea.  Thought this was weird, but whatever.  I excitedly put a pouch in a 16 ounce water bottle.  Shook the living daylights out of it for a minute, as per the directions.  Nothing.  Looked and tasted like normal water.  I tried again, another minute.  Barely had any taste or color.  This process went on for almost five minutes.  The end result was a very tired forearm, and basically water, with a super slight hint of green tea flavor in it.I tried again a few days later, same result.  I used the rest of the sachets in hot water like a normal tea bag, since it doesn't work at all in cold or room temperature water.  Will certainly never buy again.  I'm left wondering if this whole thing was a joke.

As a lifelong Pearl Jam fan, I have to admit, "Backspacer" was my least favorite Pearl Jam album to date. I wasn't sure about "Lightning Bolt".  I kind of lost faith in them after that album, but of course, I bought this album the second it came out.Right from the first track, "Getaway", this album had my attention.  What a great song to kickstart the album.  One of Pearl Jam's best songs in years.  Then it goes right into "Mind Your Manners", which had some decent success on Alt Rock charts prior to the release.  "Father's Son" follows that, which is another very good song.  Interesting lyrics to that one.  And then following that, comes "Sirens", which may be Pearl Jam's best song in over a decade.  What a beautiful, introspective song that is.  I'm skipping ahead, but keeping in line with introspective songs, "Future Days", the last song on the CD, is also a beautiful song.  One of my favorite on the album.The album has a few lows.  I'm not a fan of the songs Lightning Bolt, Pendulum, Yellow Moon, and the recycled Sleeping By Myself (which I thought was a really lame move by PJ, re-recording an Eddie Vedder Solo Album song).All in all, it's a solid album, and I'm very happy with the effort.  Eddie's lyrics are as brilliant as ever, and the band is still going incredibly strong in their late 40's.

Green Tea is my favorite drink, but I'm not a snob about it.  I like the majority of Green Tea I drink.  I do have my favorites, but I appreciate nearly all bagged Green Tea.  This one didn't make the cut.The tea bags are weird.  They seem really cheap quality.  Maybe that's why I bought this box of 100 for $6.  Also, the tea itself, no matter how long you steep it, barely has any taste.  It's one of the weaker Green Teas you'll ever drink.  I've steeped this tea for an hour, and all it did was turn bitter.  It still hardly had any of the traditional Green Tea taste.I did actually make it through the box of 100, because like I said, I love Green Tea, but I won't be buying this one again.  Sorry to the fine folks over at Prince of Peace.

There are a LOT of wheatgrass powders on the market. Most of them use whole wheatgrass, which means there is useless fiber in the drink, that's gritty and won't dissolve.  Not this brand.  This is wheatgrass JUICE powder.  Big difference.  It's basically wheatgrass shots with the water removed.This is a pure product.  The only ingredient is organic wheatgrass juice.  The taste is pretty bad.  I'm not going to lie.  If you're sensitive to strong tastes, you may not be able to drink this just mixed with water.  Even mixed with juice, it's far from delicious.  You even taste it strongly in a fruit smoothie. It basically ruins the smoothie. Bottom line, wheatgrass isn't tasty any way you spin it, lol.Getting back to the purity of the product, for straight wheatgrass powders, this one of the best I've seen.  Great product, if you can choke it down.  I'm pretty good with bad tasting things, but this is even too much for me.  I can't drink this stuff, unfortunately.  That's not to say it's a bad product.  I just can't do it. I have a 90% full container that's just sitting here going to waste.

I actually asked around, to see if this was a B-Sides album, after I listened to it for the first time.  It's the weakest material to date Jay-Z has ever released.  I was hoping for way more, given the fact that the hype surrounding this album was off the charts.I honestly think Jay-Z is being stretched in way too many directions right now, with the new baby, the whole Brooklyn Nets thing, the Sports Agent.  It seems like his creativity was shot on this album.  There honestly isn't ONE memorable song on the entire album.  Not one.  One could potentially argue "Holy Grail" is a memorable song, and if that's you, I won't argue with you.  To me, it's a Justin Timberlake song featuring Jay-Z.  It's basically Justin's song.  Jay-Z does a guest rap on the song real quick, and Justin sings the rest of the time.I see there are a lot of fake, planted reviews on here, as there usually is.  Be wary of the 5-star reviews that are 1-sentence long, and it's the only review they've ever written.  Those are phony, planted reviews to bring up the overall score.  This album is a 1-2 star album, tops.  Jay-Z's worst, by far.

I'll start this review off with a disclaimer: it doesn't taste good.  Some people I know can't even tolerate it.  If you're really sensitive to tastes, I would advise against buying this product.  If you need your protein powders to taste like candy, you're in the wrong category here.This cacao version of Raw Meal is a HUGE upgrade in taste from the original flavor, which is what I imagine sewer water would taste like.  The cacao version at least mostly drowns out the sewer water taste.  It just tastes like bland, odd tasting dark chocolate, for the most part.  The product DOES have stevia in it to sweeten, but you wouldn't even know it, by the total lack of sweetness.  I actually prefer a non-sweet drink, so I'm glad about that.  Although I still think it could use a LITTLE more stevia.Now, onto the nutrition.  You absolutely will not find a more nutritious meal replacement/protein powder on the market. I've looked -- there isn't one out there.  Vega Sport is loaded with synthetic vitamins and insoluble fiber, which will tear apart a sensitive digestive tract.  This Raw Meal has 16g of fiber, 13g of which is soluble fiber, so it's lowering cholesterol and binding bile acids, in addition to providing you with 34g of protein per meal.  Not only that, it also contains almost 100% of RDA for many vitamins and minerals, and they are their raw, whole food form, which is incredible!  The product is also loaded with nutrients that are associated with sprouting, such as SOD (super oxide dismutase), CoQ10, glutathione, etc.  This product is an absolute powerhouse.  Better than anything else I've found, and very affordable as well.  Less than $2.50 per meal for a serving of this.I highly recommend this product -- but again, only to those who don't care about how something tastes.  If you are a big taste person or have sensitive taste buds, this might not be for you.  I have seen a few people struggle with the taste, so much so that they had to throw it out or give it away.  There are tricks you can do, such as adding your own stevia, fruit, or juice to it.  But I'm telling you, it STILL tastes weird.  I don't care though, because I can drink straight Kale juice without much problem.  And that's about as gross as you can get.

This album is awful.  There's really no other way to say it.  I don't even know where to begin with this review.  It's like Justin is trying way too hard to be different and be unique with this album, rather than putting out well rounded music, suitable to his style.We've seen this before.  An artist or band that has a ton of success under the belts try to deviate far away from what made them successful in the first place.  And I understand why artists do it.  As a creative human being, you try to reach new heights.  You try to re-invent yourself.  You try to add another dimension to your craft.  But 9 times out of 10, it doesn't work.  And quite often, it's a disaster.  I wouldn't necessarily call this album a disaster, per se.  But, it's just flat out terrible.We all know Justin Timerlake can act; and he can sell the hell out of the characters he plays, but he can't sell me on this experimental music.  The music sounds forced, jumbled, and half the time, it doesn't even sound like he knew where he was going with the particular song or rhythm.  It's just a complete mess.  There are a few moments of positive vibes on the record, but the highs are few and far between the many, many lows.  TKO is far and away the best song on the album.Just a quick FYI, on sites like this, when you see a 1 sentence, 5-star review on a music album, a good portion of the time, it's the record company writing a phony review to artificially boost the ratings.  This is fact.  Don't pay attention to the ton of 5-star reviews this album got.  Just read through them.  Many of them are 1 sentence long, and it's the only review that person ever wrote. Prototypical fake review, that was placed by the record company. When you read the 3, 2, 1 star reviews, you see intelligent, well written reviews, that generally echo the thoughts that most have on the album.  That's not to say ALL of the 5-star reviews are fake, but many of them are.  Check it out of yourself.  Knowledge is power!Sorry to those who might disagree with my take on the album, but this my 20/20 Experience was a complete bust.

I have seen some people scoff at the price of this product. It's basically a little over $1 per serving. When you go into a convenience store and want a bottle of water, often you pay $1 to $1.25 for a 16 ounce bottle.  This stuff is basically the price of store bought water, so any complaints about the price are ridiculous.This is a great alternative to Gatorade.  My only issue with this product is it doesn't contain much sodium, which is an essential component of any sports drink, due to the fact that we lose so much salt during exercise.What I do, is put about 1/8 to 1/4 of a tsp of pink sea salt into 16 ounces of water, pour in the Rebound FX, and now it becomes a fully balanced electrolyte drink, with the full spectrum of 60 minerals, as well as some vitamins, EGCG, and other nutrients. With how big of a fan Dr. Wallach is about salt, I wonder why he doesn't put basically any salt in this sports drink.That's my only issue with it.  It's still a great product, and I use it often.

On the back of the box, these looked pretty similar to Quest Bars.  I was hesitant to buy it, but I decided, what the heck, and did.  They're better than Quest bars.  They're much, much more subtle tasting, and I like the consistency better as well.  These Life Lift bars are the perfect amount of sweetness, and taste fairly natural.I question the fat content of these bars, however.  The label claim is 8g of fat, but the bars are extremely oily.  It could just be the oil from the almond butter separating from the bar.  But they're THE greasiest/oiliest bar I've ever eaten, hands down.The bars just don't digest very well for me, so I'll have to pass on getting anymore of these.  I still haven't found a protein bar that I'm happy with.

Juice Plus is normal fruit and vegetable juice concentrate powder put into capsules.  If you're a reasonably intelligent person, you can buy fruit and vegetable juice powder in bulk, from various manufacturers for literally 1/10th the cost.  These bottles of Juice Plus cost no more than $5 to manufacture, if I had to guess.  The bottling and labeling is probably more costly than the product in the capsules.The outlandish, ridiculous claims this company makes is mind boggling. I don't know how they haven't been shut down for fraud.  Clever "loophole" wording, and high priced lawyers are probably how this company continues to stay open, and peddles this overpriced garbage.I'm not saying these capsules provide NO nutritional benefit, but to get any substantial benefit from them, you'd have to take 10-20 capsules a day, which would not be very cost effective.  When you buy a standard fruit/vegetable juice powder concentrate, you routinely take 1 TBSP (15 grams) of the powder.  These capsules are 750mg, so therefore, you would need to take 20 to get what I would call a nutritionally substantial dosage.I have taken this product and noticed zero benefit, because there's little to no benefit to be found in the miniscule dosages these capsules provide.  If you're taking this stuff and you're having the placebo effect, great.  Keep taking it. Placebo is just as powerful as anything.  But for someone who's not easily fooled, spend your money elsewhere.Gram for gram, this might be the most expensive nutritional supplement ever created, when you factor in the dosage needed to have significant effects on someone's nutritional profile.Again, I'm not saying this is a BAD quality supplement.  It's just misleading, insanely expensive, and putting the powder in capsules instead of offering a powder is a convenient way to rip you off even further.

Beyond Tangy Tangerine's label claim says 1g sugar, 7g carbohydrates.  The 6g of carbs must be from maltodextrin, which is in essence, a sugar as well, because it's off the charts on the glycemic index.  When I take a serving of BTT, I get a sugar reaction, as if I just mowed down 5 chips a'hoy cookies.  It's really uncanny.  So, I honestly question the label claims.  Maybe it's the maltodextrin that's causing a reaction, I'm not sure.  But this product gives me bloat, like I said, worse than if I ate a gigantic pastry.What I do know, is that while I'm sure this product has benefits, if you can digest it properly, for me, it causes awful digestive reactions.  I have been taking Dr. Wallach's Ultimate Classic, which is basically the liquid form of this product for years with NO negative reactions... and that has 7.5g of sugar per serving!  Also, I take Youngevity's "Rebound FX" product, which too has 7g of sugar per serving, and I digest that just fine.  Something's funny with this product.If I had to guess, it's the maltodextrin giving me a reaction.  But, needless to say, I can't tolerate it.  I will go back to Youngevity's Ultimate Classic, Colloidal Minerals, and I'll stay with Rebound FX.  Beyond Tangy Tangerine is NOT for me.  This was an extremely expensive failed experiment.  I still have a container that's half full, that will unfortunately be going in the trash, or passed onto someone else.

This business card holder is pretty much exactly what I was looking for.  It's cheap, serves its purpose, and looks nice.  My only issue with it, is that it's extremely hard to open.  I have had to really push hard to open it a few times, and my cards inside almost came flying out from the force.  Maybe I'll end up getting used to it after awhile, but that's my only con to owning this.  Otherwise, it's excellent.
I can't believe this thing is as cheap as it is.  Paid $2.48 and it looks great on my desk.  Looks to be very good quality for the price.  Very pleased with the purchase.

I was shocked at how much brighter these bulbs are than the standard soft white bulb.  I have 2 bulbs in my overhead lamp.  The difference between the normal bulbs and these in terms of brightness, was like 7PM sun compared to 12 noon sun.  Literally twice as bright, or so it seems.  It's great on a rainy day or something, but at nighttime, it's a little much.  Little bit too bright for my taste when I want to go to bed soon, because the super bright light is telling my body it's still daytime.I still like the bulbs, regardless.  Time will tell if I end up getting used to them, but right now, I think it's a cool change of pace from the yellowish, dulling bulbs that I'm used to.

I've had about 3 or 4 different water dispensers in my life, and this one is right up there with any of the rest of them.  It's way better than the older model Avanti I used to have, and much better than the cheesy one Poland Spring rented to me.  I love the storage space at the bottom for Coffees and Teas.  Didn't have that on my last two water coolers.For the money, this is a great cooler.  I can't see spending 2-3x as much on a water cooler as I see some of them priced at on here.  This will do everything you want a water cooler to do.  Heat your water, cool your water, store your teas/coffees, and it looks nice in the process. 5 stars!

I've been suffering from low body temperature and low pulse for 15+ years now.  I'm usually around 96.5 to 97.0 body temp, and 50-56 pulse. Both are too low.  Thyroid issues are clearly to blame.I came across the idea of using Thyroid Glandulars, and this one seemed like a good fit.  I started off taking 1 capsule a day.  Within a week, my body temperatures were a steady 97.9.  A HUGE increase.  It stayed level for another week or two, so I decided to bump it up to 2 capsules per day.  My body temp jumped even more, to 98.1.  For the first time in a LONG time, I had "near normal" body temperatures.  My pulse also went from 55 to about 64, which is a lot more normal.Finally, I bumped it up to 3 capsules per day, which is what I needed to get me to the wonderful 98.6 number.  That did it, 1 capsule, 3x per day.  Keep in mind, I haven't seen 98.6 temperatures in my body since I was a teenager (I'm mid 30's now). This is very interesting and exciting to see and feel such differences in my body.  It's so weird to me sitting in a 68 degree air conditioned room and not feeling like I'm going to freeze to death.From all of the research I have done on human health, we should be at 98.6-99.0 body temperature, and 75-85 pulse.  When I first began this supplement, I was 96.9 temp, 55 pulse.  After a month on the product, I am 98.6 temp, 68 pulse.**Update: I stopped taking the product for about a month, after I was 98.1-98.6 for awhile.  I figured I was cured, so stopped taking it altogether.  Not so fast.  Within a month, my average daily temperature dropped to 97.1, and I started feeling cold all the time again.  Just an FYI, if you do use this product, you should probably stay on it for awhile.  17 years of thyroid issues don't cure themselves in a month, lol.**

I have been hearing hype about this product for over 2 years. Mike Adams from Natural News did a video on it, lots of other health advocates have been singing its praises as well. I finally decided to take the plunge, to see what the heck this stuff was about. I have used every other brown rice protein product on the market, and they've all been chalky, and gross. I expected this to be different though, based on the hype. Well, I was wrong.This product is chalky and gritty, just like every other brown rice protein product out there. It's SLIGHTLY less gritty than others, but it's still gritty, and gross. The ONLY way to make this palatable is to add a buttload of fruit, stevia, xylitol, honey, or some other masking agent to it. On its own? Forget about it. Not going to happen, unless your taste buds have been burned off.Ok, so the taste is bad, how about results? It doesn't even feel like I'm consuming protein. When I drink whey protein, my muscles soak it up. I feel stronger. I feel like I want to lift things. With this protein, I feel like I drank a pure fruit smoothie or something. I don't feel strong. I don't feel like lifting. My muscles don't feel full. I get no traditional protein benefits from this formula, so I HIGHLY question the digestibility of this so-called wonder protein.The only plant-based protein I've ever used that works was PlantFusion. It's a combo of plant proteins, that form complete proteins, but I stopped using it because they add Fructose as a sweetener. It's the only plant based protein I've ever used, that made me feel strong, like I was actually ingesting protein. With this Sunwarrior protein, I might as well be eating actual brown rice, because I'm not getting much, if any, usable protein with this formula. And for as bad as the taste is? Forget it. Not worth it.

This is a knock-off product, folks.  It's not being sold or made by the actual Alkalife company.  I believe it's a Korean or Japanese "clone" product.  With that said, the product works!  I used this stuff for 5 years without even knowing I was using a counterfeit product.  I've been singing the praises for Alkalife ever since, so it obviously works great.  I bought a 24 pack of these knock-off Alkalife bottles 6 years ago, and I still have like 2 left.  They still work great, to this day.If you feel leery about getting a knock off product, understandable.  But chemicals are chemicals.  You can actually go to any chemical lab and buy potassium-sodium hydroxide by the gallon for dirt cheap.  Each one of these little bottles would end up costing you pennies if you did it that way.So, I give this product 3-stars, only because it's not ethical what they're doing, but it's still a good product in the end.

I have never been a huge Fall Out Boy fan.  Been more of a casual fan.  I've liked a number of their singles, but never liked any of their albums as a whole.  The albums were just never strong enough for me to hold my attention and interest in the band very much.With the sad state of rock music these days, I was left listening to virtually nothing on my iPad, so I decided to give this new album a shot.  I figured the long hiatus would either be great for the band, or the album would be an absolute clunker.  I'm happy to say for the sake of the band, and for my own listening pleasure, the album is very good.  In my opinion, the best Fall Out Boy album to date, from top to bottom.In semi-unrelated news, I almost didn't recognize Patrick Stump when I saw a clip of the band performing live.  Guy lost like half of his bodyweight!  Crazy!  In closing, this album is a must-buy for any Fall Out Boy fan, casual or serious.

For years, I was fed the lie that "Extra Virgin Coconut Oil" is the only coconut oil we should be using.  I used it, but hated it.  It always made me nauseous, and I absolutely hated the taste.  Never been a fan of coconuts in my life, never will be.  Every day with it was a struggle, and yet, it made me feel sick!I started reading the work of Ray Peat, and realized that a good majority of the population has an allergy to coconuts, and coconut oil.  When the coconut oil is refined or expeller pressed, the allegen (protein) is removed, and not only can people start enjoying a coconut-free taste, but you will also start seeing the benefits of the oil.  Gone are the days of coconut oil making me nauseous, and feeling crappy.  Now it makes me feel oxygenated, healthy, warm, and balanced. Kudos to Ray Peat for turning me onto Expeller Pressed Coconut Oil!Great stuff.

Hans De Jong is an amazing teacher/lecturer/speaker.  His work, of course, is based on The Silva Method, which was founded by Jose Silva, but I've listened to several teachers on the Silva Method, including Jose Silva himself (when he was alive), and Hans is far and away the best.This audio program was one of the first self-help courses I ever listened to, and 10 years later, it's STILL probably the best.  It's not pie-in-the-sky stuff.  It's no nonsense, factual information, on how to improve your life, and get rid of limiting, negative false beliefs.  I don't like pie-in-the-sky, fairy tale kind of stuff, that gets you all motivated, but then you end up falling short, because you're lost on the "how to". Hans tells you exactly what you need to do, to be successful.Going to "Alpha", which is another way of saying using Binaural Beat Meditation, is extremely helpful in helping you center yourself, for your goal setting, and visualization.  It's always best to set your goals and visualize them in this kind of state.  When you're doing it in other brainwave states, it's just dreaming, but doing it in Alpha, you're uncovering ways to bring about the change you need, in order to reach your goals.I love Hans De Jong's accent as well.  Very pleasant speaking voice.  I can't say enough good things about this.

I loved Dragon Warrior I.  Absolutely loved it.  Dragon Warrior II was a great advancement on the original game, although I felt it was ridiculous at times, with the difficulty level.Dragon Warrior III is almost the perfect RPG game.  It's EXTREMELY long, very complex, yet simplistic at the same time, due to the limitations of 8-bit graphics (which I actually enjoy... I don't like Graphics heavy storylines).  The addition of things like character classes mix things up nicely.  Even things like turning a Wizard into a Sage is a very cool feature.  Takes your wimpy, weak Wizard character and can eventually turn him into a pretty strong character.I honestly wish they never stopped making Dragon Warrior games for NES.  I would and could play them for the rest of my life!  Best games ever.

It's the Coen brothers by way of Alfred Hitchcock. Fargo meets North by Northwest. It's easily one of the best, if not thee best, pilots ever created. The cinematography is literally second to none. I can't remember any show being this well shot. The plot is intriguing. The dialogue is snappy. And it is so funny. The comedy in this sort of creeps up on you and takes you by surprise. I wouldn't recommend drinking milk while watching PATRIOT, as you'll end up spitting most of it out through your nose as the show sends you into hysterics. This one has the potential to become one of the most memorable TV series ever made. Pay attention throughout; the show will reward you for doing so with its various comedic callbacks.

Very choppy sound and video on the Fire Stick and on PC. I've researched this and find the Fire Stick is not to blame, nor is my connection. What is to blame is the HBO Now service itself. HBO, in all its infinite wisdom, doesn't allow the video to buffer more than a few seconds and when the buffer refills you get the stutter. They do this to avoid piracy, but somehow Prime Video, Netflix and YouTube stream without a hitch. HBO's paranoia over losing a penny has created a basically unusable app that they charge fifteen dollars a month to try and use (and will, ironically, drive more people to find other ways to watch HBO video). Speaking of the fifteen dollars -- why am I paying this much for an app that has ADVERTISING before the show you want to watch? It's already annoying on Prime when they do it and they don't always do it -- HBO Now is more expensive and shows advertisements every single time. It's really a shame it's not watchable, as the content is very good.

RETURN OF THE JEDI Review:The worst of the original 3 films (but I'd put money on it being much better than "The Force Awakens"). Yes, there is an awesome puppet creation in Jabba the Hutt, but it also has teddy-bears destroying the Empire. It's ridiculous. Han Solo acts like he's been brain-damaged by the carbonite and turned into an old-timey comedian. Luke isn't as much of a Jedi as he is Luke who we're told is a Jedi. The "sister" angle is wedged in and embarrassing. The premise of being told you HAVE to DESTROY Vader and yet being told you'll turn to the Dark Side if you strike him down is pure insanity. Another Death Star with basically the same exact weakness is silly and shameful. C3PO being this great storyteller after claiming he's not very good at telling stories in A New Hope is lazy or ignorant of a movie that was released half a decade earlier. This movie was George just wanting to get his "9 part" saga over in 3 sections. Complaining aside, it does have an AMAZING space battle and a pretty groovy speeder bike chase through Endor. Also, it puts a proper end to the saga. I don't care if Mickey Mouse has decided the saga isn't truly over ... it is -- the fan fiction from J.J. doesn't count.The Movie Itself: 7 out of 10RETURN OF THE JEDI Picture Quality:The picture quality of Return of the Jedi on Blu is second only to Revenge of the Sith. There's less DNR than in any of the other 5 and it really does look like it did on the big screen. If not for the large amount of uncleaned grain during the Tatooine scenes, I'd say it looked better than it did theatrically.Picture Quality: 10 out of 10RETURN OF THE JEDI Sound Quality:Like every Star Wars' blu, excluding Sith, the sound is as good as modern technology gets.Sound Quality: 10 out of 10RETURN OF THE JEDI 2011 changes:Jabba's palace has a bigger door made of CG.Han thawing from carbonite is slightly different (through CG).A Dug is added to one scene, but takes away from nothing.Ewoks have blinking CG eyes.R2D2's attack is now over-the-top CG.Darth Vader says "No" and then says, "Noooo." Contrary to rumor, he never screams "NOOOOOOOOOOOOO" like he did in Revenge of the Sith.All the TERRIBLE changes from the "Special Edition" are also, unfortunately, included. Disney slaps an old disc into a new cover and doesn't bother to include the ORIGINAL film? Shameful, and why I can only give this a 3 out of 5.

EMPIRE STRIKES BACK Review:As a fan of film and a fan of "event" films, I believe Empire Strikes Back to be the BEST event film ever made (along with Raiders of the Lost Ark). It is absolutely perfect, from beginning to end and, frankly, my favorite movie of all time. 'Nuff said.The Movie Itself: 10 out of 10EMPIRE STRIKES BACK Picture Quality:Best it's ever looked. Yes, there's some grain in the scenes on Hoth, but at least the scenes on Hoth are WHITE again -- instead of blue! Not quite reference quality, but VERY close.Picture Quality: 9 out of 10EMPIRE STRIKES BACK Sound Quality:Let me just repeat what I said for the other Blus and double it: Incredible. Amazing. Ear-shatteringly awesome! Wait 'til Han flies you into the asteroid field!Sound Quality: 10 out of 10EMPIRE STRIKES BACK 2011 Changes:Can't see the puppeteer's hand on the Wampa anymore.The whole scene in Cloud City with Chewie retrieving 3PO has been color corrected and sparks have been added.All the "Special Editions" are included as well. Disney's being lazy not releasing BOTH versions of this film, which is why I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5.

A NEW HOPE Review:What can be said that hasn't been said already? A New Hope introduced us to this crazy universe. It was like nothing we had ever seen. It was Flash Gordon for a new generation. It was pure amazement. It redefined the word "entertainment" and, because of that, lines of geeks and non-geeks surrounded every theater playing the film. Aside from the dated 70s looking computers (which is a change I wish George Lucas or Disney WOULD make) and a few clunky lines from the actors (mainly Mark Hammill), the movie is pure perfection.The Movie Itself: 10 out of 10A NEW HOPE Picture Quality:There's quite a bit of DNR toward the beginning -- especially on Princess Leia's face, but it lessens throughout. There's also some terrible dirt during the Tatooine scenes and a few blurry looking shots. That said, the film looks GOOD. Almost too good. Better than I thought I'd ever see a movie this dated appear.Picture Quality: 9 out of 10A NEW HOPE Sound Quality:Picks up right where Attack of the Clones' Blu left off (Sith was a rare audio misfire). The sound is so tremendous, you'll have trouble believing this movie was released in 1977. It sounds better than 99.9999999999% of movies released today!Sound Quality: 10 out of 10A NEW HOPE 2011 Changes (kept for the 2015 release):R2 hides behinds some CG rocks that look pretty real.Luke's lightsaber is color corrected during his training.All the "Special Edition" changes are also included. Disney is being lazy not including the non Special-Edition version, which is why I'm giving this 4 stars, instead of 5.

REVENGE OF THE SITH Review:Revenge of the Sith is a bleak film. If you're a diehard fan, it comes close to being traumatic (but not in a bad way, like Jar Jar). Lucas didn't sell this one short. Not at all. Sure, it should have been at least 3 hours and expanded further on Anakin's change to the Dark Side. That said -- the Emperor thought he could change Luke in a matter of seconds in Return of the Jedi. So at least it makes a bit more of an effort. The opening space battle is incredible. The banter from the original trilogy is back and nearly lives up to to the sequels. This is a very good movie. It still suffers from some of the inane "romantic" dialogue between Anakin and his lover, but Star Wars' fans have learned to deal with some cheesiness. Honestly -- no SW film, like no pizza (at least no good pizza), is without cheese -- not even Empire.The Movie Itself: 10 out of 10REVENGE OF THE SITH Picture Quality:Unlike the first 2 DNR destroyed prequels, Revenge of the Sith looks GREAT! As a matter of fact, it's the best looking of all 6 films. The opening space battle is right up there with Avatar and Planet Earth as the best looking thing you'll ever see on blu-ray. This movie is, visually, reference quality. If you're proud of your set up and don't own this film, you no longer have a reason to be proud.Picture Quality: 10 out of 10REVENGE OF THE SITH Sound Quality:I guess -- if you're a Star Wars' fan -- you can't have it all. This mix is muddled and doesn't sound nearly as good as the other 5. Still -- they set a very high standard and RoTS definitely impressive.Sound Quality: 8 out of 10

ATTACK OF THE CLONES Review:Attack of the Clones has always been -- prior to this blu-ray release -- my least favorite of the 6 movies in the saga. This release won me over. The movie is the best paced of the prequel trilogy. The downfall is the HIDEOUS "romantic" dialogue between Anakin and Padme. What a load of garbage. It's still as laughable and as intolerable as it was at the midnight screening over a decade ago. Fortunately, the rest of the movie holds up very well. This is the best directing Lucas has done since A New Hope (aside from his poor direction of actors). It moves at a brisk pace and keeps the viewer involved from start to finish (if you don't count the "romantic" scenes that bring the film to a screeching halt every so often).The Movie Itself: 7 out of 10ATTACK OF THE CLONES Picture Quality:Sadly, the movie suffers from the same DNR as Phantom Menace does on Blu. As it was shot digitally, it isn't as glaring, but there are a few moments of waxy-face that are nearly intolerable. On the other hand, the CG in the movie has never looked better. The end battle (which is essentially one big cartoon) has some breathtaking moments.Picture Quality: 7 out of 10ATTACK OF THE CLONES Sound Quality:Incredible. Amazing. Ear-shatteringly awesome! Every bit as great as Phantom Menace. If TPM and AoTC lived up to their soundtracks, they'd be the best movies ever!Sound Quality: 10 out of 10ATTACK OF THE CLONES 2011 Changes (still changed on the 2015 Blu):Anakin hears junk (such as his mother) while he's dreaming -- indicating it's a terrifying dream, instead of a wet one.

PHANTOM MENACE Review:The Phantom Menace has went from a beloved Star Wars' film in most fanboy eyes ("Not as good as A New Hope and Empire, but better than Return of the Jedi" was the common refrain) to the most hated of the prequels. The movie definitely isn't all that it could be. It isn't even close. But it has the best lightsaber battle of the trilogy, an awesome opening sequence, and WAY less Jar Jar than you remember (it's just that he's so SHRILL whenever he appears). It's also the only Star Wars' prequel that FEELS like Star Wars. It has plenty of real sets and is structured much like the original 3.The Movie Itself: 7 out of 10PHANTOM MENACE Picture Quality:The picture quality of The Phantom Menace is the worst of the bunch on Blu. It's filled with TONS of annoying Digital Noise Reduction (DNR) leading to a LOT of clayface. And even with that, the digital FX are still much sharper than the filmed shots of actors (this was the last Star Wars' film to actually be shot on film -- at least until Episode VII), which leads to the actors oftentimes looking out-of-focus or "blurred" when compared to their annoying digital counterparts.Picture Quality: 6 out of 10 (still WAY better than the DVD)PHANTOM MENACE Sound Quality:The sound in the film is INCREDIBLE. It is some of the best surround sound ever produced on blu-ray. It genuinely sounds better than the the theatrical version. The Pod Race is, in my opinion, the best sounding segment of film ever put on a blu-ray disc.Sound Quality: 10 out of 10PHANTOM MENACE 2011 changes (which remain changed in the 2015 release):The horrible cross-eyed, stoned looking Yoda puppet has been changed to CG.The HORRIBLE FX when Obi and Qui run away from the droid destroyers down the hall where you could see THROUGH them (Obi and Qui) is removed.

This is the best CASUAL game ever, if you understand physics. I have, without dropping a dime, managed to own every single vehicle (there is a ton and you do need to own many of them to finish the game), with maximum upgrades (you do need to maximize your upgrades to finish, as well). Of course I won't admit how many hours it took me to accomplish this, but I will say it all happened while waiting. Waiting rooms. Waiting for coffee to be served. Waiting for food to be delivered. Waiting for my break to end. Yes, if you were by yourself and waiting for nothing, this game would be next to impossible without a credit card. But if you live a life, you're going to be waiting. Sadly, waiting is a large part of a life lived. If you're a "waiter" (possibly waiting for a waiter), this is the best game to wait with -- and the more you understand physics, the easier this one will be (even though it will still be tough). This is a great little game. I'd recommend it for nearly everyone. At least everyone who is stuck in wait.

Pitch Black is an awesome "B" sci-fi movie. So is RIDDICK. The problem is The Chronicles of Riddick, which is a PG-13, watered-down, sellout. And it doesn't fit the character of Riddick, at all. Especially after the incredible, jaw-dropping game with Riddick titled, "Escape from Butcher Bay" (seriously, even if you HATE gaming, play this game -- it's hands down the best installment of this series). So this "trilogy" isn't quite so much as a trilogy as it is two really good, violent, no-holds-barred "B" sci-fi flicks surrounding this weird sort of wanna-be Shakespearean thing rated PG-13 and coming off as more of a parody of the first than an actual movie. It's all relatively entertaining and, if you're a fan of the character, I'd recommend buying the trilogy, but what is up with that second entry? It does drag the entire saga down. I suspect Vin Diesel was getting too big for his britches (steroids?) and we'll all be best to ignore the second installment. Even Vin agrees. Let's just pray for an R-rated fourth entry, to finish the series. Or not. Whatever. Are you afraid of the dark?

Frankenweenie obviously pays brilliant homage to the Universal horror classics, but also to newer horror flicks such as Gremlins and Godzilla. It is fun from beginning to end. The 3D is great, the picture quality -- both 2D and 3D -- is incredible. The movie is not to be missed. A true instant classic and Tim Burton's best in a long, long time.

Wow! What an incredible transfer! I expect nothing but the best from Criterion and they rarely let me down, but this time they outdid even themselves. I cannot imagine this movie looking crisper when it was first released some 70 years ago. It also has a great set of extras, including the full sequel to the movie (which is a fun little film, for what it is, despite being Hitchcock-less).And the movie? It's still the same great Hitchcock classic you know and love. Widely considered his best film from his film-making days in Europe, Lady Vanishes combines a creepy aura of suspense, dread, conspiracy and paranoia with some clever and impeccably timed comedy. Hitch always added humor to even his most horrific films, but I don't think he ever quite achieved the "peanut butter in my chocolate" levels of humor and horror that he did in Lady Vanishes (The Trouble With Harry, despite being an inferior film, most likely comes closest).This is a fun movie given a second life thanks to a stunning video restoration and audio clean up that removes all noticeable hiss, snaps, crackles and pops (at least the ones that weren't meant to be there in the first place). Placing The Lady Vanishes on your shelf will do your collection proud -- if only there weren't so many great extras that all but guarantee it will spend as much time in your blu-ray player as it does in your blu-ray collection.NOTE: I just looked through my Criterion blus and the only other transfer that has impressed as much belongs to A Night to Remember. Review for that one to come.

Exceeding expectations that weren't really there isn't that hard a task, but this is a very fun game. The premise is simple (as are most games created for tablets) -- take the cube and roll it around Q-Bert like platforms, picking up all the mini-cubes and get to your destination under a certain time to receive the perfect rating. Now that I think about it, it's a lot like Q-Bert, only without the monsters or the funny "@!" thought bubbles. It's a good game and PERFECT for short commutes, trips to the toilet, lunch breaks or any other time you need a quick way to kill time.

The price on these Pistachios keeps rising and is inflated beyond belief. A bag of these should cost no more than $10. That said, the nut itself is divine. I haven't had many pistachios better than this. They're a little softer than pistachios usually are and have a fresh taste that really makes them stand out. The only time I've had a problem with them was with my last order, when I got an old bag that had obviously sat in the heat and basically covered the bag in "pistachio butter." I haven't ordered since, but if I see these in a store, or if they can guarantee freshness in the future, I will definitely pick some more up (I went through dozens of bags of these things, prior to the "pistachio butter" incident).

I have played a lot of games lately, as my birthday and Christmas both occur in December. There has been some great games (Darksiders 2, Far Cry 3, The Walking Dead), some good games (Jak & Daxter Collection, Borderlands 2), some bad games (Ratchet & Clank: Full Frontal Assault, Epic Mickey 2) and then there's been Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. The ugliest, most rancid game I've played in all of 2012. Possibly this entire 7-year video game generation. Possibly, the worst game ever made. I'm not kidding.Let's get the "good" stuff in the game out of the way: The graphics are good and the voice acting is decent. That is all.Now for the bad:The control set up is literally the worst ever implemented in a major game. Why must you press the L2 button and the thumbstick to dodge? Why must you press "down" on the control stick and then a button to drop off a ledge instead of either down OR a button? Why are so many different actions assigned to the exact same buttons? The game ripped everything else off from God of War, why not its excellent control scheme?Cut scenes. I'm actually a fan of cut scenes in games, but I'm an even bigger fan of pacing. This game constantly interrupts battles with 30 second cut scenes to look at a tree or to zoom in on a swamp. It's ridiculous. And it makes the game impossible to enjoy. I don't mind QTEs, usually, but why can't a button prompt just pop on the screen? Why must it literally tell the gamer, every time, to "Press R2 to do such and such an action"? Just show us the R2 button -- we can figure the rest out. And don't get me started on the horrible "circle within a circle and then press any old random button when the circles align" QTE in all boss fights and many other battles.Settings: A huge, huge part of the game takes place in what looks like the forest of Pandora from Avatar. It's as far from "Castlevania" as you can get. It's ugly level design. And it's not Castlevania (which makes sense, as this wasn't made as a Castlevania game; the title was just applied to sell copies of a game that would have otherwise went unnoticed).Level Design: Wow, what idiots designed these levels? I don't even know where to start, so I won't. This is, honestly, the worst level design I've seen since The Force Unleashed (the Star Wars' take on God of War), and it's quite a bit worse than that.Camera Angle: Again, the game ripped everything else off from God of War, why not its excellent camera? Lords of Shadow (I refuse to call this a "Castlevania" game, because it isn't) has a camera that's usually too far above the character, but sometimes comes in too close. You will lose sight of the baddies you're fighting in nearly every battle. It's not because I "suck" as a gamer, it's because the team behind this game suck as developers.Repetitive Gameplay: Someone could look at an Uncharted or a God of War and think the gameplay is repetitive, but this takes it to a whole 'nother level. While those two superior games -- both of which this one stole from -- change things up and keep things entertaining. They have significantly different ways to fight many varied bad guys and bosses. Castlevania? Jump up in the air to avoid "ground pound" shockwaves, stop for 25 seconds for a meaningless cut scene, press left trigger and thumbstick (again, why???) at the same time to dodge, stop for 25 seconds for a meaningless cut scene, press left trigger again to block (although many times you will accidentally dodge, as the same button is used for both), stop for 25 seconds for a meaningless cut scene, hit R2 when the white circle meets the white circle (good luck if the background matches the color of the circles you need to look at), stop for 25 seconds for a meaningless cut scene, do the circle thing again, press a random button, stop for 25 seconds for a meaningless cut scene and the fight is finally over. This is it. That is all. It is the gameplay from beginning to end and it is unbearably awful.I don't usually actively hate any game. I actually (and actively) hated Lords of Shadow. I felt insulted as a gamer just by playing it. I feel Konami insulted all Castlevania fans by putting the name "Castlevania" on this game that wasn't even designed to be a Castlevania title. I feel critics insulted themselves by "overlooking" the game's flaws for some extra swag or an exclusive interview. I hate everything about this game. I hate this game so much, it has made me temporarily hate gaming. Please, if you haven't already, do yourself a favor and avoid this title at all costs.
