After 3 years, I'm still sitting at 73 stars in total in the first game (I've gotten 20 more in the 2nd SMG ... in a single week). There wasn't a level, or boss, in SMG2 that was difficult to the point of frustration. The levels are very short and even the toughest won't last most gamers longer than 15 minutes (usually not more than 7 or 8).The most disappointing thing about the difficulty level is the ease of beating the bosses. Only 2 bosses in the game even killed Mario as I played. Not a single boss brought me to a game over. I beat the final boss without even getting hit. If only one thing changes for the next Mario, I hope it's the difficulty level of the bosses. Rosalina (IE - The "Cosmic Guide") offering more casual gamers a play-through affords Nintendo the chance to make bosses the like of which we haven't seen in at least half a decade. The kind of bosses that make you want to throw your controller through the TV set out of sheer aggravation.Outside of the bosses being too easy, does Super Mario Galaxy equal the first? It's even better! It loses the originality that the original had (obviously), but the level design is even more stunning. As mentioned above, levels are much shorter than those found in the other 3-D Mario games. Because of this, Super Mario Galaxy 2 is the first 3-D Mario to 100% successfully translate the pulse-pounding gameplay of the 2-D games of yesteryear into the 3-D visual style gamers crave today. The other 3-D Mario games were great -- but Galaxy 2 keeps the frantic energy level up from beginning to end in a way that I haven't seen since Super Mario World.Other advantages to Super Mario Galaxy 2 over the original Super Mario Galaxy (or any other 3-D platformer out today) are the return of Yoshi, a map that's the easiest to navigate since Super Mario World, slightly improved graphics, the ability to trade off and play as Luigi every few levels on the first play-through and some great new power-ups. For a game that I incorrectly thought was going to be nothing more than an expansion pack, these improvements were a welcome surprise.Despite the improvements, one downside from the first hangs around for the second. If you didn't like the controls in the original, they'll still annoy you in the sequel. I wish they'd allow you to play with your choice of motion-control, a GameCube or a classic controller like Smash Bros or Mario Kart. The precision of a gamepad is missed. I died from the spin control not registering at all or fast enough more often than I did from anything else in the game. These are cheap deaths that would be easily avoided with a gamepad.Even with the motion-control (or in spite of it), Mario Galaxy 2 is an excellent game. In the 18 hours it took me to collect 92 stars, never once did I get bored. There's always something new and exciting to see. The power-ups are scattered throughout and just when you tire of one, another is offered. The level design really does boggle the mind. You have to play it to understand how epic it truly is.Super Mario Galaxy 2 is the very essence of gaming. It, like all the best Mario games, is timeless. The game will be as fun 15 years from now as it is today. Super Mario Galaxy 2, just like Super Mario Bros., Super Mario Bros. 3 and Super Mario World will be considered a classic when 2010's Call of Halo or Gears of Madden feels like an antique. And maybe in 15 years it will be available to play on a Virtual Console with a gamepad. Woo-hoo!

Josh Ritter is one of my favorite songwriters. I consider the one-two punch of The Animal Years and The Historical Conquests of Josh Ritter to be a highpoint in music history. Only The Beatles released two albums as close together with two styles as different that still somehow worked so completely as companion pieces.So Runs the World Away is a victim of its superb predecessors as well as a victim of the duration between albums. While it took less than a year for The Historical Conquests of Josh Ritter to follow The Animal Years, it took nearly 3 years for So Runs the World Away to follow The Historical Conquests.The time spent recording and writing the album has removed much of the spontaneity that was found in The Historical Conquests. Instead of 14 songs in 43 minutes we get 12 songs (plus a raucous, but brief, instrumental introduction) in 54 minutes. The songs suffer under the burden of their own length. Where The Historical Conquests was flighty and moved quickly from one song to the next without the listener knowing what to expect, So Runs the World Away moves slowly from one lumbering ballad to another, with only a couple songs having variety enough to break the tedium.This isn't a bad record, but it isn't a great one either. As a fan of Josh, I didn't want to review it until I heard it at least 10 times. Having now heard it over 20, there's still only a few songs that have broken through and that I've found myself humming throughout the day. This opposed to over half the songs on The Animal Years and literally all the songs on The Historical Conquests by the same amount of listens.Josh has concertedly moved away from the country, folksy twang that was found in his first 5 records, both instrumentally and vocally (lyrically, the album is a winner). With the exception of one song, So Runs the World Away is a straight up pop record, with a few dashes of folk (one song is derivative of Leonard Cohen, another of Bob Dylan). Most of this album sounds like Violent Femmes meets Bruce Springsteen, coming down from a coffee high. One tune, which is way out of left field, sounds like a b-side to an unreleased Tom Waits/Morphine hybrid single.It feels as though Josh wanted to remind people he was a "serious" artist by making sure nothing on the album was fun. That nothing crackled. That nothing felt alive. The album is perfect for play in Starbucks and for that reason I suspect it will outsell his past efforts. But it isn't close to the same level as his prior releases, especially the last two.The production value of So Runs the World Away has been upped even further from past releases and the songs have been layered with even more instruments to make sure you're still awake and still remembering what a serious artist he is, but he doesn't have you smiling this time. He doesn't have you clapping. And he doesn't have you singing his songs throughout the day, nearly unable to wait 'til you get back to a place where you can put them on and dance to them once again.Josh is known for dramatically changing his style from album to album, which is refreshing and, honestly, at this point, a relief. I do not want to hear another So Runs the World Away. I couldn't say the same for his last four efforts. Josh Ritter could do various spins on The Historical Conquests for the next 10 albums and I'd be more than satisfied. But we expect more from Josh and I am glad he did something new, despite being disappointed with how it turned out. I hope for the next album he uses The Historical Conquests as a launching pad into the next great musical experiment, rather than So Runs the World Away.In the meantime, there's enough on this album to make it worth listening to for the next year. Just don't make us wait as long for its follow-up, Josh. Maybe the world ran away with you over the last 3 years, but did your energy and ability to write a fun, catchy tune have to run away with it? I already have my tickets to see you in July when you play Orchestra Hall. Hopefully by that time you'll have a couple of new songs to debut from your next release. Songs that make the audience want to get up, dance in the aisles and celebrate all that is life. Because, truthfully, that is what you do best.

While Deadly Premonition is strictly a budget title as far as gameplay and graphics, the game excels when it comes to story, humor, characters and uniqueness. No one has ever played a game quite like this, unless they've played this game.Deadly Premonition took me 8 days to finish, which says something as the game took 21 hours to beat. I kept coming back to the title when I knew I should be doing something more productive.Deadly Premonition became a temporary obsession. When I was at work and couldn't play, I was thinking about detective work in the game. When I was out with friends, I was wondering what the characters in the game would do or say next. When I was in bed, thinking about the game literally kept me awake, wondering how long I could keep Agent York awake with the in-game coffee and food I had acquired.2 nights out of the 8 it took me to complete the main story, I stayed up all night and went to work the next day dead tired due to Deadly Premonition. Was it worth it? Surprisingly, yes. It actually has an ending that, in the context of the game, works. No, you won't confuse this for an AAA title. But if you don't have some of the most fun you've ever had playing a game, you may be confused.

I have been a "Constant Reader" of Stephen King since picking up Cujo at far too young an age 20 some years ago and reading it from front to back in a couple of days. While I've never disliked a Stephen King novel, I have been disappointed by a number of them -- especially recently. Under the Dome brings King back to his glory days. This is the Stephen King who wrote the books I fell in love with as a 10-year-old boy -- so young I had to hide his books from my mom, who wouldn't allow me to read him.Stephen King hasn't written a book this good since IT. As a matter of fact, IT and THE STAND are probably the only 2 Stephen King books I still like more than I do Under the Dome. Yes, it really is THAT good. A huge cast of characters, a compelling plot and monsters that take shape in the form of politicians and their easily manipulated public. Sure, he's hinted at this stuff before, but in Under the Dome, he really lays it all out on the table.The story also addresses the threat faced by climate change and the damage that can be done should we choose to go on ignoring the reality of global warming. But why stop there? King manages to get some commentary in on torture, prejudice, U.S. military, police brutality, religious extremism (and religion as an excuse) and general corruption.But never does the book overwhelm with its message. Never does it feel like you're being preached at. This is, more than anything else, a fast and entertaining read from start to finish. A roller-coaster ride from beginning to end and, despite its length, one of the quickest reads going because you won't be able to put it down.Under the Dome is filled with murder, suspense, mystery and all those other fun things that keep you awake at night. And nobody this side of Edgar Allen Poe is as good as Stephen King is in bringing this stuff to life and embedding it into your nightmares. This is vintage King. Under the Dome is the best book of the year and one of the more enjoyable books of the decade.

The first 20 - 30 minutes of Madworld are thrilling just for the novelty of it all, but then you realize nothing really changes, the boss battles are a bunch of context-sensitive events and the whole thing is over in about 4 hours. To be honest, they didn't even get the violence right. It's not clever enough to be funny, and too comical to be serious. I beat the game a day after buying it and sold it the day after that.So why a 3 out of 5 overall rating? Despite the obnoxious announcers who oftentimes repeat the same sentence 3 or more times in a row, the horrid soundmix and disappointing-for-a-rental gameplay length, there's something that Madworld has that many Wii games don't: Potential. At least the developers tried to make something a little different and they get an "E" for "Effort".The art direction is taken from Sin City and, for the most part, works. With a lot of fine tuning and initiative Madworld 2 could potentially turn into a good game. But as things are, the original Madworld is nothing more than a curiosity. An "M" rated game for the Wii. Although it isn't made for kids, it is, in many ways, more childish than whatever party game preceded it. Having looked forward to this game for a while now, I was very disappointed in its eventual gameplay.Here's hoping The Conduit finally gets it right. And gives us a great game that we can't complete in one sitting.

It won't play even BRAND NEW mint condition CDs (they just skip). And, to my horror, when you take the CDs out there are big circular scratches around them. I lost two good CDs thanks to this piece of garbage. This "CD Clock Radio" is the worst purchase I have ever made. AVOID!

The Global Class War by Jeff Faux pulls no punches and takes no sides -- other than siding against NAFTA and the WTO. It's about the inner-workings of NAFTA and the WTO, filled with in-depth info. on how they came to be, who fought for them, who fought against them and ultimately how Bill Clinton got them passed with the same Dem House and Senate that had voted against NAFTA under Republican Presidents Reagan and Bush. It's an absolutely incredible book and the first and only book that I've read from front-to-back 3 times in less than 2 years. This one was missed by a lot of people -- most likely because it places blame on both Republican (Reagan, Bush and W. Bush) and Democratic heroes (primarily Clinton and Gore), thereby making it hard to find an audience of anyone in the partisan battle of political books. The last book that should be overlooked by anybody has somehow went unnoticed by nearly everybody, which is very sad and unfortunate. It's an amazing piece of work that was, quite amazingly, almost entirely missed and, if you're reading this now, add it to your cart. Don't let this one pass you by.

Lisey's Story isn't as great as some are saying and isn't as bad as others are claiming.  It's a good book.  Not an excellent book.  Not a horrible book.  It really is nothing more than what it's advertised as -- a love story with dark undercurrents.  Being that it's Stephen King behind the typewriter, those dark undercurrents are nearly black.  Horrific, even.It's hard to judge the book (as so many have) from the first 200 pages.  It takes its time to get to the "action" and lets you get to know the characters before it lets you know exactly what's wrong with the characters and why they behave the way that they do.  I welcome this, as it makes what happens in the second half of the book more disturbing and suspenseful.Lisey's Story is equal parts Dolores Claiborne, Gerald's Game and Rose Madder.  It could also be seen as Misery in reverse.  This time the author has the horrific history and his wife has to push her way through it.  But unlike Paul Sheldon, Lisey Landon does so voluntarily because she is in love with her husband -- blood bools and all.More than anything, this is the tale of a couple not that far from Stephen and Tabitha King.  It's about the way a married man and woman will develop a language of their own (and we all do it); a sort of "clubhouse" language, that those outside of the "clubhouse" won't readily understand.  King does try to remind us throughout the story what words and acronyms such as SOWISA mean, but it does occasionally grate when he overuses them, as if to emphasize a theme that's been overemphasized to the point of being dull.Even though it can be pretty slow-going throughout the first half, you'll be rewarded if you stick with it through to the end.  King's note to his Constant Readers (I've purchased every King book within a week of its release since Cujo came out in 1981) is actually a pleasant read, as opposed to the note at the end of The Dark Tower (Book 7) where he almost seemed to be lecturing his fans.In the 25 years I've been reading King's work, he's certainly had his ups and downs (as have we all), but Lisey's Story is one that King fans will want to pick up or ask for as a gift.  It feels like a much more complete novel than King's last effort, Cell.  You can sense that King lived in the world with these characters and that he cared about them.  No, it isn't perfect, but it provides memorable moments of love, terror and character.  And that's enough to make it worth reading through the imperfections.

This should have been MUCH shorter. I got irritated at the lengthy detail of her childhood, adolescence and young adulthood.It's a story of search for ancestry, identity, parentage, and belonging. Those themes are why I began reading.A black Guatemalan girl is raised from infancy by an autocratic white upper-class German...under a shroud of mystery surrounding the circumstances of her birth and 'adoption by the 60-ish yo German 'mother.'The story was good and kept me reading.But the writing was wooden most of the times, self-aggrandizing at other times, and bombastic the rest of the time.Only wanting to know how it ended kept me reading.Mostly, I wish the author had gotten to the last third of the book much more quickly.

Crazy (really) awesome book.Not great literature (but it never pretends to be), but great insight, great laughter, great scenes, unbelievable mental images as we follow the twisted logic of the author's mind.Best of all, great understanding of herself, her impact on others, and how one's attitude toward life's vicissitudes can make all the difference.Jenny Lawson has NO FILTERS when she writes (or at least they aren't visible). If it pops into her head, she writes it down and sends it out to the world.Elevates taxidermy into the stratosphere.Definitely buy this book.Just don't try to read it next to a sleeping partner; you'll wake him or her up with your laughter.Also, her blog is terrific: www.thebloggess.com

About 1/4 into this book, I thought I probably wouldn't finish it.I had several bjections:1) what initially felt like far too much name-brand mention (Prada, etc) of shoes, makeup, purses, perfumes.2) I'm not a 'dog person,' so for my liking, there was too much DOG in this book3) The author, a Brit, lives in rural France but socializes almost exclusively w the expat community.I kept reading for several reasons:1) There are stretches of really good writing in the book2) I ended up objecting to the dog, Biff, far less than I had expected3) The name brand name-dropping faded just enough about halfway through that I stopped grinding my teeth4) A few native French people began to play more of a role5) Eventually I got drawn into the love storyBut I think what really kept me reading was the frequent and very well-done insertion of French phrases in the book. I speak a teeny, teeny, teeny bit of French...but now I speak more! I can even say 'It doesn't matter' in French. Wheeler tosses these sentences into the English prose in such a way that, even without her occasional interpretation in parentheses, a reader can infer meaning. Toute Allure is a little like a French phrase book buried in a fluffy romance buried in a travel story.Pas mal, pas mal! (Not bad!)

Crazy-assed manic hyper hilarious rant-filled run-on wise witty wonderful memoir (sort of) by a woman with no verbal filters (and very few other filters, actually) who has written a memoir (Let's Pretend This Never Happened) plus a blog about mental illness. Her own.It's not a book to read in bed beside a partner who is trying to sleep:Your silent laughter will shake that person awake.Your LOL laughter will surely awaken him.If he manages to sleep through that, you'll just have to wake him thoroughly up so you can read some tidbit aloud to him.Poor guy. He had a lot to put up with while I was reading Furiously Happy.I am sort of relieved Jenny Lawson doesn't live next door to me, but I do wish we could meet for coffee about once a week...although she'd probably do better with a cup of soothing herbal tea instead of the coffee.Highly recommended for oh-so-many-reasons.

What an amazing book!Elegiac, heartbreaking, redemptive...and that's just the story. The prose is worthy of all the same praise.Although is was written by a man who died in 2001 in his 70s and concerns the period toward the end of the Second World War, the story feels timeless.It's a coming of age book about the senior year (and the summer before) of a group of boys at a New Hampshire prep school, thinly disguised as Exeter.Two boys who are roommate, Phineas and Gene, excel in different ways, compliment each other in all ways...and their friendship sort of accidentally on purpose ends in tragedy.I whizzed through this book in 2 days, finding myself driven by the beauty of the writing, the inevitability of the denouement, and the story itself.Iconic. Not to be missed.

Superb memoir of a black kid growing up in apartheid, hate-infected, punishingly-severe persecution and deprivation of So. Africa. His chances of achieving anything at all were surely minus zero chance.Through the force of his illiterate mother's determination that he go to school (perhaps she saw potential in where, where others just saw another kaffir), his discovery that he loved learning, and probably most importantly that he learned to play tennis well and loved it, he earned a series of scholarships to American universities. Mathabane went on to marry, father 3 children, become a best-selling author and lecturer.The book dragged for me at the beginning and began to feel repetitious as perhaps 150-200 pages we spent detailing the horrors of growing up in Alexandra, where 100,000 impoverished people lived in 1 sq mile with no sewage system, electricity, transportation, joblessness, laws that kept the huge black population downtrodden and sequestered.Okay, I got it. I got the message early on.For me, the book really picked up momentum as he reached high school and formed his impossible dream of getting out of So. Africa and into America.He achieved more than his mother could ever have imagined. Bravo.

A sweet book.I probably shouldn't have gone into it with the expectation of 'more,' however. It starts out sweetly, it continues sweetly, and it end sweetly.Sort of monochrome; very little passion or conflict or revelation.Mennonites‚Äã are modest, eschewing pride or boastful behavior. She certainly isn't boastful, and although she admits to pride now and then, it is always is an apology.Blush was an interesting memoir of a very mild, safe, sweet childhood...and a fairly good account of the conflicts she experienced (conflicts of a very, IMO, mundane nature) spiritually and personally.But at the end, I felt I'd read a book written in a monotone. I wanted 'more.'

Slow.Unlikable characters.Southern Gothic? I don't think so. There was none of the tragic darkness and inevitability of the good Southern Gothics.Set in the south at the dawn of the Atomic Age, Godwin seems to be trying to juxtapose the murky past with the modern era as Helen, a precocious and self-absorbed mostly brat subtly battles it out w pretty simple-minded, inept Flora, her cousin who has been asked to 'tend her' for the summer while her father is presumably gone to work on " the bomb."Mostly, this book irritated and bored me...which is a shame as I've enjoyed many of Godwin's other books.

I was expecting 'fluff' when I began reading this book, but sometimes fluff is just what one needs as a break from heavy, long, difficult, political books...or one of the ponderous great classics. I like to balance myself w a paper book and a Kindle, each having different levels of intensity and painful subject matter. So this was to be my 'fluff' book.It wasn't at all! Okay, it's not Dr. Zhivago or Tolstoy or whatever, but there's real meat to it.Coburn balances three topics with grace, insight, grief, love, and compassion: travel memoir, grief, and fear of dying young.The book is definitely more than a travel story. She fears she will die young, as did her father, and the loss of him (too young; smoking; lung cancer) is something she is still working to resolve, both the loss and her own fear. So she sets off to make several trips to Europe with her young daughter (between ages 8-16), "to make memories," one gathers in preparation for what she expects to be her own premature deaths. Along the way, vivid memories of visits with her much loved and very colorful (if unreliable) father match the setting or tone of her travels at the moment.Caveat: she paints her husband as a patient saint, and she and her daughter never, I mean never, have conflict. This is too good to believe.But, wow, I enjoyed this book about 10x more than I expected to.

When the Crocodile Eats the Sun, by native-born Zimbabwean Peter Godwin who has lived on several continents and has an international perspective, is very good. It just goes on a bit too long, becomes repetitive, and feels too journalistic in several places. It traces the simultaneous aging and death of Godwin's father in Zimbabwe (where the family has lived for 2-3 generations) alongside the country's rape by Robert Mugabe.Zimbabwe used to be the breadbasket of Africa, and now the Zimbabwean currency is so valueless that it would take several wheelbarrows of paper money to buy a cup of coffee; the now use the US dollar for currency. Unemployment hovers around 85%Life expectancy: 34-37 years (primarily due to the AIDS pandemic)Yet, oddly, the literacy rate is one of the highest in Africa.Fascinating book.
Useful, mostly accurate. I'm glad we had it with us as we meandered up the coast from the Bar Area to Washington State.

Mildly interesting story.Poor punctuation throughout, with commas used in situations (I'm talking 2-4/page) in situations where a PERIOD is mandatory.Okay, I'm a picky punctuation person, but when the errors are so egregious and frequent that it makes my reading a chore, I'm not a happy camper.Example: I opened the book at random and found this..."At school we had all moved up a year again, we only had one more year left before we were all to be let loose on the world. I wasn't thinking about that yet though, at the moment I couldn't see past the next Saturday and what I could buy in town with my pocket money."That is two consecutive run-on sentences, back to back.I swear there is at least one similar example per page.Because of the myriad errors, I stumbled throughout the book.This author badly needs to hire an editor, IMO.

Really enjoyed this book.5 star-worthy for travel diaries, memoirs.More than you'll ever need to know about dealing with toileting issues while on the trails up Kibo.I'm going to Africa next month, so much of this information I took straight to heart, such as don't buy the convrtible zippered shorts/pants, because "they are SO yesterday."Now I can cross that one off my list.

Fascinating story on many levels.The biography of an "unusual" family of diverse characters, at the core of which is Henrietta Lacks.The history of HeLa super cells that have, indeed, seemed to have achieved immortality, continuing to grow in lab research cultures all over the world.There is much detailed histological and medical language, but it's presented in a way that a reader with neither knowledge nor interest in the subject will still be able to read the book with pleasure, skimming over areas that are "too technical" or delving into them deeply, just for the pleasure of learning.It's also the tale of incredible patience, tolerance, and persistence by the author to earn the trust of this quixotic, mostly uneducated, superstitious extended family who, for at least 2 generations, feel they have not been well-served by the doctors and researchers at Johns Hopkins.Very important and imminently readable book.

A little more information about the history, mystery, farming, harvesting, growing, range of, names of, etc. information about oysters than I was really expecting.There are amusing and sometimes hilarious brief stories interwoven, along w myths, obvious lies, and folk tales...I just wish there had been MORE of THOSE and quite a bit LESS of the pedantic stuff.But you know, even the pedantic stuff was quite readable, often amusing, frequently presented w tongue-firmly-in-cheek, such as this gem:"Incidentally Pliny, more an egghead than a nature-lover, had an interesting view of oyster procreation. Following Aristotle, he says it comes about through spontaneous combustion in the mud."Right.Way to go, Pliny!

Quirky Big Sur draws me into its isolated California charm, and Nepenthe, with its unique history, is pretty much the center of the Big Sur World.This book is a paean of love written by a woman who was fortunate enough to spend her childhood in residence at Nepenthe, when her grandmother owned and ran the place.There are some good recipes scattered throughout, as well as quite a bit of family history, but mostly, it's just a lovely homage to a Different World from the one we live in today.Relax, and enjoy the ride!

Honestly, this book knocked my socks off.Set in mostly in Montana, it follows a rumpled,  seriously flawed, often drunk, empathetic social worker who, in spite of his own "issues," takes his job more than seriously, esp when he encounters a barefoot kid WAY back in the mountains who is the product of a strung-out, completely nutso survivalist, a Bible-literalist guy w a submissive/evangelical wife and a passel of malnourished children.And then there is his runaway daughter, a girl he tracks throughout 2 states in his "spare" time.It's a big book in every way: it's long, it's deep, and it's wide.The ending is not happily-ever-after...but it's good enough to satisfy, and it's definitely believable.

Should be required reading, esp for those over about age 50.If all doctors had Gawande's breadth of knowledge, intellect, wisdom, and understanding, we would have better health care in the USA, and the world would be a better place.

Lovedlovedloved it!To classify it as Young Adult or Coming-of-Age is to do this book an injustice.It's funny, beautiful, heartbreaking.While the end is inevitable, at no point did I want to stop reading.The movie is pretty good, too.

This book captivated me from the first page.It has something for people of all ages: teenager angst, adult responsibility (and irresponsibility), and elder's wisdom.Beautiful writing, mystery, romance, and it moves many years thru time and location (NYC, CA, Europe).This, I think, is Donna Tartt's best book. I haven't even much liked a couple of her others and was, therefore, at first reluctant to take on this tome. But I did, and I'm glad of it!

As a member of the Internet Writing Workshop, I've read and critiqued several of these essays previously...and am awfully glad they are now available as a collection to the greater world.Gary is gifted. He has a way with words that is admirable, a view of humanity that is all-encompassing, a wit that gentles his honest words, a willingness to share the nitty-gritty of having "butt-surfed" his way thru the world in a wheelchair for the past 50 yrs, and the enviable ability to link seemingly disparate themes into a piece of writing that can take your breath away.Worth a lot more than $0.99, that's all I can say.Peggy VincentAuthor: Baby Cather: Chronicles of a Modern Midwife

Fascinating memoir by (yes, he wrote it himself) an autistic savant who also has synesthesia, that condition in which letters, words, and numbers have colors or textures or arouse emotions, like #6 is dark and scary, where Wednesday is blue but Thursday is fuzzy.The author is fascinated with pi, the squares of numbers, and prime numbers. He once memorized pi to 23,000 digits after the decimel point, establishing a record (duh). He calms himself by counting things. Many of us visit a beach for the calming aspect of it, but he finds it distracting because he spends all his time trying to count the grains of sand.The really cool thing is that he lacks most of the areas of social ineptitude that others on the far end of the autistic spectrum usually display, and he is able to maintain a loving relationship and function independently in the world.The writing is a little flat, lacking in emotion, but... he IS autistic, so all things considered, it's pretty amazing.

In the 1950s, the East End of London, an area packed with slums and tenements, was rife with poor sanitation, prostitution, disease, overcrowding, crime, abuse of women and children, alcoholism... All of these, and more, were commonplace for those who were born and died there.Perhaps worst of all was the nearly total lack of health care. Within this dismal district was a convent of nuns whose mission was nursing, midwifery, and the training of lay women in these healing arts. Into this world teeming with potential disaster comes the twenty-two year old Jennifer Worth, fresh from a failed love affair and determined to become a midwife.The nuns, as individual in personality as they are similar in their religious habits, are memorable, especially Sister Monica Jean, a slightly dotty mischief-mnaker and dessert thief whose slyness indicates she might not always be as loopy as she appears. There is a hint of calculation in her madcap actions.Of the birthing women, perhaps most enchanting is the story of beautiful Conchita, who gives birth to her 23rd and 24th babies during the course of the story and who has a long and loving marriage with a much older, hard-working Cockney jack-of-all-trades. The improbable success of the marriage is explained when Ms. Worth learns that neither Conchita nor her husband has learned to speak the other's language.For me, a home-birth midwife from California who practiced nearly half a century later, the most fascinating parts of The Midwife were those that highlighted the differences in our respective domains. While I often felt as though I was roughing it as I drove my noisy VW Bug to births, Ms. Worth on her heavy bicycle traveling ten miles through London's infamous pea soup fog at 3 AM put me to shame.I carried half a car-full of equipment; she made do with a kit that easily fit into the rear basket of her bike.One of the most educational stories revolved around a women giving birth to a baby coming the wrong way round, not headfirst but a breech. A senior nun's explanation to the young Jennifer of what she is doing and why, and the second by second description of the birth is priceless information from a bygone time.In spite of the word "memoir" appearing in the subtitle, I would not classify this book as memoir. It is disappointing that Ms. Worth chose not to revealmuch about herself, so we are unable to watch her evolution. We are left in the dark about the world from which she came. We don't know if she was city or country-bred. The details of her disappointing affair of the heart are unexplained. Was he a married man? And what about her vocation, her calling to the art of midwifery? No reasons are given, so we are denied sharing the sense of fulfillment she must surely have felt as her training drew to a close. Overall, there is little sense of her maturing into her new role, little indication of her changing - until the last line, a statement close to a revelation of faith, which came out of nowhere. It struck me as odd to have the book end with a red herring, a closing comment with no antecedent and no follow-up.While The Midwife falls more into the realm of a valuable historical or anthropological document, eminently readable, and full of unforgettable characters and their stories, ultimately I was left with the desire to know the deeper personal story lying so tantalizingly below the surface.Overall, The Midwife is an enchanting, educational, and revelatory story of the practice of midwifery in a time that seems much further in the past than just sixty years ago. Highly recommended, especially to those interested in midwifery, women's studies, and maternal and child health.

Oh boy! Another winner from Algonquin Press. Tomato Girl keeps readers turning pages till way too late into the night. From the outset, you just know all of eleven-year-old Ellie's hard work to heal her mother, reform her father, and banish the tempting teen-aged Tomato Girl, are unrealistic and doomed. It's all too much for the eleven-year-old child, the only person in her family who seems to have her head on straight, to manage on her own - and fears of the obvious consequences prevent her from seeking outside help. Against insane odds, Ellie valiantly struggles onward, carrying mesmerized readers along with her.Writing an entire novel in the voice of a child is difficult, but for the most part first-time author Jayne Pupek manages to maintain the tone, awareness, and vocabulary of a pubescent child of the South in a manner that is consistent and authentic.Kudos to both Pupek and her publisher for bringing Tomato Girl to fruition.

Babies know a lot more about being babies that adults, doctors, grandmothers, how-to specialists, psychologists, and talk show hosts do. I was blessed with a first child that was born to nurse and taught me everything I needed to know about breastfeeding. He was single-mindedly determined to nurse for 20 out of every 24 hours. Everyone thought I was crazy, but it was the only thing that truly kept him happy. He nursed while I slept, nursed while I went grocery shopping, nursed while I brushed my teeth, nursed while I ate dinner - and didn't mind when I dropped spaghetti on his bald head. If he was nursing, he was content, and so was I.Lu Hanessian's book is a thought-provoking confirmation and affirmation for those of us who bucked lots of resistance in various areas of child-rearing, taking our cues from our babies, trying what seemed to make sense, and sticking with what worked, no matter what flack it caused among those peripheral to the immediate family. Babies don't manipulate their parents; they don't even know the word for such a concept. But babies know what they need. It's too bad they have to waste so much energy trying to convince some of us to just slow down and listen to them.

A rip-snorting historical novel full of intrigue, religion, unsolved murder, passion, evil priests, power plays, injustice, lust, violence... There's even a dwarf.Finn is a medieval illuminator with a teenage daughter who shares lodgings with a widow with twin sons. The widow and the artist begin an affair, and the daughter and one son begin a...well, something! The widow Lady Kathryn soon finds herself caught between different but equally powerful loyalties to her lover and her sons.A terrific read with lots of great characters, dazzling writing, and more than everyday illumination into medieval life.

It's a measure of the success of this book that it was even published: short story collections, even inner-linked ones such as these, are a hard sell to editors and publishing houses. But books on the immigrant experience in America are popular nowadays, and Bodies in Motion is a welcome addition to the bookshelves. For the most part, however, the themes are not new. Characters protest against arranged marriage, women yearn for more freedom and education, husbands want old-fashioned and docile mates, American culture seduces with insincerity, etc.A good book with some exquisite writing, but Mohanraj might do well to have spent a little longer trying to dig deeper, past the familiar and already been there, done that.

I don't like Tom Cruise. I don't like him, his Scientology `religion,' his strutting style of acting, or the horse he rode in on. BUT. He's really good in Collateral. He plays a ruthless hit man out to eliminate 5-6 people who might potentially testify in an upcoming high-profile trial. He hops into a cab driven by Max, superbly played (I mean, SUPERBLY) by Jamie Foxx, and sets off on an all-night shooting spree.Cruise doesn't change one whit throughout the film: he's a killing machine, period.But Foxx. Omigod, Jamie Foxx begins as a taxi hack in a nowhere life and slowly becomes the reluctant hero of the film as he valiantly (and very improbably, but hey, this is an action movie, so sit back and just take it on faith) tries to save the life of Cruise's last and ultimate victim: the pretty DA in charge of the case.It's exciting and edge-of-your seat tense throughout, and only 3 things really bothered me: 1) It's not believable that a car would overturn and crash to smithereens without either of the occupants getting more than a bruise, and Cruise's clothes don't even get mussed up, 2) It's not possible for women to run that desperately fast in 3-inch heels, and 3) The very last scene of them outside at dawn overlooking a freeway and parking lot was just...empty. Anticlimactic.Anyway, it's a terrific shoot-`em-up film, if you like this sort of thing.

Griff, a precocious 9yo girl who is determined to force Jean, her mother, to grow up and take responsibility for herself, is the main focus of this book that starts with Griff pretty much forcing her mom to drive away from her last abusive boyfriend and head toward California. They only make it to Ishawooa, Wyoming, where Jean grew up and married Griffin, Griff's dad, who died in a car accident before Griff was born.Einar, Griffin's angry old father (angry cuz he blames Jean for the death of his only son), reluctantly takes them in, and Jean begins working at the local restaurant.Griff falls in love with the ranch, the old man, his Vietnam War buddy Mitch who's been nearly killed by a grizzly, and with the sense of permanence that she's been lacking all her life - and she's determined not to leave.Good story-telling, good writing, good characters, good book.

A Midnight Clear is a stunning, poignant, passionate paean to the futility and tragedy of war. The setup is 6 very young, very bright US soldiers sent on a reconnaissance mission to a chateau deep within the Ardennes Forest in France in December 1944. Use of symbolism deepens the book's meaning: the men (read "boys") play chess and bridge (without cards) with deadly passion, one is called Mother because of his mother-hen neatnik qualities, another is called Father because he's a devout Catholic who left seminary cuz he didn't think he was good enough. Their leader is Wont (his name is William Knott, AKA Will Knot, AKA `will not,' thus: won't, usually shortened to Wont), a kid recently promoted to sergeant who hasn't had time to sew his stripes on yet.So they're in this abandoned chateau in the middle of this isolated forest, burning furniture to try to keep warm, and the dialogue and situations are hilarious and horrible, but mostly hilarious...but this is a book about war, so you know bad stuff is going to happen. Reading the first æ of the book, you feel kinda guilty laughing, cuz in the back of your mind, you're wondering which and how many of these kids are going to die.Then they realize there are 6-8 Germans nearby, and their fear is palpable - until it becomes clear that the Germans are just as young and scared as they are, just as sick of war, and even more importantly, the Germans know they're about to lose the war, and they want to surrender.The denouement, when it comes, occupies no more than perhaps one single page, maybe just a couple of paragraphs, and the rest of the book becomes a weird, tragic, very believable mythic, religious, mystery play/metaphor sort of thing with the kind of events and writing that keep you riveted to the last sentence.Highest possible recommendation. I swear it'll eventually become a classic.

The Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood has become a classic, a sprawling Southern novel of the lifelong friendships of 4 women, of the tensions between mothers and daughters, and of the survival, in spite of dark secrets from the past, of love.Siddalee Walker says something unkind (but true) about her mother, Vivi, and this precipitates a gathering of the women who have been Vivi's friends since they were little girls together. Their purpose is to patch things up. Vivi was far from a perfect mother, but when the Ya-Yas (the girlfriends) bring a scrapbook chronicling 7 decades of friendship and family history, Sidalee begins to see the bigger picture.There's a huge cast of characters (most of them females and all of them Southern), but author Rebecca Wells manages to make each come alive as distinct, individual, and wholly memorable.A real tour de force. A laugh a minute with a requisite kernel of darkness at its core.

The always complex relationships between mothers and daughters seems to be even more so between Chinese mothers and daughters - and most extremely so when the daughters are American-born. Amy Tan's multi-layered family tale is set against the backdrop of her mother's progressive Alzheimer's and the confusion of past with present that is a recurring and ever-worsening problem for both the mother, Lu Ling, and her daughter, Ruth. Much of the tale is told through a series of journals Lu Ling kept when she was a young woman in China, and the comparison between her situation then and now is poitnant.Not quite The Joy Luck Club, but very, very good.

Margaret Atwood should be knighted or something. She just gets better and better, and she started out being very good indeed. For me, The Blind Assassin is her most accomplished book. Most of her books have a bit of mystery at their core, and this is no exception. The Blind Assassin is a spellbinding family saga set against the backdrop of WWI, the Depression, and Communist witch-hunt persecution, but those over-arching themes are played out within the tragedy of one family, the Chases. The matriarch of the pathetically shriveled family is Iris, and she's dying from a heart ailment. Much of the book is told as her recollections back to the wartime suicide of her enigmatic sister, Laura. There's a parallel story interspersed through the main story, and it is the posthumous publication of Laura's novel, "The Blind Assassin." There is weirdly sci-fi back-story woven throughout, a plot concocted between a couple between their bouts of lovemaking, and it becomes apparent that the young man is in hiding for political reasons. But even with plentiful clues strewn throughout, it takes a while (maybe halfway into the book) to begin to figure out all the many layers of this complex and mesmerizing literary work. There are flashbacks, flashbacks within flashbacks, distorted memories, flights of fancy - and only a writer of Atwood's consummate skill could keep a handle on all this stuff and have it make perfect sense by the end. Fantastic!

The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman is presented as the taped memories of a 110yo black woman whose life spanned the era from slavery, thru the Civil War, and on into the civil rights era in the 1960s. Ernest J. Gaines set his novel in rural southern Louisiana, and, listening to Jane's marvelous language, we follow her life from one of utter servitude to her ultimate confrontation of the white power structure. It is a book of grace, magic, history, and redemption.

Bob Dollar is pretty much a loser, but he's not a crook. He finds himself hired as a scout by Global Pork Rind, and his job is to look for farms that the company can swindle the owners out of in order to put in hog farms. He doesn't really want to do it and manages to stall his employers for pretty much the entire book, meanwhile endearing himself to most of the colorful locals and becoming rather fond of them himself.It's all set in small towns in the Texas Panhandle, which, if Proulx is to be even half-believed, is populated by people with odd names (LaVon Grace Fronk, Jerky Baum, Habakuk van Melkebeek and Freda Beautyrooms, for starters) who live in towns with names with names like Wooleybucket. Keeping pace with Bob Dollars growing love for the harsh and unforgiving region, readers find themselves really caring about these tough characters. Dollar's house of cards comes tumbling down at the end, but he ends up somehow floating to the top of the deck and, while we don't see prosperity in his future, we do see a kind of peace.Annie Proulx has another winner here.

I know many people, mostly women, who refuse on principle to watch Pulp Fiction. "It's too violent," they say, without even having seen it. And in several cases, these are the same women who love Carl Hiaasen's books. You want wacko violence? Read Hiaasen. Soooo, what's with not watching Pulp Fiction?Get over it. Watch it anyway. You won't regret it.For about æ of the movie, you just have to take it on faith that the seemingly random bits of action are eventually going to merge and make some sense - and of course they do. The business of waiting, however, is NOT boring; a little confusing maybe, but definitely not boring. There are such spectacular, tongue-in-cheek bits of acting, violence, insanity, horror that you can't take your eyes off the screen. Right now, one particular one comes to mind (no, no, not the one with the brain matter splattered throughout the car's interior): Bruce Willis knows this bad dude is being tortured in a basement dungeon by some even badder guys, and sort of against his better judgment he decides he's gotta do something about it, even tho the guy being tortured has been determined to kill him (Willis). So he's in this store on the main floor, looking for a weapon - and meanwhile you hear the horrible sounds of the guy to whom terrible things are being done - and Willis is taking his sweet time, weighing a big gun against a mace against a pistol against a cudgel against a - - -  Aha! At last, just when you're ready to scream "THE GUN, TAKE THE GUN" at him, he finds what he's looking for: a samurai sword. And off he trots to save his would-be assassin.And what a cast. In addition to Willis, you've got Uma Thurman, Samuel L. Jackson, Harvey Keitel, Amanda Plummer, etc.Unbelievably terrific quirky wacko wild and wooly violent (yeah, it is violent) nutso twisted corrupt wicked hilarious top dog of a movie.

Smilla Jaspersen is half American and half Eskimo/Greenlander living in Denmark. She is 37, unmarried, and filled with a quiet caustic rage that overflows occasionally into determined action. She is also an expert, thanks to her Inuit mother, on the properties of snow and the significance of tracks left in snow.Smilla is befriended by a pitiful child, Isiah, and the novel begins with the discovery of his body on the ground below a 7-story building, from the roof of which he apparently fell. But Smilla isn't so sure. For one thing, he was afraid of heights. For another, it appears that a needle biopsy of his leg muscle was taken after his death. But most of all, there are his tracks, only his, in the snow, but Smilla can see his panic, his running, his fear in the properties of those tracks.Smilla is nothing if not determined, and she embarks on a quest to discover the truth behind the child's death, a quest that nearly costs her her own life.Excellent, nail-biting suspense and powerful, literary-quality writing. Superb.

The first of perhaps 4 times I saw Harold and Maude was at a theater in Berkeley on University Avenue. I must have been the only person in the audience who had never seen this iconic black-humor film before, because the entire audience applauded for every credit that came on the screen both at the beginning and again at the end. It was obviously a cult film with a rabid cult following, and I wondered what I was getting myself in for.Well. I had no idea what I'd been missing! Harold and Maude (Maude is played by the inimitable Ruth Gordon in one of the best roles of her very long career) is perhaps the blackest of black comedies - and it's a hoot and a half - and then some. It portrays the unlikely but, given the context, perfectly understandable relationship (love affair?) between a death-obsessed teenager, Harold, and an life-celebrating octogenarian widow, Maude. They meet (where else) at a funeral of someone that neither of them knows and they recognize their weird common-ground: funerals.This movie is sweet. It's endearing, touching, beautiful, life-affirming - it's a romance and a passionate plea to reach out and grab life by the lapels, suck it of its essence before it's too late.Marvelous, marvelous - but a warning: you've got to be a certain kind of quirky person in a particularly quirky frame of mind to appreciate it. If you fit the description, this might become one of your favorite movies of all time.

Romantic comedy with stellar cast. Jack Nicholson plays himself, an aging Lothario chasing younger women. A heart attack lands him in the seaside home of the mother of one of those young women. This 'mother' turns out to be Diane Keaton, a playwright of some fame. An interesting little triangle develops. Keanu Reeves, the cardiologist, falls hard for Keaton, who is always one sexy dame. Nicholson falls for her, too. Keaton is in the enviable position of having 2 men, who have maybe a 25 year age gap between them, salivating over her.The scenes of the developing relationship, including a nude scene for Keaton and a bare-butt scene for Nicholson, are marvelous fun and quite believable.The there are detractions. Frances McDormand's talents are wasted in a role as Keaton's sister, a role that is far too small for her. Reeves' role is understated, gentlemanly - and ultimately unbelievable. Not unbelievable in terms of a man falling for a woman 15+ years his senior, but unbelievable in terms of the minimal emotional range he brings to his performance.But the best part by far is the fact that this romantic comedy doesn't deal with the foibles of 20-30yo actors; it focuses with truth and affection on the foibles of a 'mature couple.'Great theater.

Peter Dinklage is a wonderful actor with a huge emotional range in his body language and facial expressions, and he also happens to be one of the 'little people.' For whatever reason might be at the root of his obsession, he's a nut for trains. He works in a model train shop, and then one day the owner falls over dead and Dinklage finds that he has inherited an abandoned depot in rural NJ. He walks there, following the tracks. In fact, a lot of the movie occurs while one character or another is walking along the tracks.He makes several friends in his new community, but two are destined to become real keepers, and both of them are suffering from loss. Patricia Clarkson has lost a child, and a wacky Bobby Cannavale, the guy who runs a mobile coffee stand, is trying hard to care for an ailing father who makes unreasonable demands on him. There's also a pretty librarian who comes to rely on Dinklage, a plumb African-American 8yo who persuades him to come to her school as a show and tell specimen, some rough town guys who make the usual midget jokes, and others.Not a whole lot happens, but by the end, you realize you've watched the anatomy of friendship develop right in front of your eyes.

I bought six of these to go with a table I built for a friend and her two kids, so I have quite a bit of experience with them.. They are heavy, sturdy and very well crafted.  Malaysian crafting (their point of origin) is much better than what is coming out of China. They look and feel like a much more expensive stool. The only problem with these are the hex head lag bolts you use to put them together. . They look like they are made out of brass at first glance, but they are actually a softer alloy.Someone else mentioned that the hex tool that comes with them is cheap and strips. That is true and it does so almost immediately when installing the bottom rung.. One reason for that is that the holes on each end of the front and back cross bars, (the sides come assembled) are very tight. Once the screw gets almost flush with the leg (it needs to recess about 1/2 inch more) the trouble starts. The head on some begin to strip. Some will install but it is tough going! My drill wouldn't push it to the end.Once the head strips you are stuck with no way to tighten the rung. Luckily the softness of the metal means you can use a 3/8 inch bit to drill through the head and twist it off with pliers. You can then back the screw out with vice grips or such. 20 minutes later you are back where you started, short one bolt!  So now you need to run out and find a replacement.. Unfortunately replacements are not to be found at either Lowe's or Home Depot. I was able to make do with a zinc #14, 2 inch Phillips head. 2.5 would be perfect but the 2 was all they had and it worked. They have lag bolts but all of the heads are too wide to properly recess in the hole.To fix this issue  in my next constructions, I took a a 1/4 drill bit and reamed out each end of the rung slightly. This made the hole slightly bigger and the bolt was able to be inserted without being loose. As a precaution I added a drop of Gorilla glue to each bolt. If you have ever used the stuff it expands so it will fill any space around the bolt and jam the insert into the leg tightly.Another problem with the rungs is twisting. Each rung has a nipple with a hole in the end (the one enlarged above). The nipple inserts into the leg and the bolt is inserted from the other side of the leg. The slight angle where the rung meets the leg is not enough to fully stabilize it.  What I did was to put two drops of clear gorilla glue on each nipple before inserting it (remember to add a drop of water to the hole because Gorilla glue needs moisture to cure).. Once dry the rungs won't shift.After you have attached both sides you are ready for the top. For some reason none of my top holes were too small but after enduring the bottom issue I hit them with the drill just to make sure. I found there was a enough play in the design to slip one side of the wooden pins protruding from the seat into the leg holes and then pry the sides apart slightly to pop the other into place without loosening the rungs. The top bolts went in without a hitch.I used a ratcheting screwdriver for the entire assembly. Because the heads were so soft I preferred not to risk using my drill to drive them.  Once you get the hang of it, they are pretty easy to do...and the finished product is well worth the hassle. One thing I added were 25mm (1 inch) felt pads under the feet. They are kind of rough and my friend has hardwood floors...
It may depend on the stone...I have been trying to polish some labradorite and can't get anything but a dusty looking finish even after DAYS using the final polish cycle.

Jim Mars has always seen the big picture. I spend a lot of time looking at it as well because nothing makes sense at the micro level. Our water is poisoned with water destroying fracking, even in CA where a drought is endangering our food supply. Our food supply is being controlled by an FDA deputy director who was Monsanto's former policy director, ensuring that whatever biotech creates will be ushered into the food supply on the word of the manufacturer alone.  Our staple crops of corn and soy were the first to go.  Vaccines may sound great until you meet the mother of a vaccine injured child, one forced to go to a government court and face enormous opposition while footing all the legal bills and the cost of her son's disability.People who speak out are silenced and ridiculed. Sometimes they die mysteriously. Science is bought and paid for. Studies avoid very obvious questions while aiming to prove a point that makes money for someone. That is not science....but scientist have to eat too. I moved to my current home because it was one of the last places in Louisiana with clean water. It is beautiful with clear streams, abundant foliage and laws that require a permit just to cut a tree. But something called the Halliburton Loop Hole passed by congress to exempt fracking from the clean water act is now ready to attack our aquifer. There is no arguing that fracking poisons water. Our local oncologist went over every chemical (and they won't tell you everything) and told us the effects. The recent EPA study as damning as it was is a joke!  The structure of our corporate government is not the pyramid we think but a host of three letter agencies each of which have the same agenda....and it is not to preserve our health and well being....Perhaps the worst part of it is what we do to ourselves...Read the Rolling Stone article about the babies dying in Utah..and what is being done to the woman midwife who pointed it out....It is time we start to love one another and stop chanting the party line....Thank you Jim!

Scam....Just another attempt to make a buck on a hot topic. No pictures. No building information. One page chapters. Only the authors two cents on why you should think about where you want to put it and what you might want to put in it. You'll get more information from a friend who cares about you but knows nothing about shipping containers...Worthless even for free.

This crystal is so small that it barely weighs down the chain, causing it to hang unevenly when you suspend it. I have a larger one I bought from a vendor here that is heavier and works very well. As I remember it wasn't much more in price. This one is SO light that the chain actually inhibits its movement.

I really want this shirt but the Medium is $5 more than any other size and $2 more than it sells for on the "The Mountain" website. You get free shipping there as well if you buy $25 or more. . That makes zero sense....To make matters worse when I put it in my cart the price stays the same but the description changes to what I am looking at right now. as I write this review....  Laentina Head Case Baby Blue And Cream Stripe Design Back Case Cover For Blackberry Q10 by LaentinaFix this!!! Apparently the medium on this shirt and the Cheshire Cat are both sold by different vendors than the other sizes. While the vendors do not have the same name they do have the same problem as both describe a case by Laentina when you put the shirt in your cart. Amazon needs to pay closer attention to how these products are listed and/or give us a way to contact them when something goes wrong. You can only complain about the image...not the description.

if you are thinking of using these stones for any sort of jewelry look elsewhere for AAA or AA quality.  It is a shame that so few of Amazon's stones come with the grade assigned. These are more like B grade. You get very small flashes on some of them and even when you cut one to reveal more you find that the flash isn't very deep. What  flash there is that is larger than a penny is a very pale green..  Also the stones come looking like chunks of ill-shaped concrete. They are not nicely "edged" slabs like ones in the picture. They all needed to be cut to reveal anything worth having. And it is not easy to hold them steady in a vice for cutting without chipping off pieces..  I cut a few with a diamond edged dremel blade and found them to be brittle and easy to chip. One or two even looked like a chunk had been knocked out of them making we wonder if this was from a "discard" pile. .The photo is what the  stones look like after  WEEKS of tumbling.. The photo isn't the best but the hints of blue are just that...hints with blacks predominating and clear areas surround very small chips of flash.

I have used Oxbow Timothy as a small supplement to my buns diet for years on the advice of my bunny vet, though the majority of their diet is organic veggies and hay. I never really checked the ingredients until the GMO controversy came along... WHAT???? Almost all SOY!  Over the years Soy has been genetically modified and the latest incarnation, "Roundup Ready" soy is now in full production.  In the U.S. today, soy is genetically modified (which is very different from hybridization.. Don't confuse the two). There have been studies showing digestive issues with GMO's...but "ROUNDUP" ready on top of that!!! Roundup contains Glyphosate,  a major poison that can damage the digestive tract mouth and esophagus in humans. Just imagine what it can do to the fragile gut of a bunny weighing a fraction of what the human does and eating a diet of ONLY soy based pellets? If that is not bad enough, the FDA just RAISED the allowable level of Glyphosate, so we have no idea how much our rabbits will be getting in the future. Listen up OXBOW! Loyal customer buying another brand now!!! Trust broken!!

Aimless and lacking in instructions. I loved the earlier versions of this game but everything about this one lacks. I can't even read most of the text on my 50 inch screen, because the graphics are so poor. I pick up quests and occasionally hear from one of my fellow adventurers that we have found something someone wanted, but I have no idea how to get it to them because the map is another experiment in poor type. There are also very few vendors or neat weapons, which made the earlier games more fun. Go to inventory and you are again confronted with the tiny fuzzy text. Graphics overall are poor. The hair on many characters looks like plastic. I've grown tired of roaming around shooting things and will put this away replay Dragon Age.
This is NOT the song from the movie in name only. It is not the performance as rendered during the love scene. If you want that find a copy of the soundtrack.

I collect movies and bought this movie based on the 5 star reviews.  I just don't get it. All I can figure is that the movie industry is now paying reviewers instead of script writers.The raccoon was cute, but the lack luster script was largely carried by the 70's soundtrack. Beyond that it was two hours of battle scenes and special effects.. It also took the idea that 'evil" is a good reason to do something WAY too far. How about some real motivation?? Only one character had it because he lost his wife and child and he pretty much forgot about it when someone told him to "get over it".  He was also belittled for having a vocabulary and I'm not talking about words you'd have to look up, I'm talking about words most people used to know before the dumbing down of America. Useful only as a testament to how low our taste and acceptance of banality has fallen. To say I sorely regret this purchase is an understatement.

I was interested in finding a good video that talked about pricing and the Art world. What I found instead was a man sitting in front of a painting I didn't care for while talking endlessly about himself. Interspersed were comments from others trying their hardest to say interesting things about him. Most said that he was great at mixing colors for another artist I had never heard of. It was so bad and lacking in an real useful content that I finally turned it off. It was a serious struggle to get through the 20 minutes I watched. Glad this was just a rental.

I've tried three vendors for this stone on amazon and all produce about the same quality with Fantasia giving the best lot. What I got from this company was a lower in quality than the others with no usable sized flash showing on any rock when opening the pack. None look like the pictures even when wet. It appears that what is being sold is A grade roughs. These look like AA grade roughs in the picture but are almost all matrix and have no flash. The stone most people want when it comes to this gem is the one that produces "an oil on water like "flash" from several angles. You might find a little of that in AA stones and a good bit more in AAA. I have spotted a few tiny flashes on this shipment but none that would make a nice piece of jewelry. We are talking about 1/8 of an inch and less flash. Some have a side that looks like opalescent glass but that is not what you buy this for. I also bought a slab from the same vendor and while most of it had decent flash it only showed from one angle. I have several pieces of jewelry using Labradorite and all have more color. Much of the Fantasia pack was also a pale green and not the brilliant blue.

Looks nothing like the picture even when wet. There is flash to the piece but it is highly directional, and can be seen from only one angle As a pendant it would look like a shined rock most of the time. It is only polished on one side. I will polish the back and see if that offers anything better. I would recommend this more as an energy working stone than a jewelry selection.

Here in the South we like strong dark coffee. This combo not only brews well but it gives you three choices of strength, regular, strong or bold. It also has 5 grind settings to accommodate the number of cups you want to make. The unit does not require paper filters and has a nice wire mesh basket that does not contain much plastic. Unfortunately if you are like me and don't like your coffee or hot water to the touch much plastic, you are out of luck. The basket that holds the brewing filter is solid plastic. One star off for that, but finding one that doesn't use plastic is nearly impossible. Still we Southern folks want perfection in our coffee. Take a hint B and D! Other than making the coffee, it also keeps it warm with a built in hot plate and you can set it to wake you up with the smell of a fresh pot. Can't beat that!One issue I have found with it is that it can be hard to clean. The lid that snaps down over the grinding basket tends to get full of grinds when making large pots. You may not notice this at first but it is important to clean it. Don't let grinds sit in the basket for any length of time as the bottom has lots of divisions and is hard to clean if you let it set too long. I recommend cleaning as soon as the basket is cool to the touch.

Some toys are best left on the shelf. These highly detailed figures show local police using military grade hardware. Do you really want your child to see this as normal police work?? Apparently this toy maker does.  If your child is old enough, consider getting him or her something that encourages exploration and imagination within the scope of police positive work. A good example is the Theo Klein Police kit.

First off, the dear friend card is basically a card that says how much she loves this deck. On the flip side is her bio and website. I collect oracle decks so I purchased this deck with the idea that I could randomly pick cards for some relationships I had issues with and obtain an insight into each. Unfortunately there isn't enough variation in the card messages to use it like that..As expected, the cards are all variation of her theme that your vibration attracts same.  But several themes are actually being repeated with minor variations. Here is an example: "I can stop attractions to don't wants by do wants" , "I can get from an unwanted to a wanted relationship."  "The thoughts I think determine the relationship I attract," "By my attention to things I make choices," "I must focus on wanted to manifest wanted", "I can focus on what I do want in a relationship," My attention to Unwanted can't defy the law of attraction, "That which is like unto itself, is drawn". Because there are so many like these, they tend to come up often. The deck would have functioned better if this would have been represented by ONE card.
I love the image. You should note however that all of the Mountain Shirts I have purchased are LONG.

So much of what is contained in this movie is happening; NSA-like spying, secret kill lists with no accountability, torture, control of media and now even independent journalists being investigated. It is all here.  I remember reading that Robert Monroe made his first subliminal tapes using CIA equipment, so that is likely as well.  It would be nice if there was a Valis, That is the name of the Sci-fi element here. Worth seeing the film to find out what it is...

First do your homework. Paul Barrett testified for Chevron. Know that the compassion the book seems to show for the people of the Amazon is just an attractive stage play to hook you in. The rest of the book is a mix of well reported legal maneuvering combined with mostly subtle Donziger bashing that would give someone who doesn't know who Barrett is, the feeling they are reading a fair and impartial account. Also check the profiles of the 5 star reviewers. How many only review this book or just this and one or two other things? Most also use the basic Amazon Initial in a colored block review icon suggesting they didn't take the time to personalize their reviewer page. I fully expect to be trolled by the oil insiders...but I don't write reviews to up my ratings. I write them to give people yet another point of view on a book....read on if you like!That said, I spent over a week trying to get through the horrors of the first fifty pages of this book. It describes the atrocities committed against the Amazonian people who had dynamite dropped on their heads from planes and attempts made to move them off their land by a Texaco funded "Christian Group" out of Oklahoma. Not much more is said about this group. Having been paid to set up a new "Christian home" for the natives, they apparently watched dispassionately and silently while the oil company poisoned indigenous people's land, rivers, children and animals. You have to wonder why they never saw "the big picture", but then using religion to infiltrate and destroy culture is unfortunately one of the oldest tricks in the book. Not to worry though!  This isn't a book about bashing Christians. It is a well written and seductive bash of Steven Donziger. You get the first hint of it when Barrett bashes Donziger's 1996 book "The Real War on Crime." In it, Donziger pointed out that our criminal justice system was being seeded both at the State and Federal level with harsh triple offender and mandatory sentencing laws. Today we are finally waking up to the fact that this has made us not only the most incarcerating country in the world, but prepared us for the advent of corporate owned prisons and the movement of entire factories behind bars. He tried to warn us that we were not reducing crime by reducing people to a prison number. Barrett apparently couldn't resist bashing the one book out there with Donziger's name on it. This seemed oddly out of place in a fair minded book on the Amazon.While the evidence against Texaco (bought by and defended by Chevon ) is damning, with much of it coming from its own documents,, the onus here is placed on Donziger for his tactics. I am from Louisiana and we are fighting for our lives right now against big oil. Much of our state is dotted with injection wells that leak silently into water tables. The canals they ceaselessly cut through our marsh, allowing salt water intrusion, have caused much of the bottom of our state to disappear. Like with the Amazon, our laws have been perverted to allow open waste pits, most of which overflowed into our waterways when Katrina hit. Like the government of Ecuador, our government is complicit in both not investigating discharges and in allowing big oil off the hook when problems can be identified.  We here in Louisiana fully understand what it is like to have the officials who should protect us "owned" by big oil. If Donziger used the press in unscrupulous ways, God bless him! Every plea for justice we utter here is met by paid oil media trolls, outrageous laws and more cancers even though we are already number one in the nation. But I digress....I see this book as a lesson in the more "subtle" aspects of defamation. It is a masterwork of pro-oil propaganda that combines just enough sympathy for humanity with ceaseless pro-oil innuendo.  It often uses implied rather than direct ridicule. A good example is the statement about Sting and Darrel Hannah being involved in an ad campaign where Darrel displays an oil covered hand. There is no explanation of WHY this shouldn't be done, but it is stated as if it is just one more nail in the coffin of unfairness to Chevron....This kind of implied impropriety is deadly because it bypasses most people's logic filter. While "Law of the Jungle" starts out appearing to care about the Rain Forest it is not about suffering people. It is about a dizzying array of legal maneuvers and decisions. It could be instructive if it were not for the fact that the Trans-Pacific Partnership so few know about, will essentially circumvents our national laws to allow corporate international courts dominance in issues such as this..

The stone has a nice blue color. Not all the labradorite flashes that nice blue oil on water look. Unfortunately setting and the ring itself are very thin and not attractive. Every time I wear it the ring deforms.

Not much about photography here. Most pages are just a paragraph.. She says some nice things but does not go into any depth. . The book is mostly a collection of coffee cups in various settings. I bought it for a friend who wants to do "in the moment photography". I thought this would be great...Its just okay.

I have had to remove the battery a couple of times to get my camera to reboot and work. Produces a very grainy image on all settings. It works well when you add a secondary light source for the IR. Someone said this camera records audio. Mine does not, nor do I see audio controls anywhere on the camera.

I barely used this lens and have had it less than a year. The Aufo Focus first failed on 270 and now won't even focus on 18. I'm going to call my dealer and see what they can do but I'm not willing to pay Tamron one red cent. This lens has not been abused in any way. I will NEVER buy from this company again.

I highly recommend you get this book and slog through it with a highlighter. There is a lot of great information here. Unfortunately it gets buried in too many digressions about the character and lives of the many people who make up the story. It also makes too many forays into the ancient history of whales, the whaling industry and Marine Biology. Each of these topics would be interesting on their own, and a certain amount of this information is necessary, but the constant digression is frustrating to a reader who is more interested in the Naval aspect and what can be done to circumvent this ongoing problem.The main issues with the Navy remind me a lot of  what we live with here in Louisiana. The oil and gas industry has roughly the same MO;  make sure regulatory agencies are underfunded or handicapped in one way or another, deny the public access to needed information and when needed create laws to protect what you are doing. The Navy of course has the added benefit of evoking the security state. In the end, although often staffed by good people, the book makes it clear that these protective agencies exist only by treading carefully on the tail of the tiger they are supposed to be controlling.The third level in this war is one we have become too familiar with, the Supreme Court majority's many transgressions. As usual the story pits the corporate/military/industrial, Roberts against Ruth Ginsburg's judicial elegance in defeat. In the end, War of the Whales is not just about the demise of whales at the hands of the Navy, it is yet another showcase for a corrupt system, aided by secrecy, that has our country beaching itself while bleeding from the ears.

This T-shirt is about five bucks cheaper than other Mountain T-shirts listed on Amazon. What appears to be a good deal is NOT. Whether this is intentional deception by the buyer or an Amazon screw up, this is NOT AN ADULT SHIRT. The headline on this shirt clearly says ADULT T-SHIRT. There is no child's shirt or kids shirt listed in the pull down...but guess what I got sent? A CHILD's MEDIUM. Gave it to my friends 7 year old.Skip this one.Also note that the tag line next to my title is wrong....This is not a review of the brontosaurus T-shirt. It is a review of this shirt. Something is wrong with this page. Buy from another vendor page.

While you might be able to read the first page of this song on your kindle, the rest of it is WAY too small to see. I've tried to see it both on the kindle and my PC. It is a no go on either. I wish Amazon paid more attention to what it allows in the Kindle format.
