I love the little heart charms that say "Made with Love."  I'm glad that this bracelet easily slides on and I don't have to deal with a clasp so I can put it on myself quickly. It goes with any outfit and I can wear it for any occasion. It would be perfect for a gift for yourself or a loved one. It came in a very nice little red velvet bag too so when I'm not wearing it I can keep it in that. It's definitely a gorgeous bracelet and very affordable too! *discount received for testing and review*

This is such an adorable little sweater and I was so excited to receive it and put it on my dog. I measured her to make sure I got the proper size. She is a 35 pound Border Collie/Beagle mix. When I got the sweater and put it on her it seemed like it was too big for her but I know I measured her correctly and it was the right size. It hangs over the back of her a little. The leg holes also seemed to be too low for heron the shoulder area. She started walking funny once I finished putting it on and I was trying to adjust it to get her more comfortable in it. I think maybe my dog is just built weird because I see all the other reviewers dogs fit into this sweater perfectly. The hood is an adorable addition to this sweater though especially with the little ball on the top of it. The sweater is very soft and warm and will definitely get many compliments. The hole on the top of the neck area is perfect so you can have a leash attached to a collar underneath it. Other than my dog being built funny this sweater is adorable and I really do love it. I will have to play around with it and make it work because I want her to wear it for Christmas so bad. *I received this product free for testing and review*

I've always wanted to decorate for Thanksgiving but never knew exactly where to start. This was the perfect set to kick off my Thanksgiving decorating. It has a variety of items from pine cones, gourds, mini pumpkins, to a pack of 250 leaves. It's perfect for a table centerpiece or spread across different areas of the house. The leaves look so realistic with the fading colors too which I thought was really impressive. This whole set just gives you the perfect feeling of fall decor in a bag. This set is great quality and well made. It'll definitely last and it's better than something I could come up with myself. Now I have something I can bring out every year during Thanksgiving to decorate with. *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

I love these collapsible silicone pet bowls. They are so convenient for travel and to keep around in case of emergencies. I like to keep some in the car along with some water bottles for when we go on trips. The bowls fit into the glove compartment or the back on the seats without taking up any room. When I'm ready to use them they easily pop up and I can fill them with my dogs food or water. When I'm done they collapse easily and effortlessly. They are perfect for taking with us on road trips and bringing into hotels. My dog only eats half a cup of food twice a day so her food fits perfectly at each meal. They also hold plenty of water for my dog to drink while we are traveling. She is a 34lb. Border Collie/Beagle mix for reference. My dog does not make any messes while eating or drinking from these and does not flip them over like I saw another review mention. I have had no problems with these bowls. I love that they come in various fun and bright colors too. So far I'm very satisfied with these. *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

This is a great grooming mitt and my dog seems to really enjoy it. She was moving around and letting me know exactly what spots to pet while I was using this. She really liked the soft little bristles on it. The mitt did grab some hair and kept it in the mitt. It was also very easy to clean and remove. I think it would be better for a short haired animal though as it didn't get completely under all of her fur since it's medium length. I also like that the other side of the mitt, the red side, is kind of like a lint brush. After I groom my dog and there are stray hairs on her I can go over her with the red side and it picks up those hairs for me. It's also great at removing her hair from my clothing and the couch!! I love that as every time I brush her the hair always manages to end up on me. For me, the mitt was very comfortable on my hand. The wrist part Velcros so it can fit anyone securely. It also has a strap on the inside so I can put my hand under it to get a better grip so my hand doesn't just slip around all over the place. It can also be used for anyone left or right handed which is great. So far I'm liking this grooming mitt. Every time I grab it my dog starts wagging her tail and comes right up to me because she knows it means she's getting petted with it! *sample provided for testing and review*

This set of three travel size spray bottles is perfect and just what I needed. They are high quality, leak proof, and are a nice fine mist. They're perfect for travel or for keeping on my vanity. I filled two of them with my own face mists I made out of rose water, tea tree oil, and toner and they work perfectly. The funnel was a perfect addition and helped me so much when I was pouring everything! Kept me from making a big liquid mess. The caps stay on securely so I don't have to worry about them falling off in my purse or luggage if I'm traveling. I am completely satisfied with these and they were way more convenient than having to go to the store to buy some. The plastic on these seems a lot thicker than the ones in the travel section of the stores. *discount received for testing and review*

These are really handy little notebooks. They're the perfect size to keep in my purse. My husband also likes to keep one handy in his pocket at work as they fit perfectly. I like the perforated easy tear pages and the fact that they have binding instead of the spiral wiring. There are plenty of pages in the notebooks to last you quite a good amount of time as well. They're sleek and look good with the nice black covers with no brand name, pictures, or anything. It allows you to customize them yourself and anyone can use them. I only wish they were a tad bit cheaper. *Product provided free for testing and review*

I absolutely love these acrylic paints. The paint is nice and thick, very easy to dispense from the tube, and not messy at all. They have a great opacity to them and they are very easy to mix to get new desired colors. I like that I can water them down or make them thicker with acrylic media or pastes. These are really conventional. The drying time is very convenient on both regular thick paper and canvas. They don't bleed, drip, or anything. The colors are fantastic and they cover canvas very well without having to go over a spot numerous times. The paints are also very easy to clean from my brushes. Overall, I'm very happy with these non toxic acrylic paints.

This candy jar is much smaller than I thought it would be. It also is red unlike the photo in the listing which shows it being blue. I don't really mind that part though. The size was kind of surprising. You can fit smaller sized candy in it though like mints and things. It's actually a good size for the holidays to have out for family. May even help you to not eat too much candy! The plastic is durable. The lid closes nice and tight so you don't have to worry about a mess if it were to spill. Overall, it is a cute little jar. *discount received for testing and review*

This is the perfect little mini tree for a nice table top decoration. It can be used for a nice miniature village scene or around other small Christmas decorations. It would even be perfect to put on an office desk to add a little festive touch! It's super cute and I love the frosted look. The bright colored and shiny ornaments already on it make it look perfect. It's made very well made and I'm quite happy with it! *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

This chai spice tea is absolutely delicious and may have just become my favorite tea. I've always been a huge fan of chai tea but I've only had the kind from the grocery store. I'd never had loose tea like this. This is the perfect tea for fall and great for cold morning. I was so glad that they also included some bonus tea bags with this tea because I completely forgot I needed them to make the tea. The smell of this stuff is absolutely delicious as soon as you open the bag. You can tell that it's fresh! The tea is absolutely perfect without adding anything to it. It has just the right amount of spice to it. I don't have to add anything to it. The tea bags worked perfectly and I was so glad they were included. The resealable bag is awesome to keep the tea fresh. I've been enjoying it every cold morning since I got it. Definitely better than the stuff I was buying from the store! *I received this product free for testing and review purposes*

Just what I needed with Christmas right around the corner. I always use gift bags because they are so much more convenient and easier than wrapping presents so I am always using tissue paper. This assortment of red, green, and white tissue paper is perfect for the holidays! Now I'll be able to wrap everyone's presents with plenty of paper without having to go to the store or worry about running out as there is plenty in this assortment. The paper is very good quality and doesn't rip super easy either. It's not thin and cheap like the stuff I would buy at the dollar store sometimes. Definitely what I was looking for. *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

If you're looking for a high quality flat iron but don't want to spend a ton of money this is definitely the one to get. I am extremely surprised with this flat iron. I have tried many over the years as a Cosmetologist that have ranged in price all the way up to $300. This one definitely gives those expensive salon brands some competition. I don't even have to turn this flat iron all the way to the highest temperature and I get great results. I love that it has adjustable settings instead of just one universal setting at 410 degrees which damages so many peoples hair. The ceramic plates heat quickly and evenly and do not cool down while you're using it. This flat iron makes my hair very soft, silky, and shiny. It doesn't pull, tug, or rip at the ends of my hair at all which is a huge plus. It's great for my long thick hair. I can take bigger pieces of hair and straighten it a lot quicker than with other ones I've used in the past. I'm able to straight and curl my hair easily with this because of the design of it too. The outside isn't flat and it has a nice round shape to it so you can easily create some nice curls. This is definitely a great flat iron to have around. *discount received for testing and review*

I love this aromatherapy diffuser. It's got a beautiful design, it's a pretty big 120ml size, it's very easy to operate, and the lights change colors. It holds 100ml of water which lasts quite a long time. I love that it has an auto shut off so I can fall asleep with it on and not have to worry about it running dry. It also has an option to run for 30 seconds, shut off for 30 seconds, and then run again for 30 seconds which I found really interesting. The diffuser is also very quiet while it's running. I also absolutely love the color changes. They are beautiful to look at and there's also an option to have the colors on bright or a dimmer setting. I also have the option of picking what color to put on instead of having the colors rotate or you can have them change. If you have a child you can have them pick their favorite color and it's very easy to press the button and go to each color setting. This is a great diffuser with some cool upgrades compared to other diffusers I have tried. I definitely like the ease of this one. *discount received for testing and review*

This cast iron cat trivet is absolutely adorable. I am a huge cat lover and as soon as I saw this I had to have it. It is very sturdy and quite heavy. It's definitely good quality and made very well. I like that the bottom of the legs have rubber on them so they don't scratch any surface it is placed on. The detailing is excellent and I can't get over how cute it looks. If I didn't want to actually use it as a trivet it could easily be used as wall decor in the kitchen area. It can even be hung on the wall while not in use. I love that I can place hot pots and pans on my counter top with this and not worry about ruining the surface now. I can also take it to the dining room table as well. It stays put and doesn't slide around because of the rubber non-slip legs. I love this thing! *discount received for testing and review*

So far I'm really impressed with this Glycolic Acid pads. I like that the pads are less messy than a wash and I can easily use them to clean my neck and chest area without worrying about water dripping everywhere. I have really sensitive skin and I've been dealing with some hormonal acne lately especially on my jaw line that has been driving me nuts. I've been using these pads every night for the past two weeks after I've washed my face and neck. So far I've noticed a slight difference in the way my skin feels. I know I need to use them longer before I see a bigger improvement but I'm glad to see that I have not experienced any redness or burning. My skin does feel smoother and I do notice the little bumps are disappearing. (The bumps on my skin that were never pimples, just uneven texture.) These pads can be a bit drying though since they tighten the skin so I just use a nighttime moisturizer afterwards and it's fine. I haven't experienced any drastic peeling though which I absolutely hate and have experienced with many acne pads that always made me discontinue use. I'm definitely liking the results so far and will continue to use these. 50 pads is almost two months worth with once a day use. Since I have sensitive skin I didn't want to use them more than that, especially for the price if I end up liking them and needing more! *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

These candles are absolutely divine! Upon opening and smelling each one I was instantly filled with this satisfaction of a sweet aroma. They smell absolutely delicious and do not have an artificial smell to them. The candles are a very generous size at 8 ounces especially because you don't need much wax at all once melted to massage with. I lit the "Fig & Brown Sugar" candle and waited a few minutes. I couldn't wait any longer to test it  because it smelled so delicious so I had to blow it out! The candle has a great throw, very therapeutic and makes you feel like you're in a luxurious spa. Now, I wish my husband was giving me a back massage but he's working. I dipped my finger in the wax and put it right on the inside of my arm. It was warm and felt quite relaxing. You can also just pour the wax directly from the tin to your body if desired. The wax doesn't burn and feels very nice. Rubbed in it is moisturizing without a greasy feeling. The Shea Butter, Jojoba Oil, Vitamins A, Vitamin E and Omega 3 Oils help to moisturize and nourish the skin which is a great benefit of these candles. It penetrated into my skin nicely without leaving any sticky mess behind.These candles are perfect for a romantic couples massage between you and your partner or even just to use for a nice candlelit bath by yourself. They smell amazing, my skin felt great afterwards, and they are made in the USA. Each candle will definitely last a long time and I love the tins they come in. I definitely recommend these for gifts or to pick up for yourself. I am hooked! *samples provided free for testing and review purposes*

Great Harlequin thigh highs. I was worried these wouldn't fit me because usually "one size" items end up being too small on me but they did fit fine. I'm 5'4 and usually wear a L/XL in pants. They are super cute and great for a Halloween costume. They stay put and don't roll down at all. They don't snag and the material is very comfortable. These are definitely affordable and a great costume accessory! *sample provided for testing and review*

This is a fantastic dual shower head. I've always wanted one of these and this one is perfect. I love how it has five different functions to pick from. My husband loves the more pressurized water from the rain/aeration selection while I like the rain and massage selections. I also love that you can use both shower heads at once or one at a time. The flow is perfect on both shower heads. This was very easy to install in the shower and only took my husband a few minutes to switch from our other shower head to this one. The ABS plastic material with a chrome finish is very solid and made well. The finish is very shiny and definitely makes it look like a luxurious chrome shower head. So far I've been using this for about three weeks and my husband and I both enjoy it. No complaints at all! *I received this product free for testing and review*

These hammock tree straps go great with the hammock I just got. These are very solid, strong, and durable. The stitching is excellent! The straps are lightweight and easy to carry along in a backpack for a hiking or camping trip. It was very easy to wrap these straps around many different sized trees. The straps give plenty of room and they are very long so you aren't restricted to certain trees or you don't have to go hunting for trees that are a specific distance away from each other. They are so simple and very convenient to have along with my Petrichor portable hammock. *I received this product free for testing and review*

This is such a cute and humorous laundry room sign. It instantly added a nice simple touch to my laundry room. That room has been so boring and plain for so long. I have been looking at cute signs and decals for the walls but have never settled on one. I am so glad I got this one. It's a nice size and it's very cute. The "Sorting Out Life One Load At A Time" fits perfectly in the laundry room and makes me laugh. The sign was easy to hang and has two holes on the back for nails to go into. It's a solid wooden sign and lays perfectly against my wall. I absolutely love it! *discount received for testing and review*

This is the cutest mason jar soap dispenser. It has such a vintage DIY look to it. The quality of it is excellent. The glass is very thick, much thicker than a regular mason jar. The stainless steel pump is beautiful and shiny. It is very easy to pump soap out of this dispenser. It dispenses just the perfect amount of soap when you press down on it. It took me a while to decide exactly what kind of soap to put in it because I wanted it to look perfect and didn't want to pick a soap that would be too thick and clog it up. I ended up putting some Soft Soap in it and it worked perfectly. The dispenser instantly added a gorgeous touch to my guest bathroom vanity. I am so impressed with the quality of this dispenser and am so happy that I have this. It is much better than a boring plastic soap dispenser from the store. It would also make for the perfect gift. I couldn't be happier with this. *discount received for testing and review*

This is an awesome little outdoor speaker with an even cooler design! It has a very impressive sound to it and the quality is impressive. It gets loud enough to where my husband can easily be working on his boat outside and can still enjoy music even while using power tools that would usually drown out other speakers. My husband actually hooked it up on a carabiner and let it hang off his back belt loop so the music could follow him while he was working in the yard. The speaker is very lightweight which makes it perfect for portability. The bass on this speaker is excellent for the size of it. Connecting this to our iPhone 6 Plus' took just a few seconds. It connected with no problems at all. I also like that is has an AUX hookup in case you wanted to use an iPod or other device that doesn't have Bluetooth capabilities. This is the perfect speaker for camping, going to the beach, or other outdoor activities because it's waterproof. It charges pretty quickly and the battery life is pretty long too at about 6 hours of play time. So far, we are loving this speaker. My husband grabs it every time he goes outside. It's rugged, waterproof, and has great sound. There is nothing negative about this speaker I can say. *product provided free for testing and review*

This hammock is very impressive It's so lightweight but it can hold up to 265lbs. It's a very durable polyester. The hammock is perfect for taking on camping or backpacking trips as it's very portable. It comes in a small little attached sack that can easily fit in a backpack. It's extremely easy to set up too. This is a very convenient hammock to have around and is made very well. The hammock measures 8 feet 6 inches long and is 4 feet 6 inches wide so it is very roomy and comfortable. You're able to relax in it and not worry about making one small move and falling over. The best part about this is the price as it's very budget friendly. Overall, I'm very impressed with the quality of this hammock and definitely recommend it! *discount received for testing and review*

This is a gorgeous multicolored ombre shower curtain. It instantly added color and fun to my guest bathroom. The colors are beautiful on it and quite vibrant. The curtain is made of high quality polyester and is not cheap at all. I hung it with a shower liner behind it and it's absolutely perfect. It is the perfect size. The stitching is perfect and it was very easy to hang up. It is also very light and airy too. I love that this shower curtain is also machine washable. This kids cozy fleece blanket is very high quality. It's just as good as the ones you see on TV and get at mass retailers. It is very soft and the colors are very vibrant. These are great stainless steel coffee scoops. They are one tablespoon and that is just enough to fill a reusable k-cup pod with the perfect amount of coffee. The spoons are solid and very durable. These curtains are fantastic. on my computer screen the blue ones looked more of a silver-ish blue but once I received them they are definitely more light blue colored. They are very nice curtains, well made, and solid. They aren't very thin but they let just the right amount of light into my spare bedroom. The large grommets on the top of the curtains make it easy for them to glide open and closed across my curtain rod. The grommets are securely attached to the curtains and I have noticed no loose threads. The embroidered leaf design on the panels adds a beautiful elegance to the panels that I just really enjoy. I love that I get two panels in this set for such an affordable price. Typically I would be paying this price for one cheap panel at any big name store. I'm very happy with this simple yet affordable panels that instantly added a nice touch to my spare bedroom. I wasn't disappointed. *I received this product free in exchange for an honest review*

This 12 piece makeup brush set from Nuturu is fantastic. It includes every brush you need to create the perfect daily makeup look. The brushes came in a nicely size, perfect for travel case that looks very sleek and professional. While not traveling the case is perfect to have the brushes displayed on top of my vanity ready for me to grab. The brushes themselves are very soft with dense bristles. The ferrules are strong on them and are not loose at all. I love every single brush in this set. I can easily create an every day eye look or a more drastic smokey eye with the brushes included. I love the tapered blending brush in this set. It is the perfect size. The angled contour brush is perfect for applying blush, highlight, or contouring. The brushes all pick up a good amount of powder and don't waste much or create a lot of unnecessary fallout. While washing the brushes I didn't lose tons of hairs either which was great. These are really flexible and are easy to maneuver into the corners of my dishes to get every little piece of baked on food. I love that these scrubbers are made with silicone so they don't harbor any bacteria that creates mold and mildew. I don't have to worry about mold developing inside these! I also don't notice any gross pieces of food getting stuck inside these either which I notice with other scrub sponges. Zoey is so happy with her new toy from L&H Guerra Ltd. As soon as she got a hold of this one she was shaking it all around the room! There are two things I absolutely love right here: candles and pumpkin pie. I am a major candle fiend and have one burning in the house daily. When I look for candles I like ones that have a strong throw so they fill up my main living area. This candle definitely delivers not only in appearance but in fragrance. As soon as I opened the box my nose was over joyed with the delicious aroma of pumpkin pie while this candle was still wrapped in plastic! The candle is absolutely adorable and looks so good. I set this candle on my table for a few days, still in the plastic wrap, and every single time I walk by I smell it from 5 feet away! Even with my Yankee Candles or Bath & Body Works candles I have to put my nose right up to them to get that cold sniff. As soon as I took the plastic wrap off and lit it the aroma was even better. This is the perfect candle for fall. It is so inviting, so delicious, and instantly perks my mood up. It reminds me of Thanksgiving, of that pumpkin pie baking in the oven for dessert. It is not an artificial pumpkin pie smell at all. To me, it is authentic and that is what I love so much about it! The candle burns slowly too which means it'll last me a long time. I almost didn't even want to burn it because it looked so beautiful but as soon as I smelled it I had to and I do not regret it. The throw of this candle is worth more than 5 stars. I can smell this candle all the way down my hallway and into my bedroom where I have never been able to smell any other candle that was burning in my dining room.This is definitely a must have candle for fall and I am so glad I have this in my home. I absolutely love this candle. *discount received for testing and review*

This is one of those things that you hope to never have to use but if you ever do you hope you have one! It's a great thing to have in case of emergencies. Since this set comes with two both my husband and I can each have one in our vehicles. I love that this is a multi-use item that can potentially save your life. It has a steel blade to quickly and effectively cut your seat belt away from you. It has a double sided head of hardened steel points to shatter your windows if you're ever trapped and quickly need to escape your vehicle. It also has a mounting bracket so you can easily install it where it is easily and quickly accessible when needed. Not only can it save your life but if you ever are at the right moment at the right time you can save someone else's life with this product. It seems very sturdy and like a well made product. It's always important to be prepared so I'm happy to have these in our vehicles! *I received this product free in exchange for my honest review*

I usually use Joico K-Pak shampoo but decided to give this a try. I've been using it every time I wash my hair (which is about every three days) for the past few weeks. So far I'm impressed with how it makes my hair feel. It makes my hair feel very soft and manageable. I notice once blow dried or even air dried it is less frizzy. This is a great sulfate free shampoo that is safe for color treated hair. The Argan oil nourishes my hair and protects my color which is a plus. I don't even use conditioner with this shampoo and still find my hair nice and soft. The only draw back for me is the price. This is just what my husband needed. As a construction worker he works with his hands and heavy machinery all day. Wearing a normal metal ring in his line of work could be very dangerous. He has watched some friends get their hands caught by their rings and the results weren't pretty. We then decided he needed to switch his wedding ring to a silicone one. He had another one before this one but he ended up losing a bit of weight in his hands and it became too big. This was the perfect replacement. I love the infinity symbol on the ring so much. It just means so much to both of us like our love will go on forever. The ring fit him perfectly and is very comfortable. He can easily do everything he needs to at work without worrying about anything happening because this ring is silicone where as a traditional wedding ring is metal and would conduct electricity which would be very dangerous. I love that this ring will break away at 40lbs. of pressure too which is a great safety feature of it. A lot of the recipes are so easy to make too. They are so much more natural and better for you than drugs filled with harmful chemicals. This UV flashlight couldn't have came at a more perfect time. I noticed a strong cat urine odor in our bedroom and was looking all over the place for it. I used this light and checked everywhere. I wasn't finding anything until I looked under the bed. Two big spots of yellow just lit up super bright on the hardwood floor. With just the regular bedroom light on those spots were not visible at all. This light made them very bright, very florescent, and easily noticeable. After taking the cat to the vet and finding out she had a UTI this light has been very helpful the past few days as she continues to urinate under the bed. Now I can find the spots easily instead of waiting for the strong odor to start. It's a great light and the textured grip is also very comfortable to hold. I had another UV light similar to it but it wasn't as bright as this one. This one you don't have to get extremely close to the spot. I can easily walk around the room with the light and check without getting on my hands and knees or bending over trying to get close to where I think a spot could be. This is a great light to find pet urine spots and even after cleaning the area with Nature's Miracle I can go back with this light to ensure I got every last bit of the mess! *I received this product free in exchange for my honest review*

The drawers glide open so easily and the handles are just the right size to grab. I love the included removable mesh liner inside the drawers to prevent either makeup or jewelry from sliding around in the drawers. It keeps everything nice and organized.  The drawers are the perfect size for my everyday eye shadow palettes or blushes. I can easily fit one or two shadow palettes depending on the size of them. The top can be used for so many different things from foundations, primers, blushes, moisturizers, lip glosses, mascaras, truly anything you can think of. That is why I love this organizer. You can put anything you want in it. It is absolutely perfect for your go-to makeup items that you typically grab for. No more digging through my drawers. I can easily keep everything I love right in this acrylic organizer on top of my vanity. It goes great with any decor because it's clear and it looks so fabulous. It's made very well and completely solid. I honestly don't have a single complaint about this organizer. This book is exactly what I was looking for!! It has everything I needed to learn about all the uses for coconut oil from cooking with it in many different ways including baking cookies, coconut oil uses for the skin, and seriously so much more. This book is jam packed. It tells you the different types of coconut oils, their benefits, and exactly what oils are best for what. There are so many different coconut oils on the shelves at the store and this book will help you pick exactly what one is best for you. I always wondered what the difference between fractionated and un-fractionated coconut oil was and why it was so important to get the un-fractionated oil to use on my skin. Now I know! This book has given me so many DIY ideas and recipes to make my own beauty products which will save me money and be much more natural. The photos in the book are beautiful, the writing is done well, and I have thoroughly enjoyed looking through this book. I was so excited to get this pet carrier for my cat because it's so hard getting her into a hard crate to take to the vet. I was really disappointed in the size when it arrived. I ordered the medium and it says it's for pets up to 10 pounds. My cat is only 7 pounds so I figured that would allow her some sort of wiggle room. She barely fit in it. Once I zipped it shut she didn't have much space on the sides or above her. This would have been perfect for a vet appointment because she actually had walked right into it herself as it looks much less intimidating than a hard crate. The carrier is nice though and would be great if it were larger. I think the large size would be more suitable for her, even though this one should have worked since she is three pounds under the limit. I did like that it included the soft fleece bed. The choice of handles or a shoulder strap is nice. All the zippers work well and I LOVED that the zippers included a buckle to secure them once they were zipped together to give them extra security. I also like that it has a seat belt loop so you can safely secure the carrier during car trips to the vet. I unfortunately did not get to test that today when I went to the vet. I had to opt for my hard carrier. The screens are great so the pet inside can easily see its surroundings all around. This is still a nice quality carrier and may come in handy in the future if I ever add another kitten to the family. *discount received for testing and review*

This is by far the coolest thermometer I have ever used. As an adult, when I'm sick I absolutely hate having to put a thermometer under my tongue for a minute especially when I can't breathe through my nose. This thermometer is perfect for all ages, not just for children and infants. The fact that it's a forehead thermometer and ear thermometer in one is awesome. It means you don't have to buy multiple devices and saves money and drawer space. Right out of the box it was easy to use especially since it came with batteries. Now, since I don't have a high temp at the moment I wasn't able to see the red back light but I find that feature to be really cool. If you're in the normal temperature range the LED back light will be green. If you have a high temperature the LED back light will be red and there will be an alarm that beeps. Great product! Exactly what my husband needed for his hardhat to keep his forehead dry working outside in the hot Louisiana summer heat. He said they're very comfortable to wear and easy to attach to his hardhat. Absolutely a must have!

This is seriously the coolest quick draw gun magnet ever. As soon as I opened the box this magnet was in it grabbed the scissors I used to open the box. This magnet is VERY powerful. It was in a white envelope in the box so I had no idea what it was force-ably magnetizing my scissors from my hands. Moving on. My husband decided to install the magnet above the our headboard in the bedroom. It was easy to install. Just two simple screws. We tested out a few different guns. Our KSG wasn't able to be held by it because the gun was too slick. AR-15 held up PERFECTLY! Hand guns were held up easily as well. The magnet holding up the AR-15 was impressive. It does say it holds up to 25 LBS. which  an AR isn't nearly that heavy but it was nice to be able to have it handy right next to the bed mounted on the wall in case of an intruder. The release from the magnet is very easy. I had no trouble grabbing a gun and pulling it away (with some force) but the magnet is powerful enough to hold the gun in place and you do not have to worry about the gun falling. Only when pulling at the gun will it come off this magnet. Overall, my husband and I were both very impressed with this magnet. We are a bit worried about the strength of the magnet possibly damaging weapons and possibly scratching them so I may add some felt or some foam to the front of it for some extra protection. Guns slam against it quickly and I'd rather not bang up costly guns. *discount received for testing and review*

I was beyond excited to receive these in the mail until I realized I couldn't use them due to an allergy to cocoa butter. Let's face it: JURASSIC PARK rocked, the sequels were...meh. THE LOST WORLD was fun, and the third was essentially a waste of 90 minutes, despite Sam Neill and William H. Macy somehow being in the mix. So my expectations for JURASSIC WORLD, the continuation of a franchise that shaped my childhood to an unhealthy degree, were admittedly low.Well, I sat in the theater for two hours...smiling and cheering. Well, internally. Is JURASSIC WORLD a "good" movie, per say? Nope. But then, neither was the first, really; fun, exciting, awesome--but it was never gonna win Best Picture. And neither will WORLD. But what it does is capture some of the excitement of the first--partly through a ton of throwbacks, mostly via its fun, thrilling, wryly humorous atmosphere. This is helped in large part by some incredible CGI, and Chris Pratt as the lead: a wisecracking, macho man with a vest and a rifle and a pack of raptors. Yeah, that's right: his own pack of raptors. And it actually makes sense, as much as anything in the JURASSIC universe makes sense.The plot is largely inconsequential: a "fake" (get it? as opposed to "real"?) dinosaur gets loose, wrecking havoc on a theme park. Come on; you aren't watching this for the plot. You aren't watching this for Bryce Dallas Howard to run around the entire film in heels and somehow never trip. You aren't watching this for shallow character development and improbably action scenes. You're watching this for the thrills, the laughs, the feeling of being a ten year old chugging down Diet Coke and popcorn and grinning ear-to-ear. And JURASSIC WORLD delivers this in spades. It's got me excited for further installments, and considering I had low expectations to start with, that's pretty darn impressive.

Jay, a young Scotsman, travels across the west in search of his love Rose. Unbeknownst to him, Rose and her father have a bounty on their heads, and are pursued by a band bounty hunters, most especially Silas, who uses the boy to find the girl. Jay is about to learn that the west is truly wild, and that even love may not overcome all of its dangers.Written and directed by John Maclean, SLOW WEST comes off feeling like a slight film in many ways: the story is small, the themes small, the film itself short (less than 90 minutes), and the pace rather rapid. The focus is on characters who are never truly developed, despite rock-solid performances. Leads Jodi Smit-McPhee and Michael Fassbender are nearly flawless, and supporting roles (especially Ben Mendelsohn, Caren Pistorius, and Rory McCann) help add a certain poignancy that would otherwise be lacking.Still, there's a lot of positive here. It's well-directed; the script is strong if not ground-breaking. The film's target audience probably isn't western fans, or even people like myself who prefer "anti-westerns" (UNFORGIVEN, NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN, etc). It's more a tragic love story, and if you take it as such, it's worth a viewing. Maybe not everything it could've been, but SLOW WEST is still worthwhile, and if nothing else a promise of good things to come from writer/directer Maclean.

Normally, I begin my movie reviews with a brief rehash of the plot, usually ending with some sort of melodramatic teaser designed to lure you in (if I like a film) or make you smirk (if I don't). However, for a film like AVENGERS: AGE OF ULTRON, most of you know what you're getting into: your quirky band of heroes banding together to save the world. So going over the plot is largely pointless. Basically, Tony Stark gets a little egomaniacal, creates an A.I. using technology he doesn't understand, and now the Avengers have to assemble to stop nothing short than the total extinction of the human species.AGE OF ULTRON is the closest Marvel has come to making a "dark" comic book film (in the vein of the DC Batman films, for comparison). And the over-arching theme here is actually pretty dark: ultimate peace can only come with death. Yeah, deep. Obviously, Joss Whedon and company aren't going to beat you over the head with any of this; AGE OF ULTRON is, like the first film, laced with humor and wit. James Spader, as the titular villain, is nothing short of spectacular--he's menacing and terrifying, and yet utterly hilarious, coming off as something of a petulant teenager. There are also a few extra layers given to Jeremy Renner and Scarlet Johansson's characters, which gives the actors a little more room to maneuver. And the addition of the not-mutants--thanks, copyright laws--is actually seamless. Aaron Taylor-Jonson and Elizabeth Olsen are solid; they join Spader and the returning cast, all of whom turn in reliably good performances. Kudos also to Andy Serkis in his cameo, which as I understand it is to be expanded later in the Marvel universe.This last statement leads me to what is probably this film's largest flaw: it's filler. Really, that's what it is. Yes, it has great performances, a solid script, and themes that truly make you think. (And, yes, James Spader. He needs to be relevant again. Seriously, of all the treats in this film, his performance is tops.) It's not a weak movie; this is as much a product of love from Whedon as the first film, and it's a thrill ride from start to finish. That said...yeah, it's filler. It's building towards storylines that are yet to come in the Marvel universe. There's a sense of ho-hum here that ultimately knocks the movie down a few pegs, considering the gravity of the themes that the are pursued. It's a good film; it's even worth repeated viewings. But is it everything it could've been? Unfortunately, no. But, hey: what's here is pretty darn good. Anything to keep the novelty of Robert Downey Jr. being an action hero going, right?

Bonnie Jo Campbell's MOTHERS, TELL YOUR DAUGHTERS is a blunt, honest glimpse into the lives of ordinary, every day women. People like yourself. The collection has two great strengths: Campbell's honesty, and the quality of her prose. She isn't afraid to show the grit and warts that go with her characters.However, there is one major flaw with this collection: it gets repetitive very quickly. While her prose, as mentioned, is solid, she uses an awful lot of second person (you, your, etc.). Any college creative writing instructor will tell you to limit your use of the second person, and with good reason: it tends to stand out when it's used, therefore use sparingly. Campbell does not. Also, themes such as rape and cancer work their way into almost every story here. Again, not a bad thing, if you can take these stories one at a time. But they're collected together for a reason: to be read together. And as such, a little more variety is warranted.Ultimately, MOTHERS, TELL YOUR DAUGHTERS is a collection of very good stories, but is itself only a ho-hum collection. If you're willing to read one story every few days, then you should probably give it a shot; like I said, the writing is very good, and the characters are painfully realistic. But I prefer my short fiction collections to gel as a whole, and ultimately MOTHERS does not.

Eight miles below the surface may lie the secret to humanity's survival. A terrifying new disease is sweeping across the planet. People are slowly forgetting...first, little things. Then more important things. Finally, how to breathe, how to live. But down on the ocean floor, Clayton Nelson is working on a cure. He's the smartest man on Earth, for better or worse. If anyone can do it, it's him. Until things start happening. And communication lines are cut. Clayton's final transmission is a call for help to his brother Luke. But as Luke descends into the depths himself, he finds a world cut straight from his darkest nightmares, from snippets of horror from his troubled childhood. Waiting for him eight miles below the surface is nothing less than Hell itself.I picked up THE DEEP on a whim, thinking, "Yeah, I haven't read a fun little horror novel in a while." THE DEEP isn't fun. Not in the sense I was expecting. Nick Cutter (an alias of author Craig Davidson; hell, even the copyright is in his name) isn't in this for fun. THE DEEP is...think of the movie Event Horizon, with its pitch-perfect atmosphere of claustrophobic brutality (all other flaws aside). Now combine that with Michael Creighton's SPHERE, a little of Koontz's PHANTOMS, and a very bad acid trip. Yes, there's a problem in the sense that this novel draws so many references from other sources; but truly original work is hard to come by. What we should be excited about, however, is an original delivery.On this, THE DEEP excels. It starts slow, for a chapter or two...and then BAM!, you're on your own. The imagery is truly disturbing; I had to look away from the page at times. But the whole reason the imagery is so unsettling is because of the atmosphere Cutter has created. The two feed off each other; by the time we reach the novel's unforgiving end (after the first few pages, you'll know not to expect rainbows and butterflies), the reader is left somewhat hollowed out, racked by what they've read. This isn't a perfect horror novel; horror by definition isn't perfect. But it's one of the best horror novels I've read in a long, long time. It does exactly what it sets out to do: tip your reality upside down, chew you up and spit you out. It's one of the few horror novels I've read that is truly an all-around experience.

1977: young punk Carey likes to hang out, drink cheep liquor, start fights, and try to get laid. His friends have pretty much the same attitude. Those that're still around, that is. Because some of them are missing. You see, there are these tar-men who dissolve you into goo, and these glowing balls of light that suck the very life out of you. Also a guy who looks exactly like Iggy Pop, except he's pretty much immortal and of an extremely homicidal bent.2013. Kaitlyn is a stuntwoman/waitress trying to eek out a living in Hollywood. Her friend Jackie drags her to an industry party one night, where Kaitlyn is forced into conversation with the star of 1990s sitcom. Yes, he's hot. But his eyes are rather lifeless...his mannerisms are forced...also there's this weird metallic thing he tries to shove down her throat. And he just won't leave her alone. And he has friends...THE UNNOTICEABLES is a gonad-punch of a novel, a two-minute rock jam of pounding drums and out-of-sync guitars. Robert Brockway has created a very interesting, unique little horror/sci-fi thriller with a punk edge and a healthy sense of dark humor. It has some flaws: his two (well, make that three, near the end) narrators sound a lot alike, and that ending rushes up on you, feels completely forced, and doesn't really resolve anything (not even on an emotional level; the story doesn't feel finished, plain and simple). Normally, that's enough for me to knock off at least one star. But the ride there...man, it's a rush. It's gory and funny and unsettling and all the good little things that make novels like this worthwhile. You haven't quite read anything like it, I'm willing to bet. It's just...hell, it's just plain fun. How often can you say that?

The world of David Cronenberg is a dark and twisting place of shadows and other slithery things. He doesn't get light-hearted; his films may be laced with some incredibly dark humor--such as MAPS TO THE STARS--but they aren't comedies and they aren't going to make you smile. His films are always ABOUT something, but it's not something easily discernible. It's not necessarily something you will understand.Got that? Okay. Here's the problem with MAPS TO THE STARS: it's pretty accessible, for a Cronenberg film. And yet...it's still a Cronenberg film. It's not really a dissection of celebrity culture, inasmuch as it's a psycho-drama about family secrets and hereditary violence that just happens to play upon the charade of acting and the indulgence of celebrity. The plot essentially revolves around Agatha (an incredible Mia Wasikowska), a scarred young woman with a tenuous relationship with celebrity (she claims to have struck up a relationship with Carrie Fisher on Twitter). Naturally, very little is as it initially seems. Cue some truly disturbing imagery (disturbing, not graphic, though yes, it gets graphic eventually) that mixes dreams and reality, and a violent conclusion that doesn't tie too many threads together, but isn't supposed to, either.MAPS TO THE STARS isn't for everyone. It's for Cronenberg fans pretty much, except it's kind of Cronenberg-lite. Oh, there are some true gems here; Wasikowska is fantastic, Julianne Moore is superb, Evan Bird is pitch-perfect, and John Cusak finally gets to sink his teeth into a Cronenberg role (something I've been waiting on for a long time; Cusak is an underrated actor, thanks largely to the schlock he does to fund more independent work like this). The cinematography is on-point, and the dialogue and imagery, not to mention the sure-handed direction, is what you expect from a Cronenberg film. The themes are right up his alley and executed more-or-less effectively. But...but it just feels empty. Moments of near-greatness, surrounded by mediocrity, don't make a great film. Perhaps if this were a new filmmaker, I would be saying, "This film has a ton of promise; I can't wait for great things in the future." But this is David Cronenberg; by this point, we can expect greatness. Obviously, we aren't always going to get it; art doesn't work that way. And MAPS TO THE STARS has much to offer its viewers, if you can put up with feeling very uncomfortable (if you're a Cronenberg fan, you're used to this). But it isn't everything it could have been. It's a promising film from a director who, more times than not, exceeds that promise.

The call it the Grizzly Maze: a swath of Alaskan forest that, supposedly, even grizzlies can get lost in. As boys, Beckett and Rowan's father refused to take hunters there, feeling it was sacred ground. Well, that hallowed territory has been invaded by human poachers. And one bear in particular is very, very, VERY pissed off. Trying to stop its rampage are a sheriff's deputy, his wayward brother, his wife, another deputy because the brother needs a love interest, and a poacher played by Billy Bob Thornton...because.As you may have guessed by the above paragraph, I'm kind of down on INTO THE GRIZZLY MAZE. I went into it with so-so hopes. Thomas Jane is a grossly underrated actor, and James Marsden has shown some promise; also, when given the right material, Billy Bob Thornton can really tear into a character. Put those three (plus Scott Glenn, for God's sake!) into a B-grade throwback to the nature-vs-man horror films of the seventies (specifically, ahem, GRIZZLY), and you've got a recipe for a fun, thrilling little movie. Well...promise is all you get. The acting is mostly solid (Glenn is utterly wasted; Piper Perabo is helped by the fact that her character is deaf, and therefore she doesn't have to speak), but the script is just God-awful. I mean so bad, Thornton's character blurts out "this ain't your average bear" in complete seriousness. Plus, you have the gratuitous gore shots that actually FEEL gratuitous. And the CGI, when it's used, is laughable. (Granted, small budget; but hey, if you can't afford good CGI, stick to practical effects.)Honestly, I'd recommend INTO THE GRIZZLY MAZE only if you have nothing else to watch. I was in the mood, with limited hopes, but even then, I felt disappointed. There's the heart of a decent film here--a horror feature centered around the brothers' troubled relationship--but it throws too much into the mix. If the movie had been a little longer, a little simpler, and written by someone else, it would come more highly recommended.

Shortly after his mother's death, Ryosuke visits his parents' house. In his father's office he finds four notebooks, recently pulled from the back of the closet. As Rosuke starts to flip through them, he discovers something truly unsettling: the books seem to chronicle the growth of a psychopathic killer. The notebooks were clearly written by either Ryo's mother or father. But who? And is this some heretofore undisclosed propensity for fiction...or a memoir?NAN-CORE, by Mahokaru Numata, is, at its best, truly unnerving. There are passages that make you shiver. It's really a crime novel...of sorts...but at its best, it hits all the right elements of horror. It's short, and moves along perhaps too briskly, until the final few pages, which actually slow down too much. And yet, the imagery is vivid, the story is gripping, and the repercussions are truly disturbing. Not for the faint of heart.

A new Roger Alan Wade album is like a breath of fresh barroom air. With just his acoustic guitar and rich, workingman baritone, Wade writes and sings beautifully poetic country songs (interspersed with raunchy party numbers, though BAD NEWS KNOCKIN' fits entirely in the former category)."Warm Spanish Wine" and "The Ballad of Shine Marley" may be two of the most beautiful numbers he's written, while "Red Shoes Blues" continues his knack for finding unexpected, yet strangely appropriate ways of comparing love to everyday life. "I Lived the Life" is the obligatory outlaw ballad--obligatory only in the sense that its inclusion is expected; the song itself is, again, oddly poetic. Wade may have made a name of himself by collaborating with cousin Johnny Knoxvile and his Jackass gang, yet those in the know are aware that he's one of the most sensitive songwriters out there. BAD NEWS KNOCKIN' isn't his best album; check out STONED TRAVELLER (I whip out "Brainerd Road/Kingfisher Blues" whenever I feel like showing my friends what true songcraft sounds like) for that distinction. Yet this may be his second best overall effort; and in the Roger Alan Wade catalogue, second-best is still better than practically anything you're likely to hear through the mainstream outlets.

Ah, yes, beautiful young people are getting away for the weekend. And oh, hey, they're up to shenanigans. And there's a neighbor with a gun who has some ominous premonitions. Also people dying. And blood. And, you know, zombie beavers.ZOMBEAVERS is exactly what you think it is. And more. It's a cheap horror comedy with sh***y special effects, and a soundtrack that features a Frank Sintra-esque song called...well, "Zombeavers." I mean...come on, man. you know what you're getting. And yet, how's this: it's funny. It's legitimately laugh-out-loud funny. The script is kind of like Joss Whedon's demented brother. it's not a perfect film; it meanders in spots. But when it hits, it hits hard. It's definitely better than it has any right to be. You'll laugh, you'll cringe, you'll remember it. And for cheap horror comedies, that's saying something.

A young woman is going to her parents' old cabin in the woods to take pictures, because her mother is too stingy to have a realtor do it. Of course, her boyfriend invites a bunch of people along, because young folks have to party and go wild all the time. And naturally they get there after a string of disappearances and strange occurrences, which has roused the suspicion of the local sheriff. And, as you may expect, they stumble upon something totally unexpected, with deadly consequences.EXTRATERRESTRIAL doesn't really miss its mark. That's because it's not really aiming for anything. It's just sort of...there. The acting is actually pretty good (Michael Ironside showing up and proving he's still the best, Gil Bellows doing a great job in a supporting role as the sheriff), but the direction and script are just...blah. I can't think of another way to describe it. There's a sense of humor about the film that's admirable (CABIN IN THE WOODS-lite, make that super lite), but ultimately it's a horror film without any depth and no real substance, despite an ending that makes you want to think otherwise (which you can see coming a mile away, without binoculars). The characters are interchangeable (not a fault of the actors, who do a good job with what they're given); the plot is hokey, and everything feels contrived. Special effects are okay when they're relevant, but this would've been a much better movie if the aliens had never actually appeared on-film. Ultimately, this is a popcorn film that even fails to achieve that low mark; yeah, it'll entertain you, but you may as well watch something else for an hour and a half.

Mary Bee Cuddy is a single woman living on the frontier, unable to find a husband. When three women in town go insane, she volunteers to take them back across the Missouri River, to a church in Iowa. To help her, she recruits a forlorn drifter calling himself George Briggs. Together, they endure a harsh winter and the unforgiving frontier in an effort to do the right thing for their own reasons.THE HOMESMAN is a beautiful and haunting film, based on the novel by Glendon Swarthout (I haven't read it yet but I aim to). The lead performances from Hillary Swank and Tommy Lee Jones are flawless, and a plethora of name actors show up and fill out their bit parts: Meryl Streep, James Spader, John Lithgow, Barry Corbin, Hailee Steinfeld, Jesse Plemmons, Tim Blake Nelson, and William Fichtner all have cameo roles that help round out the film. Jones's direction is solid; the film drags a little as it reaches the middle, but a dark change in direct breathes new life into the plot. The story is original, and the characters, if not entirely likable, are interesting and three-dimensional; also, Jones has cast himself somewhat against type (at first, at least; by the film's end he's the same curmudgeonly bad*** you'd expect), and it's nice to see him crack a smile on occasion. But truly, THE HOMESMAN is a solid western that takes the tropes you'd expect from the modern "anti-western" and pits them against an interesting and compelling storyline. It's a film with layers that welcomes repeated viewings.

Shirley Jackson is a grossly underrated writer. Casual readers know her for two works: her dreary post-apocalyptic short story "The Lottery," read in pretty much every high school English program; and THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE, which set the standard for modern haunted house stories. It's easy to ignore her enormous body of work, short stories and novels that poke and prod and, yes, often times unsettle and play hell with the nerves.LET ME TELL YOU: NEW STORIES, ESSAYS, AND OTHER WRITINGS encompasses the traits that make Jackson such a pleasure to read. This is a collection of unpublished fiction, including very early fiction; essays that vary on topics (a raucous tribute to Dr. Seuss, an ode to her haunted house); humorous musings on domestic life; and a few brief pieces (mostly lectures) about writing. Throughout the nonfiction, readers will find a delightfully cynical sense of humor (remember: "The Lottery" is a very funny story in a very, very dark vein). The nonfiction is fun to read but not really worth the price of admission; you're coming here for the fiction, mostly, and though the stories are strong independently (except for the earliest pieces, which are here for curiosity's sake), taken together they're a bit repetitive, as the same themes get played with in back-to-back pieces.Now, that's not to undermine Jackson's body of work; she's one of the great 20th century American writers, known mostly for horror and ghost stories but truly just an all-around gifted writer. But LET ME TELL YOU is more for the die-hard fan, who can't wait to get their hands on anything Jackson has written. Which, let's face it, fits a lot of people. I'm giving this collection 3 stars because, as a whole, it's hit-and-miss; but when it hits, it hits with a sucker punch--sometimes unsettling, sometimes downright hilarious.

FISHBOWL chronicles the events in the lives of a select few inhabitants of the Seville on Roxy, starting with Katie and Connor, a beautiful young woman in love and her boyfriend who's seeing someone on the side. The story is bookended, such as it were, by Connor's goldfish Ian, whose existential outlook on life (inherent in his nature, as a creature who views life as a series of momentary images) perfectly fits his latest plight: he he rapidly falling twenty-seven stories to the street below.Bradley Somer's FISHBOWL has a unique take on its theme, with the incorporation of Ian, which allows the author to vent his omniscient knowledge. The prose is solid, too, and there's a nice bitter sense of humor that underlines everything. That said, Ian's tale is easily the most interesting; the short chapters keep the reader going, but after a while it slowly dawns: these characters are basically boring. Other than the framing device, and Somer's admittedly sure-handed tone, there isn't really anything here you haven't seen before. There's no edge, just the glimmer of an edge.If FISHBOWL had embraced its uniqueness, then with Somer's solid writing, it would've been a four or five star review easily.But as it is, it's a series of short interlacing chapters about characters we don't really care about...and Ian, whose tale deserves an entire novel in and of itself.

In this lyrical, almost poetic collection of short fiction, music, war, and culture clash. A professor makes a career-altering mistake about a student. The producer of a reality TV show coerces a couple to fall in love, while she simultaneously grows distant from her own partner. A woman discovers that her piano has become haunted by the very physical presence of Johann Sebastian Bach.MUSIC FOR WARTIME is a strongly cohesive, thematic collection. Rarely do stories come together to paint a larger picture like they do here, which is easily the collection's strength. On the other hand, the stories have a sense of pretension about them. They feel like M.F.A. workshop stories in many ways--though Rebecca Makkai is clearly a very strong, very talented writer. Her prose is almost poetic in spots. However, there's a sense of "so what" that pervades many of these stories, when taken individually. As such, it's not a literary collection for everyone, but if you like "higher" contemporary literature, you'll find a few small treasures here.

Picking up where the Black Crowes left off, Blackberry Smoke seamlessly blends Southern rock and country, creating songs that charge and chug, mostly polished but with enough of an edge to still grate against the grain. I'll admit that this is my first outing with the band; I caught "Rock & Roll Again" on Sirius (in my first week of having it!) and I was hooked. Most of the album follows a similar vein: propulsive Southern rock with country melodies, electric guitars sometimes segueing to drop-tuned acoustic riffs.The album is anchored by lead vocalist/guitarist Charlie Starr's lyrics: poetic but not too pretentious, bland and cliched only on occasion. To someone used to mainstream country or rock, this album will probably be like a straight-shot to the throat. But hopefully most of us know that genuinely good music exists out there. I'm rather ashamed I didn't know about Blackberry Smoke before now (hey, I'm an Illinois boy, cut me some slack), but HOLDING ALL THE ROSES has me hooked and jonesing for some more.

Nola Lantri is a slightly-introverted, sarcastic young woman with a mind-numbing job at the local courthouse. It suits her; the companionship of others sometimes makes her feel self-conscious about her own life. Which is made even more complicated by the fact that Nola is a tracist: she can sense the energy that leaves the body when a person dies. She can't tell you how or with what or why a person died, just where. It's a limited skillset, but for those who have the need--like Jack Dalton, Detective Division Commander of the Redford City Police Department--it's invaluable. Dalton has consulted Nola on a various cases, but none so high-profile as this: Culver Bryant, wealthy real estate developer, gone missing. He's left behind a frosty wife, a hyperactive girlfriend, a slick business partner, and a mysterious half-brother who has a few secrets he seems to be all-too-eager to share. One or all of these individuals is complicit in Culver's disappearance...and when mysterious packages start showing up on Nola' doorstep, she's about to find herself in well over her head, with dark discoveries just around the corner.Letitia L. Moffitt's TRACE is splendid mixture of crime, supernatural chills, romance, and mystery. But it's also a character study--a young woman struggling to find her identity and place in a society she doesn't feel a part of, dealing with a gift very few others have. The novel sets a quick pace, while simultaneously taking you deep into Nola's psyche; and yet, it doesn't reveal everything about its heroine, setting the reader up for future installments. TRACE makes for a nice, quick-paced summer read...but it's also much more than that: an insightful character study set against a romantic thriller background, with a supernatural edge that gives it an extra bite.

Jeanette, Louisiana, has been hit hard by the BP oil spill. The shrimpers in town are all leaving elsewhere. One of those staying behind is  Gus Lindquist, a one-armed man hoping to discover lost pirate treasure. Unfortunately, he's searching on ground operated by the Toup Brothers, twin marijuana dealers with a reputation for being violent and unstable. Weaving in and out of this central struggle are quirky and powerful characters, none so impressive and beautifully drawn as the Louisiana swamp itself.Tom Cooper's THE MARAUDERS is a fun, sometimes funny book with great characters and stellar prose. The story itself isn't all that strong, and some of the characters actually have very little impact on the story itself. That said, these flaws are forgivable and even forgettable. The book moves along quickly and compellingly, towards a climax that comes out of nowhere (in a good way) and leaves you wanting more.

Amelia is a single mother coping with the loss of her husband, trying to figure out her son Samuel's fascination with a monster that lives in his room. Samuel is causing problems at school and in Amelia's admittedly small social life. But really, that's only the beginning. Because Amelia begins sensing that something is wrong as well. That sudden roach infestation. Creaks and groans in the house at night. Shadowy figures haunting her waking and sleeping moments. A reality that begins to spiral into madness, where Amelia isn't sure what is what...or who she is...but she only knows one thing: you can't let the Babadook in.I'd heard this movie got under your skin. And oh boy, does it. I talked a friend who said she'd watched it a few weeks ago and it still haunted her. I found myself shaking while watching it. This is a true blend of psychological and visceral horror. Oh, there's a little gore (not much), and some things that go bump in the night. But as with the best horror films, what truly terrifies in THE BABADOOK is what you don't exactly see, but what you know is going on. What you're terrified is going to happen next. It's a film that builds on itself, descending into a sort of madness that perhaps feels a little too close for comfort.You can thank the lead actors: Essie Davis and the terrific child actor Noah Wiseman. You can thank writer/director Jennifer Kent, who's crafted a magnificent little horror film. The ending plays a little weak, considering the strength of everything that builds up to it, but it's actually rather satisfying when you stop and think about it. And if not...well, THE BABADOOK is so good, and so unnerving, that a couple of minutes isn't going to ruin it for you. It's terrifying. It's hide your eyes behind your hands and peak around your fingers terrifying. I haven't been this scared and giddy in quite a while. A good, good, scary little film.

Most people probably never stop and think about how pervasive illegal drugs have become in today's society. Probably not even if you're using them. And even people who acknowledge the fact that drugs are everywhere probably don't realize their brutal origins. We hear about the Mexican cartel violence almost daily, but it's hard to understand the severity--dare I say, the reality--of the situation unless you're directly affected by it.Hence why Roberto Saviano's ZERO ZERO ZERO is an important book. It is a detailed, unflinching account of the power of cocaine. From its humble--and disgusting--origins, to the violence it inflicts on the body and mind, to the horrific deeds people perpetrate to gain money from it. Saviano chronicles the rise and fall of various gangsters, most of whom you've probably never heard of, but who played an influential role in the chaos we see today. He also manages to sit down with lower level members, people who'll bare their souls due to arrogance, fear, or a fascinating combination of the two. This latter part is where the book really shines--when Saviano puts a face to the violence, lets inside the world as opposed to telling us about it. The only reason I gave this book 4 instead of 5 stars is because the narrative parts become increasingly convoluted. Saviano's prose is poetic; in fact, the introductory segments to each section are absolutely--and terrifyingly--beautiful. But quality prose can't hide an inundation of facts. Yes, it's informative; but it's hard to retain. The overall effect can be one of confusion and disorientation; but then again, that may be what Saviano is going for.Overall, ZERO ZERO ZERO is an important, informative read. It has its flaws, and you may have to force yourself to trudge through some parts. It's also incredibly violent; the violence isn't necessarily rendered in detail, and there aren't any photos, but there's no shying away from the fact that this actually happened...and is happening now. ZERO ZERO ZERO isn't for the feint of heart; but then, as Saviano seems to be suggesting, if things get out of hand, the feint of heart won't have a place in this world any longer.

There's a house not far from Jack's home. It's said ghosts gather there one night a year. Jack doesn't really believe, of course. But Jack is a curious boy, and there's no harm in breaking into the old building. In walking down the halls. In opening that door at the end, with the sliver of light coming out from beneath. Certainly no harm in joining the twelve individuals gathered around the table, each with a candle in front of them and a story to tell.If Dave Shelton's THIRTEEN CHAIRS has a major flaw, it's this: the central story is probably more interesting than the individual tales it weaves around. That said, those stories are chilling in a way that young adult fiction usually isn't. Shelton has a way with narration and language, crafting different voices for each of his stories. There's some gore and violence, though nothing too extreme; this is YA fiction after all. (I think I saw somewhere that this was written for children. I would say 10 and up, but then I was reading Stephen King by the fifth grade, so I'm not a good judge for that.) Mostly (as is, unfortunately, too-frequently pointed out), the true terrors come from what remains unsaid. Which is how good horror, for any audience, should be. THIRTEEN CHAIRS is an enjoyable, and enjoyably unsettling, collection of YA ghost stories by a talented author who knows how to talk to his audience, not talk down to them.

Photojournalist Naomi is in Paris, battling her self-conscious image of herself as unintelligent, while chronicling the cannibalistic murder of a French philosopher, whose husband/prime suspect has vanished. Naomi's boyfriend and fellow journalist Nathan--educated but jealous--finds himself studying a Canadian doctor whose claim to fame is an STD Nathan now suffers, but who has recently dipped into psychological studies involving his daughter.These two cases aren't as disparate as they may first appear, and before long we are plunged into a twisted world of sex and mutilation, philosophy and international politics, where nothing is as it seems.  Cronenberg's CONSUMED plays out much like his films--a violent, sexually charged descent into the world of technological and philosophical consumerism, laced with metaphors and irony and a dark sense of humor that threatens to turn vicious. Cronenberg's prose is surprisingly strong; good screenwriters don't always make good novelists, but he brings the same aesthetic here that he did to his earlier films, creating an engulfing world that slowly draws you in.Unfortunately, this is probably more eXistenZ than it is Videodrome: a watered-down version of what might have been. Of course, only Cronenberg's longtime fans may pick up on that; for newcomers, or those who haven't seen his earlier films, this will be a savage sucker punch to the gut (and groin). It builds pace slowly but steadily, and is prone to frequent waxing prosaic that borders on the tedious (though Cronenberg's attention to detail is admirable and frightening). This may not be the great horror/thriller some fans were wanting, but if you enjoy Cronenberg's films, you owe it to yourself to check this out. And if you're unfamiliar with his work...then brace yourself for a psychologically unsettling excursion into perversity that may be a little too close to comfort.

The stories in this collection illustrate a collection of flawed, sometimes morally ambiguous characters. A former police officer decides to help an abused woman get revenge. A young woman attends a chainsaw party on--and under--a frozen lake. Men on a mushroom hunting expedition encounter much more than they bargained for. A cancer-ridden environmentalist decides to take on one more extreme act.Nickolas Butler's BENEATH THE BONFIRE is a superb collection of short fiction, marvelously written, often amusing, occasionally unsettling. His characters are realistic; his plots are deceptively simple. While there are a couple of examples of the by-wrote "literary" pieces (you know the kind: they reek of MFA workshops and expensive cups of non-Starbucks coffee), mostly these stories manage to avoid pretension, which is a nice surprise in a literary collection; usually you have to mix with different genre tropes to get that. BENEATH THE BONFIRE is an accessible, yet well-written collection of fiction that offers a few truths and even more questions that may lead to truths...if you're willing to go there.

Paul and Bea are a disgustingly sweet newlywed couple taking their honeymoon on the lake she frequented as a child. Paul's a bit out of place, but he's in love and willing to take one for the team. But then he wakes up in the middle of the night and finds Bea naked in the woods. She begins acting strange in little ways that seem quirky at first, but begin to build up in a menacing fashion. And the neighboring couple is a bit odd. Perhaps dangerously so. And what's with the sores on Bea's legs, and the fact that Paul isn't entirely sure she's his wife anymore?HONEYMOON is better than it has any right to be. It starts off slow, innocently bland, and doesn't build quickly. It's something of a slow-burner, though by the final 15 minutes, things get reminiscent of David Cronenberg. It's a bit predictable, true, and stories like this inherently have weak endings (though this one is deliciously twisted just the same). But the acting from the two leads, Rose Leslie and Harry Treadway, is absolutely solid, and Leigh Janiak's direction is pretty much spotless. HONEYMOON has its flaws, but it's better than you're probably thinking it is. A nice, freaky little film.

Chuck Palahniuk is one of those authors I keep returning to every chance I get, even though I've actually enjoyed only a small portion of his work. HAUNTED is a classic; FIGHT CLUB is good if only for the promise it showed (fulfilled in the far-better film version). BEAUTIFUL YOU wasn't too shabby.  And some of the stories in MAKE SOMETHING UP: STORIES YOU CAN'T UNREAD are truly enjoyable. Although, with Palahniuk, "enjoyable" isn't necessarily the most appropriate word.The problem is, many of these stories come off as unremarkable, almost as if they're here simply for the sake of inclusion.  And some of them, like a lot of Palahniuk's work, seem to go simply for the gross-out. Palahniuk is always at his best when he uses "gross-out" humor for a higher purpose. "The Toad Prince," in this collection, is a prime example: a stomach-churning little ditty about body manipulation that is actually more than the sum of its parts. Elsewhere, Palahniuk goes for more emotional bent; "Knock Knock" is gut-wrenching for an entirely different reason. That's the thing about this collection that makes it most enjoyable: at times, Palahniuk shows a sense of heart and compassion that isn't as readily apparent in his novels.Ultimately, MAKE SOMETHING UP will be an enjoyable read for Palahniuk's legions of die-hard fans. Or those like me who simply keep reading him looking for...something. Love him or hate him, there's no denying that Palahniuk has one of the most unique literary voices on the scene today. This collection is hit and miss at best; but some of you won't care, and for others, it's simply worth the experience.

Peter Wells is an American petty crook who's wound up in Egypt in the early 1950s, after a rather nasty stint in Mexico and some wild-catting in Texas. Coming to alone and robbed in a strange room, he eventually finds his way--as all American expats do--to a bar, where a British man offers him a drink and a job: meet a beautiful French woman for dinner. Turns out, she has another job. It involves a hunchback with a dark secret, a beautiful German lounge singer with a dark secret, a suave Egyptian businessman with a dark secret, and a corrupt Egyptian police officer with a dark secret. And that's not even counting the revolution that's slowly brewing in the streets.Gore Vidal's THIEVES RUN OUT is pretty much everything you'd want in an international pulp novel: blood, bullets, and beautiful dames. Yes, it hasn't necessarily aged well (a main character named Mohammed Ali; racial stereotypes that are cringe-worthy), but it's a product of its time. I always love when a more "literary" author decides to schlub it up with the rest of us; the results can be surprising. Is THIEVES RUN OUT a lost classic? No, not really. But it's good fun, with a sense of humor and an eye for genre tropes (and breaking them, in spots). Another fine entry in the Hard Case Crime cannon.

After the world is thrown into a deep freeze, the last vestiges of humanity are trapped aboard a speeding train, arranged by class: the poorest in the tail, eating protein bars and being culled and ordered around by those from the front, the aristocrats who dine on steak and sushi. But a revolution is brewing, led by the headstrong Curtis. Their goal: to make it to the front of the train. By any means necessary.SNOWPIERCER is flawed. Let's get that out of the way first: on hindsight, it doesn't really make much sense. The story is delightfully dark and twisted (it's not a feel-good movie), but doesn't stand up to much scrutiny.
