It's easy to take apart for cleaning; truth be told, after I remove the blade and the adjustable back plate, I put it in the sink and hose around the blade and base to be sure I've gotten all of the meat grub out of it, then turn it on end to let it drain thoroughly and grease the gears before I reassemble the blade and stow it.  I use this for slicing roasts, including pork, beef and boneless turkey breast.  I don't try to get deli thin slices, just nice, thin slices suitable for the dinner plate.  When you have to slice 3 to 6 pound roasts, as I do to properly feed my hungry hordes (depending upon how many are home), a slicer is a great time saver.  The carriage rests on a slightly slanted base, which helps to keep the meat in the right location.  The thickness guide is marked in 25 divisions, and it is capable of cutting something to about 1" thick.  I've never tried it on bread or anything other than cooked meat, but I suspect it would work just fine on raw meat, and I think it might need a different blade to keep from tearing or crushing the bread.  It is a pretty big unit, so you need to have some storage space for it, but if you have to slice a lot of meat, it's a great time saver.

In this book, Cameron Gates and her new husband, prosecutor Joshua Thornton, begin to click for the reader.  Cameron meets a sweet little old lady, Dolly, who asks her to investigate the 20 year old murder of one of her girls.  Then Dolly is murdered.  Other connected murders, which occurred 10, 20 or more years ago, begin to surface.  Well written, this book keeps you guessing.  And Irving the skunk-looking cat makes his appearance in this book, which I find amusing as well.

Wood is good!  We replaced a 1952 toilet recently, and while the old seat fit the new toilet, it was kind of chipped on the underside and looked rather ugly.  A wood toilet seat feels much more solid than the plastic variety; since all of my fixtures are white, this was a natural color choice.  It installs easily, and the price is actually better than at some of the "big box" stores.  I've ordered a second seat for another bathroom.  The dimensions of the actual seat are 14" wide by 16" deep (excluding the bolts), and this is considered "round", not "elongated".  I was confused about that, so I thought I'd offer clarification in case anyone else needs it.

Good value for a package of toothbrushes.  These are brand name, and so a known quality, and this price was fair.  I like to keep some extra toothbrushes around for when my older kids come home and forget toiletries, or sometimes they bring a guest and stay the night, so the guest can feel welcome.  A variety of colors makes it easy to recognize which one is whose.

I bought this in the ivory color to wear with my dress for my daughter's wedding.  It feels very silky and soft, and has a sheen to it.  It is very lightweight, and therefore not too warm.  It was warm enough for indoors on a 48 degree day, but didn't really help when we stepped outside for photographs.  It did look pretty, and I'll probably wear it to other somewhat dressy events this holiday season.

My compactor is 25 years old, and the bag caddy has been weak for years.  I was really excited to find this and be able to replace my original bag caddy.  This makes it much easier to lift the full compactor bag out of my Kenmore rectangular under-counter compactor.
Used for a medical issue, McKesson brand jelly is very smooth and water soluble.  It's also a good value.  We will continue buying it.

This worked well on my husband's right arm, but on the left arm, where he had surgery 2 years ago, it cut off his circulation after a couple of hours.  Still, they are a kind of interesting looking accessory, and good for a dress shirt where the sleeve is slightly too long.

We recently decided to replace a 1952 toilet with a new one.  The snag was that (a) the 1952 had a 10" distance from wall to drain, while the new one had a 12" distance, and (b) the new one needed to move slightly to the right of where the 1952 model was.  This solved the problem; this closet flange could be attached to the PVC drain pipe and turned at an angle to allow both of the offsets we needed, enabling us to put down a new wax ring and set the new toilet in place.  It was a lot better solution than the plumber's idea, which was, "Hey, let's just tear out the living room ceiling below the bathroom, and I can run all new pipes and do this job right!"  Um, sure.  Or, let's try this.  1923 plaster ceiling intact, new plumbing fixture installed and working, hooray for the fact that Amazon carried this, and their available overnight delivery!
Great for the toilet where the replacement has a different offset from the wall than the original unit.  Be aware, however, that this flange won't mount up to PVC pipe, according to my plumber.

Purchased for my high school junior's chemistry class.  Texas Instruments is a reliable brand, the price was very good, and delivery was fast.  It's too complex for me, but I still go looking for the sine, cosine and tangent tables in the back of trig books if my kid asks me for help.  Oh, well, at least I can figure out the 4 basic functions on this, and the boy assures me it works well.
Sharp scissors for trimming hair.  They arrived in a very nice leather case.  Excellent deal, especially at that price

Excellent wire with all kinds of uses. I initially purchased it to train jasmine up an arbor. Worked great. Easy to bend, twist and cut. Just the other day I used it to repair a backpack sprayer and today I wired up a temporary harness for a broken taillight on my work trailer. All sorts of practical uses to make it worth keeping in a work truck or around the house. It will rust over time however. Thanks for reading.SPO

Bolted on to my angle iron trailer no problem. Holds tight completely full. Been on the trailer a couple months now and no complaints. The rubber grommets are holding strong. Sturdy and looks good too! Thanks for reading.SPO

Well it's not quite what I hoped. Bought another coverware case for my wife's Galaxy Ace Style and it is nice and grippy, as well has having the hard case. THIS case however does NOT have that soft grippy feel like silicone. Rather it feels more like a dollar store toy for whatever that is worth. I bought the orange, and the colored part is flexible but kind of hard and not very appealing to the touch. The kickstand functions as it should but feels extremely flimsy. The stylus too works, but seems more cumbersome than just using my finger. It does come with a clever male headphone jack to plug it in so as to keep from losing it. All in all... Meh. I'm getting a different case. Thanks for reading.SPO

Did not work, even when used in conjunction with their other recommended products and following all instruction to a T. Perhaps for those who occasionally expose themselves to toxins, but not the everyday risk-taker. Thanks.SPO

Been using it everyday for 3 months. Good hat. Keeps the sun off, but the brim, is flimsy like a "boonie" hat rather than a Tilly style hat. The inner portion of the top has some type of plasticized lightweight lining. That makes it hot and if you are prone to sweating, brother you'll sweat in your face all day even with the mesh band. That said, it is holding up well to tree work outside everyday, and regular washings. Thanks for reading.SPO

The case fits my wife,s Galaxy Ace Style perfectly. Ordered purple camo. The case has a nice balance of soft and grippy along with hard and protective. The screen protector wasn't the easiest to get lined up straight, but then none of them really are easy. The belt clip is a bonus and keeps her from "purse dialing" me 5 times a day. Thanks for reading.

I am a self employed landscaper in the southeastern US. Summers are brutally humid here. These shirts were only $20 so I purchased two of them. When I first put it on was concerned the embroidered Columbia logo would itch or scratch my chest when working, but I never noticed it at all. These shirts wick moisture as well as anything I've ever tried (coolmax, capilene, goretex, etc). I sweat constantly and the shirt dries continuously. From the moment you put it on it feels silky and cool against the skin. I'm 6ft tall and 200 lbs with broad shoulders and an athletic build and the XXL works great for me, leaving enough tail to tuck in if I like. Feels awesome while backpacking since my back stays cool and there is almost no friction between the straps and shirt, thus eliminating shoulder hotspots.Other reviewers have expressed concerns and displeasure over the durability of these shirts, such as their Ipod strap or some tree picked up their polyester shirt a little bit so they feel it is ruined. They can feel that way, but these are tough shirts and I'll tell you why. I use chainsaws to cut trees down on a weekly basis, I'm constantly being slapped, smacked, swatted, grabbed and flat knocked down sometimes branches. Sure the polyester sometimes gets caught, thus it "pulls" or "picks", but that's what polyester does. I have $65-$70 golf shirts that picked up worse than these... and that was golfing. I consider those to be "dress" shirts so some might say they are ruined.Just the other day I cleared 140' of fence of briars and other scrub bushes. All day with a chainsaw and brush ax. Sure I got hung up and the shirt picked up a bit, but they still don't have any holes after a couple months of almost daily wear. If you are more concerned with how you look doing something than what you are actually doing, or if you armor all your truck/suv tires, you may want to try something else. Bottom line, if you work hard and play hard outside and just want a high performance moisture wicking T-shirt and don't care about how you look doing it, get this shirt. I'm ordering more today! Thanks.SPO
It certainly did the job at a fair price. Cable is six and a half feet long and black in color. Matching HDMI connects at opposing ends. Thanks.SPO

I have used sno-seal for decades now. I love the stuff, and a little can go a long way. I use it on my full grain leather hiking boots, field boots and work boots. I treat lined leather work gloves for use in nasty winter weather and my hands stay warm and dry. I don't wear leather hats but a surveyor buddy of mine treated his "Indiana Jones" style hat with it and says it works great at shedding water now.I apply it using the hair dryer method. You can either smear it onto the item you wish to treat then heat with an old hair dryer to melt the wax into the nooks, crannies, and seams.... or you can slightly heat up the wax while in the jar to thin it then rub it onto the item being treated. Treat leather boots liberally and the waterproofing will last for months. It will significantly darken lighter colored leather, but I've never had it break down any of my leather in all the years I've used it. Thanks for reading.SPO

Meh... it's light duty material and wasn't as durable as I had hoped. I have a couple other mesh  drawstring bags I've been using for years for different purposes and they've held up great. They were purchased from athletic stores. This one is small and more suited for washing a couple pairs of ladies underwear in the washing machine at home, not to mention the drawstring toggle is junk. Don't buy it for a gym bag or wet clothes it's too small. Don't buy it for camping or kayaking it's too flimsy. I suppose it could make a decent mosquito net for your head if needed, but other than that this bag doesn't really get used at our home. Thanks for reading.SPO

A great deal for two dozen carpenter pencils. Most people probably wouldn't know they were misprints. They sharpen easily with a pocketknife. I've had pencils that the lead was all broken up inside them and when you sharpened you just lost lead and had to re-sharpen. These haven't done that. Everyone in our cul-de-sac try to help each other out on projects, so I could afford to give 2-3 pencils away to a few neighbors. Good times :)SPO

A nice little inexpensive necklace for our four and a half year old. It really changes color like advertised, and our daughter loves to tell us what mood she's in according to her necklace.  It's nothing fancy or out of this world, but it made a perfect stocking stuffer. Have any questions feel free to ask. Thanks.SPO

I've used Detoxify products before... like the XXtra clean, but save you money on this permaclean. Followed instructions to a "T." Avoided toxins for 48 hours prior, in addition to taking the constant cleanse pills. Drank at least eight 16oz bottles of water each day, along with a little juice and Rooibos tea. Used a single panel test to test myself twice a day for six days. Every one was positive. At this point I'm 18 days off all toxins, and despite still taking three constant cleanse pills each day and drinking 6-8 bottles of water, I'm still testing positive.If you've watched the Youtube videos about Detoxify products and feel this perma cleanse will help you... well it may if you only subject yourself to toxins once a week or so, but not if you are around them daily. I could have gotten the same results (and previously have) by just abstaining for 2-3 weeks and taking in plenty of water. I will not be buying these products (or any other similar) ever again.As far as the product itself.... It has a slightly strong herbal flavor. It is not a thick syrupy formula, but has the same viscosity as water. Did not make me feel sick, but I suggest saving your money even though this product is way cheaper here on Amazon.
They work as advertised. Each one had an expiration date almost two years out. Very happy with this 50ng test.SPO

Wow... this is one of those old school "throwback" toys. Santa left it in our daughter's Christmas stocking. It appears to made of hardwood and not that cheap balsa wood. I have easily launched this thing 25 feet into the air, and watched it travel a good 60 feet in distance. I don't recommend this being played with inside, as it is slightly heavy, very solid, and will easily break household objects.One of the first test flights inside, it managed to hit my wife in her forehead and left a mark! She was fine but definitely be careful with this toy. Thanks for reading.SPO

Exactly the dame as I remember it back in the 70's. I had one of these as a kid and made sure to bring it along whenever we were going to be in the car for a couple hours or more. My four and a half year old loves it, as she is fascinated by magnets anyway right now. The product is probably a little overpriced, but what isn't these days. It has held up well so far since having received it for Christmas. Magnet is just strong enough and no filings have leaked out so far. Thanks for reading.SPO

Well I waited three months to give my assessment on the magnatab. Save you money. I was excited when I found this on Amazon, but like many other reviewers, it is quickly becoming less fun to play with due to the balls "sticking." Some are stuck up, while others are stuck down. It possible to get all the balls down, but then some won't come back up, and when they do, they won't stay in place. If this toy cost $5 it would be fine, but at about $20.... keep looking. I really wanted to like this one too. Ours hasn't been mishandled in any way and still looks like it did when we first opened it up. Thanks for reading and feel free to ask any questions you may have.SPO

My four and a half year old daughter loves MLP.... and she loves temporary tattoos. These tattoos go on nice and easy, but they don't last as long as some temp tatts we have used. These seem to last for about two or three days, but are completely gone after two baths. Be aware that you are not receiving 18 pony tattoos on two sheets. The single sheet you see is what you get. It has 8 actual pony tatts and 8 additional tatts of hearts and flowers mainly. Daughter loves them so I'm happy. Thanks for reading.SPO

I'm coming back to buy 3 more of these. Awesome battery life with "D" batteries. My daughter uses this lantern every single night since Christmas as her nightlight. We start off on the high setting for about a half hour and she then turns it down to the middle setting. It stays there for a couple hours until I go to bed and turn it down to the yellow "nightlight" setting. It still shines as bright as when we first put Duracells in it. So far we're 60 days and counting on the battery life with nightly usage. Very bright lantern. Seems to be weather resistant as advertised. It's nice that it will work with triple A's as well, because if you are out of one battery you can use the other in  a pinch. I have seen these lanterns at Walmart for ~$16 as well.

I had been treating my English Pointer's ear with peroxide to treat a suspected infection. It wasn't working too well as I was having to swab the ear out with Q-tips daily. The ear was producing a foul smelling dark and oily substance at an alarming rate. I treated using this method for about two months and was close to having to by stock in Q-tips. I ordered this and treated the ear twice daily for five days. The ear showed signs of clearing up within 48 hours and the foul smell was less noticeable. The ear was completely clear, clean and pink again after five days of treatment. No more foul smell either. That was about three months ago. My pointer is so much happier now that he isn't shaking his head every five minutes. I highly recommend this if your dog has some kind of "ear yuck" you feel may be an infection. I still have about 95% of the bottle left, so it should go a long way. Thanks for reading and I will gladly answer any questions you may have.SPO

My how headlamps have come a long way. I still have my original, THE original Petzl Tikka headlamp. I admit it may have lost "some" brightness over the years, although not much, this Black Diamond Wiz headlamp rivals it in every way. My three and a half year old daughter got this for Christmas and absolutely loves it. She is always "stealing" my headlamps and flashlights, so she got a pink one from Santa.The band is plenty adjustable for even some adults to wear. The button has little tactile feel to it, but rather feels almost like a touch screen. I'm just accustomed to a stiff click, but this unit is designed with kids in mind so I'm fine with it and my daughter could care less. I mainly got this unit because of the automatic shutoff. Seemed like every time I needed one of my mini lights, the batteries were dead and that was provided I could find one at all. We found two small flashlights which had dropped behind her bed when we rearranged her room a while back. The only minor gripe is the tilt mechanism is a bit "sticky" and not very smooth.If you have any questions please feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks for reading.SPO

My three and a half year old little girl received this unicorn for Christmas. It has since become her favorite plush toy to snuggle with at night. It really is quite cuddly. It does not stand up on its own like the picture shows, but rather splays out in to a "spread-eagle" type pose. I'm fine with this since it really seems to lend to the unicorn's cuddle factor. It is very soft and squeezable, about a foot long and ten inches or so tall with bean-bag feet. My daughter loves it. If you have any questions feel free to ask and I will answer best I can. Thanks.***UPDATE 2/27/2014***It's only been two months, but the toy is holding up well. I say this because it has become one of our daughters favorite things. She sleeps with it every night. She named her "Feathers" and she always goes with my daughter to sleep over at her grandmother's house. Buy the unicorn for your child... they will love it, especially little girls.SPO

This was fun clay to work with and has no unpleasant odor like a no name brand I purchased from "Wallyworld". My three and a half year old got this in her stocking for Christmas. We have gotten tired of how play doh dries out so quickly, although I rejuvenate it with a little canola oil. This clay blends very well to make new colors. It molds readily especially after being warmed by rolling in the palms, but it does not bond to itself readily. I did not try concocting any sort of "slip" to use as glue, but I may try that on the next miniature coil bowl we try to make.It does not dry out or harden. I've had some leftover laying out for 5 days now, and it as well as the sculptures we made on Christmas day are still quite pliable. We made a bunch of snowmen and women with garden hats. We did need to use sections of bamboo skewers as an internal frame to support the clay.I will say that unlike play doh, this clay sticks a little bit to various surfaces, and the color does transfer a little bit to hands and fingers, but nothing permanent. No experience yet with it getting into clothing or carpet, but I promise I will update on the results if and when that happens. I plan on getting more of this clay just for when we go out of town or on vacation so our daughter has something a little more tactile to play with than her Leap Pad 2. Thanks and feel free to ask any questions.SPO

This is one of those great products that no one ever hears about because the Razor line just about has the market cornered. Yes those are less expensive, but if you purchase this maxi kick scooter at the right time for your child (about 3 years or so), it will end up being a very inexpensive toy over time. I paid $130 for this neon pink/black maxi kick scooter, and I figure it should last my three and a half year old another eight years plus.... that's only $16 dollars a year.The maxi scooter measures 24 in. high at it's lowest setting and that suits my 41 in. daughter very well. I almost purchased the mini kick, but so glad now that I didn't since the maxi is adjustable and has a slightly larger platform.I will concede this scooter is made in China just as the Razors are, but the components on the kick line of scooters are much better quality... the wheels, bearings, etc.The steering column does not fold down, but rather locks into place, or is removed with a "push" button mechanism. It can be a bit awkward to push the button to remove the column. I find that a small flat-head screwdriver works well for this. The height adjustment is a simple, but reliable quick release. The hand grips are really rubbery and provide excellent grip. The deck has no grip tape, but does seem to provide adequate slip protection as my daughter was riding through puddles yesterday. The deck has just the amount of flex one might expect a child's scooter to have, which really helps the carving effect one gets from the unique steering mechanism. The front wheels have a camber to them when turning.... think Can-Am roadster. The wheels are super smooth and ultra quiet on our hardwood, tile carpet, and outside on pavement.I was a little worried about my girl not getting the hang of the rear brake, but boy was I wrong. Once I showed it to her, she immediately began practicing with it. We had a couple rainy days at Christmas, so she got to practice inside before heading out. She seemed really confident right from the start. I'm so glad we paid a little more and went with the front three wheeled design. Our neighbor's child got a rear three wheeled scooter and she is constantly kicking the rear wheels when she pushes, regardless of which foot she uses. My girl is able to take big long confident strides when she pushes without kicking any wheels.If you are reading this debating between the maxi or mini, your child is probably going to fit the maxi at it's lowest setting. If you are here debating between a front or rear three wheeled design, I promise your child will be happier with this design if given the choice. Micro Mobility started out designing scooters for adults, and have since delivered a well designed quality line of children's scooters. It really is a great little scooter, and in my opinion far superior to the half a dozen different scooters belonging to the children in this cul-de-sac.**UPDATE 11-24-2014**Scooter is holding up great. Very well built. All the other kids in the neighborhood love to ride it because of the two wheels in front design, along with the built in 'camber'. I would buy this over again in a heartbeat. I've only raised the handle up about an inch from last year, so I firmly believe it will last our daughter for seven more years. Updating from 4 to 5 stars!Thanks for the time and if you have any questions feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can.SPO

My three and a half year old daughter has a fascination with alligators and crocodiles right now. Many mornings, she walks ever so gingerly into the living room and says, "Daddy, do you see the pretend baby alligator on my head"? I'm not sure what all that is about, but I had to purchase this little Schleich figure when I saw it. I plan on dropping it in as one of her stocking stuffers this Christmas.The figure is very detailed and lifelike with a "cute" expression, but it is very, very small at less three inches in length. At the time of my purchase, the crocodile was part of the add-on program... as such, I paid less than four dollars. Any questions... just ask and I will answer. Thanks.SPO

This is a nice little kaleidoscope for kids. The tin is a bit thin, but I expected that. The end cap with the beads on it rotates very easily, so it's great for little hands. The paint job is extremely vivid. It comes with a little tag, but otherwise lacked any sort of packaging. Each Christmas, we try to buy for our daughter a combination of tactile, electronic, and "old-school" types of toys. This year the kaleidoscope will be a stocking stuffer, and honestly, it just looks like something Kris Kringle himself dropped in the stocking. Any questions... just ask and I will answer. Thanks.SPO

I was purchasing some Schleich animals from "WalleyWorld"  to go in my daughter's Christmas stocking, when I noticed this rooster. It's a bit on the small side at about 2 x 2.5 x 1 inches, but it is extremely detailed with very realistic colors, markings, and textures. I got the rooster for myself since I am a University of South Carolina Gamecock, and although it's barely noticeable, this rooster figurine does have spurs on its legs. This figurine obviously would make a great addition to a child's animal collection, but it also makes a great little gift for a Gamecock fan. I paid less than fours dollars for the rooster at my local retailer. Thanks.SPO

I just picked up this African elephant today at my local "WalleyWorld" for less than seven dollars with tax. It will be a stocking stuffer for my three and a half year old daughter. The figure is extremely detailed and has natural looking colors, markings and textures. A gleam in the eye and a slight shine to the nostrils add to the lifelike appearance. This little toy has a more hefty feel than one might imagine, and is a little bigger than many of the Schleich figures. It should last for many years of play and display. Thanks.SPO

I just picked up this turtle today at "WalleyWorld" for less than five dollars. It will be a stocking stuffer for my three and a half year old daughter. The figure is extremely detailed and has pretty natural looking colors and markings. The turtle's size is between a golf ball and a racquet ball, but has a more hefty feel than one might imagine. Should last for many years of play and display. Thanks.SPO

I originally purchased this shovel about 6 years ago from Lowe's like many other reviewers. I used this shovel for work at the time, which was installing Invisible fences for canine containment. I used this shovel 5 days a week for 3 years, and it served me well. It blew all other shovels out of the water when it came to digging fine trench work for burying wire. When most shovels would "taco" in half when trying to dig in some of the semi-frozen clay soils around here in winter, this shovel never folded up. I still keep the shovel on my landscape trailer.The oversize steps on either side of the shovel have a little traction, but I added some grip tape to the steps a couple times a year as it would wear off. The half star deduction is for the handle being attached by only a single screw. That became loose soon after putting it to full time use, so I drove two more small sheet metal screws above and below the stock screw, and they have held very tight for years.Thankfully Amazon carries this shovel, because all of my local Lowe's have stopped selling this particular product, and I need two for Christmas gifts for buddies of mine that always wanted one, but would never spend the extra money themselves. Those guys would rather buy two or three cheap shovels a year, but in my opinion this tool is the perfect combination of trenching shovel, sharpshooter shovel, transfer and digging shovels. I currently own 7 different shovels (self employed landscaper) and if I could only carry one with me, this would be the one.I suggest adding two sheet metal screws to the back of the handle as soon as you purchase this shovel, as this will mitigate any chances of the handle coming off. I personally found the grip tape to be a great benefit, but I worked in ALL weather conditions back then. Thanks for reading and if you have any questions about the product, feel free to ask and I will answer best I can.

This little unicorn is just as described. It is somewhat small, as the description indicates it measures 3.7 x 0.9 x 2.6 inches. It seems to be made of a plastic/vinyl similar to so many of the little vinyl toy figurines, so it has a small bit of flexibility to it. This should keep it from breaking. It has all the detail of a ceramic style figurine. She has realistic hair texture, good muscle definition, as well as detailed mouth and nostrils. You can even tell she is a baby unicorn due the shorter horn and lanky legs, and at $3.50 plus fair shipping charges I feel this will make a great stocking stuffer.The unicorn does not come in a "blister" style package, but in a bag like a happy meal toy, which is fine, just thought it was worth mentioning. It seems similar in quality to Schliech figurines. Item arrived two days earlier than estimated. If you have any questions feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks.SPO

This UC M48 Talon spear is pretty awesome, if not perfect for my primary use. I hunt boar in the swamps and floodplains outside Columbia SC. I use this spear as a backup to my Smith & Wesson model 625. My family has traditionally hunted hogs with revolvers, and .45 caliber or not, it's still only six shots. The dogs usually handle any hog we come across with no problems, but as a last line of defense, I have always carried a large knife (Tops Condor Alert) but lets face it, who wants to go hand to hoof with a hog.I find the length of this spear to be perfect. I understand why some would want a longer handle so it can double as a hiking stick, but me personally, I keep it strapped to the back of a M.O.L.L.E. vest with a couple of custom formed pieces of Kydex attached to the vest. This setup allows my to "quick-draw" the spear like an arrow from a quiver. The shorter length keeps it from getting snagged on brush and undergrowth, but still gives me 7 feet of reach if you include my arm.The slightly blade heavy design is great for thrusting and has plenty of "heft" to easily pierce a hog. The sheath leaves something to be desired, so I made a new leather sheath out of an old baseball glove from Goodwill.I have honestly only thrown it a couple of times, and those throws were just chance encounters with rabbits. The spear threw pretty good to about twenty or so feet, although we did not eat fire roasted rabbit, the spear and blade was no worse for the wear. My M48 has been quite the topic around a few campfires and I have no doubt I have helped sell at least a couple of these because of that.Bottom line... If you plan on this doubling as a hiking staff... forget about it. But, if you hunt any large game with a revolver, or hunt in bear country for any game, the M48 add a little extra peace of mind. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks.SPO

I purchased this off a clearance shelf from "Wallyworld" on a whim one day. It sat around the shed for months until I used it on my pitchfork to unload and help spread six cubic yards of cypress mulch. What a back saver! It was most useful for the transfer of mulch from the trailer to the wheelbarrow and mulching was much easier this year. Adjustments, installation, and removal are all very easy thanks to the spade-head thumb screws. I have also used it on my transfer shovel loading sand and gravel off my driveway, which brings me to best uses and limitations.It worked better on my transfer shovel than it did on my digging shovel. It would be great for snow and transfer shovels, pitchforks, and replacement grips for gas powered trimmers. I would not recommend this for rakes, or digging implements, as it will just get in the way. It is made of a tough thermoplastic and has shown it can take some abuse. I only wish I would have thought of it first. Thanks.SPO

I pulled this from the Cateye website off the Velo 7 tech sheet regarding preset tire size choices.Tire sizeÔºö 16"/ 18"/ 20"/ 22"/ 24"/ 26"/ 700C or 100cmÔΩû299cm (default: 26")The above are all the preset tire size choices. 700c is the correct option to choose for 29" tires. 700c is a term designated to road bike tires, although they are more narrow, the OUTSIDE diameter of 700c and 29" tires are the same, thus this computer IS compatible with 29" wheels. The number to be most concerned with when trying to find info regarding 29'er tires vs. 700c tires is the ISO number 622, which designates the circumference of both tires in MILLIMETERS. The "c" in 700c is an outdated designation for width, but has nothing to do with centimeters as it is often confused. I hope this helps someone. The 700c option proved to be very accurate for my Trek 29'er. Thanks.SPO

I am but a mere novice when it comes to playing the guitar, but I purchased this SN-1 to replace the piece of junk first tuner I had. I'm very happy with the size of the SN-1. It's small, much smaller than I expected which was a big bonus. It takes up very little room on the headstock, and does not interfere when I make tuning adjustments. The "chip-clip" style clamp does a surprisingly good job of staying in place on my Ibanez acoustic and I *think* my guitar sounds better than it did while using my previous tuner.The user interface is very simple, and the display is easy to read and understand in both higher and lower lighting conditions. The instruction manual is adequate, but the SN-1 seemed very intuitive for me to use. The product arrived on time, as shown, well packaged, for what I believe to be a fair price at about eight dollars and change. I've had this SN-1 for a couple months now, and will update this review down the road. Thanks for reading, and if you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will do the best I can to answer.SPO

These are excellent gloves to have around the house. I originally purchased mine at Lowe's, and they have served me well for over three years. I have used them to: glue PVC together, scrub bathrooms, apply varnish and stains, pressure wash the house, remove a dead bird, make tie-dyed stuff, pesticide and herbicide applications, every time I use Goo-Gone, apply floor tile mastic, and so many more things I can't remember right now.The gloves are somewhat thick, but articulated. They provide warmth when pressure washing in the cold. The textured palm surprisingly provides more than enough grip for most applications. I think these gloves are a must for every homeowner for sure. I have somewhat large hands (always have to buy L or XL work gloves) and these gloves fit like a... like a.... oh well they fit great if you don't have small hands. Any questions, feel free to ask. Thanks.SPO

Well I've now had this back stretcher for about three months. As others have noted, it looks like the picture. I thought it would have some built in "flex" when I laid on it, but is actually pretty rigid due to the wooden internal frame. The ample padding mitigates any stiffness however. To adequately review the product, I feel I should first describe my back problems.First of all, I have three degenerating discs, between my "L's" 2 & 3, "L's" 3 & 4, and "L's" 4 & 5, caused from years of carrying heavy packs and sleeping in not so comfy locations. This mainly causes extreme tightness  with some pain in my lower back. My chiropractor is able to "crack" my lower back, but this device DOES NOT crack *my* lower back. It does however provide a high arch on which to slowly stretch out my back sometimes. I never do this in the morning, as my back is at its tightest, and if your back is really tight, this thing can hurt like crazy if you are not careful. I usually need to loosen my lower back up first before I can stretch it on this. Now, for the mid back...About two years ago, I dislocated the two right side ribs at my "T" 6 and "T" 7 vertebrae. No kidding, one of the most painful injuries I have ever experienced, and there have been many. At any rate, I spent almost a year going to my chiropractor, usually twice a week, before the ribs would finally start to stay in place on their own for any length of time. Now that the ribs are as good as they are going to get, I still have some residual discomfort which every so often requires a middle back adjustment from my chiropractor. This device DOES help me with this issue, as I often get one or two small little cracks in the area of my "T" 6 and "T" 7. Again this can be painful for me if I am not somewhat loosened up beforehand.Conclusion: I think this item will be a hit or miss depending on your particular back issues. I do like to put it behind my back sometimes when I find myself in my home office-chair, as the arch forces me to sit very straight. I am able to position the device anywhere along my spine, depending on where I lay on it. I use it two or three times a week for ten minutes or so at the time, and it is holding up nicely. I would advise using a small pillow under your head just like the instructions indicate, because it helps support your cervical vertebrae.I give three stars because as three stars denotes, I feel it is just OK. It is no substitute for a competent chiropractor, but it does a better job than most household objects at providing a little stretch for your back. Just be warned, if you suffer from real tightness (not muscular, but skeletal) in your back this device can really hurt you if you don't loosen up a little first. Thanks for reading and if you have any questions feel free to contact me and I will answer as best I can.SPO

Product arrived ahead of scheduled, just as described and shown in the photo, packaged in a heavy duty Ziploc style bag. I use the cable to connect our Yamaha PSR-E333 keyboard to a laptop and it performs flawlessly in this capacity. Item was an excellent buy at less than four dollars as an "add-on". I found a comparable cable at Walmart for about three times the price as this Amazon offering. If you have any questions about the product, feel free to ask and I will answer best I can.SPO

In the interest of full disclosure, this is the first guitar strap I have ever owned. That being said, the strap is fairly soft and pliable, with that almost broken in feel. I was expecting it to be a little stiffer, but I'm glad it isn't. It fit my Ibanez acoustic just fine. My guitar is nothing fancy, so I would presume the "strap locks" are pretty standard. The fit is really tight at first, so that should be a good thing. I suppose I could have unscrewed my strap locks to facilitate mounting the strap, but I didn't.The range of fit seems pretty good to me. I am 6' tall and wear my acoustic up a little high, kind of "folk style" I guess. If I want to, I can adjust it so that it rides lower around my pelvis area. One end is suede on both sides and has the tanned leather-logo patch on it, while the other end is black suede on one side and tan suede on the backside. I can't see it marring the guitar at all. It is comfortable around my neck and shoulder. Made in Canada, seems well built and durable. Once again my left shoe is happy to have its lace back, and Keith gets to keep his head fashionable. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks for reading.SPO

This is actually the first capo I have ever owned, as I am pretty new to playing the guitar. That being said, I paid close to $14 with free shipping for this capo, and I feel it is a good value. It feels well constructed, like it won't break if I drop it. The capo fits nice and tight on all six strings. Ample padding mitigates any marring of the guitar's neck. The spring mechanism is plenty tight, but not too tight to easily move or remove the capo single handed, even while playing. The capo is sleek looking, and a bit smaller than I was expecting at 3" x 3", but I have no frame of reference for comparison.Item was shipped on time, and packaged in the original Dunlop packaging. Part number: 83CB, Made in USA! No counterfeit here. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks for reading.SPO

I purchased these for my wife as part of a Valentine's Day gift. She had only played golf twice before, sharing my clubs both times. Since she enjoyed it, I got this set, which fits her much better than mine did. Now that we have been playing together more often, I have received feedback from her about the clubs.First, she likes how lightweight the set is, as it is not cumbersome for her to manage. She is about 5'7", and finds these clubs much easier to swing than mine. I notice she makes much less contact with the ground, especially with the driver, than she did with my clubs. Please keep in mind she is still learning the game, and more importantly how to swing the club properly while making good ball contact.I think this is a great beginner/entry level set of clubs. The set contains a 460cc driver with head cover (a little overwhelming still for my wife), a "fairway" wood and a 5 hybrid with head covers (she crushes both of these from the fairway), 6 and 7 irons (7 is my personal favorite club), a sand wedge (my wife's favorite club) , and a mallet style putter. I added an old 11 degree Callaway War-Bird driver to her bag, which she uses as her driver most of the time. The shafts are composite and the grips are pretty standard. Set includes: 7 clubs, 3 head covers, 1 bag.As a set, I feel it's not enough clubs to weigh my wife down, or overwhelm her when it comes to club selection, but all the distances one would need to play a round are in the bag. As she gets her swing down and adds a few shots to her bag of tricks, we may upgrade her set. Until then, she says she is very happy with these clubs and is glad she doesn't have as many as I have. If you have any questions about the clubs, feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks.SPO

.... You must use this flea killer in conjunction with the flea control, at least for a short time. There are a lot of dogs in our neighborhood, and for years everyone here has been using Frontline or Advantage. We alternated them each year and always had great success with no fleas for 8 years at this location. This year, the mild winter and ridiculously wet summer, have allowed fleas in our area to almost get out of control. Everyone we talked to in the neighborhood said their usual flea controls were not working either, so I went back to good ole' Adams flea shampoo for a month. It showed some success, but we were still noticing the odd flea with eggs in certain areas on the dogs. Research, research, research...... Ahhh, Little City Dogs... let's give it a shot.Woohoo! It's been a month and still no fleas. What we did was we bathed the dogs with Adams one last time, then give them The Little City Dogs flea control (sold separately) the next day. Three days later we started giving the dogs these Little City Dogs flea killer capsules every other day for two weeks. No more fleas or eggs. We simply put the pills in a feeding along with the Glucosamine and fish oil pills we already give them daily. The dosing indications are on the back of each pill box. Our dogs are a 75 lb English Pointer, and a 60 lb Lab/Husky mix. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer as best as I can. Thanks.***UPDATE***11-13-13 The fleas have stayed off our dogs, and the dogs have shown no adverse reactions to the product.SPO

I purchased these headphones mainly for my wife to use with her Yamaha PSR E333 keyboard, but of course I have been using them lately, and I will say they are a great value. My wife an I both have "smallish" ears, and these lightweight headphones fit perfectly. I think for anyone who has large or long ears may not find these to be comfortable.The ear cups adjust by sliding up or down at the point of connection. That connection also swivels a bit to allow for a nice custom feel. All the padding is super soft, but I could see it getting ripped if one were not careful. The cord seems well connected into the headphones and is at least 8 ft long. The little cord keeper that is included is just OK, but it functions. These headphones "seal" really well around my ears, so I have to be really careful to make sure and have my volume down before I put the headphones on, or they will really blast my eardrums. The sound......... These things sound amazing for a $25 pair of entry level headphones. When I first plugged them into my laptop and headed to YouTube, they seemed a bit muffled, so I pulled up my laptop's equalizer and was able to really get the headphones dialed in. I was able to get warm rich tones, high highs, and clear bass notes. They also do an excellent job of keeping the audio in the ear cups as my wife can't hear anything from four feet away. She loves them with the Yamaha keyboard. The included larger size adapter fit in the keyboard perfectly. The only con I can come up with is I didn't purchase them sooner. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can. Thanks.SPO

This AC adapter, in my opinion, should not even qualify to be reviewed since we all know it should be included with the product it is powering. That being said, it functions as it was intended to, which is to power a Yamaha PSRE333 61-key portable keyboard. It fits perfectly and stays put, all while transmitting electrical current from my home's 110v outlet into the aforementioned Yamaha keyboard. Thanks for reading.SPO

We had the original for years, and like many came to love the trackball. One of our dogs got tangled in the mouse cord and subsequently disconnected the internal wiring. Had a computer repair shop look at it but he couldn't repair it so I went online to buy a new one. I couldn't believe the $200-$400 asking prices for the discontinued trackball. Enter Amazon.After reading reviews on this product I was concerned about driver installation, but decided to give it a shot for $40. So happy I did. Installation was quick and flawless. Simply plug in the USB receiver and the mouse was recognized fairly quickly, although it took about 4-5 minutes before the mouse would actually function. I currently use a Toshiba L675 laptop with 64 bit Vista OS. The trackball speed was far too fast out of the box for my liking, so I went to the Logitech website and downloaded the software to customize the mouse settings. That was also easy, but you will need to know your OS properties in order to choose the correct download.I have had no issues with errant scrolling or anything else. I will surely update this review in a few months after more use. If you are a fan of the original trackball, you will love this too. It is close enough in size, weight, shape, and feel, that any differences are subtle. My one small gripe is the on the old trackball, I could pop the ball out of the bottom with my finger to clean it out. This trackball has a much narrower diameter hole, and so I need a pencil or something to pop the ball out. Other than that, I'm so happy I found this product. I plan on buying two more to stick in a drawer in case the same situation ever happens with this version. If you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will do my best to answer. Thanks.SPO

I purchased a 3 pack of the soft rubber wedgie's as an add-on to a larger order. As such, I found them to be a reasonable value. However, I'm not sure how long these will last on my steel string acoustic. I think these picks would be fantastic for classical or any other nylon string guitar or "uke". They are very grippy and have a slight concavity to them on one side for additional comfort.I love the very soft warm sound they provide. I use them mostly late at night when I can't sleep and want to play, but the rest of the family is still sleeping. Not quite as effective on the E, A, and D steel strings but certainly playable. Not so great for strumming, but fun to pick individual chords. Thanks.SPO

I received all twelve picks, which came in a small ziploc bag with an attached Fender tag. The color is great. I needed a thin pick for some softer picking on acoustic. These work great, though do not offer as warm a sound as rubber or felt picks. I find them to be the perfect compromise between heavy and rubber. The picks were reasonably priced and shipped via "prime", so I found them to be a great value as someone who only plays casually. Thanks.SPO

My old Wahl clippers were in need of replacement after about 12 years of bi-weekly hair cuts, so I naturally began reading reviews of clippers on Amazon. I had no reason to deviate from Whal as my brand of choice and felt this clipper kit would meet my needs, but I was a little leery of an online purchase after having read so many negative reviews about possibly having received used clippers. Another reviewer mentioned this item being sold at "Wallyworld" so I went and checked. Sure enough I found it for about $22 and change. Now the clipper....I have been shaving my whole head as close as I can get it (boot camp style) without using a straight/safety razor for twenty years. I am very happy with this clipper after a dozen or so cuts. I shave my head at the shortest setting sans any guards and it get so very close, but it has never ever nicked me. Included is a light green guard which feels like a "soft" silicon material. It is perfect for trimming "sensitive areas". The blades were sharp, aligned perfectly and in pristine condition. All the accessories were bagged separately inside the somewhat flimsy case.Over the years I have learned two things about clipper care: Always brush hair trimmings out of the clipper blades after each use, and regular oiling. That being said, the little "cleaner" brushes that come with almost all clipper are junk. Years ago I replaced mine with a cheap medium bristle toothbrush. It is much more effective at hair removal. Additionally, when you properly oil the blades and then use the toothbrush again a few times after oiling, you will then have a nice oil-primed brush for cleaning which you can toss in the flimsy case. I use Diawa brand fishing reel oil because the tube lasts forever and it is an extremely clean and lightweight oil. I don't think Amazon sells it but if you Google Needle Nose reel oiler, you will find it.Thanks for reading and if you have any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer best as I can. Thanks again.SPO

I love this ball during the late spring and summer here in North Carolina. It doesn't fly nearly as far in winter. I really prefer it for my drives and approach shots, but really prefer a softer ball on the green. They are a decent value, especially if you are prone to losing a couple balls each round. In the end these are great all around, all-purpose golf balls that should not hinder your game. I  always keep my eye on the clearance items at my local "Wally-Worlds", and I often find these Wilson balls there. They are currently what I have in my bag along with a few Pro V1X's's for the green. Thanks for reading.SPO

Depression afflicts millions directly, and millions more who are relatives or friends of victims. In its graver, clinical manifestation it takes upward of 20% of its victims by way of suicide, and artistic types are particularly vulnerable. In its extreme form, depression is madness. Loss of appetite, libido, ability to focus, and hope. Fear of being alone. An inner observer who watches dispassionately as his companion struggles. Its roll call includes Vincent Van Gogh, Virginia Woolf, Robin Williams, Sylvia Plath, Jack London, Hunter S. Thompson, Vince Foster, Marilyn Monroe, Ernest Hemingway, Abbie Hoffman, George Eastman, Cleopatra, Robin Williams, and others.Part of the reason depression can be difficult to treat is that it often has no single identifiable cause. Genetics, chemical imbalances, and past experience/behavior may all be important. It is hopelessness even more than pain that crushes the soul.' It is nearly incomprehensible to those who have not experienced it in its extreme mode. Claims of an easy way out are glib and most likely fraudulent.One of the many dreadful manifestations of depression is a failure of self-esteem/being taken over by self-loathing - one of its most universally experienced symptoms. It is nearly incomprehensible to those who have not experienced it. Symptoms begin with a sense of dread, alienation, and stifling anxiety. Disruption of normal sleep patterns is another devastating feature of depression. A lot of literature concerning depression is breezily optimistic, spreading assurance that nearly all depressive states will be stabilized or reversed if only the suitable antidepressant can be found.Eventually, the suitable antidepressant is found, and he's released from hospitalization. Before getting there, however, readers encounter some incredible thoughts:The word 'depression' is inadequate, a 'wimp of a word for an illness that is a 'howling tempest in the brain.' The suffering is 'beyond expression.' As for the value of psychotherapy for one with advance depression - 'virtually nil,' while group therapy is 'hateful,' and art therapy 'organized infantilism.' He fears his accounting of schemes to kill himself will seem 'especially repugnant to healthy Americans, with their faith in self-improvement.' Despite the anguish devouring one's brain, the sufferer must present a face approximating the one associated with ordinary events, try to utter small talk, be responsive to questions, and knowingly nod and frown, even smile. 'But it is a fierce trial attempting to speak a few simple words.'His most encouraging thought - that 'for me the real healers were seclusion and time.'

Bolger's summary begins by wandering around the Mid-East, going back to Iraq War I - including going inside some of the military minds of the time. Intelligence has been 'trained' to report what the enemy 'could do,' not speculate on what it 'would do.' (Prior errors include believing in 1941 that the Japanese could not fly hundreds of miles from their carriers - they had poor night vision from too much rice in their diet, that peasant North Koreans could not be tough, that the Chinese could never cross the Yalu River undetected, that the North Vietnamese would fold under U.S. bombing, the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991). Yet, there were still major questions - would the Republican Guards stand their ground?  How competent was the Iraqi Air Force? (Flew only 910 sorties, vs. over 60,000 by the Coalition, lost every air-to-air encounter, and lost 132 planes to pilot desertion to unfriendly IranWhat about the Arab penchant for raids and ambushes, disdain for stand-and-fight tactics - as reported by Lawrence of Arabia in WWI? (Fortunately, Saddam chose to make war the Western way.)Conservative estimates of Iraqi casualties ran about 20,000 dead and up to 75,000 wounded, 86,743 prisoners, 148 Americans killed, 458 wounded, and 21 captured, and thousands of tanks, artillery, APCs, and trucks destroyed. At the 3/3/90 cease-fire discussion, the Iraqis innocently raised a seemingly minor issue - later found to bring major repercussions. 'We would like to agree that helicopter flights sometimes are needed to carry officials from one place to the other because the roads and bridges are out (U.S. bombing).' It was all they asked for, and given that, they hoped for a bit of magnanimity from Schwarzkopf. And he walked right into it. 'So you mean even armed helicopters can fly in Iraqi skies?'  'You have my word,' was the response.February 15, 1991. President Bush asked the Iraqi people and military to overthrow Saddam. AK-47s and hand grenades were little help against tanks, heavy artillery, and helicopters. It took until summer of 1992 to extend a Kurdish-type no-fly zone over the Shiite south - by then, the aircraft flew cover mostly for some 10,000 gravesites. The Iraqi Shiites found the U.S. unreliable, a view encouraged by their friends in Iran. And remaining American generals learned that a large portion of Saddam's Republican Guards had escaped Desert Storm. As for a peacekeeping mission, the U.S. wanted none of it.Saddam chose to define his regime's continued existence as a victory over the vast American-led Coalition. (Bush lost his job in the '92 election.) The Arab street bought it, especially after the Kurds were boxed in, the Shiites blasted, and Saddam rearmed. On the other hand, a huge number of infidels were now polluting the holy land of the Prophet Muhammad, and bin Laden didn't like it.The guided-missile destroyer U.S.S. Cole sailed into Aden in October, 2000 to pick up 220k gallons of diesel - while also reinforcing America's support for Yemen's president. Two small boats arranged to pick up the Cole's trash for $150, then a third dingy approached, and both of its locals waved as it touched the Cole's flank.  The 500-lb. bomb opened a hole 40' across., with a third of the damage extending below the waterline.Back in Afghanistan, bin Laden received a revelation he attributed to Allah. The communist Russian superpower had failed, pulled out, and then imploded - all thanks to holy warriors in Afghanistan. If al-Qaeda could lure the U.S. to the same killing ground, that might well crippled it and run them out of the entire region. Previously he'd launched truck-bomb explosions at U.S. embassies in Kenya and in Tanzania on 8/7/1999, then the Cole bombing. Still, bin Laden did not achieve his desired result.And on it goes, years more of bloody detail.What have we gotten out of 14 years of war in Afghanistan and Iraq? At this point it's pretty clear - mostly huge negatives. The loss of thousands of Americans and trillions of dollars, as well as a huge hit to our perceived 'soft' and 'hard' power. Iraq - obviously we should have never invaded post 9/11, and also committed major errors there at the end of Iraq War I (allowing armed helicopter flights, encouraging Iraqis to revolt - only to be mowed down by Saddam's remaining forces), and now have spawned a new terrorist group - ISIS. There was plausible rationale for invading Afghanistan, but we allowed our initial success to wither away due to becoming distracted by Iraq. We neglected to build a strong Afghan army - only 36,000 trained by 2006, five years after we arrived.Bolger's suggestion, however, that we should have invaded Iraq and then left, is untenable. Obviously Sunni and Shia problems would have torn the country apart - as it almost did anyway. In Afghanistan, it simply would have accelerated the return of the Taliban, post our initial victories. More importantly - we simply should never have invaded Iraq to start with. (Invading Afghanistan was politically inevitable, though at best would have served little purpose beyond simply bombing bin Laden's camps.)

It took me several months to figure out that Vietnam was a tragic error - that we'd never win there, and there was no domino danger. I also learned a bigger lesson - that so-called 'experts' aren't always right. In fact, they've been wrong on every single call in the Middle East for at least the last half-century. Bush II's decision/deception to invade Iraq was the latest, and perhaps worst mistake. Attacking Afghanistan seemed to make a lot more sense, and we quickly swept the countryside with a few advisors teaming with the Northern Alliance, along with our Air Force.Or did we? Afghanistan then faded out of the news until about 2008, and we then realized little, if anything, had been accomplished. Fortunately, this book provides important added dimensions and answers. Prior to arriving in Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan in 11/2001, author Gall had met Russian veterans of their Afghanistan conflict, as well as listened to stories from her then journalist father who had covered the conflict. She had also traveled to Pakistan and Afghanistan - seeing Wahhabis, North Africans, and others - then looking for a new cause. Author Gall has been a reporter for the New York Times for much of this - and a more qualified source would be hard to imagine.Afghanistan became America's longest war - fourteen years later, there still is no immediately resolution in sight - despite the Afghans having never been advocates of terrorism. The Taliban have since resurged. The 'real' enemy, however, is and always was Pakistan. Unfortunately, it has been difficult to learn of Pakistan's involvement - thanks to sometimes brutal manipulation of the media to hide the truth from its own people. Galls story begins with a Northern Afghanistan Taliban surrender, November 2001. Their leader had commanded over 10,000 Taliban along with hundreds more al Qaeda and other foreign fighters. There were also hundreds of Pakistanis - advisors, trainers, illiterate villagers and religious students, and intelligence experts. About 2,000 Pakistani had been evacuated on secret flights from a nearby airfield. The Pakistanis were retired officers on contract, civilians, and only occasionally active soldiers, never in uniform. Some had been trained by the U.S. Army. Pakistan's objective - protecting its western flank; Islamists were favored as allies because they could be counted on to resist non-Muslim foes such as the Soviet Union and India, and ethnic Islamist Pashtuns in Afghanistan. (Pakistan was also concerned with controlling Pashtun nationalism - some wanted their own state.) Osama bin Laden later became a leading influence.The Taliban had been formed seven years prior with the intent of gaining control and establishing a fundamentalist Islamic regime. They enforced a strict, fundamentalist code of behavior harking back to Mohammad's time - banning music, television, and almost all recreation, required males to attend prayers 5X/day and grow their  beards long. Their contribution to society was bringing order to an often lawless countryside. By 2001 they'd come close to their overall goal. Then came 9/11. U.S. missiles demolished Taliban positions and camps, followed by Afghans on horseback seizing the territory and finishing off stragglers. Even in cities, missiles found the Taliban, guided by Afghan informers working undercover with GPS locators and satellite phones. A number of the foreign fighters resisted being taken prisoner (some feared repatriation, others were religious zealots), and both sides suffered casualties. The prisoners were among the first transferred to the Guantanamo prison in Cuba. Others, sent elsewhere by General Dostum's men, were treated warily at best - many locked in airtight shipping containers died from asphyxiation en route.The Taliban had misjudged the strength of the American attack, been greatly overextended in northern Afghanistan, and misread the strength of their standing with the Afghan population via co-opting regional and religious figures. In southern Afghanistan, American precision-bombing - guided by American special forces, also quickly decimated local Taliban. Tribal elders and opposition groups rushed forward to join the winning side. Mullah Omar, however, continued to refuse to give up bin Laden to the U.S. The other Taliban leaders surrendered, Karzai did not accept Omar's and he was allowed to escape.Years later, as the Taliban resurgence grew, critics questioned why there had not been a greater effort to find a more inclusive settlement and even a power-sharing agreement that could have prevented a return of hostilities. Algerian diplomat Lakhdar Brahimi, head of the U.N. mission in 2001 said the American and Afghan opposition would not have allowed such.A strictly honored custom is that no one enters an Afghan's home without being invited, and no man unrelated to the family enters the women's quarters. Thus, the readiness of foreign soldiers to violate this by kicking down doors in house-to-house raids and searching women's quarters became one of the most upsetting issues for Afghans. (Conversely, when you are invited into someone's home, you are under the protection of your host. Thus, the author had no fear going to interview a Taliban commander in a back street.)Taliban did not trust Karzai's promise that they could return to their homes and live in peace because they had lost the support of the people and expected retribution from opponents and arrest or worse from Americans. They were also distrustful of the Pakistanis because President Musharraf was cooperating with the U.S. - nonetheless, large numbers filtered into Pakistan. Only a single prominent Taliban official was handed over to the U.S. in the first years after 9/11.Mullah Omar's call to arms 2/03 changed the pace of Taliban activities. Police posts came under frequent attack, fliers announcing jihad and warning against collaborating with Americans and the Karzai started turning up. An alliance took place between the Taliban, al Qaeda, and a mujahideen leader. Taliban members in exile were threatened with force by ISI if they tried to avoid the insurgency, the Taliban foreign minister was jailed by Americans despite offering to cooperate, and the Taliban offered money to its members - $175/month, with bonuses for killing government officials and Americans. (Many had no other way to support their families.)The coalition had 11,500 in its force in mid-2003 (and easily defeated the insurgents then in southern Afghanistan), vs. 140,000 NATO-led and 300,000 Afghan security forces seven years later. Many of Karzai's governors and security officials were inadequate, and in some cases grossly corrupt and predatory --> losing support of large sections of the population. (Local police chiefs tended to use family members as bodyguards; the most effective ones were former mujahideen commanders with loyal networks of fighters and informants.) Governors who tried to manage more honestly were hampered by lack of money, infrastructure, and security - problems ignored by Kabul. One high-level source told Gall that the Taliban were being reorganized by funding from Arab countries and that Mullah Omar and other top commanders were in Pakistan, and protected there by their links to the Pakistani establishment.Then came years of American/NATO bombing of suspected Taliban hideouts, innumerable associated civilian deaths, and creating Afghan hatred of their 'rescuers.' Not until General McChrystal took command in 2009 did U.S. switch to protecting the civilian population. But the damage was done. (Part of the rationale for the air strikes - only having about 35,000 NATO forces in 2008 forced its use.) Reports then came of soldiers killing villagers, instead of bombs. Whenever author Gall and other reporters were able to reach the scene and interview witness, they corroborated the veracity of those claims - contrary to the reports of the soldiers. There were also reports of prisoners being abused/tortured/beaten to death - Gall even saw death certificates issued by American pathologists listing cause of death as 'Murder.' No one was charged. Others were detained for years without trial or contact with family or lawyers, sometimes fingered by malicious or misguided informers.In 2004 the U.N. and U.S.-led coalition initiated a nationwide disarmament program (Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration program) to reduce the power of militia commanders and prevent a repeat of the factional violence of the 1990s. The mujahideen's big guns and old Soviet tanks were put under government control, and the armed militias, estimated at 100,000, were disbanded. Every rural family had had men in the mujahideen, and the Taliban benefitted from their growing disaffection. While it disabled rivals to Karzai, it also removed the strongest anti-Taliban forces from the scene, creating a vacuum of power. There was no Afghan Army in Helmand (southern Afghanistan) at the time, the police consisted of just a few hundred men dispersed over a dozen district town, and the U.S. had only a small presence in Gereshk. Eighteen months later, author Gall learned that the Taliban now held sway and the area was now too dangerous for travel. People then questioned the seriousness of NATO and the government.Karzai was a poor administrator, and didn't work to create pressure to reduce Afghan on Afghan abuses. His staff ignored ordered, and he spent little time praise the troops.Suicide bombing was unknown in 2001 Afghanistan until the assignation of Ahmed Shah Massoud 9/9/01, but became increasingly common by 2006 . Afghan investigators soon discovered that the suicide bombers (mostly Afghans living in Pakistan, or Pakistanis - eg. paid $1,400 to their families, if successful; an Afghan judge was paid $40/month) and their supplies were emanating from Pakistan - especially their madrassas (free room and board, as many as 3,000 students at a site - students could be taught general subject, including math and geography, but were only tested in religious subjects). Pakistani officials repeatedly refused to take action.Bottom-Line: 'The Wrong Enemy' is interesting reading and helps one understand our failure in Afghanistan. While it is clear that Pakistan served as a refuge and training ground for Afghanistan's Taliban, Gall does not make a convincing case that had the U.S. forcefully addressed that problem Afghanistan would have turned out differently. For one thing, U.S. failure to take advantage of its initial Afghanistan successes provided an incredible opportunity for a Taliban resurgence. Another problem - Pakistan has over 100 nuclear weapons, as well as missiles and a rabid Muslim population. Her coverage of the 'Red Mosque' siege and Bhutto assassination, as well as its lawless northern region also suggests potential problems if the U.S. had further angered Pakistan's Muslims by going beyond the use of drones in Pakistan.

China holds over $1.4 trillion in U.S. debt, by far our largest foreign debt holder. As of the end of August of 2015, the U.S. trade imbalance with China is already at $237 billion, en route to an annual imbalance of $350+ billion. 'Watching the Obama administration, one might think nothing can be done about protecting American workers and companies.' says Trump. Continuing - 'What China has done to the U.S. may be the greatest theft in the history of the world.'Almost all American politicians tell us how great we are, then switch to how they're going to make America even better - all the while denying even the existence of our major problems and failing to focus on resolving them. The most obvious example - our economy, decimated by millions of illegal immigrants and their progeny, hundreds of thousands of H1-B visas, and shipping millions of jobs to Mexico and Asia.America had a $40.4 billion trade deficit in goods and services (excluding energy) in March, 2014, $121.5 billion for the first quarter of the year. Since 1970, we‚Äôve accumulated an almost $10 trillion trade deficit in goods and services ($9.552 billion) via a negative balance every year except three (1970, 1973, and 1975). Per the Center for American Progress‚Äôs 3/2008 report, that deficit has also extended to high-technology (including aerospace, information and communication technology, opt-electronics, and nuclear technology) since 2002, and includes China, Indonesia, Ireland, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan. Not surprisingly, the trade deficit is also widening, from $82.1 billion for the years 1970-79 to $5.5 trillion for 2000-09. ‚ÄòServices‚Äô are the one bright spot, barely ‚Äì steadily increasing to a $229 billion surplus in 2013. The ‚Äòreally bad news,‚Äô however, is that Alan Blinder (former Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman, Economics Professor at Princeton) contends that about one-fourth of remaining jobs are vulnerable to offshoring, mostly in the services area.Meanwhile, Wall Street is climbing to new levels as our economy now produces (record) ‚ÄòProfits Without Production‚Äô (Paul Krugman) ‚Äì providing proof that Wall Street and Main Street are no longer closely connected.Many Trump opponents contend that limiting free trade would bring back the Great Depression, citing the fact that after the Smoot-Hawley bill was passed the depression deepened. Data, however, does not support blaming Smoot-Hawley tariffs for worsening economic conditions in the U.S. Three problems severely undermine such a conclusion:1)There already were preexisting high tariffs prior to Smoot-Hawley,2)Smoot-Hawley was passed 8 months after the October 1929 stock market crash, and3)Foreign trade comprised a very small proportion (about 0.5%) of U.S. GDP at the time.Others simply assert that free trade boost U.S. employment, citing Boeing as an example. True, Boeing and a few others have greatly benefitted from free trade, but one should not forget that OVERALL, we‚Äôve imported far more than imported ‚Äì there‚Äôs no way to logically conclude that U.S. employment has benefitted overall from free trade.Some dismiss free trade as a minor issue, preferring to instead focus on federal deficits, especially expenditures for health care and Social Security. Somehow our cumulative $10 trillion trade deficit also becomes invisible to those concerned about federal debts. That logic is obviously faulty ‚Äì there cannot be any doubt that free trade has reduced U.S. employment, wages and benefit levels, as well as tax (eg. income and sales) collections. It also has increased demands for government assistance (unemployment insurance, Food Stamps, Medicaid, retraining and additional education). Treating symptoms (our large and increasing federal deficit), and focusing on symptoms (our large and rising federal instead of causes (free trade) just doesn‚Äôt make sense. Neither does ignoring our large and rising cumulative merchandise trade deficit.Free Trade has also hollowed out much of America‚Äôs manufacturing base ‚Äì driving through Detroit, Akron, Youngtown, Gary and other former industrialized cities reveals innumerable silent smokestacks, empty parking lots, and broken windows in our former factories. We‚Äôve also gone from being the ‚Äòarsenal of democracy‚Äô to relying on Russian rockets used to launch half of U.S. military and national intelligence satellites.Estimating the employment losses due to free trade requires first obtaining a figure for hourly total compensation costs. Per the Bureau of Labor Statistics, that would be $35.53 for the U.S. in 2011. (Also notable and important ‚Äì Japan ($35.71), Germany ($47,38), Switzerland ($60.40) and others have higher costs AND a positive merchandise trade balance.) Converting the $35.53 to an annual cost (about $74,000), and dividing that figure into the average annual trade deficit for the last five years (about $500 billion) creates an estimate of 6.7 million potential job gains from eliminating our merchandise trade deficit.Other important benefits would also result from eliminating our merchandise trade deficit ‚Äì reduced demand for government services, improved psychological and physical health for the long-term unemployed, increased sales and income tax collections, higher wages and benefits for many of those still employed, and improved U.S. ability (via co-location) to conduct R&D linked to refinements of existing products and production processes.The losers from doing such ‚Äì profits at large corporations and Wall Street, and the wealth and incomes of the 1%.What‚Äôs the easiest way to eliminate these deficits ‚Äì direct government action. We also need to examine how Japan, Canada, Germany, Switzerland and others have managed to avoid this problem, despite even higher labor costs, as well as determine how to prevent the problem from undermining our service sector in the near future.Another major problem for our economy - the estimated 12 million illegals and their progeny, taking jobs from Americans and lowering wages for millions more.Candidate Trump also opposes the 5,544-page Trans-Pacific Partnership free-trade deal, calling it 'insanity,' as well as far too long to be understood, and doesn't cover currency manipulation - the number-one weapon within Free Trade used by foreign countries to hurt the U.S. and take away jobs. (China is not part of the TPP deal, but widely expected to join in the next few years.)Trump also calls NAFTA a 'disaster' and vows to renegotiate or break the deal if elected. (I can't wait!)In other areas, Trump would significantly cut the Department of Education's funding, support school choice, defeat ISIS by taking their oil wealthy, and replace ObamaCare.The 'good news' in this sea of red ink? Donald Trump has identified Free Trade and illegal immigration as major sources of our economic doldrums! His election would go a long ways towards fixing our economy. Let's replace 'Free Trade' with 'Fair Trade.'

In Italy, it is one out of 17,100, and one of 1,800 in the U.S. Sixty-two countries have lower lifetime risks of maternal deaths than the U.S.Among poor countries, higher national income is associated with better health (up to about $10,000/capita in purchasing power parity), among 'rich' countries getting richer does very little for health.
