But Kerr doesn't spend nearly enough time in that era (71 C.E.) to give us the flavor of the years of true Elven greatness.Likewise, far too late in the saga she introduces the race of Dwrgi, who, other than corresponding to Water as the other races correspond to the other Classical Elements (Elves the air, Horsekin fire, Dwarves the Earth, and Humans Aethyr), manage to add essentially nothing to the storyline.Similarly, there are individual characters who are given large and promising introductions. We are led to believe they are going to play major roles,  but then Kerr gives them no set purpose in the story. They make their entrance to the sound of trumpets and exit to the sound of crickets, having done little more than add color to a scene or two.After writing fourteen previous novels, Kerr, with surprising authorial inefficiency, seemed to be cramming this one full of odds and ends just so she could finish up the series. I kept sensing that she meant the Deverry Saga to have one more book (perhaps the fourth of "The Dragon Mage" Cycle or a fifth to "The Silver Wyrm") in order to really do the series justice, but that, for some reason, she could not make the tale she needed to tell maintain the critical mass to be a fifteenth or sixteenth volume. Instead, book number 15/16 is hidden somewhere inside THE SILVER MAGE like a fetus in fetu.Given the sheer scope and timeline of the Deverry series (at 2.5 million words written over a period of twenty three years, it covers 1000 years of Deverrian history), it's far from amazing that bringing the series to a close would present some real difficulties. Authors far more talented than Kerr (or me) have problems ending their own epic tales. I was seven-eighths of the way through THE SILVER MAGE before I got a whiff of where the book would be ending. I'm not certain that, to that point, Kerr knew either. Or, let me correct that: Kerr has always maintained she had the ending in mind, but that she had just a foggy idea of how to get there. In the end, she got there just by deciding to get there (insert kettle drums here).After the resolution (which I won't spoil), the book ended, ironically enough, with a surprising abruptness. After there being a full fourteen novels about the world of Annwn, THE SILVER MAGE didn't unwind the Eternal Knot Kerr had designed. Instead, like Alexander facing the Gordian Knot, it cut it. THE SILVER MAGE screeched to a halt as though it was a speeding car on the Interstate that just managed to avoid going through the guardrail.The series asked many long-standing questions of itself, starting all the way back in Daggerspell, written in 1986---Why, what, and how, exactly, was Rhodry's wyrd Eldidd's wyrd? And what was the great debt that was owed to Rhodry by Jill through the thousand years the story covers?---Kerr definitely answered the questions in 2009's THE SILVER MAGE, but the answers seemed to lack the necessary gravitas.Very unsatisfactorily, Kerr spent very little time on any sort of coda to her story: Characters who had been of great importance all through the saga left the stage with no fanfare at all, not as much as a fare-thee-well. Lesser characters did not even get an honorable mention as the lights faded.All in all, THE SILVER MAGE, though well-written, seems curiously unfinished.***Having read all of Kerr's Deverry Saga in the matter of a month and a half (roughly a book every three days), I took note of a number of central themes. Here they are, in no particular order:1. CHANGE:  Life is change. Despite what the characters say, that one's fate cannot be turned aside, it's clear that humanity does not know what its fate is. The smallest decisions can cause a "Butterfly Effect" which echoes down the ages. And we are that butterfly, always free to flap its wings.2. SOCIAL EVOLUTION:  The Kingdom of Deverry begins its days as a war-torn geographical entity, hardly a Kingdom at all, a place that is wracked by internal strife. Men kill each other over minor points of "honor." Although time passes incredibly slowly, and there are many reversals along the way and much fear and xenophobia, ultimately the Kingdom is unified, violence becomes less acceptable, and the kingdom begins to trade with and share knowledge with its various neighboring states. The Taer Angwidd (Unknown Land) of the earliest novels becomes a known land wherein live Elves, Dwarves, Horsekin, Dwrgi, Gel Da'Thae, Dragons, and other humans. "Ethics" begins to replace "honor" as the basis of the social code.3.  LIFE LESSONS: Every character goes through any number of reincarnations. Your mother in one life may be your mortal enemy in another. Your life is eternal even though the body you wear in any particular life is not. And because each life represents an opportunity to learn, each life is precious.4.  THE ROLE OF RITUAL:  Kerr's ritual is tied up with the use of magic in the Deverry books, but strip away the pyrotechnics and ritual becomes a grounding force in the world, one that helps to define all actions as sacred. This is in keeping with the Kabbalah, upon which she based her dweomer system.5.  THE POWER OF WOMEN:  Kerr is a Feminist, and not for nothing does the great ritual that closes the book involve no men in its working. As the saga evolves, Women become increasingly central to the tale as the teachers, the healers and the bearers of knowledge. Men have temporal power as kings and warriors, but women, as the bearers of Life and Secret Knowledge, are the keepers of the Spirit.***The numerous storylines in the Deverry Saga all become one, ultimately. But here is my summary of them:1. The Tangled Wyrd:  Nevyn, Jill and Rhodry are the three central "present-day" characters of the series. Most of the series concerns the interactions of these three, whether in past or present lives.2. The Transformation of Rhodry: Rhodry is born a human warlord, but as the story evolves, he evolves, passing through identities as a human warlord, a human prince, a slave, an elf, a dwarven ally, and a dragon.3.  The Return of The Elves: Having been brutally displaced by the Horsekin from their near mythical cities of the past, the various far-flung Elven survivor communities slowly reunite and begin to re-establish their kingdoms.4.  Evandar's Trick:  Evandar is the mythological Trickster due to whose ill-considered, incompletely thought-out schemes the history of Annwn is so bloody for so long.5.  Alshandra and The Horsekin:  In trying to incarnate his race, Evandar gains the enmity of his wife, Alshandra, whose rekigious/warrior cult soon swells and causes the Horsekin Wars.6.  The Dark Dweomer:  Dark Dweomermasters attempt to destabilize Deverry.7.  The Great Krysello:  Rhodry's half-brother Salamander, a jokester with serious intent travels to The Westlands, Bardek, and The Northlands serving the needs of the kingdom.8.  The Dragons' Lair:  At first merely characters in the Horsekin Wars, the dragons become a major theme that brings the saga to its close, hence linking all storylines.9. King Maryn and The Silver Daggers: In what amounts to an independent novel within the saga, King Maryn unifies Deverry.Another reader might choose different elements; for example, I consider the Dwarven stories (including Haen Marn) to be part of the Horsekin Wars, just as I count the brief story of the Dwrgi under that rubric. I'd be interested in seeing others' comments on this series.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings. Some readers will insist that Tolkien's work, and Katharine Kerr's, falls under the rubric of "High Fantasy," but the difference between the two genres seems, to this reviewer, to be equivalent to the difference between purple and violet.More relevantly, fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into the genre, whatever name we give it. In truth, Tolkien breathed life back into the old Northern European myths about Elves and Dwarves and Trolls. The good Professor, an Oxford Don whose specialty was Philology, would be proud of Ms. Kerr, who puts her own fascinating and lively spin on the old myths.The prolific Katharine Kerr taps into the ancient Celtic traditions to create the world of Annwn (literally meaning "Nowhere" in Welsh), an incredibly detailed, incredibly graphic land of the imagination filled with lost mountains, far valleys, and towns and villages whose denizens, most unknowingly, exist in a world filled with "Dweomer.""Dwimmer," meaning "magic" or "sorcery," is an ancient English word, probably derived from the original Brythonic language spoken by the Celtic Britons in pre-Roman times. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with The Bristling Wood, book number three, should bring you right up to THE SHADOW ISLE. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of fourteen novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone). THE SHADOW ISLE is the fourteenth book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry series, and is book three of "The Silver Wyrm Cycle," the fourth and concluding cycle in the saga.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, Jill's preincarnation.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.THE SHADOW ISLE begins with an interesting turn. Haen Marn, the Shadow Isle of the title is a dweomer island, occupied by dwarves. It has, to this point, played a minor role in the saga, but in this eponymous book, Kerr gives it it's due.Haen Marn vanished from Annwn when the Horsekin raids began some sixty years ago, rematerializing in the very earthly country of medieval Alba. For those of us who are not Celticists, Alba (or Alban) is the ancient Celtic name for Scotland. The Albans seem entirely nonplussed by the appearance of the dweomer island, assuming it came from Cymru (Wales) because of the language its odd inhabitants speak. For the denizens of Haen Marn, Alba seems Deverry-like, but they are bewildered by the cult of the sheep worshippers---at least that's their assumption about the Holy Lamb of God. Kerr, like all authors, can't resist the obligatory inside jokes that propel all storytelling. The hoped-for return of Haen Marn to Annwn may well be the first sign that peace is returning, in what has become essentially a world war.The Elves, after a thousand year long nomadic existence, are beginning to settle in towns, and there is talk of returning to their ancient cities if only the Horsekin raids can be stopped.In Deverry, things are taking dark turns. Although the Deverrians and their allies manage to defeat the invading Horsekin in set battles, their victories have not blunted the Horsekin appetite for raiding, pillaging, slaughter and slavetaking.Neb and Branna continue to study dweomer, though Neb is fixated on his past life as Nevyn. Considering himself the world's greatest dweomermaster returned, he begins to condescend to his teachers, and in his attempt to recover all of Nevyn's vast knowledge, he takes steps that may or may not lead him away from the Light.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.THE SHADOW ISLE is very much a "transitional" book. Nothing begins or ends here, despite the idea of some readers that THE SHADOW ISLE would end the series. Rather, it's a bridge to the concluding book of the Deverry Saga, The Silver Mage.Although THE SHADOW ISLE isn't able to stand alone, the quality of Kerr's writing continues to reach the same high standards it has evolved toward over the twenty years it took her to write the series.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings (I was recently advised by a role-playing fanatic that Tolkien's work, and Katharine Kerr's, falls under the rubric of "High Fantasy," but the difference between the two genres seems to be equivalent to the difference between purple and violet).More relevantly, fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into the genre, whatever name we give it. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with The Red Wyvern, book number nine, should bring you right up to THE SPIRIT STONE. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of thirteen novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone). THE SPIRIT STONE is the thirteenth book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry series, and is book two of "The Silver Wyrm Cycle," the fourth and concluding cycle in the saga.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, Jill's preincarnation.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.THE SPIRIT STONE follows immediately upon The Gold Falcon.  The warlike Horsekin, driven by their increasing religious fervor for the Alshandra Cult, have built a fortress right at the place where Horsekin lands, Gel Da'Thae lands, Elven lands, Dwarven lands, the Kingdom of Deverry and The Rhiddaer all share their borders, essentially dominating Annwn with the ability to strike in any direction. The fortress must be destroyed.After briefly sketching out the crisis facing modern-day Deverry, Kerr takes us back in time to just before the opening of Daggerspell (book one of the saga). After the death of Branoic the Silver Dagger, Nevyn has been searching for Brangwen's latest reincarnation, and finds her. Her name is Morwen, and she is Jill's immediate preincarnation. Abused, mocked and feared as a witch for having a harelip, Morwen's only real happiness in life is being nursemaid to Salamander, who is her young, half-elven nephew. When Salamander's Elven father comes to take him away from his neglectful mother, Morwen happily goes with them. She befriends Loddlaen, the son of Nevyn's old apprentice, the dweomermaster Aderyn and the Elven dweomermaster Dallandra. Not even a formal apprentice himself, Loddlaen, unbeknownst to anyone else, recklessly decides to teach Morwen dweomer.The second half of THE SPIRIT STONE recounts the assault on the Horsekin fortress of Zak Gral. During the assault, Salamander discovers a "shewstone" that holds the secret to the Silver Wyrm's transformation back into a man.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.In reviewing the earlier Deverry novels, I noted that Kerr's writing was often unpolished and rough-edged despite the incredible energy of her storytelling. Kerr's introductions of new characters and plot twists always seemed to have an odd sense of afterthought about them. Since the series is written non-linearly, Kerr was able to plug in elements as needed to move the storylines along, but these plug-ins sometimes seemed sloppy, as when  unforeshadowed events suddenly troubled preincarnated characters we already thought we knew well, throwing the basis of their storylines a bit out of balance. In THE SPIRIT STONE, Kerr takes the time to put a fine finish on the rough edges, and to clean up after herself, literarily.The volumes of "The Silver Wyrm" Cycle "feel" different than the rest of the Deverry Saga; there is a sense of completeness to them that the earlier volumes simply didn't have. This is not merely because the story is drawing to its close. Rather, the books feel more self-contained. A reader, unfamiliar with Deverry, could pick up THE SPIRIT STONE and enjoy it as a stand-alone novel.Kerr's authorial voice is stronger than it has ever been. In describing Morwen's first sight of the Sea of Grass, Kerr writes so splendidly that even I, a person with no graphic arts talent to speak of, was moved to consider sketching what she presented to my mind's eye, a perfect portrait in words.As I noted in my review of The Gold Falcon, Kerr suffered a serious health problem and was forced to take a lengthy hiatus from the Deverry saga between 2000 and 2006. While just a shade less satisfying than its predecessor book, THE SPIRIT STONE earns five well-deserved stars.  Katharine Kerr's ability to write matured tremendously in those six years, and her deft handling of plot twists, past events, and new characters is a sign of her growing ability and sheer talent as an author.

I read this extremely unoriginal book when it first came out in 1977, around the same time as The Silmarillion. Tolkien was all the rage then with my friends, mostly, I think, because the happy Hobbits smoked a lot of pipe-weed. But that's something else.THE SWORD OF SHANNARA is the illegitimate spawn of The Fellowship of the Ring. A group of people, including a couple of rustics, a dwarf, elves, men, and a wizard, go on a Quest, involving a long trek, a dark cavern and an evil monster, all because of the aforementioned sword of the title.I hated this book when I first read it at age 17, because it was SO, SO nakedly derivative of Tolkien, and weakly written to boot. It was JRRT without the epic style. Every time Hendyl was described as an "irascible dwarf" (and that was every time Hendyl was described) I wanted to spit. I suppose that, as per The Lord of the Rings all dwarves (except Snow White's boyfriends) are irascible. Why couldn't Hendyl just be a nice guy? THAT would have been original.Of course, almost all modern Sword and Sorcery/High Fantasy owes it's existence to Tolkien. Feist and Kerr, and Kurtz, and George Lucas in STAR WARS, and others have recognizable dwarves and elves and dark lords (though they may be called by different names or not).  But Brooks went nuts. Every character, the settings, the plot, the whole schmear, is Tolkien rebooted in safe mode.Commenters say Brooks started THE SWORD OF SHANNARA in 1967, prior to reading Tolkien in college, and finished THE SWORD OF SHANNARA in law school. For one thing, "starting" a book could mean that he wrote seven paragraphs and laid it aside for five years; in short, it means nothing.Brooks unquestionably read Tolkien before or while writing the bulk of THE SWORD OF SHANNARA. I will give him credit, though, if he could write anything, no matter how thin and derivative, besides exams during law school.In the recent past, I did try to read The Elfstones of Shannara, but gave it up within a few pages. I also tried re-reading this, but gave it up almost as quickly. It couldn't hold me; I already knew the story, and the quality of the writing is, very, very unlike Tolkien, too watery to sustain a second visit to Shady Vale.The egg salad quality of the writing is what truly distinguishes this book from Tolkien. Given the baldly derivative nature of Brooks' novel, I'm surprised that the Del Rey imprint was launched with this book, and I'm equally surprised that this has remained a big seller. But then, in 1977, there wasn't much Fantasy around, as opposed to today, where it drips off the bookshelves.As an adult, I'll revise my opinion of THE SWORD OF SHANNARA upward just a tick. "Hate" is far too strong an emotion to expend on this book, but I wouldn't recommend it.I suppose that pre-teens new to Fantasy and people who can't hack their way through Tolkien's idiosyncratic written brand of Brewer's Biblical can enter the fantasy portal here. Otherwise, there's nothing much here that wasn't done earlier and far better.

Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with A Time of Exile, book number five, should bring you to the first book in the saga, Daggerspell. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of twelve novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone). THE GOLD FALCON is the twelfth book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry series, and is book one of "The Silver Wyrm Cycle," the fourth and concluding cycle in the saga.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, Jill's preincarnation.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels, which now number fifteen. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.The world of Annwn has changed a great deal since the days of The Fire Dragon (book number eleven). THE GOLD FALCON opens some forty years after the Deverrian victories in the Battles of Cengarn and Cerr Cawnen. The Elves of The Westlands and the Elves of the Southern Isles have been reunited. The Guardians have begun to be born into the world of Time, but being very new souls, most of them are suffering from a condition much like autism. The folk of The Rhiddaer, the Elves, the Dwarves, the Gel Da'Thae, and the people of Deverry have ongoing military alliances and trade agreements. They have been able to hold off the Horsekin Hordes, but the Alshandra Cult continues to spread, with converts even in Deverry and the Rhiddaer. Alshandra's priests and priestesses call for the destruction of the Elves. "Witnessing," dying in Alshandra's name, is considered a holy act. War is imminent.Some 550 years have passed since Brangwen's death. It has been 70 years since Nevyn's death and 40 since Jill's. Both Nevyn and Jill have been reincarnated, this time as Neb the Scribe and Lady Branna, a dowerless daughter of a minor lord. They meet and fall in love and are betrothed. Their long-delayed lovers' reunion causes their great, dormant dweomer powers to become manifest, and although they both begin to remember their past lives and knowledge, they still need to be trained. Salamander, returned from Bardek, and Dallandra the Elven Dweomermaster, undertake to train their own former teachers.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.Due to a serious health problem, Kerr was forced to take a lengthy hiatus from the Deverry Saga between 2000 and 2006. Her ability to write matured tremendously in those six years. THE GOLD FALCON brims with a sense of joy. Kerr survived her own illness and in celebration, she has brought her creations home. In reviews of the past Deverry novels, I have taken Kerr to task as not much of a literary stylist. Her writing always had rough edges and a lack of polish, despite the amazing energy of her storytelling. She was a competent popular novelist, but hers was never the type of writing that inspired cheers or tears in a reader. THE GOLD FALCON does.Although THE GOLD FALCON is a simple, straightforward tale told in the Deverrian present, lacking any preincarnation or reincarnation episodes or major plot twists, the quality of Kerr's writing has reached a new level in this book, which rightly and richly deserves six stars. Wedded to her already impressive storytelling abilities, the fineness of the wordcraft in THE GOLD FALCON makes this far and away the best of the Deverry novels so far.

Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings (I was recently advised by a role-playing fanatic that Tolkien's work, and Katharine Kerr's, falls under the rubric of "High Fantasy," but the difference between the two genres seems to be equivalent to the difference between purple and violet).More relevantly, fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into the genre, whatever name we give it. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with The Spirit Stone, book number thirteen, should bring you right back to THE FIRE DRAGON. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of eleven novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone). THE FIRE DRAGON is the eleventh book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry series, and is book three of "The Dragon Mage Cycle," the third cycle of the four in the saga.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, Jill's preincarnation.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. In THE FIRE DRAGON, Nevyn, his apprentice Lady Lillorigga and Jill's male preincarnation, Branoic the Silver Dagger, place Prince Maryn on the throne of Deverry.Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels, which now number fifteen. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.At one point in the Author's note, Kerr describes "The Dragon Mage" Cycle as a quintet of books. Apparently, The Gold Falcon, which she had already begun, was intended to be part of the quintet as well. Kerr had, as with Days of Air and Darkness, obviously reached another turning point in her storytelling and was unsure what direction to take. In the event, "The Dragon Mage" became not the longest of the Cycles but the shortest, a triptet.An attentive reader, particularly one who is reading the books in sequence, will discover descriptive paragraphs spotted here and there that were lifted whole from earlier volumes. It's a minor quirk. This happened in Days of Blood and Fire and Days of Air and Darkness, where the Deverry Saga had also begun to take seemingly unexpected turns. Apparently, this slightly nettling use of cut-and-paste is an indication of Kerr catching her literary breath. Fortunately, in THE FIRE DRAGON, it's much less noticeable than before (where it was hardly noticeable), which means that only a truly Obsessive-Compulsive reader like myself would catch it. It takes nothing away from the storylines.The first half of THE FIRE DRAGON concerns the unfinished storyline of Prince Maryn and the Silver Daggers begun in The Bristling Wood and continued in A Time of Omens, The Red Wyvern and  The Black Raven. King Maryn's reign over a reunified Kingdom of Deverry, conceived in glory, has been birthed in tragedy. Kerr teaches the reader a critical lesson of history, fictive and non-fictive, that despite the chronicled victories of males won on battlefields, much of the unchronicled fate of kingdoms lies with females in the Women's Hall, in Milady's bedchamber, and in the hands of midwives.THE FIRE DRAGON's second half continues the tale of present-day Deverry. An alliance of Elves, Dwarves, Humans, Gel Da'Thae, and the dragon Arzosah Sothy Lorezohaz  has defeated the Horsekin Army of the putative goddess Alshandra at the Siege of Cengarn. In the wake of victory, a mixed company of Elves, Dwarves and Men (along with Arzosah) escorts Jahdo Ratter back to his distant home of Cerr Cawnen, hoping for a defensive alliance with the citizens of the Rhiddaer. Shortly after they arrive in Cerr Cawnen, a Gel Da'Thae deputation reaches the city, also seeking the same alliance.Cerr Cawnen is thrown into chaos however, when the High Priestess of Alshandra's cult, the Raven Woman, who was at the Siege of Cengarn, arrives with a small army of Horsekin who are demanding the aid of the Rhiddaerfolk against the Deverrians and their allies. A dweomer-battle ensues in Cerr Cawnen, and though the Horsekin are again defeated, Rhodry Maelwaedd is mortally injured in the battle. The Guardian Evandar, preparing to follow his people into the world of Time, works one last great dweomer, and Rhodry, who has been undergoing a metamorphosis throughout the saga, is transformed into a dragon, the Silver Wyrm of the fourth cycle; and so ends THE FIRE DRAGON and "The Dragon Mage" Cycle.Kerr has created a raft of memorable and vivid characters and events in the series, and THE FIRE DRAGON is one of the best books of the entire series. If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.Kerr is not a great literary stylist, but she's a damn good straight-on storyteller. And if you're visiting Deverry, that's what you'll find: A damn good straight-on story that you can enjoy.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings (I was recently advised by a role-playing fanatic that Tolkien's work, and Katharine Kerr's, falls under the rubric of "High Fantasy," but the difference between the two genres seems to be equivalent to the difference between purple and violet).More relevantly, fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into the genre, whatever name we give it. In truth, Tolkien breathed life back into old Northern European myths about Elves and Dwarves and Trolls. The good Professor, an Oxford Don whose specialty was Philology, would be proud of Ms. Kerr, who puts her own fascinating and lively spin on the old myths.The prolific Katharine Kerr taps into the ancient Celtic traditions to create the world of Annwn (literally meaning "Nowhere" in Welsh), an incredibly detailed, incredibly graphic land of the imagination filled with lost mountains, far valleys, and towns and villages whose denizens, most unknowingly, exist in a world filled with "Dweomer.""Dwimmer," meaning "magic" or "sorcery," is an ancient English word, probably derived from the original Brythonic language spoken by the Celtic Britons in pre-Roman times. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with The Black Raven, book number ten, should bring you right back to here, where you began. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of ten novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone).Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, Jill's preincarnation.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. In THE BLACK RAVEN, Jill's male preincarnation, Branoic the Silver Dagger, is betrothed to Lady Lillorigga at the very end of The Time of Troubles.Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels, which now number fifteen. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.THE BLACK RAVEN is the tenth book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry series, and is book two of "The Dragon Mage Cycle," the third cycle of the four in the saga.Half of THE BLACK RAVEN takes place in the Deverrian present. Having been defeated at the Siege of Cengarn, the followers of the Guardian Alshandra (who had been masquerading as a war goddess) are scattered. The High Priestess of Alshandra's cult, the Raven Woman, has fled. Without Alshandra's interference, the Guardian Evandar has convinced most members of his race to incarnate in the world of Time.The second half of THE BLACK RAVEN concerns the unfinished storyline of Prince Maryn and the Silver Daggers begun in The Bristling Wood and continued in A Time of Omens and The Red Wyvern. Prince Maryn has all but won the war and ended the century-long Time of Troubles, but the emphasis is on "all but." A skilled and victorious warleader, the charismatic Maryn, unused to being said nay, must struggle with the politicking and intrigues of his slowly-coalescing Court, the remaining lords still at war with him, and, possibly worst, the hearthstone strife caused by his indiscriminate womanizing.Kerr is a talented storyteller but not a literary stylist. Kerr has created a raft of memorable and vibrant characters in the series, particularly the womenfolk, of whom Princess Bellyra and Lady Lillorigga especially stand out in THE BLACK RAVEN.  But, as has been a problem in past volumes, Kerr's introductions of new characters and plot twists seem to have an odd sense of afterthought about them. Since the series is written non-linearly, Kerr is able to plug in elements as needed to move the storylines along, but in THE BLACK RAVEN, these plug-ins sometimes have the feel of lumpy spackle hurriedly applied to the various unplugged holes in the huge storyboard she has created.In THE BLACK RAVEN unforeshadowed events suddenly trouble preincarnated characters we already know well, throwing the basis of their storylines a bit out of balance. The series would not have this feel if Kerr could randomly rearrange the various segments of the several progressing stories she is telling---indeed, she extensively re-wrote both Daggerspell) and Darkspell at one point in order to strengthen the series---but even this reviewer admits ruefully that ridding the Deverry books of a fault most readers would hardly notice  would require her to essentially re-write the series from back to front, a ridiculous proposition.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.Kerr is not a great literary stylist, but she's a damn good straight-on storyteller. And if you're visiting Deverry, that's what you'll find: A damn good straight-on story that you can enjoy.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings. I was recently advised by a role-playing fanatic that Tolkien's work (and Katharine Kerr's) falls under the rubric of "High Fantasy," but the difference between the two genres seems to be equivalent to the difference between purple and violet. More relevantly, fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into the genre, whatever name we give it. In truth, Tolkien breathed life back into old Northern European myths about Elves and Dwarves and Trolls. The good Professor, an Oxford Don whose specialty was Philology, would be proud of Ms. Kerr, who puts her own fascinating and lively spin on the old myths.The prolific Katharine Kerr taps into the ancient Celtic traditions to create the world of Annwn (literally meaning "Nowhere" in Welsh), an incredibly detailed, incredibly graphic land of the imagination filled with lost mountains, far valleys, and towns and villages whose denizens, most unknowingly, exist in a world filled with "Dweomer.""Dwimmer," meaning "magic" or "sorcery," is an ancient English word, probably derived from the original Brythonic language spoken by the Celtic Britons in pre-Roman times. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with The Fire Dragon, book number eleven, should bring you to THE RED WYVERN. However, given the numerous storylines and recurring characters in different incarnations that have developed over the course of nine novels so far, it's far easier to read the books in sequence (and you're advised to ignore the separate cycles, which do not really stand alone).Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, who is now reincarnated as Jill.Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. In THE RED WYVERN, Jill's male preincarnation, Branoic the Silver Dagger, and Nevyn work together to reunite the shattered Kingdom at the end of The Time of Troubles.Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels, which now number fifteen. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.THE RED WYVERN is the ninth book in Kerr's fifteen book Deverry oeuvre, and is book one of "The Dragon Mage Cycle," the third cycle of the four in the saga. As such, it marks a midpoint, a place where all the strands of the intricate Celtic knot she's designing overlay each other.Kerr, who had been publishing the Deverry books at the rate of one a year, wisely took more time to craft THE RED WYVERN, and the positive results are evident. This is a tightly-written story that addicts the reader virtually from the first page. This reviewer read THE RED WYVERN, all 416 pages of it, in one sitting.Four-fifths of THE RED WYVERN concerns the unfinished storyline of Prince Maryn and the Silver Daggers begun in The Bristling Wood and continued in A Time of Omens. Kerr emphasizes a heretofore minor character, Lady Merodda, as the tale progresses. We also meet her daughter, the lovely young Lady Lillorigga, whose Dweomer talent is being misused by the enemies of Prince Maryn. Lillorigga, with Nevyn at her side, must work to undo the evil.The remaining fifth of THE RED WYVERN gives us brief glimpses of the land of the Rhiddaer, the city of Cengarn, and the dweomer island of Haen Marn, as well as keeping us up on the progress of the characters Dallandra, Rhodry, and Evandar the Guardian. These glimpses resolve themselves into intersections within the overall plot.Unlike most Sword and Sorcery/High Fantasy authors, Kerr creates very strong female characters, starting with Jill. Although the men of Deverry believe they are in charge, it's becoming increasingly clear that the hand that rocks the cradle is the hand that rules Annwn.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous and sometimes the result of illicit love affairs between close relations, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The individual plotlines of the Deverry storylines are straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements within the stories themselves probably would have had the average reader screaming.Kerr is not a great literary stylist, but she's a damn good straight-on storyteller. And if you're visiting Deverry, that's what you'll find. A damn good story that you can enjoy.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings, and that fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into that genre. In truth, Tolkien breathed life back into old Northern European myths about Elves and Dwarves and Trolls. The good Professor, an Oxford Don whose specialty was Philology, would be proud of Ms. Kerr, who puts her own fascinating and lively spin on the old myths.The prolific Katharine Kerr taps into the ancient Celtic traditions to create the world of Annwn (literally meaning "Nowhere" in Welsh), an incredibly detailed, incredibly graphic land of the imagination filled with lost mountains, far valleys, and towns and villages whose denizens, most unknowingly, exist in a world filled with "Dweomer.""Dwimmer," meaning "magic" or "sorcery," is an ancient English word, probably derived from the original Brythonic language spoken by the Celtic Britons in pre-Roman times. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with Darkspell, book number two, should bring you to DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS.DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS, the eighth book in the fifteen book Deverry saga, is the concluding fourth book of "The Westlands Cycle," the second of four cycles in the saga.DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS was originally supposed to be the second book of a planned trilogy, as reflected in its formatting, since like it's predecessor book, Days of Blood and Fire, DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS is divided into numbered chapters titled, strangely enough, given Deverrian antipathy to the 'Rhwmanes,' in Latin.Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was somehow magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, who is now reincarnated as Jill. Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS continues the story of the Siege of Cengarn begun in Days of Blood and Fire. Jill uses her powers as the greatest human Dweomermaster to attempt to turn the tide of battle.Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.Unlike Days of Blood and Fire which recounts a story told entirely in the Deverrian "present," Kerr returns to her non-linear style of preincarnation flashbacks and reincarnation flashforwards that have been typical of the saga. In this case we return to Jill and Rhodry's younger years and meet the winsome Lady Sevinna who is the intended target of a poisoner. Kerr's characters are born, die, and are reborn time and time again, as they work out their incredibly complex interlinked karmic "Wyrds".DAYS OF AIR AND DARKNESS is a tightly-written, exciting and intricately detailed story written in the highly cinematic style that Kerr makes her own. Still, an attentive reader, particularly one who is reading the books in sequence, will discover descriptive paragraphs spotted here and there that were lifted whole from earlier volumes. While a description of a Dweomer technique for example, might not really change from book to book, Kerr should have taken the minimal time to reorder sentences or replace an adjective or two in such gleanings. Kerr was apparently tiring of churning out a book every eight months or so, and it shows. In point of fact it was to be two years before the next book in the Deverry  saga,The Red Wyvern was published.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The plotline of the Deverry books is straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements probably would have had the average reader screaming.Kerr is not a great literary stylist, but she is a damn good straight-on storyteller. And if you're visiting Deverry, that's what you'll find. A damn good story that you can enjoy.

THE DEBT is more of a psychological thriller than an action thriller. The action simply provides the bedrock for the psychodrama. THE DEBT is a remake of a 2007 Israeli film which was rather different.The acting in THE DEBT is excellent, particularly that of Jessica Chastain as the younger Rachel. Chastain is a talented actress who, though she has appeared in many films, has fortunately managed to avoid celebrity. Helen Mirren, who plays the older Rachel turns in her usual work of stellar caliber.It is 1965. Stefan, David and Rachel are Mossad agents tasked to capture the Mengele-esque "Surgeon of Birkenau," a Dr. Vogel, who is living inconspicuously in East Berlin, practicing gynecology twenty years after escaping justice for his war crimes of useless and horrifying medical experiments on Auschwitz inmates.They capture Dr. Vogel but when they attempt to sneak him "over the wall" into West Berlin things go badly awry, and so the three agents are forced to care for him while awaiting extraction. Realizing that his captors have become as much a set of prisoners as he himself, the wily Vogel (who is an unrepentant Nazi to the core) begins to torment them psychologically; eventually, he makes his escape.Recriminations fly back and forth. Finally, Stefan convinces David and Rachel to agree to the story that they killed Dr. Vogel while he was trying to escape. Eventually, they are extracted, and return to Israel as heroes, where they are feted and invited to speak publicly about their successful mission.Thirty-odd years pass. Stefan is now head of the Mossad. Stefan and Rachel have been married and divorced, and have a daughter who is a notable Israeli journalist. Their daughter writes their memoirs which become an international best-seller.At the same time that their daughter's book comes to print, a Ukrainian journalist announces that he has gotten an exclusive interview with a old man claiming to be the Surgeon of Birkenau. Rachel, Stefan and David's thirty-five year old lie begins to unravel. How they deal with that unraveling and the consequences they face make up the kernel of THE DEBT.I didn't like THE DEBT. I can't appreciate films where the motives and motivations of the characters get twisted into Turkish Taffy by dint of their own stupidity. There's something pathetic about watching intelligent people knowingly sticking their feet into bear traps, and that's what we have here. THE DEBT's biggest failing is the moral relativism of its characters. Dr. Vogel is the only character who seems to have the courage of his convictions, however twisted they may be. What I kept asking myself as THE DEBT played out was why the three agents simply didn't kill Vogel after their first botched extraction attempt. In the end, their lie, made true, would have been a better resolution than the self-imposed unresolvable ethical morass in which they lived their lives.

It's said that J.R.R. Tolkien invented an entirely new genre, "Sword and Sorcery," by creating The Lord of the Rings, and that fully 30% of all fiction books published today fall into that genre. In truth, Tolkien breathed life back into old Northern European myths about Elves and Dwarves and Trolls. The good Professor, an Oxford Don whose specialty was Philology, would be proud of Ms. Kerr, who puts her own fascinating and lively spin on the old myths.The prolific Katharine Kerr taps into the ancient Celtic traditions to create the world of Annwn (literally meaning "Nowhere" in Welsh), an incredibly detailed, incredibly graphic land of the imagination filled with lost mountains, far valleys, and towns and villages whose denizens, most unknowingly, exist in a world filled with "Dweomer.""Dwimmer," meaning "magic" or "sorcery," is an ancient English word, probably derived from the original Brythonic language spoken by the Celtic Britons in pre-Roman times. Likewise, "cwm" or "coombe," meaning "valley," appears only on Great British maps, the first variant being Welsh and the other Old English. "Weird" is a modern English word which means "bizarre," but it derives from the earlier word "weirding," a term applied to occultists who were supposedly able to alter fate.In keeping with ancient Celtic beliefs, Kerr crafts her epic in the form of an Eternal Knot. Theoretically, every tale she tells is the beginning, the middle, and the ending of the story, so that beginning the series with Days of Air and Darkness, book number eight, (alternatively titled A TIME OF JUSTICE in Great Britain) should bring you to DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE.Though DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE is book three of "The Westlands Cycle," the second cycle in the fifteen book Deverry saga, it's very clear that Kerr was uncertain what direction the saga was to take at this point. DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE is book number seven in the saga, and in one of the blurbs is described as "the first book in a new trilogy." Is there a trilogy hidden within the quindecimal saga? The hidden trilogy's name ultimately became the book's alternate U.K. title, A TIME OF WAR.DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE's formatting differs from the rest of the saga to this point as well, since the book is divided into numbered chapters titled, strangely enough, given Deverrian antipathy to the 'Rhwmanes,' in Latin.Kerr's representational humans are descendants of European Continental Celts (Gauls), an historic people made up of numerous tribes who were decimated and dominated by the Roman legions commanded by Julius Caesar, circa 50 B.C. According to Kerr's mythology, the tribe living in the invented Gaulish Kingdom Devetia Riga was somehow magically transported to Annwn, where they established the Kingdom of Deverry.The Deverry books concern the life stories of Jill, the heroine of the saga. What Jill does not know is that her life is inextricably bound up with that of the Dweomermaster Nevyn. Long ago, Nevyn was once Galrion, a Prince of the Realm, but youthful impetuosity led to his exile, and more importantly, to the deaths of several innocent people including his royal fiancee, the Princess Brangwen, who is now reincarnated as Jill. Brangwen's tragic death caused Nevyn to take a rash vow---to live until he had undone all the wrong he'd caused. As DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE opens, Jill is at the peak of her powers as the greatest human Dweomermaster.Kerr tells the long tale of Brangwen and Galrion in what amounts to a series of short novelettes-within-the-Deverry-novels, which now number fifteen. Along the way, Kerr fleshes out her colorful, lively universe, which is populated not only by the Deverrians, but by Elves and Dwarves, among many other beings.DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE is, like The Dragon Revenant, a story told entirely in the "present" without the preincarnation flashbacks or reincarnation flashforwards typical of the saga. Kerr's characters are born, die, and are reborn time and time again, as they work out their incredibly complex interlinked karmic "Wyrds".Despite some flaws, DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE is a tightly-written, exciting and enjoyable, internally consistent and intricately detailed story written in a highly cinematic style that Kerr makes her own.As for the flaws, let us just say that Kerr is not a great stylist, but she's a damn good straight-on storyteller. Her failings as an authorial stylist become more evident in DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE. An attentive reader, particularly one who is reading the books in sequence, will discover descriptive paragraphs spotted here and there that were lifted whole from earlier volumes. And while a description of a Dweomer technique, for example, might not really change from book to book, Kerr would have been a bit more respectful of her audience if she took that little bit of extra time necessary in this vast and sweeping epic to reorder sentences or replace an adjective or two. Still, all in all, its a failing many readers might not notice at all.Additionally, Kerr's introductions of new characters, and particularly new races, always seem to have an odd sense of afterthought about them, and in DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE, she drops an entirely new world on us with little foreshadowing (another indication that she had reached an undecided turning point in the saga). The book opens with our introduction to Jahdo Ratter, a boy of the Rhiddaer, a land roughly adjacent to Deverry's Arcodd Province, and populated by the descendants of Deverrian serfs who fled the kingdom during the Time of Troubles.And so, vertiginously, we suddenly discover that 'Taer Angwidd,' the presumptively empty northern 'Unknown Land' on Deverry maps, is teeming with very nearby humans, dwarven metropoli, dragons, and the fascinating race of the horsekin, troll-like humanoids who have the psychic ability to communicate with horses (much like the not-quite human Lord Perryn of an earlier episode).The horsekin (whose name reminds me, I apologize, of a vestigial body part), are divided into the Gel Da'Thae, a cosmopolitan race, and the "wild" horsekin of the plains, called Meradan (demons) or "The Hordes" by the Elves, and who behave like the Mongols' Golden Horde of old.DAYS OF BLOOD AND FIRE continues the uninterrupted story of Princess Carramaena begun in the epilogue to A Time of Omens. Carramaena is the human wife of the Elven Prince Daralanteriel. She is pregnant with their child, the soul of whom belongs to one of the members of the race known as The Guardians. Facing extinction in their alternate dimension, The Guardians have decided to attempt to be born into the world of matter and form.Not all Guardians want to share this fate, and one, Alshandra, has appeared to Men and Horsekin as a goddess, demanding that Carramaena be killed. Carramaena and her unborn child are now trapped in the besieged Deverrian city of Cengarn. The only way to lift the siege of Cengarn is for Rhodry Maelwaedd to seek out and form an alliance with the dragon Arzosah Sothy Lorezohaz.Rhodry continues what has become an ongoing character metamorphosis: Once Rhodry Maelwaedd, a human ruler, he was exiled by his brother. Becoming Rhodry of Aberwyn, a mercenary Silver Dagger, he was ultimately captured by his enemies and enslaved, with the name Taliaesyn. Rescued from slavery, he discovered his Elven roots as Rhodry ap Devaberiel. He has now become allied with the Dwarves who give him yet another new name, Rori, and set his feet on the path to finding the dragon.If you haven't read Katharine Kerr's "Deverry" books, you will find that very, very unlike Tolkien's Middle Earth, Annwn is rather tumbledown and casually violent. The stink of horse manure fills the air of the towns, roadside inns crawl with lice, ale, the universal drink, is dipped from open barrels (flies and all), drunken men with swords go to war over herds of pigs and cows or an inflated sense of ego disguised as honor, rape and robbery are commonplace, illegitimate children, though scorned, are ubiquitous, and the Deverrian tongue is replete with curses, most of which cannot be reprinted here. Kerr seems to delight in coming up with more and more outrageous expletive phraseology, my favorite of which is, "By the scaly underside of a dragon's ... !"J.R.R. Tolkien wrote like the restrained University Don he was. Middle Earth has the vertical intellectual airiness of the dreaming spires of Oxford. Kerr writes like the Rust Belt native that she is. Working-class Deverry spills horizontally off the pages in an entertaining flood, which is why it took fifteen full novels to tell the tale.The plotline of the Deverry books is straightforward rather than rococo, with just a few curves here and there. There's not a lot of mystery here, not a lot of unanswered questions, and any resolution of suspense tends to be pretty much what you'd predict. In the end, the reader has to keep track of more than enough incarnations and karmic twists that the addition of diversionary plot elements probably would have had the average reader screaming.As this reviewer stated earlier, Kerr is not a stylistic author, but she's an excellent, nay, damn good, storyteller. And if you're visiting Deverry, that's what you'll find. A damn good story that you can enjoy.

For starters, both Madking and I want to tell you that this item was sent to me for free in exchange for my honest review. Now that we have that out of the way, I can tell you that all of the feedback I have is positive!They give a nice warm light, similar to incandescent, perhaps a slight greenish cast. Madking says they are 50W equivalent, and I think that's correct. They are just a bit less bright than the 60W incandescent or the 14W CFL to which I compared. Like incandescent bulbs and unlike CFLs, they come to maximum brightness immediately.In use, they get warm but not hot. I could still grasp the bulb with my bare hand after it had been on for 15 minutes.They are sensibly packaged in a protective plastic clamshell which fits snugly in its cardboard box.The glass bulb is clear, so I think these would be most appropriate in applications where they will not be seen directly, like in a lamp where they would be hidden by a lampshade or frosted glass.

For starters, both Solememo and I want to tell you that this item was sent to me for free in exchange for my honest review. Now that we have that out of the way, I can tell you that most of the feedback I have is positive. I love these!For the last eight months or so, my "go to" headphones have been the Koss Pro4S Full Size Studio Headphones, Black with Silver Trim. I'm not going to tell you that the Solememo are as good as those, but they put in a very credible performance. They can't go way down into the low bass frequencies or way up into the high treble nearly as well as the Koss can, but they do a pretty reasonable job, I think. And they are bright and faithful in the midrange. They are very decent and quite clear. I've used them for both classical music and some pop mixed in as well. In the orchestral pieces, I found that on certain recordings, the SE09's could make the trebles a little shrill. Not terrible, but definitely noticeable. In addition to music, I've also listened to a couple of hours of an audiobook and found their performance on that assignment quite good.Combine all this with their "go anywhere, do anything," capability and I think they are winners. I like to walk a mile or two every day. I wouldn't try to do that with full size headphones, but it's no challenge for these. They stay put comfortably and are are just unobtrusive enough so that you don't look like a Space Ranger, yet folks will know you're listening to something and won't try to start a conversation with you while you have these on.I encountered a small problem pairing them with my Motorola Moto G2. I noticed that the Moto was trying to pair the SE09's with another set of BT headphones (which were power off) that I'd been using. This prevented the smartphone from connecting. Once I told it to forget the other pair, these paired up immediately. The Solememo's will tell you when you've powered on and they'll tell you when you've connected to Bluetooth. I mean that literally. The headset says, "Power on," and "Your headset is connected," at the appropriate times, as well as "Power off," when you shut them down.The internal rechargeable battery has good capacity. I've used these for about five hours so far, and they're still on their initial charge, but I'm getting "battery low," from the headset voice.But, for me, the best part is how comfortable these are. I have used quite a few different earbuds, both wired and BT, and after about 40 minutes max I have to take them off because of ear discomfort. This is the first set I've ever owned that I was able to wear for extended amounts of time!Control placement is good. I was able to adjust them in my ears without accidentally pressing buttons--a problem I have had with others. Changing volume, pausing and resuming is easy and the on/off is out of the way, so you're not hitting it accidentally.If Amazon allowed half-star ratings, I'd give these a 4 1/2, the 1/2 star deduction for the slightly screechy treble. However, I can't do that so I'm rounding up to a 5 on the strength of their extraordinary and very welcome comfort. I have other earbuds that sound a little better, but I'll be using these from now on because perfectly flat audio response means little if your ears hurt.This is a fine product for what it is--an inexpensive way to enjoy your audio entertainment while you get your exercise. If you're up for some serious music appreciation, then sit yourself down on a comfortable easy chair, get out your expensive, over-the-ear studio headphones and enjoy. If, however, you also need to get a little physical activity, then you're going to have to make some concessions. With these Solememo SE09's, the concessions will be easier to take than the exercise.

This is an attractive and useful group of five cooking tools designed for use with cookware having nonstick surfaces. They are large and hefty but have good balance with a comfortable grip and are a pleasure to use. On my kitchen scale, each weighs between 5 and 5 1/2 ounces. For comparison, my plastic Farberwares are under an ounce and half each!What makes these unique is that they have a stainless steel bracket (I'd call it a stand) about midway along the handle that will keep the business end of the utensil off your kitchen counter or stovetop when you set it down. It can still drip, but it's not going to come in contact with anything before you use it again with whatever you're cooking. I like that--no kitchen cleaners in the Pasta Sauce.I've used the spatula most often and have run it through the dishwasher four or five times. It cleans up nicely and suffers no damage. I've also used the solid and slotted spoons a few times each. I can detect no damage to my Calphalon and Anolon nonsticks whatsoever. Given that these tools are made by Silverstone, this is unsurprising.My worry here is that the metal bracket could come in contact with the nonstick surface during use. If you were to drop the spatula, for instance, while flipping your "over easy," it's not impossible that the stainless steel piece could mar the pan's surface. But they are so comfortable and easy to hold that this doesn't seem like much of a possibility.Another minor concern is that the metal bracket prevents these utensils from nesting together in a compact way. If you store your kitchen tools in a canister or similar kind of container rather than hanging them, they will require more space than their more conventional counterparts.

This is a fine product. Unfortunately, the packaging is not very good. I notice that many of the other Amazon reviewers did not receive a lid, rendering the can useless. I was lucky--I got all the necessary parts. In my case, however, there was no printed material in the box--no instructions, no warranty card, nothing. The cardboard shipping box in which the Step Can arrived was too flimsy for the weight of the thing and had partially opened up. My paperwork probably escaped when that happened. I was able to work out how to assemble and use it by going to simplehuman's website and looking at the product videos available for this unit.I find it to be a very well-made and well conceived item. The lid consists of two parts: A sort of "collar" that fits over the can and hides and secures the top of the trash bag that you've wrapped over the can's top edge, and the flip-up lid enclosed inside that collar. The lid is piston-damped. You open it by stepping on the pedal. When you release the pedal, instead of just falling on to the top of the can, the piston closes it slowly and noiselessly. The arrangement of the lid inside the collar also means that the can requires no additional clearance from the wall. You can push it into a corner as far as it will go and the lid will still be able to move through its range unimpeded. Mine is 24 3/4 inches tall with the lid closed.
