Add another 10 inches for the lid open. It's 18 1/2 inches wide, 12 3/4 inches deep.It's all very stable. Stepping on the pedal causes absolutely no movement of the can other than the lid raising. It seems very durable.It has a compartment into which you can stow a supply of simplehuman's trash bags. They provide you with a starter pack of their "Code K" bags and they are as high quality as the Step Can. They are very strong, not clingy and they are easy to use. Unfortunately, they are a little too pricey for me--23 bucks for 60 bags. The Target Tall Kitchen Bags that I'd been using with my old Rubbermaid Trash Can fit perfectly, are more economical and are strong enough, I think. (Although, as another reviewer has pointed out, the interior of the can has nooks and crannies and if a bag were to leak, clean-up might be difficult.) I can't store the Target bags in the can's built-in compartment, but I don't find that a serious drawback.I don't know who is responsible for the poor quality packaging, Amazon or simplehuman. Partly for that reason, I make no star-rating deduction for the flimsy box and partly for the fact that the product itself (if you have all the parts) is excellent and I'm glad to own it.

Prior to receiving this lamp, I had been using Globe Electric 52061 Swing Arm Clip Lamp, Black, a similar "Architect" style desk lamp. I purchased that one because I wanted a desk lamp that would not take up space on my desk and that I could elevate high enough so that it would cast useful light on a large area of my desk. That lamp satisfied both requirements. This one does, as well, and then some!I have it clamped to the middle of the back edge of my desk. The clamp is very solid and steady and the the lamp can be locked into it, so that it won't accidentally lift it out while its position is being adjusted. Thanks to the long swing arms, I am able to have the lamp set up so that the vertical distance from the surface of my desk up to the 22 watt circular fluorescent bulb (75-100w equivalent) is about 28 inches. The bulb is centered over my desk, about 15 inches in from its back edge. This arrangement allows me to have bright, useful illumination for the entire surface of the desk (which is 28" deep and 64" wide).My PC keyboard, the printer, the phone and the area where I write with pen and paper are all very well lit. I have the shade tilted backward slightly so that the light from the bulb doesn't go directly into my eyes as I work. I also have tilted it slightly away from the PC's LCD screen to avoid reflections there. The upper arm and the bulb holder both have a mechanism that allows me to lock them into place so they won't shift, even if I bump into the lamp.If this fixture were no more than that, I'd be satisfied. But just to sweeten the deal, it has a very large magnifying glass incorporated into it. When I need to thread a needle or tighten the tiny screws in the hinges of my reading glasses or read small print, it is a welcome aid to my tired old eyes.This was the perfect solution for me. The lamp is well-made and seems durable.One additional note: This lamp comes with the bulb in place and connected but with loose foam pads behind the bulb which, I presume, are there to protect it during shipping. They are easy to miss when setting up this fixture. I think it would be wise to remove them before use, as the bulb does get hot.

For starters, both Mengo and I want to say that this item was sent to me for a nominal amount for reviewing purposes and that I was open to both positive and negative feedback regarding the product. Now that we have that out of the way, I can tell you that most of the feedback I have is positive. I love these!For the last eight months or so, my "go to" headphones have been Koss Pro4S Full Size Studio Headphones, Black with Silver Trim. I'm not going to tell you that the Bumps are as good as those, but they put in a very credible performance. They can't go way down into the lower bass frequencies or way up into the high treble as well as the Koss can, but they do a pretty reasonable job, I think. And they are bright and faithful in the midrange. They are just surprisingly decent and quite clear. In addition to pop and classical music, I've also listened to an hour or so of an audiobook and found their performance on that assignment equally good.Combine all this with their "go anywhere, do anything," capability and I think they are winners. I like to walk a mile or two every day. I wouldn't try to do that with full size headphones, but it's no challenge for the Bumps. They stay put comfortably and are are just unobtrusive enough so that you don't look like a Space Ranger, yet folks will know you're listening to something and won't try to start a conversation with you while you have these on. That was an issue for me when I did my walks with conventional wired earbuds. I'd have to yank them out of my ears to catch what was left of the first sentence spoken to me.Pairing was no problem at all. The Bumps will tell you when you've powered on and they'll tell you when you've connected to Bluetooth. I mean that literally. The headset says, "Power on," and "Connected," at the appropriate times, as well as "Power off," and a couple of other phrases.The internal rechargeable battery has good capacity. I've used the Bumps for about three to four hours so far, and they're still on their initial charge.I have two minor quibbles. First, I wish that the semi-rigid neckband was just a tiny bit longer. It felt like it was pulling the earbuds backwards a bit when I had them comfortably seated in my ears. I had to really push it under my hair in the back to give myself enough slack. Maybe I have a big head, but I see others making similar comments, so perhaps Mengo could give us another half inch to work with when they make Rev. A.Second, every time I'd touch the earphones to put them on or adjust them, I would inadvertently press one of the buttons. There isn't much room for Mengo to work with on this. After all, you want the earpieces to remain small, but perhaps a guard or a ridge around the buttons so that a more deliberate press is required is called for. If Amazon allowed half-star ratings, I'd deduct that much for these two issues, but they are not worth a full star penalty.This is a fine product for what it is--a way to enjoy your audio entertainment while you get your exercise. If you're up for some serious music appreciation, then sit yourself down on a comfortable easy chair, get out your expensive, studio, over-the-ear headphones and enjoy. If, at the same time, you also need to get a little exercise, then you're going to have to make some concessions. With these Mengo Bumps, the concessions will be relatively small.

There have been no new versions of this App since 2011. It is clearly abandoned software. You can download only the Trial Version even when you are on this page for the Full Version. It does run but stops every few minutes to remind you that it's the Trial Version. If you try to upgrade, you come back here to the free Trial Version. There is no way that I can find to upgrade to the Full App.It's kind of a pity, because this does seem to be a pretty well-thought-out and full-featured Audiobook Player with a nice interface. It hung up on me once after a few minutes and I couldn't get the Widget to work and resume the last book, but those just look like bug fixes to me, probably caused by the fact that I'm running a version of Android from 4 years after the last time Akimbo was maintained (Lollipop 5.0.2). You might have better luck if you're running an older Android, and maybe it will even allow you to upgrade, but I wouldn't count on it.It's useless to me unfortunately, and I've uninstalled it.

My home was built in the '70s and all of its hinges squeak. Storm door, front door, kitchen cabinets, bi-fold doors in front of the washer and dryer, and so forth. It was a symphony of creaks and squawks around here. Until I got a can of this product!I have always preferred "dry" lubricants over regular lubricating oil. I think they attract less dirt and dust and are not affected if exposed to the elements--cold in particular. It used to be that you'd get a flexible tube of graphite particles and you'd "puff" them on to their target by squeezing the tube sharply. This dry lube works differently. It's wet!The lubricant particles are suspended in a volatile liquid which allows you to spray them where you need them. Then the liquid evaporates quickly, leaving behind just the dry lubricant.The stuff worked great! All squeaks have been silenced and all hinges move as though they were ball-bearings. I keep accidentally slamming my kitchen cabinet doors because they now move so freely!You must shake the can vigorously before you spray in order to suspend the dry lubricating particles in the liquid propellant. It has a metal ball inside to facilitate this process. It comes with a thin tube that you can plug into the spray nozzle in order to accurately direct the spray. The tube then stores in a groove in the cap. It's a little ungainly there, I would have preferred to be able to store it along the side of the can, but that's just a quibble.

I've been using TP-Link networking equipment on my home network for the last few years. I have the TL-WDR4300 Wireless N750 Dual Band Router and the TL-WDN3200 N600 Dual Band Wireless USB Adapter on my Vista machine. I tested this Adapter on my Win8.1 machine which has a built-in Realtek 802.11ac networking card, so I'd be able to make head-to-head comparisons. I transferred several 5+ gigabyte files back and forth via WiFi from my NAS and compared times. In all the tests I made, the TP-Link performed at about 96% to 98% of the speed of the built in Realtek. Pretty respectable performance, I think, considering that you just plug the TP-Link into a USB port and never have to open the PC's case.I have one additional observation that I think may be helpful. As I said, I've been using TP-Link USB adapters for several years. I did have a different TP-Link USB adapter fail on me. I was using it with the supplied USB cable, rather than plugging it directly into the PC's USB connector and I think that this may have been the root cause of the failure. The adapter gets hot when in use. If it's plugged directly into your PC, it likely will have good air flow on all four sides so the heat can dissipate. If you're using it with the cable, you will probably lay the thing down on your desk, as I did, thereby impeding airflow and potentially causing an overheat.In the month I've been testing this adapter I've had no issues of any kind--no disconnects, no crashes, nothing. I'm very impressed with TP-Link. I think they make excellent gear at very reasonable prices.

This is a nice, good-looking set of Bath Mats. They are soft and plush and stay put with a non-skid backing. I have the larger one in front of the tub/shower and the smaller in front of the sink/vanity.Since so many of the negative reviews here concentrate on the way these shed in the washer and dryer, I decided to launder them after only a few days of use to see just how bad the problem was. I washed on gentle cycle in cold water. There was some shedding, but nothing too terrible. Drying on low heat was another issue entirely. After just a few minutes, the lint screen was covered with a thick mass of fibers. I cleaned that off and restarted. Checking again after a few minutes, I found the same situation. I cleaned again, but found the same situation again in 10 minutes.The last job my old GE dryer ever performed was drying these mats. Afterwards, I discovered that, though it continued to tumble, the dryer no longer heated up. Now, I don't know if this breakdown would have occurred no matter what I was drying--the dryer was an old dinosaur manufactured circa 1970--but I'm skeptical about coincidences. I think the heavy build up of material on the lint screen caused the old fellow to suicide by overheating. Because of the uncertainty about cause and effect, however, I'm averaging a 5-star "these look great" review and a 1-star "appliance killer" review.From now on, I will just vacuum these like area rugs when they need cleaning.

I have tried gel-ink pens in the past and, though they wrote smoothly, they tended to blob when first starting. I was pleasantly surprised to find that these "hybrid" pens do not suffer from that malady. They write smoothly and without blobbing or smearing issues. The textured grip is soft and comfortable to hold.Though these are "Medium Point," I think they they possess a somewhat finer point than other medium points I've used, but have less of the "scratchy" feel that fine points often have.The point retraction mechanism feels strong and secure, likewise the pocket clip.

I bought the 1-quart size to handle two frequent jobs: Rice for 1 or 2, which I make 2 or 3 times a week; and Pasta Sauce for 1 or 2 which I make 2 or 3 times a month. It performs both of those tasks with ease. I've owned it for about 4 months, so I estimate that I've used it around 50 times. I love it!Cooking performance on my dinosaur of a GE electric stove is outstanding. Water will continue to boil slowly and sauce will continue to simmer steadily with the burner at its lowest setting if the cover is on the pot. The pot has good heft. According to my kitchen scale, it weighs about 18 ounces, 28 ounces with its lid. The handle stays cool during cooking.Clean-up, inside and outside, is a breeze (I hand wash it with an Ocello No-Scratch Scrub Sponge). I can see no breakdown of any kind in the coating on the inside or the outside. I use plastic utensils only.I'm very pleased with this little guy! Highly recommended.

These work really well. For this price, I would have been impressed if it was just one screen protector--but it's six! I was glad to have more than one, because I messed up on the installation the first time and had to discard that one. If you order these from eTech, you'll get a packing slip and on the bottom will be a recommended YouTube video to watch that demonstrates a painless installation method. I found the video very helpful. I wish I had watched it before I ruined one of these instead of after!Be advised that these are matte-finish protectors as opposed to perfectly clear ones. This surface helps to minimize fingerprints and smudges but does slightly affect how it feels under your finger tips. It's not quite as slick and smooth as the naked LCD screen.I find this product to be high-value--low-price and very decent quality. Highly recommended.

When the cable that came with my used iPod touch 4G began to malfunction--it would charge, but not sync--I began to search for a replacement. An OEM Apple cable is ridiculously expensive. There are some very inexpensive USB to 30-pin cables, but the reviews for those tend to cast doubt on their reliability. This one, I thought, had the right balance of reasonable price and good reviews.It has functioned perfectly in the few weeks that I've owned it. My original cable probably stopped working due to an internal short. The area around the strain-relief (the collar where the cable emerges from the plug) at both ends had really broken down and gotten frayed, probably the result of the prior owner pulling on the cable instead of the plug to unplug it. This Amazon Basics cable has very beefy, durable looking strain-reliefs and I expect it will hold up for a long time.Highly recommended.

I like oatmeal and will often make a pot of McCann's which stores well in the refrigerator and provides me with breakfasts and/or snacks for days. But sometimes there is no leftover oatmeal in the fridge to rewarm for a bedtime snack, and no will on my part to make a batch, so I keep a supply of Quaker Instant in the pantry. No, it's not the same, but it suffices. Gluten-free or not, this Chex Oatmeal is quite good and, when microwaved with half water-half milk, does a good impersonation of the consistency and taste of the real stuff, leaving the Quaker in the dust.The two flavored varieties (Maple-Brown Sugar and Apple-Cinnamon) are very good, natural tasting and not too sweet. They will set you back 170 calories each without artificial ingredients (although, the Maple-Brown Sugar does contain "Natural Flavor," whatever that might be) The Original contains one ingredient: Whole Grain Oats. Each pouch of those yields 130 calories.I just saw these in the King Kullen circular for this week at two and a half bucks apiece. That's more than the Quaker, but still reasonable for six packets, I think. I intend to keep a box close at hand.

I don't think I'd ever had freeze-dried fruit before trying these. I enjoyed them--all three flavors--very much. They are merely fruit morsels with all the water removed via a freeze-drying process. They are almost like intensely fruit-flavored crackers. "Crispy," is an entirely accurate way of describing themHowever, there are two 800 pound gorillas in the room that need to be discussed. First is price. I don't base my reviews on price because it can and does fluctuate, sometimes wildly, over time. Furthermore, what I might consider expensive you might not and vice-versa. However, at their current price these will set you back about a buck per 1/3 ounce bag. That's too rich for my tastes and I would not likely buy them for that reason (I was provided with mine for free by Amazon's Vine Program).Secondly, these are made in China. You know, land of melamine cat food. Remeber all that? To their credit, the manufacturer doesn't try to hide this fact and is quick to point out that these are, "processed in freeze dried facilities that are U.S. FDA-registered and Internationally-certified (HACCP) which is a third party audit regulator," and that, "they are also routinely tested independently by FDA certified labs in the United States." I guess I'm OK with that, but it's something you should be aware of before buying. If they were less expensive, I would definitely purchase them as a diet-friendly (40 calories per bag) sweet snack.

I used to use Target's store brand select-a-size paper towels because I figured that, "Paper towels are just paper towels--they're all the same." Then about 18 months ago, I moved and as a sort of joking housewarming gift a friend gave me some Bounty paper towels. What a revelation! They really are vastly superior to store-brand in terms of absorbency and durability and because of these properties, you wind up using fewer which makes them economical. They are my "go-to" brand now.Just a few months ago, I switched from the "Mega" size rolls to the "Huge," which is the largest roll size. I have a Polder freestanding paper towel holder and the rolls fit fine. I find that about 85% of the time, a single sheet does the job so a roll will last an absurdly long time.The only potential drawback is that you'll need a substantial amount of space to store 12 of these. I keep them in the bottom of a linen closet and they take up the entire area.

I've tried two other products from this company, Kernel Season's Popping Corn, 16 Ounce Bags (Pack of 2) and Kernel Season's Movie Theatre Butter for Popping & Topping Popcorn, 10 Ounce Shakers (Pack of 2). I was quite pleased with both of those and rated them highly. I'm not as impressed with this product, unfortunately.It's not unpleasant in any way, it's just that I don't really get much of a flavor of any kind from it. I believe that this is because I now pop my popcorn using the aforementioned butter-flavored popping oil, and that provides more buttery flavor than this seasoning, so I can't detect it when I sprinkle it on. However, the oil adds only a mild flavor, so that would seem to indicate that the taste of this shake-on seasoning is very subtle, at best. Even if I add enough to coat the popcorn, my taste buds just don't detect much of anything.

This is a stainless steel and plastic electric kettle that will boil water in amounts ranging from 0.75L (25 oz) to 1.7L (57 oz). It has a sensor which, when the water has come to a full, rolling boil, turns the kettle off with an audible click. It has a comfortable, "stay-cool" handle as well as a translucent plastic water gauge to make it possible to know how much water it contains. It has a lid that flips open to make filling easy.The electrical cord plugs in to a base which is entirely separate from the kettle itself. You place the kettle on the base, turn it on by depressing a large plastic switch lever on the kettle and wait patiently.If I put the minimum amount of cold tap water into the Hamilton Beach, its auto-shutoff will trigger in just about 4 minutes. Repeating the experiment (after the kettle has cooled) with the maximum amount of cold tap water, results in a time to shutoff of 7 1/2 minutes.Three minor quibbles: I wish the minimum was less than it is, so I could boil just enough water for a single mug of tea--say, 10 or 12 ounces. I also find the positioning of the water gauge, beneath the handle, a little inconvenient to see. Lastly, if you fill the kettle to the maximum, when the boil is complete, the handle (particularly near the top) does get a little warm, but not enough to burn you or be bothersome. If I could deduct a half star from my rating for those combined shortcomings, I would. However, I don't consider them serious enough to warrant a full star.

About 18 months ago, I moved into a new place with an old GE electric stove in it. The stove works well, but the top surfaces of the coil heating elements are uneven. A heavy pan presses down on them and flattens them out so I get even heat, but my old Farberware 7-inch skillet, at 14 ounces, wasn't up to the task. The Anolon weighs 27.5 ounces and has no trouble with this assignment.Cooking performance is wonderful. Nice even heat with no hot spots. The interior is so nonstick, that a fried egg placed in the center of the pan will slide to one side if the oven isn't level! Handle is comfortable and stays cool.You have to hand wash it, but cleanup is a breeze. Nothing sticks. I've had mine for 3 months and use it at least two or three times a week, but it still looks brand new, inside and out. I'm always entertained by the fact that the interior is so slippery that when I rinse it, I don't have to dry it, because even water doesn't stick to it!I noticed when I got mine that there was some variation in the color of the interior nonstick surfacing. This worried me at first, but it is a purely cosmetic issue and doesn't affect cooking or cleanup.I paid 21 bucks and change for mine on sale. Definitely a bargain! Highly recommended.

I read the reviews for this before I purchased it (as I always do), including those that remarked that, when loaded up, it's somewhat unstable. I thought that perhaps if I put my 12 inch cast iron skillet (which weighs as much as a battleship) on the bottom, that would anchor the thing and keep it stable. No such luck.It leans slightly when loaded up--the back of the bottom is against the wall of a cabinet, the back of the top leans out about 5/8 inch away from that wall. That's the extent of the tilt.I'm not dissatisfied with it. It does the job and it's not like the thing is in any danger of toppling over. The pans don't fall out because of the tilt, there's no side-to-side tilt and I've had no problems of any kind with it after about 2 months of use.In fact, in all other respects, it's perfect. The shelf spacing is generous, the shelves are sturdy, removing and replacing pans is easy and the flat top shelf accommodates a small covered saucepan quite nicely, just as the product photo shows. I would recommend that you arrange your pans from heaviest to lightest as you go from bottom to top. That will improve its stability.It would be a 5-star product if it were not for that tilt.

I bought these a few years ago because I needed underwear and, at the time, they were on sale. I have, in recent decades, been a Hanes kind of guy, but I decided to try these since they were a bargain.By my reckoning, I have worn, washed and dried them at least 40 times. They continue to fit very comfortably and show no signs of wear. No stretched elastic, no holes at the seams or anywhere else. One thing I do that may lengthen their useful life is to dry them only until they are slightly damp and not bone-dry. Then I remove them from the drier, fold, put them in the underwear drawer, and leave the drawer slightly open so they finish drying without heat.They are 100% cotton and made in Honduras.Recommended.

I like to walk--even when it's cold. As long as it isn't raining or snowing or arctic-frigid, I'll get a mile or two in every day. I have a nice LL Bean down-filled coat that keeps my body warm, but my head was cold--more specifically, my ears. On really cold days, by the time I'd finished, I felt like I had an earache!I had an old polyester watch cap that didn't help much. I don't like earmuffs and I also didn't care for the look of those headband things that cover your ears but not your head. That's when I decided to try one of these.It's a complete success. It's comfortable to wear and keeps my ears happy and warm. I have kind of a big head and when I first got this it felt a little tight, but through subsequent wearings, it seemed to loosen up just a bit and now it fits perfectly. I wear it as shown in the product picture with a "cuff" at the bottom as opposed to "gangsta" style where you just pull it down as far as it will go so you look like a doofus.Recommended.

I've been dieting--either to lose weight or maintain it--for the last several years. I count calories and, in order to that effectively, I weigh everything I eat. I have tried a number of digital food scales during this time, and this Escali is, hands down, my favorite.It has many virtues. It's accurate. It can weigh in grams, ounces or pounds+ounces at the push of a button and can switch between them while weighing. It has a large, easy to read LCD display. It can weigh up to 11 pounds. It has a generous auto-shutoff that resets its timer if the weight changes, so it will never cut off in the middle of weighing something. It can work with negative weight, so you can zero the scale with a container full of something and then remove the amount you want. It can measure to the nearest 0.05 ounce, so if you want 2 3/4 ounces, you can get 2.75 instead of 2.6 or 2.7 ounces like many other food scales. It runs on ordinary AA batteries and you can use rechargeables if you like. It is quite durable. Mine is 3 years old and going strong.I see that some folks are saying that you have to use small plates on the scale's platform so as not to block the readout, but I find that it's very easy to use a dinner plate and just slide it back until I can see the LCD. The Escali's weighing platform is large enough that the plate won't topple over. Another complaint I see here is that it's hard to turn off. That's "user error," I think. You turn it off by pressing and HOLDING the on/off button for a couple of seconds. It will turn off. However, if you've just zeroed the scale a second ago by pressing briefly on the on/off and then try this procedure, it won't. I think that's where the confusion comes from.The issue described in the number one review concerning the scale automatically resetting its zero-point if you add very small increments of weight very slowly after setting it to zero is correct. If I "tare" the scale and then keep adding one popcorn kernel every few seconds, I can sneak several grams of them on to the scale without it registering a weight change. In practice I've never found this to be a problem. Once the weight is non-zero, this no longer occurs. So, if you wanted to weigh out, say, 25 grams of popcorn, you would begin by pouring 10 or 15 grams worth on to the scale to start, and from there, you're fine. You can then add one kernel at a time (if you are very patient) and you'll eventually get to a completely accurate 25 grams.It cleans up well, but you can't wash it in the sink. It isn't waterproof and if you run water on the thing it will get into the electronics and it won't turn on anymore. However, I did this once and found that if I just let it sit and dry out for a few days, it came back to life, as good as always!Dieting is hard. The Escali is not. Highly recommended.

I purchased this Carrying Case just about 2 years ago for my Garmin 50LM. I don't like to leave my GPS in the car, so when I return home I put it into this case and carry it into the house, and the next time I need to use my GPS to drive somewhere, I take it with me.In the meantime, the case protects the 50LM's screen and offers a bit of protection for the unit. It's not so heavily padded or armored that it would protect my Garmin if I were to drop it, but it does allow me to stuff the thing into a coat pocket or a briefcase or a bag of groceries and not worry about scratching the screen or otherwise damaging it.It has held up quite well. In the 2 years that I've owned it, I've used it to round-trip to the car and then back inside at the very least 200 times, and it still looks brand new--both the case and the Garmin. I've owned several Amazon Basics products and find them to be the perfect combination of value and quality. This case is no exception--it is good, simple, economical protection for your GPS.Highly recommended.

I've finished off the first of the two 16 ounce bags of this popcorn. I love it.I pop mine on the stove-top using Kernel Season's Movie Theatre Butter for Popping & Topping Popcorn, 10 Ounce Shakers (Pack of 2). If I follow the instructions on the packaging, I get a pot full of fluffy, white popcorn with virtually zero "old-maids." The butter-flavored oil makes drizzling additional melted butter on top unnecessary and that keeps this snack diet-friendly but still delicious.The packaging tells us that this is American grown, non-GMO popping corn. It contains no other ingredients. It comes in a sturdy plastic package with built-in resealable zipper closure.Recommended.

I've been either dieting or maintaining my weight for the better part of the last six years. Popcorn, even oil-popped, is an excellent snack for a dieter--until you put butter on it. And if I pop it in Canola or Peanut oil, that's exactly what I wind up doing in order to get the taste that I crave.However, I find that popping my popcorn on the stove-top using a small amount of this Kernel Season's Movie Theatre Butter for Popping & Topping adds just enough buttery flavor to the end product so that I have no urge to drizzle any additional butter over it. I have not tried it as a topping simply because I just don't find it necessary.The ingredients listed on the bottle: Soybean oil, Sunflower oil, Canola oil, Natural butter flavor, Annatto (for color). Contains Milk and Soy.Recommended.

I've owned several Amazon Basics products and I find them to be a perfect balance of value and quality. These rechargeable AA's appear to fit right in with that assessment.When I received them, I put 2 in a Logitech Wireless mouse, 2 in a Maglite flashlight, 2 in an Escali digital food scale and the last 2 went into the remote control for my cable box. All 4 devices powered up instantly without issues and all continue to work, with much daily use and without further recharging, a month later.The pair that went into the flashlight are most indicative of the quality of these batteries, I think. I keep it close at hand in my desk drawer and use the flashlight frequently, anytime I need to see something small in suboptimal lighting. The 2450 mAh Energizers that I usually rely on would have required recharging by now, but these Amazons are still going strong!I cannot yet speak to their long-term durability, but based on a month's use I can recommend them.

For the last few years, I've been weighing my food at every meal in order to either lose weight or maintain it. I have owned several digital food scales during this time. This one stacks up pretty well against the others. Its virtues are well documented in the other reviews here, but I'd like to mention a few weaknesses that I don't see mentioned often or at all.First, the scale is a little slow to react. If you are gradually adding food in small increments (like, say, popcorn kernels) you will overshoot your target weight unless you stop after each addition and wait for the Taylor to react. All food scales suffer from this to a certain extent, but it seems particularly noticeable with the 3842.Secondly, The LCD is not sealed waterproof. On two occasions, I accidentally spilled a little liquid on it, and in both cases that liquid found its way underneath the plastic covering of the LCD. A food scale is going to be used in a wet environment and this flaw is unacceptable.Lastly, although I love the glass platform, it is not removable for cleaning. You must clean it in place. If I could detach it from the body of the scale, I could just wash it under running water in the sink, like a dish. Unfortunately, that's not possible.I've deducted a star for the combination of these three shortcomings. Otherwise, accuracy, convenience, ease of use, the Taylor 3842 is a winner.

I've been using Logitech keyboards and mice for the last decade. I like how they just work and I've never had a problem with installation--until the MX800 combo. The keyboard was fine, but the mouse would not "pair" with Logitech's Setpoint software. Fortunately, I had the brainstorm to check the Amazon reviews for such a problem and see if anyone had worked out a solution for it. I found the answer in a review by Lawrence C Reardon posted on 3/28/2014. You just have to "unpair" the keyboard using Setpoint. Then the mouse will pair immediately and you can pair the keyboard again. It's just my guess, but based upon other reviews describing this situation, I think it may be a problem with old Logitech drivers already existing on the target machine and getting in the way.Once everything was working, I found much to like. I have the wired Logitech Illuminated Keyboard on my other machine and love it. The MX800, because it's wireless and therefore battery powered, only lights up when your hands approach it and then remains lit while you type. I slightly prefer the wired version because I don't like the illumination switching on and off, but it is still a very appealing feature to my old eyes. I'd be happier if I could just have the illumination on constantly, and I'd be happy to recharge more often for that luxury. At the very least, I'd like to be able to set the delay interval for the keyboard turning off its illumination once I've stopped typing. Strangely, I can do that only if I turn off "Activate illumination with hand detection," but I like that feature and don't want to disable it. If Amazon allowed half-star deductions, I'd use that feature for this shortcoming, but I don't think it's worth a whole star.The mouse can track on any surface (I have mine on a wooden desk) and is on a par with other Logitech mice I have used. It has a multitude of buttons, which are programmable as long as you have Logitech's downloadable Setpoint software installed.Both mouse and keyboard come equipped with rechargeable batteries which can be recharged by means of a USB cable (included) without removing them from their respective devices.I've deducted a star for the installation woes which had me saying words that I wouldn't want small children to hear. The combo, once working, is a five-star product.

I like these headphones quite a lot.I'm not an "audiophile," and I don't know if there's anything to the headphone "break-in" argument or not. I've had these for about a month, I use them daily to listen to music of all kinds as well as the spoken word. I guess a total of about 25 or 30 hours of use all told. I also played a pink noise loop through them when I wasn't using the PC for anything else. Perhaps an additional 20 hours there. Everything seems clear and undistorted with no break up or rattling at high or low frequenciesThe Adaros are not noise-cancelling headphones, but the soft leather ear cups do a very good job of sealing out the rest of the world so nothing interferes with whatever you're listening to. I liked that they seemed to give a very flat response across the audio spectrum. The last pair of headphones that I owned sounded like they had a built-in "loudness filter" that artificially hyped the treble and bass and I was always fiddling with a software equalizer to try to remove that. With these, I use the equalizer to just tweak the sound to my liking.The Adaros seem well-made. They are very comfortable to wear and feather-light (6.9 ounces on my kitchen scale). Unlike other headphones I've seen, they are understated and unobtrusive in appearance--flat black with a Razer logo on the outside of the ear cups. However, the audio cable is a bright, neon green.

I've been a "walker" for the last 10 or 12 years. I started for health reasons, but it has become an essential part of my daily routine and now I find that I just don't feel right without a couple of miles every day on my Rockports.Walkers come in two subspecies: step-counters and distance-speed trackers. I belong to the latter group. I've owned a couple of pedometers but my preference now is to use Google's MapMyWalk website to calculate my mileage. You just put down mouse clicks on a street or satellite map and Google accurately calculates the distance using its GPS data. If you've taken notice of your start and end times, you can figure out your speed.The problem with accuracy when using devices like the Omron is twofold. First, it has to count your steps. This it does by sensing slight shifts in inertia as you walk. Some pedometers are more accurate than others at achieving this, but there is always some degree of error. Secondly, to compute total distance walked the device relies on its user to correctly tell it his or her stride length. If the value given is off by even a slight amount, the resultant mileage for a walk of several thousand steps can be misreported by a significant amount.I have found that the best way to deal with both these difficulties is to calibrate the pedometer by "backing in" to the correct mileage. That is, walk a known distance. Measure it by using MapMyWalk or by driving the route with your car and using its odometer. Then convert that distance to inches and divide by the number of steps the pedometer says you took. Input that value as your stride length. I find that this approach will cause almost any pedometer to give a decent approximation of distance covered. The Alvita will predict your stride-length based on weight and height and I found that, for me, it was spot on with its guess, and no recalibration was necessary.Ordinarily, with devices of this type, you need a very small Phillips' head screwdriver to insert or remove the battery. The Alvita has eliminated this requirement by securing its battery access cover with a small slide lock. I had no difficulties with the process. I had no problems with the belt clip or with the unit staying put. I inserted it into my belt at my side and that is where it remained. The instructions are not as clear as they could be, but you can decipher them with a little head-scratching--especially if this is not your first pedometer.I had two problems with the Alvita. Firstly, the only way to reset will take the device to its factory settings, losing all your personalized data. If you do two walks in a day, they get added together--you can't do the first, reset, and do another walk. The second is that, though it calculates distance accurately and consistently, it does not report time spent walking or speed. For me, that means I must take notice of when I start and when I finish so that i can manually calculate my speed. Other pedometers I've owned do one or both for their owners. This limitation means I get no advantage over the above-mentioned MapMyWalk method. I make no star-deduction, since these shortcomings would not be objections for step-counters--clearly the target audience for the Alvista.

In addition to the uses for these that everyone is familiar with, I also use them to hold down light weight objects in the dishwasher--plastic items like storage containers and spatulas, metal mesh coffee filters, and so forth. Between water, heat and detergent, this is a kind of torture test for rubber bands and I have had others that lasted just a few washes before snapping. These are routinely going for 20 or more washes before giving up the ghost!These appear to be good quality elastic bands, 1/8 inch wide and forming a circle about 2 inches in diameter when they are relaxed.I see some reviewers are having them snap the first time they try to use them. I have not experienced that kind of failure with the bands that I have used thus far.They are manufactured in Thailand by Acco which appears, based on the packaging, to be a US Company, and the package net weight is at least 5.6 ounces.

Since moving to a new place with an old dishwasher about a year ago, I've been using Cascade powder detergent. About a month ago, Target had the Mega-Value size of Finish Powerball Tabs on sale at a price that made them competitive on a per wash basis with the Cascade powder, so I picked up one of those. I find them both excellent, and this product is just as good as either one.Everything comes out clean, glassware is spot free and sparkling, nothing left stuck on dishes or pots, silverware clean. No residues were left in the dishwasher after the wash completed. The fragrance was pleasant but not excessive. I base my ratings on a product's performance, not its price which can change over time and, therefore have given these five stars. However, I have to say that, at a buck per wash load, I wouldn't buy these.

I tend to have problems with the skin under my arms when I use deodorants. I used to be able to use Degree Men's Deodorant, but about two years ago, they changed their packaging and, I think, their formula as well because now the Degree causes irritation for me. I switched to Dove Men+Care "Cool Silver" deodorant at that point, and have had no problems since.Unfortunately, the "Fresh Awake" variety does cause irritation for me. It's not as bad as with some deodorants that I've used, but I do feel it and that's not the case with the Dove Men+Care "Cool Silver" deodorant mentioned above. The packaging says that it is "1/4 moisturizer," so it is definitely a different formula and, apparently, one that I'm sensitive to.Be advised that this is a deodorant only. It contains no antiperspirant.

I've been a "walker" for the last 10 or 12 years. I started as a way to help with weight management, but it has become an essential part of my daily routine and now I find that I just don't feel right without a mile or two every day on my Rockports. I've owned a couple of Pedometers but my preference now is to use Google's MapMyWalk website to calculate my mileage. You just put down mouse clicks on a street or satellite map and Google calculates the distance with its GPS data.The problem with accuracy when using devices like the Homedics is twofold. First, it has to count your steps. This it does by sensing slight shifts in either body angle or inertia. Some pedometers are more accurate than others at achieving this, but there is always some degree of error. Secondly, the device relies on its user to correctly tell it his or her stride length. If the value given is off by even a slight amount, the resultant mileage for a walk of several thousand steps can be misreported by a significant amount.I have found that the best way to deal with both these difficulties is to calibrate the pedometer by "backing in" to the correct mileage. That is, walk a known distance (at least a mile, I'd say--more is better). Measure it by using MapMyWalk or by driving the route with your car and using its odometer. Then convert that distance to inches and divide by the number of steps the pedometer says you took. Input that value as your stride length. I find that this approach will cause any pedometer to give a decent approximation of distance covered. When I did so after the first walk with this unit, I found that subsequent walks along different routes were reported with good accuracy (a tenth of a mile over a mile and a half).You will need a very small Phillips' head screwdriver to insert or remove the battery. I had no difficulties with the process. I had no problems with the belt clip or with the unit staying put. I inserted it into my belt at my side and that is where it remained for several miles of walking. The instructions for setting and resetting the unit are clear and easily understood.

This is a very nice grab bar--strong and sturdy while still maintaining an attractive appearance. If you install it correctly, it could save you from a potentially disastrous bathroom fall.Unfortunately, the instructions for making such an installation are not very good and I've deducted a star for that weakness. Moen has chosen to provide them in three different languages, but instead of giving you three different instruction sheets, they combine them all on one sheet causing a difficult to read jumble. The diagrams, which are critical for this type of project, are worse than useless and in fact are sometimes misleading.Moen says that you must mount the grab bar so that it will be screwed into wood studs. They do not mention that they make a product for mounting their grab bars in situations where there are no convenient wall studs! I had to discover that on my own. It would have been nice had they made mention of this. It is the Moen SMA1005CH Home Care Securemount, Chrome and Amazon sells them. You Tube has a video that explains how they work and how to install them (just search for 'Moen Securemount' in the YT searchbox). They're pricey at about twenty bucks for the pair of them that you'll need, but they've been independently tested and will do the job safely.If you're used to doing home improvement projects, then you're probably good to go with this and you'll be rewarded with a good looking and functional addition to your bathroom. If that shelf that you installed last month fell down with a crash two days later, this mightn't be a good choice.

This seemed like a really nice little accessory. Seven ports, powered, attractive and a two-part power supply like you sometimes get on printers and laptops so you don't have to contend with a "wall wart"--great, right? Unfortunately, I didn't have much success using the thing.The hub has two ports on the side and five along the back. The instructions state, "When powering a device that requires a lot of power, connect your USB device to one of the two USB ports on the right side of the hub." I found that whatever I plugged into those two "high power" ports worked great. Whatever I plugged into any of the other five ports did not. If I plugged my USB keyboard and the transmitter for my wireless mouse into those ports they worked, but an External HDD and WiFi dongle in the other ports did not. If I reversed them, I had the opposite problem!I had the external power supply that comes with the unit in service, so that was not the culprit. I suspect that my problem was that all four of my USB devices "require a lot of power," but only the two ports on the side can deliver that. If this is a powered hub, that seems odd. Maybe the unit was defective and the ports along the back just didn't work. I don't know.I've had good success with other AmazonBasics products. This one's poor performance surprised me.

Lately, I've gone "old school" and have been using Cascade powdered dishwashing detergent in my ancient GE dishwasher. These Platinum Actionpacs appear to do as good a job. My Cascade Powder will leave some peanut butter on the knife, but so do the Actionpacs. Dishes and pots were clean. Glasses had no spots. No residues were left in the dishwasher after the wash completed. The fragrance was pleasant but not excessive. I base my ratings on a product's performance, not its price which can change over time and, therefore have given these five stars.The problem I have with them is: Why? How are these superior to the powder Cascade detergent I'm using? If they were no more expensive, than I could make a case that they are just a more convenient alternative. But the fact is, these cost significantly more per washload. If you find the tiny increase in convenience that they offer justifies the increased expense, then I guess they make sense, but I don't.

I own many OXO products--garlic press, shower caddy, kitchen tongs, can opener, cutting board, and on and on. What is apparent in all of their wares and what attracts me to them is that it's very clear that, when designing them, OXO looked at each of these common household items and asked, "How can we make this better than everyone else?"This Box Grater is a perfect example of that philosophy. It has three different grating surfaces and a slicing surface, a comfortable, padded handle, a non-slip base so that when you place it on a cutting board it will stay put and it even comes with its own 1-cup attachable container that will catch and measure what you've grated. The container also has its own cover as well a non-slip base so that you don't lose that feature when it's positioned on the grater. It's a pleasure to use.I have one small complaint. If Amazon allowed half-star deductions, I would use that here, but it isn't serious enough for a whole star. OXO has made the grater narrow enough so that it can be easily stored in a kitchen drawer. On one narrow face is the finest of the three graters and on the other is the slicer. The problem is that other than, perhaps, carrots or parsnips, there is very little you can slice with the slicer. Even a cucumber is too wide. Potatoes are out of the question. This, I think, was a design choice. The manufacturer wanted the product to be easy to store and, apparently, decided that the slicer was likely to be infrequently used anyway, so they compromised its functionality. Since this is first and foremost, a grater and not a mandoline, I can overlook it.

I usually buy the Charmin "UltraSoft" Mega Rolls when I need TP. I like them for their efficacy as well as their economy. This "Basic" Charmin compares very favorably to its brand mate.The Basic really is basic--no scents, no patterns, single ply. Yet, it's significantly better than the economy Target product I used to favor a few years ago. It's softer, stronger and at least as inexpensive. Those have got to be the primary criteria on which to rate this mundane but very necessary product. Each of these double rolls lasts about 60% as long as an Ultrasoft mega roll.The box in which the 40 rolls are shipped is surprisingly small. I was expecting a Mastodon-sized container with "Charmin Basic Toilet Paper" emblazoned all over it, but was pleasantly surprised. The Charmin box is just 16"x21"x9". Your neighbors will think you got a new computer.I think that when I use these up, I will go back to the UltraSoft. It isn't quite as economical, but the small price differential is outweighed by the luxury-feel of it. That said, I don't mind having these and would switch to them if the others were to become unavailable.

I'm using these for myself. I have problems with "dry eyes," and I discovered years ago that cleaning my face first thing in the morning and last thing before bedtime was very helpful in treating that annoyance. At first, I used the Cottenelle wipes, but after a month or so, I started having problems with the skin on my face, particularly my eyelids. Then I switched to Tucks, after reading that the ladies like that one for removing eye make-up and getting rid of bags under the eyes. Those worked well too but the Witch Hazel they contain, if it gets into my eyes, is very irritating so I have to be careful to keep my eyes closed and to rinse my face with warm water afterwards.Enter the Seventh Generation Wipes. They don't upset the skin and they don't sting if they get in my eyes. I'm using them for about a month now, and they seem like a great solution for me. I'm very pleased.At first, I thought they weren't sufficiently wet to do a good job, but I've changed my mind. In fact, I now think that they have *exactly* the correct amount of moisture to do their job without making the skin overly wet--whether that skin is your face or a baby's butt!Note: These are NOT flushable. Sewage treatment plants all over the US are having problems with wipes like these getting flushed and then clogging up the works. They do not break down like toilet tissue. You must dispose of them properly.

This is reasonably good popcorn and somewhat healthier than others in that it utilizes Smart Balance as its fat rather than butter or some synthetic chemical butter-flavor. It pops well. If you follow the directions and remove it from the microwave when the popping slows, there is no burning and very few "old-maids."The fat numbers for this product are somewhat better than butter dressed popcorn, but the calories per portion are about the same. I think when I buy popcorn I will get the "Blast O Butter," variety. If I'm going to have a snack, I'd prefer that one.

I've been using Neilmed products for the last few years. I have terrible sinus problems, and a few years ago, my doctor recommended that I try Sinus Rinsing (NeilMed Sinus Rinse - 2 Bottles - 250 Premixed Packets - Value Pack) and that has made a HUGE positive difference for me. I have always found Neilmed products to be of the highest quality.When I received the Sinufrin, I found that it was wrapped in a hard plastic cocoon that was very difficult to remove. Similar products have a tear-strip to simplify removal of the shell, but the Sinufrin did not. Then when I tried the sprayer, nothing happened. I concluded that the sprayer mechanism was defective and when I contacted Amazon, they were kind enough to send me a replacement.As I struggled to remove the plastic shell from the second unit, I noticed that my fingers were getting wet. Sure enough, when I checked inside, only a small amount of liquid remained. I checked the original I'd received and found the same and then realized that the first sprayer hadn't worked because there wasn't enough fluid left inside. I combined the two in one sprayer and then had enough to make it function. I found the sprayer not to my liking, even when I made it work, despite the fact that this type of "metered" sprayer is my favorite. It has a "wobbly" feel that I don't get with the Afrin sprayers of the same type.Sinufrin's Oxymetazoline solution is 5-star and the equal of Afrin, the gold standard, in every way. My rating is based on the serious flaws in the sprayer outlined above.

Each of the items in this series of Stocking Holders--the sleigh and the two reindeer styles--weigh about a pound. They are very pretty, make a nice display and you can adjust the number of reindeer so that they match the number of stockings you have to hang.I've tested their ability to support weight by hanging a plastic bag from each and then gradually adding weight to the bag. Up to about 14 ounces, they're great--trustworthy and steady. Beyond that, though, they become increasingly unstable and likely to tip over and crash to the ground. I'd say 24 ounces is the absolute maximum.I've given them kind of a neutral 3-star rating because your satisfaction will depend on how you use Christmas stockings in your household. If the stockings are mostly a decorative thing for you, or if you put just a few lightweight items in them, say, some candy canes, an Amazon Giftcard and 4 AA batteries, they'll work fine and look good. But if you really like to load them up with lots of little toys, candy and novelties, these are not a good option.

But if you really like to load them up with lots of little toys, candy and novelties, these are not a good option.NOTE: Despite what is shown in the photo, this item is just the sleigh. The reindeer are sold separately.

As luck would have it, I caught a monster cold just a few days after receiving these, and consumed the entire complement of 18 in about a week and a half.Generally coffee is my 'go to' hot beverage of choice, but I do occasionally have a cup of tea after dinner or, as in this case, when I have some upper respiratory ailment. That tea is always Lipton's regular tea in traditional flat teabags. I find little difference between this tea and that one. It's quite mild and the taste was, to me, almost indistinguishable from Lipton's regular product.

As with most hardware these days, the only hard copy documentation you will receive with the Seagate Central is a Quick Start Guide which then refers you to online sources for further information. That's fine and I accept that. Unfortunately, the online information was pretty sketchy and in one case did not agree with the screens I was seeing presented to me by the hardware. The Seagate has an option to "Reset to Factory Settings," which is good since I had to do that more than once until I figured out what I was supposed to do!Once I got beyond that difficulty, the Seagate Central seemed a solid performer, if a little slow. I started by creating a 1.5TB Truecrypt container file on the unit. That is a torture test for a hard drive because it is writing and accessing for the entire time (32+ hours for the Seagate Central). I believe that this speed is about 10% slower than the drives in my Netgear NAS, but is still acceptable. File transfers to and from the encrypted container have been fine since then. Those transfer speeds would be meaningless, since encryption/decryption is involved.I then put a few HD movies and YouTube videos in the Public directory of the Seagate. I have a Roku 3 in my network which, sadly, is not DLNA compatible so I couldn't test the unit's abilities as a DLNA server. I do have the MyMedia app for the Roku though, and using that was able to stream everything through to my TV. That went well--no halting or stuttering or buffering.It's a solid performer, but I find the documentation issues serious enough to deduct a star from my rating.

I use this car charger for my Kyocera Kona cellphone that has the same type of micro USB connector that this comes with. It works well. It seems like it takes approximately the same amount of time to charge the Kona as the home charger that came with the phone.It fits snugly into the cigarette-lighter, but releases without a fight. The supplied USB to micro USB cable fits on both ends the way it should, not too tight or too loose and the 4-foot length is convenient.

I'm a big believer in generic and store brand over-the-counter medications. I find that in many (though not all) cases, they are just as effective and significantly less expensive than the big-name, national brands. Tylenol, Advil, Benadryl, Sudafed, Cortizone-10, etc. are all either Kirkland, Member's Mark, CVS or Target products in my medicine cabinet.I take a Benadryl equivalent before bed and realize two benefits from doing so. It not only allows me to sleep without any allergy symptoms, but actually helps me sleep by making me pleasantly drowsy. I'm happy to report that this Good Sense Diphedryl is as good as the name brand in both respects.I have used this brand several times in the past. For the last few years, I've been buying Diphenhydramine HCI 25 Mg - Kirkland Brand - Allergy Medicine and AntihistamineCompare to Active Ingredient of BenadrylÆ Allergy Generic - 600 Count. For twice the price as this, you get 6 times as much! That one also works as well Benadryl. If you don't want that much, I can recommend the Good Sense 100-count.

These are fabulous! The dried fruit is sweet but not too sweet and soft. The nuts are fresh-tasting and crunchy with just the right degree of saltiness. The combination is perfect. One foil-lined pouch makes a satisfying and delicious snack for between meals, TV watching, whenever. There are no artificial ingredients or preservatives.Each pouch will get you 190 calories and 14% of your daily fat allotment, so they're not diet food, but they make no representation of being so. On the positive side, you'll get 8% of your fiber and only 3% of your sodium.My one concern is price. At their current rate, each pouch works out to a cost of about a buck. That's somewhat more expensive than a candy bar or a small bag of chips, but far healthier and just as tasty.

Let me start by saying that I love my Roku. That's why I gave it five stars. Generally, if I see that a product that I'm familiar with has a lot of reviews (2600+ as of this writing) and that the other reviewers have gotten it right (4.3 stars) I won't bother to write my own. But there are a few negatives that not too many folks here are talking about that you should know about before you purchase the Roku 3 in order to make an informed decision.First, the Search. Roku is making a lot of noise about the inclusion of this function and it is a very useful thing to have. But, its scope is very limited. When you search for a movie, it will check only the top eight services: Netflix, HBO GO, VUDU, huluplus, Amazon, Redbox, Blockbuster, and Crackle. So if one of the other 700+ channels (that Roku also likes to talk up as another incentive to buy their product) has the flick you want to see, you'll never know it. To search manually would take far longer than the running time of the movie you seek.And while we're on the subject, let's talk about all those other channels. Specifically, let's talk about the huge number of FREE ones. One of my least favorite old sayings is "You get what you pay for." I hate it because it denies the possibility of getting a bargain and it asserts that if you spend a lot, you'll get something good. Neither of those is valid. Unfortunately, it is largely true here. Most of the free movie channels draw on the library of films that are in the public domain. Old, mostly forgotten or unpopular entries that you'd have to be pretty desperate to consider seriously. The more modern ones are so obscure that you can't find them in IMDb or Rotten Tomatoes. There are exceptions. I found "The Third Man," and "D.O.A." in the free channels, so there are a few good ones, but they are rare.And when you do find a treasure, you're still not out of the woods. Many of the copies of the films in the free channels look like they've been sitting under a tarp in grandma's basement for the last half century. They're not the carefully restored and remastered versions you'd get on a commercial station like TCM.One last thing to point out in regard to the free channels is that they have advertising. They have to support themselves somehow and I don't really begrudge them doing this. Furthermore, the number and duration of commercials is less than you'd get on a broadcast or cable station. But it is there and it does interrupt the flow of the film you're watching.Some of the free channels are worthwhile. NASA has a channel, Crackle has recent high-quality films from Sony, and PBS has recent shows from their catalog. But for the most part the freebies are...well...awful.Before you can truly love, you must understand the limitations and shortcomings of your beloved. Otherwise it's just infatuation. The Roku's specialty is to act as a conduit between *paid* entertainment providers and you. That's its strength and its intended purpose and it does that job very well. Fortunately, the pay channels are not very expensive. Netflix, Amazon Prime, and many of the others are less than 10 bucks a month for all you can watch. If you're already subscribed to HBO on your cable, you can get HBO GO for no additional charge and have on-demand access to all their currently playing films and shows.But, if you think that you'll just pay for the Roku box and then live together happily ever after with the free channels, I foresee an acrimonious divorce in your future.

I'm using this desktop with Windows Vista. The product was clearly intended for Windows 7 and especially Windows 8, but works well enough with Vista.The keyboard is dome-shaped and very slim. It is split in the center with the two halves pitched toward each other, so that when you place your hands on the keys, they can be in a more natural position, turned slightly toward each other with wrists rotated downward toward the outside. There is a built in wrist rest which is smooth and has just the right amount of cushioning to be comfortable but supportive. The space-bar is split as well. The keys have a sculpted, slightly convex surface to accommodate your fingertips. They have a nice amount of smooth travel and excellent "clickiness."The keyboard comes with a riser which fits on its wrist side. This gives it a downward tilt--exactly the opposite of most other keyboards which have fold-out feet to give an upward tilt. Its use is optional. I couldn't get used to it and don't use it.The function keys have alternate uses controlled by a slide switch on the extreme top-right of the keyboard. Most of these alternates uses are for Windows 8 functions and do nothing in Vista. There is a calculator hot key which does work in Vista.The Number Pad is a separate unit. I like this because I seldom use it and can put it out of the way and then center the keyboard more easily in front of my monitor.The mouse is significantly larger than any other mouse I've ever used. To me, it feels like holding a baseball. I think that Microsoft has done this so that they could put the thumb rest higher up on the side of the mouse than usual which, in turn, forces you to rotate your wrist slightly when mousing. It takes a bit of getting used to, but after a while begins to feel very comfortable and natural. It is a wheel mouse and features tilt-wheel functionality in addition to the standard features.If you have Windows 7 or 8, you can download the "Microsoft Mouse and Keyboard Center," which will allow you to customize your new Desktop set. If you are running Vista or earlier, you'll have to use 3rd party software to do this. X-Mouse is a good choice and it's free.

If you've seen this program in use and you know in advance what you will be getting, and that's what you want, then go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, exercise extreme caution. It is very powerful and capable. But it is also a very complex piece of software and not easy to learn. I tried it, decided it was several light-years beyond what I wanted, and chose to uninstall it.And that's when the fun started.Pinnacle installs about a dozen different applications when you run its installer. But when you run its uninstaller, it removes only the base application and leaves everything else on your disk--gigabytes worth of software. It took me an entire afternoon with Revo Uninstaller to get my PC back to where it had been beforehand. I had to find all the apps Pinnacle had installed, remove them one by one, and then remove *hundreds* of registry entries and *hundreds* of directories that each app's uninstaller failed to deal with. It was a nightmare and I'm still wondering what I might have missed and what will now fail to work because I deleted something I shouldn't have. It was an unmitigated disaster.I would recommend that if you decide on installing this, that you first create a Windows Restore point. Then, choose the "Custom" install and just do the Pinnacle application itself. If you want all the other add-ons and libraries and tools, you can add them later, and  if you decide to uninstall, you'll have a much easier time than I did.

I'm a big believer in generic and store brand over-the-counter medications. I find that in many (though not all) cases, they are just as effective and significantly less expensive than the big-name, national brands. Tylenol, Advil, Benadryl, Sudafed, Cortizone-10, etc. are all either Kirkland, Member's Mark, CVS or up&up (Target) equivalents in my medicine cabinet.I have terrible sinus problems. A few years ago, my doctor recommended that I try Sinus Rinsing (NeilMed Sinus Rinse - 2 Bottles - 250 Premixed Packets - Value Pack) and that has made a HUGE positive difference for me. However, sometimes when my allergies really act up (like now, in late summer) or I catch a cold, I still need Afrin Decongestant Spray for a day or two, otherwise I'll wind up with sinusitis. When I tried my store brand strategy with nasal spray a few years ago, it was a dismal failure. The one I had purchased burned the inside of my nose when I used it and seemed less effective than Afrin. I threw it away and went back to the gold standard.I'm happy to report that this Good Sense spray is as good as Afrin in every way. It clears my congestion and does so without irritation just like Afrin.With Oxymetazoline sprays like this, you mustn't use them more than twice a day and for no more than three consecutive days. I find the "pump-sprays" much easier to use than the "squeeze sprays." I have several from all the Afrin I've purchased over the years, so I rinsed one out and transferred the Good Sense to it. The pump-spray top screws open, and I could just stream the new spray into it.In the future, if I can get this product at a lower cost than the Afrin, I will do so. (By the way, make certain that when you compare price, you note quantity. Some sprayers are one full ounce and others are one half ounce.)

My first reaction on seeing these was, "Does the world really need another Chocolate Chip Cookie?" In this case, I think the answer is yes.Keebler has tried to create cookies using only the ingredients that you would use if you were making them at home. They contain no artificial ingredients or flavorings. The result is a very appealing cookie that definitely does have a "homemade" taste and consistency. Most store-bought cookies I've tried have either a chewy or a crispy texture. These are buttery and delicious and have a light, slightly crumbly texture. Definitely not chewy, but not what I would call crisp either.The packaging is the new type that has a peel-up tab that self sticks to the package to reseal. This works well and saves a Ziploc.I've been buying Target Chocolate Chip cookies for the last couple of years, ever since a well-known Consumer's magazine rated them highly. I'll check the price on these if I see them and, if the difference is small, I'll take these home from now on.

These Keebler El Duende cookies are very much like "Golden Oreos," (if you happen to be familiar with those) except that they have a mild, lemon-flavored filling instead of plain vanilla.I don't understand why so many reviewers are unhappy with the amount of filling in these. I thought it was about as much as you'd get in an Oreo. Perhaps they were comparing to Oreo's "Double-Stuffed," varieties, or perhaps there is some variation on a lot-by-lot basis and I was just lucky. Otherwise I have no explanation for the dissatisfaction.The wafer part of the cookie is crispy and light and complements the filling nicely. It is, I think, a bit smaller than an Oreo. It measures 1 5/8 inches in diameter. I didn't have an Oreo in the house to compare against, but my impression is that the Nabisco product is just a bit larger.I liked these. They were sweet and lemony without being too much of either, and I would recommend them.

This is a non-refrigerated, microwaveable meal containing pasta and tomato-meat sauce. The packaging states that it is "100% Natural" and contains "No Preservatives." How Barilla is able to give us a tomato and meat sauce in liquid form but without any chemicals to keep it palatable is a mystery to me. The plasticized tray packaging is sealed tightly with a stout film cover, so I guess that's the key.The primary ingredient is Gemelli pasta which is made with Semolina wheat and Durum flour. The one portion will give you 6 grams of fiber (24% of a 2000-calorie diet). For those of us who have reached the stage of life where fiber intake is critical, this is a wonderful bonus.This is the third of these Barilla meals that I've tried. In the past, I've found the pasta a little too tough for my taste, but this time it was fine. Definitely al dente but good. I found the 1-minute cooking time to be fine.The rest of the ingredient list yields nothing suspicious other than "Xanthan Gum," and "Tapioca Starch."The meat sauce is packaged in a separate "Sauce Tray" which fits in the main packaging and is microwaved with it. When heating is complete, you remove the sauce tray and pour it over the pasta. That works well. Prior to heating, you peel back the film covering over the sauce to vent the package. I had no difficulties with any of this. Just be careful to read the instructions before you do anything.The package will give you 350 calories with 6g of fat and 570mg of sodium. The sodium is high (24%) as it is in virtually all pre-packaged meals. It seems the manufacturers have learned how to control all the nutrients--calories, fat, cholesterol, carbs, everything--except salt.I don't think I'd go out of my way to eat this, but for what it is--an ultrasimple, convenient, quick meal that you could stick in your briefcase or backpack on the way out to work or school--it was pretty good. If you don't have access to a cafeteria and don't want something from the deli or the take-out or fast-food places, this is definitely a good alternative (as long as there is a microwave in the break room).

I try to eat nutritiously, but I believe in moderation, so I will occasionally have a snack that is less than healthful if it has a taste I find appealing. I'm partial to beef jerky, certain types of chips and Snickers bars. Just not too often.These Slim Jims will not be joining my short-list. They are, I guess, sausages of a sort--foot long tubes about a 3/8 of an inch in diameter. The outer skin is taut and crispy. The inside is soft and somewhat mushy.They are made with beef and chicken, but there is no discernible meat flavor--just spice heat. I guess they would be a good accompaniment to a beer or two, but I can think of other things (salsa and corn chips, flavored pretzels, etc.) that I'd rather have with that beverage.Nutrition on these is hair-raising, even for a guilty pleasure. A less than one ounce snack which will deliver 140 calories, 23% of your daily allotment of saturated fat and 20% of your sodium, not to mention some nitrite--that's pretty hard-core.Sorry, Jim. I'll pass.

Literary Fiction hasn't been working for me lately. Books others find exceptional I find improbable and overwritten. Crooked Heart os a lovely book about unlovely people. The small WW2 British setting adds a quiet charm to a tale of grifters conning each other. A bitter mother with a disappointing son crosses paths with a not as young as his years boy in need of additional care. Setting themselves up to take advantage of those around them, Crooked Heart shows how deeply they need to find someone to trust. Evans has a light literary style free of pretension but full of lovely phrases. There are no larger than life heroic people in Crooked Heart but there are plenty of recognizable ones.  I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this book and I have already suggested it to several family members.

This is a very nice looking hub for current use and standards. It works for USB 2.0 and below so may need to be replaced as 3.0 really takes hold. For now, it's a huge improvement on my underpowered four slot hub, I understand the concerns about the cord length although I found it perfectly adequate to my needs. It's long enough for the average desk setup but won't give a laptop user much flexibility. I wish it was slightly more powerful - iPad data transfer works well enough but not being able to charge all peripherals is annoying. Data transfer also good on a variety of portable drives and cameras. Overall very solid hub choice.

I'm familiar enough with college ball and the impact of the cultural changes but I am not a fan of college ball. I approached Billion-Dollar Ball wanting to understand the hows and why's of it's coming to dominate the conversation. While Gaul has extensively researched, interviewed and explored the cultural changes money has brought into the game, he fails to capitvate the non-fan. I left the book with as many questions as I entered it with, but they were different ones. Billion Dollar Ball expects a working knowledge of college football and some key figures in it. It was hard to get into the narrative of deals while also figuring out context. I continually felt that if I knew more about the subject I'd be getting more out of the book. I wanted to explore the post football lives of these kids - do they feel exploited by a for profit system they can't profit from? Was it worth it? Overall, an excellent indepth study of college ball, money and the bind universities are in but not one for the curious non fan.

I found this an odd mix of material for a beginner given the book positioning itself as for long term colorists. There are tips and examples on how to color and why you blend medias. Then the designs themselves tend to the overly open with a distinct 70's throwback vibe, vry DIY. Absolutely killing the book for me are the inspirational quotes included. Some of these are from people I find extremely objectionable and it doesn't soothe me to color along to their words. One star for adding popular poster quotes to an art experience.

Good for use with a wide variety of media. Some pages are suited to inking, others to coloring or pastels. Space varies from wide to narrow depending on the artwork. Good book to share as there will be a few pages to everyone's taste but (unless viewer is open to multiple art styles) not a complete books for a single style. I really love this book but an occasionaly overuse of black space was an issue for me.

As I mentioned in another volume I struggle with 1 and 5 stars. I love this incredibly unique series and the exposure it offers my whole family to modern artists. I don't mind paying a premium to support the concept and allow them to contract with diverse artists. Unfortuantely not all of these artists understand the concept of a coloring book. Some, like Shag, do a very good job of leaving lots of white space for inking. Others produce an almost entirely black page that is true to their style but useless. My 15 uear old looked at ome page and said "What the (redacted) am I supposed to do here? Did he even think about me??" Not sure how the creators can reign in these artists, it it keeps a fine product from being an essential one.

This product varies wildly between five stars and one. An ongoing collection of pages from modern artists, I origjnally started buying these for myself but they spark my teens / tweens imaginations like nothing else. Unfortunately half the artists don't seem to understand the coloring concept of a coloring book. Some of the pages are ready for beautifully unique inking. Some are so heavily shaded and pre-inked black that there is nothing at all to do. I'm not sure how the creators could handle this with the comtracted artists, but it's a problem. Truly unique product, but this is a not insignificant flaw.
Nice, full page patterns suited to pencils or fine tip markers. Good variety of design from full flowing to geometric. Well designed.
Interesting mix of patterns, good quality paper, but imperfect. Some pages have excessive unused white space, leaving design centered in middle. Feels wasterful.

I received this sharpener as a guft and was so happy with it I came back to buy another! The review have made me nervous but to be fair my experience with this product is exceptional.
