I have used it on Prismacolor Premier and various pencil brands I picked up in Germany without incident. Quick, exceptional points and easy use.

These pencils have a smoother grip and harder lead than my PrismaColor tin. Easy to lay down color, if not quite as smooth as the other brand, lends well to shading or striping for effects. Love the case, which slants the pencils easily toward you when opened. A nice addition to my pencil collection and definitely the one to grab for coloring on the go. Very unlikely to spill out.

Beautiful and unique coloring book for the fan of mid century design. Takes color well from multiple brands of colored pencil. Offers full scene living room pages and pages themed to one type of object, such as a bowl or clocks. Minimal waste of space in book, focus is on objects to color. Would love a follow up book!

I tried to cancel this order when I realized the showerhead had no bar. (With sizes in the house ranging from 6" to 4" easy adjustment is important. That's my mistake and the rating does not reflect this.) The showerhead installs easily, all the parts I needed (save instructions) were included. Visually, it looks very expensive and offers some interesting styling. In practice the water settings are "decent light pressure" and "is this thing still on?!?" I don't think I'll be changing settings again, but I won't change showerheads just yet. The light setting is ok for my current needs.  In the under twenty range this may be worth considering, but you won't be blown away.

Edit: i notice since my purchase the photo and description have changed. While it still shows me the neon pens in my account, tje selliing page no longer shows and lists them. Leaving review as is in case they switch back.I wish this set had been as shown and described. The bonus pens were not included.  I like the easel stand and the markers flow nicely with some streaking. Extremely easy to control, very thin pen tip, but 20 pens instead of 26. It's hard to give a four star review when you're shorted 25% of the product.

Coates writing style is engaging. The way he chronicles his internal thought and reaction process is very approachable for a white reader from different life experience. His descriptions of past events are concise and visual, easily putting the reader in the moment.  The conceit of the book is practical. What will he need to teach his son to survive without diminishing his joys. He spends a good deal of time weighing his accumulated experience of America versus a consideration of the very different experience of his son via technological and geographical differences to arrive at a strong compare / contrast without putting words in anyone's mouth but his own. Coates frequently takes pains to emphasise that his words are addressing his own lived experiences, not a global one. The dangers his son will face are unique to black lives, but they will take a different form than they did for him. The constant remains the need to be superhuman, to continually rise above.  A must read for 2015.

The snap in dividers are really only meant to be used in a 3 ring binder, where having a snap in divider is kind of less useful than in a spiral or other notebook. I would have liked more versatility of use as far as which they could be used it, ie unsplit holes for a 3 ring and tabs for a spiral. The colors and patterns are fun and pleasing. the bookmarks all line up in the same place so the tabs are not visible on their own if you have multiple ones in place. I think the design misses on some key points but I like the attempt to provide more interesting tabs for my binders.

We use a variety of OGX shampoos and while the TRESemme looked interesting, we didn't like it as much as our current product. The scent is a little strong and not to my taste (one daughter said "It smells weird") On a variety of hair types it rinsed out easily, left the hair feeling clean and did not weigh it down at all (even the baby fines). Hair felt less silky than with the OGX shampoo and the baby fine hair in the family spent the next day wih a lot of static / flyaway issues. Not banished to the guest bath, but something we'd probably not seek out,

150 pages seems very minimal for a three subject notebook. I could see using the dividers to seperate sections for a single class, keeping labs from class notes, for example. Having the dividers be moveable in a multi - subject scenario means your notes are doomed to end up out of order! This premium notebook comes with a premium price and I'm not sure I agree with it. On to the good news!The covered spiral is something I didn't know I needed till I saw it - one of those Of Course moments. No more snagged skirts or refusal to leave the backpack behind. Love the pen loop and the writeable subject tag. The dividers seem durable but are not too difficult to remove or move. Pages are decent quality, taking pen or ink well. Overall, a great product with some price and marketing caveats.

This is a solid product with excellent attention to detail. The moveable divider is easy enough to relocate without feeling flimsy. The writeable spiral tab is a great feature I didn't know I needed till I saw. I love covering those annoying snaggable spirals with a protective case and having a pen clip as well! The paper takes pencil amd ink well, is of decent quality, and removes smoothly. Pretty impressive for standard school use. On to the bad news.Because price is very flexible on Amazon I try to rate products only on their quality. In the case of this notebook I have to stress my 5 stars are only for the product itself. Is it 2x as good as a standard notebook? 3x as good? In my opinion it's 5x to 7x as good, but certainly not 12x or 15x as good. Because our schools don't have lockers, my kids are ridiculousy tough on their school supplies. Last year I experimented by buying a few premium Mead products and they were the first thing to survive the school year intact. I have high hopes for the survival of this notebook!

Great shipping labels. Strong adhesive (I still cover the address with clear packing tape because my printer is ink-jet, not laser). Easy feed, no jamming, easy to remove from backing. I have one printer that hates all Avery labels, sadly it hates these too, but my main printer adores them. Loads no problem and the print is crisp.Also good size for work "posters" but be careful of the surface because it could damage it. These are NOT reposition-able so they need to be changed frequently to avoid residue problems. I like the lack of tape and smoother look to the "poster" over putting info up on plain paper.

My 11 year old is extremely fussy about fabrics and fits. We generally buy her Land's End Interlock Polo for school. I expected her to reject this shirt but she really likes it. The length is good, a bit longer than some brands. She wears a Land's End 10 and a 12 in Aeropostale so I went with a 10/12 M. Her older sister complimented her on the fit right away. it's a tighter to the body girl cut so I'd definitely take that into account if your daughter is plus size. Mine is not thin, she is a athletic and so pretty average overall. The navy is a true dark blue. The fabric is soft and the sleeves hit at a good length off the shoulder. The collar is a bit stiff but softens somewhat with washing. No discoloration on two washes, will update whan I notice fading. Very happy with this product.

Watkins overwrites. If that's your thing, there is much to appeal in Gold Fame Citrus. If a phrase like "the colloidal taste of hummus in her mouth" makes you sigh, this isn't the right book. Watkins strength is in long descriptive sentences that meander through multiple destinations before arriving at their end. Plotting is a weaker point. Things happen inorganically, focus is lost. Ig, the toddler, is a plot device rather than a fully realized character. Personal development fluctuates, giving the impression that the child is regressing but Watkins is vague enough that the reader is unsure if this is intentional. Gold Fame Citrus will reward those looking to study descriptive phrasing but leave readers seeking a solid narrative out in the cold.
Interesting look at BRCA through one family's personal history. Good and sympathetic overview to the novice, additional insights and details for the more informed. Well worth checking out.
Good home scissor, no split ends after cutting, good balance, sharp.

Quick and easy fun. Each turn has actions for each player giving it a fast pace. Easy enough for all ages to pick up without being dull. Similar in difficulty level to King of Tokyo. Players can choose from different strategic styles for a friendly or resource raiding approach. Picking up the expansion pack!

Kara is an engaging, age appropriate heroine. She lacks some basic sense which is appropriate to the age and necessary for the plot. Side characters are a mix of well conceived and red herring. With a complicated backstory, decent suspense pacing and full resolution there is a lot to like in From Where I Watch You. But, and here is the spoiler / trigger warning, like so much YA with a female protagonist there is a sexual assault subplot. Because of course and especially in a suspense novel. The book is not better for it. The same aims could have been achieved by a more original path.

This is a mini version of the standard Mead 5 Stars. It's adorable but overly featured. I like the tear away pages ( perforated is less messy! ) and the pen clip. This is easy to slip in a briefcase or backpack. Won't last a full year as an assignment planner but excellent for quick notes, lists, etc. 3.5 stars - the spiral cover keeps the notebook from snagging but also limits range of motion for the cover. On such a small pocket pad it feels bulky.

Ever After has too much going on for it's own good. This series hasn't captured me and I think I need to give up on Deveraux. The book has MAJOR consent issues as the heroine's therapies are not only unprofessional, but involve physical interactions the hero cannot consent to. If he were drunk / roofied her actions would be illegal. As it was, I remained unconvinced they weren't. If informed consent isn't important to you, there's a decent beach read here.

Decent product with moderately strong hold. Easy to restyle, inoffensive scent. Thicker and a little harder to work with than American Crew, my normal styling paste. Would use again but don't like enough to switch.

While we prefer Black's solo work we really enjoy this series with Clare as well. In the first book Call discovered a secret that made him a danger to everyone around him. Here in fhe second he relies even more on his friends as he tries to evade what may be a dark destiny. His family has secrets of their oen and Call begins to suspect they wish him harm. Good use of side characters and world building, basic narrative about being afraid of your own power. Kids really identified with Call's quest to overcome his own (very) dark side. Excellent middle grade adventure,

Not sure what value the soft rubber grip adds. The pouf side was tough to use as it retracted imto the gripper and couldn't be squished about for grewt lather. The loofah side was very abraisive, almost too much. It was harder to rinse. Grip edge not easier to hold than a loofah and pouf alone.

I was torn between three and four stars. Goodman's book is very readable to those interested in the financial side of rock and roll but is unlikely to appeal to readers seeking out a less detailed read. Klein was a consummate hustler in an era of the same, always an angle to benefit himself. Finishing Goodman's book I understood why Klein has been so polarizing. He presented himself as a benefactor while taking what appears to be often extreme advantage of his clients. Given the absolute corruption of the industry at the time, Klein no doubt deserves more credit that he gets. While he did appropriate artist's rights he also was at the forefront of freeing those rights from the label's iron hold. His financial ideas were often innovative. Those who dislike Klein will not change their mind from this detailed look at his practices. Those to whom Klein is new will find a nuanced, occasionally favorable, look at a key figure in early rock and roll.

I thought this bracelet would be larger in person than it was. It's not skiimpy, but based on the illustration I expected a lightweight yet bold piece. This is perfectly proportioned for a teen or tween who likes Alex & Ani bangles. (I'll try and get a reference photo up.) it's not so small as to appear fragile but it is petite enough not to suit me. The sizing is excellent - fits a 7" wrist or an 8" due to the chain extension. Very adjustable. The diamond chip is set at the top of the heart while the plate around the heart is nicely faceted for decorative sparkle.

I love the Swiffer dry pads for quick and easy cleaning between real cleaning sessions. They handle dust, dirt, and hair well but are not useful for things like sand or crumbs. The wet pads are good or spills but leave a sticky dull residue that I either have to rinse or live with. I tend to use them only on small areas. The extremely light nature of the pole and pads coupled with their arthritis friendly package make this an essential product for my house.

This works extremely well for privacy. it's a fairly thick screen and a smudge magnet, but it absolutely blacks out the screen from the side. There is a loss of resolution that was noticeable to me but not a dealbreaker. Application was similar to other screen protectors, takes some patience. Screen response is still excellent, no issues with lagging response or lack of recognition. Not perfect, but very decent option.Pros: Works, good responseCons: Thick, easy to smudge / scratch, some resolution loss.

A slow start and a rushed ending kept me from loving Ancient Appetites - and it caused my 11 year old to abandon it. Once you get about 1/3 in the careful worldbuilding and deft characterization make this AU Victorian Steampunk worth reading. Lots going on here, with twisting motivations and questions of personal morality in play. Would appeal to readers who enjoy fantasy suspense. May pick up the sequel.

I would suggest this bag for it's clear utility, great price, and sturdy construction to anyone not daunted by tackling an MC Escher quality labyrinth of zippers.  The bag packs so flat that I was at first concerned it would not be up to the challenge for which it was intended *(light weekend or multi day travel, with multiple changes of clothing and toiletry bag).  It turns out that this is the complete Jason Bourne luxury model escape kit in bag form, in fact it is entirely possible that Bourne may still be lost in it somewhere.  The staggering number of compartments and their zippers planted the idea in me that if I were ever  to start unzipping each compartment they would yield only new, more zippered compartments leaving me stranded on the precipice of a yawning nylon void, and that I may be lost in that effort never having found the end, or an exit, or perhaps just left inside a zipper edged realm questioning my place in the cosmos‚Ä¶ which in fact might also be contained inside this bag.  This is like a five legged pant.We begin fairly smoothly‚Ä¶ four securing side strap clips release the full depth of the main body, and a large double zipper opens for your basic "place to put clothes and things" affair.  From here our footing is less secure regarding four side pouches (open top net pouches for ‚Ä¶snack bars most likely, and long zipper sided water bottle pouches with fold over non fastening tops), a secondary main space, a zipper which releases and deploys an entirely second backpack (with airy net shoulder straps and space for pens, wallets, snacks, and microfiche).  It unzips off the back of the main bag. This new backpack nestles it's limbs and cuddles back up to the host bag fairly easily for re-zippering.  There is a pouch only available when deployed - which seems to have literally been designed to hold a passport and a sandwich close at hand.This isn't even it's final form, though.A recessed zipper panel on the underside opens to release a full backpack harness for the main pack with abdominal and shoulder cross straps.  You can either roll the cover panel up and secure it with a dedicated bottom velcro pouch, or you can let it hang free as an over exaggerated rear flap to ensure your pants (or knees or calves) never have to touch an unknown surface while sitting on public transit.In all, I packed two and a half typical bags worth of content into this bag including one of those other bags, and I think I could have worked in more if I'd taken my time.  The top carry handle is comfortable and useful when navigating airline or train seating.  I missed my typical cross shoulder strap for carry-ons, but the pang of that loss will very likely lessen in short order.Pros:  Great amount of storage, light frame while structurally sound, very versatile, amazing price.  Being larger on the inside, awesome for fans of Doctor Who.Cons:  Like the cult film House, I worried that by putting anything into it, I would have to drive to another state and break through a medicine cabinet mirror to repel into a wall and find it again.Optional ProTip:  Consider getting secondary market dedicated zipper pull adornments for each pouch, so that when someone is asking for your papers, you know to open the Hello Kitty, whereas when you are pushing off hunger, you know to grab the Casino Dice.  Otherwise you might be there all day testing zippers.

Fantastic print (giramondo) but I didn't care for the stiffening material in the flap. The bag is pretty tight to fit more than an evenings essentials, making more suited to a clutch than cross body. Excellent placement of pockets, good closure.

Broader than the title suggests, One Righteous Man ties together other notable figures of the time into a balanced look at the uphill fight they all faced. The author doesn't shy away from Battle's own flaws, resisting the urge to turn a heroic man into a sainted hero. The book is stronger for this clear eyed look.Although well versed in the place and era, I still learned quite a bit about the political corruption of 1900's New York. Written accessibly, the whole would appeal to a casual reader of history, race relations or early New York. Loved this book.

I've read a lot about WW2 and was interested in learning more about pre-WW1 Russia. Lieven has produced an admirable and extensively researched book but not a highly readable one. With the challenge of unfamiliar players and a steady introduction of same, The End of Tsarist Russia requires slow and careful reading. This is a historian's history, not one for Sunday reading. interesting for it's different perspective, it requires serious commitment from the casual reader. Better for readers already versed in the region's history.

These gloves run a size or so smaller than some other brands. On the positive side, the grip design works as intended - less sliding and dropping of tools. As I wanted these for various art projects, some of which involve hand casting metals, that was an important safety consideration. Not suited to tasks that require full tactile feedback, but not so thick that you feel ham fisted. Good air circuation, interior coating comfortable. Overall very good for a light-duty disposable.

Great staying power - I've used this brand before and they don't come off in daily use. In addition to their intended use under dinner chairs, etc, I've also used them on the backs of my picture frames to avoid the metal scratching the walls. Not too thin, not too obvious. Also good for tabletop items like metal based lamps.
Easy to clean, no weird smell, feels secure. These are pretty similar to Nuk pacifiers, but I like the material better. Nice pacifier.

If you like Kirshenbaum's style then this collection will more than satisfy you. I was new to him and did not. Expecting something sly, irreverent and potentially moving, instead I found something colder and snider. The narrator seems to feel he is not the same as those around him, while displaying all the same notes of narcisstic self importance. There's nothing truly surprising here as shallow unhappy people pretend to have meaningful interactions while assessing if the other person is important. Try a sample before you order.

Dunaway is a fair and entertaining storyteller. I'm interested in rock history, but my knowledge of the Alice Cooper Group was minimal. Insightful, interesting and easy to read but I went with 3 stars over 4 mostly for reasons of style. The book is more a selections of moments, as many memoirs are, than a linear narrative. Sometimes that really works, here it made the story less essential. I'd set it down and forget It for a few days. Better than most rock books, but not epic.

For reference, my preferred brands are Krave, Fresh Market, Boar's Head & Oberto's. We really enjoyed this brand of jerky, even the turkey (which we usually find textually unappealing). Chef's Cut was very tender, not mushy, lean and well flavored. I'm not a huge fan of poultry jerky at all but I would have any of the four flavors again. The pepper beef seemed appropriately spicy to me but two members of our household thought it was too strong. If you like Krave, this brand is of similar texture. If you like Oberto's, it's going to seem extremely soft.

I'm conflicted about this book. Leap finds herself surprised when her perceptions of what the group will be like don't match their words or actions. On the other hand, she strives to give a clear eyed accounting of the realites of life in this community of limited opportunties. The audience for this book is likely to share many of the assumptions Leap herself makes, and therefore also find themselves surprised. In a scene where a member of the group angrily confronts a police officer who has come to speak Leap is nonplussed by other members of the group being concilatory to the officer. Her fear is the man confronting will escalate the situation. As a reader, I already know the reverse is far more likely. Worth reading, but not without issue.

While largely unfamiliar with Mitchell going into the book I found Man In Profile fascinating. Mitchell's influence on modern feature pieces is, I now realize, profoundly underappreciated. Dealing primarily with his career and his work as opposed to his personal life or (thankfully!) armchair analysis, Kunkel makes a compelling argument for Mitchell's continued importance. For those interested in early 20th century New York or newsmen as a whole, Man in Profile is a solid choice.

Betts writes a beautiful memoir of finding herself and her career path as a young expat in Paris. Coming from a background of some ease, her early struggles will seem lighter to readers from less comfortable ones. This is not to take anything away from her hard work. Without the training and experience she came to Paris with thriving in it would have been more difficult. With it, she still had to identify and seize opportunites. Strongest in the first half where her fish out of water uncertainity is more relatable, but still compelling in the second. Betts book is a well told tale.

In an ultimately depressing slice of life graphic novel we follow a U.K. doctor from his troubled childhood to his troubled adulthood. No one is truly happy or satisfied in this pessimistic look at how we evade or embrace our inner demons. Male focused in many ways despite an equal number of female characters, The Bad Doctor gives most we meet an unhappy-in-their-own-way diagnosis.Dealing with OCD, depression, professional and personal dissatisfaction, The Bad Doctor can be summed up by the phrase "Is that all there is?". 2.5 stars as it does detail a specific life in a vivid manner but no higher as it lacks the insight to rise above the rote detailing of how the doctor fails himself and his patients at the same time.

The source material is excellent as Morias has obviously done intensive research. The perspective is fresh, as it's rare to read an english language book on Cuba not predisposed to the American point of view. Holding me back from really engaging with Morais's book is the style. I don't know if the translation is poor or if the author is very journalistic in his approach but the result is a very dry read. What could be a thrilling narrative is bogged down in workmanlike prose. Will reward a diligent reader but will not captivate a casual one.

Cole Cohen has an interesting neurological condition and she writes well when detailing the challenges she's faced before and after diagnosis. This is the rare book where I wish a third party had taken alternating chapters. Cohen's focus is naturally narrow but the telling of her life eventually becomes claustrophobic. It's a very good memoir, 3.5 stars perhaps, but it had me rushing toward the end.

There are no huge surprises in this soapy tale of two lovers meeting a their shared boyfriend's funeral. Charlie, Presumed Dead, has a number of twists along the way, but most will be spotted by fans of the Big Conspiracy YA books. Heltzel turns out a strong version, keeping her target market enthralled. Me 11 year old can't wait for a sequel. "You will simply LOVE this book!" Lena and Aubrey form an unlikely friendship as they travel the world trying to unravel the mystery of Charlie's death. Drug dealers,betrayal and potential danger keep them moving. A transgender character is referred to as a "ladyboy". This may be accurate to the country the characters are in, but it required a discussion on the term not being accepted American usage. Lena and Aubrey come across as interesting and resourceful. Definitely in for a sequel.

I think the age rating on this book is a little high - I'd slate it more 4th grade to 6th. Nice collection of mild ghost stories with a class 'round the fire' format updated to include a mysterious room of strangers telling their tales. Big hit with my 11 year old - "This book will make sure you know what story you will tell when your friends want to spook you, and it WILL backfire on the person who had the idea to start the game of stories." One character speaks in dialect, which seemed unnecessary. My fifth grader found confusing, thinking it was a case of poor grammar. Overall, a good fit for a target market slightly lower than indicated.

The premise of the books was intriguing, but the mystery was thin and the main character inconsistent. I found it difficult to engage with and my 11 year old (it's target market and an avid reader) DNF'd it. There's a lot happening here for the sake of the plot and not driven by realism or the motivation of the characters. Strong idea, but didn't work for me.

How fun is this book?? That said, keeping me from five stars are a few slow sections, occasional slides into camp, and slips in the first person tense. (I'm not a huge fan of first person and it really jumps out at me when the time shifts. If a first person narrator knows something she shouldn't or alludes to something she'll know later while the tense is set as present, it throws me right out of the story.) The Royal We is a semi satirical but very sympathetic look at the romance of Will and Kate (with major changes, of course). Being a potential princess is far from easy. Betrayal, partner swaps and unfounded suspicions all add up to Bex and Nick being pure soapy fun in book form.

I don't know if we all received the same models - for clarity I'll start by saying that my earbuds came with 4 fit sizes and I had no problem getting a good fit. They don't slide around or fall out at all. For comparison purposes, my current favorites are a set of Heartbeats by Beats. These are much better for my needs. The Phiaton MS 100 BA have excellent mid balance. The high and low is acceptable, but I agree that the bass is not dominating. (For comparison purposes again, the bass is superior to the Heartbeats, which I found too strong in the highs, giving them a tinny sound for pop music.) The pouch is cheap and disposable - a faux suede drawstring deal. Instructions are weak but the inline controls were responsive and (once figured out) reliable in use. Sound quality on calls was very good, and I strongly preferred these over the Heartbeats for casual music use (indierock, blues, rap). Very clear and balanced over all. With some tweaking on the low end these would be more impressive but as they stand I really like them. Gave my Beats away.

Snyder has been a hit or miss author for me. This time around was the same. I loved coming back to Yelena but it felt off - she seemed less sure of herself, less savvy somehow, than in earlier books. Yelena is still a strong character but rather than a Yelena who has grown wiser we got a Yelena who was softer, less calculating. It's a choice, but it's not where I thought Yelena would evolve. As well, the world building was less intense. I didn't emotionally engage. A major problem for me was the tense changes. I'm not a huge fan of first person. I enjoy books with alternating character perspectives but going from first to third only works for me if the first person is set in a different time period, like a diary. Not sure I'll read the second.

I was initially unsure about this line of cases but I've come to really like them. They look and feel like luxury items. On the downside, the upper edge of the phone is exposed as the case only rides up a small bit and does not come over to cover it. There's no scratch protection if you're trying to retain a perfect appearance for later resale. Otherwise, it's great. Good grip, doesn't slide in the hand or on a table, good quality included screen protector. I have a gold phone and the dark brown looked great with it. The interior of the case is smooth and rubberized. Snaps on easily and very securely. It's not going to work for a shock protective Otterbox style need, but the ullu is nicer than the Apple branded leather cases. (The edges at the very face of the phone seem more like plastic than leather, but I can't find a seam, possibly they have been coated with something?)

Honestly, I expected to just say "It's a pencil, what do you expect?"  Cheap pencils have issues with the leads falling out or becoming broken and wobbly. Expensive pencils with colorful exteriors can sharpen very unevenly. Mechanical pencils can snap quickly. As it happens, I was really very impressed with these. On the negative side, I mistrust the long term durability of plastic on a pencil destined for the bottom of a backpack. I wish the eraser was larger or replaceable. (I often use a seperate eraser stick made of what appears to be the same material as this so it's not a huge issue. On the positive side, these were a huge hit in my household. I brought them out at homework time and my kids have a strong positive reaction to the colorful appearance. One, who prefers using mechanical pencils, loved the hardness of the lead and wanted to take them to school. The other, who has never expressed any kind of lead preference, also made a bid for ownership. (The leads do produce a lighter line than a conventional pencil which makes me wonder if they would be accepted for the standardized testing in the schools? We recently moved to computer based testing, so it was less of a concern.) Erasing is smooth and easy, sharpening was even on all sides without lead wobble or imbalanced wood (I ground one all the way down to test it's build). Quality pencil, big hit with a variety of ages. Not the cheapest choice, for sure, but a great option for a fun school supply. Maybe buy an eraser stick, though.

Inconsistent character actions bog down what could have been an exceptional read. My teen was bored but my 11 year old loved A Wicked Thing. Interesting twist on the Sleeping Beauty story with a good eye to the consent issues that underline the tale. If cliffhanger endings bother you, give A Wicked Thing a miss - too many issues feel unresolved at the end for the book to fully satisfy. As a coming of age story about a princess who wakes up in an alien land and has to figure out her own path, there's a lot I liked here.

I wouldn't use this with my projectors as it seems to take a while to write and transfer data, but it's got great capacity for the price. Using it to transfer files between home and the office. For kicking around in my pockets it's got a good size and easy grip, not as slick as some sticks. Decent but not amazing product. I'd not test the waterproof nature - the cap doesn't seem to seal as well as my reliable waterproof equipment. Could probably survive a quick dunk but not a real submersion. Of course, if you're routinely swimming with your drive still in your pocket... Decent but not category shattering.

Performed well in my video camera. I plan to swap it out into a handheld gaming system since the write speed seems to be close my low capacity competitor card. I'll update if it dies (I've never had a competitor brand go bad) but if it holds up as well I may switch brands. Good option.

I'm mixed on this case. The pebbled leather is beautiful - distinctive and deeply saturated with color. The feel is better than the Apple branded cases. What holds me back from really loving it is the exposure at the phone's top. Button access and port access is necessary, but I expected the very top of the case to have a protective lip to prevent scratches. Instead, it's exposed. The snap case interior is a soft finish hard material that will keep scratches from forming as a result of the case, but the exposed top might make this a poor choice for someone trying to preserve phone appearance for resale. The owl is embossed and super cute. The case snaps on easily and snugly, if it just had top protection I'd be much happier with it. Looks and feels great, but not a full bumper.

I'm mixed on this case. The pebbled leather is beautiful - distinctive and deeply saturated with color. The feel is better than the Apple branded cases. What holds me back from fully loving it is the complete exposure at the phone's top. Button access and port access is good, but I expected the very top of the case to have a protective lip to prevent scratches to that surface. Instead, it's fully exposed. The snap case interior is a soft finish hard material that will keep scratches from forming as a result of the case, but the exposed top might make this a poor choice for someone trying to preserve phone appearance for resale. The owl is embossed and super cute. The case snaps on easily and snugly, if it just had top protection I'd be much happier with it.

Whenever I read a YA book I also have my kids read it because I'm not the target market. While I recognized Haunted's influneces, I found the twists were handled well and the world building very strong. My tween sobbed over the ending and asked me to find more books by the author as soon as possible. She read through dinner, skipped a trip to the arcade, and finished the book in 48 hours. My rating was 3.5 to 4 stars, hers was over 5. Promising new series with most points resolved by the end, but not for impatient readers. Haunted unfolds at it's own pace with the next installment a year away. Great choice for middle grade readers who enjoy gothic or light horror.

My daughters love Nerf products and frequently have friends over for Nerf Wars so I thought they'd all be excited to try the BOOMco product. The girls all rejected it on the grounds that "those are for boys". Closer questioning revealed the BOOMco marketing is aimed solely at teen and tween boys, making the girls view the toy negatively. It's a shame, because the gun itself is pretty fun. This is a pump action so not suitable for kids with poor hand strength or smaller kids. The targets have a decent lifespan but I agree with other reviewers - clean your darts or give up on the stickiness. My set also came with a sample of the round balls for throwing at the gun or targets - these were great as a replacement for their indoor dart set. Good Nerf alternative for tweens boys.

Eunsun Kim is a very direct writer. This is such a strength when dealing with a life story that could easily become overwrought. She details extremely challenging circumstances with a factual focus that keeps them from being unbearable to the reader. Hunger, death, family seperation, all occur in Kim's escape from North Korea and her long quest for personal freedom. Her respect for opportunity and work shine through. Kim strives not to feel sorry for herself, even as so many doors were never open to her. Her simple approach makes the book accessible to many readers. A deserved bestseller in other countries, A Thousand Miles To Freedom deserves the attention. Likely to be my memoir of the year.

So good. Discovered this on a listening station at a local shop and fell in love. New-to-me high quality soul tracks with extensive notes about who the artists are and the circumstances surrounding the tracks. The liberal number of unreleased tracks would be a bonus to someone familiar with the label but as I wasn't, it's all fresh and original. I'm in for the whole series.

I love storage bins and cubes. I use them in my car, in my house, at work. Unfortunately I do not love this storage cube. It's completely unstructured, there is not even a thin board for the base, much less a stiffening frame. The result is a slouchy bag that flops in on itself unless completely filled with items of low weight heavy items cause the bag to sag when moved. The handles are scratchy and short. Both hands are required to carry the cube or everything will spill out. Because of the lack of structure, you can't balance it against your body and have one hand free. On the positive side, the material is very thick, the colors consistent and pleasant.This product would be good for immobile storage, perhaps for shoes in a mudroom or cleaning supplies under a sink.
Very elegant tray for snacks. Very nicely constructed. Nice size for serving snacks for 10-15 people.
Premium quality wired headphones. Super comfortable. Cups cover ears completely.  Very accurate sound with excellent bass. As good as my Senns.

If you've ever owned a boar you know the money pit it can be to keep the boar looking nice. Washing and waxing the boar frequently protects against corrosion, paint oxidation and abrasions. Meguiar's flagship is an excellent wash and wax for maintaining your boat but I wish it was a little bit easier to remove the dried wax.

The tank top is nice and the material and seems are well constructed. We just joined Gold Gym and started Yoga and exercise classes. I will probably pick up a second since I'm at the gym several days a week. I'm a little confused by the "Bra" in the title though.

Nice looking dress watch.  Definitely looks a lot nicer than the price would imply.  I'm an Invicta fan so I'm glad to know their quality is still good.  The casing was a little bigger than I expected since I have small wrists but it looks great. My only gripe is the band is so long I had no choice but to take it to a jeweler in the mall to resize. They also sell band resizing kits for adjusting the band yourself on Amazon.
Nice basic case for the budget Kindle Fire. Protects the tablet and has a nice folding stand.

I love art and I love fashion.  I even love silk. So this scarf is the perfect accessory for the Impressionist lover.  The material seems well constructed.  Simplicity sent me these for a fair review.
Who doesn't love a fedora.  It's cool and practical at the same time.  The Simplicity hat is well constructed of nice materials and it really looks sharp. Simplicity sent me these for a fair review.

I do a lot of outdoor activities including backpacking so I'm always on the lookout for good insulated gloves. They are comfortable.  The material seems durable and well constructed. They fit average hinds just fine. Simplicity sent me these for a fair review.
Decent quality synthetic dish towels.  Excellent value for the price.

0:45 Mins THIS IS COOL.  I've been using semi-annoying USB to VGA adapters for the longest time.  With those you have to install a special driver. With this handy little adapter its just PLUG and PLAY! It even dumps the audio to a 3.5MM output.

Works perfectly with my Sony DSC-HX60V camera. I like how small and light the charger is. Easily stash it in a small bag along with the camera. The LED light on the box indicates when the battery is charging or fully charged.  The spare battery works as well as the OEM battery.  What more can you ask for?

I just used these on a cross country road trip. The sound quality is excellent, definitely a step up from my previous generation Brainwavz earphones. The ear cushions that come on the earphones were too small for me but they send many, many different kinds to swap.  I settled on the large black ones because they had the best noise cancelling and comfort. The on-lanyard controls work perfectly with my iPhone 5S and Samsung Galaxy 6. Brainwavz sent the to me for a fair review and I was moderately impressed. I own  lot of earphones and earbuds and these stack up there with my Senns.

For the price I don;t think you should be expecting a wood and metal replica.  This is a manufactured cosplay piece. Yes, it's plastic. But it looks pretty sweet and seems plenty durable for many days of fun.
So I got to wear this once before my daughter stole it. Yes it's comfortable but it may be too irresistible for kids not to swipe.

My daughter really loves these Bluetooth earphones. They fit comfortable. The sound quality is excellent.  They are super adjustable and fold up compactly. No more dangling cables.  Brainwavz sent these for me for a fair review and I have no reservations about recommending these to anyone looking for a nice Bluetooth headset.

I've been working up to a full marathon next year so I'm mostly training and doing half marathons. Anything above 5K it really becomes essential to keep hydrated. Feilaiger sent me this for a fair review. The belt is made from nice materials and the stitching is precise. MY only complaint is the bottle holder is a bit tight for regular size water bottles and the straps that are meant to hold the bottles in at the top are difficult to take off while jogging.

I just used this on an extensive travel weekend. I have a bad habit of eating up my phone battery while flying so I was looking for a rapid charger for my Android phone. This charger arrived and it feels like a sturdy plug.  The phone charged super fast at my stopovers on my trip across the country.  Veepeak sent me this plug to review and I'm pretty impressed with the quality.
Perfect replacement part for my old Whirlpool washer.

Very nice stainless beer mug. Double wall design keeps beer cold extra long.  Just big enough for a can or bottle of beer. Cleans really easy. There are no hard to get corners.  Comfortable in the palm of my hand. Ready for game time!!! X-Chef sent me this mug in exchange for my unbiased review. Having reviewed several of their items now I can say that the quality of their products is really good.

Tested this drive in Windows 10, Windows Server 2012 and Redhat Linux on a Dell R710 and it works great. Internally this uses a MATSHITA DVD+-RW UJ892. This drive is $10 cheaper than any other UJ892  drive currently on Amazon. That's 35 percent cheaper. It reads an writes an amazing number of formats. Package includes the external drive, a USB cable and a USB power cable. The drive worked for me without any power connected. Not sure why that cable is needed.Drive : MATSHITA DVD+-RW UJ892Type : DVD±R/RW DL RecorderFirmware Version : 1.04Buffer Size : 1 MBRead CD Text : XReturn C2 Pointers : XRead CD-R : XRead CD-RW : XRead DVD-ROM : XRead DVD-RAM : XRead DVD-R : XRead DVD-RW : XRead DVD-R DL : XRead DVD+R : XRead DVD+RW : XRead DVD+R DL : XRead Digital Audio : XRead CD+G : XRead VideoCD : XWrite CD-R : XWrite CD-RW : XWrite DVD-R : XWrite DVD-RW : XWrite DVD-R DL : XWrite DVD+R : XWrite DVD+RW : XWrite DVD+R DL : XWrite DVD-RAM : XBuffer Underrun Protection : XModes : Pa, LTA, LDA, LSA, LRA, LRA, LRA
Worked like a charm in my HP 15T notebook.  Popped it in an everything tests fine.  I run a few virtual machines and this coupled with my i7HQ make for a sweet little DEV workstation.
This book is a must read.
Humans, Orcs, Elves, Magic....fulfilling great destonies...you see where this is headed. If you are a fan of epic fantasy then this is your kind of book. A bit on the dark side.
Perfect addition to the single bed we picked up for our nephew while he is getting used to his new bed. Really important  especially if your child has a history of rolling out of bed.
Used this to run my PC HDMI input to a projector and external receiver for doing presentations.  PC + Projector + Receiver + This = Sweet HTPC
Used this to connect my older computer to an older TV to use as a monitor.  Worked great.  Seems like a solidly built adapter.
I used these for my ZPacks Arc Blast as a liner.  Just finished a long section of the Colorado Trail and the bag held up perfectly.
Cute and protective case.

There aren't many options when you are looking for a half-height Lab rack.  Most are too heavy and expensive. The Tripp Lite 18U can be easily carried by two adults and the castors work great, even on the berber carpet in our hallway. We have this rack 1/2 full and have easuly shuttled it around the office.  The build quality is excellent.[+] Light Weight but durable (~125lbs)[+] All sides are vented[+] Front and back are hinged and sides are removable[+] Heavy duty casters make it easily mobile[+] Fits standard size components (Dell R710, Riverbed appliance, Cisco Switch, etc).

In this delightful book, the narrator, Alice Whitley, is on a mission from Mimi Banning's publisher, to see to it that the reclusive author completes her novel. She camps out at Ms. Banning's Bel Air mansion and sees very little of the author, but is fully-occupied with Mimi's 9-year-old son, Frank.Frank is one of the most unforgettable characters you'll find, an irrepressible, wordy, eccentric boy, something of a savant, who favors 1930s clothing (the year of this story is 2010), does not get along with any other kids at school, and takes Alice's full time and attention. The first-person narration, told through Alice's exasperations, makes Frank even more vivid. This is also something of a mystery story, as Alice becomes intrigued with Mimi's family history, and especially: who is Frank's father? It's complicated by the appearance of Xander, a good-looking handyman, piano teacher, and sometime resident of the mansion, since Alice (and we) are left wondering who he is, other than a flaky, charming ne'er-do-well who appears and disappears often. With that, and Mimi's uncertain progress on her novel, and Frank's frequent meltdowns, crises and mishaps, the reader is in for a heady mix of mystery, comic mishaps, unexpected twists and some serious emotional turns. The story is fast-moving, well-told in the first person, and the characters -- Mimi, Alice, the publisher Isaac Vargas, Xander, and especially Frank -- are well-drawn and compelling.Very worthwhile, entertaining, and unforgettable. A splendid first novel from this author. Highly recommend.

This unit serves two basic functions: it will detect AC current when you point it at wires, sockets or other electrical devices, without the user having to touch the location (as you would, say, with a multimeter), and it will, when plugged into a 3-prong socket, report any anomalies in the circuit. It's a very practical device for anybody working around a household circuit, whether a professional or the homeowner, certainly as a warning that you're near a live circuit. It's something I wish I had during a recent renovation.It ships in plastic clamshell packaging, stiff and hard edged enough to chop vegetables -- that is to say, difficult to cut open. There's a "quick start guide" -- a 3x4" paper -- tucked inside the cardboard liner, so you have to get the packaging fully open to find it. The paper refers you to the Sperry website but you still have to click down to find a PDF user manual. The full URL, to save time:file:///C:/Users/Dell2008/Downloads/vd7504gfi_use_english.pdf (this is off the manufacturer's URL at:)http://www.sperryinstruments.com/en/resources/manualsThe battery -- a shirt-button sized L1154 -- ships separately, inside the clamshell, and you'll need a small Philips screwdriver to open up the device and insert it (the icon on the little door shows which way to insert the battery). The manual (in slightly stilted English) mostly talks about what what the device might not detect in a circuit, but the main thing with this device is that it will alert you that something is amiss. This device seems useful for checking any AC circuit, not just GFCI, The tester will, if inserted in a GFCI socket, pop the socket's breaker (or button) if you push the tester button at that end of the device, so it's a good way to check that particular kind of installation.The device also ships with a plastic sheath for the 3 prongs and you should try and keep it on the unit if you toss it in a tool box -- and be careful about storing it where other tools might press the upper button, the one design matter I believe to be a slight flaw. There's no on-off switch.As for the AC detection at the other end, this tester seems more sensitive than an older Greenlee voltage detector I had, as it can sense live AC at a further distance, up to an inch away in some cases. In all, this device is sensitive, practical, useful for homeowners and professionals, and should be close at hand if you're not sure you turned off the circuit and need to check, one last time, before you touch the wiring yourself. Strongly recommend for anybody's tool box.

It's a sturdy and well-designed backpack, with two main compartments, with an inner one suitable for a laptop (our 11-1/2x16 Dell fit just fine) with a cloth divider to separate the laptop from other objects (you may have to be careful about lumpy things like power blocks, since the rear section will be up against your back). The outer compartment can hold accessories, including a standard tablet; it's a divided compartment with slots for small objects (including pens/pencils) sewn in the divider. Both compartments have double zippers that look strong, and the fact that they both only unzip halfway down means the bag won't open fully and dump its contents. The outer side mesh pockets are fairly small, but there's a large open pouch outside, in the center.The shoulder straps and back padding are very comfortable, and suitable for either use on a bicycle, say, or simply for hands-off baggage carrying if you're on a trip and juggling other luggage (there is a handle but it's auxiliary and not comfortable for carrying it long distances). The bright green will keep you visible in low-light traffic but has an added advantage: you're not apt to overlook it in one last walk-through in a darkened hotel room. It's soft construction, no rigid framing, so it can press to less than 3" thick if not in use.In all, it seems comfortable, well-designed as a laptop/tablet carrier, functional and comfortable for day use or as part of a travel ensemble. Highly recommend.

This is a dark journey through a war-ravaged landscape. It's not the usual Civil War tale of battles and the usual soldiers; rather, it makes the western Carolinas and east Georgia look like Germany during the Thirty Years' War, or maybe some dystopian novel of post-devastation America, whose inhabitants are mostly starving civilians, armed robbers, horsemen of no particular loyalty, lost amid a ruined countryside. Callum, a 15-year-old horsethief who had ridden with irregulars (which side? asks a character; "it doesn't matter much"). He's now on the run, a band of murderous bounty hunters on his scent. He and Ava, a young woman displaced by war, now wander across areas scorched by Sherman's army.The author's attention to period detail and the mundane details, notably horses' limitations and health, is good, and his prose is terse and a steady read. It's a story of war's victims and the wraiths on the fringes, not the ones who made it.- - -"I just realized," said Ava."What?""The genius of it. All this. Sherman. Think: Nobody's going to want to fight any longer, they don't have nothing to come home to."Callum looked at a dead dog by the side of the road, shot, its tongue blue and still."It's hell is what it is."Ava nodded. "Exactly."

This is a good, compact backup-power battery for two AC power devices, and, coincidentally, a port for charging mobile devices with USB cables. The AC plug-ins in back really do rotate, which is important because many AC cords end in bulky, blocky transformers or such and these rotating sockets help fit them. The unit might not handle large-wattage devices but for what it's designed for -- routers, say -- it's fine, and that means you can keep your AC devices online in a power outage (and recharge mobile devices as well). As a lifeboat in an outage it's a great help, and it's a convenient place to recharge mobile USB-cable devices in normal periods. The unit is a convenient size, about the size and shape of a book, and can fit many cramped areas.The UPS sets up easily, and the little feet can snap in to allow it to stand up or lay sideways, depending on your space needs. The indicator lights are good indicators and very bright green. The device shipped with its own "quality assurance test" printout which had test and accuracy data, which was reassuring. I'm using my routers on it and notice no difference in wi-fi or internet quality. In all, a nice addition to a PC station and an enhanced capacity to ride out outages and retain internet connection.

This book originally published in 1981 and had the benefit of first-person sources: the surviving women who had served and who provided many anecdotes, personal accounts amid the ongoing story of the women's bomber and fighter regiments. The stories of the PO-2 regiment -- biplanes engaged in night-intruder raids and enemy-territory drops -- are hair-raising. The other two women's regiments, flying Yak-1 fighters and Pe-2 attack bombers, proved to be brave and capable pilots, with several women scoring impressive totals of German aircraft. All three regiments would fight in the biggest battles of the war -- Crimea, Stalingrad, Kursk, Berlin -- and one, the biplane unit, would be re-numbered as a Guards regiment, the highest unit award, and a number of women in all three regiments won the Hero of the Soviet Union medal, the highest individual honor. Well worthwhile for people interested in military history, Soviet history and women's studies. They served because the Soviet Union had its back to the wall and needed any combatants they could get, but once the women had the chance they proved to be an elite, courageous, resourceful and deadly.Highest recommendation for this unique book. If this isn't on the reading list at the US Air Force Academy, it should be.(Plane types are Yakovlev Yak-1, Petlyakov Pe-2, Polikarpov PO-2.)

This is a tremendous, well-imagined work, its prose readable but elegant, its characters vivid. It‚Äôs a multi-layered story, with interlude chapters for backstory on the main characters, centering on «eda, needed because of the considerable mystery of their identities, including √áeda herself, growing up rough as a ‚Äústreet wren‚Äù and yet finds even she is not what she thought she was. The story is never confusing, never drags even in 600 pages, and immerses the reader.The setting ‚Äì the city of Sharakhai and the surrounding deserts ‚Äì is a fantasy setting that vaguely evokes that of old Arabia or Persia, but only vaguely. This setting is in a place with two moons, in which the gods and the supernatural of Sharakhai seem to have real force, in which women can be elite warriors and pit fighters in the arena. It‚Äôs a place in which trade ships (and pirates) sail on desert sands, and do so plausibly for any reader familiar with sailing. Many of Sharakhai's details -- spices, foods, class distinctions, mannerisms -- are familiar to us in name and texture, just enough for us to identify with this world. In some ways this book evokes Dune more than a typical medieval fantasy ‚Äì the book is that superb.√áeda is a bold but complex, and compelling character, and the strong relationship she has with her mother, an equally-strong protagonist, is central to this story. She‚Äôs a character worth following through these many pages and into the sequels to come.Strongest recommendation.

Setup was easy, though multi-step. The printer was quick to make wireless connection to my system, using the WPS option. Software setup to a computer on the network went OK, and the first prints ‚Äì Epson test paper prints on 8x11 paper ‚Äì came out fine. I also printed a 4x6 color glossy from my own photographs and it was surprisingly good quality.Epson setup includes an option to monitor your use of the scanner so they can offer you specials. Privacy-minded users may want to decline this part.As for scanning, you can insert a memory card from a digital camera, in most common formats (SD, SDHC, SDXC and their mini versions), into the printer, or use the USB ports (e.g., a thumb drive) or send it wireless, since the image file has to export somewhere. File limitations: scanner output is JPEG (or, from the Epson Scan software, PDF or WSD web) format and only up to 2MB, which is OK for documents, and our scans were indeed OK. The Epson Scan software allows you to operate the scanner from there, which is helpful, and it appears to be similar to their software for other Epson scanners, including default file storage and file-name assignments (default is img001, 002 etc. though you can specify otherwise).The unit does provide for some file manipulation (cropping, etc.) before printing, and you can swap photos in/out of the card. You can also print directly from a camera that uses PictBridge (many Canon DSLR cameras, for instance, seem to use PictBridge), or from mobile devices like cell phones or tablets.Downsides: paper can accommodate a number of different sizes up to legal but very limited quantities, The shallow trays (two) are an obvious design compromise to keep it small, though it helps that the unit can do two-sided printing. Users have to close the output tray any time they need to reload either of the two paper trays below it, and tray 1 (photo stock) tends to slide in too far past its (very light) detent point and needs to be fished back sometimes. The lid to the scanner hinge doesn‚Äôt seem disjoint or detach as some scanners will; you can get documents or something as thick as a magazine under the lid but that seems to be it, not, say, an open book.Scanner resolution is only 1200x2400. (By comparison, my older Epson V600 scanner has 6400x9600). This is still fine for document scanning (B&W or grayscale) but may pose some limitations in terms of picture scanning, as opposed to direct uploads from mobile devices or cameras. Plastic paper and output trays seem rather fragile and users should take care that they‚Äôre fully closed and the display folded down when the unit is not in use or is being moved.In all, it is indeed a small-in-one unit, reasonably compact and wireless, and reasonable quality given its limitations. Its main virtue is that it can serve as scanner, printer and photo printer in various sizes of media, doesn‚Äôt take up as much desk space as the three separate units and may even be reasonably portable, or it can serve as a standalone for any mobile devices or cameras happening by, if you simply want to scan or download and then print.

A good solid surge protector, and a thoughtful design. Six AC sockets, oriented sideways, which can be helpful, with the last two of them spaced to accommodate transformer plugs (which is to say, something with a bulky end on the cord). I have this unit in a hobby/tool shop room, and the dust covers on the AC sockets is a nice touch in a room with dust and sawdust. The metal housing seems solid. The 1000 joules' protection is good (my ordinary hardware-store surge protector had 245), esp. if you're working with electronic equipment. The rear cover has four slotted openings that you can use to hang the unit on a wall; the openings are kind of tiny but they can still take small woodscrew heads or small hooks, and they're in a =o= shape so that you can slide the head up or down inside the opening for a solid hang. In all, a good surge protector for shop (or even home) settings.

Plus side: the 800 joules' protection is a strong point (my hardware-store power-strip/surge protector only had 245). The rear cover has four brackets that can accommodate wall hooks or push pins. As a simple surge protector, it's okay.Downsides: the wall outlet is a straight-out plug (right-angle plugs can be more convenient, esp. on baseboard sockets). The "rotating" sockets on the unit seem to be surface only (basically, dust covers), as plugged-in components won't rotate, or at least not without more force than I'd want to attempt. There's only four outlets, and closely-spaced and in a head-to-foot alignment, so anything with a transformer (AC to DC) block on the end will need an extension. The two USB plugs are 2.1A shared, so effectively it's one USB, and it's on the same side as the AC sockets, which is probably there's four ACs, not six. Also, if this surge protector is on the floor, as it's apt to be underneath, say, a PC or desk, it's going to collect dust.

It's a handy little device whose main virtue is portability, roughly hand-sized, with a flip-out 3-prong plug (no cord, a good thing), with two AC sockets and one USB socket, and also a row of four LEDs that seem to show battery level. This gadget is a convenient size to pack with mobile devices or laptops, to take on trips and use for AC-powered devices or USB charging. I've tried the battery (unplugged) and the USB outlet will charge a cell phone on its own if the power is out, and the surge protection is handy if you're traveling and the power is uncertain or you've got electrical storms nearby. That's all it does: one AC plugin, two ACs out, a USB port for charging, and an internal battery to charge small mobile devices, if needed (no accessory parts). It does seem to recharge quickly enough, but may continue to take power if left plugged in.The packaging seems user-friendly and recycleable. The main instructions are on the inner cover (it warns you not to use hair blowers or steam irons, since its capacity is 1000w and meant for mobile or small electronic devices -- of course), and seems to indicate that the USB is best for charging mobile phones or tablets. The package also includes two leaflets, in tiny print, one a "declaration" of conformity with FCC rules on electromagnetic compatibility, and the other an instruction/warranty leaflet. The latter has a warranty you need to examine carefully, since it comes with a lot of "buts" and a complicated claim process. The instruction part of the leaflet talks about Belkin products that have mounts, phone and coaxial connections (RJ11/RJ45) that have to do with other Belkin products, not this one.In all, a simple, easy-to-pack, and handy companion for your mobile devices and laptop, especially on the road. Highly recommend if this fits your needs.

This is a nonfiction book about generations of families living on either side of what had been the 1949-1967 ceasefire line in Jerusalem, and then re-named Assael Street (or Asa'el, the very spellings are in dispute). It's a place with a view of the Temple Mount, and its neighborhood -- Abu Tor -- is also on the Hill of Evil Counsel, where Judas supposedly met with Caiaphas, and where Moshe Dayan and his Jordanian counterpart, in 1949, would draw a ceasefire line, divide a neighborhood on a map with two grease pencils, and leave a permanent border, sometimes visibly barricaded, sometimes not so visibly.The book reads, oddly enough, like a James Michener saga with its focus on the families there, their lives and travails, but it is sensitively written, and about real people on the knife-edge: a small dead-end street on the border between East and West Jerusalem. The author is at his best at telling the stories of several families, Jewish and Palestinian, over the years as their goats and chickens stray into no man's land, as Israeli and Jordanian soldiers snipe at the people (some times fatally) and UN officers negotiate border alignment and, in one case, look for dentures dropped in the zone.We learn about the brief conciliation and tentative friendships of these neighbors after the 1967 war and the replacement of barbed wire with a common street, and the gradual hardening of suspicions as outside events affect these people. The author's a bit conclusory in his review of outside events but he does show how these people are affected personally, as security checkpoints tighten, as the Israeli occupation questions house and property ownership, as they encounter hassles over ID and building permits, as an oversized new building goes up smack in the middle of the neighborhood. A new wall is coming, proposed as a division between East and West Jerusalem, to this very place, again.The narrative does leap back and forth in time, although the author's focus on a few families helps keep it coherent. He has a sympathetic way of writing about these people, Palestinian and Israeli, that does shade toward the former, although it's more a matter of telling about personal misfortune rather than getting into polemics. Vae victis.The book is worthwhile as sociology, a story of how events and a very unique geography affects a small neighborhood. It's not so much a "microcosm" of the larger conflict as it is a camera, a street view during some stormy decades. Strongly recommend.

This is a lively and unusual kind of detective story. Constance Kopp is someone who is determined, assertive and adventurous, and who won't accept the limits her times -- 1914, New Jersey -- place on her as a single woman. It's a dangerous time: her nemesis is a silk-factory boss in a Paterson, NJ, that is in the midst of labor strife and pro-labor courts and police. She's a spunky, likable character, speaking in the first person here, and her character is believable and interesting, as are her unmarried sisters. There's a backstory woven in this, as well as the main plot, a dangerous conflict between her and the boss and his thuggish confederates -- it's rooted in a real-life story and seems true to the period and the characters. And it is something of a mystery: maybe we know who the bad guys are, and maybe there's more, much more to it.Strongly recommend -- and here's hoping that this character has sequels.

This book's merit, the author's talent, is in its layered narratives, something that raises it up from a war story to something more literary. It interweaves the wartime memoirs of Poxl West, a young Czech Jewish refugee who escapes occupied Europe to serve in a rescue squad in London during the Blitz, and then as an RAF pilot, with the coming of age, 40 years later, of his adoring teenaged American nephew Elijah, at a time when the memoirs publish and Poxl becomes famous. The stories are well-told, the characters believable, and the book takes on more interest as the stories become darker, more complicated, more unexpected. It can be surprising, and at times compelling.

This remarkable, moving book evokes a time and places ‚Äì Italy and Argentina in 1913 and later ‚Äì in which women were confined in narrow roles, roles enforced violently at times. Yet Leda, using her wits and musical talent, disguises herself as Dante and proceeds to cross all boundaries of poverty, nationality, gender, class, sexual orientation, romance. The later-day ‚Äúin the closet‚Äù doesn‚Äôt even begin to explain the times and the dangers. Discovery could be fatal, literally, so her rise through the new tango scene is terrifying as she continues her disguise in the most public way, on stage as part of a rising music group in a field closed to women. The story ‚Äì and her back-story, flashbacks to her home village in Italy ‚Äì makes the reader want Dante so somehow win in the end, or at least somehow survive the dangers in every step, every dance.‚ÄúThis new life brought many freedoms. She could smoke, she could walk the streets at night, she could curse and spit into gutters. She could hold down a job that paid twice as much as anything a woman could do with her clothes on. But there were also new demands. She had to be extremely careful with her posture (head up, shoulders squared) and her gait (long sure strides, no swaying hips). She had to exude confidence, if not outright bravado, at all times ...‚ÄùThe prose can be hypnotic, lyrical, flowing, an evocation of the time and place and a new craze: ‚Äú...that was when they truly merged, the song robust, men dancing again, with each other or with whores and by the third song the guitarist had emerged from the back room and joined back in and it was magic to blend sound with them like this, with strangers, and the sound they made was red red red and stripped of all the lies they told all day and night to survive these Americas, a naked sound that pulsed with everything they longed to be and never would become except like this, alone in a crowd, playing tango. They played for two more hours, during which the wounded violinist bled to death in the back room ...‚ÄùAn astonishing, enthralling, gripping story of a time and a main character whom the reader will understand, follow, dance with. Highest recommendation.

The unit comes with a power cord, CD with a setup wizard and users‚Äô guide, and a short LAN CAT-6 cable. (Users‚Äô guide also available as a PDF file at the trendnet.com website.) All very well, so far.The unit itself is about the size of a deck of playing cards and has a WPS button and a 10/100 LAN port. (10/100 Mbps LAN speed isn't a good sign if you want fast wireless speeds through an existing LAN system.) The unit ships with a printed tag showing the preset wireless settings (wi-fi name, wi-fi key, management log-in); this, unfortunately, is part of the plastic cling wrap and peels off the unit, so you should probably keep it with the CD or someplace else that‚Äôs safe.The CD itself will bring up a setup menu on your screen, with buttons. Unfortunately, clicking on the "Setup" button got this:‚ÄúError executing file.E:/SetupWizard/Setup.exeThe requested operation requires elevation.‚ÄùElevation? (I thought this was bad English but judging by other reviews, you really do need to put this thing up high). Anyway, using a file manager (Windows Explorer) I could go to that file on the CD and double-click the setup.exe file, and go through the routine. I did try this setup on two different older computers -- Vista and Windows 7, natural enough if you want to use this unit to upgrade an older home network, and I wanted to use this unit as a new wi-fi spot on the far side of the house, which has CAT-6 wiring in the walls and a TP-LINK wi-fi router already at a central location. I could get the TEW unit to join the LAN system and make a wireless connection to a laptop; the signal was stronger on that side of the house, as I had hoped. I could not get the WPS buttons to work, however, but could connect the laptop manually, entering the wi-fi key. Trouble was, the TEW also kept cutting out for reasons I'm still trying to discern -- one moment it's there, one moment it's gone.I'll keep working with this unit, but so far it's problematic. The dead link in the Setup wasn't a terribly good sign, either, suggesting that perhaps this product could have used more debugging or testing before it went on the market. (Yes, this is a free product under the Vine program, but it is costing in terms of time, frustration and effort trying to make it succeed). I'll add supplemental comments if I can make this thing work any better.ADDENDUM, Aug. 6, 2015: Spent three more hours today trying to make this product work, and, yes, I "elevated" it, and tested the wi-fi with the wi-fi laptop six inches away. Still no luck -- and the Setup display still locked up on two different laptops as before, in fact it wouldn't go away and I had to re-boot both, with a hard Windows restart (black screen, stark type) on both. I'm left wondering what's on the startup CD. I've had PCs for over 30 years and this was not "easy" even for me. Two stars. No hits, no runs, one error.

It's everything you need both to self-teach yourself how to use WordPress, but also, if you have your own website in mind, even if it's a clutter of words and images, you can use this book to construct your website as you self-teach. WordPress itself is open-source software -- that is, WordPress.com will provide a means of hosting your site with their software (continuously updated) or, instead, you can go to WordPress.org and download the that software (version 4.1, in this book). Either way, much of the hosting and software is free, easy to use, and well-known. WordPress is a platform where you can download and use plugins, themes, widgets -- and the book tells you what/how/whether to use them -- and more, often free as well. You'll learn both formats, though much of the book is directed to the simpler WordPress.com. If you're new to all this, you'll have no problem thanks to this book.The format is brightly visual, color-coded by chapter, and walks you through, step by step, in creating a website and selecting the components. The text is succinct, clear and helpful, and arranged in an easy-to-follow layout. Even the font is relatively large and easy on the eyes. In all, a very helpful, one-volume resource to create your own website using WordPress.

Website comments, ‚Äúlikes‚Äù, ratings and feedback are, as we see in this book, a major part of the internet‚Äôs social and economic fabric, not simply background chatter. It‚Äôs interesting that this review appears on Amazon, part of the Vine program, and is itself one subset that Mr. Reagle touches on. Major retailers like Amazon do include users‚Äô comments, and many sites are devoted to reviews and critiques, Goodreads, Yelp, Zagat ‚Äì rating different goods and services and in differing presentations.We also learn how the comments are a variable culture, with its trolls, bullying and misogyny, and a source of manipulation, of ratings, businesses and customers. We learn about the manipulators ‚Äì the ‚Äúfakers, makers and takers‚Äù ‚Äì in this area. It‚Äôs a lesson in Web sociology as well as consumer economics. It‚Äôs a detailed tour, but it‚Äôs a lively story at times, as the author brings up some of the controversies, conflicts ‚Äì and victims ‚Äì and puts them in context. We see how this culture can shape, shake and sometimes distort the internet. In all, it‚Äôs an important look at a new, vital and sometimes-troubling Internet subculture, and he keeps it within 185 pages. Highly recommend.

The chair comes in a large crate, but still needs assembly. The crate came with four major sub-packages with chair back, arms/pedestal/wheels, swivel base, chair seat, instructions and tools (two wrenches, one hex key, extra bolts/nuts) included. Packaging was somewhat crude, with sub-assemblies wrapped in cardboard and cellophane tape. Chair assembly took me about 40 minutes.I had some problems with the chair back assembly. The instructions weren't clear as to the back-adjustment piston positioning ‚Äì is the lever arm up or down, for example? Also, I found the back (tilt) adjustment stiff and unworkable, but found out ‚Äì by trial and error ‚Äì that careful rotation of the piston cylinder can stiffen or loosen the piston. (This was not in the instructions). Also, given the forces on the chair back hinge ‚Äì the two bolts where the seat and back join, and where the back pivots in adjustment ‚Äì users may want to put a washer on each bolt to save wear and tear. The chair probably needs more washers in any pivot points involving rotation and variable stress‚Äì chair back, back piston attachment points ‚Äì or some other fasteners.Once assembled, the chair seems comfortable, very much so, and the lumbar back support is a fine idea. The chair will adjust vertically and in back if the pneumatic cylinders are working; the arm rests and headrest also adjust vertically. In looks and ergonomics, it‚Äôs a fine chair. The straps mean that it would be cooler on a warm day.Once assembled, it's a good, comfortable chair. The looks are striking -- a little severe, or at least modernist, but if you're looking for comfort and functionality it's just fine. The manufacturer should re-think the packaging, and maybe ship it mostly- or fully-assembled ‚Äì the chair, with the base, arm rests and headrest detached, would have fit in the crate. At least the manufacturer should least ship it with more assembly, and with more washers.

Assembly is fairly simple, mainly clicking the arm assembly into the base, and connecting the power cord. The power block is a little bulky, may crowd other plug ins if it‚Äôs on a power strip, but you probably should have it on a power strip as it uses some energy (the red power button stays lit whether the lamp is on or off).The unit is good-looking, somewhat elegant in a tech-y way, and if folded in the vertical (closed) position, has a relatively small footprint on a desk or table. The light, in my experience, is warm when lit but not unduly so, and provides a good pattern of light but need not glare if positioned and set to the right light level (user has a choice of five). The upper arm, containing the light, feels metallic but seems to dissipate any heat, and gives the unit physical stability and solidity, esp. when folded, so it seems to be reasonably durable.Flexible positioning: Lower arm tilts 30 degrees forward from the vertical and 90 degrees back, and will rotate horizontally almost 180 degrees to either side. The upper arm can rest folded down against the lower to be compact when not in use, and can raise up 180 to full vertical; it also rotates laterally about 150 degrees to either side from its usual flat-downward angle. It can position within any of those four arcs and hold the position (although it gets a little tippy if it faces in some direction away from its base). This allows the user considerable flexibility in positioning the light, and the five light settings mean that the light need only be as bright as needed.In all, it‚Äôs a practical, good-looking, and economical light for desks, work tables or any work surface. Highly recommend.

It's a compelling story: how an American physician, Sumner Jackson, somehow stayed on in Nazi-occupied Paris, at his job at the American hospital, while he and his wife Toquette aided the Resistance and assisted downed Allied fliers -- and all this while living at No. 11, Avenue Foch, with their young son, on a block with Gestapo offices at No. 58, 72 and 84. It would be implausible as a spy thriller, but this story is real, and this author was able to interview key participants in this story. The story is certainly gripping, the author was able to convey the first-person feel of wartime Paris, and his characters -- Gestapo, Resistance, SS, the Jacksons themselves -- are vivid. That this family, enemy aliens after 1941, could continue their activity, with this level of exposure, with a child at risk as well, is breathtaking.
