The zombie books I normally read aren't what you'd expect. They're not the norm for zombies. I've never watched The Walking Dead. Basically, I'm the worst zombie fan in the traditional sense. This is why I was nervous about reading Shana Festa's Induction. I was afraid I was going to be a good audience for it. And I felt a bit intimidated by reading a traditional zombie novel.  But you know what? All of those worries were unfounded. I found myself lost in the pages of Induction quickly. Shana Festa is such a talented writer that I felt surrounded by her world within a few chapters. I was on the edge of my seat as I read this book. Festa was able to incite a very real feeling of fear when it comes to her take on a zombie apocalypse.  The inclusion of Daphne, Emma's beloved dog, was such a sweet touch. At times, I doubted Emma. She wasn't the easiest character to like. But her resolve and utter badassness redeemed her. The relationship she had with her dog solidified my like of her. She was rather fearless when it was needed. Her lack of mercy was a refreshing break that I enjoyed because it was absolutely warranted.  The one thing that always stood out to me was Shana Festa's ability to kill off a character in any way at any time. A lot of readers will enjoy this. It makes for a more edge of the seat, gripping read. But I think this is where reading predominately Young Adult literature has ruined me. I felt like the deaths sometimes overshadowed the rest of the story. The feeling of hope was missing and it stood out to me. But like I said, a lot of readers will enjoy the more realistic aspect.  Shana Festa definitely has something promising with the Time of Death series. With this debut, she has shown a strong handle of storytelling with a fluid grace. I will definitely be tuning in for the rest of this series. And if you're a zombie fan, you're missing out until you pick up Induction!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Wow, wow, WOW! This was the first book of Ruth Silver's that I've had the privilege of reading, and wow! I was blown away. The setting of Dead Girl Walking was so descriptive that I instantly felt enveloped by the world of Princess Ophelia Dacre.  The attention to detail didn't end with the setting. Each of the characters in Dead Girl Walking seemed so unique that I truly felt like I had met a new group of people. As the princess left behind her identity of Ophelia and submerses herself into a new life of Leila, the Grim Reaper, I felt like I was right there with her. The struggle with her new life and new responsibilities was showcased in a searingly honest way that allowed me to experience her resistance, too. For those of you who enjoy romance, there's definitely a budding connection in this book. But it isn't the focus of this story. I was so appreciative of that. It was enough romance to satiate my HEA-loving heart, but the focus of the book was on Leila and her journey.  I can promise you that this will not be my last read of Ruth Silver's works. Her talent is captivating, and I cannot wait for the next book in the Royal Reaper series to continue following Leila's adventures as a novice Grim Reaper. It can't come soon enough!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

We all know I struggle with New Adult. I was skeptical about Priya in Heels. As soon as I saw that Tyler was a musician, I prepared myself for disappoint. But Ayesha Patel surprised me entirely and delivered a clever book that I adored!  Not only did the author deliver on witty characters who stood out on their own and a slow-building romance that I supported so easily, she gave me a glimpse into the culture of India. I devoured the details of Priya's heritage right along with the budding romance. Ayesha Patel was able to weave a book as rich in detail and beautiful as the culture she focused on.  The characters in Priya in Heels were so enjoyable and diverse. Priya's friends often had me laughing at their antics. As for Priya and Tyler, I was sold and swooning from the very start. The romance wasn't heavy handed or dark like I've sadly come to expect with New Adult. It was light and charming in the best of ways.  If you're a fan of Big Bang Theory or Penny Reid, then you'll find a new favorite with Priya in Heels. It's a smart romance filled to the brim with enjoyable characters and endearing love.**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Shay West continues an action-packed adventure with Twisted Reflections. This book is a perfect follow-up to Dangerous Reflections. It picks up in the perfect spot and launches the reader right back into the complicated world of Alexis Davenport.  Even more so than the first book in the series, I could really tell how much Alex has evolved as a character. Shay West does a fantastic job with character development, and Twisted Reflections is a testament to that. A lot of new elements are introduced into her life, and the lapse between time traveling gives the reader a perfect chance to experience how Alex handles her extraordinary life.  The ending was very fitting, and I cannot wait to continue this amazing series. Shay West has outdone herself with Twisted Reflections, and I cannot wait to watch her grow even more as a writer.**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

I'll admit right from the beginning that mermaids aren't my thing. They always remind me of Ariel, and I'm not the biggest fan of Disney movies. (I've never really watched them. For shame.) But the way that Tiana Warner writes them, I'm a fan y'all! Gone are the fairy tales. I really enjoyed the angle that the author portrayed mermaids.  Meela was a strong main character. I feel like Tiana Warner was really able to capture her voice and make Meela seem so real and authentic. Even though she was fierce, Meela had her moments like the rest of us. What I didn't like was the drawn out back story. I'm always weary of information dumps, but I don't think that's what the author intended. I just think that less would have been more with such a drawn out glimpse into the past.  Tiana Warner is such a talented writer. I think with time, she'll only get better and better. While mermaids aren't my thing, I was still easily swept up into the world of Meela. If you're looking for Ariel, I don't think Ice Massacre is for you. But if you love a good and gritty fantasy, then you'll enjoy this epic tome.**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

The action packed into the pages of Rogue puts you on the edge of your seat! I was swept away by the dystopian style setting and action surrounding it. Chelsie Shock does not skimp on details and a solid back story which makes this a very immersive and enjoyable read.  At times, I felt the pace of the story drag. But overall, the dynamic of the world and how the characters related to each other spurred my interest and pushed me on. There is even a sprinkling of romance in there for those of you who love to swoon!  The premise of Rogue was definitely interesting. It wasn't too far fetched, and those books are the ones that terrify me! If I walk away from a book realizing that it could actually happen, you better believe I'll lose sleep over it. To me, that shows just how amazing the author is and Chelsie Shock and Rogue definitely fall into that category!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Love triangles and cheating are my biggest turn-off in books. No One Needs to Know had a lot stacked against it before I even turned to the first page. But I was completely shocked and proven absolutely wrong. Love triangles can work whenever authors handle them with finesse like Amanda Grace did. I was absolutely blown away by this book. I loved it!  The book switches back and forth between Olivia and Zoey. I daresay if Liam's point of view had been used, I'd be less enthusiastic because of the circumstances. But I really grew close to the characters of Olivia and Zoey. I was skeptical about Olivia at first. It seemed like she was going to be a tangle of stereotypes, but like the rest of this book, she surprised me. It was really easy to root for Olivia and the relationship forming between her and Zoey.  No One Needs to Know was a pleasant surprise. I wasn't ready to let go whenever I finished this book. It's definitely one that I could see myself reading over and over again. I'm positive that fans of YA LGBT novels will fall in love with Olivia and Zoey's story!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Whoa. Sadie the Sadist is just as humorous as it is depraved and horrifying. I went from laughing uncontrollably to cringing and wishing for mind bleach while reading this one. It only took one sitting for me to finish this book, though.  There is plenty of gore to go around with Sadie the Sadist, but I didn't mind it. I was genuinely intrigued in seeing the world through Sadie's point of view as her sanity rapidly deteriorated before my eyes. This book is nothing like what I'd normally read, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. If you have a strong stomach and can handle unbridled depravity, then you'll definitely enjoy Sadie the Sadist.**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Predator & Prey? Yes, please! This novella is very short, coming in around 30 pages. The punch that James D. Horton packs into those pages is phenomenal, though! This story came to a close way too early for me. I enjoyed every element of it, and I can't wait to spend more time with Lily and Wolf.  Lily is my kind of heroine. She radiated determination and grit. I wish more heroines were written like her! I really enjoyed Wolf, too. I chuckled at his ironic name. The relationship between the two really works out well. Intensity, of the good kind, is one of the adjectives I'd use for them!  Like I said, this book is on the shorter side. But I am still amazed at how quickly I was drawn into it. You just simply cannot go wrong with reading about Lily and Wolf. I know the second book in the series is going on my TBR pile!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

I think that I'm one of the few that love the idea of serials. I'm not ashamed to admit that I gravitate towards shorter books. If an author can pack a punch into a shorter story, then count me in. And that's exactly what A.J. Bennett has done with Hired Gun. It sets the tone as an amazing series opener. By the time I was finished, I was on the edge of my seat wanting more.  The way that the author introduces Thorne and his background definitely captured my interest from the start. I felt like he was introduced perfectly in relation to the story. Even though this was a serial, Bennett capitalized on really fleshing out her characters and making them believable and intriguing.  Hired Gun sets the stage for the next book in the series so well. The ending caught me off guard, because it ends so abruptly. But I feel like I can see where the next book is going. The suspense is going to kill me until I can get my hands on the next book in this steamy and explosive series!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Eh. That really sums up my feelings about Feuds. It wasn't bad. It just didn't keep my attention or interest. A lot of the time I spent reading this, it felt like a chore. I'd glance over at the stack of books on my nightstand and wish that I could read something else. What I thought I was getting was going to be a dystopian with a beautiful cover. What I feel like I got was a tease of dystopian with a heavy helping of romance and a deceptively beautiful cover.  The potential was there. It was begging to crawl out from behind the insta-love. I think that's why this book was so eh for me. I'm really into dystopians. I will devour them like no other. And while there's a great premise to Feuds, it's never elaborated on. There's hardly any world building. There isn't even much character building. It's just a big ol' pot of 'here's some insta-love, so let's just ignore everything else'. Nothankyounope.  Sometimes I feel like Young Adult feels like it has to delve out insta-love. But the readers of Young Adult fiction aren't five year olds who watch Disney movies and expect a perfect Prince Charming and a happily ever after. Sure, a happily ever after is nice. But we don't need a perfect set of coincidences to get there. We want something that seems real. Something that we can relate to.  All in all, I won't be tuning in for another book in this series. As much as I want to know about the society that this story is set in and Davis' past, I just can't sit through more declarations of lust thinly veiled as love. The characters grated on my nerves because of the insta-love. There was simply nothing to redeem this book for me whenever I got to the end. It was just a lot of potential that was overshadowed and ignored.**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

Before I even begin this review, I want to dismiss all of the talk of The Fault in Our Stars and Zac and Mia being so alike. They're two very different stories. Yes, cancer is an integral part of the story in both of these books. But the similarities beyond that are so slim. Over and over, I heard that Zac and Mia was the new The Fault in Our Stars (mind you, Zac and Mia was written and published first). It gave me a lot of expectations going into reading Zac and Mia and I really wish I wouldn't have had those.  A.J. Betts deserves a standing ovation. She was able to take something very sensitive and build a beautiful story injected with humor and a wide range of emotions with Zac and Mia. At certain times, this book would be sobering for me as I sped through it. Other times, I'd find myself laughing at Zac's wit or his mother's antics. This is a book that's about more than cancer. Don't get me wrong: cancer is a huge part of it. But this book isn't wholly consumed with only being about cancer. There's so much depth to it.  I hate to admit it, but I really loathed the character of Mia. She deserved empathy from me, I know. She faced an impossible situation, and I don't think I would handle it much better. But I'm a sucker for characters being strong and overcoming obstacles. I felt like Mia just succumbed to her fate. The entire time I was reading this book, I wanted to throw her some boxing gloves and tell her to fight.  Zac, on the other hand, was the highlight of this book for me. It's rare that we get a male character in Young Adult that we get see the world through their eyes. With the way that A.J. Betts wrote Zac, I wish we had that privilege more. There was plenty of wit and reflection weaved throughout his story that perfectly balanced the matter at hand. I missed him whenever I finished reading this book. In fact, I missed his entire family.  If you're a fan of young adult who enjoys a good contemporary, then please pick up Zac and Mia. It has a hint of romance, but the story is so much more than that. Just do yourself a favor and go in with an open mind. You just might find your next favorite book!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.

There is so much packed into the pages of this book! I didn't read the first book in this series, yet I did not struggle to get into the story. Alexis Hall is a master at inviting you into her world. There are a multitude of things happening in this book. Not  once did I get confused, though. It was a very easy and enjoyable read for me.  Absolutely amazing is all I can say about Shadows and Dreams. I could gush about this book. Really, you should read it if you love urban fantasy served with a side of sass. Now excuse me while I go track down the first book in this series!**I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review with no compensation.
I just love this coffee mug! The lid has a large rubber seal on it so it just presses into the top of the mug so there isn't any threads to line up to screw it on.

Nice little scale. It calls for a 500gram weight to calibrate the scale but it doesn't come with one. If it came with one then I'd give it 5 stars. A nickel weighs almost exactly 5 grams so I just use one of those instead.

My first ear stud was a tiger eye mounted in a gold stud. That was back in 1978 and the gold plating has long since worn off. I've been looking for a replacement for a long time. I've tried ones that are silver like this one but they all had shafts or pins that were so short that with the back on it it irritated my ear lobe too much to comfortably wear it.Now these have a nice long pin or shaft on them and the little grove for the back to stay on without pinching my earlobe. And it looks good too. So these will do until I can find some that are gold instead of silver. If you like the Tiger Eye stones then you should like these.

I have one of these that is 11 inches tall and has 7 ball's in it. It looks great so I bought this one to give to my sister for Christmas. When she opened it she loved it. I liked this one so much I almost kept it and gave my smaller one to my sister. Now I have to find something for next year for my sister.

I have one of the first Kindles and the first Kindle Fire's. The main thing I didn't like about them is they don't have a slot for a SD card slot or a micro SD card. That's why I bought this tablet. This Lenovo 8 inch tablet with its 16GB of memory & a slot for a micro SD card is way better than my kindle fire and cost about half as much. With a 32GB micro SD card I can have my entire music collection in it and all my Kindle books and still have over half the memory available. The Lenovo has better sound, and with the 8 inch screen its a lot easier to use than my kindle fire and is lighter, faster, and thinner than my kindle fire.I spent a lot of time looking for a tablet and I'm very happy with the Lenovo. So if you are looking for a good tablet for a good price I have no problem recommending this Lenovo 8 inch 16GB tablet.

On the plus side this vacuum does have plenty of power. On the negative side it's pretty big around and with the caster's on it stick out far enough to be a tripping hazard. If you have a small shop like I do floor space is a bit limited and this vacuum has a large foot print. There's one other problem with it. It doesn't come with a full set of the usual tools that normally comes with a shop vacuum. It only has two floor tools with the hose and two wand's. There's no round brush or a crevice tool. That little round brush head is the one I use the most to clean up the fine sawdust that gets on every thing when sanding a wood project. I couldn't find just a brush tool for it and I ended up buying a whole set of vacuum tools for it just to get the round one I needed. And like most workshop vacuum's this one makes a lot of noise too.For my needs in my shop this vacuum doesn't do the job very well. I think I'll stick with my ShopVac since its a lot smaller around and takes up less floor space. If you have a large shop with a lot of space then this one would probably work well for you.

I've almost always loved Dawn and I've used it for years, since back in the 1980's. There was a while that they had changed something in its formula that caused my hands to break out with some sort of a allergic reaction but after a few years, and a few emails to them to tell them about it, they changed what ever it was and it quit making my hands break out. This has always been a good dish soap and has been great at cutting grease and getting greasy dishes, pots, and frying pans nice and clean. Even though I use my auto dishwasher to wash most of my dishes I still have to do some of the worst ones by hand and this dish soap has no problem getting even the worst ones clean. I have sensitive skin and cant use just any dish soap and out of all of the ones out there, this is hands down the best for sensitive skin.

These are quite a bit smaller than what they say they are. I wear a size 11.5 to a size 12. When I got these they looked to be about a size 6. I couldn't even begin to get them on my feet. I am a pretty big guy at 6'-4" tall and about 240 pounds. But from what it said about these socks I figured that a size large should fit me, if at the largest limit of that size. But they are so small that even after trying to stretch them out as much as I could I still couldn't even begin to get my foot in them. So if you have a size 11 or larger foot forget about thinking that these might fit you. The big bummer about these is that I really needed some good compression high top socks to help reduce the swelling of my feet and lower legs.  I've given them a 2 star rating even though I couldn't actually wear them. I figured I'd give them a bit of a break so that those that they actually do fit can give them the average rating that they deserve.

I bought a .22 Ruger semi-auto pistol way back in 1979 at the local Coast to Coast store. It was $125.00 and was the very first gun, and a hand gun at that, that I bought. I didn't get any kind of manual with it or anything showing &/or telling how to strip it down and clean it. So when I saw this book available on the very first gun I ever bought, I jumped on it! Well, I should've read more of the listing about the book and what it is about. It turns out that it's pretty much a history about the Ruger .22 Semi-Auto pistol and NOT anything about field stripping it, or taking it apart to clean it, or aftermarket parts to overhaul one of the older .22 models like the one I have.  Now this is an interesting book on the history of the Ruger .22 hand gun. But for a book explaining how to take apart and put back together one of the Ruger .22 Semi-Automatic Pistol's, this is pretty much a flop. If you want a history book on Ruger hand guns then you might find this one interesting. But if you are looking for a book on how to field strip a Ruger .22 Semi-Automatic Pistol, this isn't what you want.

I have a "Smart Phone" that I bought, new, a year ago at Radio Shack. So maybe the thing is to far outdated by now, I don't know. First of all this QUICKLINK OBD2 Wireless Tool did not come with much of anything for instructions on how to use it, or what to expect to get out of it.  First of all the thing did plug into my 2002 Nissan Pathfinder SE diagnostic plug under the dash with no problem. I did find out that I had to get an app for the Quicklink downloaded and installed in my cell phone. This information about needing the app was NOT in any of the information in the package that the QUICKLINK thing came in. Although there are instructions in the packet that the Quicklink came in but they are in at least 4, or more, different languages, other than English. There are some basic instructions in English but there's nothing telling how to use the Quicklink thing. I spent 2 days messing with the thing trying to get any information out of it about my Pathfinder. After several hours wasted over 2 days of trying to get this thing to work I finally gave it up as a bad idea.  Overall, I'm just happy that I have a very nice diagnostic code reader to check all available computer diagnostics in my 2002 Pathfinder, and this one ain't it. This is due to my habit of every time I buy a used car the first thing I do is get the Dealership Shop Manual for it, if possible. If that is not possible, then I get the best available shop manual for it and any diagnostic code reader that is available for it. I've found that in the long run, as in if I plan on keeping the vehicle for a long time, this is the best investment for it that I can make.  I really hate to say this, but, I suggest that you NOT invest your money on this thing. There are better and cheaper ways to get the self diagnostic codes from a vehicle without having to waste a lot of your hard earned cash on something like this QUICKLINK Wireless tool.  When you are having problems with a vehicle the first thing is, is it newer than 2000? They changed the way to get the cars self diagnostic codes on a lot of cars around 2000 to 2003. A lot of cars from the late 1980's to 1999 can do a self diagnostic that the garage or dealership will charge you around $100 or more for. All you need is the Chilton's book for your car and do a little trick with the ignition switch. Simply turn the key over to on, (not start like trying to start the car) then off, do it 3 times then turn the key to on, and leave it there. Now one of the dash red lights will start flashing. All you need to do is count the flashing. It will do the codes in sets. Like a code 23, it will blink 2 times, short pause, blink 3 times, then a little longer pause, then it will flash the next code. When its done it will give 5 flashes, then another 5 flashes. A code 55, that means that's all the codes. Doing this will tell you if you have a Oxygen Sensor that's burned out or not working right, it will tell you if the sensor in the exhaust is working right. This will tell you the same things that the computer at the auto shop will tell them when they hook your car up to it and charge you around a $100 for. Now this is where you need the Chilton's book on your car or you can look up the diagnostic codes online.  My father had a 1986 Chrysler Newyorker  and it had problems with the O2 sensors and the Speed sensor. The dealership wanted a couple hundred bucks just to look at it. I got the Chilton's book for $19 and the 3 sensors for it all for under $100 and it took me about 30 minutes to replace the sensors and it was running fine. The dealership would have charged well over $500 to do the same thing.  Any who, I messed with this QUICKLINK thing for several hours and I never did get it to work or give me any information, useful or otherwise. I have other vehicles but my 2002 Nissan Pathfinder is the only one I have that it will plug into. Maybe you will have better luck with it, but in my opinion it's a waste of money to buy it and a waste of time to try and use it.

Ended up settling for this one after problems with 3 others from local store. Figured it would be alright since Westinghouse used to be a good quality brand. First thing the clock was a spazz. Set the date & time, turn it off and back on and not only would the time be wrong but the date would change. Every time I turned it on the date would be anywhere from a couple weeks off to several years ahead or behind. I figured Oh well, I have plenty of other clocks and it doesn't matter if it has one or not since the picture was good. And it did have a great picture! Just before I bought this one a friend had got a 42" Vizio and tried talking me into getting one. But comparing his Vizio to this Westinghouse, this one had a far better picture. His Vizio was like watching TV through a screen door compared to this Westinghouse. I was pretty happy with it. It could have a couple more HDMI plugins on it and the speakers could be a little better. And for the price it should have WiFi built into it. But it wasn't too bad of a TV. Until a couple days ago.The drain for my kitchen sink got hopelessly clogged the other day and I was working on that while the TV was on. Then I noticed the sound quit. Turned around and looked at it and it was turned off. I thought. Now the thing wont turn on. I unplugged the power converter from the surge-protector power strip and plugged it in a different wall outlet. Still wouldn't turn on. Took the power converter out to my workshop and tested it with my electrical tester and it was putting out the voltage that the sticker on it says its supposed to put out. So there's nothing wrong with the power converter. I've emailed Westinghouse customer service, 3 days ago. I got a confirmation email from them that they received my email but haven't had any other contact from them. So tomorrow I'll start the game of Phone Tag with the automated phone system and see if I can talk to an actual person and find out if this thing has a reset button somewhere or a little fuse somewhere that can be replaced. Usually that's all is need when something like this just shuts off and wont turn on. Unfortunately I cant find the extended warranty I think I bought for it. By my receipt its 6 months past its Westinghouse warranty. Any which way I look at it I'm screwed out of $584 bucks I paid for it. 18 months of use just ain't worth that much. That comes out to just over $32 a month to have it. I ain't going to say what the cable company is screwing me for. But for $32 a month I may as well of had one of the rent to own things. Then it wouldn't cost me anything to replace it.So, if you already have one of these, good luck. Maybe you will have one that will last for years. I just wish I could have read some of these before I settled for this one because it sure didn't turn out to be worth what I paid for it. Specially since I had saved up my money for 2 years to buy the stupid thing. Being on SS disability what I paid for it is over half of months income for me.

This printer was made to waste ink on purpose. Even if you seldom use it to conserve on ink, it was made to deliberately waste even more ink than usual before it runs each printing job. Here's the HP link to how it uses its ink;[...]That link is from the HP Customer Support where I posted the question of why it uses the photo black ink for plain text printing when it has a full X-Large Black cartridge for text printing. All I got was the run around from them and never did get a strait answer.This printer is made to waste ink before each printing job by doing a head cleaning cycle each time its used. I seldom needed something printed and I've never printed photo's with mine other than when I first set it up I did a test print of a photo. But yet after about 2 months it was out of photo black ink and color ink even though I hadn't printed anything in color. So I put a new set of cartridges in it and notice that the X-Large Black cartridge was still full. 2 months later and maybe half a dozen pages of black text printed, mostly shipping labels, and its out of color ink & photo black ink again. Oh, and it will not print anything when it thinks its out of photo black & color ink. Even with a full X-Large Black cartridge in it. For the few pages printed and the amount spent for ink to print them it cost about $5 to $10 a page. If I used it to print dollar bills that would work in a change machine I would be loosing money.This thing was deliberately designed to be a inkoholic and isn't very good at printing either. Stay away from this printer unless you want to waste a LOT of money for ink that you don't use. This has to be the worst printer I've ever seen or used.I hate to say it but, I've gone back to using an Epson printer. It's slower but at least I DON'T have to feed it a new full set of ink cartridges every couple of months when I haven't even used it.

This is a really cool case for anybody that is a hunter. Its easy to put on the phone and doesn't block any of the plugins or buttons, and all of them are still easy to get to. It even helps to protect the camera lens by being raised higher around it. I really like that part since I use the camera a lot and want to keep its lens protected as much as possible.The one thing that really sucks is the screen protector that came with it. As usual with these I got a bunch of air bubbles under it once I got it stuck on the screen. What sucks is how easy the screen protector is to scratch. After I got it stuck to the screen and when I was using the little card that came with it to work the bubbles out from under it, before I new it it had put several long deep scratches in the screen protector! Now that's not much of a screen protector when the little stiff paper card that they send with it to use to get the air bubbles out from under it actually ruins the screen protector by putting big scratches in it! It's brand new just installed and looks like its been with a kid dragging it around for a year. It's definitely the worst excuse for a screen protector I've ever tried. And I've tried several over the last couple of years.As for the little stylus that came with it, it doesn't work very well either. It's a couple of times bigger than what's really usable for this phone. And it takes a lot of pressure to get it to work. This is my first cell phone and I just got it a couple months ago. So there might be a setting somewhere to make the screen more sensitive to touch but if there is I cant find it. So this little stylus is pretty much useless.The little guitar pick looking thing is kinda cool. But don't use it on the screen protector. I think its only for opening the case to remove it from the phone. But then just about anything thin, flat, and stiff will work for that.Overall, the case is great looking and I love it. The extra's that come with it, not so hot. So for the case I give it 5 stars, I dropped a couple for the worthless extra's that came with it. Like that poor excuse of a screen protector. And usually those come in sets of 3 because you almost always ruin the first one just trying to get it on the screen strait. The ones I got for my Kindle all came in sets of 3 any who. They only give you one so if you don't get it on right the first time,,, too bad.

I got a couple of these to use on some 30 round magazines for my new Ruger Mini-14 .223. The magazines are by TAPCO INTRAFUSE. They are made from some sort of molded polymer and are very nice magazines for the price. But this loader does not work with it. It also will not work with the Ruger factory made 5 round magazines that came with my Mini-14 .223. I don't have a 10 round mag or a metal mag for over 5 rounds to try it with so it might work with one of those.Since these will not work with the 30 round mags I have, these loaders are going back.

I just got a 16 foot boat with a 50 hp motor and needed something like this to put on the battery in it. So this came along just in time. I also have a 4x4 Scout I use just during hunting season and once I got the batter charged back up in it this has helped to keep it full charge. Now I need to get another one so I can have one in the boat and one on my Scout.It's real easy to use and even though its not a charger, just as an experiment I put it on the 12volt battery out of my Scout when it was real low on charge. After 24 hr's this had it back up to full charge giving it a good slow deep charge. It should be good for a couple of months since its only 2 years old and is a 60 month battery. After hunting season is over I'm going to take the battery out of my Scout and out of the boat and put them in my workshop so I can switch the charger back and forth every few days to keep a good charge in the batteries.I'm going to have to get another one now since it does so good.

I've always liked the quiet of hand sanding with some music going to get in the writhem of the music lets me put my hands on auto pilot while I'm thinking about something else. When I need dust collection and want to put up with the noise I have several electric palm sanders that have their own dust collection bag and don't need the shop vac going all the time. With this the vac hose is always flopping around and in the way and then the noise of the shop vac going all the time, Ugh, not fun no more. I would rather just leave the hose off and use it as a plain sanding block. Now if I had a quiet shop vac to connect it to, then maybe it would be more fun to use.

My one favorite point on these is only one wire to tie the two together. That's if you are using them with the Bluetooth. I can now play all the music that I have stored on the chip in my phone without having to plug it into the speakers. Now I might have been doing something wrong but I needed to have the speakers plugged into each other to play in stereo. Ideally, with using the Bluetooth I shouldn't need any wires at all to play my music over both of them in stereo. But, maybe I was doing something wrong cuz I had to have a 6' jumper cord to plug into the typical speaker jack on each speaker to get both of them to play.  As for sound quality. About what I expected from such little bitty speakers. As in, not much for volume. What sound that they can put out isn't too bad. But they are weak on the amount of volume. Even with them plugged into my laptop for more power they still don't get the volume quite up there. And when it does get close they start getting into that static realm along with bad sound distortion. Now I'm a retired machinist with over 25 years running extremely noisy machines and I've gone target shooting with everything from .22cal pistol & rifles, 9mm pistol, .22Mag 20Gage over under, 7mmX57mm Mauser, and a Chine's SKS 7.62mmX39mm. Plus I shot competition on my local High School ROTC Rifle team for 4 years shooting in a indoor range. my point is that I have a lot of hearing loss. Especially up in the higher ranges. So just because I cant hear these speakers as well as I think I should, it doesn't mean that nobody else will either. But, the sound distortion that I could hear at max and close to max volume was still there in spite of my poor hearing or damaged hearing.  Overall, do I think that these speakers are really worth the $57.59 price tag they have put on them? NO. They have a little American Flag on the bottom of the packaging they came in and it says "Designed and Engineered in the U.S.A."Below that it says; Concu (or Conqu) Fabrique aux U.S.A.  MADE IN CHINA  FABRIQE EN CHINAThe upchuck of all that is that these little speakers were designed here in the states. But they gave the job of making them to the Chine's. We need the work right here in our own country so why was the manufacturing job given to China? I work many years in manufacturing and there is no excuse for not having items like this made by our own people. Lets try to keep American Made to mean something. Today it means about as much as something Made in Japan did back in the 1950's and Made in China does today. As in "this is junk".

Just got my set of these today and tested it out. First thing the directions that are inside the lid tell you to calibrate it. Tells you how to turn it on for calibration then you are supposed to put a 500.0g weight on it. Well, I doubt there's very many people any where, and especially in the States that would happen to have something that weighs exactly 500.0g.  That's 500 grams. Or half a Kilo, right? So the only way I had to check it is with the old stoners trick of weighing a nickle. A nickle weighs a nickle, or just slightly under. So any time you need to check a set of light scales, put a nickle or 2 on it. Each one should be 5grams or a touch under. Like 4.9grams if its an old one about worn out or a lot of it worn off.  Any who, calibration of this may get to be a problem since it is set for auto calibration only with a 500 Gram benchmark weight. I have some test weights but the largest I have is only 25 grams. But it does pass the nickle test so as long as you don't want to use it for something very precise like I was going to use it. And that's to weight out gun powder for making my own reloads. For the price on it I should have figured it would be about this accurate.  For things like Weight Watchers, or as my dad and I called it when mom went to them "Fat lookers" these scales should replace the cheap spring type scale that my mother always had to use.  As for using this for mail, I don't know. Small packages it should work for those with no problem. Light weight letters, I doubt it. But still for the price, you cant beat these unless you need fractions of a gram to be accurately. For that I suggest a nice set of balance beams scales. I have a nice set from Harbor Freight. They are made of brass and supposed to be something of a novelty, but they work great. And are still a very cool novelty.

About the only good point on this is the light. It is fairly bright, not sure how long it will last but it is bright to start with.The cork screw is kinda cute, but too small to actually be considered usable. As for the rest of it, it got ruined by being over polished. The screw driver points are now useless since the sharp edges that they need have been polished off so that they are rounded over making them useless. What good is a flat screwdriver or Philips head driver that is already worn out? The knife blade is pretty dull but I like sharpening knives any who. About the only thing besides the light that is actually usable is the bottle opener. But even on it the hook part that you use on the rim of a bottle cap has been rounded off almost too much to still be usable.I was a precision machinist for over 20 yrs. and one of shops I worked in we made small hand tools. Who ever did the polishing on the pieces for this must have been stoned or on some drug of some sort cuz they have been rounded off way more than needed. Any who, I've seen small multi-tools that were a lot better and a few that were a lot worse. As it is the only thing practical and usable on this is the light. So I suggest finding a better one to spend your money on.

I usually like granola bars with the chocolate chunks. But this one was yuck. First, when I opened it, it looked like it had been stomped on or ran over or something. It was mashed flat and spread out and started falling apart. As for taste it had a weird off after taste to it and the texture was real gritty like it had dirt in it or something. Between the weird aftertaste and gritty texture it wasn't very appetizing. Not something that I will be looking for more of.

I've had several toaster ovens over the years. A few years back I got frustrated with trying to find one that actually worked like it was supposed to and made it a personal quest to find that perfect toaster/convection counter top oven. This one is in the smaller range that I didn't do much searching through since I was looking for one to take the place of my broken oven in my gas stove.As a basic, small toaster oven this is a pretty good one. It has a expanded back so that it can bake a small pizza up to 8" dia. It has simple controls. One knob that you turn to set the temp that you want and a second knob to set the timer. That's it. No digital temp controls, no multiple functions to select one from. It preheats in just a minute or two so it's quick and easy to use and doesn't use a lot of electricity.My Oster Convection Toaster Oven is about twice the size of this one and is the one that I chose after test driving 7 or 8 different ones 2 or 3 years ago. There are a few things that this smaller one is more suitable to use instead of the bigger one so the two complement each other. And now I hardly use my microwave for anything other than re heating my cup of coffee.Just one thing to remember. This is a toaster OVEN. So don't expect it to toast your Bagels by just sticking them in it, turning it on to Toast, and go off to another room doing something else and expect your Bagels to toast and NOT get BURNED. That's why a normal toaster pops the toast up after its finished the toast cycle. So you have to watch this as it toasts what ever it is that you are toasting. So that you can remove it as soon as it is toasted to that perfect color that you like. I just mention this because in my research of toaster ovens I found that several people had wrote negative reviews on several toaster ovens because they almost burned their kitchen down when they went off doing something else after putting their Bagels in it to toast them. And of course, since they were not there to remove them when they were done, after the toaster oven turned off the Bagels continued to sit in the hot oven and started to burn. So they blamed the toaster oven instead of themselves for not paying attention to it. I'm pretty sure that in the directions on these things that it tells you in one way or another, do not leave it unattended.One other thing for those that are concerned about it. This one does have a grounded plugin on it. The cord is nice and heavy, if a little on the short side. Most of the toaster ovens that I've tried in the last several years have the polarized plugin. So if you have a older home that doesn't have grounded outlets in the kitchen you might want to look for another one or order a plugin adapter while you are ordering this.So if you are looking for a basic, simple, small toaster oven, this will probably fill that need. If you are looking for something to actually replace using your big oven in your stove for most of those smaller baking jobs then you probably wouldn't be happy with this. For that I would suggest the;Oster TSSTTVMNDG Digital Large Capacity Toaster Oven, Black/Polished Stainless AccentsAfter I did my research on these a few years ago that was the one I decided was the keeper and I'm still happy with it.

At first it looks like a good idea. In practice it ain't so great. Cheap plastic fittings on the ends that leaked from the first time I tried to use it. It's pointless to try to use for watering your yard since it is only at its full length when it has pressure in it. So the only thing its good for is watering while holding it or for washing your car. And that's only for as long as the fittings hold up, which isn't very long. It's definitely not worth the $49.95 they are charging for it. After using it I wouldn't pay $2.00 for one.

This is a nice cute little set of Mortars & Pestles. There's just one thing about these that I really don't like. And that is the rough surface on the ends of the Pestles and on the inside bottom of the of the Mortars. They are very rough and feeling them is like dragging my fingernails across a really rough chalk board. To use one and actually rub the end of the pestle across the bottom of the Mortar just sets my nerves on fire and makes them try to go crawling off somewhere on their own. Just thinking about using one of these gives me what me mum would call a bad case of the shidders. I got out my air powered high speed angle grinder and used a special sanding disc made for extremely hard metals that I figured would work on ceramics and used it to smooth down that rough surface on them. I got most of the worst of it smoothed down a little bit but just lightly rubbing the end of the pestle in the bottom of the mortar is still like dragging my fingernails across a genuine slate chalk board. Gives me the shidders just thinking about it! I cant even pick one of them up now without my skin wanting to crawl off someplace and hide. ;-)So if fingernails dragged across a chalk board sets your nerves crawling you probably wouldn't like trying to use one of these. Now if things like that don't bother you then you would probably like this set. Now if I can get the bottom inside the Mortar smoothed down a little more then I'll be able to use them, I hope.The rough finish on the inside bottom of the Mortar and on the end of the Pestle is the reason that I gave these a 3 star rating. I suppose they made them this way to help them be able to crush things to a powder easier. Any who, if the fingernails on a chalk board thing bothers you, you might want to try a set of glass ones instead of the ceramic. I wish I had ordered the glass one instead too. If I cant get at least one set of these polished down and get rid of the rough then I'm ordering a glass one.

I just got mine day before yesterday and have only had a little time to try it but that's all I needed to see just how much this thing can suck up! It has way more, several times more sucking power than my 1.5hp ShopVac and makes only a fraction of the noise the old shop vac does. Besides its super sucking power I cant believe how quiet it is! I was hoping to find one that wasn't as noisy as my old shop vac but have a lot more suction power and this is it. The first time I turned this on I had my TV on at normal volume and I expected not to be able to hear anything else but the vacuum. Surprise! I could still hear the TV and understand what they were saying without any problem at all!As for sucking power, this thing is like, WOW! I bet it could suckup and hold a bowling ball with the end of the hose. I'm a bachelor with a strong aversion to house cleaning. Add to that a bad lower back and a neck injury that makes doing anything quite painful. So needless to say, but I will any who, my place is a little more than say,, a disaster area. It would just about take a tornado to clean it up. With that in mind this vac is just what I needed. It's light weight and has such sucking power I only have to go across an area a couple of times for it to suck up rocks, sand, dirt, goat heads, stickers, and everything else that has built up over the years. My old shop vac couldn't suck up the same stuff this one did in a minute, even if I run my old one across the same area all day.My only complaint about this one is the wands that came with it. They are so flimsy! Granted, they are light weight, but they are also very crooked. When I stuck them together with the bow in each one going the opposite of the other it almost looks like a snake crawling across the floor. With the bow in each one turned the same way it makes a nice rainbow shape. Maybe not a complete rainbow, but enough to be very notice able. It would really  help if they had a little larger inside diameter and a little thicker wall so that there was more to them. Also if they had a larger ID it wouldn't restrict the suction power like the ones it has does. But, other shop vac tubes that are stronger, longer, and don't have a bow in them, will fit and work with it's hose.I have a pretty good upright vac but the beater bar in the head of it likes to catch on a string in the carpet and unravel it wrapping it around the bar in the process. It does pretty good in large open area's, which I don't have cuz of too much stuff. And even though it has a hose and attachments, when using the hose the beater head keeps running and it makes all sorts of noise.  I'm so glad that I decided to give this one a try! It has so much sucking power and is so quiet I can hardly believe it. I've never in my life seen or used such a strong vacuum that is so quiet! It probably even has enough suction power to run one of those small roller brush heads that work off of the air flow. Even if it doesn't it still has enough suck power to pull up all but the deepest dirt in the carpet. I highly recommend this vacuum for anybody looking for a new one. You might want to pick up a set of stronger & longer wands or tubes for the hose but it still does pretty good with the ones that come with it. This has to be the best vacuum anywhere for under $100. Besides, if you don't like it you can always send it back. But I'd bet that after you try it you wouldn't let anybody take it away from you for anything.So if you are looking for a good deal on a great vacuum you should give this one a shot. I bet you will be very happy with it.There's one other little thing and that's the bags for it. They are a bit expensive and a little hard to find other than on Amazon. So after using the one that came with it I'm going to try one of the blue wrap around paper filters that I use with my old shop vac. It doesn't have the plastic ring to hold it on but a good sized rubber band or small bungee cord should hold it on over the paper filter inside it.

I've had a bad back for over 30 years and I've almost always needed something behind my lower back when driving. I recently got a Nissan Pathfinder that has an adjustable lumbar support built into the seats back but its about 2 to 3 inches too high for me and for where I need the support. I was hoping that this would be just right for what I need but its not quite right. It's too firm and too thick to really be comfortable. Now if it had an air bladder in it so that it could be inflated making it larger and firmer or soft and small would make it a lot better and work for more people. Depending on what kind and how much support you need for you lower back you might be able to use this.The best part about it is you can belt it around yourself or around the back of your seat or chair to help keep it in place.

This worked Ok with my Kindle Fire, but I'm not really crazy about it. It definitely isn't worth close to $20 for it. If I was to buy this in a store I wouldn't pay more than a buck for it.Being as short as it is makes it a bit odd and harder to use than the usual pen is. Also the end is too big around. I was hoping that it would make it easier than my big fat fingers are to use the touch keyboard on my Kindle. But the big end on it and short length make it hard for me to touch the right letters with it. Now if the tip was about 1/4 of it's size or smaller, about the size of the head of a wooden kitchen match, and tapered down to it like a normal pen is, and a bit longer, then I would probably like it a lot more since this would make it easier to use.

This dropped right in my 1992 Dodge Dakota with the 3.9 V6. It saved me a little over $20 for the cheapest one I could find in the parts stores, which was this same radiator at Auto Zone. All the other parts stores wanted at least over $60 to $100 more for the same part. I'm happy with it and it was easy to install. So if you need one for your 92 Dakota and have at least minimal mechanical skills you can save yourself a lot of bucks by putting this one in your truck yourself.

This is now my favorite shirt! It's very comfortable and made of light weight t-shirt material. It's a true Triple Extra Large with a long enough tail and fits my 6'-4", 250 pound body just right. The first time I wore it in public I got several comments on it from people that liked it. As well as several disgusted looks from those prudes that are against the use of Pot for any reason. Of the two I think I got at least double the complements from people that liked it over the few that obviously didn't.Some of the shirt colors don't show the pot leaf very well. I got the light gray one and it shows the leaf nice and clear. The black, charcoal, and green ones the leaf doesn't show up very clear at all.Overall, this has now became my favorite shirt and should last for a couple years if I take care of it. If you like it, go for it! It's well worth what it cost.

This is a really cool hat! The printing on it has been well done and should stay there for many years. My only problem with it is its a bit undersized. If you really need a XL then don't bother with this one. It might be slightly bigger than just a large, but it's not close enough to X-Large. It might stretch after wearing it long enough but the trick is putting up with it being too tight until it starts to stretch out. It would be a lot better if they had used hats with adjustable velcro straps on the back. But, other than that, It's still a really cool hat!

This looked like a pretty neat do-dad to speed load my clips for my Ruger pistol. I have a couple of the original 9 shot clips for it. One that came with it and an extra I bought for it and I also have a couple of 10 shot clips made by Ruger I bought later. The 9 shot clips couldn't load at all because they couldn't be pushed in far enough. The ten shot clips went in far enough but still one of them wouldn't load at all and the other one would only take one or two rounds at a time and I had to shake it and pump the clip in and out for each round that made it into the clip. And then it still wouldn't fully load the clip.This thing may work with other clips but it wouldn't work with mine. So in my opinion its just another gimmick to take your money from you. If you try it, be prepared to send it back. Mine went back the same day that I got it. At least it didn't cost me anything to try it out. Since it did sorta work with one of the 4 clips I have and it might work great with somebody elses clips, I gave it 2 stars instead of just one.

I got this because I normally like the smell of apple cinnamon because it makes me remember what it was like when my mom used to bake apple pies. This is nothing like that. One of the bottles sitting by itself behind my flat screen TV was just about right. I tried to find just a 2 pack of the night lights for these and ended up only being able to get 6 of them just so I could try one of these out.So I put one of the Apple Cinnamon oil scent in one of the nightlight things and plugged it in an outlet in my front room. It wasn't long before the smell was overpowering and had my sinuses clogged up so bad I couldn't breath. I had to take the thing out of the front room and put it in my spare room I use for storage at the far end of my trailer. Even with it closed up back there the smell of it was way too strong. I've turn the little adjustment thing down as low as it will go then covered the top of the hole with a piece of tape then plugged it in the outlet above my washer & dryer. That just about reduced its output of the smell to the point I can almost stand it. But its still bothering my sinuses and I cant take the over powering smell of it.I don't know who had the idea for this scent and who it was that came up with it but they sure got something wrong with it. Normally my sinuses are not that sensitive but this stuff really set them off. As much as a hate to waste stuff, unless I can find somebody that likes these and I can give these to them then they are going in the trash because I just cant take the burning and constant running of my sinuses. From now on I'm going to stick to the Fabreez stuff cuz this Air Wick stuff is just way too strong.

I had a "Mr. Coffee BVMC-EL1 Cafe Latte" maker the fall of 2011 and had a lot of fun making the different drinks. But it wasn't near as nice as this one is. For making the milk frothy it used a funky whisk like thing run by a little motor in the lid for the little coffee pot. It worked great, for a while. But the little motor that made the milk foamy wasn't big enough or powerful enough to last very long. Using it 2 or 3 times a day it quit working after only 3 months. With the way this one, the "Mr. Coffee BVMC-ECMP1000 Caf√© Barista Espresso Maker" does the milk it should last for a long time.I also like the way I don't have to worry about how much water to put in the tank or how much milk to put in its little tank either. The machine automatically uses the same amount every time. And if I want a little more water to my Latte or Cappuccino I only need to press the Espresso button and it will give it another shot of hot water.On the little tank for the milk there's a little knob that you use to select Latte on one side or Cappuccino on the other. With it set to Latte the milk comes out nice and hot and lightly foamed. On Cappuccino the milk is frothier or more aerated than on Latte. You can adjust just how foamy or frothy you want your milk, from lightly foamy (Latte setting) to very foamy with lots of bubbles (Cappuccino setting) just by where you set the knob. It's just like turning the volume knob on a radio.For the amounts that it brews, a Cappuccino single serving is a little over Ω cup (150ML). A double serving is a little under a full cup (225ML).A single serving Latte is about 1 full cup, 8 oz. (225ML) A double Latte is 1 ¬Ω cups (350ML).An Espresso single serving is between ¬º and a 1/3 of a cup (75ML). A double serving is a little under ¬Ω cup (125ML).So when brewing any one of the selections a double serving is actually 1 ¬Ω servings instead of 2 full servings.There is one thing that might become a problem with it. And that is the little filter cups. As a retired machinist and seeing how these were made I can see a problem with them getting clogged up with fine debris &/or mineral build up from the water. They have a double bottom in them with several tiny holes smaller than a needle in the inside piece. There is a small gap between the part with the holes on the inside and the outer piece that has a single hole in the middle that's a little bigger than the ones on the inside. The only way for water to pass through it is by being under pressure. And as small as the holes are it won't take much to clog them. And when enough minerals from the water build up in the tiny holes and between the bottom pieces they will have to be replaced. I think it will be just like the holes in a shower head getting clogged up with minerals. Except the holes in a shower head are several times larger than the size of the tiny holes in these filter cups. I'm only using water that has been run through one of the Brita water pictures with the replaceable filter to help prevent the buildup. If only bottled water is used in it that might help prevent buildup in them too.I think it's a bit over priced. $200 for a machine to make coffee a cup at a time is a pretty high price for something made mostly of plastic. And of course, it is made in China. So it probably cost about $2 to manufacture it. So personally I'm not very comfortable with recommending buying this one at this price.

It does what its supposed to do and that's to keep people from snooping and seeing what's on your screen. Unless they want to get right up and look over your shoulder. I wasn't as concerned about privacy as getting rid of the glare on the screen and protecting the screen. But as some of the other reviewers have pointed out the loss of details in the images on the screen aren't really worth the trade off. I suppose that if you lived in the big city and used a lot of public transit it would be worth having. Overall personally I didn't like it and for the price for only one of them, really not worth it. But then that's just my opinion of it.

I did have the glare reducing screen protector on my Kindle first. It was alright for reading but for watching video clips or movies it was like watching TV with finger prints all over my glasses. I didn't really realize the difference until I took it off and tried one of these. It's not all that difficult to get these on if you do all the prep and are very careful. Make sure the screen is as clean as you can get it. I used a microfiber cloth to polish the screen and clean all the surface of my Kindle. Then laid it on a clean microfiber cloth while putting the film on the screen. First made sure that my hands were as clean and oil free as I could. Take the time to get it lined up and work the bubbles out as you go. One of the small microfiber cloths around a credit card and use the edge of the card works pretty good. Its worth the effort to protect the screen on it and once you get it on the screen right you can hardly tell its there. Sure beats that blurred frosted look of the anti glare one I did have on it.

What I got wasn't quite what I expected. From what I've read in a couple reviews on it I'm not the only one a little disappointed in it. I needed something for a Hoya plant for indoors so I really didn't need something with a hole in bottom of it. As for the liner the recycled paper its made of doesn't look like it would last very long. So for a few touch ups I gave it a couple coats of spray Polyurethane on the inside and a couple on the outside with brown stain in it. Then I used about half a tube of Plumbers Goop to stick the plastic lid from a can of Folgers Coffee upside down over the hole in the bottom. Used most of a spray can of gloss Polyurethane on the outside to finish it off and it looks pretty nice. It's probably not enough to make it waterproof but should be enough to keep it from falling apart. I let it sit outside for 3 days to let the Polyurethane cure out before I put my Hoya start in it. It looks great and I really hope the Hoya plant, or actually its a vine, takes off and grows. My mother had one and it was over 40 years old with at least 150 feet of vine and after she passed away my sister destroyed it. I managed to salvage 3 leaves from the garbage and got them to grow some roots in a glass of water. Now I hope they will take off and grow now that I have them in some dirt.As for the hanging wire frame for the pot it looks pretty good. It looks like its been dipped in some sort of rubber or plastic coating to keep it from rusting. The hanging chains look like they have also been powder coated or enameled to keep them from rusting.If you don't like the appearance of the pot and want to take the time there's a few things you could have some fun doing to it to help it last longer. Give it a couple coats of clear acrylic or Polyurethane or something like that and brushed on would probably work better than the spray I used. Then get artistic with some paints or if you got kids let them have at it with some paints and you could end up with something nice and unusual for your flowers on your patio, deck, or wherever. It wont only make it look a lot better it should help make it last a lot longer. If this one last for a while I think I'll do just that. Get a few more and see what I can come up with. They are cheap enough so if they don't last its no big deal. And like somebody else said, if the paper pots fall apart I can find some plastic ones or clay ones or something else to use in them.

For years for a cold pack or heat pack I've just taken a folded up hand towel, soaked it full of water and put it in a big Ziploc baggie. Then either put it in the freezer for a cold pack or microwave it for a heat pack. This has always worked but usually have to wrap another towel around it and then the heat pack usually leaks. But for cheap and easy its hard to beat.Now after getting tired of frozen plastic & getting burned by hot plastic this is a very nice alternative. This works best as a heat pack. I have a fairly high power microwave and it only takes a minute and a half to two minutes to get this plenty hot. Depending on your microwave I would suggest starting with one minute and see how hot that gets it. Then depending on how hot you got it it's hard to say how long it will stay hot. Of course if you fold a good hand towel around it a few times it will stay hot longer. As for a cold pack it didn't really work all that well. I left it in the freezer for a couple of days so it was as cold as it was ever going to get. I used it folded in half then a towel around it to place it on a infected tooth. Now that was one long weekend waiting to get to my dentist! Alternating between this and a frozen wet towel in a ziploc baggie got me through it till I made it to my dentist. Of the two uses for this, hot or cold, I would have to say it works better as a hot pack. Calling it a "Whole Body Wrap" is really misleading. The picture on the box showing it laying across the back of a woman is also a bit deceptive. She must be a rather small woman for it to look so big laying on her. It's actually about 6.5" wide and about 22" long. It's just the right size to lay across the small of my back or on the back of my neck and shoulders. In my opinion I don't think its really worth the original price of $20 but the reduced price of $12.72 is about right for it.

This is one sweet little Bit Driver! The cylinder that holds the bits works just like the revolving cylinder in a hand gun works. It also has 2 built in lights. 3 if you count the one on top that points forward or backwards to show which direction the switch is set for. It has a little spot light that points at the screw you want to take out or where you want to put a screw. It has another light inside the cylinder that holds 12 driver bits, so you can see which one you want to select. To select the bit driver you want all you do is pull the big sliding switch on top back towards yourself. This turns the light on inside of it and retracts the bit that was in use, if there was one,(The light turns off automatically after a few seconds). Then just turn the cylinder till you see the bit driver you want in the little magnifying window on top. Then just slide the big selector switch forward and it loads the bit into the front of the driver. When a bit driver gets too worn out to use any more you just load it like your going to use it, then pull it out of the front of the driver. Some of the small ones are hard to get hold of so you might need a pair of pliers to pull it out. Then just stick a new one in the end of the driver, then pull the selector switch back to load it in the cylinder. The only thing I don't like about mine is the revers/forward switch just above the trigger slides back and forth too easy. With just the slightest touch it changes the direction the driver turns. It needs a spring notch or something to click it into place so it stays there. One thing that's kinda funny is you can use one of the mini USB plugins to plug into the bottom of the handle of it and the other into the USB on your computer to recharge the battery in it! Or if you have an adapter with a USB plugin to stick in the cigarette lighter in your car or truck you can use it to recharge this bit driver. The mini USB plugin for my TomTom GPS fits it perfect to plug it into the cigarette lighter to recharge it. It does come with a wall adapter to recharge it with a normal power outlet.As for using it. It does have a surprising amount of torque for its size. Bit changes are quick and easy. I'm not sure how long it can be used before it needs recharged. But for its size, its the perfect thing to replace the loose screwdrivers in the kitchen junk drawer. As well as being handy in the workshop. With Fathers Day coming up I have no problem recommending this little jewel as a gift for any dad that likes tools as well as the dads that don't have much for tools.

This little jewel is in my workshop on my workbench between my Tormek Tool Grinder and Dewalt Scroll Saw. For having only one little LED bulb in it, it's very bright. With the long flex neck on it it's perfect for using my Dewalt Scroll Saw. And with the single bulb it doesn't have that weird multiple shadow effect that the LED lights with several small bulbs in them do. The light from it is also perfect for doing those small detail bench jobs that are hard to see with the overhead florescence lights. One other thing nice about it is no heat. A regular light bulb this bright would put out some heat. Enough that it could burn you if you touched it in the wrong place.Even though I put mine to use out in my workshop it would do just as well and be just as nice as a light on a desk top. Or even as a light on your night stand next to your bed. With the easy to find button to turn it on and off and being bright enough to read by it would make a nice bedside light as well. What ever use you might need a small but bright lamp for this one should fill that need. With the low power usage, no heat from the bulb, and with LED bulbs lasting pertnear fer ever, this is a good buy fer what ever ya use it fer.

I think they put this in the split bottle with 2 liquids that mix together when you use it just for a advertising and sales gimmick. It looks like they were trying to copy the liquid drain cleaner that's in a 2 liquid bottle too. As for a stain remover I guess it works about the same as their old single liquid does. It cleaned my greasy jeans I had on when I was helping a friend put a new clutch in his Dodge Dakota pickup. I used it on one leg and used my own mix I made by putting some liquid Tide & water in a spray bottle. Mixed it with about enough Tide for 2 large loads to about a quart of water. Used that on the other leg of my greasy jeans. After they were washed and dried I couldn't tell which leg I used the Resolve on from the one with my home made stain remover. So personally I don't see any reason for the extra expense to use this on my laundry. Besides that trying to get the same amount out of each side of the bottle is almost impossible. So for me for anything that my own mix doesn't work good enough on I'll just use the single liquid stain remover that's a lot easier to use and works just as well.

At the time I saw this I had been looking for a good scroll saw for a couple of months. This looked like just the thing I had been looking for and jumped on it. Then I found the one major flaw they made when they designed it. And that is it will only take a specially made blade with pins. The blades are only 4" inches long with only 3" of teeth on them, and this is the only saw that they will fit. Plus they only have 4 types of blades. There are 3 TPI sizes, course, medium, and fine, and a course tooth one that the ends are turned 90 degrees so you can change your direction of cut. And to top that off, they cost several times as much as the normal pin end blades do. I have no idea why they would make such a nice scroll saw that can be used free hand or clamped to a table top and do so much more than the usual bench top scroll saw, and then cripple it by making it so that it can only use these short, special, and very expensive blades. Because of that it is now sitting in my shop on my top junk shelf with my other failed tools. If they make the blades cheaper, in price not quality, and add a few more TPI choices then I'll get it down and get some use out of it. Until then its just another dust collector.

I figured for the price of this that it would have wimpy sound with little volume. But for under ten bucks it would at least make a nice case for my MP3 Player. Since it takes 2 AA Batteries that's no big deal when I have several sets of the AA rechargeable batteries for my digital camera's.After I put a pair of fresh charged AA's in it and plugged my new little SanDisk Sansa Clip Zip 4GB MP3 Player (Blue) into it I played Iron Butterfly In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (long version) just to test its full range of sound. When I heard what came out of this little thing I couldn't believe it! The little thing sounded absolutely fantastic! Even with the little speakers only a couple inches apart it still managed to give that left to right to left effect to the sound of the drum solo with all the deep bass that goes with it too. The long organ solo with all its highs was as close to perfect as it could be. The experiment of testing it with In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida was just flat Jaw dropping! It sounded so good I just had to do it again, several times.Now because of its size and only being powered by a couple AA batteries it doesn't have a lot of window rattling volume that vibrates your teeth, makes pictures fall off the wall, dogs howl, babies cry, and cats run for cover. But it has way more volume than the speakers in my Dell 17" Studio laptop, more volume and far better sound than what comes out of my Kindle Fire, far better than what I get from the Logitech S-150 USB powered speakers I have connected to my laptop. And those are way bigger and cost about 3 times as much as these little SmashBox Speakers do. I've tried several small speakers just for my laptop and not a single one of them comes close to the quality and quantity of sound that I get out of this thing for my MP3 player.I haven't tried any of the other small portable speakers for my SanDisk Sansa Clip Zip 4GB MP3 Player (Blue). One reason is the price of them. Most are at least twenty bucks or more. But mainly because I would have to buy 2 of them and then get the stereo splitter so I could have stereo sound.And look at this little SmashBox. For its small size you still get great sound, in stereo, and a nice padded case that will hold just about any size music player. Now if you are lugging around something like a big iPad or the 7" or bigger Kindle Fire, or any of the other electronic pads just for listening to your music then you need to spend $35 or so and get a SanDisk Sansa Clip Zip 4GB MP3 Player (Blue) or any of the other cheap music players out there. The little Clip Zip even takes the micro SD card and I have my entire 17GB music collection on mine. And this little SmashBox speaker thing has room inside it for my Clip Zip, earbuds for when I want to listen to my music by myself and NOT listen to everybody around me, and the power cord to recharge my Clip Zip and still have room for a extra pair of AA rechargeable batteries to power the speakers.I highly recommend this for anybody that would like stereo speakers for their MP3 player and on a budget. Especially if you already have some AA rechargeable batteries. If you don't have some already they are well worth the investment for when you get a digital camera. When you get a digital camera then the rechargeable batteries are a necessity.

Other than being a Doctor Who shirt with the Tardis on it the main reason I bought this was that one word, "Glowing". Now any other shirt or item with a picture on it like this and it says "something name of item "Glowing" something name of item. I take it to mean that something is supposed to "Glow" in the dark. As in; Doctor Who "Glowing" Angels have the Phone Box,,, I take it to mean that something about it, most likely the Angels, are Glowing. As in Glowing in the dark. Since for something to be "Glowing" requires the item to be in the dark so that it can be seen, "Glowing".For those of you that this was too complicated. It says "Doctor Who Glowing Angels Have The Phone Box" I assumed that meant at least the Angels to possibly all the printing on the shirt would Glow in the dark. I have other T-shirts that glow in the dark and I even have a set of bed sheets with comets and stars on them that glow in the dark. So I expected at least some part of this shirt to glow in the dark. I don't know if anybody else's shirt glows in the dark but the one that I got does NOT glow in the dark. Now, having white on black it would seem to "Glow" under a black light. but it doesn't say anything about it being a black light shirt or needing a black light for it to Glow.Any who, it is a pretty nice shirt. The printing on it, (or silk screening if that's the way it was done) seems to have been well done and has pretty good detail. The tag for who made the shirt that was sewn into the back of the neck of the shirt has been cut out. So I cant tell who actually made it.I was going to give it only 1 or 2 stars because it says that its "Glowing" when it does not glow. But, since it is still a pretty nice shirt I'm giving it a 3 star rating. Now if it did NOT have that word "Glowing" in its listing I would have gave it 5 stars. This is the second shirt that I have bought like this. I ordered them both at the same time, both of them said that they were "Glowing" shirts when neither one of them glow. It would take a black light or setting them on fire to make them actually glow.

According to the measuring instructions to find what size you need I needed a large. It says if the circumference of your head is between 23 1/4" to 24" inches you need a large. and 24 1/4" to 25" inches you need a XL. OK, my head measures 23 3/4" inches so this helmet should fit me. It doesn't. First, it sits up too high like it has about an inch too much padding in the top but it has hardly anything for padding in the top. The worst fit is the width at the front of me ears. It's so tight, its very painfully tight on the joint of my jaws. It puts so much pressure in the area in front of my ears and down to my lower jaw its too painful to leave it on for any length of time. It was bad enough that it gave me a bad headache and there is no way that I would be able to leave it on for more than half a minute, and I doubt I could stand it for that long.
