It felt like I had my head in one of those mid-evil torture devices like a big bench vice that they keep screwing down tighter and tighter till it crushes your head like a melon or giant walnut.As for its functions. The full face flip up is really nice and the built in vents for air intake in the front and out flow in the back should help keep your head cooler when riding in the summer time. I've always wanted a helmet like this one and it really bums me out that its so far undersize. I've thought about getting something like a soccer ball that I can let the air out of, stick it in the helmet and use my air compressor to pump it up and force it out a little wider where its so tight on my jaws and ears. Maybe if I leave it like that long enough it will reshape it enough that I can use it.What it comes down to is ordering a helmet online and expecting it to fit you properly is like trying to order a pair of shoes online. Both of those items are something that you really need to be able to try on for fit and comfort before you buy them. And that's something that just cant be done when ordering those items online. There are many things that can be ordered online without having that personal touch to check for size, feel, and fit. But then there are many things that you just cant get the right fit ordering it from a picture online. This is one of them.Overall I can recommend this helmet, if you buy it from a store where you can try on several of them and find the one that fits you comfortably. However, I cant recommend ordering one this way online. Chances are you will not get one that fits you properly &/or comfortably.

OK, maybe I'm a bit thick and don't get the joke. But, just where's the "Glowing"? That one word was the main reason that I bought this shirt. Now I'm very bummed out since there isn't anything on, in, or about this shirt that is "Glowing". Now maybe "Glowing" means something else over yonder on the other side of the big pond. Over here, it generally means that something, in this case the Tardis Union Jack on the shirt, is suppose to "Glow" as in "Glow in the dark".So if you are thinking about buying this shirt thinking that the word "Glowing" means that it will glow in the dark, forget it. Because there isn't anything about, on, or in this shirt that glows. In the dark or anywhere else. Except maybe under a black light. But I don't have one so I don't know if it does or not.Now if they take that word "Glowing" out of the listing then I'll change my rating from one star to five.

This is one cool looking Thermometer & conversation piece to put on my display shelves in the front room. I first saw one of these several years ago. I cant remember where it was and even though I really wanted to get one they were way too expensive. I stumbled across this one while looking for something else and couldn't believe the price so I just had to get one. It is pretty accurate but, it has a kinda wide range between the colored balls. It gives you the temperature in 4 degree F increments instead of the 2 degrees F increments that a regular thermometer does. It may have wider increments than a conventional thermometer but since the balls are so big once you can remember how many are floating is what temperature you can tell what it is at a glance. It's pretty simple really. The fewer balls floating in it the warmer it is, the more balls floating the colder it is.Now I have to get one of the big ones for myself and a few of them this size for gifts for those that are hard to shop for.UPDATE DAY LATER;  Just smack a me up side me head. Something has been bugging me about the number of glass balls inside this thing ever since I took mine out of the box. It only has 7 glass balls in it but the one in the photo has 10! What's the deal? You show a picture of one with 10 glass balls in it then in the slightly smaller than usual print you list;  *Glass sphere's inside thermometer rise or fall depending on temperatures  *7 colored spheres  *Gold finish on ∞F/¬∞C tags attached to liquid-filled spheres  *Design based on Galileo's original thermometerA lot of people would consider that deceptive advertising. OK, some listings use a "STOCK" photo of the item that might not look exactly like what you will get. But they usually tell you this in the listing. But displaying a photo of one with ten glass balls in it when you are sending ones with only seven is awful close to fraud.I started to give this a full 5 stars. But because of the difference between it and the photo in the listing I'm only giving it 2. If you change the photo and let me know, then I'll change my rating. After looking at several of the other listings one of these with 10 glass balls in it is at least 17" inches tall and over $20. The other ones I seen that are around 11" or 12" tall only have 5 glass balls in them but still cost more than this one does. So even though its being deceptive with a picture of one with 10 in it when the one they send only has 7, at $10.42 it's still the best deal out of the ones I've seen that are available. I will assume that you got the photo's mixed up and accidentally used one for a 17" tall one with 10 balls in it instead of a 12" with seven balls in it.Any who, in spite of the possible deception, when considering the price of this one with 7 balls VS the others of the same size available that only have 5 and cost more, I have to recommend this one. I can also recommend it for a gift for that person in your life that is so hard to shop for. Just about everybody would think this is something pretty cool and unusual, and cant help but like it.
I really like Metisse's music. I first heard it when Boom Boom Ba was used in the TV series Dead Like Me. I like the easy mellow sounds of her music and its one of my favorites for relaxing to.

Even though this knife was made in China it is surprisingly well made. Which is very unusual for something that was made in China where they make the worst products in the world. The one I got actually works like it was made by somebody that could almost be called a craftsman. The steel the blade is made of is of good quality and came with a pretty good edge on it. It only took a couple minutes with my kitchen steel to put a razor edge on it. It opens easily with just the flick of a finger. The blade locks open and is very solidly mounted. It even has an emergency belt cutter built into the back of the handle and a striking point on the end that can be used to break a window made of safety glass. If struck properly and with enough force.If you like collecting knives or are just looking for a nice one for a reasonable price I strongly suggest getting this one. It's now my favorite for daily carrying and use.

This is a pretty cool bottle opener. The one I got is solid brass or bronze, I think. It's not magnetic anyway and too heavy to be aluminum. The hook for opening bottles can also be used to pop a top on a can of soda or beer too. It has now replaced my old favorite opener, The Lizard Lip. If you like collecting unusual openers or unusual doodads and gizmo's that have a function and work, I suggest adding this to your collection.

Since it is cheap, mine was only $7.91, I didn't really expect too much in the quality department. But even the cheap stuff when it has parts that are easy to make there is no excuse for deliberately making it look like a 2nd grade kid made it in crafts class.It is a unique design with the Dragon's wings being the bottle opener. Just lift the wings as far as they will go and the notch on each wing forms the opener. Pretty simple really but they still managed to make the wings off center on mine. So the notches have one longer than the other so both of them wont fit on a bottle at the same time.The blade starts out as one of the cool looking ones that looks like a snake. Those are a bit difficult to sharpen right but come on, don't use a regular flat grinding wheel on it and take the curves off!I have several unique knives that I paid from around $8 to $18 for and they are nice knives. There's no excuse for making crap when all it takes is a little attention and care about what you are doing to make them come out nice. I know, because I was a machinist for well over 20 years. Running the production machines that made this is what they call a "put & take job" As in you stand there all day taking the finished part out and putting the next one in the machine. And its no more difficult to make the part right than it is to make them looking like crap. It just takes a tiny bit of care and attention to and about what you are doing. I could make better looking parts for these while extremely stoned & half asleep.While this is a very poorly made knife, even for as cheap as it is, it's not quite the worst one I've got. It's almost as bad, not quite but almost as bad as the German knife I bought that was supposed to be a classic spring assisted blade that's long and slender with a black handle, silver caps on the ends and a silver Eagle on each side of the handle. When I got the 2 knives I ordered they had swastikas on each side of the handle and looked like they had laid in a gravel parking lot with heavy traffic for a week and been ran over a couple thousand times, in gravel. This one wasn't quite that bad, but close.This is actually a Carnival knife that you win for popping under inflated balloons with a dull dart. Or the ring toss or one of the many other rigged things to take your money while you try to win the giant stuffed animal (that has never been won by anybody and looks forty or fifty years old) for your girlfriend.If you still want this knife for your collection of odd knives it can still be sharpened enough to be a letter opener and you might get lucky and get one with the wings bent right so the bottle opener works. But don't expect anything that looks much like a Dragon Knife.I'll try to get a couple photo's uploaded later so you can see what they really look like. If you still want to get one anyway, good luck.

As somebody else said, this doesn't come with directions. But then it doesn't really need any. What is if for? to keep a bottle of wine cold longer than it would be just sitting on the table. How do you use it? Chill your bottle of wine. You can also chill this in the freezer at the same time. Set Chiller on table, put bottle of wine in it. Enjoy.I think we have gotten used to everything having instructions simplified and written out so that even the dumbest person can follow them. If they did write some out for this they would probably be something like this;Remove OXO Steel Wine Chiller from boxRemove OXO Steel Wine Chiller from plastic bag.Place plastic bag in trash. DO NOT give Plastic Bag to children to play with, Plastic Bag is not a toy and is a suffocation hazard.To use OXO Steel Wine Chiller place Chiller in freezer. If you do not have bottle of wine chilled place bottle of wine in refrigerator at this time to chill.When wine is chilled remove from refrigerator. Remove OXO Steel Wine Chiller from freezer.Place chilled OXO Steel Wine Chiller on table. Place chilled bottle of wine in OXO Steel Wine Chiller.A small towel or cloth can be placed over wine bottle in OXO Steel Wine Chiller to keep it chilled longer.Enjoy.When I read "Wine Chiller" I pictured a stainless steel bucket with a bottle of wine and ice in it like in the movies. But this isn't even close to being big enough for ice to chill your bottle of wine. Unless its been crushed down to almost snow. So as a "Wine Chiller" its a failure. But for keeping a bottle of wine chilled during dinner it does that pretty well.I found by putting it in the freezer for a half hour or so before using it helps a lot. Then using a small dishtowel or nice cloth napkin to cover it and the bottle of wine in it also helps to keep it chilled longer than just sitting in the bucket.If you are a frequent wine drinker with your dinner then you would probably like one of these. Or even just for that occasional family dinner at the holidays it would look nice on the table. Or one at each end for a large family. If your not a wine drinker then you probably wouldn't have any use for this except as a gift for somebody that is.

I have seen a lot of these body wraps lately and its confusing on what will help and what doesn't. So when the opportunity came up to try a Detox Body Wrap of course I went for it. First I will talk about what comes with this product. You get 8 applications, first you take the bandage and let it soak for 10-15 minutes while this is happening you take a packet of powder add warm water and the clay forms, once this is done you spread it on the area, take the warm bandage, make sure it is not to hot, ring out excess water, apply clay to area and wrap bandage around it. To keep it warm place saran wrap around it. Leave on for one hour. Take off bandage, wash it, wipe off excess clay. After a couple treatments your skin will look and feel tighter in the area. I did my arms where the jiggly are. It works maybe not with just one applications but after a few you will notice a difference. Your skin is also softer and refreshed.*I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased opinion.

Still shopping, but leaning toward a Surface 3 over the Surface 3 Pro or any Surface 4 variant. For those scanning reviews to make up *your* mind, the only turn off to these sweet devices is how remarkably non-repairable they are. The case is glued together, mitigating not only the chance to upgrade RAM or SSD card, but battery replacement is problematic, as well as expensive (I've seen articles quoting anywhere form $200-$450).So I am viewing the Surface as sort of disposable. It will last as long as it lasts (which may well be for a while past warranty), and when it breaks or the battery dies I will likely replace it. Therefore the strategy will be to buy CHEAP :>. Not interested in investing over a grand on some variants of the PRO. Rather spend a few hundred, get a great hybrid computing device, and then shed no tears when it dies.I also like that the Surface 3 does not have a fan. Sure, there's a smaller processor, but I am in the Steve Jobs camp that says computers should be seen and not heard. ;>cheers

Ubiquiti produces a line of very high quality wireless networking equipment for the IT professional. The gear is often sold through market specific distributors, but Ubiquiti products showing up here on Amazon are perhaps a sign that technically savvy folks who don't do IT for a living have discovered that for the price you can't beat Ubiquiti's offerings.This is a sector antenna which provides a 90 degree angle of coverage. It is designed to mate specifically with two types of Ubiquiti WiFi radios; the Rocket M 2.4Ghz, or for managed WiFi installations, the Unifi AP Outdoor ... (Ubiquiti ROCKETM2 2.4GHz Hi Power 2x2 MIMO AirMax TDMA BaseStation) and (Ubiquiti UniFI AP Outdoor+ Wi-Fi 802.11 b/g/n, 2.4 GHz speed, speed upto 300 Mbps). By the way, the antenna has a 90 degree sister found here: [[ASIN:B004FVQ5DG Ubiquiti AM-2G16-90  AirMax Sector 2.4 GHz 2x2 MIMO BaseStationSector Antenna]].The advantage of the above combo is reliability and noteworthy coverage. When configured as an access point, the combination of this antenna with the aforementioned radios means you can not only shoot a signal several hundred feet, the antenna is a good "listener", meaning the relatively weak signal from consumer WiFi devices such as laptops and smartphones some distance away is picked up where other gear would not read the signal.Conversely, when configured to receive an existing WiFi signal the combo again will work to bring in a weak signal where other equipment would not.The installation is easy, but you need a bit of tech savvy to program the radios. It's worth the effort though to achieve stable WiFi over a distance.I'll give you one configuration tip right now to save some hair pulling; unless you are connecting to other Ubiquiti equipment with an "M" in the model number, turn airMAX OFF, and set the channel width for 20Mhz for best compatibility. :>

This is an excellent product from an excellent company. However, its use is tailored for a very specific purpose. It's designed to mainly work with certain other Ubiquiti wireless products. Also, this is not a user friendly push-a-button to configure consumer item. It has a somewhat complex feature array. Just for openers you must know how to change the TCP/IP configuration on your computer from DHCP to a static IP address in order to program the airGateway. Having said that, there are a number of reviews posted on Amazon from folks who do not appear to be IT professionals yet got the job done. The benefit if you go to the trouble of setting this gizmo up is that for its price it's a very solid piece of equipment that doesn't have to be rebooted and futzed with on a daily basis. It just works. Please note there are three different models of the airGateway as described below. But first, what exactly does this little gadget do?The airGateway is a Wireless Access Point (WAP) designed to seamlessly connect to Ubiquiti wireless devices that bring internet to your premises, but do not  to necessarily transmit a WiFi signal throughout that premises. Such devices are typically known as Customer Premises Equipment or CPE. The airGateway is made specifically to plug into the power supply designed for Ubiquiti CPEs. The CPE is typically mounted outdoors for best reception, for example on a roof eve or a pole, in order to make a line-of-site connection to the corresponding radio on the other end of the link. But the power supply for the CPE is normally INSIDE the structure... so plugging an airGateway into the power supply connects it to the CPE and transmits the internet signal it receives via WiFi to the interior of the building.Ubiquiti CPE devices have applications ranging from obtaining internet in rural areas, to RV camping, to boosting weak hotel WiFi signals. In one example, folks living in a rural area might get their internet not from DSL or cable -due to a lack of service in their area- but instead get their internet from a Wireless Internet Service Provider (WISP) that beams a signal from a nearby hilltop. Often a dedicated CPE device must be installed at the customer's location and pointed directly at the antenna of the transmitter the WISP is using to beam the internet out. This setup makes for a nice reliable connection that can bring the internet into the building via an Ethernet cable run between the CPE and the customer's network, but such a rig does NOT provide a WiFi signal. Since WISPs often use Ubiquiti equipment due to its low cost and high reliability, the company came up with this cheap and effective add-on to create that missing WiFi link. Again, the air Gateway simply plugs into the same power supply (inside the building) that feeds power to the outdoor CPE connecting to the WISP (or whoever). BTW the outdoor Ubiquiti radios usually employed are its "airMAX" products such as the NanoBridge, NanoStation, PicoStation, and several other models. Here are some links: (Ubiquiti NB-5G22 NanoBridge M5 Cost-Effective 5GHz 22dbi MIMO) and (Ubiquiti NanoStation locoM2 2.4GHz Indoor/Outdoor airMax 8dBi CPE) and (Ubiquiti PicoStation M2HP 2.4GHz 802.11g/n High Power Access Point). Each model has its own characteristics and is selected based upon the specific environment it is installed into.Another example, seen in several Amazon reviews, is on an RV. If an RV sets up camp in a location that has WiFi, yet the received signal is not strong enough to reach into all the nooks and crannies of the RV, such as someone lying in bed trying to get the weather on their smartphone, then a Ubiquiti NanoStation (as an example) could be installed outside the RV (perhaps mounted on the rear view mirror bracket) and pointed directly toward the park's WiFi antenna. Then an airGateway could be plugged Into the NanoStation's power supply INSIDE the RV and transmit a nice strong signal throughout the vehicle.Yeah, you could use any old wireless router in the RV instead of the airGateway to spread the WiFi around, but why take up the limited space of an RV with a bulky wireless router when an airGateway is tiny, doesn't take up another precious AC outlet, and is cheaper than any [good] WiFi router! This of course is based on having made the investment in a piece of outdoor equipment to pull in a decent signal. And I'll tell you, an externally mounted CPE is a good idea for any frequent RV'r who can't live without internet. I've designed RV park WiFi systems and it is NOT easy to place wireless access points in such a way they send a strong signal into every RV in the park. Too much aluminum reflecting and bouncing the signal all around!As a third and final example I would point you to an excellent review by danijag who used an airGateway coupled to a Ubiquiti CPE to boost the signal from a weak hotel WiFi signal. You could of course use such a set up to capture and rebroadcast ANY weak Wifi signal. The secret that makes all these applications work is that the Ubiquiti CPEs have a directional, HIGH GAIN antenna and a very powerful radio. This enables them to beat out any "department store" competitor by a mile when it comes to locking onto a weak signal. Here is the link to the review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R1XIAVE64OAZ97/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00JIOG8CI.BTW, you could theoretically use an airGateway with other wireless products or by itself if you purchased a Ubiquiti power supply to fire it up (Ubiquiti POE-24 Power Over Ethernet 24vdc 24W 1Amp), but that is almost overkill as there are other generic solutions to fit that bill, including equipment from Ubiquiti.Here is a breakdown of the models:1) airGateway standard model - 2.4Ghz Ubiquiti Networks Airgateway Indoor AP (AIRGATEWAY)This is the lowest cost model but it has only an internal antenna. It has good coverage in the same or maybe adjacent rooms, but signal strength will drop off if you have to go through more than one wall.2) airGateway LR (Long Range)  - 2.4Ghz  (Ubiquiti Networks AIRGATEWAY-LR AIRGATEWAY INDOOR AP EXT ANTENNA)Slightly more expensive but has an external antenna for more range. If need be you can swap in a bigger antenna such as this Asus model I've had good luck with: Asus Omni Antenna (WL-ANT-191).3) airGateway PRO - 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz  (The item on this page)This is the dual band version, which also has only an internal antenna, so same caveats as the standard model apply.Hope this helps. If you go to youtube and search on "ubiquiti airgateway" there are a few airGateway configuration videos. However these may confuse more than clarify. Reviewer Llamadave included a link in his review to an excellent blog post about how to do the whole set up from A-Z. It is here: http://www.amazon.com/review/RDJ4J1GRS34IC/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00JIOG8CI.

You have to admit that erecting your own personal cell tower is a pretty cool concept. However, there seems to be a bunch of misleading information about these Verizon network extenders in the reviews and Q&A found throughout Amazon. And the vendor descriptions of the optional external GPS antenna can also be misleading at times. I'm not going to pretend to be an expert, but I've messed with a few of these devices over the years and wish to pass on a few tips regarding what I've learned.TOP 10 THINGS TO KNOW ABOUT THESE NETWORK EXTENDERS1) What models are available?Model SCS-26UC4 - This is the first  version of the extender introduced in 2009 and is no longer being sold by Verizon, but is available used/refurbished through outlets such as Amazon and eBay. The main difference I am aware of is that this older extender only can only download data at "1x" speeds (much slower than 3G). This model also handles fewer simultaneous calls (3) than the updated model noted next. The SCS-26UC4l was reduced in price to $99 (with rebate) when the upgraded model came out, but now usually sells for more used. For a few people however THIS is the preferable model to purchase. I will explain below. BTW - when these extenders first appeared on the market, cell calls placed through them were NOT charged any minutes. It was a truly free call. Those days are long gone as Verizon now charges the minutes based on your calling plan for either extender or cell tower calls.Model SCS-2U01 - This improved model was released around 2010. Mainly it adds 3G data (also known as EVDO or EVolution Data Optimized), so internet speeds are improved. It also handles up to 8 simultaneous calls. These units are still available from Verizon's website, as well as used through 3rd party sites such as Amazon or eBay.Model SCS-2U3100 - This is the 'business' version of the extender, and is available (as of this writing Nov 2015) through Verizon, and again, used via 3rd party sites. This model features self-registration, extended coverage, more simultaneous calls, and can be daisy-chained to up to five business extenders total to greatly increase coverage area. The basic coverage of one unit is advertised as 7,500 sq ft, as opposed to 5,000 sq ft of the model SCS-2U01. To get this range you must register this particular model after it is plugged in and working by dialing #48 on your Verizon cell phone. Until that is done coverage is only a fraction of the 7,500 sq ft advertised.2) Do I need to register my extender?Lots of misconceptions here. NEW extenders purchased from the Verizon website are automatically registered when purchased. The extender is assigned to the Verizon Wireless account you log into (or establish at the time of purchase). The exception is the business model (SCS-2U3100) as described above. USED extenders must also be registered to work (doesn't matter whose account it is registered to), but a used device may or may not be registered when you receive it because the previous owner has the option to UNregister their device.Which begs the perennial question: "Help! Do I need to RE-register my used device onto my own Verizon account, and if so, how?" ANSWER: Don't worry about it. In most cases the extender will work just fine as long as it is registered 'somewhere', and I think it's rare for someone to take the time to UNregister their unit. See the troubleshooting section below if your used device does not work before freaking out about registration. Remember that the extender is a one time cost. There are no recurring costs billed to the Verizon account the extender is associated with. Per minute charges are related to the cell phone used, not the extender. The only reason to get the extender assigned to your own Verizon account is to program the one single feature you have control over, which is to setup a prioritized list of phone numbers. For most people though this is a pathetic feature. Reason being, contrary to what's stated in several reviews you can't actually BLOCK certain phones from using the extender. All you can do is enter a list of cell phones that get priority... meaning if all the available slots are used (8 for the current non-business model SCS2U01) then any phone initiating a call whose number is entered in the priority list will bump someone off who is not on the list. Big deal. How many people are going to have 8 simultaneous calls running?Being able to actually block certain numbers from using the device (black listing) and/or allow only certain numbers (white listing) would be a far more practical feature for most residential use. Why? Because an extender can often transmit a cell signal up to hundreds of feet (depending). ANYONE can use that signal... for voice or data! Do you want a bunch of yahoos you don't know using up YOUR internet bandwidth while they try and connect to Netflix via their smartphone and take in a movie? And if you have a data cap on your internet service the issue is compounded. Under the current implementation of the extender (all models) that is exactly what can happen. That is why for some people the older model (SCS-26UC4), which has only 1x data speeds, is preferable. At least with a 1x extender it will throttle any strangers' attempt to gobble up your internet connection.3) Do I  need an external antenna?Misinformation abounds regarding this question. The first thing to understand is that your extender has TWO antennas. The little antenna sticking out of the back of the device is for transmitting (and receiving) the cell signal. The closer a cell phone is to this cellular antenna the more bars appear on the phone.Inside the extender (under the hatch cover on top toward the rear) is the GPS antenna. This antenna has NOTHING to do with the strength of the cell signal or the quality of the call. It's there simply to identify the location of the extender for 911 calls and whatnot. I bring this to your attention because the folks who sell aftermarket external GPS antennas occasionally will lead consumers to believe that their extender will work better and you will "get more out of your extender" if you buy an external GPS antenna. Poppycock. Very simply, if the GPS LED is solid blue you don't need another GPS antenna. Repeat, if the GPS LED is blue you are good to go. See below if your GPS LED is red. In that case you may or may not need an external GPS antenna.With that question hopefully settled what remains is; do you need a different cellular antenna? There are indeed aftermarket cellular antennas that can a) increase the range of your extender, and b) focus the signal in a specific area. The stock cell antenna is omnidirectional or just "omni", meaning it covers a full 360 degree area. Replacement antennas may be omni as well or be directional to cover a specific area. Just remember in all these examples that unlike WiFi, you can't password protect your extender! It's open to whoever the signal reaches to.Let's start with the simplest cellular antenna replacement; an omni that screws directly in the back of the extender just as the stock one does, but provides greater coverage. I have tested three such antennas. Surprisingly, in spite of claims of higher gain, two of the three replacements were worse than the factory antenna. The third one, a $15 TECHTOO antenna gave about 1 bar of gain over the stock antenna. Not bad for the price, and it is easily the cheapest and quickest way to boost the output from your extender: TECHTOOÆ Wide Band 5dbi 700-2600Mhz 3G 4G LTE Omni Directional Antenna with SMA Male Connector for HUAWEI CPE Router B593/B310/B880/E5172/E5175/E5186/B890 / ZTE MF253/MF283/MF25D/MF28G /MF28D (Black). Don't ever tell Verizon you replaced your antenna because it no doubt breaks your warranty. (i.e. keep the original antenna ;>).Moving up the food chain there are replacement antennas that sit apart from the extender and attach with a cable that provide even more gain. I have one of these on order (Wilson Electronics 800/1900 MHz Magnet Mount Antenna with SMA Male Connector - Retail Packaging - Black), and will update the review after trying it out.If you wish to direct the signal from the extender in a specific direction (excluding other areas from coverage) you need a 'directional' antenna. For example Wilson makes a so-called 'panel' (flat) directional antenna that mounts on the wall and beams the cellular signal in a roughly 70 degree pattern across the horizon. This antenna provides a significant boost in coverage over the aforementioned omni models because of its size, and because the signal is not being radiated in all directions. The model # that has the correct "SMA" plug for your extender is 311135 (WILSON ELECTRONICS 311135 Dual-Band 50_ Wall-Mount Panel Antenna).Finally, there are many aftermarket cell "boosters" that come with an amplifier and antenna. How do those fit into the equation? I know little of such devices though, except to state with some certainty that boosters cannot distinguish between a Verizon network extender and a "real" cell tower (it's like some version of the old Beggin' Strips commercials: "Dogs don't know it's not a cell tower!"). But to give you an idea, these devices typically have an antenna that you point at the cell tower (or in this case the network extender) and then another antenna that sits on a desk or counter that shoots the signal around the room. Why would you want one of these products? It might make sense if you get good coverage with the Verizon extender around the house but have, say, a pool house or other remote building that only gets a bar or two of coverage. Boosters can cost more than an extender so you have to be prudent here. There is a well rated Wilson amplifier kit costing about $200 that would pick up the signal from the extender at a distance and then re-transmit the signal locally (Wilson Electronics  DT - Cell Phone Signal Boost for Small Home or Office - Retail Packaging - Gray). If you don't have internet at the remote location this product might be a wise choice. But if you do have internet you have to weight the cost against simply purchasing another extender.4) The lights will not all turn blue on my extender!OK. The following bits of knowledge came at the expense of blood, sweat, and even a tear or two. So listen up. Unless all other lights turn blue the SYS LED won't turn blue. From there, decoding the "Verizon Code" varies according to whether you have the older 1x model (SCS-26UC4) or the newer 3G model (SCS-2U01)...On the older SCS-26UC4 the GPS LED tends to stays red (solid or flashing) REGARDLESS of what the issue is (like network/internet connection issue or GPS lock issues). For example if the internet connection is down, it's the GPS light that often stays red, not the WAN (Wide Area Network) light as it should. So you have to ignore what the manual says about the LEDs and assume you may have either network issues or GPS issues. Or if you're having a bad hair day, perhaps both. Don't despair, keep reading.Here is a list of issues I've discovered that will prevent the GPS LED from turning blue:a) Extender not registeredb) Hardware failure (rare)c) Incompatible internet routerd) Internet router unpluggede) Internet connection downf) extender is geographically outside Verizon's licensed frequency rangeand finallyg) weak GPS signal (the extender can't see enough GPS satellites to lock to)The above list applies to the newer SCS-2U01 units as well, except the LEDs on that model give better indication as to the issue. If you have a WAN (Internet connection) issue I've found that the WAN light appropriately stays flashing or solid red. The Achilles Heel of the SCS-2U01 is that the  SYS LED will sometimes go blue (which normally indicates all systems are go) temporarily, even if the WAN LED is red. Go figure. Neither model will work however until all lights are blue.But actually, the REAL Achilles Heel of the SCS-2U01 is that it is surprisingly incompatible with a number of brands of internet routers out there. I first spotted an Amazon review noting this, and we too have gone to extender purgatory more than once due to the extender not liking the router. Coverage on how to determine if your extender is cool with your router is in the following troubleshooting section...MAKING THE LIGHTS TURN BLUEa) Wait. Do nothing for an hour or two after you've placed the unit near a window and plugged in power and a network cable running to your router. It can take a newly setup extender that long to lock to GPS and turn all the LEDs blue.b) Be sure the extender is registered. It doesn't matter to what Verizon account. This mostly applies to used units. Try to register the extender to your Verizon Wireless account. Whether the registration is successful or the system complains the device is already registered, you're good to go either way. If the extender is registered to another account then only if you really really want to set which cell phone numbers have priority do you want to go through the hellish experience of actually talking to Verizon and coaxing them to transfer the device into your name. Reviewers report mixed results on this endeavor. And as previously mentioned, charges will NOT rack up on the account of the previous owner. Charges are based on the cell phone using the extender, not the extender itself.c) GPS lock. For the older SCS-26UC4 regardless of what its lights are doing, or the newer SCS-2U01 if its GPS light stays red for more than an hour or two, make sure the extender is placed in view of the open sky. Sticking it near a window is not a guarantee of a GPS lock. Try to place the unit outside where the sky is most open. You must have both power and Ethernet cables connected so you are limited by the length of your cords. THEN WAIT AT LEAST TWO HOURS. If the GPS and SYS light go solid blue in that time you probably need an external GPS antenna.Anecdote: At one of our locations we have a good view of the sky but there are tall redwood trees in one direction and a hill in another direction. This was enough to require an external GPS antenna to get clear of the obstructions. If your extender came with a separate GPS cable then you can simply unplug the GPS antenna (you wiggle it out of its socket) and plug in the cable in its place. If you don't have a cable you can get a 20 footer from Amazon (Universal 20' Antenna Extension SMB Male to SMB Female extention cable 20ft 6M compatiable with SIRIUS XM Radio Garmin GPS Receiver). Sometimes its cheaper to just get the cable with a GPS antenna. I purchased a cheapo $10 GPS antenna here on Amazon (External GPS Antenna with SMB female for Verizon Samsung 3G Network Extender plus led light key chain) with a nearly 10ft cable. So far it works great and has born up against the rain. Also, a company called GILSSON sells a variety of GPS antennas that look to be good quality and have longer length cables available. I have one on order and will update this review after it's been in operation for a while.NOTE: At the time of this writing the only Amazon reseller offering the Gilsson line is a vendor called NAVSPHERE. With a reseller rating of a miserable 86% I therefore chose to pick mine up off eBay.d) Internet connection. There are two things to try here. First, plug the network cable coming from the extender into a port on the router that is already being used by another device and wait 20 minutes. The logic here is simple; individual ports on routers go bad. Second -and this addresses the router incompatibility issue- temporarily plug your extender directly into your broadband connection. Don't worry about rebooting the equipment, just wait 20 minutes. If the lights all turn blue your extender does not like your router.On this last note we were able to solve the problem of two different routers being incompatible with an extender. It's technical but I'll attempt to explain in plain English. In both our cases the router did not have 'DHCP' turned on. This is the service that hands out IP addresses to all devices when they connect (either wirelessly or via plugged into a port on the router). The extender is no exception. It needs an IP address to work. On some more complex home/small office networks another piece of equipment on the network may have the job of assigning IP addresses. But it seems the Verizon network extender wants to get its IP address from the router it is plugged into. So before shopping for a new router have your tech person check to see if DHCP is enabled on the router.After all the above if the unit still won't turn all blue this reviewer is out of ideas. It might be a bad extender, or perhaps you live outside Verizon's "licensed spectrum". Verizon has a coverage map that refers to "Broadband Services ... coverage area", "... enhanced Services ... coverage area", "Extended Broadband Services ... coverage area", "Extended National..." bla blah blah. It's nearly as complicated as the tax code.5) Can I use the extender with satellite internet?Definitely maybe. You probably know that all calls on a Verizon network extender are routed through your internet connection. Call quality therefore is only as good as your connection to the internet. Normally this is not an issue as voice traffic only needs a fraction of the bandwidth required for, say, music and video. Still, voice traffic is "real time" and any hiccups on your internet connection will reflect in call quality, With satellite internet this core equation is multiplied, as the packets of info (voice or data) take a 45,000 mile trip to space and back in addition to wherever else they're headed. And that's just one-way. Still, it can work, albeit with a noticeable delay on each end of the call. You will hear people going :"Hello. Hello??" because they don't hear you right away. I would recommend being on the latest and greatest satellite service for best results. We are on Wildblue EXEDE and it works OK. At times the EXEDE network gets bogged down and call quality can greatly suffer. This is definitely a Plan B solution.6) Will my non-Verizon prepaid phone that uses the Verizon network work OK?Yes! Any non-Verizon pre-paid phone that uses the Verizon network such as TracFone, StraightTalk and others seems to work fine with the extender (which is interesting because such phones are reported to not work on all Verizon cell towers). The only "downside" is that you cannot use these phones to register your extender, because you cannot create a Verizon Wireless account with such phones. If you don't have any actual Verizon phones you can't buy the extender from Verizon because you must have an account to do so. This where Amazon and eBay and such come in. You can just buy the device from such sources. If it arrives already registered you're set. If it is not registered, any friend or relative with a Verizon phone can register it to their account. This in no way affects their service and no charges are levied. See the registration section in this review which explains why I am claiming this.7) Should I buy my extender NEW or USED!!I have to say, I love buying used to save a little money. Bottom line, the used market is about PRICE and RETURNABILITY. If the price is well bellow the $250 dollar cost new, AND you have patience for things maybe going more wrong at first than with a new unit, AND you can return the unit with no hassle, then fine. Just remember also, if you have the Chutzpah to go toe to toe with Verizon about how they SHOULD be pumping 3 or 4 bars into you locale you might get an extender out of them at a discount or for free. It happens, but it may take some tenacity.8) Where should I place my extender?The thing is, the ideal location to get a GPS lock may not be the ideal place for best coverage of the areas important to you. The saving grace is that both the GPS antenna and/or the cellular antenna can be remotely located from the extender. My first strategy would be to go for placing the extender itself in a nice central location for coverage to your phones. If you don't get a blue GPS light in that location you can pull the GPS antenna out of the extender and run a cable to place it in a window (or outside if need be). I like this strategy for two reasons; 1) it is easier and cheaper to remote the GPS antenna than it is the cellular antenna. 2) I don't think its necessarily wise to follow conventional wisdom and keep the extender itself in a window to get a GPS lock. The extender runs pretty warm to begin with. Placing it in direct sunlight will just make it run hotter and almost certainly shorten its life. I'd much rather stick just the little GPS antenna in a window pane. The lady of the house will likely appreciate the improved aesthetics as well. :>9) MISC:How to tell if you're cell phone is connected to your extender as opposed to a cell tower:Dial #48How to read the signal strength reaching your phone:Android phone: System Settings / About Phone / StatusiPhone:Dial *3001#12345#* (google: "lifehacker See the Actual Signal Strength on Your iPhone" for more)10) Soapboxit would be nice to see Verizon launch the 3rd generation of the extender that included touch-ups like the ability to white list and black list phone number, LEDs that display properly, better setup instructions, and lower pricing. Unfortunately there is a built in conflict of interest here. First, for each call made on an extender, which uses the public internet to route the call as opposed to Verizon's cell tower network, that is one less call Verizon needs to beef up its own network to handle. Plus at $250 to $399 a pop, Verizon is making a handy little profit off you for each extender it sells. Since Verizon is the only supplier of compatible extenders they pretty much own the market for these devices and thus there is no pressure to lower pricing or improve the extender. ;>Cheers!

You have to admit that erecting your own personal cell tower is a pretty cool concept. However, there seems to be a bunch of misleading information about these Verizon network extenders in the reviews and Q&A found throughout Amazon. And the vendor descriptions of the optional external GPS antenna can also be misleading at times. I'm not going to pretend to be an expert, but I've messed with a few of these devices over the years and wish to pass on a few tips regarding what I've learned.TOP 10 THINGS TO KNOW ABOUT THESE NETWORK EXTENDERS1) What models are available?Model SCS-26UC4 - This is the first  version of the extender introduced in 2009 and is no longer being sold by Verizon, but is available used/refurbished through outlets such as Amazon and eBay. The main difference I am aware of is that this older extender only can only download data at "1x" speeds (much slower than 3G). This model also handles fewer simultaneous calls (3) than the updated model noted next. The SCS-26UC4l was reduced in price to $99 (with rebate) when the upgraded model came out, but now usually sells for more used. For a few people however THIS is the preferable model to purchase. I will explain below. BTW - when these extenders first appeared on the market, cell calls placed through them were NOT charged any minutes. It was a truly free call. Those days are long gone as Verizon now charges the minutes based on your calling plan for either extender or cell tower calls.Model SCS-2U01 - This improved model was released around 2010. Mainly it adds 3G data (also known as EVDO or EVolution Data Optimized), so internet speeds are improved. It also handles up to 8 simultaneous calls. These units are still available from Verizon's website, as well as used through 3rd party sites such as Amazon or eBay.Model SCS-2U3100 - This is the 'business' version of the extender, and is available (as of this writing Nov 2015) through Verizon, and again, used via 3rd party sites. This model features self-registration, extended coverage, more simultaneous calls, and can be daisy-chained to up to five business extenders total to greatly increase coverage area. The basic coverage of one unit is advertised as 7,500 sq ft, as opposed to 5,000 sq ft of the model SCS-2U01. To get this range you must register this particular model after it is plugged in and working by dialing #48 on your Verizon cell phone. Until that is done coverage is only a fraction of the 7,500 sq ft advertised.2) Do I need to register my extender?Lots of misconceptions here. NEW extenders purchased from the Verizon website are automatically registered when purchased. The extender is assigned to the Verizon Wireless account you log into (or establish at the time of purchase). The exception is the business model (SCS-2U3100) as described above. USED extenders must also be registered to work (doesn't matter whose account it is registered to), but a used device may or may not be registered when you receive it because the previous owner has the option to UNregister their device.Which begs the perennial question: "Help! Do I need to RE-register my used device onto my own Verizon account, and if so, how?" ANSWER: Don't worry about it. In most cases the extender will work just fine as long as it is registered 'somewhere', and I think it's rare for someone to take the time to UNregister their unit. See the troubleshooting section below if your used device does not work before freaking out about registration. Remember that the extender is a one time cost. There are no recurring costs billed to the Verizon account the extender is associated with. Per minute charges are related to the cell phone used, not the extender. The only reason to get the extender assigned to your own Verizon account is to program the one single feature you have control over, which is to setup a prioritized list of phone numbers. For most people though this is a pathetic feature. Reason being, contrary to what's stated in several reviews you can't actually BLOCK certain phones from using the extender. All you can do is enter a list of cell phones that get priority... meaning if all the available slots are used (8 for the current non-business model SCS2U01) then any phone initiating a call whose number is entered in the priority list will bump someone off who is not on the list. Big deal. How many people are going to have 8 simultaneous calls running?Being able to actually block certain numbers from using the device (black listing) and/or allow only certain numbers (white listing) would be a far more practical feature for most residential use. Why? Because an extender can often transmit a cell signal up to hundreds of feet (depending). ANYONE can use that signal... for voice or data! Do you want a bunch of yahoos you don't know using up YOUR internet bandwidth while they try and connect to Netflix via their smartphone and take in a movie? And if you have a data cap on your internet service the issue is compounded. Under the current implementation of the extender (all models) that is exactly what can happen. That is why for some people the older model (SCS-26UC4), which has only 1x data speeds, is preferable. At least with a 1x extender it will throttle any strangers' attempt to gobble up your internet connection.3) Do I  need an external antenna?Misinformation abounds regarding this question. The first thing to understand is that your extender has TWO antennas. The little antenna sticking out of the back of the device is for transmitting (and receiving) the cell signal. The closer a cell phone is to this cellular antenna the more bars appear on the phone.Inside the extender (under the hatch cover on top toward the rear) is the GPS antenna. This antenna has NOTHING to do with the strength of the cell signal or the quality of the call. It's there simply to identify the location of the extender for 911 calls and whatnot. I bring this to your attention because the folks who sell aftermarket external GPS antennas occasionally will lead consumers to believe that their extender will work better and you will "get more out of your extender" if you buy an external GPS antenna. Poppycock. Very simply, if the GPS LED is solid blue you don't need another GPS antenna. Repeat, if the GPS LED is blue you are good to go. See below if your GPS LED is red. In that case you may or may not need an external GPS antenna.With that question hopefully settled what remains is; do you need a different cellular antenna? There are indeed aftermarket cellular antennas that can a) increase the range of your extender, and b) focus the signal in a specific area. The stock cell antenna is omnidirectional or just "omni", meaning it covers a full 360 degree area. Replacement antennas may be omni as well or be directional to cover a specific area. Just remember in all these examples that unlike WiFi, you can't password protect your extender! It's open to whoever the signal reaches to.Let's start with the simplest cellular antenna replacement; an omni that screws directly in the back of the extender just as the stock one does, but provides greater coverage. I have tested three such antennas. Surprisingly, in spite of claims of higher gain, two of the three replacements were worse than the factory antenna. The third one, a $15 TECHTOO antenna gave about 1 bar of gain over the stock antenna. Not bad for the price, and it is easily the cheapest and quickest way to boost the output from your extender: TECHTOO¬Æ Wide Band 5dbi 700-2600Mhz 3G 4G LTE Omni Directional Antenna with SMA Male Connector for HUAWEI CPE Router B593/B310/B880/E5172/E5175/E5186/B890 / ZTE MF253/MF283/MF25D/MF28G /MF28D (Black). Don't ever tell Verizon you replaced your antenna because it no doubt breaks your warranty. (i.e. keep the original antenna ;>).Moving up the food chain there are replacement antennas that sit apart from the extender and attach with a cable that provide even more gain. If you don't get a blue GPS light in that location you can pull the GPS antenna out of the extender and run a cable to place it in a window (or outside if need be). The extender runs pretty warm to begin with. Placing it in direct sunlight will just make it run hotter and almost certainly shorten its life. I'd much rather stick just the little GPS antenna in a window pane. The lady of the house will likely appreciate the improved aesthetics as well. :>9) MISC:How to tell if you're cell phone is connected to your extender as opposed to a cell tower:Dial #48How to read the signal strength reaching your phone:Android phone: System Settings / About Phone / StatusiPhone:Dial *3001#12345#* (google: "lifehacker See the Actual Signal Strength on Your iPhone" for more)10) Soapboxit would be nice to see Verizon launch the 3rd generation of the extender that included touch-ups like the ability to white list and black list phone number, LEDs that display properly, better setup instructions, and lower pricing. Unfortunately there is a built in conflict of interest here. First, for each call made on an extender, which uses the public internet to route the call as opposed to Verizon's cell tower network, that is one less call Verizon needs to beef up its own network to handle. Plus at $250 to $399 a pop, Verizon is making a handy little profit off you for each extender it sells. Since Verizon is the only supplier of compatible extenders they pretty much own the market for these devices and thus there is no pressure to lower pricing or improve the extender. ;>Cheers!

You have to admit that erecting your own personal cell tower is a pretty cool concept. However, there seems to be a bunch of misleading information about these Verizon network extenders in the reviews and Q&A found throughout Amazon. And the vendor descriptions of the optional external GPS antenna can also be misleading at times. I'm not going to pretend to be an expert, but I've messed with a few of these devices over the years and wish to pass on a few tips regarding what I've learned.TOP 10 THINGS TO KNOW ABOUT THESE NETWORK EXTENDERS1) What models are available?Model SCS-26UC4 - This is the first  version of the extender introduced in 2009 and is no longer being sold by Verizon, but is available used/refurbished through outlets such as Amazon and eBay. The main difference I am aware of is that this older extender only can only download data at "1x" speeds (much slower than 3G). This model also handles fewer simultaneous calls (3) than the updated model noted next. The SCS-26UC4l was reduced in price to $99 (with rebate) when the upgraded model came out, but now usually sells for more used. For a few people however THIS is the preferable model to purchase. I will explain below. BTW - when these extenders first appeared on the market, cell calls placed through them were NOT charged any minutes. It was a truly free call. Those days are long gone as Verizon now charges the minutes based on your calling plan for either extender or cell tower calls.Model SCS-2U01 - This improved model was released around 2010. Mainly it adds 3G data (also known as EVDO or EVolution Data Optimized), so internet speeds are improved. It also handles up to 8 simultaneous calls. These units are still available from Verizon's website, as well as used through 3rd party sites such as Amazon or eBay.Model SCS-2U3100 - This is the 'business' version of the extender, and is available (as of this writing Nov 2015) through Verizon, and again, used via 3rd party sites. This model features self-registration, extended coverage, more simultaneous calls, and can be daisy-chained to up to five business extenders total to greatly increase coverage area. The basic coverage of one unit is advertised as 7,500 sq ft, as opposed to 5,000 sq ft of the model SCS-2U01. To get this range you must register this particular model after it is plugged in and working by dialing #48 on your Verizon cell phone. Until that is done coverage is only a fraction of the 7,500 sq ft advertised.2) Do I need to register my extender?Lots of misconceptions here. NEW extenders purchased from the Verizon website are automatically registered when purchased. The extender is assigned to the Verizon Wireless account you log into (or establish at the time of purchase). The exception is the business model (SCS-2U3100) as described above. USED extenders must also be registered to work (doesn't matter whose account it is registered to), but a used device may or may not be registered when you receive it because the previous owner has the option to UNregister their device.Which begs the perennial question: "Help! Do I need to RE-register my used device onto my own Verizon account, and if so, how?" ANSWER: Don't worry about it. In most cases the extender will work just fine as long as it is registered 'somewhere', and I think it's rare for someone to take the time to UNregister their unit. See the troubleshooting section below if your used device does not work before freaking out about registration. Remember that the extender is a one time cost. There are no recurring costs billed to the Verizon account the extender is associated with. Per minute charges are related to the cell phone used, not the extender. The only reason to get the extender assigned to your own Verizon account is to program the one single feature you have control over, which is to setup a prioritized list of phone numbers. For most people though this is a pathetic feature. Reason being, contrary to what's stated in several reviews you can't actually BLOCK certain phones from using the extender. All you can do is enter a list of cell phones that get priority... meaning if all the available slots are used (8 for the current non-business model SCS2U01) then any phone initiating a call whose number is entered in the priority list will bump someone off who is not on the list. Big deal. How many people are going to have 8 simultaneous calls running?Being able to actually block certain numbers from using the device (black listing) and/or allow only certain numbers (white listing) would be a far more practical feature for most residential use. Why? Because an extender can often transmit a cell signal up to hundreds of feet (depending). ANYONE can use that signal... for voice or data! Do you want a bunch of yahoos you don't know using up YOUR internet bandwidth while they try and connect to Netflix via their smartphone and take in a movie? And if you have a data cap on your internet service the issue is compounded. Under the current implementation of the extender (all models) that is exactly what can happen. That is why for some people the older model (SCS-26UC4), which has only 1x data speeds, is preferable. At least with a 1x extender it will throttle any strangers' attempt to gobble up your internet connection.3) Do I  need an external antenna?Misinformation abounds regarding this question. The first thing to understand is that your extender has TWO antennas. The little antenna sticking out of the back of the device is for transmitting (and receiving) the cell signal. The closer a cell phone is to this cellular antenna the more bars appear on the phone.Inside the extender (under the hatch cover on top toward the rear) is the GPS antenna. This antenna has NOTHING to do with the strength of the cell signal or the quality of the call. It's there simply to identify the location of the extender for 911 calls and whatnot. I bring this to your attention because the folks who sell aftermarket external GPS antennas occasionally will lead consumers to believe that their extender will work better and you will "get more out of your extender" if you buy an external GPS antenna. Poppycock. Very simply, if the GPS LED is solid blue you don't need another GPS antenna. Repeat, if the GPS LED is blue you are good to go. See below if your GPS LED is red. In that case you may or may not need an external GPS antenna.With that question hopefully settled what remains is; do you need a different cellular antenna? There are indeed aftermarket cellular antennas that can a) increase the range of your extender, and b) focus the signal in a specific area. The stock cell antenna is omnidirectional or just "omni", meaning it covers a full 360 degree area. Replacement antennas may be omni as well or be directional to cover a specific area. Just remember in all these examples that unlike WiFi, you can't password protect your extender! It's open to whoever the signal reaches to.Let's start with the simplest cellular antenna replacement; an omni that screws directly in the back of the extender just as the stock one does, but provides greater coverage. I have tested three such antennas. Surprisingly, in spite of claims of higher gain, two of the three replacements were worse than the factory antenna. The third one, a $15 TECHTOO antenna gave about 1 bar of gain over the stock antenna. Not bad for the price, and it is easily the cheapest and quickest way to boost the output from your extender: TECHTOO¬Æ Wide Band 5dbi 700-2600Mhz 3G 4G LTE Omni Directional Antenna with SMA Male Connector for HUAWEI CPE Router B593/B310/B880/E5172/E5175/E5186/B890 / ZTE MF253/MF283/MF25D/MF28G /MF28D (Black). Don't ever tell Verizon you replaced your antenna because it no doubt breaks your warranty. (i.e. keep the original antenna ;>).Moving up the food chain there are replacement antennas that sit apart from the extender and attach with a cable that provide even more gain. I have one of these on order (Wilson Electronics 800/1900 MHz Magnet Mount Antenna with SMA Male Connector - Retail Packaging - Black), and will update the review after trying it out.If you wish to direct the signal from the extender in a specific direction (excluding other areas from coverage) you need a 'directional' antenna. For example Wilson makes a so-called 'panel' (flat) directional antenna that mounts on the wall and beams the cellular signal in a roughly 70 degree pattern across the horizon. This antenna provides a significant boost in coverage over the aforementioned omni models because of its size, and because the signal is not being radiated in all directions. The model # that has the correct "SMA" plug for your extender is 311135 (WILSON ELECTRONICS 311135 Dual-Band 50_ Wall-Mount Panel Antenna).Finally, there are many aftermarket cell "boosters" that come with an amplifier and antenna. How do those fit into the equation? I know little of such devices though, except to state with some certainty that boosters cannot distinguish between a Verizon network extender and a "real" cell tower (it's like some version of the old Beggin' Strips commercials: "Dogs don't know it's not a cell tower!"). But to give you an idea, these devices typically have an antenna that you point at the cell tower (or in this case the network extender) and then another antenna that sits on a desk or counter that shoots the signal around the room. Why would you want one of these products? It might make sense if you get good coverage with the Verizon extender around the house but have, say, a pool house or other remote building that only gets a bar or two of coverage. Boosters can cost more than an extender so you have to be prudent here. There is a well rated Wilson amplifier kit costing about $200 that would pick up the signal from the extender at a distance and then re-transmit the signal locally (Wilson Electronics  DT - Cell Phone Signal Boost for Small Home or Office - Retail Packaging - Gray). If you don't have internet at the remote location this product might be a wise choice. But if you do have internet you have to weight the cost against simply purchasing another extender.4) The lights will not all turn blue on my extender!OK. The following bits of knowledge came at the expense of blood, sweat, and even a tear or two. So listen up. Unless all other lights turn blue the SYS LED won't turn blue. From there, decoding the "Verizon Code" varies according to whether you have the older 1x model (SCS-26UC4) or the newer 3G model (SCS-2U01)...On the older SCS-26UC4 the GPS LED tends to stays red (solid or flashing) REGARDLESS of what the issue is (like network/internet connection issue or GPS lock issues). For example if the internet connection is down, it's the GPS light that often stays red, not the WAN (Wide Area Network) light as it should. So you have to ignore what the manual says about the LEDs and assume you may have either network issues or GPS issues. Or if you're having a bad hair day, perhaps both. Don't despair, keep reading.Here is a list of issues I've discovered that will prevent the GPS LED from turning blue:a) Extender not registeredb) Hardware failure (rare)c) Incompatible internet routerd) Internet router unpluggede) Internet connection downf) extender is geographically outside Verizon's licensed frequency rangeand finallyg) weak GPS signal (the extender can't see enough GPS satellites to lock to)The above list applies to the newer SCS-2U01 units as well, except the LEDs on that model give better indication as to the issue. If you have a WAN (Internet connection) issue I've found that the WAN light appropriately stays flashing or solid red. The Achilles Heel of the SCS-2U01 is that the  SYS LED will sometimes go blue (which normally indicates all systems are go) temporarily, even if the WAN LED is red. Go figure. Neither model will work however until all lights are blue.But actually, the REAL Achilles Heel of the SCS-2U01 is that it is surprisingly incompatible with a number of brands of internet routers out there. I first spotted an Amazon review noting this, and we too have gone to extender purgatory more than once due to the extender not liking the router. Coverage on how to determine if your extender is cool with your router is in the following troubleshooting section...MAKING THE LIGHTS TURN BLUEa) Wait. Do nothing for an hour or two after you've placed the unit near a window and plugged in power and a network cable running to your router. It can take a newly setup extender that long to lock to GPS and turn all the LEDs blue.b) Be sure the extender is registered. It doesn't matter to what Verizon account. This mostly applies to used units. Try to register the extender to your Verizon Wireless account. Whether the registration is successful or the system complains the device is already registered, you're good to go either way. If the extender is registered to another account then only if you really really want to set which cell phone numbers have priority do you want to go through the hellish experience of actually talking to Verizon and coaxing them to transfer the device into your name. Reviewers report mixed results on this endeavor. And as previously mentioned, charges will NOT rack up on the account of the previous owner. Charges are based on the cell phone using the extender, not the extender itself.c) GPS lock. For the older SCS-26UC4 regardless of what its lights are doing, or the newer SCS-2U01 if its GPS light stays red for more than an hour or two, make sure the extender is placed in view of the open sky. Sticking it near a window is not a guarantee of a GPS lock. Try to place the unit outside where the sky is most open. You must have both power and Ethernet cables connected so you are limited by the length of your cords. THEN WAIT AT LEAST TWO HOURS. If the GPS and SYS light go solid blue in that time you probably need an external GPS antenna.Anecdote: At one of our locations we have a good view of the sky but there are tall redwood trees in one direction and a hill in another direction. This was enough to require an external GPS antenna to get clear of the obstructions. If your extender came with a separate GPS cable then you can simply unplug the GPS antenna (you wiggle it out of its socket) and plug in the cable in its place. If you don't have a cable you can get a 20 footer from Amazon (Universal 20' Antenna Extension SMB Male to SMB Female extention cable 20ft 6M compatiable with SIRIUS XM Radio Garmin GPS Receiver). Sometimes its cheaper to just get the cable with a GPS antenna. I purchased a cheapo $10 GPS antenna here on Amazon (External GPS Antenna with SMB female for Verizon Samsung 3G Network Extender plus led light key chain) with a nearly 10ft cable. So far it works great and has born up against the rain. Also, a company called GILSSON sells a variety of GPS antennas that look to be good quality and have longer length cables available. I have one on order and will update this review after it's been in operation for a while.NOTE: At the time of this writing the only Amazon reseller offering the Gilsson line is a vendor called NAVSPHERE. With a reseller rating of a miserable 86% I therefore chose to pick mine up off eBay.d) Internet connection. There are two things to try here. First, plug the network cable coming from the extender into a port on the router that is already being used by another device and wait 20 minutes. The logic here is simple; individual ports on routers go bad. Second -and this addresses the router incompatibility issue- temporarily plug your extender directly into your broadband connection. Don't worry about rebooting the equipment, just wait 20 minutes. If the lights all turn blue your extender does not like your router.On this last note we were able to solve the problem of two different routers being incompatible with an extender. It's technical but I'll attempt to explain in plain English. In both our cases the router did not have 'DHCP' turned on. This is the service that hands out IP addresses to all devices when they connect (either wirelessly or via plugged into a port on the router). The extender is no exception. It needs an IP address to work. On some more complex home/small office networks another piece of equipment on the network may have the job of assigning IP addresses. But it seems the Verizon network extender wants to get its IP address from the router it is plugged into. So before shopping for a new router have your tech person check to see if DHCP is enabled on the router.After all the above if the unit still won't turn all blue this reviewer is out of ideas. It might be a bad extender, or perhaps you live outside Verizon's "licensed spectrum". Verizon has a coverage map that refers to "Broadband Services ... coverage area", "... enhanced Services ... coverage area", "Extended Broadband Services ... coverage area", "Extended National..." bla blah blah. It's nearly as complicated as the tax code.5) Can I use the extender with satellite internet?Definitely maybe. You probably know that all calls on a Verizon network extender are routed through your internet connection. Call quality therefore is only as good as your connection to the internet. Normally this is not an issue as voice traffic only needs a fraction of the bandwidth required for, say, music and video. Still, voice traffic is "real time" and any hiccups on your internet connection will reflect in call quality, With satellite internet this core equation is multiplied, as the packets of info (voice or data) take a 45,000 mile trip to space and back in addition to wherever else they're headed. And that's just one-way. Still, it can work, albeit with a noticeable delay on each end of the call. You will hear people going :"Hello. Hello??" because they don't hear you right away. I would recommend being on the latest and greatest satellite service for best results. We are on Wildblue EXEDE and it works OK. At times the EXEDE network gets bogged down and call quality can greatly suffer. This is definitely a Plan B solution.6) Will my non-Verizon prepaid phone that uses the Verizon network work OK?Yes! Any non-Verizon pre-paid phone that uses the Verizon network such as TracFone, StraightTalk and others seems to work fine with the extender (which is interesting because such phones are reported to not work on all Verizon cell towers). The only "downside" is that you cannot use these phones to register your extender, because you cannot create a Verizon Wireless account with such phones. If you don't have any actual Verizon phones you can't buy the extender from Verizon because you must have an account to do so. This where Amazon and eBay and such come in. You can just buy the device from such sources. If it arrives already registered you're set. If it is not registered, any friend or relative with a Verizon phone can register it to their account. This in no way affects their service and no charges are levied. See the registration section in this review which explains why I am claiming this.7) Should I buy my extender NEW or USED!!I have to say, I love buying used to save a little money. Bottom line, the used market is about PRICE and RETURNABILITY. If the price is well bellow the $250 dollar cost new, AND you have patience for things maybe going more wrong at first than with a new unit, AND you can return the unit with no hassle, then fine. Just remember also, if you have the Chutzpah to go toe to toe with Verizon about how they SHOULD be pumping 3 or 4 bars into you locale you might get an extender out of them at a discount or for free. It happens, but it may take some tenacity.8) Where should I place my extender?The thing is, the ideal location to get a GPS lock may not be the ideal place for best coverage of the areas important to you. The saving grace is that both the GPS antenna and/or the cellular antenna can be remotely located from the extender. My first strategy would be to go for placing the extender itself in a nice central location for coverage to your phones. If you don't get a blue GPS light in that location you can pull the GPS antenna out of the extender and run a cable to place it in a window (or outside if need be). I like this strategy for two reasons; 1) it is easier and cheaper to remote the GPS antenna than it is the cellular antenna. 2) I don't think its necessarily wise to follow conventional wisdom and keep the extender itself in a window to get a GPS lock. The extender runs pretty warm to begin with. Placing it in direct sunlight will just make it run hotter and almost certainly shorten its life. I'd much rather stick just the little GPS antenna in a window pane. The lady of the house will likely appreciate the improved aesthetics as well. :>9) MISC:How to tell if you're cell phone is connected to your extender as opposed to a cell tower:Dial #48How to read the signal strength reaching your phone:Android phone: System Settings / About Phone / StatusiPhone:Dial *3001#12345#* (google: "lifehacker See the Actual Signal Strength on Your iPhone" for more)10) Soapboxit would be nice to see Verizon launch the 3rd generation of the extender that included touch-ups like the ability to white list and black list phone number, LEDs that display properly, better setup instructions, and lower pricing. Unfortunately there is a built in conflict of interest here. First, for each call made on an extender, which uses the public internet to route the call as opposed to Verizon's cell tower network, that is one less call Verizon needs to beef up its own network to handle. Plus at $250 to $399 a pop, Verizon is making a handy little profit off you for each extender it sells. Since Verizon is the only supplier of compatible extenders they pretty much own the market for these devices and thus there is no pressure to lower pricing or improve the extender. ;>Cheers!
