Despite appearances, this review contains no real spoilers.This movie may at first appear to be a turkey, but stick with it. I don't even know how the DVD ended up in my Netflix queue. I like James Garner (Wyatt Earp in Hour of the Gun and Jim Rockford in The Rockford Files), but not enough to pull down his entire filmology. But there it was in my mailbox so I fired it up. I nearly stopped the movie twice during the first 20 minutes or so. Initially the film gives off the scent of a poor attempt at being a light hearted war comedy.But the root dialog, once they get to it, catapults well over the top of the outdated opening (with James Garner's character giving every Navy Wave who comes in range a pat on the behind).The fanny patting stops however when Garner tries it out on prim, proper, fresh faced Julie Andrews (Mary Poppins, The Sound of Music), who plays Emily. She slaps his face good, and the movie upshifts a gear, but we're still not there. We first need to be exposed to what appears to be the Garner character's main claim to fame. He plays a procurement expert for a Navy admiral. He's good at obtaining things you're not supposed to be able to obtain during war, especially WWII England. You're not sure if his character will be similar to Jon Voight's highly enterprising 1st Lt. Milo Minderbinder in 'Catch 22'... or perhaps the more conservative obtainer of the unobtainable, Ensign Pulver in John Ford's classic 'Mr. Roberts'... or maybe the unabashed and hilarious 'Crap game' character in 'Kelly's Hero's', played by comedian Don Rickles. But it soon doesn't matter because Garner's real mettle, which comes out in a conversation with his newly acquired girlfriend's mother (the girlfriend being Julie Andrews), which reveals the character is about far more than then acquiring fine liquor, French perfume, and gourmet steaks (and fanny patting).Watch the movie up to the conversation Garner has with Julie Andrews's mother. That is where this film actually begins. Then you will know if the movie is worth your time. All the little spoilers I've been giving you up till now in fact spoil nothing, because, again, the movie begins here. Enjoy!Signed,former patter of a small handful of fannies

Great enclosure. I have this mounted on a wooden telephone pole in extreme conditions of wind and rain. Every time I open the enclosure all that I find is the odd spider web or two. Never any signs of water stains. Unit includes a double 110AC outlet at the bottom of the box, with an adjacent knockout for another double outlet.

The one thing I've noticed about Dell hardware is that it usually outlives the software. Our older Optiplex was humming along just fine, but Dell did not release any of the required hardware drivers (to drive the network card, video display, etc.) for an OS other than WINXP, so we had to upgrade. But out of the several dozen Dell laptops, desktops, and servers I've touched over the years, nary a one has had a hardware failure other then the odd hard drive failure from time to time. Dell hardware -especially the business class Optiplex line- is essentially bullet-proof.The refurbished market however adds a layer of variables to the purchase of a used computer, albeit Dell or any other maker. I was therefore delighted to receive this computer from CORETEK and find that it surpassed my [somewhat tempered] expectations. The computer was packed and shipped in a professional manner similar to how a new Dell arrives from the factory. Custom sized box and foam retainer fit the computer perfectly. Each component packaged individually (computer, keyboard, mouse, power cord). Clear and concise documentation regarding the specifics of the refurbished aspect of the unit, with a printed product key for Windows 7 HOME (with a 90 day support warranty), and -surprise surprise surprise- (that's my Gomer Pyle imitation) an actual Windows DVD. I had forgotten what they look like.The computer booted up perfectly and the Device Manager showed no dreaded yellow exclamation points for missing drivers. Well done CORETEK!

I bought this device to take to the local nightclub to detect when women were attracted to me. Read 0.0 all night. That can't be right.Then I took it to work to see if it would detect when my boss was lying to me. My boss told me I was doing a good job, when in fact I do next to nothing at work. The device did not pick up her deception.Then I tried to see if it would detect when I start to smell bad so I'd know it was time for a shower. Everyone shifted to the other side of the elevator when I got on, yet not a peep from this so-called detector.Then I took it to the beach to locate old coins in the sand. Nada.So, it can't detect ‚ô•‚ô•, BS, BO, or $$.Oh. It *does* accurately detect beta, gamma, and X-ray ionizing radiation and reads out either in microSieverts or microRoentgens, has a night display, an audible and vibrating warning when radiation spikes, and comes in a small yet sturdy all-in-one housing, and uses easy to replace batteries..... if you're into that sort of thing.

This product is actually sold for less $$ on the actual zmax website. As of this writing (Feb 17th, 2014) the single treatment lists here for $15.31 + $9.99 shipping. You can make the same purchase on the zmax site for a few dollars less. And, for $3.00 more you can get the entire 4 part kit on the same site. Be sure to click on specials to obtain the free shipping discount code. (HINT: The bottle of Small Engine Forumla can be used in your car engine. It's the same stuff as the engine treatment. So the kit is an even better deal).Now for two amazing zmax stories:Story #1: I had just bought a Honda Accord with 110K and an automatic transmission. Upon taking it on the freeway I noticed a problem with the tranny that I hadn't picked up on while test driving the vehicle (darn it). Once the car hit about 60MPH the overdrive cut in (effectively a 4th gear). But the moment I backed off on the accelerator the overdrive would instantly disengage, then re-engage a moment later. The effect was quite jarring and happened every time.Out of desperation I bought a bottle of the zmax transmission treatment and added it to the car (I had seen the old commercials on TV where they drive a car treated with zmax hundreds of miles with no oil in the pan). Within a couple of days of adding the treatment the bucking of the overdrive cutting out and in had completely stopped, and NEVER HAPPENED AGAIN AS LONG AS I OWNED THE CAR.Story #2. This one's even better. I had a Toyota Corolla, again with the automatic transmission. Out of the blue the tranny started making a noise. A loud noise. It happened mostly while backing up (gear shifter in reverse). It was a terrible scraping noise that sounded like metal on metal, like two garbage can lids being rubbed together. Again, out of sheer desperation, I bought a bottle of the zmax tranny treatment and poured it in (and no, the transmission was a tad low, but not empty of fluid). I swear, the sound stopped and HAS NEVER RETURNED!

What is going here? As of Feb 15th 2014 this product is listing for $129 and up. Huh? I bought mine last year for $14.95. This IS a $10-20 unit and is in NOW WAY worth a penny more. It does NOTHING other than play audio. No music controls, no hands free calling, nothing other than plug into a standard 3.5mm jack of any old digital music player that has one. There are dozens of FM xmitters that do what this thing does for $10-20. The vendors listing this item are either crazy, or, they think you are.I might also mention that the only reason I came to this page was because mine BROKE, and in fact has been failing intermittently for months. But not it failed completely and I am in the process of testing the warranty service of the distributor. Will report back with an update when they respond.UPDATE: I contacted the reseller who sold me my unit through Amazon, TripleNet Pricing, and they flat out refused to help with warranty service, not even providing me the manufacturer's contact information. I then googled the manufacturer, Coby Electronics Corporation, and found they went out of business late last year. They were reportedly bought by 'Gordon Brothers', who is not honoring the warranties. So now what is on sale is a questionable product, at a ridiculously high price, with a questionable warranty. So I just bought a similar item (Excelvan FM Transmitter Car Charger Adapter For BlackBerry /Sony / Samsung and mp3/mp4 Player) that is well reviewed on Amazon, however I hasten to add this item is far less expensive on eBay.

I just went through four backlit keyboards trying to find one that that is actually usable. The first Three failed miserably, but this Logitech keyboard really fits the bill. Bright white backlight, ez to press keys with a fluid yet certain stroke, firm base, thin yet sturdy. Really one of the better keyboards I've ever used, backlight or no backlight. This keyboard comes in both wired and wireless versions as well. I personally prefer the wired version simply because it's just that much less RF in the living area.Having said that however, there are a few flaws in the design of this keyboard that belie the "logic" intimated by the manufacturer's name. Here are some thoughts on How Logitech could could achieve 5 stars for this keyboard:1) Take a look in the closeup photo of [what should be] the six keys above the arrow keys (INS, DEL, HOME, END, PgUp, PgDn). But wait, there are only five keys. The INS key is missing! It has been moved way up top to the function key row, ostensibly replacing the SCROLL LOCK key. Now it's OK to dump SCROLL LOCK (I personally have never used it except by mistake), but why did they move the oft used INS key? Longtime keyboarders are used to a six key grouping in a stacked two row arrangement. This is going to really mess up touch typists, but also if you look at the keyboard to type, then when you need one of those key you instinctively look for the GROUPING PATTERN as much as the text on the keys. Since the DEL key on this keyboard is now a single long key that spans both rows I found that when seeking DEL my hand instinctively went to the lower key on the stacked set... which is the END key. Totally through me off and now I must train my mind (if you have ever been asked for a phone number that you know but can't recall until you walk over to a phone and mimic the dialing pattern you know what I mean). Why? Why did you do this Logitech? To add to the confusion, the lettering on the DEL key is near the top rather than centered... and it is the lettering that is lit up, so at night when relaying on mainly the backlighting to type, the DEL looks even more out of place. I might point out that the wireless version of this model, which seems nearly identical to the wired version, maintains the traditional six key pattern. What was the wired design team smokin'?2) Another flaw in this otherwise awesome keyboard is the lighting of the function keys. If you look at the photo you will notice that the F1-F12 keys are now *alternate function* keys, meaning you must press the FN key in tandem with a function key to get the legacy function such as F1 for Help (although thankfully when accessing the thesaurus in MS Word SHIFT+F7 still works).Perhaps this is a reasonable move to people who don't use the traditional function keys much, and instead prefer the new primary functions Logitech has assigned to those 12 keys, such as start a program like mail or music. I tied to adapt to the Logitech paradigm, but the first time I went to send an email and hit the email key (what used to be F2) instead of sensing that my email program was already running (Outlook) and open up a new send mail window in the foreground, the key instead triggered a second instance of Outlook to open. Not all that helpful.One other drawback to this new F key layout is that if you go to use the legacy functions keys in dim light, the F1-F12 labels that are now on the front portion of the keys are not backlit. Hello?! Logitech? This is why we bought the keyboard.... to see the keys in the dark! Neither are the labels on the PRINT SCREEN and PAUSE keys lit, instead, just the funny looking (and too small to make sense) symbols next to the label. The symbols are lit, but not the text right next to them that we've been using to identify those key as long as we've been keyboarding. Again.... what were the designers thinking? Why not just light up the whole key?3) The cord. What happened here? Here you have this beautiful, smooth, silky, feels-just-right keyboard, and attached to it is the scrawniest, stiffest USB cord I have ever born witness to. It is so stiff it tends to remain in whatever coiled, twisted, kinked position it has worked its way into, rather than smoothly and naturally unkinking itself when stretched out. The cord is like the anti-matter opposite of the keyboard itself. It's convincing evidence that wherever there is good... it's evil twin opposite naturally arises (a.k.a. Data and Lore). This seems to be a fundamental law of the cosmos, so maybe the design team is not to blame here.4) Finally, the "programability" of the keyboard is weak. Logitech provides its SetPoint software that allows the user to reprogram certain keys. Great, except the software seems needlessly limited. The first thing I wanted to do was assign a string of characters I type often (my full name) to a function key. Can't do it. You can only assign a single letter to a key. To achieve the capability I assumed was there -known as a macro- you must install a 3rd party utility... and hope it's compatible with your version of Windows. It would be great to see Logitech add the ability to assign a string of characters to a single key.----------------------For your reference the three keyboards that did not pass muster:1) AULA wired gaming keyboard (AULA BE FIRE 3 Colors LED Backlit Expert Gaming Wired Keyboard). Even though it is a full sized keyboard the keys themselves are smaller than normal. Moreover, instead of stenciling the key labels on dual function keys in top/bottom arrangement ("@" symbol above the "2") they placed the labels side-by-side which is just plain BIZARRE. The action on the keys was nowhere near this Logitech unit. Furthermore, instead of backlighting just the keys, the entire base of keyboard is unnecessarily lit up. Rather distracting.2)(Impecca KBL200 Slim Illuminated Keyboard - Large Font - Bright LED Backlit Keys). This keyboard has very large easy to read keys, and in fact would be a good choice for someone actually vision impaired. The tradeoff however is the terrible feel to the keys. A bit sticky. No fluid action at all. I had many missed keystrokes. This keyboard is not even in the same ballpark as the Logitech.3) I also found a backlit keyboard on eBay that was quite promising (search eBay: KBA-TG82R-BTURUS Backlit Sealed Surface Keyboard w/ Touchpad). This is a compact keyboard, with the keypad removed to reduce its size. The action on this keyboard at first seems GREAT. The whole keyboard is coated with a rubbery material that has a very solid feel to it. The Achilles heel with the unit however is that it takes an unusual amount of pressure to actuate a key. There is a pleasant and reassuring click of sorts when you make a letter, but you have to mentally focus on being sure you press hard enough to make that letter. Worse, the space bar only has actuators on each end, but none in the middle. So you have to press extra hard to make a space if your finger happens to land in the middle of the space bar.

Well it's made in China, but it's not your run of the mill Chinese mass production /minimal QC strategy. This drive caddy is smart from head to toe. Smart design, smart look, smart packaging, and smart marketing.I've had mine only two days, but it transferred a terabyte of data flawlessly as I upgraded to a new computer. The unit comes with a both a USB 2 and USB 3 cable, and being relatively new to USB 3 I decided to run some comparison tests. Copying a 1GIG file I got the following readings:Drive caddy to USB3 using USB3 cable: 25 secsDrive caddy to USB3 using USB2 cable: 45 secsDrive caddy to USB2 using USB2 cable: 48 secsObviously a USB3 cable is mandatory for achieving USB3 speeds, and the one included with the drive, although relatively short at just over 3', is stout and sturdy. It's also a plus that the company who sells the the drive is smart enough to market it properly on Amazon. They realize the damage bad reviews can do and actually seem to address customer's problems when they arise. I've seen so many no-nothing-about-the-product PR specialists for a manufacturer *act* like they are helping by posting patronizing, self-serving, feel-good messages that do noting to help, that this approach is refreshing.Long live USB3! (until USB4 comes out)

When I was perusing these reviews to ascertain if this show was worth the time, I saw someone had said that 'The Duchess of Duke Street' was every bit as good a Downton Abbey and Upstairs/Downstairs. To me the gulf between Downton and Upstairs could be measured in miles so I dismissed the review. Downton is a rare gem that occurs only when story, acting, direction, set/production, and all those other ineffable, hard to quantify qualities come together to make *magic*. That series stands alone. I had just come down from watching first Downton and then the good but not great current rendition of Upstairs when it was time to consider this series.Wow. Magic! It's here. But, it's a different kind of magic. With Downton the magic is apparent in the very first episode. Not necessarily so with Duchess. It takes a while for this series to show its stuff, but the ride is absolutely worthwhile. The lead character Mrs. Trotter (the Duchess), is a bit harsh and abrasive. They did not draw her as likeable (which is actually refreshing). I have no idea what the real person Mrs. Trotter was based on was like, but if you suppress any reflexive urge to turn the show off because of Trotter's demeanor you will be rewarded with a rich and varied tale that winds it way through the events leading up to, during, and after WWI.In fact, I would venture to say that Duchess at the very least rivaled, if not surpassed, conveying the devastating effect the war had on Britain. Regardless, the breadth and depth of this series as a whole is nearly unparalleled. An array of writers produced a far flung, eclectic set of stories such that you never know what's coming next. You are taken here, there, and everywhere as the life and times of Mrs. Trotter - and the people in her life- unfold for your viewing pleasure. By the end of the series you are in love with all the characters (I particularly loved the head waiter) and truly sorry to see it all end. I cried. I am a man, and I cried. More than once. Not an empty drama for the sake of drama. It makes you think as well as emote.

There used to be a TV show called "Mystery Science Theatre 3000', where a human and an assortment of mechanized miscreants would watch a really lame movie and crack jokes throughout, talking over the dialog. It was one of the best shows around, so naturally they took it off the air. The show was at its best when poking fun at films with highly implausible plots and silly dialog. Throw in a few models/actresses attempting to impersonate tough policemen and you had a theme the MST3K gang could really work with. Regrettably, MST3K is gone for good, so fodder such as 'The Last Stand' cannot be serviced properly. In lieu of that we bring you an excerpt from Saturday Night Live's `Pumping Up with Hans & Franz', where in some far off quantum reality Dana Carvey and Kevin Nealon are still animating these most entertaining characters... who try to imitate their hero/god Arnold Schwarzenegger.We cut live now to the show as it opens:Hans: I'm Hanz!Franz: And I'm Franz!H&F: And we just want to... pump [clap] you up!Hans: Hey Franz! Look at this on the te-le-vi-sion! It's an Arnold Schwarz-en-egger movie!Franz: That's impossible. Arnold doesn't make movies any more.Hans: No! No! It's him. It's Arnold! He's a massive dy-na-mo... flexing his massive biceps and shooting everything all around him. He plays an ex-cop from Caleefornia.Franz: Hans you ignorant slob. That is NOT Arnold. That's an Arnold-wannabe. Look. It's some girlie-man wearing an old man Arnold mask.Hans: What? That's not Arnold?Franz: No. Look at him. Look at that physique. Look at the flab!Hanz: Oh Franz, you may be right. He's a flabby girlie-man!Franz: Oh yah Hanz. That is a flaborama.Hans: Yah. He needs a flabondectomy.Franz: Yah. Arnold will NEVER look like that horrifying flabomaster of a girlie-man.Hans: Yah. He needs to take his mask off and show himself for the girlie-man he truly is!Franz: Hey Hans! Let's call Arnold and tell him to look at the phony flabby man. Arnold can work out his fabulous muscles and talk to us at the same time.Hans: Good idea Franz.... ring... ring... ring.Franz: Is he there?Hans: No. I got an answering machine. It says he is on vacation after wrapping up `The Last Stand'.... ... ...... ... ...Franz: Let's watch `Walking Tall'.Hans: Yah. Joe Don Baker is a REAL man.Franz: Yah.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_and_Franz

Hello?! Did I hear another reviewer say "ok, but nothing amazing."? Wow. I would like to taste the cookies that person thinks are amazing, because these oatmeal chocolate chip cookies are the THE BEST cookies I've ever tasted in my ENTIRE LIFE. They're the best ever. It's not Mrs. Fields folks, nor Toll House, nor even the fresh baked -and sometimes even warm- chocolate chip cookies sitting in the lobby of Doubletree hotels. Nooooooooo. No, Uncle Eddie cookies are bar-none the best cookies in the known universe. They rule over all other cookies.I have it on good authority that The Cookie Monster loves these cookies best!!!When I dream, I dream in *UncleEddieVision*. (copyright 2014)If I was trapped on a desert island and could only bring minimal food stuffs... these babies would be on the list. Bart Simpson used to claim that Butterfingers were a major food group. Wrong! It's these puppies! They are too die for! You can't live without them. They're death cookies.And speaking of that, if I *was* on my death bed and my family asked me if I had any last wishes, I would beg for a case of these cookies.If I committed a capitol crime (physically impossible for anyone on Uncle Eddie's cookies), and was sent to the chair... for my last meal I would request to dine exclusively on these goby gooey treats.Conversely, if you die and have to spend some time in Purgatory, I hear they serve Uncle Eddie's cookies in the waiting room. So what's to worry? Well, you do want to avoid dropping down into that 'other place' ... they actually serve these cookies there as well, but they have no taste. True damnation.Uncle Eddie's cookies should be standard issue in the army, on ambulances, and on St. Bernard rescue kits. All airline and hospital food should be jettisoned in favor of these cookies. If I was President I would make Uncle Eddie's the National Cookie. The world would be a better place.If I was given the choice between eating one single Uncle Eddie's Vegan Oatmeal chocolate chip cookie, or going on a date with the most beautiful woman in the world... I'd take the woman. (I'm not stupid).

One whiff of this product and it is quite clear it is the real deal... very potent.. i.e. concentrated. I purchased for help with a respiratory condition. Truthfully, I'm taking several other oils and supplements as well, so it is hard to quantify the efficacy of this particular oil. However, I use the science of Applied Kinesiology for all purchased supplements and this Marjoram oil product tested as being exactly what it claims to be.---------------------------------------------I use Applied Kinesiology for determining efficacy of food and supplements. In twenty plus years I've found it to be the single best diagnostic tool available. After trying out a number of super low-cost LED based solar lights listed on Amazon -all of which originate from China- I came to the conclusion that virtually every device I purchased is on the one hand useful and workable, while on the other hand is very cheaply made. Very simple designs... very low cost components... mass produced with minimal QC. The result is a light that basically does work but has high failure rates. That's the business model, and we consumers help drive that model with our bargain hunting sensors always on full alert.One of the two lights I ordered one failed almost immediately, thus a 50% failure rate. But that was easy to remedy thanks to Amazon's liberal return policies. And it was worth the trouble because these really are great lights. I might note that depending upon the supplier (and quite probably other factors) you may receive one of at least two different versions of this light fixture. One version is as pictured, with an opaque, protruding dome cover, and another model that has a flat, transparent cover that exposes the LEDs (you can actually see the little LEDs making up the array. I much prefer the latter model, both because it's just cooler looking, as well the fact that the one that died was the former design.I tried to post a couple of customers images to show you the different styles, as well as the innards, but can't seem to do so for this product. Finally, for anyone finding that the light does not stay on in dim mode all night you can replace the stock battery with a higher capacity battery. The unit comes with a 4.5 volt battery, so I used three AAA replacements installed into one of these inexpensive carriers (2Pcs Spring Clip 3 x 1.5V AAA Battery Holder Case Box Wire). The carrier just fits in the enclosure. Unlike many of the solar lights I've been trying out, the battery in this unit is not technically replaceable (it does not plug in to a socket), but the leads are long enough that anyone handy with a wire cutter/stripper can swap in the replacement carrier ez-pz (no soldering required). The light must of course receive enough sunlight to charge the higher capacity battery set.

These did the trick for an application involving strapping a large antenna to a pole. I've never used 'quick release' clamps before but I really like them over conventional hose clamps. You can pivot the screw out of the way and quickly enlarge or tighten the clamp, then swing the screw assembly in place and tighten.Quality seemed fine. Clamps tightened firmly with no slippage.

Whilst scanning Amazon for a USB CD/DVD writer, I spotted an ASUS unit -a well established and highly reputable brand- and the price and review ratings were good, so I bought it. Upon receiving the drive and copying some files off a CD to a solid state hard drive (SSD) it seemed the drive was a bit pokey on the transfer rate. So I ordered two other USB writers from Amazon; a Samsung unit and this Amazon Basics unit. After timing the transfer rate on all three drives, as well as measuring the transfer rate on my four year old HP DV6 laptop for reference, I realized that the ASUS was not so pokey after all... but I also stumbled on the fact the Samsung unit was three times faster than any of the other drives, including my laptop! All told I think the Samsung is a better deal. Here is a mini-review:Drive models tested:ASUS External Slim 8X DVD-RW Writer (ASUS External Slim 8X DVD-RW Stylish Cut Design Optical Drive SDRW-08D2S-U/BLK/G/AS)Samsung USB 2.0 Ultra Portable External DVD Writer (Samsung USB 2.0 Ultra Portable External DVD Writer Model SE-218CB/RSBS)AmazonBasics USB 2.0 8x DVD Writer (AmazonBasics USB 2.0 8x DVD Writer External Optical Drive (Black))Speed Tests:Transfer Rate (copy 266MB file from CDROM to SSD) Windows 8.1ASUS drive.............1.25MB/s avg (3 minutes 18 seconds)Samsung drive..........3.0MB/s  avg (1 minutes 35 seconds)Amazon Basics drive....1.10MB/s avg (3 minutes 25 seconds)HP laptop..............1.2MB/s  avg (3 minutes 20 seconds)Included Software:ASUS drive............A couple of power management utilities, and a link to a firmware upgrade procedure that did not work.Samsung drive.........Nero Express Essentials v12 (media management utilities, backup utilities, media player*, firmware updater)Amazon Basics drive...Cyberlink Media Suite v10 (media management utilities, no media player)* requires $5 upgrade to play MPEG media such as DVD moviesI did not run any burning benchmarks, mainly because I was short of blank media at the time. But the ASUS and the Amazon Basics units would have to have some remarkably better burn speeds over the Samsung to beat it out, given that I read from CD/DVD media far more often that I write to it. The Samsung also has the best bundled software. It actually comes with a media player, albeit a crippled one that requires an update to play DVD movies encoded with the popular MPEG-2 compression codec. To be fair, a royalty is paid to the MPEG mafia for each unit of player software that includes the MPEG codec (the word is that Windows 8 doesn't include a media player for MPEG movies because Microsoft no longer wanted to pay a $2 license fee to distribute the codecs in a world increasingly moving to streaming media).

This tea was recommended by a friend a long time ago when I was having respiratory problems. It did help, and subsequent use over the years indicates this is a good general drink for improving/healing the respiratory system. It also seems to help speed up a sluggish digestive track.I forget where I first bought this package about 8 years ago, but the price tag on the bag says $1.75. Those days are certainly over! I have found the same tea on eBay for nearly half price, with free shipping. Search on "Kungfu Tea Chinese Herbal Grosvenor Momordica".

Keep you refund trigger finger warmed up when you order these. My first set (as others have reported) were DOA. Amazon of course made the return painless and costless. The second set flickered on/off now and then the first couple of days, but since have been working fine for the last few weeks. I took the control box apart, and the circuity driving these lights is rather laughable. A tiny unsecured circuit board kind of flopping around inside.But the thing about these lights is that they are Cool with a capital C. They're fun. They stretch out 20 feet to slightly illuminate the surroundings with multi-colored LED lights shining through likewise multi-colored Chinese lanterns (the quality is actually decent on the lantern hardware. It's an appealing presence and they kind of make you happy as they glow merrily through the evening.I would not be concerned about the reviews commenting on the lights losing their longevity as time passes. It's really ez to pop in a replacement battery. I posted a photo that shows what it looks like inside the control box when you remove the four small phillips screws. The original 60mAh AA battery has been replaced with a $2 Tenergy 2600mAh rechargeable. You need enough sun to fully charge the battery, but a quality battery (like this or an Eneloop) is going to last longer than the original even if it never reaches full charge.

This is a good book but I would like to pass on two caveats:1) Not everything you need to build a Windows networkThis is not a network administrators guide. I am setting up a Windows 8.1 / Windows Serer 2012 network from scratch, with only a Windows XP / Windows NT server background. This book does not cover all that's needed (and with the possible exception of the title it doesn't really pretend to). For example, the phrase "roaming profile" a staple technology for the user experience end of things, is not even listed in the index, whereas in Mark Minasi's 'Mastering Windows Server 2012 R2' the index lists 1/3 of a column for that term.2) Needs additional examplesGiven that I am building only a single server network, much of the book's material regarding Server 2112 was superfluous. However the passages I did read, while on the one hand included thorough explanations of a feature or technology, I often noted that they went no further. The book is a bit 'sterile', meaning, I would often read the section about a particular feature, and then wished the author had drilled down more. I was understanding the principals involved, but did not have 'context'. There were few real-world examples or workarounds. Passages are lacking tips about fitting the discussed piece into a larger context. I don't recall reading any 'from-the-trenches' anecdotes. For example, I wanted to choose the best approach for architecting storage on the server, but after reading the entire storage section, including one or two conflicting statements, I still wasn't sure of the best approach for my situation. But I would again stress that I did not read the book cover to cover, and am speaking only of the few chapters I did read.Having said that, clearly this is a highly regarded book and I am happy to include it in my reference library.

The best way to view this film is to go into it knowing as little as possible about the story. Fortunately, most of the descriptions I read about the movie before seeing it were inaccurate... thus the rather surprise ending was just that... a surprise. As it should be.Director Martin Ritt holds court on how to properly unfold a such story whose plot is based on "plans within plans". This is a movie that needs to be payed attention to in order to be *fully* appreciated. But if you don't there are still rewards in taking in the dank, black & white, otherworldly images that weld themselves to your consciousness. This film works on several levels, with timeless themes that make the ride worthwhile. Tip: Watch Richard Burton closely. His manner. His facial expressions. He is a master actor whose every move informs. Just don't assume he knows the whole story.One thing that can be revealed without incurring spoilage is that we run into 'George Smiley' in this film. Wasn't Smiley a character animated by Alec Guinness in the popular spy film 'Tinker Taylor Soldier Spy' and the 'Smiley's People' series? Why yes... the novels all these teleplays were based on were written by John le Carr√©. George Smiley is the author's recurring MI6 spy.'nuff said...

I cannot say enough good about this product. I had a *severe* thyroid imbalance and the symptoms started clearing within an hour the first time I tried it years ago. It is a natural formulation you may wish to consider as an alternative to more aggressive therapies.I would also recommend you check out Lugol's Iodine (J.CROW'SÆ Lugol's Solution of Iodine 2%). I use the two products together to keep my hormones balanced. Those concerned about Fukushima fallout should also check out this premium form of iodine. Here is a tip a Naturopath taught me; don't take the iodine internally. Rather, take a Q-tip and dab a silver dollar sized swath on your arm. Your body will only absorb what it needs. Reapply when the stain on your arm has vanished.

I have drinking Kava for about 20 years. I love it. Besides being acid neutralized it tastes delicious. My nutritionist even signed off on it because it does not make you jittery nor does it seem to spike you blood sugar like regular coffee. But it is much cheaper to buy direct from Smuckers online store. I'm afraid Amazon will delete the link, so just google "Smuckers kava coffee".ps - Nothing against Amazon here. The retailers listing Kava here are simply pricing it way above what you pay going direct to Smuckers. 8oz jars sell for about $10 ea in muliples, with free shipping over $50.

There are very few too-good-to-be-true things in life that in fact do turn out to be true. But this is one of those products. I have only used this product for one day, yet I am reviewing it due to the dramatic overnight results.I had a severe respiration problem that was getting progressively worse lately. Almost any toxin/allergen in the air puts me on my back starving for oxygen. I actually had to phone 911 a few weeks ago to get some oxygen when a few wisps of smoke from a distant forest fire wafted into my neighborhood. Contemporary medicine has provided no solutions. The few days leading up to trying Miracle II Neutralizer were the worst yet, and I was running out of options. Then a friend showed up at my doorstep with a gallon sized container of this product. To make a long story short I started drinking 6oz of the liquid every 4 hours. When I awoke the following morning I was breathing near normal. By that evening respiration was completely normal. Needless to say, this product's name is not exaggerated.Testing* later revealed that this is indeed a highly concentrated product and is actually as unbelievably inexpensive as it is unbelievably effective. My health practitioner determined that merely 4 drops of the solution in 6oz of tap water is equivalent to taking a straight 6oz of the product.Also, be reminded that the FDA places severe restrictions on what makers of products such as these can claim about their efficacy. Thankfully forums such as Amazon reviews tell what the manufacturer of Miracle II cannot. And now I've told you my story. In an age of a population with decaying health, and a medical industry co-opted by the pharmaceutical industry, citizens need to inform each other in such forums as these that there are indeed alternatives to expensive (and harmful) prescription pills and operations.* I use Applied Kinesiology for determining efficacy of food and supplements. In twenty plus years I've found it to be the single best diagnostic tool available. In the hands of the right practitioner (that's the key) one can derive answers to questions such as: "What is the correct dose of Miracle II Neutralizer?". In other reviews I've elaborated on this science.Reviews of other great supplements and remedies on sold on Amazon:* Super Green food supplementhttp://www.amazon.com/review/R1NDIZDWP080A7/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permSpirulina PowderNutrex Hawaiian Spirulina Pacifica 16 OunceElectrolyte Supplementhttp://www.amazon.com/review/R18A5D85F99FYV/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permTraumeel Pain Relief Ointment (homeopathic)http://www.amazon.com/review/R13LL1AU24AEDF/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permPoison Oak relief (homeopathic)http://www.amazon.com/review/R3LDE89MJ83HQ6/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permXO mold and pathogen killerhttp://www.amazon.com/review/R3OKJ4DCUFAP1W/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permEleuthero teahttp://www.amazon.com/review/RUMO9NE7BQZ1B/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permOther great products that I haven‚Äôt reviewed yetSilver Biotics (non-toxic colloidal silver alternative)Silver Biotics Immune System SupportGrapefruit Seed extract (universal ‚Äúcure all‚Äù)Liquid form: Grapefruit Seed Extract Liquid ConcentratePill form:Grapefruit Seed Extract 100 Tablet

Just before ordering these 1/8" rope winches I had taken delivery on a 1/4" rope ratchet that was a different brand (Carolina North 10010 1/4" Rope Ratchet with 8' Solid Braided Polypropylene Rope, 150 lbs Capacity). The 1/4" ratchet from Carolina North is very impressive for its cost, and I would rate quality as Good to Very Good. By comparison, I would rate these 1/8" ratchet as "Fair" quality. They work, but next time I would definitely buy the other brand (the 1/8" version of the Carolina North brand was not available on Amazon at time of purchase).A little more detail: There is a note on the packaging of this item that it has been "improved" by upgrading the ratchet wheel from plastic to metal. It was hard to tell, but I *will* say that the action of this ratchet (ratcheting the load / releasing the tension) feels a bit "cheap", whereas the Carolina North item had a nice smooth feel. I am using this item for a slightly more rigorous purpose than hanging grow lights, but I wouldn't doubt that this ratchet is up to the job of holding lights up. But if you appreciate a better quality solution I think the Carolina North brand is a better product (assuming their 1/8" version is of similar quality to the 1/4" item I bought).Either way, Happy Growing!

I took delivery of this 1/8" rope along with a pair of 1/8" rope ratchets (Apollo Horticulture GLRP18 Pair of 1/8" Adjustable Grow Light Rope Rachet Hanger w/ Improved Metal Internal Gears). The rope included with the ratchets was of a notably higher quality than this rope, and gave me something to compare to. This rope under review frayed surprisingly easy when it was drawn across the edge of a rough cut 2X6. I just don't see it lasting so I returned it.Gotta love Amazon. Free return shipping if the product is unsatisfactory.

High marks for this mini-winch...1) The guts are metal, not plastic.2) Four screws hold the mechanism together, so you can take it apart far enough to wash out any dirt and grime that build up around the wheel (a rivet at the pointy end keeps the spring loaded release from flying off into Netherland.3) The rope is high quality with a nice smooth feel. The ends are terminated in such a way to prevent fraying.4) The ratchet makes a really cool noise when you tighten your load down.To set it up, thread the rope into the ratchet from the bottom and then rotate the knurled wheel to make the rope pop out the other side (very reliable. It's not a thread through a needle sort of thing). Hook the ratchet to what you are tying down and then either tie the other end down with the far end of the rope directly or tie the additional hook to the rope end first. To cinch it tight just pull on the end of the rope you threaded through the ratchet. Note that there is no "winch handle" to cinch it tight. You are using the strength of your hand(s) pulling on the rope.A solution that allows for actually ratcheting rather than hand pulling on small jobs might be this handy little item: Ben-mor Cables Inc C78005V Mini Winch Clothesline Cable Tightener. I almost bought one of these for my application (cinching down a tarp cover on a deck), but it seems it would be a bit tedious tightening it down each time the tarp cover is put in use.

I live in the boonies and got fed up one day about not having the right glue or tape on hand. So I went on a buying spree and bought a wide variety of differing types of tapes and glues. So no more boo hoo when something comes loose.The plans are to someday write up a comprehensive comparison review on both product categories, but you know how plans go. In the meantime I find that I reach for this Fusion brand more often than anything else when the urge to glue come upon me. It does glue most anything together. And I like that it does not clog up the nozzle after sitting for a while. It's always handy and quick when you need it.The only thing I've learned to shy away from using it on is vertical surfaces. It's a bit runny and takes a while to set. So you get drips. For that kind of job I often use my other favorite adhesive Eclectic Prod. 170011 Marine Adhesive Goop.Happy gluing!

This review is mainly for people who use/believe in energetically testing products through the use of Applied Kinesiology (muscle testing). This Nutrex spirulina tests very strong... even better than the NOW brand.I have been purchasing the NOW brand of spirulina for years because they make great supplements. Spirulina is not cheap though, so I decided to look for an alternative of equivalent quality. The only thing I found that's a lot cheaper than the NOW brand is the bulk packaged products from places like China. Although such products could be muscle tested for purity I decided to not even bother. I noticed that the Nutrex spirulina is a bit cheaper than the NOW brand, and I like the idea of sourcing from Hawaiian waters.Delightfully, the Nutrex spirulina tests a bit stronger than the NOW spirulina. Not a *huge* difference, but given that it is also cheaper I jumped ship to the Nutrex brand (about $5 cheaper on a 1lb. jar at time of this review 4-2013). As a plus, the Nutrex product comes in a dark GLASS jar compared to the plastic bottle used by Now.By the way... I've used applied kinesiology for 20+ years and trust it over any lab test. The key is to find a practitioner who knows how to do it properly. Muscle testing a nutritional product alleviates the nuisance of trying to evaluate claims by the manufacturer (organic or not, clean waters, properly processed, etc.). Muscle testing bypasses all that nonsense and simply measures how effective the product is. For example, we have tested various non-organic products that rated better than their organic counterparts. Organic labeling can [unfortunately] be misleading.

This is one in a series of reviews that will eventually be posted for every Alice in Wonderland title available on Amazon. When the Tim Burton rendition of AIW with Johnny Depp was due out in 2010 I thought it might be a good time to go back and watch the benchmark Walt Disney production from 1951, which I saw -or assumed I saw- as a child. It was a chance to get reacquainted with the many varied characters from the story as sort of a warm up for the Burton film. Upon viewing the Disney classic I was astonished to realize that I had likely never seen more than a few clips (at most) of that beautifully rendered Alice in Wonderland. So much seemed brand new. Nor did I have a memory of ever seeing any other "Alice" production. Then I realized that I had never read the book! Wait a minute. Where then did my memory of the Alice story come from? The curiosity sparked by that question ultimately led me over the next two years to accumulate every version of Alice in Wonderland still in existence. Well over 40 by the way!This general commentary continues over in the review sections for both the 1951 AIW production from Walt Disney (Alice in Wonderland (Masterpiece Edition)) and the 2010 production starring Johnny Depp (Alice in Wonderland). As these are the two most well known Alice's, rather then attempt to add yet-another-review for those two films, it seemed like it might be a more fun use of the provided space to muse a bit on the popularity and remarkable longevity of the story spawned by Lewis Carroll in 1865, as well as to share with you a bit of what I picked up while watching these 40 or so renderings of Alice in Wonderland. All other Alice productions listed by Amazon have a specific review for that title.REVIEW OF THIS 1981-82 PRODUCTION OF ALICE IN WONDERLAND . . .It is interesting to see what non-English speaking cultures do with the British born story of Alice in Wonderland. Of the 40 plus Alice productions I've viewed to date, several come from "foreign" contributors in France, Japan, the Czech Republic, and Korea/Germany. Probably the number one reason I decided to try and watch every version of AIW in existence is because of how each production renders the book so uniquely. Each and every AIW version is a distinct rendering of someone's vision of how to convert Lewis Carroll's words into moving pictures.Nowhere is this uniqueness more apparent than the AIW offerings from other countries. And now we have a recent entry from Russia! It's actually a 1981 production that recently found its way onto Amazon. The jacket design is the first clue to the individuality of this production. In viewing it you might infer that this is a 'jokey' installation of AIW, a cartoon, and with imagery that is both unique and at the same time adorable.Right on all counts. The number one reason to buy this DVD is to enjoy the remarkable imagery employed in this animated telling of both `Alice in Wonderland' and `Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There'. The stories are [thankfully] told in two separate installments, with Looking Glass actually having been produced the following year in 1982. Anyway, I could try and describe this beautifully rendered Russian imagery, but just a glance at the Cheshire cat on the DVD cover tells the story. The entire cartoon reeks of this playful approach to bringing Lewis Carroll's characters to life.Obviously the animators were not concerned about taking a hint from John Tenniel's illustrations, so the next logical question is, how close does this cartoon follow the storyline and dialog of the book? This has actually become my key question as I unwrap each new Alice production that comes my way. Are we going to experience scrupulous enactments of each passage of the book (each of Alice's discrete adventures), related in the correct order, with no mixing of the two books? And are we going to hear Lewis Carroll's textual descriptions and dialog as written? No. This just doesn't happen. Every production departs from the book(s), it's just a question of degree.With this cartoon you get the "standard deviation pattern" of so many Alice installments whereby many, but never all, of the book's passages are rendered, combined with [at times] a strict verbalization of the original dialog which punctually veers off into adhoc, nothing-to-do-with-Carroll dialog. So, no, this is not the Holy Grail Alice production a purist may be wondering about. However, besides being a fun ride, the animators have incorporated some elements from the book you may have never seen before. For example, recall in the book when Alice is falling down the rabbit hole. She has this thought; "I wonder if I shall fall right THROUGH the earth! How funny it'll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward!" Well, the animators decided to actually illustrate people on the other side of the Earth walking upside down. Why has no once else ever thought to do this!?At another moment in the rabbit hole Alice thinks "'Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?' and sometimes, 'Do bats eat cats?'". Well guess what. We get to see that thought played out in a visual form. We also get to see a visual of when Alice thinks of sending a pair of boots to her feet once a year, while super-sized in the Hall of Doors. These are the kinds of elements, along with the cool animation, that endeared this version of AIW to me.As mentioned, the DVD also includes `Through the Looking Glass...'. The same animators are at work here bringing us the same Russian inspired imagery. We see the Red and White King and Queen not clothed in their original `Michelin Man" Tenniel style wardrobe, but rather Czar inspired Imperial layered costumes. We see a Jabberwock, not rendered as an evil monster, but rather a jokey cartoon figure. On the other hand we get a full reading of the Jabberwocky poem!Notes: The Amazon description states that subtitles are in English, German, and French, but on my DVD it is actually English, Russian, and French.---------------All the Alice reviews in this series are on Listmania:1) Click on my user name2) Click on 'Listmania!'3) Then click on See 'Entire List'.

I bought this item to place on my key chain simply as a reminder to repeat the Om Mane.... mantra as often as possible, as I will get engaged in day-to-day life and forget otherwise.The item does indeed appear to be pewter, although I'm not an expert. The pendant is a bit soft and malleable (naturally), but it's been on my key chain for a few months now and doing just fine. At some point in time the relatively thin circle of metal that goes around the key chain will probably break and I'll lose the item (I'm hard on things), but it will likely be found by someone deserving, and I'll just purchase a replacement. Who says this isn't a perfect world? ;>

As noted, this film borrows from Dark City, Blade Runner, Terminator, The Matrix, Fahrenheit 451, and Total Recall, but this movie falls far short of those greats. There is a difference between employing genre, plot, character, theme, and other such elements from past movies and rolling them in to a creative, inspired, and unique film experience, compared to such films as this which represent nothing more than simply stealing from the successful and not even attempting to cover your tracks.Christian Bale looks great in this film, but his beyond-Neo super-human antics have no basis for believability, whereas the Matrix properly set the plausibility stage for how one man could kill dozens. We saw the same implausible kind of ripoff with the Selina character in 'Dark Knight Rises' who performs Trinity-like moves with the same lack of foundation. They're hoping we won't notice, or care.Equilibrium is also full of the kind of plot twists and unexpected character behavior audiences tend to go for.... except, again, absolutely no set up for the twists, so it gets less and less easy to suspend your disbelief, while at the same time easier and easier to predict what's coming next as the movie drags on. By the end of the film you are fed up with the nonsensical sequences, you realize there's not a fresh piece of meat to be found in this turkey, and you start to regret the time you've invested. Save yourself the trouble and instead catch one of the aforementioned films you haven't seen yet! :>

Although this is not a true story, I used to have a client who at one time fell into the clutches of a cult from this era (the 80s), and he stated that this film is dead on accurate. The client was deprogrammed out of the cult, then went to law school to become an attorney that sued such cults, and also helped to deprogram others.This film is brilliantly written, produced, cast, and acted. It plays like a documentary. You will actually feel like what's happening is absolutely real and someone just happened to have a video camera handy. What exactly is happening? You are witness to the events that unfold for a lost human being searching for the truth and being misled and waylaid by a "Unification Church of Sun Myung Moon" style religious cult. This was the notoriously corrupt cult that received so much alarming press in the 1980's, the same decade 'Ticket to Heaven' was made.Laid bare are the seductive techniques employed by a cult to draft new members. You are taken full cycle -from the victim's state of mind that opened the door to such a path, to his indoctrination into the cult, to his programming once membership was gained, and finally to his "kidnapping" by family and friends who then commence to deprogramming him.It is the incredible realism of this film that makes it so compelling. The actors involved -including the great Saul Rubinek, who turned in a memorable Star Trek Next Generation episode as a villain in 'The Most Toys' - must have had to wash off some emotional scars that undoubtedly accumulated during filming. This is an adult film. Lock the kids up somewhere! :>

I just recently took delivery on this timer to replace an Ergo Systems timer purchased from Amazon that died in about a year. After poking around and seeing poor reviews for so many of these timers, I was relieved to find that this unit was better received. The quality and good engineering of this product showed immediately. The battery is already charged, so you can program the timer without having to plug it into an outlet (once you remove the slip of plastic that keeps the battery from being discharged while in transit).There is a simple and advanced programming mode, and unless you need to create a LOT of events the simple mode works great. I did need to refer to the manual for initial programming instructions (thus 4 stars), but the timer programmed properly, was then automatically active, and the first timer event worked. So, very pleased so far.UPDATE: In use for several months and all is well.

This splendid film is a John Wayne "sleeper" and a true classic. It is a rare Wayne movie where he plays a "bad" guy (but not really). Moreover, it is a western you can view with gals who would normally steer away from this genre. I wouldn't come right out and call it a chick-flick, but it does have feminine appeal. The lesson given is how does a Quaker family (who call themselves 'The Society of Friends') behave when the water is cut off to their ranch by a cranky neighbor. Taken in by this high minded family when he is wounded, Wayne's character finds a plaque on the wall of his bedroom that reads as follows:"Each human being has an integrity that can be hurtonly by the act of that same human beingand not by the act of another human being"Wayne is transformed upon witnessing how his Quaker hosts respond to the life threatening action taken by the neighbor. He is also touched by the angelic devotion shown to him by his pretty-as-can-be love interest Gail Russell. If you have seen all the great westerns and are now seeking then ones you may have overlooked, this is a great place to start.BTW - another Wayne western that is not played all that often is "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance". Great character driven plot. One of the few films where Wayne dies. And the ladies may favor this one as well. Violence only where it is required, a hard working family plays witness to the injustices inflicted upon western neophyte Jimmy Stewart, and there's a strong female lead for the lovely Vera Miles.

I had seen the 1990 British version of this political drama first. It was so good I was keeping my expectations tempered for fear of a watered down American version. But this US version is very well done. Brilliant even. Full of detail and nuance. Impeccable casting. Kevin Spacey is one of the smartest actors in Hollywood and the script is worthy of his talents. The same can be said of the entire cast. This is a very different story from its British counterpart though. Yes, it's about politics and greed and betrayal, but from a different angle juxtaposed to what the Brits did. Both series are top notch thrillers in their own unique way.House of Cards illustrates the seedy underbelly of politics. If you really want to get a sense of how politics corrupts, how people can rationalize their corrupt acts -including murder- and still sleep at night, here is a great teacher. You witness first hand the enormous pressure elected representatives face in order to go-along-to-get-along. You come to realize that reform from within is made architecturally impossible.While viewing this series I was watching Kevin Spacey's character (an influential congressman) look his friends/associates directly in the eye and tell the most sincere of lies without a blink of his own eye. All to benefit his own personal agenda. I was reminded of another series about people in positions of power that portrayed the exact same behavior... The Sopranos. So, we have gangsters and politicians rendered as amoral liars that are willing to kill to get what they want. These fictions of course could not possibly reflect real life.

Oh come on. This film makes sense only if the story is explained to you. The cues for the dream passages are simply not articulated well. It's like the director didn't really care if you understand what's going on. And why is this girl even dreaming? Where are we going? Storywise there's no THERE there. The movie doesn't end, it simply stops. It's like the film broke mid-reel and both the audience and take-up reel are left spinning in perpetuity. Still, it's David Lynch, and there's wonderful film making -if not story telling- taking place.If you loved Twin Peaks you will likely love this film. If you were disappointed by the untidy loose ends of Twin Peaks... the pointless plot points, the surrealistic path that leads nowhere, and the unresolved elements of the last episode, then you may be equally disappointed in Mullholland Drive, which was initially devised as a TV pilot. The pilot was rejected, so Lynch tacked an ending on to it. What ending? What got resolved?David Lynch is a brilliant film maker, rendering unparalleled mood and intensity on the screen. But he has some internal compulsion that pushes him too far. He's creative enough to invent new metaphors, but he sticks with the old ones, as with the dwarf and the draped room (Mullholland Drive is arguably the opening episode for season 3 of Twin Peaks). Surrealism is great, but give it meaning David... even 'pretend' meaning. We want to go for the ride, but you never get us to the destination. That would be OK too if you would at least give us something to wrap our willingness to suspend-our-disbelief around. But there's just too many needless sub-mysteries and we lose interest.When the unsatisfactory ending to Mulholland Drive arrives you almost don't care because it's clear that the investment you've made in following the story turns out to be nothing more than mental masturbation. The film's got some great moments though, and still worth the view. Just temper your expectations. For me Lynch is at his best when someone hands him the story and he simply makes the movie. Dune was a masterpiece.

When I first googled for a replacement spark plug cable set my eyes about popped out of my head at the prices. And then I found a link for this Bosch set with distributor cap on Amazon. Roughly half the price I had seen on most other sites. Remarkable that Amazon is becoming a go-to site for car parts now too. Delivery was quick, the order had the exact parts advertised (the Bosch part in a new Bosch box), and coupled with a rotor I also found on Amazon I had the whole rig installed on my Corolla in a few minutes. What's not to love?Note: I did not have the same experience as the reviewer who says you need to twist 90 degrees. My cable set had the cable permanently attached at the cap end, and the spark plug end simply needed to be pushed on as normal... and it did click into place. Do NOT twist 90 degrees.UPDATE: When I placed the order on March 5th 2013 the price was $26.49, plus $5.49 shipping. On March 16 the price now shows as $43.16 and super saver shipping. Not the great deal from a few days before. Perhaps the vendor had mis-priced the itemearlier. Oh well.

I had this particular kit kicking around for some time before putting it to use by lending it to a friend who had suffered a direct impact to her knee when falling. Several days after the injury she was still experiencing quite a lot of discomfort, but upon applying first the cream, and then later taking the sub-lingual pills, she experienced clear and direct relief from both forms of the Traumeel. It seemed by combining both the topical as well as the internal forms gave the most effective relief, as well as triggering of the healing process.Heel is a trusted name in our family for many years. The right homeopathic, used in the right dosage, can be an inexpensive and powerful way to address various health issues. I am thankful companies such as Heel have put together kits that help lay people find the right remedy.

After a bit of research this [very complete] kit turned up as having the best price for a branded timing belt / water pump replacement. I hadn't thought of changing the fan belts at the same time, and was happy to see them included. I had a mechanic do the job, and he reported no issues with fit or quality of the parts. Yeah!I might add that I pushed this job about 15,000 miles past the recommended 60K interval, yet the old belt was still in great condition (at least on visual check). The water pump impellers were also still in good shape. So yeah, I maybe could have pushed it even further, but I'm really really glad I did the job now because all the goofy little noises coming from the engine have stopped! The new serpentine belts helped, but the mechanic also said the old timing belt tensioner was the one part that was worn, and that it can get noisy when this happens.Kudos to the supplier who put this kit together. Good work.

The three excellent reviews from  Brad Ackerman, R. Jensen, and zolof911 posted here at the time I stopped by tell the story of this product quite adequately.I wanted a "pure" power strip sans the extra cost of surge protection, as most outlet strips want to throw that in for market appeal. I wanted a strip that could not be easily turned off, as with so many other strips simply staring at them hard seems to flip the flimsy rocker switch. And I wanted to be able to plug in a large number of power bricks without having to resort to shorty extension cords.This unit does all that. Turning the AC outlets 90 degrees so that many/most bricks stick OUT in the air rather than DOWN over another outlet was a simple design choice, yet so few power strip designers have had this light bulb come on (hello!?).If they had placed the cord at the opposite end of the toggle switch we would be talkin' 5 stars here.

Reviewer Publius is correct when saying: "So in short, 1) Pull the spring trap back 2)Lay the hook all the way down on top of the spring 3)Slowly lift the cheese up just to the point it catches on the hook".In fact, Victor is the only brand I know making this style trap that really does work. Smaller Mice can be very light on their feet, and clever, and you really do need a trap with a 'hair trigger'. You do need to set the trap so that the wire is barely under the tab on the cheese platform to achieve that hair trigger. Anyone who gets their finger bit by one of these traps (ouch!) is simply handling it incorrectly. If you don't want to get bit don't put you fingers in the line of fire!Recently Orchard Supply Hardware dropped the entire line of Victor traps for a lower cost brand called TomCat. The TomCat traps look exactly the same, but they can't be set with that all important hair trigger. Thus the mice at my place were getting a nice meal of peanut butter every night. I also tried one other brand when I couldn't get the victor and it too failed to spring.And yes, peanut butter works better than cheese on our brand of meeeces. But not that natural, wholesome style peanut butter that is a bit runny and needs to be mixed well each time you open the jar. That's for people. No, you want the Jiff brand for mice. That stuff sticks to the trap platform like glue, and the mice have to wrestle it out of the holes... and that activity is what springs the trap. I suppose Skippy would do in a pinch.It's a shame I had to order a mouse trap online, but I could hear the mice moaning in the dark corners of my house when I clicked the submit button on my Amazon order.
The old amp meter in my RV had died and this unit fit the same hole. Works perfect. Reads a low 1 amp load no problem. Lots of hardware included. No complaints!

Although this little LED array is billed as a dome light replacement --and it does indeed come with a variety of adapters for that job-- I actually installed it in my RV to replace a 12vdc light bulb used to illuminate the stove area. The existing bulb draws 5amps of current, which is just too much when you're running on batteries.Given the price, the form factor, the overall lumen level, and the fact that the array comes with a sticky backing that made it ez to mount to the fan hood, this light seemed a perfect fit. And it is! Very very bright. Easily lights up the entire stove area. In fact, I had bought two of these thinking that's would it would take to adequately light up the area. But one unit did the job so well I actually did use the second one to replace the dome light in my 92 Corolla. EZ install and it works great!Current draw on this array is about 300ma.UPDATE: May 2014One of the two units I bought died. It was the one over the stove. It went "Super Nova" on me, going way bright and then 95% of the LEDs going out. It also created a short circuit which almost burned out the 12vdc power supply hooked to it. For all I know it may have been grease build up or something that shorted it out. The one in the car keeps on truckin'. So what am I going to do? I'm gonna BUY ANOTHER ONE!

I do not own this product. So why am I writing a review? Because I was telling someone a story today about how I determined the best ice chest on the market a while back, and it's Igloo. Then I realized prospective cooler buyers would like this story...We do a lot of camping in a Westfalia and often go to the desert. Ice always gave out in a few days. We started wondering if one brand of cooler would keep ice longer than another, so we went out and bought every cooler we could find at the local stores. We placed the coolers (about 8 of them) in a room, each with one block of ice, closed the lids, closed the door to the room, and checked the melt rate periodically.To cut right to the chase, the IGLOO ice chest lasted the longest (5-6 days), and the ice in the Coleman cooler melted first (3 days). I forget the exact models, and also the other brands, but Igloo seems the best all round brand.

How do they design, build, and ship overseas a really cool 2.1 speaker system and ship it to me for free under Amazon Prime for $38? How do they add bells and whistles like a wired remote with separate volume and bass controls, and aux input and headphone jacks? How do they make it so EZ to assemble that I didn't even need to open the manual? How do they make a sound system that when I plug it into my desktop computer it sounds even better than my old Klipsch computer speakers?At $38 I figure I could make a mistake on this purchase and not care to much. But this system sounds great, build quality is decent, and again, I love the wired remote. What's not to love?I LOVE it when I make the right buying decision!

I've received a couple of these hats, but I'm not as impressed with these as the others. Here is my assessment after using it:Pros*It is creepy looking and ideal for Halloween or theatrical events*Fairly realistic looking for kids*Didn't result in allergy attacks or other skin irritationsCons*Quality is average and hat is cheaply made*My daughter isn't a fan even though she loves animal critters (coincidentally, her "spirit animal" this month is a wolf as assessed on an online kid test site she loves)*Exorbitant price for what you getThis one gets an average rating. A lot of people seem incredibly enthused over their hats, so maybe mine was a misnomer. Reviews for other hats and puppets are forthcoming are far more favorable, so I'm suspecting I might be the outlier here. I received the wolf hat at a discount for an unbiased review, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

I have pretty clear skin, but sometimes hormones or dirt and oil in the pores causes the occasional, but massive, blemish. I try to resist the temptation to pop it to avoid scarring, so I prefer products that act fast. I'm also a fan of natural remedies, and when hearing some of the benefits touted, I decided Tamanu would be worth a try. Here are my takeaways from using this oil for pesky blemishes:Pros*Interesting but not unpleasant nutty, herbal fragrance*Works just as intended. Rather than waiting a couple of days, I applied the oil to my cleansed, toned skin with a clean cotton pad, and the next morning the blemish had come to a head. I used it for 2 more days, and it had all but disappeared.*Caused no skin irritation, and without me meddling with my skin, I didn't exacerbated the problem with self-inflicted skin inflammation.*Non-greasy and no sticky residue*Satisfaction guarantee is always a bonus*Price and quality are fair for normal consumers*Even though it's shown to be beneficial for other ailments, I don't have those, but the multi-use appeal is notableCons*Will cause clothing stains so exercise caution when using*Doesnt work as quickly as anticipated, but all skin types differI'm no longer skeptical, and it's a relief finding something that handles blemishes quicker than waiting or scarring my skin by picking at it prematurely. I did receive this product for free for testing purposes and an unbiased review, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

I bought this same style of dress (different patterns) last summer, because I was 70lbs heavier and needed a good cover-up. I took a gamble with the one size fits most, and the fit was perfect. This year I still had my former cover-up dresses, but they had stretched from my previous size and were too large. I gifted the larger ones to a friend and decided to purchase this style again, because I'd loved them for the support up top and the beautiful patterns. This dress and the five others I bought fit perfectly, so it does seem as though one size truly does fit most. I have no problem wearing these dresses as regular sundresses in public, because they aren't revealing and are perfect to combat the heat in Atlanta during the summer. My friend is pleased, because the dresses I gifted her were still in good shape (I'm picky about my laundering and do what I can to preserve the look of my clothing), and I'm thrilled about being smaller and having the boldly colored patterned dresses I love.

I've bought a few different king sized sheet sets for my bed, but my daughter was due for new sheets for her queen-sized bed, so I jumped on the opportunity to get these. Here are my takeaways on the new sheet set:Pros*Current price is excellent for consumers at the time of review*300-thread count isn't going to be the luxury expected in 1800 thread count sheet sets, but these are comfortable and cozy for my 9-yr-old*The chocolate brown offsets her comforter set beautifully, so decor is nicely congruent*I've run the new sheets through the wash twice and had no issues with fading or wrinkling, and the sheets are still soft*No evidence of fraying or improper threading in the seams*Daughter loves the sheet and I hate laundry. Bonus!Cons*Not the highest quality sheets made, but definitely not inferior.*RV without the current sale ($29.99) is a little steep for most wallets.Overall, I'm more than pleased with the sheets, and I'm happy when my kid is happy. I did receive my sheets free in exchange for an unbiased review, and positive ratings are never guaranteed.

Tea tree oil alone is phenomenal for a number of purposes including homemade, organic household disinfectants when mixed with water, for aromatherapy to revive the senses, mild pain relief applied topically when mixed with a carrier oil, a safe way to repel head lice and as a skin softener/acne combatant when listed as an ingredient in a number of lotions. Epsom salts alone are an excellent way to purge toxins from the body when added to a bath, are well-known for easing aches and soothing inflammation and swelling of sports related sprains/injuries, help facilitate elimination when constipated, and they even make gardens flourish. Take both tea tree oil and Epsom salts and combine them and you have a potent foot soak. Here is my experience after testing the foot soak several times and why it warrants 5 stars:Pros*Lovely fragrance that stimulates without overpowering*Amazing soak after long hours in front of my standing workstation. Even with an anti-fatigue mat, I experience aching, swollen feet, and these symptoms are alleviated after a nice salt soak*Feet are soft after a good soak and it's easy and pain-free to slough off dead skin and shave down callouses with my rechargeable callous remover. Because it's also a disinfectant, there is less chance of infection if I become over-zealous with my pumice stone or clippers and accidentally injure myself (happens because I'm clumsy, too, afraid to say)*Large container and combined cost at the time of review make this soak an economically practical purchase for consumers in need of foot love*Costs far less than a salon pedicure, and all you need is a tub large enough to submerge your feet, adding an appealing convenience factorCons*None noted at this time but review will be revised if this changesI love this foot soak, and even though I don't suffer from athlete's foot or common foot fungal infections, I know it is a great remedy. I did receive the tea tree oil foot soak free for testing purposes, and positive ratings are never guaranteed.

I've been seeing a trusted chiropractor for quite some time, and I asked what supplements, if any, were truly beneficial to the body. His advice was fish oil, but to make sure to get at least 2400mg of EPA and DHA per day for optimal health benefits. This one rates a 5, and here is exactly why:Pros*No nasty fishy taste and afterburps (I've experience this with other brands, and so not pleasant)*Massive bottle and taking only one extra recommended pill per day satisfies the 2400mg requirement*Science proves omega 3's are beneficial to the brain, heart, joints, skin and other major systems*I dislike large pills, and compared to some other fish oils with less potency, these aren't nearly as large or unpleasant*Great quality and price for consumersThus far, I've loved taking this fish oil. I get my proper daily dose recommended by my chiropractor, and anything to potential improve chance of longevity from a scientific standpoint is something I highly recommend. I received  these supplements at a discount for testing purposes and an unbiased review, but I never guarantee a positive rating.

As a longtime sufferer of insomnia who often works through the night and sleeps during the day, I'm a huge fan of sleep masks. I've tried flimsy ones which barely keep the light out, ones that broke within a short timeframe, and ones that were cheaply made and uncomfortable. Getting the Dream Maker Sleep Mask and trying it out for several days has lead to this assessment:Pros*Soft, cushion-light, and lightweight*Keeps the light out and contoured away from my eyes*When I do sleep, I enjoy better quality sleep during the daytime with this mask*The earplugs aren't annoying and cancel the mewling of my cats who make sleep difficult at times*I like how the nose piece helps to keep more light out without stifling*Luxurious feel helps me rest easierCons*A little pricey for consumers, but they are good quality*The adjustable strap is a bit of an annoyance, and sometimes I have to play with it to get comfortable (only design flaw noted)Except for the two cons mentioned, I have found no other issues with this sleep mask, and I've put my others to the side. I recommend spraying a little lavender on your pillow prior to slumber to help you relax and sleep even more quickly. The only model I had for my mask was my daughter, because it's impossible to take a blind selfie properly. I did receive my mask for free for testing purposes and an unbiased review, and positive ratings are never guaranteed.

Several reviews on hair repair product options later, and I tried this Moroccan oil, because I'll try anything to restore my hair to its former healthy state. I've learned my lesson about over-processing but this is a tough, lingering problem. Frontline is the best topical flea and tick repellent I've found for my cats. I prefer a topical solution, because it's hard enough to catch my rescues to dose them each month. Other vet options were injections, and I didn't like the idea of what might could go wrong. Even though the cats act like jerks sometimes and new furniture isn't on the agenda as long as they live, I love them and seek out the best options to keep them comfortable, healthy and happy. I'd absolutely recommend Frontline Plus, because a flea-ridden kitty is a miserable one, and that just sucks. I advise buying the larger quantity boxes, because its less expensive per dose. I've used Frontline Plus on my cats for over five years, and they've never experienced adverse effects or reactions.
