The Blue Ridge Mountains are less than two hours away and are home to some of the most beautiful waterfalls in the southeast, but some of the hiking required to get to them is brutal for one as clumsy as me. I've never had the opportunity to own trekking poles, so I'm always worn out and have tripped over a tree root or two before making it to the waterfall of choice. One nasty fall can easily end in that last goodnight on some of those narrow trails with no barriers to the steep ravines, and after test running these poles on some of the local park trails to prepare, these are my thoughts:Pros*Portability makes life easy for me, and these poles easily collapse and fit without a fight into the sturdy bag they came with*My confidence in avoiding injury or worse has increased, because the poles help keep me steady with the rubber hand grips*I love the adjustable height feature, and I've tested the poles enough to have them out of the bag and locked in place at the ideal height in a flash. I've tried walking sticks before, but they're never at the proper height and I usually end up carrying them or ditching them along the trail.*These trekking poles are deceptively lightweight for the rugged tasks they're made for, and after a few local hilly trails locally, it's obvious they will meet the tougher challenges on the fall agenda to take on some of the most treacherous hiking trails awaiting me in the Chatahoochee National Forest*My legs and feet don't hate me when I use the trekking poles. I've used compression stockings and excellent sneakers for my excursions, but the shock-absorbency of the poles is impressive. Some aches are to be expected after any strenuous cardiovascular task, but since the poles take the brunt of the impact, aches and pains are a fraction of the former pain I used to experience afterwards.*Superior quality and reasonable pricing make these poles highly appealing to any hiking enthusiast, and it's obvious they were designed to last a long timeCons*None noted at this time, but I will revisit my review should that changeI don't know why I didn't think of trekking poles in my life before, because they are awesomeness quantified, and when these wear out at some point in the far future, I'll be buying another set. I did receive these trekking poles at a modest discount for an unbiased review, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

Essential oils are huge in my household, and I especially love concentrated oils with a variety of uses. Ylang Ylang is one I had no experience with, but I've researched essential oils and most are useful when steam distilled from the actual plant they're derived from. Synthetics are bunk, so always check the labels. Here are my thoughts on this brand of Ylang Ylang Oil.Pros*Steam distilled process. 100% natural, and large quantity*I love the light floral fragrance. It's not powerful or overwhelming, and I'm enjoying it for aromatherapy in my office diffuser.*Glass dropper is included, allowing for a more precise dosage than the average plastic dropper.*Is a nice calming, soothing addition to a warm bath, and there's no need to use too much of it to achieve the result.*According to most of my research, Ylang ylang is good for anxiety, stress, and anger, helps maintain healthy skin (including excema), helps the nervous system, and reduces blood pressure. Some research also indicates there is insufficient evidence to deduce Ylang Ylang is beneficial, but I believe in trying natural solutions over pharmaceuticals as often as possible..*When used is as a moisturizer, I enjoy the fragrance and my skin feels smooth and soft.*I wrecked my hair going from no processing to over-processing overnight a few weeks ago, and since Ylang Ylang is recommended for scalp stimulation to help hair growth, I've been using it for that, also.. So far the jury is out on this, but it doesn't leave my hair limp and gross when I use it on my scalp overnight.ConsNone noted, but pregnant women are advised to refrain from using Ylang Ylang until further researched.If something negative happens while using Ylang Ylang for external use only (I wouldn't see the benefit of ingesting it), I'll come back to revise my review.I did receive this product at a discount for an honest review, and I never guarantee 5 stars or recommend a product I wouldn't use.

I am a huge essential oils fan, and I was a wellness advocate for another brand that was high quality but high priced. I love this lavender oil, because I can use it for so many things. Unfortunately she caught a bug last week, but it gave me the opportunity to test this lavender oil, and it worked beautifully to calm her and put her to sleep. These Goggles fit perfectly without pulling my hair, and I love that they really are anti-fog. The suction on the goggles is excellent, and I feel better knowing my eyes are protected against harmful UV rays. The tint enables me to swim unfettered seeing underwater crystal clear again, and when I surface, I'm not blinded by the sun. The ear and nose plugs were a nice bonus. I received this for a discount in exchange for an honest review, and they're an awesome addition for the summer.

The seller set the expectation that the shoes ran a bit small and to order a size or two larger, so I went two sizes higher. They fit exactly, and my daughter loves them. The little monkey charms are adorable, the little bag that came with it is perfect for her pool stuff, and  she's already made the box into an art box to hold her art supplies and fashion creation drawings. Quality of the flip flops are pretty good with nice, thick soles for added comfort, and although I received this product for a discount in exchange for an honest review, I'd  consider purchasing them again in the future. Thanks, Mottos!

I like these little headphones, because they are compatible with my iPad Mini, iPod, PC, and good mic quality when I tested them on a business Google hangout. The sound quality is good but not great, and while they are comfortable for awhile, they hurt my head after awhile. I like that the cord is braided and flexible, allowing me to migrate effortlessly from my sitting to standing workstation (both in close proximity from one another), and the quality is on par for its price range. Not the best I've tried nor the worst. Thanks, Sentey, for allowing me to review these at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review!

I'm the first to admit I'm not the best about getting proper nutrition, and I definitely don't eat the fruits and veggies I should. I nag my kid to death and make sure she gets her servings in but often work so much I neglect me. Cranberry supplements are a great addition to the ones I take, but it's not so much because of UTI infection problems. These small, easy-to-swallow pills have an insanely high concentration of amazing vitamins, and there are just some of the benefits I've researched:Because cranberries contain proanthyocyanide which prevents the formation of plaque, it's great for oral health. Cranberries also have anti-inflammatory properties that reduce inflammation of the gums to help teeth-supporting tissues.A 2005 study revealed cranberry can also help prevent H.Pylori infection, a bacteria which can cause peptic ulcers and stomach cancer.Cran contains antioxidants that fight free radicals (bonus age fighter!). For those unfamiliar with free radicals, they're nasty little things able to cause damage to cellular structures. Cran ranks among the highest fruits with antioxidants.Their anti-inflammatory properties make them great for reducing chronic inflammation in the stomach and large intestine and are mostly responsible for the cardiovascular benefits, too. The phytonutrients are responsible for fighting inflammation and with the combined antioxidants help lower LDL (bad cholesterol) and total cholesterol for cardiovascular health.Studies are showing a possible link between cranberries potential anti-cancer and immune system boosting abilities. I'm watching for more peer-reviewed studies and conclusive findings and will update if I find something significant.Even though I received these supplements in exchange for an honest review, I accepted the review because I know cranberry supplements are potent agents supporting overall health and wellbeing. I'll be purchasing these regularly from now on.

Whether the science supports their efficiency or benefit, my personal experience is incredibly positive. I wear them for exercise and for working at home, and I love compression sleeves enough that this is my second pair. I'm self-employed and work on a computer at home alternating between sitting and a standing station. These paired with my sneakers and anti-fatigue mat take pressure off my legs and knees, and they fit perfectly without cutting off circulation. I'm sure I look incredibly fashionable when wearing this combo with sundresses or PJ's when working in the house, but I say comfort first. High quality material and I love the black color, because the sleeves aren't grungy looking after outside fitness activities. I have other reflective gear for being out after dark, and the reflective stripes are one more notch on the safety scale. Thanks, Fitness Foundations, for sending me this product for a deep discount in exchange for an honest review.

This is a nice eyelash and eyebrow serum that seems to be working. It's clear and thin, goes on without any think gunk. I really like it, because it's opthamologist and dermatologist tested, causes no irritation, and has also seems to make my lashes and brows thicker., the most important thing. I was cursed with sparse eyelashes and a few sparse areas in my eyebrows, and I've experienced thickening in both arenas. Unlike one prescription brand side effects I've heard of occuring, my eye color hasn't changed at all to my relief. I've been using it twice a day, and even though the vial is small, a little will last. Even though I received a discount for this product in exchange for an honest review, I like it so far.

My face is in love with this light, refreshing scent. It's a light floral as claimed and not overbearing. No stinging or tearing of eyes, and my skin feels so clean and lovely when I use it that I'm adding it to the permanent beauty regimen. I received this product at a discount for an honest review, and I like it so much I'll continue to buy it. Thanks, Foxbrim!

I was surprised at how quickly I received my aloe vera gel, and I decided to go ahead and try it for a few of the recommended uses. Yesterday at a summer splash pool party, I got a pretty harsh sunburn on my shoulders (not sure how I missed it when I use sunblock like a fiend), and as soon as I put this gel on, I felt an instant cooling relief. Because it is purported to be a daily moisturizer, too, I decided to try it in lieu of my usual lotion. It did absorb quickly, and my skin feels amazing--I'd even shaved my legs and they feel silky smooth, too. I love that it's 99% organic and made in a US facility. The money-back guarantee also helps build my trust, and I've been reading articles half the evening on all the other benefits of Aloe Vera gel covering everything from GERD to anti-aging. I think I've just found my moisturizer replacement. I received for a reduced cost in exchange for an honest review, but I LOVE it!

Worked okay for protection, but hard to apply without air bubbles underneath, and it is definitely not anti-finger print. For the price, it's decent, and the screen protector was for a kid's tablet, so it worked out okay. Now get "crazy" and down vote it. I notice it's happening with a lot of 3 star reviews, so my next review will be on my blog on the manufacturer, and I'll research all the other products. I had considered giving this protector a generous 3.5 stars until the seller showed the weren't looking for less than 4 and 5 star reviews.

I won a tablet for my daughter, and it needed a cover. This one exceeded my expectations in price and quality. It is still going strong after a couple of years (I know, I'm really late on this review), but it has taken a considerable bashing in those few years. It's still functional, and when I clean finger smudges and such off, it looks pretty good even still.

My daughter was huge into Monster High, and she loved this doll because the dress, her unusual color (not your average doll color, but a monster doll color), and she begged me for hair stripes like the doll. I said no, because 6yrs old was too young, but she still loved the doll and played with it forever. Not bad quality for the beating it took between her and my nieces.

I thought this was a good idea. I have ~200 lumens flashlights that cost twice this flashlight / charger combo. And it looks impressive and feels good in the hand with the rubberized exterior. But after using it for a couple of days, I was rather disappointed.I'm only rating it average for 3 reasons :1. The flashlight button is quite difficult to press. I'm not sure if it is an issue only with my light. The lower button is much easier to press, so it might be a manufacturing defect.2. The flap protecting the ports from water and dust is rather loose, and is easily knocked open.3. USB charging requires you to manually turn it on. Almost all other USB chargers will start charging your device when you plug it in.I also had the red (low battery) light turn on after only using the flashlight on high intermittently for less than 10 minutes. I will run a test to see how long it takes to deplete and update.I'm also a little disappointed at the low capacity (3000 mAh) and that it is only water resistant instead of waterproof, but as these are stated in the product description, I did not lower my rating based on that.

I've owned a number of headphones over the years, and I know what I like : good quality earbuds for portable use, clear and accurate sound reproduction, no perceivable distortion, over ear headphones for desk use, and avoid anything that says "enhanced bass" like the plague. I like DJ type headphones because they're closed (so no one else complains about noise), blocks external noise, have a neutral sound quality (if I want to tweak the sound, I want to do it with an equalizer) and I have a strong distaste for boosted bass, as it tends to drown out the details of a musical piece.The closest thing I have to this is the Sennheiser HD280 Pro, which I purchased in 2003. Even taking inflation into account, this one is still about 3 times what I paid for the Sennheiser. So what's the difference?The most obvious difference is the build quality, The HD280 has come plastic clips on the headband. They broke within the first week of me owning it, and I was only using it at home. I fixed them in place with clear packing tape, and they've held up well over the last 12 years, but it was still very disappointing to have it break so soon after buying. The A5Pro is built like a tank. Lots of aluminum all over. It is heavier than the HD280, of course, but surprisingly not that much heavier.The headphones come with cushions that fit over the ear, but in my case, just barely. I'd like larger ear cushions. The cushions are easily removed and replaced with a slight twist. The included cushions are 93mm in diameter. 80mm (on-ear) and 110mm cushions are also available. The cable is detachable, locks in place when pointing down, and - this is the part I really appreciate - can be attached on either the left or the right. I thought I read that there is a shorter, non-coiled cable with mic input available that can be used on a phone, but I have not seen it for sale.Speaking of travel, it can fold into a really compact size, and comes with a simple cloth bag for transport. When folding the cups up, there is a pretty loud click as a plastic clip releases for it to swivel up. This is the only part I'm worried about it breaking, as it is not easily replaced.Sound isolation is good, but not as good as a well fitted pair of earbuds. It also works both ways - it keeps external noise out, and it keeps what you're listening to from leaking out. The cushions are nice and soft, and fairly comfortable, but if you're not used to DJ style phones, you may find them tight. And you will definitely feel the weight. My HD280 feels more comfortable, but it is like an old pair of shoes, broken in, and the comparison is not fair. I recall the HD280 felt tighter when it was new as well.OK, enough about the construction and the great design. How does it sound?It sounds great to me. I hear all the details very clearly, and it does appear to be quite neutral (I have no way of measuring this except by comparing it to other headphones, like the V-Moda M-80, which sounds a fair bit brighter. Bass is not artificially boosted (yes!) but if you're listening to a bass heavy track, you definitely can hear the bass. I tried it with a range of music, from classical, to vocals, instrumentals, rock, and it performs superbly. Compared to my HD280, it sounds more substantial. Don't get me wrong, the HD280 sounds great, but when comparing it side by side, it sounded a bit hollow. I'm sure I'm not using the correct audiophile terms for this. The difference is not great, but it is definitely there, and easily heard.The headphones claim to be able to handle 3500 mW. I'm not sure what 3500 mW will sound like, but I'm pretty sure it's a recipe for hearing loss. When I first plugged it into my computer, I had the volume at 40%. It was loud! On the bright side, I didn't detect any distortion even at that ridiculous level that was not there at a lower volume.Used with my phone, the sound level seemed slightly lower compared to my earbuds, but surprisingly not by much.The only thing that gave me pause is the price. It fluctuates a bit, but no one is ever going to describe it as "inexpensive". It has a great design, solid build quality, and sounds great. Is it worth 3 times the price of the Sennheiser HD280 Pro? That's a hard question to answer if you're not a professional DJ. If you like DJ style headphones, however, it is definitely worth considering.Now I just need to figure out where to buy the 110mm cushions from.

This is my 3rd stapling pliers, the other two are the Bostitch B8  Xtreme Duty 45 Sheet Plier Stapler, Black (B8HDP) and the Rapesco Porpoise Classic Plier Stapler, 40 Sheet Capacity, Chrome (R81000A3). I purchased the Bostitch for a project originally, and this as well as the Rapesco were provided for review. No one person really needs 3 stapling pliers, obviously.The Bostitch could be opened up to be used for tacking (to stick a sheet of paper to a cork board, for example) and requires slightly less force for the same amount of paper, either due to the design of the staples or to the longer handle. The Bostitch's handle is plastic, unlike this and the Rapesco, which are 100% metal.Comparing the Rapid K1 and the Rapesco Porpoise, they have more in common than not. They can both pin as well as staple by changing the anvil (pinning is similar to stapling, but the legs bend outwards instead of inwards - like using a pin to hold a few sheets of paper together. It's easier to remove than staples). By size, weight, looks, and construction, they are very similar. One major difference - the Rapid K1 handles a 50 page stack of regular copier paper without any problems, but the Rapesco doesn't grip it as well. Fair enough, given that this one claims to have a 50 page capacity, while the Rapesco only claims 40.In use, on the same stack of paper, I find the Rapid K1 to need just a bit less force to staple. The end result looks identical. They have the same mechanism for loading staples, but I find the Rapid K1 to be more difficult to load, as the hook that holds the spring in place is not as smooth to engage and disengage as the Rapesco. The Rapesco has ridges on the bottom handle for a better grip, but the ridges don't really make any difference in the grip. The spring on the Rapid K1 looks stronger - the wire is about twice the thickness of the Rapesco.Summary of above sentence : this stapler requires slightly less force for the same amount of paper, has a stronger spring to hold the staples in place, but loading staples is slightly more difficult as it doesn't unhook as easily.The paint on this Rapid K1 protects it somewhat from fingerprints, but the price difference for some of the colors make it a bit hard to justify. Fortunately, there is also a version without any paint on it if all you care about is utility.I find the Bostitch to be easier to use, but if you're worried about plastic parts breaking, this or the Rapesco are both good choices. This one has an edge with thicker stacks of paper,

There are many things to like about this bag. Let's start with that.It's a small backpack designed to hold two GoPros and some accessories securely. The case is very well made. The material feels great, the zippers smooth, it is comfortable to wear (in one position - more on this later) and while wearing it, you can easily swivel it to the front to access the items in it. Thought has been given to small details, like an oversized zipper pull so that it is easier to grab when wearing gloves.It has one main compartment (where the foam insert goes in) with two zippered pockets (cables, memory cards), one smaller compartment where you can put accessories, and a tiny compartment lined with a softer material for a cell phone - that should just barely fit the largest phones today. There's a smaller phone pouch on the main strap that will not fit a phone with a 5" or larger screen. I wish the front pouch is not there, so that I can use a Polar Pro backpack mount.The foam insert is easily removable. I suppose you could get your own foam insert built for custom gear. The one supplied will hold two GoPros inside a waterproof case (they must be inside the case, or it will rattle around), two BacPacs (battery or LCD), one wireless remote, and two batteries.The most comfortable way to wear this is to sling it diagonally, with the strap resting on the left shoulder - as shown in the video. You could wear it on your right shoulder by not slinging it diagonally, but it is not as secure or comfortable. There's a smaller cross strap to further secure it so that it doesn't move around. That small strap needs to be unclasped to swing the back forward to access the backpack - or to hold it in front when you're in a crowded place and you're worried about pickpockets.I think this bag deserves more than 4 stars, but not quite 5 stars, due to the high price and inflexibility with the inserts.

Full disclosure : I was offered this unit for review by Arkon, but with no obligation on how I write my review, after they saw my review on the GN047.I could go on about how much I disliked the GN047 - it falls off frequently, it was finicky to put on, the clips look fragile, and the ball socket was a bit loose for a 5" Nuvi (the 2460).First improvement : there is only one beefy clip instead of two small fragile looking clip. MUCH easier to install. And the most important part, it stays where you put it.Next improvement : the ball appears to be slightly larger. It holds the same GPS without shifting. So there's no need to constantly adjust it. And when you do adjust it, it doesn't just fall off the vent like the GN047.If there is one negative, it is the price, about $5 higher than the GN047. But it is worth the difference just to avoid the frustration that is the GN047. However, at this price, it comes close to the price of a dashboard friction mount (a sandbag mount) which is more convenient - it has more flexibility in mounting positions, and it doesn't block the AC on hot summer days. In fact, an AmazonBasics friction mount is less expensive than the price of this right now. Vent mounts do hold the GPS more securely than friction mounts, especially after about a year of use when the grippy part seems to lose its effectiveness. The reason I got the GN047 was because my Nuvi on the Garmin friction mount was sliding off every time I make a turn.Again, I did receive this at no cost to me for review, but I feel that it is totally worth the higher cost compared to the GN047. If you're considering getting the GN047, do yourself a favor and get this one instead.

I received mine free for review, but I will gladly pay for it.I had an earlier version of the Contigo Autospout (the Addison). This one has a few improvements over it :1. Screw-in straw that won't drop off2. Switch to lock the spout from popping out3. Carabiner clip built into the handleI used that for more than 2 years before I lost it. It had functioned flawlessly, and for one handed use (e.g. when cycling) I find it to be very convenient, and it was my favorite non-insulated water bottle. I was about to buy a replacement when I was offered this one.It has the same features : screw off top makes it easy to fill, and easy to clean (I highly recommend the Oxo bottle brush). Spring loaded spout pops out when button is pressed, spout easily closed with the thumb. Shield keeps spout from coming into contact with clothes, although it won't keep out fine dust. I have Camel bottles with a spout that needs to be lifted manually. There's just something satisfying about having it flick open at the press of a button. I'd sometimes find myself absent mindedly opening / closing the spout continuously while reading, much to the irritation of my wife.I filled it with water, removed the straw (it is more likely to spill without the straw), turned it upside down, and shook vigorously for about 30 seconds. There were a few small drops of water, but I'd say it is indeed spillproof. Leaving it upside down for a few minutes, nothing spilled.One issue with the Addison is that if left in the sun, the expanding air will force some water out. I expect this to have the same issue. Might be an issue with elevation changes as well - I'll test this the next time I go on a hike.A couple of small negatives about this bottle : the lock is a bit difficult to operate with one hand using the thumb, and it seems to take a little more effort to suck up the water compared to the older design. The lid felt heavier than the previous one as well.I think the improved straw is worth the slightly higher price compared to the Contigo Addison. The lock is a good assurance against it popping open in your bag.

I had to look at a photo to confirm that those two plastic tabs really fit around the corners of the LCD panel. Together with the two elastic bands for the lower part of the laptop, it works surprisingly well and smoothly with my T450s - opening the case means that the laptop is opened, and I don't need to remove it from the sleeve in order to use it.The material feels like some kind of synthetic fabric, and the shell is mostly rigid. It has a 3D pattern that should provide some additional cushioning in case of bumps without adding much bulk, and it looks quite attractive as well.The only problem with this sleeve is that there is no space for a power adapter or accessories such as a mouse. It also blocks some vents and in some cases may cause a laptop to overheat and throttle down. If you're worried your backpack may not provide enough protection, or if you want a sleeve around your laptop at all times to protect it from scratches and knocks even when in use, this is an excellent choice, especially for laptops with excellent battery life and doesn't run too hot.

While this is a great looking laundry cart, there are some flaws that really shouldn't be there in a $50 laundry basket.First, there is a small gap on one of the side frames. Not a big deal, and if this is the only flaw, I'd have rated it 5 stars.The hooks where the laundry bags hang from don't just drop easily into the top rail. This is a minor point, and again, if this is the only flaw, I'd still rate it 5 stars.Next, the edges are sharp. If you knock into a corner, even at a fairly low speed, it is going to hurt a lot. I wish the edges are beveled or rounded. I may try doing this with sandpaper to see if it affects the finish on the bamboo.Finally, the casters are stiff and the cart does not roll easily. Yes, I did check to make sure they're not locked.For the same price, I bought the Seville Classics Heavy-Duty 3-Bag Laundry Sorter Cart a year and a half ago. Still working great and looks just like new. Like this one, it has great build quality. It doesn't look as attractive as this one with its bamboo frame, but the casters roll smoothly and there's no sharp corners to knock into. The casters on this one is what I'm really unhappy with. Other than that, assembly is very easy and everything fits together perfectly. All attachment points on the bamboo frames have metal screw threads embedded into the bamboo frame so there's no fear of the threads getting stripped. I will try to find replacement caster wheels and to sand down the edges, but for a laundry basket at this price, it shouldn't be necessary for me to do so.

This is my first "real" backpack. I've had other backpacks, but none of them are as large, or have an internal frame. With a little adjustment, it fits me comfortably. I was surprised by how light it is relative to the size. Adjusting the torso fit strap is easy - as long as you're making it shorter. I'm not exactly flexible, but I could easily reach the loops and pull it to tighten until it is just right. If you over-tighten, however, you'll need to take it off to loosen it. Not a major inconvenience.The backpack does not fit either of my teenage daughters, however. They can carry it, but even when adjusted for the shortest torso length, it does not fit them perfectly - if the shoulder straps sit perfectly, the waist belt is an inch or two too low. They're 5' 3" and 5' 7" - not exactly short. I believe it will fit them better as they grow.The number of straps on this looks quite intimidating at first glance, but a closer inspection showed what they're for. Some of the straps may be more easily adjusted by another person after you've put on the pack (remember that I'm not flexible). There's a large main compartment with top access and a zipper for side access, and a few smaller pockets - one zippered pocket on the lid, two zippered pockets at both sides of the waist belt (the only ones easily reached without removing the backpack), two side pockets for water bottles, and a compartment for a hydration pack.Tag on bag says it is made in Vietnam. The backpack has a limited lifetime warranty - Kelty's website says it includes material and workmanship, but does not include normal wear and tear, or damage from hazardous weather, animals, UV light or abuse.

I really want to like this activity tracker. But the limitations are just too frustrating to me.I've been using a Mi Band for the last two months. It is a very inexpensive device and looks nowhere as solid as the UP3. I'll compare the two devices later. First, let's look at what the UP3 provides.If you want an app that nags at you, provides lots of feedback and tips, points you to studies about health and fitness, this app is for you. On the other hand, if you just want something to track your activity, you may feel irritated by the app. I don't think it is quite that bad, but I would have preferred a much lower "nag level".The UP3 contains an accelerometer (to track movement), heartbeat sensor, galvanic skin response (to measure skin conductivity), and according to the specs on the website, tracks respiration as well. Anything else it tracks - your weight and caloric intake, are entered by you into the app. The only interaction with the app is to tap on it to wake it up, then to put it into either wake mode (running icon) or sleep mode (moon icon). It doesn't appear to be strictly necessary - I forgot to switch it once and it seems to still measure my sleep that night.The accelerometer works as advertised. It would measure steps even on a treadmill or elliptical (provided you're moving your arms on the elliptical). Heartbeat sensor seems to be used only to measure your resting heart rate. Sure, it is good to know my resting heart rate when I'm sleeping, but it would have been great to know my heart rate when exercising. I'm not sure why this is not provided - I can only guess it is due to some technical limitation.I have no idea what is galvanic skin response used to measure with the UP3. Maybe it is only used to keep track of whether the tracker is being worn? GSR together with heart beat and blood pressure is used in a lie detector, so maybe the UP3 can tell if you're lying when you're entering your weight.The clasp is quite frustrating for me. The video makes it look so simple to put on, but for me it has been frustrating to put it on with one hand. Maybe it gets easier with practice. I almost lost it 3 times in the 1 week I've been using it when the clasp came undone because I brushed it against something. Fortunately I noticed it in time.The magnetic charging cable is very nice, but not perfect. The cable is short and inflexible, and the strap on the UP3 is inflexible as well. You need to position everything properly when charging, and sometimes it involves propping up the UP3 with a book. A short and flexible USB extension cable may be helpful.Battery life of about 7 days seem pretty accurate. The UP3 can vibrate to alert the wearer of alarms or reminders. For some reason, I cannot set one time off reminders. Reminders will repeat on the same days every week.Now, let's compare it to the Mi Band.The most obvious difference is price. The Mi Band sells for about 1/10 of the price of the UP3. It does not have a heart rate monitor (rumors that the next version will have it) but you can get one for much less than the difference in price, and the HRM will track your heart rate during exercise, and not just resting heart rate.The next difference is battery life. Somehow, the Mi Band can last for 30 days on a single charge. Extremely impressive.I thought I'd test this by wearing it together with the Mi Band. Either by sheer coincidence, or by some strange interaction, my Mi Band that had been working flawlessly for more than a month suddenly malfunctioned after I installed the UP app and added the UP3, and it died the next day. I don't blame Jawbone for this - if there's any fault here, it lies entirely with the Mi Band. As a result, I couldn't do a side by side test of the two, but in terms of number of steps measured, they seem to be in the same ballpark.Compared to the UP app, the Mi Fit app is very spartan.Now this is the part that disappoints me the most : what the Mi Band can do, and the UP3 cannot.1. Smart lock. Android allows you to add a Bluetooth device as a trusted device. What this means is that if your device and phone are close to each other, the phone will remain unlocked, unless it has been idle for a long time (a few hours), or you explicitly lock it. It is very convenient, and I miss it terribly.2. Notifications. The Mi Band can vibrate when you receive a phone call. With 3rd party applications, you can also have it vibrate on other notifications, such as when receiving SMS, a chat request (Hangouts, Whatsapp, etc.). To me that's the most useful function I want out of a smart watch, and I can get it without having to deal with the high price and short battery life of a smart watch.I didn't quite expect it to handle notifications (although it should be possible through software) but I was genuinely shocked and bitterly disappointed when I can't use it for Smart Lock. I don't see the UP3 under paired devices in my Bluetooth setup. If it's not a paired device, it cannot be a trusted device. I was so sure I made a mistake, and started searching the web for a solution, but I could not find one.I rated this 3 stars because it does what it is supposed to, and it appears to do it reasonably well. But compared to a Fitbit Charge HR (which has heart rate monitor, and adds a display, for a lower price) and to a Mi Band (no heart rate monitor, but MUCH cheaper and adds a bunch of convenience features that has nothing to do with activity tracking), I find it extremely hard to recommend this to anyone. It may be the most advanced tracker, but a lot of that potential is unrealized.

I prefer to carry my DSLR with additional lenses in a camera backpack. I currently use a LowePro Fastpack 200, and I'm able to squeeze in a 5D Mark III with a 24-105mm f/4L, a 50mm f/1.4, a 580EX flash, and a 70-200mm f/2.8 IS in the top compartment. That's a fairly heavy load to be carrying around, but it is fairly comfortable, and it leaves my hands free. With that backpack, it is very easy to take out the camera - slip off a shoulder strap, swing it in front, open side pocket, and remove camera.There are two main disadvantage of the backpack. The bulk can be pretty awkward in crowded places, and everyone knows that you have photography equipment in there. It's harder to keep an eye on things when it is on your back.This messenger bag doesn't look big, but to my surprise it fits that whole list of stuff mentioned above - apart from the 70-200mm lens - pretty comfortably. There's still some space left that will fit another small lens, or the camera's battery charger. There's also two pockets - one velcroed and one zippered - that will hold the usual spare batteries, memory cards, filters. There's also a slot in the side compartment that can fit a tablet. My 11" Acer Chromebook fits in there fairly comfortably as well.All the camera gear fits into a pod that can be removed. If you want to use this for something other than photography gear, the insert comes out easily with all your gear securely held in it. Without the insert, you can fit a 13" or 14" laptop in there, though it is a tight fit with the 14".There's a zipper to access the tablet sleeve without opening the flap. You can reach your tablet, wallet, purse, or whatever small item you store in there without showing everyone that you're carrying a camera in your messenger bag.The bag is sturdy, the shell made of nylon and is water resistant, and it is quite attractive. And it comes with an amazing 25 year warranty.Much as I like it, I do have one quibble about it. The clips that hold the bag closed are somewhat awkward to operate. The buckle is partly recessed into a flap, and if you have fat fingers like mine, it's not easy to release the clip when carrying the bag. It's also difficult for me to buckle it back up without looking at what I'm doing - that may get easier with practice.It is not as comfortable to carry as the backpack - no surprise, since weight is distributed across two straps. But the way weight is distributed, it is not bad, and significantly better than carrying the backpack with only one strap.Overall, I prefer the backpack for long trips, especially if I have to bring it on a plane, but this messenger bag looks perfect for a day trip when I don't need huge telephoto lenses.For anyone who finds the country of manufacture important, the tag says the bag is made in Vietnam.

This hole puncher is built like a tank. It has a big footprint and is really not meant to be moved around. I can't really tell if the "50% less effort" claim is true - it does take less effort to punch through thicker stacks of paper. It can punch through 45 sheets of copier paper with a little effort. The springs are really strong on this one, so it takes a fair amount of effort to press it down even if there is no paper. But punching through paper only takes a little incremental effort. The arm makes it really easy to push down with the palm of your hand, unlike smaller hole punchers.Hole position is perfect. When aligned properly, which is really easy to do, the distance between top of page and top hole and bottom of page and bottom hole is identical, and middle hole is positioned exactly in the center. And of course it fits a 3 ring binder perfectly.I've owned hole punchers where you can adjust the alignment guides, disable the center hole, even change the position of the holes. This one has nothing adjustable. The only moveable part (other than the handle) is the lock, to hold the handle down, potentially saving some space. No need to worry about accidentally releasing the lock and having the handle spring up. To unlock, you need to press down a bit on the handle before unlocking.The base is plastic and has 4 little felt circles to keep it from sliding around. It doesn't grip as well as rubber feet, but it does the job and does not slide around in use.The tray is the weakest part of the hole puncher. It does not latch / unlatch smoothly, and when removing the tray to empty it, I usually spill a bit of the chips. Maybe it will get smoother with use. A little disappointing in an otherwise fantastic hole puncher.If you have lots of material to punch, and the table space for this, it's a great hole puncher.

I own another stapler that can staple 40+ sheets of paper, the Bostitch B8HDP. I've had it for over 4 years now, and it is what I'm comparing this stapler against.Construction : the Bostitch has a plastic sheath over the metal guts. This Rapesco is all metal. Plastic may make it more comfortable to hold. While the Bostitch's loading mechanism is a plastic clip that will probably be the first thing to break, this Rapesco is all metal and looks like it should outlast me easily.Staple : Both the Bostitch and this Rapesco takes special staples. The Rapesco staple is very slightly wider (1/2" wide) and almost twice as thick - about 1/128" for the Bostitch and 1/64" for the Rapesco.Use : I tested with a stack of 45 sheets of normal photocopier paper. Even though the Rapesco Porpoise is rated for 40 sheets, it stapled through it without any problem. The Rapesco (with 24/8mm staples) may take slightly more effort than the Bostitch (with 3/8" PowerCrown) but the difference is negligible. I do have large hands (glove size L to XL), but it was very little effort to operate either stapler.Other uses : The Rapesco has an anvil (the part at the lower "lip" which bends the legs of the staple) that can be rotated to pin paper instead of staple them together. What's pinning, and what is it used for? Normally the legs of a staple bends inwards to hold paper together. In pinning, the legs bend outwards, to form almost a straight line. It is used to hold paper together temporarily as it is easier to remove. The Bostitch cannot be used for pinning.The Bostitch, on the other hand, can be used for tacking. The lower jaw can be unhinged and the stapler used to, for example, tack notices to a cork board. The jaw of the Rapesco is one solid piece, so that's not going to work.Price : The Rapesco is almost half the price of the Bostitch.If you need to staple thick stacks of paper (normal staplers can handle about 20 sheets) this stapler is an incredible value. Just remember to buy the special staples - it does not take "normal" staples.

The box that this comes in is huge. Due to the shape of the contents, there is a lot of empty space in the box. Don't panic when it arrives at your front door.The satin black finish on the units is subtle and does not draw any attention to it. There are two LEDs on the sound bar that provides status. I don't find them distracting, but if you do, black electrical tape is always an option. The subwoofer fires to the right side when placed as intended, when you're facing the TV. The sound bar is just a little bit longer than my tiny 42" Panasonic TV.Setup is extremely simple. Significantly easier than wiring up a surround sound system, and all parts except for wall mount are included. If you want to mount this on the wall, a drilling template is supplied, but you need to get your own mounting hardware (2 x drywall anchor if necessary and screw).As the name suggests, the connection between the sound bar and the subwoofer is wireless. The sound bar needs 2 connections - one for power, through a power brick, and one for input. The woofer needs to be connected to a wall power socket, but can be located anywhere within 50 feet of the sound bar.An optical (TOSLINK) cable is supplied. If you want to use RCA cable instead (or in addition) of optical, you need to supply your own. Either way, physical installation consists of :1. Connect power cable to subwoofer2. Connect power cable to power brick, and power brick cable to sound bar3. Connect optical cable from TV to sound bar4. Insert coin battery into remote controlIf you need longer power cables, the cable type for both the subwoofer and the power brick is the common IEC 60320 C7 (a.k.a. "Figure 8") ungrounded cable.You're done. You can start using it. The supplied remote control has a few buttons : Power, volume up / down, mute, input select, bluetooth, and 3D. Using the input select, you can choose between 3 inputs : optical (LED is green), RCA (LED is yellow - actually more like a lighter green) or Bluetooth (LED is blue). Power it up, it takes about 3 to 4 seconds before you start hearing sound. If you have a separate audio player with RCA out, you can hook up both your TV and audio player to the sound bar.Some additional setup makes life just a little easier. First, turn off the speakers on your TV. Not only is the sound from this way better than the TV's speakers, there seems to be a small but detectable time difference between soundbar and TV speaker output when I play video from my BluRay player, resulting in a very odd echo effect. Next, you can configure the sound bar to recognize your TV remote's volume up / down / mute buttons, so that you can use the TV remote for these instead of the sound bar's remote - less juggling of remotes when watching TV.Some people have mentioned that it comes on when the TV is turned on. It only happened once with me - if I turn off the switch behind the sound bar, then back on, it is in standby mode. When I turn on the TV (using the TV's remote control) after that, the sound bar comes on as well. But when I turn the TV off, the sound bar remains on. I have to use the Klipsch remote control to put it in standby. After that, turning the TV on does not turn on the sound bar, but adjusting the volume will turn it on, so it's not a major hassle. It would be nice if it turns on / off together with the TV though.Bluetooth pairing took me a couple of tries to set up. When I turn the sound bar off and on again, I had to disable / re-enable Bluetooth on my phone to get it to reconnect. I need to experiment more with this, and will update this review. By comparison, my Jabra Bluetooth devices connect flawlessly to my phone almost every time.The sound from the TV is best described as "better than nothing". Compromises obviously have to be made when fitting speakers onto a flat panel TV. That this sound bar sounds better than the TV should come as no surprise to anyone. But what surprised me is how much better it sounded. Obviously the bass that was missing from the TV's built-in speakers adds a whole new dimension to the sound. But even the mid range sounds much clearer. Speech is definitely easier to understand. And you can crank up the volume very high without much distortion.I tried the "3D" effect but I'm not impressed with it. It does change the sound, but I felt it's for the worse, and I couldn't really detect any 3D effect. I'd consider this a very good stereo speaker system, but it won't give you an immersive experience of a true surround system.The manual is pretty minimal and is mostly pictures with few words. The only part I found just a little confusing is the instructions on how to reprogram the remote control buttons - the step numbers are jumbled around, but it's not difficult to figure it out.1. When LED on sound bar is solid green, press and hold MUTE button until LED flashes yellow2. Press button to be reprogrammed (MUTE, VOL+ or VOL-). LED will change to solid yellow3. Press corresponding button on TV remote control 4 times slowly. Each time the LED will flash green.4. LED will go back to solid green when programming is complete.I measured the total power draw of subwoofer + sound bar with a Kill-a-Watt and got the following measurements :Standby : 1 WOn : 9WSoundbar On, Subwoofer Off : 5WOn, volume cranked up : 10WBoth the sound bar and subwoofer have physical power switches located at the back if you want to trade convenience for saving power.

Tastes OK, not too salty, fish smell is a little strong. Definitely recommend some pepper on it, or a sprinkle of lemon juice. Salmon texture is not great, not surprising since it comes in a soft envelope. Canned salmon have a better texture but this quantity is about perfect for a single person. A nice addition of protein to a lettuce salad.

It's inexpensive, has power to spare, no ugly wall wart, uses a detachable C7 ("figure 8") cable, and supports USB OTG. Device won't charge when using USB OTG. OTG cable provided.For those who don't know what it is, USB OTG allows you to connect your supported Android phone on one end, and a USB flash drive, mouse, or keyboard on the other end, to use the device. Flash drive may require additional software - especially if you have an unrooted Nexus device.I like the detachable cable. If I'm traveling overseas, I can usually pick up a C7 cable for that country and leave the supplied US cable at home. The transformer is contained within the unit, no space-occupying wall wart with this one.It would be nice if it had a metal casing instead of plastic, and if it had come with some cables. I picked up a bunch of 1.5' USB cables from another online retailer, put everything in a compact bag, and I have enough outlets to recharge everyone's devices when we're on a family vacation.

It didn't take much experimenting to figure out how to install this, which is fortunate since it did not come with any instructions. I contacted Retrospec Bicycles and was told that no instructions is available. Basically, you attach one part to your bicycle - hooks over the handle and a velcro strap around the post. Then lift the handles in the basket straight up, slot everything nicely into the part attached to the bicycle. Lower the handles, and the basket is locked in place. I suggest pressing down on the basket to make sure it won't come into contact with the front tire even with a lot of weight in the basket. There's a support that can be adjusted for distance from post, but be careful with that - I managed to pinch my finger adjusting that as it is fairly tight. Gloves would be good if you're clumsy like me.The basket is heavy, but this is obviously not meant for road bikes. It provides an easy way to carry things for short commutes. I can carry a backpack, but it gets pretty warm. Having it in the basket means I can get to the train station without getting all sweaty. It's well constructed and the fine mesh at the bottom is a nice touch.

They do taste good. They taste rather sweet to me, and I do have a sweet tooth. The kids don't find it too sweet though. For some reason, the apple flavor seems to taste less sweet than the other two, even though it has about the same amount of sugar. Speaking of sugar, it does have quite a lot of sugar - 12g - is roughly equivalent to about 1/3 can of regular soda. So don't just eat them thinking they're nutritious. I find the crust to be a little soft and gritty, but not too bad. They do make a relatively healthy snack in moderation.

I received this cable for review, as well as the PVC type, both 3 ft length.The cables are well constructed and the ends molded nicely. They're also quite flexible. The TPE might be slightly more flexible than the PVC, but the difference is very small. The most obvious difference between the two is the feel - the TPE feels soft and rubbery, while the PVC feels hard and smooth. The feel of the TPE cable is quite unusual, unlike any other cable I have. The PVC feels just like a "normal" cable.The photo shows the cable looking more like red, but they're definitely pink - a pink usually associated with baby girls. It definitely stands out - I have no other cables that looks anything like it. This cable will definitely not get lost in my bag.The reason for getting either the PVC or TPE APLWL cable is the color. It's not a lot more than most cables, and the color makes it easy to pick out in a bag filled with other cables. Especially this one.Normally, for charging, the longer the cable, the greater the loss. Since USB is only 5V, and the wires usually very thin, the resistance adds up. A 3 ft cable is a good compromise. I recently purchased a PortaPow USB Power Monitor, so I could tell how much current is flowing through the cable.Apparently the most power hungry device I have, a Nexus tablet, would only charge at 1.1A. I tried different cables and chargers and the results are identical. So I can only report that this cable performs flawlessly at 1.1A. If I get another device that draws more power, I'll report back.Used for data transfer, it performs flawlessly, like any other decent USB cable.You can get decent cheaper cables from reputable companies, but this is not a lot more to pay for a well built cable that is colorful and easy to spot.

I received this cable for review, as well as the PVC type, both 3 ft length.The cables are well constructed and the ends molded nicely. They're also quite flexible. The TPE might be slightly more flexible than the PVC, but the difference is very little. The most obvious difference between the two is the feel - the TPE feels soft and rubbery, while the PVC feels hard and smooth. The feel of the TPE cable is quite unusual, unlike any other cable I have.The reason for getting either the PVC or TPE APLWL cable is the color. It's not a lot more than most cables, and the color makes it easy to pick out in a bag filled with other cables - as long as they're not blue Ethernet cables.Normally, for charging, the longer the cable, the greater the loss. Since USB is only 5V, and the wires usually very thin, the resistance adds up. A 3 ft cable is a good compromise. I recently purchased a PortaPow USB Power Monitor, so I could tell how much current is flowing through the cable.Apparently the most power hungry device I have, a Nexus tablet, would only charge at 1.1A. I tried different cables and chargers and the results are identical. So I can only report that this cable performs flawlessly at 1.1A. If I get another device that draws more power, I'll report back.You can get decent cheaper cables from reputable companies, but this is not a lot more to pay for a well built cable that is colorful.

This is a great set of screwdrivers with just the right sizes for probably 95% of your around the house tasks needing either a flat or Philips head. The black oxide tips really do seem to help with the grip. Despite another reviewer's claim, I did find these heads to be magnetic and easily hold the screw. I'm attaching a photo showing me holding it vertically head down with a screw magnetically attached. The two smallest sizes are very handy for those hard to reach screws like those tiny ones for battery compartments.The holes in the handle serve multiple purposes: you can use them to hang them for storage. You can also put another driver through the whole to get better leverage and grip on hard to budge screws. Between that and the oxide tip, you should experience much less slippage (and stripping of screw heads). The grip is comfortable and the bulbous end is a good fit in any hands. I would highly recommend this set, especially to a new homeowner/renter who needs a decent affordable set of screwdrivers to serve most purposes.

The Zippo 12-hour hand warmer is a must have for anyone who spends a decent amount of time outdoors in cold winter months. While it touts being able to last up to 12 hours, I've actually been able to get even more hours out of it. It is slim, easily fits in a pocket and stays very warm. Here's how it works:-Pop off the chrome upper half lid-Take off the catalytic burner unit-Fill with lighter fluid (sold separately)-Put the catalytic burner back on-Light - Once lit, put back on the lid and put into the fabric bag.I also had a previous version, which came with a different lighter fluid refilling reservoir. It had a wider fill opening, making it more susceptible for spills. They have improved that design. While it works very well, there are a couple things I don't like about it: it is sort of a hassle to get it filled, lit, and ready to go. It takes me a couple minutes, so I have to make sure I leave enough time to get it filled and lit before I go outside. Also, if you aren't careful, it is easy to spill fluid as you are filling the warmer's reservoir. Furthermore, it is sometimes tough to tell exactly when the catalytic burner is lit. You can easily tell if you are in complete darkness, but in the light, it is harder to tell. Despite the hassle, I still love having this hand warmer and use it frequently.

If you've know of the brand "Kibbles and Bits" and understand it is made of dry dog food with smaller, softer, meatier chunks, then these Alpo Meal Helpers are essentially all "bits" which you can mix in with your choice of kibble.We have small dogs, so a little bit of this goes a long way. I usually don't even mix a whole pouch with their dinners. All the dogs love these, but especially our Tibetan Spaniel and Pomeranian. They aren't mixed with any gravy, which makes it not messy at all. If you have a picky eater and don't want to hassle with the mess of mixing in wet pouches of dog food, then these may be good for you. Also, I've used them as treats for the dogs, giving them a few of these bits here and there.

I don't get pedicures often, so it's a special treat to pamper my feet now & then. They do get pretty atrocious when ignored for too long! I get nasty calluses on the sides of my big toes and around the perimeter of my heels, because of the way I walk.Rough skin isn't my only foot issue - I've also suffered from plantar fasciitis for years because of large heel spurs growing underneath. After orthotics, special shoes, and other external methods didn't help, I had surgery 5 weeks ago to remove one of the heel spurs. It is healing slowly, and because I can't afford to slow down and rest as much as I need to, it still aches and hurts a lot. My doctor has been giving me ultrasound treatments to reduce inflammation and pain, but I only see him every couple of weeks at most. Much to my VERY happy surprise, this device feels almost the same as the ultrasound vibrations at the doctor's office! And provides almost as much relief! And, I can use it every day to help relieve the pain - more than once, if I want! The brush attachments & sonic waves, combined with soothing lotions, feel absolutely wonderful!As a pedicure device, it has some limitations. When I ordered this gadget, I thought the brush/file head would spin instead of just vibrate (I don't read descriptions very thoroughly, I admit). I suspect that spinning would be more effective when it comes to sanding down the calluses, though you would go through the textured pads really fast. As it is, the device emits a subtle vibration (at 3 varying speeds) & you move the brush in a circular motion to gently rub down the rough areas. It provides more control this way, I think, though it still wears down the textured pads pretty quickly and I can't find replacements at Amazon! On my first try, I did use it for a long time on various settings, and my feet felt REALLY nice. It is much more gentle than the Ped-Egg (OUCH - whoops), and provides more subtle & soft results. My feet have stayed very soft for days.The device is indeed water resistant in the shower, though it's a pretty awkward way to scrub your feet while standing up (I did not try in a sit-down bath). I really liked it best outside the bath, when using the brush attachment to apply a soothing peppermint cream to my poor aching feet. Using the different speeds and a circular motion, the sonic vibrations & softening lotion felt FANTASTIC. I could barely walk on my sore post-surgical foot after a long day of painting walls & moving furniture, and after an hour with this gadget my foot felt as good as new! The very-stiff brush bristles are kind of hard to clean, when it comes to lotion, but it's all worth it!As a pedicure kit, it's okay. It's not a fast process for softening & pampering your feet, but you're supposed to be relaxing right? What I would REALLY like to see with this device/kit, is a) extra sanding discs for the calluses because they wear down too quickly, and b) some kind of case for all these attachments. Between the plug, dock, brush, brush heads, and covers, you get 7 different pieces and no way to really store them together unless you keep the original box. Even a cloth drawstring bag would be handy; I just know I'm going to lose at least 3 of these pieces within a few weeks. Because of these issues, I wanted to give it only 3 stars, but those sonic vibrations left my foot pain-free when nothing else helped! As a post-surgical healing aid, I'd give it 10 stars out of 5! But I understand, that's not exactly a common issue, and more people just want a quick and pleasant pedicure. The other reviewers make some valid points on that issue, but I adore this thing and am going to use it a lot!Also, the loud BEEPS when it wants you to switch feet are kind of unnecessary, and they scare the crap out of my dogs.

I've been overall pleased with most aspects of the Amped Wireless Titan AC1900 router. It boasts high coverage and performance and it delivers in those areas, which are what matter most with a router. I've had no trouble connecting any of my devices to it from the furthest extents of the house. Also, I've been getting faster speeds and fewer lags and buffering when streaming video (though there are so many factors at play, I can't say it's all because of the router...still...). The setup was easy with the wizard and most of your standard router settings are easy to find and change. I had no trouble finding and setting up the guest network and security. I was up and running within 10 minutes of getting it out of the box. I've never had a router where you could purposefully limit the range, which this router has - good for a dorm room or small dedicated office where you don't want the signal broadcast everywhere. Another feature I didn't realize I wanted was the ability to turn off the LEDs.Overall I have very few gripes about the router. There does seem to be fewer settings available for tweaking, compared with my old TP Link. My former routers (TP Link & D Link) also did a better job with giving descriptions and explanations within the settings you are tweaking. This one doesn't have as much documentation embedded on those settings screens. The wi-fi analytics tool app I found pretty much useless. It lets you analyze the available wi-fi networks and things like channel strength. However, it isn't a full fledged router settings manager and doesn't show you any sort of network map of the devices connected. At this price, I would hope there would be more options for managing the router from your smartphone.Overall, this is a very powerful router with a very wide range. It would just be nice if it had a few more options and documentation within the settings.

I don't think I read the description very well, because I was expecting it to be about a foot long & maybe 6" tall at most. Imagine my shock when the UPS man came strolling up the walk with such an enormous (yet not very heavy) box! This dog is so big! Stands 15" tall and stretches to a full 3 feet; it is pretty substantially long when not stretched, too. The slinky dog in Toy Story struck me as looking like a hard plastic toy (I don't know if that was intentional, or if it was just my imagination), and this one is very soft, huggable, and just delightful! Looks just like the dog in the movie, to me, but really big and really soft - all good things!I think any kid would go crazy for this, even if they aren't a huge Toy Story fan (if that's possible). Even if you consider it just a stuffed animal, it is pretty unique! I never imagined a slinky would be so soft and hug-worthy! What kid wouldn't love a big soft dog that stretches halfway across your bedroom?I don't know if this will ever be considered a "collectible" for Disney/Pixar enthusiasts, but for the adult collector this would make a really fun conversation piece. The surprisingly large size makes it so playful, and I think his spring-shaped belly would be a fun way to display some of your smaller Woodys & Buzz Lightyears. Maybe I'm not normal because at 43 I still like stuffed animals, but to me this seems like a good gift for a Toy Story fan of any age!Amazon needs to figure out something different for shipping though, to avoid damage to the original box. Despite being all alone in a generously-sized box with a lot of crinkled kraft paper for padding, the original display box had gotten crushed somewhere along the way so it has very crumpled corners & sides, plus a big rip in the top of the cardboard. Obviously you can't really "break" a stuffed animal, but with the holidays coming, gifts look nicer if the box hasn't gotten all beat up first. Kids probably don't care anyway, but I prefer to give a new-looking gift!

This thing is so awesome, it's ridiculous. Though it has clearly been designed for a frequent traveler, or maybe even a professional coder who hauls a lot of tech around the office, it also suits my different needs rather perfectly. I make things for art/craft fairs, and have to haul a lot of very random, awkward things to every show, and it has been wonderful!It is extremely durable, even internally - it can take the punishment of a metal cashbox full of change without so much as a scratch, even while the other section is extremely overstuffed with snacks to share with show visitors. The side pockets are the perfect shape to lug bottled water or pop (in bottles or cans), and the front pocket has little sections for wallet basics as well as a surprisingly roomy area for the other essentials so I don't have to bring my purse if I don't want to! There's even a flatter zip pocket above it that is the perfect size for my phone, to keep it from knocking around into things the other crowded areas (also allows one-step access to grab my phone, score!).Today I took it with me to run errands on my bicycle. I had to drop off a fragile package first, which was well-padded in one of the primary compartments. Next, I stopped at the grocery store for a few things...but apparently I was hungry because I bought a LOT OF THINGS. Again I was able to cram everything into this amazing backpack without so much as bruising one apple! It was packed pretty tight (I was real hungry, no joke) but I still carried it home on my bicycle quite comfortably.I can really see where this would be perfect for travel. It has a perfectly-sized, well-protected compartment for a laptop, though I don't carry one I would feel very comfortable shoving my iPad in there. I also don't carry a lot of files or briefs (though a sketchbook and pencils are not out of the question) and while they would fit well in there, it will also carry all my clothes and toiletries MUCH better than the typical Jansport backpack that I might normally lug with me for a weekend trip. Not just more heavy-duty (and attractive), but it has myriad pockets inside the myriad pockets, to fit all sorts of weird items you might need for whatever it is you do. Also, it has a padded sleeve on the back which makes it easy & convenient to slide on the handle of a rolling bag for travel.It looks elegant but simple - you can see the quality, but it's not so ostentatious that it would automatically attract thieves. I'm very proud to carry it around, but not so deeply concerned about watching it every second for theft like I might for a designer handbag that cost the same amount. Maybe I'm just being foolish, but it doesn't trade looks for function. It simply looks like a very well-made, high-quality, heavy-duty backpack.I will say, if there is a drawback (other than the price, which is fairly steep), it is not only heavy-duty, it's also very heavy. This is to be expected with something that has so many great pockets and so much padding for your delicate electronic devices, but it might not be something you want to take on long hikes unless you're really used to a good amount of weight before adding anything to it. It's really not a huge drawback, and not very surprising when you take into account all the things it can haul, but it's heavy enough to merit a mention.Still give it 5 stars. I absolutely love it!

We have a camper, which I've been slowly decorating in a vintage tiki style. Previously, I had some straw-style Hawaiian-themed placemats that were very cute, BUT...one of them got mildew after rain came in the dinette window, and the other got ruined when somebody (me) spilled chocolate milk all over it. These are not just a perfect replacement, but MUCH more suited to the task of camping!The look is very nice - they look like a bamboo/grasscloth with just the right texture, so in my camper they echo the tiki style. But, I can imagine them being very versatile for any room; they're really a neutral color that will look fine in any decor. The texture feels similar to the nubby straw placemats I had before, but with a slightly more rubbery feel. This is fantastic in my camper because they a) won't slip around on the dinette table, and b) they will REPEL moisture (in the form of water or chocolate milk) instead of soaking it in and getting ruined. Honestly, what was I thinking getting fragile, non-water-resistant anything for camping? I'd feel very comfortable using these outdoors as well as inside. Even on a gross campground picnic table, they will keep the food neat & tidy and easily wipe clean after a meal.LOVE them. I'd recommend them for any home, but especially for any camper!

Considering the price of this unit, I think you can get much better results from one of the many other options available. This unit touts its versatility as a 5 in 1 device. However, I found the open grill/griddle positions to be close to useless, due to the amount of time it took to cook. I had to turn the temperature up to sear and it still took me over 20 minutes to cook pancakes. I tried doing burgers and it took equally long. I placed my hand about a cm up from the grill on sear and I could have held it there all day. It only felt like it got moderately hot. The grease collection does not function well either, since the grill is level. Also, I wish the grease collection cups had a way of locking in place, instead of just being separate and possibly sliding out of position.The plates themselves were very easy to clean with the ceramic coating. I was nervous since the grill ridges were very deep - I was afraid food would get stuck and I wouldn't be able to clean it, but that was not the case.If you were planning on using this as a panini press, you might be okay. That functioned alright. The size of the plates seemed bigger than other presses I've tried. You could easily fit two large sandwiches on it - so that's a plus. However, I would avoid this if you are truly looking for a versatile device that can also function as a griddle. There are too many other options on the market that function as a panini press better for less.

This is one of the best backpacks I have used as far as quality and design is considered. It has all the features you would expect from a premium backpack, plus more. Most notably, I love having the crush proof compartment for delicate items. I feel much more secure putting my glasses, phone, watch and other more fragile items. It has lots of small pockets in smartly designed places, including a vertical zipping small front pocket. It is also designed to be used as a daypack for outdoor enthusiasts, meaning you can insert a water bladder if you want. There are also convenient side pockets for water bottles. It features a main large compartment, two mid-size compartments, then the crushproof area and a front small pocket. And each of those compartments has sub-compartments within.It may be slightly undersized if you are looking for a pack to carry all your electronics and a lot of books or papers. I think it can do one well, but not both. I can fit a very large laptop, plus a tablet in there, and have room for all my cords. However, there isn't a ton of extra space beyond that. It fits very comfortably with wide straps, a padded back, and torso straps.Overall, this is a very well crafted, designed, and constructed backpack, suitable for most, but not all uses.Pros: High Quality Zippers  Lots of compartments  Crush proof pocket for glasses, phonesCons: May be too small if you need to fit in a lot of electronics and books

These are awesome. I make some items to sell at a local consignment shop and usually make my own tags, but these seemed so much cuter for my Halloween designs. The size is PERFECT for the small circular stickers I got from Vistaprint for my logo, and I used small rectangle price stickers for the other side. The tags are a good thickness that won't rip or bend easily while still being lightweight, and the little hole at the top is perforated but not removed (so you will have tiny black dots all over the place after assembling them). It comes with two 50ft lengths of jute twine that can be cut into whatever size you need for each tag. For my Halloween products, the jute added a really nice touch!! This would be cool for a rustic, homey-looking holiday or birthday gift wrap too.I thought the quality was awesome for the price. You get a ton of them, and I like the fact that you can cut the twine to variable lengths. I like everything about this product. If the online photos look like what you're seeking, you'll be very happy with the quality once you receive it!

Very, VERY soft!!! One side has the textured pattern seen in the photo, and the other is just a ridiculously soft plush faux fur. The textured side is extremely soft too, but the other is like, a level of softness that feels almost otherworldly. This blanket is going to be so nice and warm in the winter!! The pillow forms didn't quite fit our pillows (our pillows were slightly too large) but we still managed to cram them in there anyway - made for very hard, overstuffed pillows! Not the covers, which are insanely soft, just the loft because we were too lazy to buy new pillows and tried to fit 20" of pillow into an 18" cover. Covers have a zip closure, but it's an invisible zipper, which means it's hard to find and grasp but will not leave uncomfortable zipper marks on your face if you fall asleep on that side of the pillow.The diamond pattern as shown in the photo is actually much more subtle in person; it's more of a texture with a slightly lighter thread color outlining the diamonds. It doesn't look like white outlines at all, just adds a little something extra to the look and feel of the material. It's a very rich purple though, so you have to really like purple! The blanket is a bit thinner than it appears in the photo, which is actually good because this soft faux-fur material can get mighty hot after a while - you definitely would not want it to be any thicker or heavier! The blanket is a nice big size too, plenty of room for snuggling with a friend under there. Much bigger than your average "throw" which generally leaves your toes sticking out.The way it comes packaged is PERFECT for gift-giving. I suspect they had this in mind for the holidays and packaged it accordingly (it would be great for a dorm room or housewarming too, but it is wrapped with wide red ribbon that vaguely implies "Christmas"). It comes all folded into a tight rectangle with cardboard inside to keep it from collapsing, and has ribbon looped through a shiny cardboard label detailing the materials, washing instructions, etc. It really does look nice! I could imagine it sitting atop a small pile of fully-wrapped presents, just as is without any additional wrapping. Then the recipient could wrap themselves up in the soft blanket while opening the other gifts! Sounds like a very merry holiday indeed.Pros: SUPER soft, blanket is an excellent size & perfect thickness, diamond pattern/texture is very subtle & not at all tacky.Cons: Really must make sure the recipient likes purple! And you may have to work out a blanket-sharing schedule with your pets, because they like super soft faux fur just as much as you do.Draw: I don't know if the pillow forms are really necessary. How many people want to match their pillows to their throw blankie? Maybe a lot, I don't know. I wound up taking my too-large pillows out and letting the dogs cuddle with the empty pillow covers. That way they don't get too possessive of the large blanket & I can have it all for myself!

This seems like a perfect food for small dogs - nutritious, tiny kibble (good for problematic mouths like Pekingese & Pug, or elderly dogs), it is a flavor my dogs usually go nuts for...I don't know why they didn't like it. I thought they would go bananas for it! I've tried Nutro brands with dogs I've had in the past, and they liked it. Maybe mine are just hopelessly spoiled after having tried AvoDerm, they always eat that with no problems. This Nutro, they ate some of it but all 3 of them left a good portion in their bowls. And since I mix their dinner with a bit of canned wet food, these tiny kibbles seem to become one with the bowl when abandoned until the next day's meal - very hard to clean out the leftovers.I am not giving this a bad rating because I seriously believe this is very good dog food. It's very healthy, full of natural ingredients & excellent nutrition, I trust the brand, and I think the kibble size is perfect for small breeds or elderly dogs. My dogs just didn't seem to want to eat it, and they refused to explain why. I'm going to say they're very spoiled, and there's nothing wrong with the Nutro! I would still recommend it to anybody.

I still recall the day I upgraded my 20GB Xbox 360 HD with a 100GB HD and thinking, "There, now I'll never have to worry about storage again." Fast forward 4 years, lots of Rock Band DLC and the ability to store full games to the HD and I find myself at about 90% full. Enter the Seagate 2TB drive. Now I can have that feeling again of, "There, now I'll never have to worry about storage again."This Seagate game drive seems to be a pretty typical 2TB hard drive, priced similar to other 2TB drives, but with officially licensed Xbox One or Xbox 360 compatibility and design. When you consider the basic Xbox One 500GB console is currently priced around $350 and the newer 1 TB model is about $400, you could get the 500GB model and one of these drives (currently $100) and spend about $450 and have a total of 2.5 TB of storage. Basically, an extra 1.5 TB for an extra $50, which isn't a bad deal. Of course, you have to consider your current usage and potential future storage needs.The main thing I think it lacks is a little more in the way of instructions for transferring data from the console to the drive. While it wasn't that difficult for me to figure out, it might be a little more challenging for a parent who is not as up to speed on how these work. Especially considering it is an officially licensed Xbox product, it was surprising there was little more than a short pamphlet describing the drive's features included. I wish it would have gone into more detail about how it handles in-game DLC licensing content vs game content. It was not the most user friendly in that regard. I finished transferring data and wasn't positive if I was going to be able to play with DLC once it was moved to the drive (I was).
