A little more clarity in what it would and would not transfer would have been helpful as well as explanation on what you need to do if you use it on an Xbox 360, then upgrade to the Xbox One. I plan to do this in a few weeks, so I may update the review if I hit any other snags in that process.

I've been taking Viva Labs CLA for almost a month now. While I haven't been noticing any significant weight loss I can solely attribute to the supplement, I have noticed these Omega-6s did leave me feeling full for longer, even when taken with relatively small meals. They are the same large size as the largest fish oil pills I have taken - so expect large pills. However, they did go down easy and you don't get the fish burp after taste like you would with the fish oil. To gain the full effect, they recommend taking 1-2 of these three times daily. Taking 2 of these three times daily seems excessive, unless you are obese. Multiple respected websites I've read state the recommended dosage as a supplement is 3.4 grams, which would be three of these. Taking more may not give you an added benefit, just run you out of the supplement twice as fast.

I'm a moderately active individual and have been been pretty active with workouts recently, but haven't ventured into the realm of energy supplements and similar products. I'm glad I tried the Cellucor - C4 pre workout mix. I definitely felt increased energy and stamina throughout my normal workout and beyond. Even after I finished my normal routine, I felt extra energy to run an extra 20 minutes after my workout.I'm glad I read the label and reviews so I was prepared for that tingling feeling from the niacin. If you haven't taken a supplement like this before, you should definitely be prepared. I really didn't mind the taste at all. It was very fruity and not overly "chemically" tasting. While it did give me a bit of a boost, it wasn't overly strong and I could see how you might need to take more than just one scoop to really reap the benefits, or maybe even add an additional supplement or cup of coffee beforehand.

The Stanley Classic Vacuum bottle is a decent recreation of an American classic. I do not have another original "US made" Stanley thermos to compare this to. However, I can say I am reasonably pleased with its ability to retain heat and cold. It works better than a comparable Thermos brand bottle and a large hot water carafe I have. I placed ice in it and 5 days later there was still solid ice in it. I also put hot liquid in it and it was still hot enough for my liking by the end of the day. If you can fill it with hot water before pouring in your drink of choice, I think you will notice a better heat retention. The only issue I have with it is the handle is very stiff and completely made of plastic. The handle should at least have a metal insert in it, as the plastic feels very flimsy and gives it a sort of cheap feel to it.

SUPER tight and sturdy - I think it is a fine product, IF you have a very large, strong dog to run with. I have small dogs, but one of them (a Tibetan Spaniel) pulls on the leash all the time so I thought this might be a good way to walk her. The bungee is so tight that she can't stretch it at all, and because of that she's always running right next to my foot - this is a recipe for big time tripping over each other and face-planting the sidewalk.Bottom line is, might be great for your big strong Rottweiler, Pit Bull, etc, but this is not going to work for small dogs. It does say that it works best for dogs over 30 lbs, but I'd increase that to probably 50 lbs.

Very disappointing. The elastic is not tight enough to even feel it on my foot, and the pad is thin and weak. I liked the old Strutz "As Seen on TV" pads as they were VERY thick and really hugged my arches, but they're getting hard to find. This FootMatters cushion is NOT a good alternative. If you need very light support for inside a shoe, it might be somewhat useful, but if you have painful plantar fasciitis, this won't do anything. I have sport-fit athletic socks that offer more support than this product.I don't know if this was a fluke, but they came packaged in a thin plastic bag (like a sandwich bag) with no labeling. Was it a return? Or do they all come this way? It looked a little sketchy, but I wouldn't have minded if they worked. The fact that they have no support and were packaged so strangely makes me wonder if this was some kind of switcheroo. Skip it.

I have toy dogs (a Pekingese, Pomeranian, and a Tibetan Spaniel), and these kibbles are just a tad too big for them on some days. I try to mix it with some wet food with lots of gravy to soften them up a bit. I don't know if it's the size or the flavor, but two of them (the Peke & the Tibbie) can really take it or leave it - some days they will cheerfully eat their dinner, other days they sniff at it and then look at me like "Can I have something else?" Ironically, the Pomeranian is the only one who truly loves it, and she only has 5 teeth so I didn't think she'd be able to chew the large kibbles at all!It does seem to be very healthy for them, though they don't have any particular allergies or conditions so they don't really NEED a specialty food. I haven't noticed any adverse effects; their digestion works great on this food (when they decide to eat it, of course). I probably won't buy again because they just don't seem to like it very much so I'm always scraping sticky old kibble out of their bowls the next morning. They all LOVE AvoDerm (toy dog formula, chicken flavor) so I'll switch back when this bag is gone. They like this CORE food well enough so I don't have to donate it to charity, but not enough to buy again.Doesn't mean that it's not a good quality food, just a matter of taste. Though if you have tiny dogs, you may want to consider the kibble size.

The Command Decor Damage-Free Wall Tiles are a great way to display art on walls without causing damage. If you are familiar with command strips, then you already have an idea of how they get attached to walls with the ability to remove without causing damage. With this product, they've gone the extra step to provide a mountable base onto which you can attach artwork, chalkboard, or dry-erase board.The art itself sits about 1" from the wall, which gives it some depth. Additionally, there is an optional riser to allow you to position art even further from the wall, which allows for the possibility to overlap and create some unique setups.It is super easy to install - especially with the integrated level within the base! You don't have to worry about putting any level lines on your wall. The instructions are clear, with words and pictures. There are also examples of other artwork you can choose to easily slap on the base. I would expect you can just buy different artwork (and not pay for the base again), but I'm not seeing where that is a product alone. It would be great to be able to switch out the artwork based on your mood or the season, especially since they make it so easy. This will be 5 stars once I see the ability to buy other art tiles w/o the base.

For making free-standing lace embroidery, this is The Stuff. It feels like a thick sheet of plastic when you hoop it, and holds even heavy lace designs very well. It takes a fair amount of rinsing to remove it all (you can tell when it's completely gone because the lace will not be sticky anymore) and the soaking bowl gets kind of slimy afterward! But all worth it because the final designs are beautiful and never fall apart. I never have gaps where the embroidery has pulled apart when I use this. That's not to say that thread never gets snagged and messes up, but you'll find that happens occasionally on pretty much any project if you sew/embroider a lot.Previously, I had been using a fabric-style stabilizer for making lace, which tended to have some problem areas after soaking to remove the stabilizer. The fabric style is easier to wash away & the final product feels softer against sensitive skin, but so many of my designs had parts that became disconnected or didn't catch, that I had to spend hours repairing them and it wasn't worth it.

These are awesome. They look nice - fancy enough to be part of a design, not just a hidden attachment. And the magnets are pretty powerful. DO use some interfacing inside your fabric when attaching these, or the magnet may pull your project apart too much. Actually you should use some interfacing anyway, but you may want to step up to a medium or heavy interfacing instead of lightweight, just in case.GREAT deal, much cheaper than I've found in craft supply stores for closures that didn't even look as nice as this.

The links are smaller than the chain necklaces I've bought in the jewelry-craft aisle of various large retailers, thus harder to work with for attaching pendants & such using the needle-nose pliers. Better for the type of pendants that slide on using a jump ring, I suspect. Otherwise, pretty sturdy and good colors.

I have been a FitFlop devotee since they first came out with the thick-soled flip-flops so many years ago; they hug my problem feet so nicely and are the only shoes that don't leave me limping in pain the next day. I've since purchased the house slippers (pink & fuzzy!) and winter ankle boots (people say I look like an elf in them), along with several more pairs of flip-flops! I have plantar fasciitis, arthritis, and some other painful undiagnosed issues, so most shoes hurt. Not these!All my previous pairs of FitFlops have been pretty wide and not super feminine, so I was VERY surprised at how dainty and light these shoes are. Absolutely delighted, to tell the truth! I had ordered as kind of a compromise-shoe for summer, something that wouldn't look too terrible with a pretty summer dress but wouldn't hurt my aching feet even if I took some long walks. But these are seriously CUTE!!! I actually WANT to wear them with everything because they look great, it's not a compromise at all!!The fit is fantastic. The soles are light as a feather, but still hug my foot to keep me well supported. This helps with my foot pain as well as a tired back after spending 8 hours on my feet in a marble-floored retail store. Shockingly, they are actually super comfortable right out of the box, with no breaking-in period! After about 10 hours of continuous wear without socks (all standing or walking, very little sitting), I did notice a little rubbing on my right heel, but that's a lot less than I expected after spending the last 6 months in thick socks. No rubbing on the sides of my feet, near my toes, around the strap, nowhere. Oddly, my feet weren't very sweaty either - I don't know if they have wicking material in there or what, because my feet usually get pretty gross without socks. They feel WONDERFUL! I could not be happier with these shoes. If they made them in fashion colors, I would buy 65 pairs of them. Even though they are pretty spendy, I admit. I'd sell a kidney. Worth it.They are quite a bit more narrow than the traditional FitFlops, but my feet are *average* (not narrow or wide) and they fit perfectly. If you have an extra wide foot, they may not fit you quite as well as some of the traditional FitFlop designs. But for average & narrow feet, I think this is a perfect, perfect, perfect shoe. And so much cuter than orthopedic sneakers!!

My dogs love Greenies! They don't have grain allergies, but I think they love these even more than regular Greenies. They go bonkers whenever I open the bag and stop whatever they are doing to chew and enjoy this healthy treat. And I love them because they're very easy to break in half - one of my dogs is very small and only wants very small treats.Greenies are expensive, but they are the best!!! One treat that my dogs ALWAYS love and is actually pretty good for them! (well, their teeth anyway)!

The AeroGarden 3SL has one major thing going for it, compared to all the other "self-contained" growing apparatuses: SIZE. I believe the SL in the model number refers to slim. It is just that and fits pretty easily on a kitchen countertop and underneath upper cabinets. The upper arm extends, so it could start off fitting under our taller upper cabinets. As the plants grow, you easily raise the arm up and it still fits under our shorter upper cabinets.Another critical review of the product cites the proprietary bulb as a drawback and that you can easily make this product DIY for cheaper. That reviewer is correct. However, the proprietary bulb is what allows the top section to be so slim. And not everyone wants to make their own. If you just don't feel like making it yourself, then this may be for you. The device has a handy fertilizer reminder light that goes on every two weeks to remind you to add fertilizer. Instructions for setup were clear. The main disappointment with this herb garden is the flimsiness of the constructions. The extendable arm feels very weak. The housing for the bulb is also not very solid. Be careful around this if you are dealing with big heavy pots and pans. I could see  someone accidentally taking the top off.This herb garden may be good for the apartment dweller or someone with limited counter space. However, just know you are paying for a kind of cheap bunch of plastic pieces.

After using this product for about a week, my asthma got a whole lot worse. At first I thought I had caught a respiratory virus, but in general I felt fine - other than having trouble breathing. It continued to get worse & worse, so that even the lightest amount of exercise (a 10-min walk with my dogs, going up a staircase) would leave me gasping for breath. It felt like trying to breathe through a very clogged filter, or at times felt like I was trying to just sip air through a thin straw. I nearly called my doctor to get checked for pneumonia, even though I had no fever - I just couldn't breathe!There are no warnings on the product literature that I could find, but a couple of internet searches revealed that Garcinia can interfere with the effectiveness of asthma medication. I take an inhaler twice daily to keep my asthma under control, and occasionally use an albuterol inhaler for acute breathing trouble, or before exercise to ward off a possible attack. I've had it all my life, and it doesn't usually keep me from exercising even if I forget a dose or two of my daily medication, but while taking HCActive I was having terrible trouble breathing all the time. I even had to sleep sitting up, or else be awakened in the middle of the night by an asthma attack.So, I didn't get to give this a very lengthy trial, I had to quit in order to get my asthma back under control. In the short time I did take it, I didn't notice any drop in appetite or change in metabolism, and I obviously could not exercise because I could barely breathe - just changing into my workout clothes made me winded. I definitely didn't lose any weight; I think I actually gained a pound or two. After discontinuing use, it took about 4 days for my breathing to get back to almost normal. Maybe I would have seen more effectiveness if I'd been able to take it longer, but not being able to exercise makes me doubt it. Honestly, I never gave "appetite suppressant" much respect because I eat more out of habit or boredom than hunger, but a few months ago I tried a different product that actually worked - I sincerely WANTED to snack but was just too darn full! So, now I know that my appetite is capable of being suppressed, but while on HCActive, my appetite returned with full force. I don't think anything about HCActive worked for me. I have read it can be very effective at increasing your fat burn during exercise, but if you can't exercise because you can't breathe, that becomes a moot point.If you don't have asthma, you may have good luck with this, I really don't know. But if you do have asthma and take daily medication to control it, please be warned that this could potentially be very dangerous.

I'll probably only get this brand of tape in the future. It works so well. It can probably be accused of being too sticky - which is good. This is the tape to use when you need a real, strong duct tape. The two pack comes individually wrapped, so you can be sure it won't be dried out when you need it. I didn't have any issues with tearing it with just my hands. I would suggest also storing it with some sort of plastic wrapping it. Depending on where you set it, the side adhesive will stick to whatever it touches.

My little dogs (a Pekingese & a Tibetan Spaniel) absolutely LOVE this food. I mix their dry food with a little canned at dinner time, and they usually try to eat around the kibble as much as possible - not with this food! They both station themselves at their bowls and barely take a breath until it's gone! This bag of lamb-formula also included a sample of turkey-formula which they loved even MORE!I will say...it seems to create a very, um, robust digestive situation. They've gone from making 1-2 healthy poops per day on Pedigree right up to 3 very LARGE poops per dog, per day. It all seems quite healthy, it's just - surprising! I don't know if it has a lot of fiber, or is just easy to digest, or what. More to pick up, but I'm glad they're healthy!My dogs don't really have any food sensitivities that I'm aware of, but I'm always keen to try something good for them. I don't know if we'll be following this company's recommendations for the "rotating diet" but I would like to buy it again because they really love it!

Bottle Battle!!!!Bottle Battle by Zune is a new, fun game you can play outside (or even inside, if you have a large enough space and aren't worried about a stray flying disc breaking something). Please watch the manufacturers video on this product page for a quick and simple explanation of how it's played. I like that all the components come in their own carrying case, with straps to hold each one in its place. Set up was very easy - it only took about 5 minutes in total. The components are a decent quality build, too. The metal poles have numbers and a small plastic slider, to act as a scorekeeping mechanism. This was a smart design choice.If you like these types of games, but are getting tired of tossing bean bags, big washers, or two golf balls connected with a string, then give Bottle Battle a try for a new challenge.

This is our latest in a series of many countertop grills, and so far one of the best we've ever had! Our most recent (and previous favorite) was the Cuisinart version, which we used for years with no problems (& will probably keep for our camper). This new Foreman has a slightly larger grill area than the Cuisinart, which is nice for toasting sandwiches on extra-wide bread or grilling more/larger pieces of meat, fish, poultry, etc. The floating hinge is VERY large, and accommodates the way the ceramic plate edges seem to "surround" whatever you're cooking, but feels very loose at times, like it is about to slide right off the food! Of course, it doesn't (or hasn't yet), but can be a bit startling!The best feature is the ceramic - it heats up super fast and cooks the food much faster too! It doesn't stick to food at all, even fish, which tends to stick to everything. This also means cleanup is a breeze! The clip mechanism that attaches the plate to the grill takes some getting used to, but otherwise I love these ceramic plates a LOT. I could feel the fast-heating appeal when I washed a fully-cooled plate under hot water and it got as hot as the water almost immediately! No wonder they cook the food so fast! Grilled cheese sandwiches used to take almost 10 minutes on the Cuisinart, on this Foreman they take 3-4 minutes tops (and the bread is perfect crispy with nice grill marks).Also love the fact that you can set the specific temp and set a timer right on the grill, plus it has general temp/time guidelines printed directly on the grill itself. This is GREAT because if they were on a separate piece of paper I would lose it instantly and never remember what settings are correct! So far I've used their advice for temps & times and everything has cooked just perfectly.The waffle plates are not ceramic, so they're a little tougher to clean (also because of all the little waffle holes, haha), but it's really not too bad. Also they cook a little slower than ceramic, but that's okay. Unless you're making two huge waffles for one person, they're kind of hard to separate once they're cooked! But, we haven't had a waffle iron in years so this is a really fun little feature. However, there is one problem with making waffles on this, and that's the "lie flat" feature.The "adjustable height" feature has two settings: up or down (incline or flat). Maybe it's just our particular grill, but the "flat" position actually puts it at a slight decline angle. This is a huge problem for waffles, which have to be cooked flat, because the liquid waffle mix oozes down the back of the grill and makes a huge mess. The back of the grill is NOT non-stick, doesn't come apart, and involves a lot of nooks & crannies that are nearly impossible to clean thoroughly. This could have been solved if the adjuster-knob had a couple of intermediary settings instead of just two, so instead we're experimenting with propping the back of it up on some magazines to make it level. So far we have not succeeded in finding the best angle, because waffle mix drips out the back every time. I'm not using the flat setting for anything else, even though you're supposed to use it for sandwiches, because I can only imagine trying to clean butter out of there! Yes, my grilled cheese slides off when the grill is inclined, but I'm always there to catch it.This is really the only problem with the grill, otherwise I love it! And seeing all the other 5-star reviews, I'm wondering if I just got a bad one and all the others actually lie flat. Don't let it hold you back if you're thinking of getting this grill, the ceramic plates & other features make it worth it.

Setup: Very simple. It walks you through the process using a quick start menu. Of course, there are lots of other options to set up the router and the zones exactly how you want. I also really like how on the admin screens, it shows a split screen with the settings on the left and a sort of help screen on the right - for people like me who know a bit about networks, but is not a professional IT person, and still want to tweak the settings.App: I've just started playing around with the TP-Link Tether app. I like how it displays all devices connected and gives the option of renaming them right within the app. However, there are limits on what sorts of settings on the router itself you can control. You can turn on/off parental controls, turn on/off and rename each wireless channel and guest networks. Those guest networks on/off toggles are handy to have on a phone app, in case you have guests and don't want to share your password.Range: If you are going from a wireless a/b/g/n to an AC router, you will probably notice an expansion in range. Prior to this one, I had a D-Link AC750 router. I think that one actually gave me a slightly wider range, though I plan to experiment more with placement to see if it improves. So far, I've had some spotty connection stability at corners of my house where I didn't used to have a problem with the D-Link router.Speed: No issues here. I seem to be able to maximize all my up/down speeds from my ISP. I have over a dozen different devices connected at once and can easily wirelessly stream HD video to multiple devices. The quality of stream from my Slingbox seemed slightly poor, though I can't confirm it is a result of this router. More testing is needed.Other features: 2 USB ports should allow for file/media sharing from an external hard drive to the devices on your network. Also, it should allow for connecting a printer for print sharing on your network. My D-Link router does not have these features and I wish it did.Overall, you can probably upgrade to a cheaper AC router and get the benefits of dual channel support and wider range. However, if you are looking for the USB ports, this may be a good option for you. Also, the app capabilities are limited, but what it does do, it does well and makes it easy. I really like this TP-Link router and if I can improve its placement to help with its range, I will probably bump the review up to 5 stars.

This doesn't seem to position right into the palm of my hand the way it seems like it should, but the low height overall really lets you get excellent leverage when scrubbing. Some of the dishes that have not cleaned well with my regular dish brush (notably our favorite pizza pan, which always gets cheese baked onto it) work really great with this scrubber! It definitely is not abrasive on non-stick surfaces, but removes the gunk pretty easily nonetheless. The drip tray keeps each scrubbing pad fresher longer, and keeps the sink cleaner too.As a few other reviewers have mentioned, the shape doesn't allow for effective corner-scrubbing in square or rectangular pans. Also, if you have something filled pretty deeply with soapy water, prepare to get your arm wet because this guy is short! Those are relatively small complaints, though. For the price this is a really nice little scrubber. And I love that you can buy replacement heads instead of just replacing the whole thing - that saves money and waste.

I don't have kids, so I haven't quite understood why Legos are so hot right now. But this resembles our beloved Class C RV and was under $20 so I had to have it.WOW SO MUCH FUN!!!!! Why is this one so cheap while other Lego vehicles are like $50-150? It's small, but not tiny. It's super cute, with all the fun little details inside. I had a total blast putting this together!I imagine if you are familiar with Legos, the instruction books are all fairly similar. There are two books for this one, with the Legos separated into two groups, to match each instruction book. There are not many words, lots of pictures, but everything is clear. Reminded me a lot of Ikea, but with smaller pieces and no allen wrench!Well I'm addicted to Legos now. If only I could find more really cute kits that were just as appealing as this little camper!

I go through black embroidery machine thread like crazy, so I'm always looking for a bargain - unfortunately, some of the bargains I've found online did not result in great quality in person. This thread is so nice!!! Really nice thickness, softness, stitches out evenly, feels good on the final design, I absolutely love it!!!The white is nice quality too, of course - pretty much the same as the black. I don't go through that quite as quickly, but this was a great deal and I'll definitely use it. I don't want to forget this brand! I love itFor reference, I use a Brother Quattro 3 for embroidery. It's a GREAT machine but still occasionally gets tangled on the cheap thread. This thread glides through like a dream!

I like to have a large water vessel nearby throughout the day, and on my nightstand while I sleep, because I like to drink water all the time. After I dropped my last cup and broke it, I thought this sounded like a fun option for adding a bit of flavor to my water. I don't really like the sports-bottle style, and I need a cover & straw because otherwise my cat will stick her head in there!The strainer/divider doesn't seem to sit firmly in the container, and the holes are pretty big, so you kind of have to just keep large chunks or sections of fruit on one side because any pulp will just float through. That being the case, your fruit will have to sit in there for quite a while before it actually flavors the water at all. To get any real flavor, you'll have to squeeze your fruit a bit which means you'll have pulp floating around. That's not a big problem for me, but then - what's the point of the divider?The bigger problem is that the cap is not a screw-on, instead it smushed on with a thin rubbery seal around the top. I never felt it was sealed especially well as it seemed to drift up a millimeter or two every time I closed it. After only about 3 weeks of use (refilling about 3-6 times per day), the rubber seal fell right off into the glass! I tried to put it back on, but it never sealed tightly again. The lid just sat loosely in the container with no tightness at all. I tried using it that way for a few days, until it tipped over and fell off the treadmill, spilling 24 oz of water all over the floor.This is not well made. Save your money.

Though apparently my dogs are giving this treat 0 stars, I'll give it 3 because they are pretty finicky. I'm not willing to taste them myself in order to give a really well-rounded review; I love you Amazon, but even I have limits.These seem nice and healthy, they're soft, they're a good size for breaking up if you have one small dog and one smaller dog (such as a Pekingese & a Tibetan Spaniel) - it seems to have all the bases covered. I thought they would love it! But they won't touch it. All the Pekes I've ever known have been picky about their treats, and my current little girl is no different...however my Tibetan will usually eat anything (including fuzz, plastic, and small pieces of yarn). When I passed these out, the Tibetan happily took one, chewed for a moment, then spit it out in her dog bed. The Peke wouldn't even take it, not even the small bite I broke off for her. Sniffed it four or five times, then walked away. If she'd had a "REJECT" stamp, the scene would have been complete.I really don't think there's anything wrong with these treats, in fact they seem quite healthy and well-made. Maybe my dogs just don't like lamb? They are more into chicken, as a rule, but I haven't seen them reject anything so firmly in a long time. If your dog likes lamb, maybe this could be a big hit in your house. Or not. Maybe they're more like health food for people; good for you, smells bad, tastes terrible. Pass the bacon.

The one thing that would make this set perfect would be to include a small plastic tub to be used as a liner for the smallest basket. It is very small, as you can see from the stated dimensions and there are very few things you can fit in there that won't fall out. Any handy person should be able to improvise and find something that would fit. These fit very tightly into my pegboard and don't move around when grabbing things out of the baskets. They are good quality, sturdy, and vinyl coated for protection and durability long term.Pro tip: Put them at the bottom of your pegboard, so the baskets fall under the base of the board. They take up less pegboard space that way.(One weird thing about the shipping from Amazon - they used a slightly smaller box than needed so parts of the largest wire basket had broken the box and were poking out when it arrived. This has nothing to do with the product itself and does not impact my star rating, just something to be aware of).

The iDevices Kitchen Thermometer does exactly what it says, with the only drawback being the limited connectivity range between the base and your device. I tested it with the probe that plugs into my convection oven and the iDevices thermometer was consistently only about 5-10 degrees higher, which was probably due to the probe not being in exactly the same location. The base is magnetic, and there is a provided metal plate with an adhesive backing. This would allow you to have it be magnetized anywhere. However, I just keep the base stuck to the fridge when not in use. I also like the probe wire wraps and the fact that the two snap together, which makes it easy to store when not in use. The description on amazon indicates it is compatible with Android. However, the box does not specifically indicate Android compatibility and only includes the icon for the Apple App Store and not Google Play Store. I can confirm, there is a compatible app for Android devices. As said before, it would be nicer if the range were a little larger, but I can still comfortably sit in the adjoining living room and monitor the temps from the couch instead of getting up, which is nice for low/slow roasts. Also, if it does disconnect, it quickly reconnected once in range.PROs:-Accurate Dual Probes-Magnetic Base - can stick to fridge when not in use-Probe wire wraps keeps them tidy when not in use - They two wraps click together for easy storage-App available for Apple and Android-Large, bright temp display at the baseCON:-Limited bluetooth range (but quick to reconnect once in range)-App could stand a UI redesign. Text is unnecessarily small

I think my hair might be too short (approx chin-length) to work properly with this gadget, although after reading the other reviews I suspect that might be why I didn't get tangled or stuck in it!  It was a real challenge to get it into the right position to actually pull any of my hair into it, and once it did, it kind of sat around the barrel very loosely. The instructions say that it will beep 3 times when your curl is ready to release, and I never did get it to beep after spending a good 20 minutes curling my whole head - even having timed it for more than 30 seconds on some sections of hair.That said, the curls I was able to get were loose, smooth, and quite pretty. I think it might look nicer (and be a little more user-friendly) if my hair were just a few inches longer, so I'll try it again when I grow it out and update my review if necessary. Based on the other reviews, it doesn't sound like you'd want to use it on super-long hair either because it seems to get stuck inside the barrel mechanism. Maybe medium-length hair is the best for this type of curler.It's very bulky and heavy, and takes up a ton of space in the hair-gadget shelf of the closet. It's also hard to align your hair sections correctly into the small hole where it needs to be for proper winding, especially toward the back of your head, using the mirror image. It doesn't work unless you use fairly small sections of hair, even for wide/loose curls, so it takes quite a lot longer than a regular curling iron. I do like the general look of the curls, but it's such a hassle that this would only be a "special occasion" hairstyle for me.

I have two small 3-yr-old dogs, one Pekingese and one Tibetan Spaniel, and they both LOVE THIS!!! Usually I feed them a bit of Mighty Dog mixed with Pedigree "Small Dog" kibble, and they either finish it or not, depending on how hungry they are. After their first meal of Cesar (still mixed with the Pedigree) they now go NUTS at dinnertime every night! They squeal and dance while I'm preparing their bowls, and they finish every last bite. I don't know if we'll ever be able to go back to Mighty Dog now, they love this too much!I think we got the Chicken Stew flavor, rather than the Beef Stew in the photo. My dogs are around 15 lbs each, and they each get approximately half a container of Cesar per day mixed with about 1/2 cup of dry kibble. It looks almost like people food and is very easy to mix with kibble. They particularly like it if every last kibble has a bit of Cesar flavoring on it! I suppose one drawback might be that the containers don't fit with the standard can covers, but the containers are small so it's really not necessary (there aren't many leftovers). The lightweight containers will be easy to transport when we take the dogs camping with us, or when we have to leave them at a kennel. I think we may be long-term converts to this dog food!

This magnetic world map puzzle is a great tool to get your kids interested in geography in a fun way. In a globalized society, having knowledge of world geography is essential. The level of detail to this map is appropriate for the targeted age level. The pieces do not neatly align with borders and multiple small countries may be grouped together. This is understandable based on the target age (what 5 year old would not lose Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Vatican City, etc). What is also great about this map is the artwork. There are graphics to show certain points of interest, which can start other conversations with your kids. For instance, Russia shows a train across the country to represent the Trans-Siberian Railway. You also see the Pyramids of Egypt, the Taj Mahal, the Eiffel Tower, among other landmarks.I would have preferred slightly stronger magnets to hold the pieces in place better, but the overall weight is relatively light, considering the material. (Stronger magnets = more weight/price) I would have also preferred some more accurate borders. However, that would have prevented some of the nice artwork from being as visible as possible. This is priced correctly considering the size and scope. I have seen handmade wooden map puzzles go for over $100, just for a single continent (with country specific pieces - designed for older kids/adults). You might think the price is kind of high for a simple puzzle. However, if you think of it as a tool to start a lifelong interest in geography and consider its material, it is really right in line.

There sure are a mixture of reviews on this product. I have been using it for over two weeks now with absolutely zero problems. There definitely seems to be something going on with customers receiving knock off versions instead of the actual Belkin Mixit. The cable is slightly longer than the stock Lightning to USB cable that comes with your iProduct. It seems to charge at the exact same rate as stock.As far as the negative reviews go, I think the review from Mr Birge is probably accurate. Be sure you order this from a reputable seller and you will likely get the non-knockoff version and it will probably work without issue.

The two best things about this soap dispenser: (1) solid, metal, sturdy construction; (2) the whole thing pops off at the top of the sink so it can be easily refilled. It was such a pain to have to unscrew the reservoir under the sink every time to refill the old one. It is slightly pricier than my last soap dispenser, but has a feel like it will last forever. There are plastic pieces in the mechanism and the threads/nut are plastic, designed to be hand-tightened. However, that should require little manipulation and therefore, should leave little to wear and tear.Installation was very simple (once I got my old one out of there, which was a pain). Basically, you just put the top part through the hole, screw in the mounting nut under the sink, then screw in the reservoir. Instructions were very clear, though so simple they were unnecessary.

The Stiga Evolution Table Tennis Racket is a great step up from more basic rackets with noticeable improvements over basic models in the $20-$40 range. Since this is your primary piece of equipment in the game, I think it is totally worth it to spend a bit more money for an upgraded racket. However, if you are just looking to outfit your rec room with some basic equipment, this is probably overkill.The first thing I noticed about this racket was its balanced heft. It was a bit heavier than my former paddle, but still easily controllable - not too heavy, but not too light. Ball strikes were also much more consistent and controllable. I had much more reliable returns, regardless of where on the bat face the ball hit. Be prepared for a bit of a learning curve if you are going from a basic racket to this one. It is taking some time to get used to the speed and spin, but that will come in time. I am getting a bit more speed than my 5-ply comparison racket (this one is 6-ply) and spin seems a big step up.The only flaw I noticed was the tape covering the plys seemed very loosely adhered out of the box. I pressed it down harder and it seems to be staying.Who this is for: the amateur player who plays regularly and looking to upgrade your racket without completely breaking the bank.

I've been a longtime fan of Rosetta Stone's language-learning programs; these people clearly understand how the human mind learns new skills. They put a lot of work into producing high-quality products.This set comes in a very colorful package that will be a delight for kids to open. It includes a hardcover book for them to play with while parents install the software and set up the online subscription, and works on desktop, laptop, or tablets.My nephew has been decidedly unexcited about learning to read in his school programs, but this is going to be lots of fun and very helpful for him. Kids need a reason to learn, they need to see why it will be fun for them and not just another thing that adults are telling them to do. I hope his younger brother will be interested in checking this out too!If you're looking for a holiday gift for children in your life that will be more than just a toy, this is an excellent option. It will enrich their lives in the long-term, but on Christmas morning still looks like a fun and colorful book set (cuz nobody wants to be the one who gave that "educational" gift that gets tossed aside immediately).

This is a very decent set of wired headphones and a good value if you are paying around $30 or less for them. The sound quality is above average with quality bass levels. The box boasts a 40mm driver unit. I did not notice the mid-ranges as very muddy as another reviewer noted, but I did feel the higher ranges tended to be a bit washed out at times. Though these are advertised as "fully enclosed," it does not mean the foam pads go fully around the ear. They are designed to sit on-ear. However, I was able to wear them for over an hour with little to no discomfort. The foam pads are comfortable and the wide headband made it so they didn't add excessive pressure. I appreciate the compactness of the foldable design, which allows for more easier travel. Also, I like the aesthetics of them, with the raised Pioneer logo over circular grooves, with a chrome circular bezel around the outside.Specs:Impedance: 32 OhmsSesitivity: 105dBFrequency response: 10Hz to 30,000HzMax input power: 1,000mW

My dogs don't have any allergies that I'm aware of, but thought I'd try this high-end food because I love them and want them to be healthy! At first, my Tibetan Spaniel was very enthused, taking each kibble away to her secret lair to savor like a special treat - the Pekingese was unimpressed with it as a treat, but that is her way. Still, I thought we were onto something. I mixed it for dinner with a bit of their old kibble (Pedigree) and some canned food, which is their usual dinner.After a few days, the Tibetan seems much less impressed. She often leaves some kibble in her bowl after dinner, and it seems to be a higher percentage of this expensive food while more of the Pedigree has been eaten. If anything, she feels pretty neutral about both and neither one tastes better. The Peke enthusiastically finishes anything that is mixed with canned food, so she's no help at all! She is finicky about treats, but always finishes her dinner.If your dog has grain issues or other allergies, they will probably do quite well with this. The flavor seems to be good (I haven't tasted it, just going by my dogs here) and there is no trouble with digestion. If your dogs have no issues and you're okay with commercial food, you can probably save money and just get a "healthy-ish" food at the grocery store. If mine were over the moon for how great this tasted, I'd continue to get it for them despite the higher price, but the fact that they don't seem to care and have no health problems - I'll probably go back to Pedigree. Good quality stuff if your dog needs it though!One issue that is a sure star deduction however, is the non-resealable bag. It's a HUGE bag, and stuffed quite full, which seems a good value at first but it's nearly impossible to recluse even with multiple sturdy chip clips. It has to start tasting stale pretty fast, I would think? Especially for small dogs like mine that only eat about a half-cup each day. Even at the current high-end price, I'd still pay a dollar or two more for a zip-closure bag that keeps it from getting stale.

These are very cool! The stickers are thicker and more substantial than regular labels, and really do work just like a chalkboard. I don't have a real chalkboard eraser handy (though I did use regular classroom chalk) but they wiped off just fine with a scrap of cloth. The stickers are large and easy to see, easy to use, easy to write on, easy to erase. I suppose the erasability might be a drawback if you rub up against them by accident, but this is far outweighed by the benefits of being able to change the label without actually changing the label. I love it!

It seems everyone is looking for a way to get their whiskey and bourbon cold without diluting it with regular ice. This freezable whiskey glass has a partially liquid-filled pocket. You place the glass in the freezer upside-down until the liquid freezes. Pour your whiskey into the glass and the frozen glass cools it without diluting it. There is also a rubberized base for gripping and to prevent excessive sweating. I would probably pass on this method of cooling your favorite rye or even getting it as a gift for someone.Problem 1 - the method of packaging the set of two glasses led to one of them being cracked upon delivery. Because the glass was cracked, the liquid inside leaked out of the glass. I think there is a weak point near the top of the glass. Also, the method of packaging seemed pretty flimsy. For this reason, I would avoid buying this as a gift for someone. Still, one glass was intact, so I was able to try it out.Problem 2 - it really didn't cool the whiskey all that much very quickly. It did cool my lips rather well, and room temperature whiskey passing over cooled lips does sort of give it a cooler sensation. I just didn't think it chilled it enough. I probably didn't leave it in the glass long enough. However, when you do, that leads to problem 3.Problem 3 - After a while, the "ice" embedded in the glass starts to melt partially and you see the ice/liquid mix move around within the glass. You also see the "frost" on the outside melt in weird patterns. It is not a very "pretty" sight. It is just ugly, especially with the black silicone base. One potential solution of this is to use the glass simply to chill the drink, then pour it into another glass. For that reason I gave this two stars, instead of one.If you don't like the whiskey stones or the huge ice cube, this might be a way to cool your drink, as long as you don't care about looks. And hopefully, you'll get a package with both glasses intact.

The description is accurate - feels like a solid, soft fabric out of the package, yet dissolves completely in water! You *could* use an additional thin layer of the clear, lightweight water-soluble stabilizer on top, but I haven't encountered a need for it yet. This was my first time making free-standing lace on the embroidery machine, and it came out absolutely perfect! It's AMAZING to watch it dissolve in water, crafts meet science in the coolest way!! I used a small bowl of warm water, but temperature didn't seem to matter. It feels a bit sticky if you reach in and mess with the project while the stabilizer is melting; make sure it dissolves completely before drying it out. I let my lace lay flat on a paper towel overnight, and it became stiff-but-flexible, perfect for sewing on embellishments!This package is quite small, I got it just because I wanted to make sure it worked before committing to a huge roll. I liked it so much that I ordered a big roll immediately after trying it out, but found I was also able to use some of the decent-sized scraps. If you don't have a piece big enough to hoop, you can overlap them to make them hoop-able for stitching out a project. I tried this and it stitched just perfectly; the stabilizer melted away just like it did in a single layer and the final product looked exactly the same as the single-layer projects. Don't throw away those scraps!

I don't know why this is so good on eggs, but I don't want to eat my eggs without it! Sure, you could sprinkle salt & pepper separately, but this is just magical. I love it! I've sprinkled a little on english muffins too. It's like, breakfast salt, haha!This bottle is HUGE - I could not find it in stores, so I was willing to pay extra for what I thought was a small, normal shaker. But this is a pretty good deal for a really giant container of Mixed Up Salt. I may never run out again!

Wish these came with instructions, but they're very easy to figure out. Just poke some tiny holes in your fabric, attach the backing, and you have a beautiful professional looking snap closure! SO much easier than traditional sew-on snaps, and gives a polished look to your final project. I use them on handbags and they're awesome! Adding some interfacing (even just a small square of it) between the prongs and the washer really helps to protect your fabric upon repeated use of the snaps, opening & closing your handbag (or whatever you've made) over and over. The magnets are good quality too - stick to each other but not TOO tight, just the right amount.This seems like a very good price to me, considering how many you get. I haven't really shopped around though, it just seems very reasonable for what I wanted. Honestly, any time I go into a fabric store I buy WAY more than I came in for, so ordering online saves me a lot of money even if it would have been a little cheaper for the same product in a brick-and-mortar!

I've been doing basic sewing for probably 30 years, but have never tried a serger before. I always wanted one, but when it arrived...it was VERY intimidating! All those threads, those dials, the extra needles, how do you even do this?? The videos that came with it made me even more afraid of the thing - they're very poorly produced, blurry, and go way too fast over the more complicated parts, such as threading the loopers. Thusly, after excitedly unwrapping my new serger, I let it gather dust in my sewing room for nearly a year before even turning it on!Finally I took an all-day serger class at the American Sewing Expo, which finally made me less afraid of the thing, so I finally gave it a shot. It came pre-loaded with some white thread and pre-set to a basic 4-thread overlock, so really all I had to do all along was step on the pedal and go! Unfortunately, the machine I used in class was an incredibly expensive, self-threading BabyLock, so I'm still struggling with looper threading and some of the other settings for decorative edges. This machine CAN do lots of interesting edges, don't get me wrong - it just takes some dedication to learning how. It's a powerful little machine, but it doesn't hold your hand. You have to practice; serging is not the same as sewing!The books that come with it are much more helpful than the videos. The booklet that outlines the settings required to do various decorative stitches is extremely useful, but it's not a bible - be prepared to tweak and experiment with different kinds of fabrics before tackling your real project. Having taken a class beforehand was very helpful too; if you have access to a class and have never used a serger before, I highly recommend signing up, if only to get accustomed to the terminology and have some tips from serger veterans. The main operation book does tell you how to thread the loopers, but this takes practice! Also, after I spent an entire day struggling with a lower looper that looked right but didn't serge correctly, a friend tipped me off that you often have to re-thread the entire machine, left to right, even if you're only trying to change just one of the threads. I don't know why this worked, but it did!This is a GREAT price for a powerful little serger, and is a good starter model for newbies, but be prepared to do some research on the side & plan on practicing a LOT before it will give you the professional results you want. Don't be like me, don't be afraid to touch it for nearly a year! It's not scary at all, and it can do a ton of cool things. You can figure it out if you put a little time into it, and for very little money you will add a whole new dimension to your sewing!

I had started playing the first couple Assassin's Creed titles and was seeing improvement in each one up through Brotherhood. I really got bogged down in Revelations and sort of got bored with the series. So, unfortunately, it took me a long time to get back into it and play AC IV: Black Flag. I was missing out. This game is a marked improvement over AC III in the controls and the environment. A huge open world environment gives you lots of things to do. Adding the seafaring component of gameplay really freshened up the type of gameplay I was getting bored with (climb up big buildings, accidentally trigger a chase scene with guard, kill said guards, walk away). Don't get me wrong. There is still an element of repetition in the missions, which AC games really have a hard time shaking since the original. However, for the most part, the fresh perspective and setting made it much more bearable. I really wish I had started playing this one earlier.If you were like me and got bored with some of the earlier iterations of Assassin's Creed, just watch some videos to get caught up with the story and jump into Black Flag.

This is NOT my first pair of FitFlops; a few months ago my basic black ones just looked too beat-up to wear outside the house & my sequined black ones broke a strap. Clearly I love the FitFlops and can't go without a black pair! They're all quite comfortable & hug my high arches, helping tremendously with plantar fasciitis pain, but this pair is even BETTER! Not only is the flower pretty (but subtle), there is a bit of padding beneath the T-straps now, so the top of my foot feels just as comfy as the bottom! Also the padding decreases any slight looseness, so my toes don't try to grip the shoe at all, which caused a few foot cramps in the sequined pair.I also have FitFlop slippers and ankle boots - they really work for my ouchy feet!

We loved every minute of ten seasons of this goofy, over-the-top, sugary-sweet show, and the finale of Season 10 was clearly meant to be the series finale. Most of the series regulars had departed, and a group of new "orphans" were tacked on in S11 just because otherwise there would be no plot whatsoever. Notably, all the early characters (Jessica Biel, Barry Watson, etc) who had moved on at various times throughout the series all returned for a heartwarming cameo in the Season 10 finale, yet were barely mentioned in S11.Granted, one of the reasons we loved the show was that so many of the plot lines were pretty ridiculous, but S11 went so far past the mark that it barely even made sense. We pushed through and watched the whole thing (because hey, you don't slog through an entire series just to give up halfway through the last season) but if we ever sit down and watch again, we're just going to pretend that they didn't really make Season 11 and skip it.We read a few articles online that Season 10 really was intended to be the last season, and it's very clear that the final episode that year was meant to be the series finale. I don't know how they talked Stephen Collins, Catherine Hicks, and Beverley Mitchell into coming back for this pointless farce, but most importantly - I don't know WHY.

The Oral B Crest Complete Whitening Kit is a bundle of decent products designed to get your teeth whiter in as little as two weeks.  Mostly what you are buying is the toothbrush, some extra heads, and whitening strips.  It also has some extras such as a small bottle of mouthwash, some whitening toothpaste, with a small tote bag and a luggage tag? I have a feeling this pack was designed for swag at a dental conference or something.Toothbrush:I think the toothbrush is great.  I love that it comes with a travel case where you can also store the extra heads.  I always brush too hard and it has a light I can see in the mirror to notify me when I'm brushing too hard. The only bad part is that it seems to take awhile to fully charge.  However,  I think you can probably still get several days out of it with regular use before having to recharge, even when only mostly charged.Whitening strips:Pro: Super sticky when applied to dry teeth.Con: Tough to adhere to moistened teeth.In short, they will stick well to the upper teeth. With the saliva near your bottom teeth,  you probably want to use cotton in your lower gums while trying to adhere the strips to your lower teeth. My teeth did seem a little whiter after using, but it was hard to discern a noticeable difference.Mouthwash:The peroxide whitening mouthwash left me with a weird aftertaste,  sort of like dried mushrooms.  It was really weird.  It also leaves a slight foaming residue.  Definitely not something I was used to, but not terrible, and the aftertaste went away quickly.Toothpaste:This kit included some whitening toothpaste.  I can't really say it made my teeth any whiter by itself,  though.Whitening power:I think if you were really committed to getting whiter teeth to go to all the hassle of using this entire kit and the strips for two weeks,  you could probably get better results from a professional dentist.Overall:You are basically buying the toothbrush here with a bunch of extras.  The toothbrush is fantastic though, leaving my teeth feeling super clean.  However,  it was about the same as the other Oral B Healthy Clean Precision 1000 (which I also own).  I like the travel case and the extra brush heads and head holder.  However,  I'm not sure the kit is worth the extra expense.

The newest version of Rocksmith sees some improvements and advances in game play over the prior version,  making it a joy to play and stick with. I got the original Rocksmith and was pleasantly surprised at how much it was able to teach me.  However,  the menu and progressing through the lessons was a little unintuitive.  It was tough to get from just playing a song,  back to the lessons.  The newest version has a much more intuitive menu,  where it is easy to just pick up and play some songs, or, if you are going down the lesson track, to sit down and learn a song, or specific part of a song to master a technique.The "guitarcade" is a collection of mini-games to help practice your technique. It is themed around an 80s style arcade,  which doesn't really fit with the rest of the style of the game, but that's okay, it's still fun.  You will have no problem with lag as long as you use the audio out through the RCA cables and not the HDMI or Optical out.One aspect of this version that is both good and bad is the inclusion of the lead or rhythm guitar learning track (or you can choose bass track).  With the last version, you would learn aspects of the lead guitar along with aspects of the rhythm guitar.  I like that it provides an option to focus on what you do best (or want to focus your learning on). On the other hand, I liked having all parts of the song intermixed in one track. I'm mainly on the rhythm guitar learning track, but I really miss being able to play certain lead riffs.There is enough variety of styles and genres in this to keep you interested,  even if every song is not your cup of tea. You should find enough songs to learn to make it worth it, no matter your musical taste.  A great game and a big improvement over the last version.

I would definitely say these are more like "tea towels" than traditional flour sacks. The weave is very tight and even, crisp white, with perfect edges. They work great in my embroidery machine (which is what I bought them for) but aren't as popular with my customers as the more traditional-looking flour sack style.They're not bad towels at all, just know before you order that what you're getting is a set of crisp white tea towels.

I figured out how much it would cost me to wind this many embroidery bobbins on my own, and this box is BY FAR a better deal. I just got my first embroidery machine about 2 months ago, and go through bobbins pretty fast, so it's fantastic to have so many on standby when I run out of bobbin thread in the middle of a project. The bobbins themselves don't look exactly like the ones that are specific to my Brother machine, but they work just great. The box was packed neatly and I am extremely happy with these.

My arches are very high, and in the summertime my Fitflops conform to my feet like a firm version of memory foam, helping alleviate pain from plantar fasciitis. I've been wearing cheap slippers for too long & my feet hurt, so I shelled out to get some REALLY GOOD slippers like these.They're a little tight in the toes, and take a while to break in, but I really do love them. I suppose if I spent more time standing up, they'd break in faster! At first they felt very hard and cold but after a few hours I was reluctant to take them off. After wearing them for about 6 weeks now, they're starting to conform to my feet and feel good. Even though the backs are open, they are quite warm and cozy.The bottoms are extremely thick and waterproof, so I have no problem going outside in a little bit of snow or rain to get my dog if I need to. That was a must, for me!They're taking longer to break in than I expected, but I do love them so. I feel like the long break-in period means they will not fall apart easily and I can wear them for many winters to come. They are VERY good quality, solid, warm, and well-constructed. Much pinker than in the photo! Pretty close to Barbie Pink, which is a bonus for me but may not be for you!

Before you open the box, gather up 4 AA batteries and one of those tiny little Phillips-head screwdrivers. One of the screws holding my battery cover in place was in so tight that it took 4 different screwdrivers and the screw head is almost completely stripped now - I won't be screwing this back in too tightly, on the off chance that the batteries may die someday.The box is much, much bigger than the pieces require, so they rattled around a lot during shipping and the "stage" portion is pretty scratched up. I'm sure my 5-year-old nephew won't care very much but it just seems like they're trying to make you think you're buying a much larger, more impressive toy than you actually get. Inside, the smaller pieces are divided into plastic bags in a way that makes no sense whatsoever - basically you need to open every single bag before you can assemble even one portion of the final toy. The packaging engineers at Playmobil need to buy a few pieces of Ikea furniture and take a lot of notes about how to package in a logical, space-saving way that follows the chronology of assembly. Ultimately it only took me about 55 minutes to assemble the whole thing (about 15 of which involved wrestling the battery cover), but fortunately I didn't have my nephew over my shoulder impatiently demanding to play with it sooner. So if you're getting this as a gift for someone, open 'er up and assemble it FIRST.The light feature is pretty cool, and the fact that you can broadcast your own music through the speakers is fun. The speakers are very cheap and sound tinny, but it is a pretty inexpensive toy so what can you expect. Unfortunately, kids today are accustomed to very sophisticated technology so I don't know if my nephew will find that to be a cool thing for long or not. Fun idea though. It does come with two pre-loaded songs that are pretty awful, and the volume control has two settings: "not that loud" and "slightly louder." Plugging in an mp3 player, iPod, etc, is very easy through a headphone jack connection (which means you can use anything that has a headphone jack) but integrating a small holder for your iPod or phone would be a handy improvement.Once assembled, the stage does look pretty cool and the instruments (especially the guitars) are great looking! The band members, not so much. As others have mentioned, they're all dudes, which is pretty outdated, and their outfits - OMG. Does the designer think that today's kid's love Def Leppard and Bon Jovi or what?? VERY dated, goofy outfits. Maybe current "rock bands" do dress like 1980's AC/DC tribute clubs, but just in case, maybe Playmobil could offer some other "bands" to play on your stage, even include a little keyboard or DJ booth in the future. This has some potential for expansion, if your kid doesn't break it first - everything feels a little flimsy but I suppose it all depends on how hard they want to rock out.Loved the idea of this, but am not too impressed with the execution.

We originally got this for our younger dog, Peach, who is a puppy mill rescue and has some separation anxiety when I leave the house. It seemed to make her pretty sleepy, which will be excellent for thunderstorms and fireworks but not for everyday use. We don't use it with her very often because for general purposes, I'd rather not have her sleep the day away. She's a sweet, playful dog so I don't want to knock her out unless there is something she is REALLY upset about (i.e. fireworks).I decided to try it on our senior dog, Dennis (very senior - 16 yrs old), because some nights he just gets so fussy and can't seem to get comfortable enough to settle down and go to sleep. He's on a variety of other medications and supplements due to his age and various ailments (arthritis, deteriorating vision & hearing, etc) so I checked with the vet & the natural ingredients in this Calming Aid would not interact with anything else he takes. It REALLY helps him get to sleep if he is having a rough night!Our dogs are small, under 25 lbs, so they're supposed to get only 1/2 treat per dose. Unfortunately, the fact that these must be stored in the fridge makes them really hard to break in half without mushing them into oblivion. Honestly, Dennis does better with a whole treat anyway, with no adverse effects that I can see. Half a treat does nothing, while a whole treat lets him sleep. He likes the taste, too. Many of his treats & supplements must be given to him over & over because he spits them out the first 3 or 4 times, but he chews these right up happily.In general our dogs have pretty mellow personalities, so if your dog is really crazy and energetic, it might just make them calm. For mine, it makes them sleepy. But for some situations that would otherwise be upsetting for them, it's not really a bad thing to have them take a little nap instead of having a freak-out.

My pekingese, Dennis, is a pretty ripe 16 years old. He has arthritis in his back & hips, is nearly blind and seems to have some trouble hearing, too (tries to respond to noises but generally looks the wrong direction). For the last year, he seemed to be feeling worse & worse and would sit on his bed wailing for help several times per day. The vet had him on several pain medications but we couldn't increase it anymore, so they suggested he may be suffering from some mild dementia due to his advanced age, and recommended a veterinary supplement (not this one - stick with me, it will all make sense soon). After a few days, little old Dennis decreased his wailing and began getting up to have a snack or ask to be let outside for a potty break.The change after beginning the vet supplement was mild but good, so I asked them if it would be okay to add this product (Canine Plus Senior) to his daily treats; they said it couldn't hurt. He seemed to get even better, even faster! It's almost like, he was crying before because his belly hurt but he didn't know why - now he seems to know when he's hungry or has to go potty, and gets up to do something about it. He seems to have a little bit of an easier time getting around, too, so I think this is helping with his arthritis (just a little bit, but still). The two supplements seem to be working well together, but the Canine Plus Senior seems to be the more helpful one for Dennis. If we skip a day, he seems to get very fussy and confused again within the next 12-24 hours.It's not a miracle cure, don't get me wrong. He's still a half-deaf, mostly blind, arthritic 16-yr-old dog. This really seems to have made him more comfortable and energetic though, and a lot less confused, so I am very happy we discovered it! He likes the taste too, so we don't even have to wrap it in lunchmeat (unlike the ones from the vet). I'll definitely be buying more when we run low!

First the good: it definitely does charge your iPhone 5, and does it very quickly. So, as a backup charger, that's very good. I often work at art fairs where I may be outdoors for 12 hours or more with no access to electricity, so being able to charge my phone at some point is very important. Make sure the Power Case is charged all the way up before you need it, because you get one charge out of it and then it needs to be plugged back in. To me it seems to take a very long time to recharge the battery once it has been used to charge the phone.Other reviewers have mentioned the bulky size/weight, and I will too - for a backup battery, it's not unreasonably heavy, but as a general case, it adds some fairly significant bulk to the phone. Maybe if I had gotten it at the same time as my phone, I would be used to it, but I've had my phone for a year and am accustomed to its size and shape so adding this large case feels a lot different. Also, I currently protect my phone in a thin, light, plastic case with a pretty design on the back - sue me, I'm female, I'm a designer, I like my phone to have a little personality. So, for charging, I have to carefully snap the phone out of my normal case before snapping it into this charger case. I have no desire to switch to this Power Case full-time in favor of the cute one. I LIKE my cute one, and this is the electronic equivalent of a Hefty bag.The thing is, it charges the phone so quickly that there's really no need for it to be a case rather than an external charger. I would actually like it a lot as an external charger! As it is, I have to take apart my other case, snap this one on, charge for less than an hour, then take it apart again and put my old case back on. If it were lighter, more streamlined, and let's face it - better looking, it might have more use as a case too, but as simply a backup charger, it involves a lot of extra unnecessary steps.I used it twice and went back to my old external charger for art shows. I still take it along if I'm concerned about using my phone a lot for long hours without access to electricity, but I find it pretty inconvenient and prefer to use something else when possible.

EDIT/UPDATE: These stupid crap spools have now ruined countless projects. If you thread them beneath the spool as my machine dictates, they become wound around the spool pin because the spool cap doesn't fit neatly inside the small end of the spool. If you thread them above the spool, they fit into the larger spool cap perfectly but continually get caught on the bobbin winder. Either way, first they get stuck, then they yank the bobbin thread through the project, then the needle snaps in half. I wish I could give this thread a rating of negative infinity! DO NOT BUY if your machine feeds thread from below the spool, it will not work!- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -I don't really follow color charts; I look at what the design is going to require and what color fabric base I'll be using, and sometimes vary widely from the recommended colors for a particular pattern. If you prefer to follow color charts exactly, you may have a problem with these for two reasons. First, based on the other reviews, these color numbers may not match up with your machine's brand or your pattern's advise. Second, the color number is printed on a sticker at the end of the spool, which must be removed before use. Maybe you could peel it off carefully and stick it carefully somewhere inside the bottom of the spool, I'm not sure.I have a Brother DZ820E, which is basically the same as a PE770. It came with a starter pack of Radiant Thread, which worked great, so I sought this brand specifically. The thread is nice quality, rich colors, and usually moves smoothly through the needle and inner mechanisms of the machine. With 100 spools, you obviously get a pretty good variety, but I was disappointed to not see more shades of gray and no "peach" that looks quite right for a caucasian skin tone (I like to embroider a lot of pinup-girl motifs). Also, be aware that these are are 550 yards, so they're about 1/2 the size of what I was used to - the spools themselves are shorter in height, not thinner wound. There are plenty of infrequently-used colors that should last a good long time on a small spool, but for things like black, you'll run out extremely fast. Wish they could have skipped a shade or two of bright orange and thrown in an extra black.Though the thread is nice, the spools are hateful little things! They are the main reason for the 3-star review. They are cheap plastic, with rough edges where the thread occasionally gets caught. The worst part though, for my machine, is that they don't fit tight to the spool cap for mounting on my horizontal spool pin - other brands I've purchased (Marathon, ThreadArt) fit neatly into the spool cap like a puzzle piece and rarely get tangled around the pin. These spools leave a small angled gap between the cap and the spool, and the thread gets wound up around the pin CONSTANTLY, stopping the supply of thread to the machine & needing to be rethreaded every single time. It is extremely annoying and hard to prevent. In fact, just as I was typing this, some thread got tangled up so tightly around the spool pin that it actually snapped off the end of the needle way down at the other end of the sewing machine.I've had almost no fraying with this brand of thread, but the spools are just too much of a pain for me to ever buy these again. I've got the ThreadArt sets back on my wish list and will just have to try and supervise these spools as much as I can to try and keep them unwinding smoothly off the spools.

First off, this review is of the EnviroBulb PAR30. This is the version without the diffuser cover. The LED light is around the outer right and reflective material angled in the center spreads the light out. Without the diffuser, this is a very intense light, which I like, but may not be for everyone.It fits perfectly in our standard size recessed can lights. I‚Äôve had other bulbs that fill the can and practically touch the sides. This works great with our dimmer switch, too. It doesn‚Äôt have any hum and smoothly dims from brightest intensity to lowest. I‚Äôve tried other CFLs that claim to be dimmable, but they just bounce around at different intensities. Not the case with this EnviroBulb. While I do not have the capacity to test and verify their energy savings capacity and lifespan, I can say that the emitted light is bright and intense, but pleasant. If the energy savings are anywhere near what they claim, it is well worth the increased cost of these LEDs, especially considering their superiority over CFLs (whose light quality I cannot stand).I would like to see all of my can lights replaced with an LED bulb like this, but due to their cost, I will probably have to replace them one at a time. I can‚Äôt afford to just buy an 8 pack of these the way you could with incandescents. Here‚Äôs one thing to keep in mind with LEDs - there is a wide variety in bulb shape and design. I have a couple in my home from different brands and they look completely different. If you are buying them one at a time and are using them in open recessed light cans, you may want to make sure you are getting the same kind, if you care about the matching aesthetics of the exposed bulb.

This divot repair tool would make an excellent gift for any golf aficionado. There are many similar tools out there (for the same price or more), but don't have all the extra tools this does. Most others have a magnetic ball mark and the ball mark repair tool, but they don't have the bottle cap opener, cigar holder, can opener and club rest. I especially like the club rest. When I walk towards the green with my wedge and putter, I hate having to set the putter down on the wet grass. So I just pull this out, stick it in the ground and set the putter into the top grooves. This is such a simple thing, I can't believe all of these tools don't have it. For this reason alone, this warrants 5 stars.I can't see using the bottle cap opener much since I don't usually have bottled beverages on the course, but if you are a cigar smoker, the same thing functions as that. The tool also has a heft most others lack - made of a thick, polished metal, it definitely has a solid feel in your hands.

So first thing is that these gloves seem to run small in size. I normally wear a women's medium in gloves. These fit except they are too long in the fingers. I think a size smaller would have been too tight.The gloves are well made and are pretty warm though I don't think they would be warm enough if I wore them while shoveling snow. Which is too bad because they have extra padding in the palm and thumb that makes it comfortable to use a shovel. I wore them while raking leaves and I appreciated the comfort of these gloves. I really wish the fingers fit better, though. It is difficult to pick up small items.Overall, I think these are nice but may not fit perfectly for most people.

The size I got was a little too small. But I also don't like the fact that the zipper doesn't run all the way to the top of the boot. That makes it rather useless. So I'm returning instead of exchanging. Free return though which surprised me.

I liked the way these look but they are too narrow for socks. Free return though. I would exchange them for a larger size but if the half size up didn't fit, one whole size would be too long so I'm not even going to try.

I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.I LOVE the smell of this conditioner, I think it is the Camellia. I used another product before that had that in it and I also liked that scent very much.This does not come in a jar but in a tube. It takes up less room in my already over-crowded shower shelves. It is a good conditioner but more for frequent use than the really deep conditioner you need when your hair gets dry. But if you use a good daily conditioner, you don't usually need a deep conditioner too often. I like it, but I will stick with the deep conditioner I use when I color my hair.

I received this product free in exchange for my honest reviewI liked the way this serum feels on my skin, it absorbs quickly so I was able to wear it under my makeup. However, I did have a couple of breakouts. My skin seems to be sensitive to retinols, I think. I am just using a very small amount around my eyes now and it isn't causing any problems but I haven't noticed much of a difference. I wish this just had the Vitamin C without retinols, then I could use more. This might not be a good choice if you have sensitive skin.

I love the color, black denim looks great and these are slightly faded but still appropriate to wear to work for business casual dress code. I wish it was more of a narrow skirt but I still really like it. Holds up fine after washing. There is a little bit of stretch in the fabric that makes it so comfortable.

These boots are cute but you have to put in inserts as there is no support at all. They don't look expensive and they aren't. They are fine for wearing outside if the weather is dry. I have no expectations that these would hold up in the snow but I didn't buy them for that. I will get some pretty good use for the price. A pretty good deal.
