After testing the speed on this card on my Android HTC Evo 3D, it rated it close to a Class 4 Device.  The price seemed great for a Class 10, but the card  speed is way below the specifications.  Would not recommend this product.  Amazon refunded my purchase.

Purchased 2 of these for my Wife and I to take to the gym.  I wish Amazon they would let you select the color, as we both ended up with Red ones so I had to mark our initial on them so we knew whose was whose.They are very easy to setup and select your personal combination, they are not to clunky. I noticed some folks said they don't fit on their gym lockers but we have no problem at ours.If your looking for an easy to use combination lock that you can set your own combination, this is one is great, especially for the price.

Purchased this Water bottle because I started going to the gym and I needed something to bring my Water and Gatorade in. The design is very nice and fits nicely in your hand.  I opted for the Smoke color which looks very good.  The meter around the lid is a cool feature to remind you how much liquid you have drank, but I haven't really used it.

I previously have owned two of the Belkin SurgeMaster Wall Mounts without the USB ports so when I saw this model at a great price I jumped on it.  Being able to plug my Mobile devices in with just a USB cable is very convenient.My only beef with this model is they rotated all the outlets 90 degrees from the older model, so if you have a lot of plugs that are slim and wide, they end up covering over the middle outlets depending on how you plug it in.

Purchased the TEW-680MB last week for my living room, it was to replace my 4 year old Dlink DAP-1522.  This product is so much better and easier to use.  I have 4 devices in my living room connected to it:  LG TV, Xbox 360, Panasonic Blu-Ray Player, and my Onkyo Receiver.There is no lag at all between this device and my router (which is the Linksys E4200 V1) which is in another room.  I currently have it connected on the 5ghz band.  I love how you can see the details on the link quality and status by going to the status page of the device. (see below)  Even with the signal strength at 55% my link quality is at 98%.Extra Info  Link is UpChannel  149 <--> 5745000 KHz ; Central Channel: 151Link Speed  Tx  324.0(Mbps)  Rx  364.5(Mbps)Link Quality  98%Signal Strength  55%This device was so easy to configure compared to my old DAP-1522 and took me less than 5 minutes to setup.  When using my Xbox 360 as a Media Extender to play music and movies from my PC there is no lag at all, if I run the network performance test it list a HDTV quality link between the two so I know this device is working well because with the old device it was listed at a standard TV signal with the occasional spikes in signal loss.P.S.  Make sure you update the firmware on this device from Trendnet's website before you set it up.

This review is purely on the protein taste and mix-ability and serving size.First of all this stuff is expensive, I ordered the 2.2 lb container of Vanilla Bean.  First thing I noticed was it said 20 servings, the 2 lb container of their normal Gold Standard 100% Whey has 29 servings.  The scoop for the Platinum Hydro Builder is like twice the size of the Gold Standard yet they both say mix with 8-10 oz of liquid.  I tend to use fat free milk, when I put a scoop of the Hydro Builder in my shaker cup, I can sit there shaking it for 5 minutes and it doesn't fully mix,  There is a lot of powder on the bottom of the cup that doesn't seem to mix at all. Also the stuff that does mix seems to turn the milk very foamy and thick and its almost gross to drink.As for the taste, its ok but nothing to write home about, maybe I should have gotten the Chocolate since that's the flavor of the Gold Standard Whey I use and like.Also why does this stuff have 50mg of Cholesterol, seems like a little excessive, I'll probably just go back to the normal Gold Standard 100% Whey once I finish this container.

This case is nothing special, its to thin to really protect the phone.  Get this if you don't want scratches on the back of the phone, that's about it.  No lip on the front so you can place it screen side down.  If you want a lite weight slim case with little protection get this case, if you care about keeping your phone looking good and safe if it drops, this case is not for you.
Ordered this to open my Macbook Pro 13" and it worked perfectly.  No issues removing the screws or placing them back.  Great price.

I really wanted to give this toothbrush 5 stars, but I just couldn't.  It's not a bad device by any means but it's partly a step backwards from the Flexcare+ model and is it really worth the price?Let me start off by saying this is the 4th Sonicare Toothbrush I've owned.  I had the Essence, than the Flexcare, than the Flexcare+ and now the DiamondClean.If you have the Flexcare or the Flexcare+ do you really need to upgrade to this model?  Probably not, Sonicare's own website states you get a 44% better clean using the new DiamondClean heads, so the handle obviously makes no difference.Don't get me wrong the new handle is very cool, slick design, even slicker charging options, but did Sonicare have to remove features to do this?  For instance:The battery icon is now 1 solid icon rather than 3 different slices, now you can't tell when the battery is getting low.The button to change modes was removed, now there is one button for power and mode changing, this means unless you want to splatter toothpaste all over your mirror you need to change the mode in your mouth while trying to squint at the brush to see what mode it's on.Why was the UV cleaner removed?  Ok, I really didn't use this often but it was cool to know I had it.This toothbrush is very expensive, and your basically paying for the cool charging technology, and the absurdly overpriced new brush heads.  Currently a pack of 3 runs almost $35. In contrast a pack of 7 ProResults can be had at a big name Warehouse store for around $40.Also while putting your toothbrush in the cup for charging is cool, is that really practical?  If anything it's going to start making the bottom of the handle sort of gross, how many germs collect in that cup overnight unless you clean it every day.So in conclusion, cool charging technology does not take the place of convenience features.

Purchased this on ebay, brand new got a great price, cleaned it thoroughly and the first time I used it I almost threw up.  There was a very very harsh plastic taste.  I emailed Camelbak, they said try cleaning it with lemon juice.  Tried that and it didn't help, then I emailed the person on Ebay, he said try cleaning it with baking soda, tried that and no luck.  Emailed Camelbak again and they told me to return it to the seller (which I obviously can't do now), Camelbak said they could not replace it since they had no extras.After playing around with it a little more I think I've actually determined the bad plastic taste is coming from the cap, so now I just take off the top before drinking.  While it keeps the water relativity cold, the taste of the water inside far outweighs that pro.

For the price, these are good.  They have a little bit of a cheap feel to them, but the sound quality is quite good and the glowing green definitely makes them look pretty cool.They are surprisingly lightweight, which allows you to wear them longer without discomfort. I do wear glasses sometimes and I did notice the pressure on the ear pieces of my glasses a bit more than I do with my other headset, so I think they do squeeze a bit tighter (which in theory provides a bit better noise isolation).I also tried these out as regular headphones on my MacBook pro using the included wire.  The wire is too short to have much range of movement and I noticed a constant feedback with them.  So, I can't really recommend them for use as a regular headphone replacement, at least with a MacBook (which shouldn't be too surprising).

This is what I would call a backpacker's ultralight tripod for a photo enthusiast, but you probably need to be gentle with it. What does that mean? Well, it means the thing is small enough and lightweight enough to consider trekking up a mountain or on a multi-mile hike, but not sturdy enough to take much of a beating. The general feel of flimsiness and concern about its ability to support larger cameras is the reason I knock one star off. Otherwise, I quite like it.It is surprisingly full featured with adjustments for nearly every angle and even include quick release pad so you can quickly switch between mounting it and holding it. It won't replace my more heavy duty tripod for normal use, but I can easily see myself taking in along when space is tight or for day hikes with my family.  I also just got back from Japan and there were a number of places that I kind of wished I had a tripod with me. This is lightweight enough that I wouldn't hesitate putting it in my luggage the next time I go somewhere like that.

This is the 2600 mAh version. This means it has a single power out and really can only fully charge a cell phone once.  Some of the reviews are for the 7600 mAh version which looks a lot better to me.This 2600 mAh isn't as compact as I think it could be.  I just used a panasonic device that was more compact and had at least this much battery life.  It also has a button on it which I cannot figure out what it really does.  There is an absolutely terrible pictogram in the instructions that don't make sense to me for what the button function is.Overally, this works as an okay backup for a single device and is a good way to carry around a bit of a life saver for whatever devices you may need in the course of the day.  I really would prefer a device with a bit more power or for this size to be a bit more compact.

Now when you are watching the movies on the couch with you great big tub of popcorn and cheesy poofs you don't even have to get up when your wife complains about the lights.  Just whip out your phone and get the job done.  This works so well that you can practically hear the cholesterol hardening your veins as you flip channels.This is yet another product that you want to show off to your friends to prove that the future is arriving every single day.  Definitely a cool factor and they actually work right once you get the install figured out.  This is where I did struggle a bit to get it right, but it mostly seems to be working now. There are a number of other reviews on here with tips and tricks which I did take advantage of during install. If you are comfortable with installing a normal light switch, then this shouldn't be too difficult for you to install as well.  Soon enough, you'll also be irritated at the mere thought of getting off the couch to refill your cheesy poofs.  Maybe soon there will be a drone delivery system from the kitchen to the couch that you can also summon with your phone...

I have numerous hand-helds and I really question that this product is worth much more than my go to handheld (Motorola MH230R).  This is larger and heavier.  You only really need this one if you anticipate being in a full on rainstorm and expect to be quite a bit further apart. The other pseudo features like vibra alert, etc don't really buy you much IMHO. I like to go mountain hiking / climbing with buddies and this is a little bit big for those trips that I'm trying to save a bit of weight and bulk.That said, it is a very good unit.  It is rugged and should stand up to the elements.  So, if you do want to worry a little less about the thing getting ruined in the rain and feel more confident about that distance you can use it over, it is a very competent unit.

This aerator has changed our wine drinking completely.  We have always enjoyed a casual drink of wine, but never thought an aerator was worth the trouble.  That has all changed.  The before and after results with this wine quite literally get looks of shock from all of our friends.  Even box wine has a phenomenal difference with this device and it is so easy to use.  Absolutely, hands down worth it for even the most casual of drinkers.

I was a little skeptical, because I have about 5 other camping air mattresses and I am rather picky.  However, I have to say that this is a great backpacking mat when you are concerned about size and weight. When I'm not as concerned about weight, I'll still go with my other pads for a bit more comfort.I am a side sleeper, so I was very skeptical that I wouldn't be digging my hip into the ground.  This is only the case if you don't inflate it fully. For other mats I have usually found that I need to have them slightly deflated to feel the best. With this one, if you turn on your side when it isn't fully inflated, your hip (at least mine) would manage to find the empty pockets.  So, just inflate it fully and no problem.Air nozzle is nice.  It has to be pulled in a certain direction to take or lose air, making it easy to inflate without scrambling to close it.The mat is quiet. No much rustling around, disturbing everybody around you.  The pillow is okay, but I need a bit more height to the pillow, so I still needed to add an extra inflateable pillow.

This does exactly what it says. I think to fully enjoy this product that you would want to have it hooked up as media device on you home theater, which can be done either directly or by having a TV or other device that supports home DNLA so that you can stream from your computer to your TV.  For just casual video file viewing on your PC, it provides a lot of cool features that I'm realizing I probably won't take advantage of very often and I can't really see needing this program.I like the fact that it does have mobile apps so that I can stream to phone (android).  That features works well, but I did have to dig around a bit to find out how to turn that on (go into settings -> preferences -> Home DNLA).

This became the perfect compromise for my wife and I.  We had recently added a 3" gel memory foam topper to tour bed, because I've got minor back issues.  She never quite loved it and often complained that this was too much, preferring the normal pillow top on our bed.  When we got this, we originally intended it for a guest bed, but after opening it and finding it so plush we decided to try it on our bed.  This has added a plush, soft layer to the memory phone topper which really makes it the best of both worlds and now we both are happy.

This is a very entry level computer that fits the bill for what I wanted to do with it - web browsing / word processor for the kids.  However, it comes with bloatware that really slows it down. Honestly, at this price, don't expect more than what you are getting.The first thing you probably should do is install the latest Ubuntu over top of it and get rid of Windows 8.1.  This is easy to do.  Just get a bootable desktop ubuntu USB from their website.  This will give you a basic desktop operating system without bloatware, but also include some free office replacements (Libre Office). It isn't necessarily something for everybody, but I got my kids setup with it and it works great.You can then give them their own limited rights account and set them up with Firefox.  I also installed an extension on Firefox that let's you blacklist or whitelist specific websites.  In addition, you want to set up that computer to use Norton connectsafe DNS server.  This is really easy to do and I would give you a link if Amazon didn't strip those out.  Just google it.  You can have different levels of protection and you can really turn it up high to prevent them from going to undesirable web sites.And just like that, you'll have a very serviceable web browser / homework computer for the kids.As for out of the box, this thing isn't particularly usable due to too much bloatware on it.  You should strip out McAfee and my recommendation would be Norton Internet Security.  It uses a lot less CPU than McAfee and is more powerful than Windows Defender.

Great for when you need extra battery life, but if you are worried about getting it wet I don't see how this would work. You can get a "skeleton" housing the gives access to ports and will provide some protection against damage, but will not provide water proof protection.http://www.amazon.com/GoPro-AHDKH-301-HERO3-Skeleton-Housing/dp/B00CSQYVWMOtherwise, it is a bit heavier than a non-powered pole, so be certain that you'll want that extra battery life and that you don't need a waterproof housing.

Love this scent! Perfect for everyday. Not too heavy, but also not sickeningly sweet. I can easily wear this out and about without feeling too showy. Just a nice smooth scent that actually doesn't give me a headache. It seemed like it doesn't last as long as my standby, DOT, so you might need reapply if you need it to last all day. Overall very pleasing!

2:00 MinsEasy to install.  Immediate difference in streaking. Streamlined look.My old wipers were streaking pretty bad, I installed this and immediately noticed the difference.The little cover also shades the actual blade, so I think the sun won't "bake" it as much as blades that don't have a little cover on them.In the video I show how to install the wiper blades on a Nissan vehicle.  The same procedure worked on a Kia.

These scissors work great with tape.  They are very solid, sharp, and completely non-stick.  On one hand, the color is a little obnoxious. On the other hand, with my other scissors I'd often find myself wondering "where did I put those scissors" only to find them lying a few feet away.  This makes them really visible.

This lens works great as a 55 - 200mm lens.  It is better than the kit lens, but don't make the mistake we did and hope that you won't need broader angles than 55 mm.  After out 18 - 250 lens quit we thought that perhaps we could get away with just the 55 - 200 for a bit, but that is not the case.  We ended up going back to a 18 - 250 lens for the versatility.

3:56 Mins This is a heavy duty stapler.  It feels solid in your hand with no plastic parts. It works easily and staples through thick packets with ease.The video shows the unboxing of it and demonstrates stapling several packets of paper.

Although both Amazon and FRAM's website think this will fit a 2010 Nissan Murano, it doesn't.  Either that or I got a defective one.  Although the size and appearance look very, very close, the rubber gasket around it was just slightly too big and I could not get the housing to snap back on after many attempts.  If I tried to force a clip to close, it would just snap right back open.On the plus side, Amazon gave me a full refund.

I'm very mixed on whether this should be a 3 star or 4 star review.  I've decided to give it a 3 star review because, frankly, I had to keep googling youtube videos to figure out how to do things that should be very easy to do.  Once you figure out how to do it, then you realize how powerful the editor is.This year I've created projects with Cyberlink PowerDirector and iMovie.  Not surprisingly, when you just want to quickly put together some clips to post to facebook, iMovie wins.  Next up, I like power director, but it is only slight ahead of Pinnacle Studio.One really nice thing is that it has a lot of built in transitions and effects.  I found the export menu to be one of the easier menus I've used.I liked the clip editor screen quite a bit (after I youtubed a tutorial).  However, I used color and brightness correction on a snow video (sledding) and the final result didn't look very good.  It really struggled to properly correct the snow.One thing I really didn't like is that the effects / transitions labeled "GPU" wouldn't preview render for me at all.  This is very annoying, especially since I have a Radeon r9 270x GPU.  I also pulled up the GPU monitor when doing export and as far as I could tell it never even used the GPU.  I do have an i4770 CPU, which it pegged at 100%. So, as far as I can tell from reading the documentation, you have to have a Nvidia GPU or you will not get any advantage from your GPU.All in all, this product didn't leave me especially unhappy with it or very excited about it. In other words, I don't see much of anything that makes it stand out as an obvious winner.

What I have used this for:Mountain biking on some trails in Colorado.  Plan on using it for hiking and snowshoeing.My favorite part of this device:It works in both the dark and direct sunlight. Even on a completely sunny day with fresh snowfall (super bright), I can clearly see the screen.What I won't use:The pedal attachment for pace setting.  That isn't something I'll use mountain biking.  If you are a road biker, then perhaps it would be more useful to you.What else I like about it:This unit has water proof certification up to about 3 feet of immersion, so I don't have to worry about dropping it in mud, splashing water in it, or dropping it in the snow. It is lightweight.  It has a cool "Surprise me feature".  Just set your destination or workout goal and it will give you a few route options to choose from.What I don't like about it:No bluetooth to connect to your phone or computer (you need to look at the next model up).  The resolution on the maps is pretty low compared to my phone.  Entering a destination is a lot slower than entering it on my phone and it didn't have a relative's street listed in it.  Loading maps is way harder than just using google mytracks or pre-caching google maps on my phone. It doesn't come with a clip attachment so that I can just easily attach it to my backpack strap for quick reference. Even if I did want to use it for my car, it refuses to provide directions for a destination more than 125 miles away.This device really is pretty good. It has a mostly dedicated purpose (biking).

My kids love the thing. It glows in the dark (ball, net, hoop, outline of backboard), which definitely enhances the cool factor.  it is made of quality materials. It is light years better than a typical cardboard and plastic over the door hoop.However, the breakaway rim is too tight.  When I pull down on it, the entire plexiglass backboard bends almost more than the rim spring gives.  Speaking of which, there is no vertical stabilizer bar on the backboard which makes me afraid that one of these times the kids are going to hang on the rim and break it.  Yes, I've broken plexiglass before, so, I know it can happen.It fits pretty well over the door, but not perfectly. I have to force the door shut, which make me think it will end up warping the door.Putting together isn't hard, but I did give up on using the little included sheet metal wrench and just grabbed a socket wrench.

We've used Carnation Instant Breakfast before, so my kids are used to mixing powders into milk for breakfast. I was worried that they wouldn't like this as much, but they both declared that it was delicious! I also tasted it and it was good. They also beg me to buy PediaSure pre-mixed drinks, but they don't really need that much at once unless they've been sick. So I love the powder because we can measure just the right amount for them based on how they've been eating (or not eating well), and use it to fill in the holes for their nutrition. Great buy!

This is a very sturdy and attractive addition to a backyard patio. I wasn't sure what to expect for an Amazon Basics brand item like this, but i'm pleasantly surprised.  It has been the recipient of numerous complimentsI'd expect most people to be able to assemble it in about 20 minutes.  There isn't anything too complicated.  Perhaps the most difficult part was moving the box it all came in, because it is rather heavy.The one thing I don't like about it is that it can rust and should be covered when not in use.  This is disappointing, because it looks nice just sitting there with or without a fire.

This is my 3rd portable bluetooth speaker in this small form factor.  For the price and size, I think it sounds pretty good.  It has decent range, pretty good sound, and is very lightweight.  Paring it was really easy as well.Do not mistake this for one of the jawbone, bose, or beats bluetooth speakers that cost a lot more.  This is nowhere near that quality of sound, but it is a good value and very portable.  Sizewise, it would be like if somebody had a 1 inch high coffee mug.
If you've read the title & synopsis you know the entire plot. There are no sub plots or relationship dramas to be found. At best this is a pretty decent reenactment.

The unit overall is pretty nice looking and fits in well with my stainless steel kitchen. It is much smaller than I thought it would be and actually will probably retain a permanent position on the counter top. The only downside is that the three dials give it more of a retro look, rather than a modern look.  The function is also rather retro with having to turn the dial all the way to the right and then back to start cooking.For toasting bread quickly I'll probably stick with our regular toaster for most jobs.  This is slower, and I didn't notice any real difference in terms of even toasting.  That said, this does seem to have more fine tunability over the degree of toasting. Every toaster I've ever had gives a wide range of toasting, but they always seem to really burn the toast if you go even slightly past the lowest setting.  This toaster doesn't suffer from that.Where this shines is the ability to bake or reheat small meals, like a 9" pizza. And if you are willing to wait a few minutes, deliver a much more pleasant reheated piece of pizza than the microwave. We also use the individually frozen cookies and can bake just a few at a time without heating up the giant regular oven - perfect!

You know, the kind of cooking shows on TV where they say a meal only takes 20 or 30 minutes to make, except they leave out the fact that they had an entire team prepping everything for 1 hour before the chef started actually making it? Yep. So the chef goes on the show, and chops a few herbs just to make it look like they actually did some of the cooking themselves. And when they chop those herbs, what do they use? Exactly! A Santoku knife! So if that's the ONE piece of equipment they're actually using on the show, it must be important, right? Ever since I started watching those cooking shows I've been wanting a knife this this, so I had to get one!And I must say I'm beyond happy with this knife. It's a "mini" but I've found it's just perfect for most jobs in my kitchen so far. I've used it for herbs (of course), lettuce, avocados, small veggies, small pieces of meats, you name it. It's sharp and precise. It's easy to grip and hold, and comfortable in my hand. It cleans easily. And now I feel professional! Great knife to add to your kitchen!

I have been in love with Skip Hop designs ever since I bought their owl backpack for my daughter a few years ago. I got it before they went mainstream (into major department stores and Amazon) and had to buy it from a little boutique online so I was so excited to see this cute little duo on Amazon! I think she will love subbing out her owl for this penguin. It has bright colors, the decorations are stitched on strongly, the zippers work well. It was a bottle pocket and a mesh pocket within the little front pouch too, so has a few extra places to stash their tiny treasures.She is still using her owl pack after 4 years, so based on my experience, I can say these packs are:- High quality: strong sturdy materials, the decorations are integrated really well, made of good materials.- Durable: It has held up with daily use and preschool projects and lots of airplane travel in the past 4 years!- Sized perfect for kids: the size and weight is perfect for kiddos. I just wish the corners weren't quite so rounded because you do need to slightly flex a letter-sized paper at the corners to be able to zip up the pack- Cute! The kids love picking their characters to wear. It's not just a printed-on disney design. It's like a little friend to them!I would highly recommend any backpack that Skip Hop makes!
Looks great, but I'm disappointed with the sound field.  It just isn't very wide, so the separation isn't really there like I had hoped. Range and clarity are good, otherwise.

Looks great, has good protection, but it is so slippery I drop it all the time.  I've dropped this phone at least half a dozen times with this case on it. The phone hasn't broken and the case doesn't even look scratched.  However, I think I've dropped it this many times because it is quite slippery.  Much more slippery than the phone itself.This is too bad, because it looks great and doesn't add bulk.

I struggled between three and four stars. It is an innovative, smaller alternative to standard power strips, but after deliberation, I have to knock it down to 3 stars because of two things:1) One side of the cube is pretty much useless in all but one configuration.  Whether you have lying flat on a floor / desk or mounted under a desk, one of the outlets will not be usable.  Not unless you want this weird, off balance cube with cables coming out in all directions.  So, realistically, it is only 3 usable plugs. The only way you get all 4 plugs is if you have the cube mounted such that the cable goes through whatever it is mounted to.2) It only has 2 USB outlets. In today's world, 2/3rds of my devices can be plugged in directly to USB without a clunky adapter.  This could really use a couple more USB outlets.  Perhaps the internals of the device don't allow room, but it certainly seems to have external surface area for more.That said, it is relatively attractive, seems solidly built, and has a very sturdy cable.

We use this for our kids to practice, so no adult input (I don't play soccer!). But so far it's been great for our little ones (4 & 6). They don't kick the ball hard enough to need the stakes that come with it, but I love that we have them for when they get older and more aggressive. Right now it's awesome that they can both play with the rebounder net and have it rebound right back to them since I'm not always able to help them practice. It's also easy to set up and we love that we could easily take it over to our neighborhood park for more practice. It seems to be high quality and included very detailed and easy to follow instructions. Love the carry bag too. Overall a great product!

I've been using this for a few weeks now, and I'm starting to see slow results. My thighs look firmer for sure. However, I've only been able to use the cream once a day because: (the con): I really hate the way this smells! I feel uncomfortable smearing this on and then getting dressed and going to work. It really smells awful! I have to hold my breath while putting it on! So only at bedtime for me. It's also hard to rub in....it's much easier if your skin is completely dry, not just towel-dried. So wait a few minutes after showering. But it does take some work to really rub it in. I will keep using it to try and see more results and let you know how it turns out!

These sheet protectors are great for so many things around our house. I use them for my recipe binder, all the actual hard-copies I rip from magazines. Pop them in a sheet protector and then into my binder. I can put it right on the counter while cooking and not worry about drips or spills. We also use them for the kids' artwork and school papers that we want to keep in their boxes. Easy to use and great quality!

The size, shape, noise levels, and battery life all work very nicely with this shaver. It captures he whiskers effectively. I've replaced my couple year old Norelco with this shaver that was wearing out.My only complaint is that the length selector / adjustment guard isn't as secure as my previous Norelco.  The Norelco had a little twist dial that would always stay in place.  This one does well at keeping the length from getting too short, but it easily slips to a longer length setting.
This cable works exactly as advertised (USB 3.0). It has a thicker cable and is gold plated which makes it look and feel high quality.

We thought this headphone kit was a great way to disguise learning as a hands-on project. Not only that, but kids get to actually put it to use afterwards and have the gratification of having built it themselves and knowing how it works instead of just buying it at the store. The booklet has a fun book-like look to it with facts and photos and is in full-color. This is key since it doesn't seem like a boring black-and-white adult instruction manual. We had to help my son with assembly. The age is "8 and up", so the "up" kids could probably do it without help.The finished product doesn't have amazing sound, but that wasn't expected. One star off for the sound quality.  The construction of the headphones is on the "cheaper" side, and they probably won't last with use from a normal active child. One star off for the construction quality.Overall, a great afternoon craft/science project with no high hopes of having a high-quality lasting product. It is what it is.

We use this as a trainer for our kids who are just starting out in baseball. The kids are young, but past the t-ball stand stage. This works great as a next step trainer. The ball is easy to place on the top of the stand. We use different sizes of balls, from practice "whiffles" to real baseballs, and they all work great. The angle really helps the kids get used to a more skilled batting position, and the adjustable height is crucial for young kids. We didn't have any problems with assembly. Would recommend for kids ages 5 and up.

This board looks beautiful and performs beautifully. We used both black and colored (red, green, blue) dry erase markers on it and they worked equally well. Ink goes on smoothly and erases easily. Magnets stick with no issues. The kids use this as a resuable art/play board, but I would buy more for my own office use. Looks are trendy and modern. Great buy!

Based on all the positive reviews I bought one, ignoring the sprinkling of reviews saying they've had the device quit on them.  Well, mine showed up and was basically dead on arrival.  Powered on, but no sound.  Tried all troubleshooting to no avail.  I'd rather not have to keep the packaging for the next year just in case I have to send it back, so I won't be getting another.

I typically have used Tums when I get a bit of heartburn.  They seem to generally work well, except when the heartburn gets a bit more severe and I have to take them multiple times in a row.  With the Zantac, I haven't had to take follow up doses so far.  I also like that I don't have to chew it up to get the effect and I can proactively take it.  This is particularly true if the heartburn kicks in after I lay down for bed and I don't want to have to brush my teeth again (yes I try to sleep on my left side to help). Not dealing with chalking mouth is a definite plus.

Solid performance, low power consumption and runs cool!I bought this to upgrade an EVGA 680.  Not only does the 980 have double the pixel rate of the 680, it does it while using less power (165w vs 195w) and running about 10C cooler.  Simply amazing.This is the "reference" card, which out-of-the-box is a bit slower than the "superclocked" versions.  However, you can increase the GPU and Memory clocks via EVGA's free "PrecisionX" software.This is my third EVGA branded NVidia card.  Why EVGA?  Go spend some time on their forums, and see how they handle things like firmware problems and RMAs.  I've never had a problem, but it is comforting to know the support is there if I ever do.  And investigate their "step up" program, where anytime within 90 days you can upgrade to a different product for just the price difference.

Best wheel cleaner I have found!Despite claims of some products, none of them will get everything off without a bit of elbow grease.  This comes the closest of any, but will still need a bit of brushing to get all the brake dust.This product also has a fairly pleasant aroma, rather than the typical caustic/burning aroma of many others.  I have used a lot of Griot products, and while they certainly aren't the cheapest -- they have all been solid performers.  This is no exception.Highly recommended!

I have several USB automobile chargers, but none of them compare to this one.Very compact, at only 2.5" long (most of which goes inside the car's accessory socket) and about 1-1/4" at the widest spot.  Made from very nice materials, with elegant packaging, an LED indicator, and three -- count them -- THREE high-power outlets rated for 2.1A each.  With two iPads and an iPhone plugged in, this charger did the job and charged all devices without a hitch.Highly recommended -- this is now my favorite USB auto charger!(Sample product provided for evaluation.)

You won't be "crabby" when using this charger!  Just under 2" square and just over 1" thick, with flip-out plug prongs which make it compact and easy to put in a bag or case.  Exterior finish is a satin black, with color silkscreened logos and text.Unlike some competitors, BOTH of the two USB outlets are rated for 2.1A each, meaning you can charge two high-amperage devices (like iPads) simultaneously.  I simultaneously plugged in two iPads, and both indicated full charge current.  The adapter got slightly warm but never hot during charging.I had never heard of Crabby Digital before this product, and was skeptical -- but this charger is a quality product that I would not hesitate to recommend.  (Sample provided for evaluation and review.)

Excellent materials inside and out.  Very sturdy "hard shell", with a nice woven nylon exterior and soft felt-like interior.  The zipper is high-quality nylon with a rubber-encased metal pull.  A reinforced woven nylon carrying handle makes carrying easy.  Four padded dividers are provided, and can be easily relocated using their Velcro attachments to make up to (6) separate compartments.This is an excellent case, perfect for Cards of Humanity or any similar size/shape cards.  (Sample product provided for evaluation and review.)

The purpose of a charger case is to provide additional runtime, and this case does that very well.A standard Lighning receptacle at the bottom is used to charge the case battery.  While charging, there are (4) indicator lights which progressively light from right-to-left as the battery charges.  Four solid lights indicate the case is fully charged.  Rated at 4100mAh, this case will roughly double an iPhone runtime.Inside, there is a Lightning connector that engages the iPhone's Lightning receptacle when you slide the iPhone into the case.  This connector provides full data pass-through, so you can Sync the iPhone while in the case.  There are sufficiently-sized cutouts for the iphone camera, flash, speakers, headphone jack, and volume/mute controls.Battery power is engaged by a momentary press of the switch, located on the front of the case at the lower right corner.  As with charging, the (4) indicator lights show the current charge level of the case battery.Useful for more than just iPhones...  There is also a standard USB receptacle on the right side of the case.  This is a power output that can be USED WITH ANY USB DEVICE.  For example, I have used it to charge a Bluetooth headset, and it could also be used to charge any other phone using that phone's USB cable.The case does add some weight/bulk to the iPhone, but that is unavoidable with any battery case. If you need extra runtime, a little extra size/weight is a reasonable tradeoff to avoid a dead phone.The case does have some flaws.  First, I found it very difficult to use iPhone's the volume up/down buttons and mute switch while in this case, as the cutouts are deep and slightly mis-aligned. The kickstand is unstable, and only works if you have a perfectly level surface and no vibration or movement -- otherwise, the case will fall over.  Finally, the USB socket at the right bottom corner has some pretty sharp corners, and this can make holding the case uncomfortable.This case does what it promises, housing an iPhone and approximately doubling runtime. However, difficulty accessing volume/mute controls, the unstable kickstand, and the sharp corners of the USB socket are significant flaws that make daily use problematic. If you need a battery case every day, I suggest looking at other products and paying a bit more.  But at this price point, the case is an excellent value and functions very well for the occassional need to extend battery life.  (Sample product provided for evaluation and review.)

VERY happy with this shredder!  It is amazingly quiet, and the micro-cut particle size is very secure.  An added benefit of the small particle size is greater bin capacity -- compared to a cross-cut with the same size bin, the micro-cut particles pack together better and that means more pages per bag.  Staples are no problem.  The instructions for credit cards are contradictory, but credit cards CAN and SHOULD be run through the same slot as paper, where they get micro-cut for security.  The smaller "strip cut" slot is only for CD/DVD media, and does a great job as well.

Works perfectly on the Hopper receiver.  Simply connect your antenna, plug it into the receiver's USB port, then access the receiver settings and "scan" for channels.  Provides another tuner which helps avoid recording conflicts, particularly during sports season!

I absolutely love these switches!  Once installed and programmed, they automatically track sunrise, sunset, and even daylight savings time year-round at YOUR location.  You can choose to have lights turned On/Off at Sunset/Sunrise, or you can specify an offset (like "On 30 minutes after Sunset" and "Off 30 minutes before Sunrise").  There are manual programs as well, but the real beauty of this switch is the ability to track sunrise/sunset times year round.  Highly recommended!

This pump fit my older Maytag Neptune perfectly.  Installation was less than 30 minutes, and involves only removing the back of the washer, then two hose clamps and an electrical plug.  The old pump had gotten very noisy and was not always getting all the water out of the washer.  The local repair shop quoted me $99 for the part, plus a minimum of $150 for the service call.  It was an easy repair and big savings doing it myself!

Nice size, bright easy to read digits with a non-glare screen.  Generally accurate, but truncates rather than rounds -- so for example 13.69 still reads 13.6, not 13.7;  but 0.1v is close enough for most applications.Overall, a great product at a great price!

After having two of the plastic manifolds crack and leak, I decided to step up to brass.This manifold is heavy and well made, the only plastic on this is what surrounds the swivel connector -- but the swivel connector itself is also brass, so even if that plastic breaks the connection will still be secure.  Full size ball valves appear to be stainless steel, in trouble-free nylon seats.My only complaint is that the valves can be VERY difficult to turn.  Even with fairly strong hands, (3) of the (4) are very difficult to turn and lubrication did not help.  Keep a pair of pliers handy (or make a wooden extension as I did) unless you have very strong hands.

Perfect match for the original, individually carded with Fluke branding.BUY A SPARE!  At some point, you WILL blow this fuse.  For me, it happened when I had been measuring current on an auto circuit, then picked up the meter to check voltage -- but forgot to change the leads back to voltage.  DOH!  It only takes a split second of inattention, and you'll be without current-measuring capability until you get a replacement fuse.

Very effective.  One tablet per day over three months raised my ferritin level from 35 to 180.I did experience a bit of stomach upset, but less so than with other products I tried.  My doctor recommended taking C with iron, so this combination tablet makes that very convenient.

Good quality wire!  Like the #12 I reviewed earlier, the extra-fine stranding and silicone insulation make this #10 wire VERY flexible and therefore easy to route around obstacles.The silicone insulation is approximately 0.042" thick, and is imprinted with "10 AWG 200C". It is reasonably tough against abrasion and very resistant to heat. When soldering, there was no deformation or shrinkage of the insulation.I measured the stranded bundle at approximately 0.138" diameter. Given the very high number of fine strands, this appears more than adequate to meet the #10 specification for stranded wire.There was a minor issue with the original shipment, but the seller (Acer Racing) responded within minutes and immediately took care of the issue.Highly recommended wire and seller!

I filled this with ProGold PG2000.  Contrary to some other reviews, I have had no trouble with leakage even though PG2000 is very thin.The oiler works well to deliver small amounts precisely.  Even a partial drop can be easily delivered.my only complaint is that the tip is a little large.  The tip size is necessary for the design, which incorporates a valve at the tip.  But for extremely fine work, the tip is just too large.

Not only is this a great angle grinder, the price is astounding!The grinder itself is well made, and the side-switch is so much better than the typical "paddle"switch found on competitors. I have bought two of these - one for home, and one that gets heavy daily use on a job site.  No problems with either one.The price would be good if all you got was the grinder, but you also get a CASE and FIVE wheels with it!  That's an outstanding value.

Very high quality three-way tap.  Rugged, thick material feels like you could drive a truck over it without damage (but I haven't actually tried that).  The orange color makes it stand out, even in a dusty or cluttered environment.  Whether just adding outlets, or making room for transformers, this tap gets the job done!

Good material, but won't stay put!!  These used to be great, but for some unknown reason Rubbermaid changed the design to use USELESS tiny suction cups.  It simply does not stay attached, even after cleaning and polishing the sink surface.

Excellent timer switch!  I was tired of having to replace the old "spring wound" timers, which would inevitably begging to "stick" and never turn off.  This one has NO MOVING PARTS, so no sticking!  And it is a simple press of one button to get the stipulation you want.Easy to install, especially since it requires no neutral wire.  Looks very modern and is easy to use.  I do wish it came in " almond" color, but could only find it in white.  Even with having to replace the other switches and wall plates so everything matched, the added convenience and reliability made it all worthwhile!

This is basically a decently written novel of romantic suspense set in elite Los Angeles among a lot of people connected to the entertainment world.  The protagonist is Thomas a journalist from the Midwest who when writing an obituary for a deceased Hollywood bigwig is taken under the wing of the dead man's daughter.  From there he meets a lot of rich movie people and the Matilda Duplaine of the title.  This is well written, escapist fare but never very believable and comparisons to the writing if F. Scott Fitzgerald or Daphne du Maurier are not really deserved.

This is a comfortable full or double sheet set.  You get the full sheet, the fitted sheet and two pillow cases.  I am sending this set back to college with my son when he comes home from Thanksigiving as it is exactly the size he needs in his apartment.  The elastic on the fitted sheet fits well at least right now.  The price is right and the quality is more than acceptable.

This is an old fashioned book both in its language and  design .  It purports to tell the stories of some "cursed" places from around the world.  Forty different stories are selected.  Some of them are modern and well known (The Amityville Story from Long Island)  while others go back centuries and are more obscure.  There are maps with each story that are "vintage" but also quite difficult to use.  A few scary looking drawings are scattered throughout the book as well.  The subject matter of this volume might be appealing to young teenage boys but I think they would find the language quite difficult to access. The physical design of the book is quite attractive but I am not exactly sure who the book is targeted toward.

This product actually seems to reduce my stress and anxiety.  Possibly there is a placebo effect going on there but for now it seems to help.  I have not really noticed any positive effects on my concentration or focus but I have not  experienced any bad side effects either.

It seems that once highly touted Garcinia Cambogia Extract is not the miracle for weight loss it was thought to be.  I had no appetite suppressant effects that I noticed at all.  Hard as it is to face cutting calories by eating mostly vegetables, whole grains and lean proteins seem to be the only way to lose weight.  There are many Garcinia Camborgia Extracts available on the web and I fear none are really helpful in lasting weight loss.

This is a gimmicky novel that I did not really enjoy.  The descriptions of life in Southern California are somewhat interested but I didn't really relate to the major characters and the book was a disappointment to me.

This is my first time trying a Rug Doctor product and it does a decent job spot removing ordinary household stains.  It has a nice clean smell which is a plus.  The minus is it is a little overpriced and there are some really tough stains with which it is just not that effective.

THE HEART YOU CARRY HOME by new author Jennifer Miller is well rendered and engaging.  This is the story of Becca whose father is a Viet Nam vet and whose estranged husband is an Iraq War vet suffering from PTSD.  This is a book with important themes that many readers will be able to relate to and even those with no direct relationship with veterans will find interesting.

Having been a Special Education teacher for many years often working with students with the highest needs I really enjoyed reading Jim Kororis's new novel.  I'm not surprised to find that the central character Ethen is based on author Jim Kokoris' own son.  The book is very well written and readable and there is some humor in the book as well as angst.  And I love the cover.

I wasn't quite sure what to expect from a fresh new Bible designed for women but decided to give this a try anyway as my personal Bible is in tatters.  I discovered it is a regular New International Version of the Bible that has some essays from women writers I personally never heard of but I assume are important in Christian circles.  The essays are sprinkled throughout the Bible in an attempt to help women relate with the ancient messages.  There are some brief biographies of the contributors, a well rendered topical index and several blank pages for notes at the back of the book.  I am for anything that encourages people to read especially the wisdom of past generations and  that contributes to a healthy spirituality so I endorse this volume.

I suppose I should have known with dimensions of 17" by 24" how small this bathroom rug would be but the actual size did take me by surprise.  In a very tiny bathroom this minute rug might work very well as it does provide more than enough enough space for an adult to stand on when emerging from the bath/shower.  I do like the color (I got yellow) and the "popcorn" texture feels great to stand upon and I also like the way it looks.  I have not had the rug that long  but the longevity of some other items I have had from the DII company has not been lengthy as while serviceable their products from my past experience are not particularly durable are of high quality.  This might work well in a very small guest bathroom or any other small bath that is not used very often.

I had at least four rabbits in the front yard all the time this summer so I was interested in using this product. After using it, I not only had no rabbits, but all the yards within sight had all their many rabbits gone also.  I sprayed way too heavy because I emptied the bottle in much smaller area than the product claims.  I think I left the sprinklers off for a few days,  but the rabbits came back in less than a week... way less than the 30 days advertised.I think if you don't water your lawn, get lucky with no rain, etc., this will keep the critters away.

My husband's all-time favorite razor is a Remington XR1340 rotary triple header... better than any Norelco he's ever had... so we were interested in seeing how this screen type Remington razor worked.  This razor does not shave very close... but it does work in some areas the triple headers can't get to.  It is difficult to clean and looks like you could cut yourself doing so.  This might be good for a second razor for  travel or if you don't want a really close shave.

The twenty-eight stories in HOW WINTER BEGAN are quite varied.  True, the stories are book ended by tales featuring Irene a waitress and single mom living in San Antonio.  In between though we have characters living in places such as North Dakota, Florida, East Texas, New York City, Nebraska, and more.  Most of the stories are set in contemporary times but a few could be considered historical.  Quite a few of the stories are narrated in first person though some are in third and there is even one in second.  Many but not all feature Latina women and one that I felt was the least genuine, "Liking It Rough" is based on memories supposedly from a forty year old male Houston police officer.  The stories are mostly well written, thoughtful and intelligent but there are a couple of clinkers in there that simply don't work.  The stories are all quite short and the entire book can be read and digested in a couple of days.

While I am not sure there is anything mystic about this throw it is an attractive and very comfortable item.  It is the  perfect size for when you need a little extra warmth while reading or watching TV during the coming autumn and winter seasons.  It would make a nice accent piece if there are coordinating furnishings. and you like purple.  But mostly buy it for the comfort and easy care in the washer (cold water) and dryer (low heat).

While I like the vivid beet color of these travel "cubes" they were quite a bit smaller than I had visualized.  That said you can get a surprising amount of clothing and cosmetics in these three almost weightless bags that fit well inside each other even full. I can see them being my only bags on a long, weekend trip where I only need casual clothing that can be a bit wrinkled and really don't want the hassle or cost of checking anything on an airplane.  For longer and more formal trips I will still need more luggage though my husband or son could probably get by with just these though they would object to the feminine seeming color.  More included paper instructions on how to pack items efficiently would also be appreciated.

BECOMING MARIA: LOVE AND CHAOS IN THE SOUTH BRONX is a well written memoir form Sonia Manzano.  Manzano survived a tough childhood in the Bronx of the 1950's though the book shows affection at times for her chaotic family and neighborhood. This is the inspiring story of the woman known to millions as Maria on Sesame Street.  Recommended for about seventh graders and older and possibly a special interest to Latina girls.

I've been following Jonathan Kellerman's series of mysteries starring psychologist Dr. Alex Delaware that are set in LA and its environs for years.  While Kellerman's new book THE MURDERER'S DAUGHTER does make a few mentions of Delaware the star here is  Dr. Grace Blades a superwoman psychologist who can solve the most traumatized patient's needs, track and fight bad guys, pick up strangers for anonymous sex and is the heir to millions of dollars.Life did not start all that well for Grace who we are told has a super high IQ.  Her biological parents were neglectful no hopers living in a trailer court in the Southern California desert.  One eventually killed the other and then committed suicide leaving little Grace to a series of foster homes.  She finally finds a good home with an elderly foster mom on a former movie ranch but when some disturbed children from a cult come to stay there too a very handicapped foster brother ends up murdered and the foster mom has a heart attack from shock.  But Grace is soon taken in by a pair of older and wealthy Jewish psychologists who eventually send her to Harvard and grad school plus make her their heir.Grace is wildly successful in her practice specializing in treating people who have been traumatized by terrible events and especially those who have relatives who are murderers.  One of the kids from the cult comes back in to her life first as a one night (or actually hour) stand, then as a patient and ends up dead with other bad guys chasing Grace from LA to Berkeley.  You have to suspend quite a bit of disbelief to believe in the sometimes almost silly plot but Kellerman's California descriptions are always worth reading.  I have a feeling this may be the start of a new series for Kellerman though he is still pushing out the Delaware books and has started a new golem series with his son Jesse.

I found the taste of this drink tasty enough but I like almost anything that has chocolate in it.  The drink provides quite a bit of protein and not a whole lot of sugar and just 100 calories.  It makes a tasty enough afternoon snack but I doubt that it is something I would order again.

These are very tasty snacks as my whole family will agree.  There is just the right amount of garlic and parmesan flavor.  The pretzel crisps are satisfying and just what you need when you crave a crunchy snack food that is not too unhealthy.

"A Touch of Death" was originally published in 1953 and re-released as part of the outstanding Hard Case Crime series in 2006.  It's another compelling crime noir from a master author.  The protagonist is Lee Scarborough, a former college football star who has hit on hard times.  He's barely scraping a living as a salesman, when he meets a young woman with a plan.  She knows about a hidden cache of money, and she needs Lee's help to get it.  Of course, there's more here than meets the eye, and Lee soon finds himself running from the law.Williams' work here is top-notch and loaded with the kind of hard-boiled language and descriptions characteristic of the genre ("You knew she could turn on the honey-chile like throwing a switch at Boulder Dam.").  Lee is a typical crime noir character - he's not inherently bad, but he's willing to do some bad things to survive.  Of course, this type of book always has a gorgeous femme fatale, and "A Touch of Death" gives us three, focusing on a lovely widow (Madelon Butler) who may or may not have murdered her husband.  Madelon is a sociopath of the highest order, and the character is fascinating.  Another winner from Hard Case Crime.

Social problems are common across a wide variety of adolescent mental health problems, including anxiety, depression, ADHD, autism, and so forth.  In addition, many adolescents who do not have any overt psychopathology also experience difficulties with social situations.  Thus, books such as "The Science of Making Friends" are much needed in the field, especially those that focus on evidence based approaches.  The author has much experience treating these problems at UCLA's PEERS Clinic.  The book can be used by many different populations, including clinicians in the field, but it has also been written so that parents can use it directly to help their adolescents."The Science of Making Friends" starts with a consideration of why social skills and relations are so important.  This chapter helps parents and others understand the context of the problem and provides much practical advice, including how parents using the book can introduce it to their adolescents.  Chapter two explores what makes a good friend and how to go about finding them.  This section is well-considered and discusses the role of shared interests in friendships.  Again, practical activities are described to help parents and adolescents navigate this area.Subsequent chapters get into the nuts and bolts of social skills training, including good conversations; starting, entering and exiting conversations; and handling problems such as verbal teasing, arguments, and rumors/ gossip.  It's great to see that a brief chapter even addresses the rising problem of cyberbullying.  These sections are loaded with information.  Each social skills is described in detail and parents are provided with 'coaching tips' along with case studies of 'success stories."  Fortunately, the tips are developmentally-sensitive, acknowledging that good social skills for adults differ from those for adolescents (she calls them 'contextually relevant').  For example, one chapter examines electronic communication.  This section, though, is perhaps a bit shallow and focuses more on safety issues rather than social skills.  However, I think overall that this book is a solid addition to the arena of adolescents social relations and could be helpful to many families.The book is accompanied by a 30-minute DVD of role-play demonstrations of the social skills described in the book.  Each skill is followed with a series of questions to help the audience reflect on the skills.  The quality of the DVD is fine, although the scenarios are obviously filmed in what looks like a very formal medical library and the actors seem to be graduate students.  However, seeing these social skills in action unquestionably could be helpful for many adolescents.

I haven't owned a baster for awhile, as my last one was too small and difficult to wash.  The Fox Run Brands Bellow Baster solves both of these problems.  It can be used for all kinds of kitchen tasks, including basting a roasted turkey (the most obvious task), transferring liquids, or moistening items while they are grilling.  As other reviewers have noted, this baster is quite large, so it works for all kinds of jobs.  Of course, that also means that it takes up quite a bit of storage space.  Instead of putting it in a drawer, I store my baster upright in a container with my ladles and spatulas.  I also love the brush that comes with it, which helps ensure that you can properly clean the baster after each use.  The baster is perhaps larger than what many people will want or require for their cooking needs, but it's always great to have this kind of product around for those times when you do need it.

OXO Good Grips is one of my favorite brands because of their high quality across products, and this 3-Ring Trivet Set is another example of their exceptional work.  The trivets are made of durable silicone, which is difficult to burn and dishwasher safe.  Of course, the main attraction here is that they come in three different sizes that nest within each other, which is a nice, space-saving storage feature.  You can use them singly or together, depending on your needs; they can even be used side-by-side for long pans.  It's so convenient having these around the kitchen so that you can put hot pots or pans on your table or counter without worry.  So far, they have worked well for my needs.  My only minor complaint is that they are not terribly attractive in red, reminding me too much of a stove burner.  However, when in use, that becomes irrelevant.

"Stoner" is another re-discovered should-be-a-classic from the New York Review Books Classics series.  Why this book is not better known is a mystery to me.  It tells the story of William Stoner, a farmer's son in the early 1900s who is encouraged to go to college by the local county agent.  The plan is for Stoner to attend the new agricultural school at the University of Missouri and then return home with ideas to help his father's hardscrabble farm survive.  Instead, he unexpectedly falls in love with literature and decides to stay for a graduate degree and then to teach.The book is a revealing character study of the type of person who we all know ‚Äì a passive man who allows life to happen to him without ever doing much of note or taking control of his destiny.  Stoner rarely reflects much about his life or what he wants, and as a result, he rarely succeeds.  "Stoner" is written in a direct, simple style that belies the depth of the writing.  Nevertheless, this is a story that is likely to resonant with many people.  The supporting characters are also wonderfully etched with great details, and so many scenes are heart-breakingly realistic.  For example, his parents confusion (and ultimately shame) when Stoner decides to stay at college is gorgeous in its lack of sentimentality.As a professor who went to Mizzou, I was struck time and again by how accurately Williams paints the academic life.  Too often, books about academics are breezy comedies filled with handsome professors wooing beautiful co-eds while getting entangled in hilarious scenarios.  I wish it were that exciting!  Instead, "Stoner" depicts the drudgery and pettiness of the academic life.  Where professors don't speak to each other for decades and use their students as pawns.  As such, "Stoner" can be a bit of a depressing read; however, I found it all so overwhelmingly brilliant that it was an uplifting experience.  ‚ÄúStoner‚Äù is a must-read.

This compact book reviews the various cuisines around the world and is published by the same people who bring us the famous Lonely Planet set of travel books.  "The Food Book" begins in Europe (France specifically) before moving to other areas of the world, including Asia, the Middle East, Africa, Oceania, and the Americas.  Most of the best-known cuisines of the world are represented here.  Each country's overview includes discussions of various food issues, such as the culture of foods (e.g., how is the food eaten or sold), regions, feasts, etiquette, daily meals, essential produce, shopping, preparation, defining dishes, and drinks.The book is chock full of beautiful color pictures of the food, people eating or shopping, and so forth.  I think that if you're planning a trip to a country included here, then this book would provide a nice overview of what you need to know about the cuisine.  It is not, though, a cookbook, although it does include a dozen recipes scattered throughout (e.g., French onion soup, elotes, chimichurri).  "The Food Book" is an interesting read that certainly whet my appetite for some foreign cuisine.

I've become a big fan of Japanese-based pen company, Pilot Pens.  Their products are all first-rate; I've never had any problems with them.  The Acroball Medium Point (1.0) are a real highlight.  The hybrid ink allows the pens to write as smoothly as gel pens, but the ink looks and dries like a ballpoint pen.  The pens are designed with comfort in mind -- the barrel narrows right where you hold the pen, and the rubber overlay makes the pens easy to hold.  I love how they look and feel.Because they are Medium Point, the writing is bold and prominent with beautiful, bright ink.  This packet comes with five colors green, purple, orange, light blue (turquoise), and pink.  I love using the purple, green, and orange pens to correct student papers as the ink stands out brightly against black type.  The Acroball are definitely one of my favorite pens available on the market today, and they are a bargain for the price.

"Labor Day" is a lovely, moving story of a 13-year-old boy (Henry) coping with his depressed mother (Adele) in a small New Hampshire town.  Henry's parents are divorced, and the two live like hermits - rarely venturing out except to stock up on easy-to-keep foods (canned soup, frozen fish sticks).  Clearly, the divorce was hard on Adele, but she was already spiraling downward long beforehand.  Things take a dramatic turn, though, when they encounter a stranger, Frank, at a local store.  Frank has a dark past, but Henry and especially the extremely lonely Adele overlook it.  The book tells about the events that happen over the next few days - a languid, hot Labor Day weekend.Joyce Maynard is clearly talented; a lesser author could not take the somewhat unbelievable main plot and turn it into such a surprisingly sweet, gentle story.  She manages to make Adele a sympathetic, multi-faceted character, even when her judgment borders on the ludicrous.  Adele's desperation to be loved, and Henry's desire for an accepting father figure are palpable, even though one must suspend disbelief a few times along the way.  "Labor Day" is not the kind of book I typically read, but I'm glad that I did.  It was skillfully written, touching, and had complex characters.  This is top-notch contemporary writing.  I can't wait to see how Kate Winslet interprets the role of Adele in the upcoming movie adaptation.Note: This review is for the Kindle version.  The ebook has been formatted and transferred extremely well, with no obvious errors.  It also includes a table of comments with links to individual chapters.

The Mead Weekly Planning Desk Organizer is a clever product that can be used by busy professionals at work or by anybody wanting to be more organized.  It consists of a file folder holder with 5-slots - one for each day of the work week.  Two stickers are included for the front panel; one lists the days of the week (Monday through Friday), and the other is blank and can labelled however you like.  For example, students could label each slot with a different class, or parents could label each slot for a different family member.  I applied the Monday through Friday sticker, and I really love it.  I can put everything I need for each day into the slots as reminders to work on various projects throughout the week.  It seems particularly suited to teachers, as you could put your course prep and handouts for each day into the slots.  The system is really flexible and can adjust to your needs.  For example, it can be used to sort mail (outgoing, junk, bills, etc.) or to leave messages for different family members.The only drawback is that the holder is somewhat cheaply made. For something that is likely to receive a lot of daily wear and tear, it should be made of plastic or wood.  Instead, it's made of hard cardboard covered in paper.  The green paper covering already had started to come off when it arrived - I'll try gluing it back on to last longer.  Otherwise, I really like this useful file holder.

Cook's Illustrated is my favorite cooking magazine, and I purchase nearly every cookbook they publish.  The magazine picks a small number of dishes each issue and has experts try various recipes and variations in order to develop the 'perfect' version of each dish.  I have never been disappointed when I've tried their recipes.  They also focus on trying to make dishes relatively easy for home cooks.Their cookbooks follow the same pattern.  They always explain their process and what worked and did not work.  I have to admit that I am not a big fan of baking -- I prefer cooking, especially things that are hard to mess up, such as soups.  However, when I do bake, then I turn to Cook's Illustrated because of the perfection of the recipes.  I love this latest cookbook from them, which focuses on baking.  It includes every type of baking you can imagine, from quick breads to custards, including some savory pastry, such as pizza crust, rolls, and quiche.  The authors also include a nice section covering the products they use, including pans and ingredients.  As always, this cookbook is a first-rate product that makes cooking easier.

When I was a child, Clue was always my favorite board game.  My older siblings always played it with me on Christmas Eve, so it brings back special memories.  The game is fairly simple and can be played with ages 8 years and older.  Most of you have probably played it before, but if you haven't then the basic goal is to identify a killer.  A murder has been committed in a grand old mansion, and players need to identify who committed the murder, in which room, and with which weapon.  You do so by asking players questions and getting clues.  The game is great for children and adolescents because they have to think critically and also not be impulsive.  If you guess too soon, then you're likely to be wrong and lose the game.This version is the 'classic' game, with the old graphics and pieces.  The game has changed a bit over the years, so I'm really happy to have this classic version.  Clue is a fantastic, fun game that every household should have in its game cabinet.

Monopoly is perhaps the most iconic board game out there.  Most everyone has played it before.  For those who have not, the basic idea is that players move around the board trying to buy properties and avoid properties owned by other players.  If you land there, then you have to pay "rent."  The winner is the last person with money -- everyone else eventually goes bankrupt.  It can be a long, intense game, which can be fun or irritating, depending on your mood.  I love it personally.This version is a return to basics -- the old iconic Monopoly.  Over the years, minor changes have been made to the game, mostly in the way it looks and so forth.  Also, special versions have been released.  I like this basic, classic version because it brings back nice memories of playing Monopoly with my family.Monopoly is a great game for players 8 years and older.  It helps children and adolescents learn how to count money as well as budgeting issues.  I remember getting to play when I was a child made me feel grown up.

I teach a course on Family Therapy, so I am always looking for resources on working with different types of families.  Therefore, I was thrilled to receive "Working with Adoptive Parents: Research, Theory, and Therapeutic Interventions."  The editors are two clinical psychologists, Virginia Brabender and April Fallon, and they have gathered together a variety of mental health professionals who contributed chapters.The chapters cover important issues, including parent-child attachment issues, diversity needs, children with special needs, and therapy suggestions.  The book is research-based, so the authors cite research evidence throughout the text.  In addition, they often use case studies to illustrate important points.  The book plays well to its intended audience by ending chapters with an extremely useful set of "Practical Points" that summarize the main take-away points.  The book primarily relies on attachment and emotion theory, which makes sense given the population it targets.  However, I would have liked a bit more incorporation of empirically supported treatments; for example, a discussion of behavioral techniques for child acting out problems could be useful for many adoptive parents.

I love the classic board games I played as a kid, such as Sorry.  It's the kind of game that you can play at any age and enjoy (it's recommended for ages 6 years and up).  For the uninitiated, Sorry is a board game where the goal is to move colored plastic pieces from the start to your home base.  It's much like the game Trouble, except instead of rolling dice, you pick a card to determine the move.  You can also 'slide' by landing at the beginning of the slide -- which displaces any pieces on the slide pad.  It's always fun to send players back to the start!  Sorry is a fun, simple game.The classic version uses the old graphics and so forth from the original version.  The rules handout includes a number of variations, including a quick version that uses 3 instead of 4 pieces per player, partnership Sorry, and an advanced version for adults that involves scoring and keeping track of points.

The Puzzle Sort & Go is a clever accessory for puzzle fans of all types.  The kit includes stackable sorting trays to hold your puzzle pieces, which works for puzzles of up to 1000 pieces.  You can sort pieces by color, pattern, or type (e.g., edges) to assist in putting together your puzzle.  Before I had these trays, I used to end up with a bunch of unsightly piles of puzzle pieces that often got scattered and were difficult to sort through.Another major use of the trays is for easy cleanup.  Like most people, I don't have enough space in my home to have a table dedicated to puzzles, so I often need to put away a puzzle when I have company or when I do housecleaning.  The trays stack and fit into the box, allowing you to store a puzzle whenever you need to do so.  You can even transport your puzzle to another site via the box.  I also like using the trays to make sure that I don't accidentally push piles of puzzle pieces off the table and end up with a mess, which happens to me more often than I care to admit.  This product would make a perfect gift for puzzle lovers of all ages.

California Fidelity Insurance, Kinsey's prior employer, has just paid out $500,000 on a death claim when the "dead" man (Wendell Jaffe) is spotted in Mexico.  Kinsey is hired to find him, but in the process she comes across some unexpected information about her past as well.  "J Is for Judgement" is a typical entry in the Alphabet series.  As usual, Kinsey is able to ingratiate herself into the lives of the people she's investigating, which includes Wendell's ex-wife, sons, former business partner, and girlfriend.  I love the series, but I do sometimes find it hard to believe how often Kinsey is taken in as a confidante, even when it might not be in the person's best interest.  She must be extremely empathetic and convincing.The mystery here is below average for the series.  There's a lack of a solid resolution, and Kinsey often does some rather stupid things (there were a dozen times when I thought that she should call the police).  What makes this book interesting are the developments in Kinsey's life.  These issues are contrasted by Grafton to the relationship between Kinsey's neighbor (Henry) and his annoying brother.  I love how Grafton is able to so subtly and naturally move the narrative of Kinsey's life slowly forward without ever interfering with the mystery in each book.  So despite the somewhat weak, slow-moving case, "J Is for Judgement" ended up being a fun read for me.Note: This review is for the Kindle version.  The transfer to Kindle is good, with no noticeable errors or formatting problems.  A table of contents with links to chapters is included.

I'm a huge fan of the Hard Case Crime series; unfortunately, "Night Walker" is the weakest of the dozen entries I've read so far.  The book starts off extremely well, with the protagonist, David Young, being picked up by a good samaritan.  Young is a sailor on his way to another stint in the service.  Of course, things quickly go horribly wrong, and Young finds himself in the hospital covered in bandages.  The plot up to that point is rather exciting, and the reader has no idea where it's all going.  However, it ends up going nowhere - very slowly.Author Donald Hamilton is best known for his spy books and the Matt Helm series, and he first published this book in 1954.  Although the book does start as a crime noir, it veers off toward an uncomfortable mix of spy novel and action without ever really finding its tone.  Hamilton tries to make Young more interesting by giving him PTSD (or its 1950s equivalent), but the character still ends up being fairly generic.  Even the book cover, which are usually fantastic in this series, is pretty boring.
