For fans of Hard Case Crime, "Night Walker" is worth the read, especially considering how short it is (I read it in about six sittings, which is unusual for me); it's not bad but it doesn't live up to the quality of this fine series.Note: This review is for the Kindle version.  The transfer to Kindle is good, with no noticeable errors or problems.  It includes a Table of Contents with links to each chapter.

I'm a big fan of Novak Djokovic, so I purchased "Serve to Win" to learn more about his life.  In that respect, the book is a bit of a let-down, given that it is not a traditional sports autobiography and focuses more on his recent diet changes and resulting tennis success.  Novak does share some stories about his life, including a few passages about growing up in war-torn Serbia.  At night, his family would hide in a bomb shelter, and in the day, he would practice tennis.  He's lead an extraordinary life, which is probably part of the reason that he is so popular in Serbia today.However, the book spends most of its time discuss his health issues over the years, particularly the various breathing and fitness concerns that plagued his early career.  These problems climaxed during a long five-set match at the Australian Open in 2010 against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.  Toward the end of that match, Djokovic crashed - he ran out of energy and lost the final two sets quickly.  He talks about how frustrating it was to train so much and still have so little gas left in the tank at the end of long matches.  The match happened to be watched by a Serbian nutritionist, who suggested that Novak be tested for allergies, especially gluten.  Fast forward a year, and Novak is experiencing an incredible winning streak - winning three majors and finishing 2012 as the #1 player.Djokovic's gluten-free diet is explained in detail.  I don't plan on using this diet, but I do appreciate the balanced tone he takes in discussing it.  He doesn't claim that it's for everyone or that it's a miracle diet.  He simply sets forth what it did for him and how he follows it.  Novak even cites research on its effectiveness, while maintaining that he's not a medical expert and so forth.  The book includes a section detailing what Novak eats during a typical day along with recipes; I like that he breaks it down into his four rules for eating, which could be simple for many people to follow.  If one wants to start a gluten-free diet, then this book could be a good initial guide.So how about the tennis fans?  Will they enjoy this book?  I did overall, even though I kept hoping for more behind-the-scenes information.  He mentions matches only in passing and mostly to illustrate his poor conditioning before his diet or his improved fitness after going gluten-free.  Not much dishing here, although he does note his anger when Andy Roddick famously questioned his health issues (Andy recently gave a more explicit version of the story whereby he and Novak almost came to blows in the locker room).  Ultimately, though, Novak has perhaps become too statesmen like, too sporting, to give us an insider's view of his life.  In the meantime, "Serve to Win" will do.

"The Girl with the Long Green Heart" was originally published in 1965 and later reissued by Hard Case Crime in 2005.  The book tells of a long con attempt by John Hayden, a small-time con man who has just served a prison sentence.  He meets up with one of his former partners, Doug Rance, who has a proposition - one big con before John retires.  Although he's hesitant, John decides to go along as he has big dreams of buying a rundown bar outside Boulder, Colorado, and making a success of it.  The long con involves a Canadian land scheme and a New York businessman named Wallace Gunderman.  Of course, there's also a beautiful woman involved - Gunderman's secretary, Evie Stone - who is the titular girl with the long green heart.I enjoy stories of long cons and Block knows this genre so well.  The book is rife with realistic details, although these details may bore some readers.  The plot was a bit easy to figure out early on, but Block's writing always makes the trip fun, even if the destination is a bit predictable.  I particularly appreciate Block talent for descriptions.  Evie, for example, smells "as clean and alive as a newly mown lawn."  Later, John gets a meal in a cheap diner, where the "food was greasy and so were most of the customers."Note: This review is for the Kindle version, which was published by Open Road in 2010 rather than Hard Case Crime (I also have the paperback HCC version).  The electronic version is excellent; I did not find any noticeable errors or formatting problems.  It includes a table of contents with linked chapters as well as a brief autobiography of Block with 10 photos taken from various points in his life.

Like most adults, I've played Yahtzee dozens of times since I was a child.  It's the kind of game that everyone knows, or else they can learn to play quickly.  This version is retro, as it recreates the design of the game from the 1950s (although it's funny to see a huge QR code plastered on the front of the box -- definitely not 1950s!).  The game consists of five components: five standard dice, a Yahtzee cup, a pack of scoring cards, eight bonus chips, and a direction booklet.  Whereas the standard Yahtzee cup is blue plastic, the classic version is cardboard wrapped in paper with a metal bottom.  When you shake the dice, it makes that classic Yahtzee sound (which I kind of like).My only quibble is that the game has so few pieces that they should put a bit more care into making the cup - it's made out of pretty much the same material as a Pringles container.  Also, they only include 20 scoring cards - they could be a bit more generous here.  Each card does have room for six games, but an average player will run out of cards fairly quickly and need to purchase a replacement set.Hasbro recommends the game for ages 8 years and up.  Playing can help a young child learn to count and add, so there is an educational element to the game.  However, it's still a fun game, even for children.

The Big Boss Electric Citrus Juicer is a solid, entry-level juicer.  I have been trying to add more fruits to my diet, and it's nice to have some freshly squeezed juice from time to time.  So this juicer suits my needs very well.  In particular, the juicer is easy to use and clean.  The top of the juicer has a "cone" where you place the citrus fruit -- it's pretty much like the hand-held juicers you can buy at the grocery store.  However, the "cone" rotates to extract the juice.  I appreciate the simple design.  I also love that I can use the bowl as a pitcher, so that saves one dirty dish.  I've used the Big Boss several times, and I have not had any difficulties with it.  It's nothing fancy, but then I have a fancy juicer that I never use because it's too complicated to use and clean.  It gets the job done.

I get frustrated using hand-held pencil sharpeners, as it seems impossible to obtain a sharp point with them.  Not to mention getting hand cramps after trying to sharpen a few pencils in a row.  Whaaaaa.  So I'm loving my new Westcott iPoint Curve Axis Electric Pencil Sharpener (that's quite a mouthful!).The sharpener yields extra sharp pencil points.  Just what I wanted!  Yay!  Emptying the sharpener is a breeze - just remove the plastic holder on the bottom and slide it back onto the sharpener.  I like that it is clear plastic, so it's easy to see if it's getting full.  The best feature of the sharpener is that it's adjustable for different sized pencils; just rotate the dial on the top.  This feature allows the pencil to be inserted in such a manner to maximize the sharpness of the point.  I was able to sharpen three dozen colored pencils in just a few minutes.  They are extra sharp for all my drawing needs!  The sharpener is even sleek looking - everything I could want in an electric pencil sharpener.  I just wish I'd had this when I was still in school.  Thank you Westcott!

If you're looking for inexpensive, basic white binders, then these may be perfect for you.  I like to use three-ring binders to store materials for my various work projects, and these binders work well for that purpose.  They're not fancy, although the front and back covers (as well as the spine) include a clear overlay that allows you to insert a standard piece of paper.  Thus, you can label or decorate your binders in any way you'd like.  The inside covers include vinyl pockets so that you can store un-punched paper or small materials.  The other feature I like is that the three-ring mechanism is not mounted on the inside spine but instead is offset to the right, which allows the notebooks to lay completely flat when open.  These notebooks would be particularly good for college or high school students (e.g., storing class notes or turning in projects).  The one drawback is that the folders are a bit flimsy looking, so I wouldn't use them for certain tasks (e.g., carrying to class every day).  I plan on using them to store work materials, such as handbooks, on my book shelf.

I love label makers, and the DYMO LabelManager is by far the best one I have ever used.  You can use it wirelessly or by plugging the included usb cable into your computer.  Setting up the system was surprisingly easy, and I was able to use it within minutes of unboxing it.  What I love most is that you can use any fonts.  All you need to do is type into the text box what you'd like to print and then select the font.  It's also simple to add pictures or graphics, including clip art or files from your computer.  It can even make barcodes!  You can charge the labelmaker via your computer or the included wall plug.  In addition, refill labels come in a variety of widths, which is a fantastic feature.  This labelmaker really does it all!

I enjoy having a variety of comforters for my bed so that I can change them seasonally and get them cleaned.  So this duvet cover is a terrific addition to my collection.  This beautiful cover is 100% cotton and feels great against the skin.  The ivory color goes well with so many different colors, so it fit well into my existing bedroom colors and matches most sheets fairly well.  It looks really gorgeous and is well worth the price.

America's Test Kitchen is part of the Cook's Illustrated brand, and they write fantastic cookbooks.  They specialize in taking a recipe and testing every possible version of it until it is absolutely perfect.  I was a bit surprised to see them expanding into the "small number of ingredients" cookbook style.  However, I knew that if anyone would get it right, they would.  And indeed they did.  The feature I like the best is a short blurb before each recipe explaining "Why this recipe works."  These mini-tutorials can be applied to your everyday cooking skills.  For example, they explain that when frying eggs, you should cover the pan, which helps the eggs set.Each recipes cover the gamut from appetizers, soups, pastas, casseroles, and dessert.  They are perfect for simple yet tasty weekday meals.  Recipes do sometimes rely on processed or convenience foods, such as canned beans or V-8 juice, so many of these dishes would not be very good for people on low sodium diets.  Unfortunately, they do not offer any nutritional information for recipes.  However, even for people watching their diets, many of these recipes would be appropriate, as they contain just a few, fresh ingredients.  Full-color pictures of completed dishes are included for approximately 1/3 of the recipes.  In addition, color pictures accompany many of the "Test Kitchen Tips" that are scattered throughout the book (e.g., pitting olives, washing leeks, making a foil packet).  As with their other cookbooks, "6-Ingredient Solution" is packed with great ideas for the home cook.

This book is a well-researched and informative look at an important topic: child anxiety disorders.  Children often experience anxiety, and parents are sometimes confused about how to react.  In particular, they may over-react by being protective, or they may fail to see the severity of the problem.  Thus, I was pleased to see that this book includes detailed information about treatment as well as helpful pointers for involving caregivers.  After all, children with anxiety often have anxious parents.The sections on family accommodation and boundaries are particularly useful.  As a mental health professional, I've seen time and time again the lengths to which families will try to accommodate their child's anxiety, which can lead to secondary problems.  The parents of children with anxiety often fear that they caused the problem, so this section can help them to see that, although they did not cause it, they need to be part of the solution.  I could definitely imagine having parents read this section to help them understand the situation better and their role.The treatment outlined in this book is based on solid, empirically-based interventions for child anxiety - mostly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and related approaches.  References are included throughout, documenting the efficacy of the treatment.  Of course, there are many books that describe CBT for child anxiety; what sets this one apart is the focus on caregivers.  For example, the authors sensitively address the role that parent anxiety may play in the treatment, which I found particularly useful.  Brief case studies are sprinkled throughout the text, allowing the reader to see how the treatments work.I should note that, although this book is subtitled "A guide for caregivers," it is written for mental health professionals working with caregivers of anxious children.  I think that this book may not be easily digested by parents without any background in psychology or mental health.  For example, the section on 'emotion regulation' begins with this sentence: Self-regulation describes the system by which an individual returns to a state of equilibrium after an event has caused a disruption in some element of functioning.  I would not give this book to parents and expect them to be able to read it easily and make the suggested changes; however, I would use it to guide the treatment I do with families.  Maybe assigning sections for 'bibliotherapy' may be possible with some parents.  Indeed, it contains many useful analogies that I will be using in the future with parents.

Harry Healy is a small-time crook who has just made bail.  He's broke, so he reluctantly agrees to be a drug courier for a Miami Beach Dutch businessman (the titular uncle).  Things immediately go wrong, of course, and he finds himself being framed for a crime.  The book details his efforts to elude police, the goings-on of various low-life criminals who framed him, and the police working on the case.Peter Pavia's "Dutch Uncle" is entry #12 in the Hard Case Crime series; it was written expressly for the series (as opposed to the re-releases from genre masters that the series also includes) and published in 2005.  It's the tenth I have read, and so far, I'd have to say that it's the weakest.  The major problem is that it's an overly busy book, with a multitude of characters who come and go and really don't add much to the story.  The main character is particularly vague and bland, which is a shame given how important a strong central character is to this sort of crime book.  The writing is ok, but not as colorful as I expect from the series.  The Hard Case Crime books are always fun to read, and I did find this one somewhat enjoyable; however, there simply are far better entries in the series.Note: This review is for the Kindle version.  The transfer to e-book has been done with care, and I found no obvious errors.  It includes a linked table of contents.

I use my Westcott Paper Trimmer mostly for cutting down sheets of paper for use in my day planner.  This type of job doesn't require that the paper be completely even, so this trimmer is perfect for my needs.  The scoring feature is nice and allows you to check before making a cut, and the titanium cutting blade is sharp enough for most household needs.  I tried cutting a manila folder in half, and it worked fine.  I also like the swing out ruler, which allows one to measure paper before cutting.I do have two problems with the trimmer.  First, the metal plates on the cutting surface and ruler have obviously been glued to the plastic base, and the glue is visible around the edges.  It makes the trimmer look cheap and somewhat dirty looking (I keep thinking that it needs to be cleaned).  Second, and more importantly, the trimming blade is on the outside edge of the trimmer handle, leaving it exposed when lifting the paper holder.  I already almost cut myself (my finger came into contact with the blade).  I have another Westcott cutter, and the blade is in the middle of the trimmer handle, so it is not exposed unless you put your finger in the gap in the paper holder.  Overall, though, for the price, I think this trimmer is a good product.

This sampler pack of Numi Organic Savory Tea includes 6 different flavors: tomato mint, spinach chive, fennel spice, carrot curry, broccoli cilantro, and beet cabbage.  Having six different flavors was fantastic, and I enjoyed sampling them.  Some of them are quite tasty, and given their savory nature, they do taste a bit like vegetable broth.  I found them a pleasant change from regular tea, to which I normally add some sweetener.  They also smell quite nice.  I did find, though, that they need to be piping hot.  As they cool, the teas tend to become quite bland, and I needed to reheat them because they tasted odd when cold.  These are great for mid-day pick-me-ups or late at night when you feel a bit hungry and need something to tide you over until bedtime.

I love glazed carrots, or I should say that I like the 'idea' of glazed carrots.  Too often, they're like Pictsweet Glazed Medallions - sickly sweet and mushy with no hint of that buttery taste that makes glazed carrots so delicious.  These carrots really aren't glazed. "Glazing" implies that they have been sauteed and browned in butter and brown sugar.  These carrots are just (overly) cooked carrots in a super sweet brown sugar sauce.  Maybe I'm expecting a bit much from frozen carrots, and as a singleton, I do appreciate the single serving size (which is actually two servings).  However, the off-putting taste of the glaze prevents me from buying these carrots again.

I remember these kinds of multi-colored pens from when I was a kid in the 1980s.  I was excited back then to get a Big 4-colored pen, but I recall that it broke pretty quickly.  Perhaps this kind of pen never went away, but I was surprised to see that they seemingly have become quite popular again, especially with people using Filofaxes.  I hesitated to buy one until I saw that Paper Mate now makes an InkJoy version.  I've had some issues with other InkJoy pens - several of mine have leaked or had blobs of ink collect at the tip.  However, given that InkJoy is one of Paper Mates higher end pens, I hoped that the new Quatro would have solved some of these issues.  So far, so good - no leaking or ink blobs.The pen is fairly attractive, with a wide white barrel and a hard rubber gray grip; I do wish that the grip was a bit more comfortable, but then I don't plan on using this pen for large writing jobs.  The pen seems sturdier than the ones I had back in the 1980s, although the click mechanism feels somewhat flimsy.  The inks are the typical Paper Mate shades of black, dark blue, red, and green.  I like Paper Mate because their ink tends to be dark, and the pens write smoothly.  I edit and grade many papers, so I enjoy having the different colored inks in the same pen and being able to change easily.  It's a fun pen that could be useful to many writers and doodlers.

These Russell+Hazel pockets are designed for the mini binders - I use the kind that are designed to hold 5 1/2 x 8 1/2 inch paper.  I love to use the smaller binders because they are so easy to handle and store, so I organize my various work and home projects in a series of them.  Because I use so many of them, I'm always looking for new inserts to use in them, and these attractive pockets are a nice addition to my collection.  Each pocket is 6 5/8 x 8 3/8 inches, so they are a bit wider than most accessories I use in mini binders.  Because they are wider, they can also be used as dividers.  Each of the pockets has a different colored stripe on the edge, so they actually work quite well as dividers.  I also appreciate that they have pockets on both sides, which I think all pockets should.I have a few minor issues with these pockets. First, I was surprised that even though the pockets are made of paper (nice card stock), they are not reinforced at the holes.  Second, the pockets are rather shallow - a bit over 3 1/2nches deep - so I hesitate to put taller items into them.  Third, they are very pricey for paper pockets.  I'm glad I purchased Russell+Hazel Mini Paper Pockets as they look great in my mini binders, but at this cost, I wouldn't buy more of them.

"Promised Land" stars Matt Damon and Frances McDormand as employees of an energy company; the two work as a team going into small farming communities and buying land in order to drill for natural gas - or fracking.  Damon plays Steve Butler.  He's good at his job because he grew up in a similar small town and can relate to the people he meets.  As the film starts, Steve has just been promoted, and he's sent to another (unnamed) community in rural Pennsylvania expecting to wrap up sales in a few days.  However, he's underestimated this particular hamlet, and he finds himself battling the townspeople, an environmentalist (John Krasinski), and ultimately himself.The movie has a terrific pedigree - an Oscar-nominated director (Gus Van Sant), a story by an acclaimed hipster writer (Dave Eggers), and an Oscar-winning co-author (Damon writing along with Krasinski). Plus, the always amazing McDormand is along for the ride.  And the movie almost lives up to all of that, although it fell just short for me, with an ending that didn't match the movie's overall tone.  Nevertheless, there's much to like about "Promised Land."  Damon and McDormand make a fantastic and fully believable team, who find themselves in realistic yet funny situations as they try to woo the town.  The depictions of life in a rural area and the local people are pretty much spot on also.  Too often Hollywood movies populate small towns with the type of quirky, eccentric townspeople better suited for episodes of "Green Acres."Some audiences are going to take issue with "Promised Land" due to its somewhat dewy liberal politics, although I suspect that environmentalists may argue that it doesn't go far enough.  Therein lies it's charm for me - the movie does have an agenda, but it's unspooled in a (mostly) subtle manner, with compassionate and likeable characters on both sides of the green divide.  I found myself entertained more often than lectured to, which is the effect that a good 'issues' movie should have on its audience.

As several other reviewers have noted, the GTMax Repid Car Charger is rather cheap looking and not very attractive.  However, it gets the job done.  I have used it regularly on road trips to charge my Kindle 2 and Kindle Fire.  It also works for my Blackberry.  The adapter plugs into the car cigarette lighter, and charges your product.  I was concerned that it might break or fall apart easily, but after more than 2 years of use, it's still in perfect shape.  The GTMax is a great buy and a must-have for Kindle fans who don't want to be stranded with an uncharged ereader.

This bird flash card set is absolutely adorable! It's made in Japan by Midori, the renowned paper company, and is part of their line of animal mini flash card sets. The cards are white and cut into bird shapes. The set is very small (about 2 inches long and a bit more than one inch tall at its highest point) - the picture with a penny next to it is accurate.If you plan on using the bird flash cards as an educational tool, then you need to write small or be brief due to the limited space. The odd shape of the cards also presents a challenge. The paper is quite thin. The pack contains 81 cards; when I received it, I estimated by the size of the bird that it was only 30 pages, but it does actually have 81. (Why 81? Maybe to allow multiplication tables up to 9?) This thinness makes it somewhat hard to turn the pages. In addition, when I wrote on it, although my ink didn't bleed through, it did often show through to the other side of the card. So I wouldn't recommend using the flashcard with information on both sides unless you write very lightly.However, as one would expect from Midori the paper is high quality; they really specialize in excellent thin paper. The cards are somewhat slick and glossy, making them seem fairly durable if used carefully - the pages don't rip off of the key ring very easily. Despite being glossy, the paper actually takes ink quite well, and I have been able to write on the cards easily with a variety of pens (rollerball, fountain, ballpoint, felt-tip).I really love this flash card set, and I have purchased several others in the animal line. I think these flash cards may be useful for teenagers or college students, but because of their size and thinness, I would not recommend them for younger children. I personally bought them for decorative purposes (the turtle is the most adorable) just because they're so unbelievably cute.

This package comes with three separate small holders for the Midori Traveler's Notebook system.  One holder is rectangular and the size of a typical business or credit card, and the other two holders are slightly smaller (roughly 2 3/4 inches wide and 2 inches tall).  One is intended to go on the inside cover, as it opens on the right, and the other is intended to go on the back cover, as it opens on the left.  These holders are the perfect size for holding stamps or small stickers.  The pouches stick extremely well onto either the paper covers of Midori notebook refills or to the leather cover itself.  They fit into either the regular size or the Passport size Midoris (I have the Passport size).  It's difficult, though, putting one on the inside of the back cover for the Passport size, as the elastic band is tied in the middle of the leather cover.  Although these are designed for the Midori, they could be used for any small notebooks, icluding Moleskine, Field Notes, and Rhodia.  The holders are a bit pricey for what you get, but they add a nice personalized touch to the Midori and are well worth it.

I absolutely loved these rubber monkey key identifiers - they were extremely cute, and I received many comments about them.  Unfortunately, they started to fall apart almost immediately.  Within a few days, several of the monkeys had started to lose their features when the coloring rubbed off of them.  A couple of the monkeys split apart within weeks and no longer stayed on the keys.  I did actually have one that lasted several months, although it eventually fell off too.  They were cute but not long enough to justify the purchase.

I purchased a Lamy Safari Fountain Pen last year and have been using it often.  When it ran out of ink, I was concerned, a s a newbie to the fountain pen world, about how complicated it would be to replace the cartridge.  I became even more concerned when I saw reference to "converters" and people online talking about using an eyedropper to fill them.  Apparently, there are numerous ways to refill a Lamy, but the easiest is to buy these refill cartridges, which are called "converters" for reasons unknown to me.  However, it's quite simple.  I just opened up my pen, removed the empty cartridge, and then stuck this product into the barrel of my Lamy.  When I screwed the barrel shut, the cartridge was pierced and ink began to flow.  Hallelujah!  The refills were fantastically priced, with a box of five for just over five dollars.

"Vocal" is the second song released in advance of Pet Shop Boy's new dance CD, "Electric," and it's another winner.  The song is all about being in a club and becoming one with the music - being carried away by the thumping bass, writhing dancers, and the feeling of euphoria.  They really captured the feeling perfectly, and it's one of the best dance songs PSB have released in many years.  Neil's vocals are muted, almost robotic, which adds a melancholy feel to the proceedings.  The lyrics also convey the yearning to feel part of something:  I like the people/ I like the song/ I like the singer/ He's lonely and strange.  This kind of song is what PSB do best - a real club thumper with reflective lyrics that can appeal to outsiders or just make you want to dance.The song was produced by Stuart Price (Madonna, The Killers), and he brings a current club sound to it; indeed, several top dance radio shows played "Vocal" within its first week of release.  I've been a huge PSB fan for years, and I'm constantly amazed by the high quality of their releases.  However, even I never expected that they'd be making such extraordinary music 30 years after "West End Girls."  Bravo to PSB!Note: This review is for the 6:34 album version of "Vocal."  This site often combines reviews of various versions of songs.

This is a beautiful string of pearls that I gave to my girl friend for her birthday.  There was 62 pearls in the strand plus 2 in the earrings.  I did not measure the diameter, but they are a nice size.  The color was good and there were no obvious flaws.She liked them very much and couldn't wait to try them on.  They came boxed well and seem to be worth the price I paid for them.

If you own a grand father clock this is the oil to use for its lubrication.  3 in 1 oil or 10W30 motor oil will not due.  This is a fine quality synthetic oil (as opposed to whale oil)  is well suited for the purpose.Included with the one once bottle is a long tip for reaching deep into the mechanism for those hard to reach gears.  This oil goes far so One ounce should last a very long time.

I was very pleased with the work that Rossi Engraving did for me.I ordered the small 1 X 3 inch engraved plate for the grand father clock I had just constructed.  They did a beautiful job that I was proud to apply to the clock.The plate is a soft brushed gold and the lettering was bold enough to easily see from a few feet away.  The price was quite nominal for the work they did.I received the plaque very quickly and in less than a week's time.  It was well wrapped preventing any damage.When I require additional engraved items I will not hesitate to reorder from Rossi Engraving.

Lots of pin hole leaks from the start.  At first I thought it was because I had stored it in the garage for several seasons, but then after reading other reviews, I realized the plastic is inferior and will leak no matter what you do.  I tried taping it with electrician's tape but that was a fiasco.  It just developed more leaks and eventually more water was coming out the holes than was coming out the end of the hose.However, it does the job of draining water from my basement sump pump to the back of my yard.  It won't last for more than a season or two and then needs to be replaced.  It is very flexible and will go around corners easily.  This larger size will accommodate  a higher volume of water than the inch  tubing.  Overall, it is good and prevents basement flooding which is its primary job.

These flashlights are very handy to have around the house.  The four pack makes it convenient to stash them in the car or around the house.  They are made of black anodized aluminum, not cheaply made plastic lights.  They are fairly bright for their size and have a zooming action for a focused beam.  There is also a blinking mode for whatever.  Each click of the on switch cycles thru the functions.The zooming action was stiff at first and I couldn't figure out how to make it work.  You just have to pull it out  hard.  There is a small strap that can be attached but I found this to be too small and mostly useless.It does not come with any batteries so you'll have to buy some.  I suggest alkaline batteries because they seem to last longer.  Each unit holds three AAA batteries.Overall, I was pleased with these flashlights and I know they'll get some use.  In fact, I used one already.

This is the second Victor J. Stenger book I have read and I must say it's the best of the two. Stenger tackles every aspect of religion and how it relates to science.  He pulls no punches nor does he make apologies for what he says.  He is truly a New Atheist along with the likes of Dawkins, Dennett, Hitchens and Sam HarrisThe folly of faith is that it has no support in science or reality.  Faith depends upon a person's beliefs and an intuition that they are true.  The author says that, "Science flies  us to the moon, religion flies us into buildings".Stenger uses a lot of science in his persuations about religion and God.  Though briefly touching on Evolution, he says most Christians don't believe Evolution is true, but instead think God has guided us on the evolutionary path, which is not what Evolution is all about.Of all the New Atheists, Stenger is the only one who is a physicist.  I found his chapter on Quantum Tunneling extremely interesting.  It is the only book that really explains the theory and it backs my own thoughts on the matter.This book also deals with  Near Death Experiences, or NDEs,  and Reincarnation.  His take on these experiences is that there is insufficient evidence either way to support belief or non-belief and that probably more research needs be done in this area.  He also delves into faith healings and Eastern Mysticism.Overall, this is an important book for anyone who is looking for answers on the issues of God, religion and how they relate to science.  The author is definitely writing from  an atheist's point of view and he uses his scientific education and training to support his views.

Good stuff.  I used this silicone sealant to glue in the glass panels on my grandfather clock I had built.  It was definitely hard to squeeze out of the tube but seems to be bonding well enough to the wood and glass panels.I read that other reviewers had had trouble with the sealant coming out of the other end of the tube.  I squeezed carefully at first, then rolled the end of the tube up when it was partially empty.  This worked and also made the tube easier to manage.Another problem is the tube is primarily a one time use in that it dries at the end of the applicator making it useless after the first use.  I suppose you could clean it with a big nail, but I didn't.  There's not really very much sealant in this tube so I guess you won't be wasting very much of it.

I bought this as a spare blade for my Rockwell circular saw.  It is identical to the original and makes a smooth narrow kerf cut in wood surfaces.Being a thin blade, it is more sensitive to damage or warpage from nails or metal objects encountered when sawing through boards that might contain these items.  So I bought this one as a spare should the kit blade become damaged.

This stuff is very easy to work with and provides a hand rubbed finish with no drips or runs even though generously applied.  I just used a rag and wiped it on, going back and forth with the grain.  It really has a strong odor so I recommend  working outside or in a very well ventilated  work space.  Two or more coats looks the best.I also strongly recommend rubber gloves as it is very difficult (and unhealthy) to get off the hands.I used this stuff on a grand father clock I built and it looks great.  This is the very best furniture varnish I have ever used and I will always keep some on hand.

I have been eating these dried berries for several days now.  They are hard but not excessively so.  Kinda chewy. I either eat them as is right out of the bag or mix them in with blue berries and strawberries in a bowl of cottage cheese.They have a distinctive flavor which takes some getting used to but they are extremely good for your health.  I have noticed no differences yet, but it's been a very short time and I am in very good health.  I like them and would buy again..

This veneer is a very thin laminant.  It is a much lighter color than depicted.  It is smooth but unfinished. It is easy to cut with a scissors or utility knife.  If it gets wet, it will curl up like a leaf, so wood glue will cause it to bubble and warp.It takes a stain evenly and well.  I applied a varnish over that with good results .  I used it for the case back of a grand father clock I built and it matched the other oak wood  perfectly.

The cherry stain is not exactly the color I was looking for, it seems too orange and not dark enough.  It does go on easily with a brush and can be easily wiped off for a smooth appearance.  I used three coats for the best effect on a grandfather clock I built.  One quart was enough for the entire project.I wish there had been a stain chart available so that I could have made a better choice.  But it's a good quality stain.

Love these prunes.  Good source of energy.  They keep you regular and provide a good source of potassium.  Package stays sealed so they don't dry out like little rocks.  Prunes are high in antioxidants and are more healthy to eat than a candy bar.In a 12 pack, the price is low and more affordable for me to buy.  They have no harmful  preservatives or other foreign chemicals so must be refrigerated after opening..

I had previously purchased the Rockwell Versacut circular saw but it had its drawbacks.  I needed to cut some interior grooves  for retaining the glass panels in the grandfather clock I was buildings.  The Versacut's plunge insertion would not easily give me the right depth, so I bought the TK3441K circular saw.  It worked great, making easy and smooth cuts exactly where I wanted them.  The narrow kerf was appreciated.The one thing I did not like about this saw is the grip.  It's uncomfortable to grip and makes controlling the path of the blade more difficult.  I am left handed so using that hand, it's hard to see where the blade is going because it's positioned on the left side of the machine.  This might not be the case for right handed individuals, however, I did not have these problems with any of my Skill saws.Being small and compact, this saw will fit into tighter places than a full size saw.  Unlike the Versacut, this saw will cut all the way through a 2X4 on one pass.  The blade is more delicate than the Skill saw blades, so hitting a nail would be disastrous  for it.  Due to its small, rather delicate blade, this saw is better suited for hobbies or cabinetry work.  I would not want to build a garage with it.Overall it's a handy tool to have that has unique uses.  I just wish it had a better grip.

I have had trouble with my hands cracking, especially the tips of my thumbs, almost always  in the winter when it's cold.  It is a very painful condition. I have used other products in the past.  They worked somewhat but Dermasil Dry Skin Treatment has worked the best.  It heals my skin in just a couple of days.This lotion is thicker than most lotions and just a little bit goes a long ways.  I put it on at night and when I wake up in the morning I can see the healing that has taken place.  This is good stuff.

Olive leaf is an ancient remedy for many disorders.  It has been used for thousands of years in the Old World.  It is useful as an antibacterial, antifungal and antiviral.  It can also be used to control high blood pressure.Nature's Way olive leaf contains 20% oleuropeins which is a very high quantity of active ingredient thought to be causing the benefits.  It is very useful for controlling gut bacteria responsible for yeast infections and other bacteria and viruses in the gut that can cause autoimmune disorders.  For this purpose, olive leaf can be alternated with oil of oregano, which is phenomenal  for that purpose.I depend upon Nature's way products to provide quality supplements with the purest ingredients.  So far, they have not let me down.

I guess we all know the story of how Columbus discovered America, however, there have been very few films depicting the journey or the man himself, who to most of us is a mystery.There have been dozens of movies made about the Civil War, the Revolutionary War and other facets of American history, but none about its  actual discovery.  The land, of course, was known to the Vikings and perhaps the Chinese and other groups prior to 1492 but was still unknown to most of Europe.In thin 1992 film, the 500 anniversary of the voyage, Gerard Depardieu portrays the 39 year old Christopher Columbus.  The story of how a common ordinary man has the ambition and the opportunity to discover new lands rumored to exist to the west of the Atlantic ocean.Although Columbus made three actual voyages to the Americas, only the first two are detailed in the film.An interesting side note is the Inquisition is depicted in frightening detail as some of the supposed heretics are burned at the stake in the public square for all to see.I enjoyed the movie but felt it was a bit lengthy and dragged out.  Sigourney  Weaver's portrayal of queen Isabella was a bright spot in the film.  And I'm not sure that Columbus' seemingly benevolent  treatment of the native Americans is historically accurate.  Otherwise, it's a great and interesting film.

This is a rather beautiful coffee table book containing many very interesting and informative maps.  There are many maps I have not seen before.  One of the more interesting maps is the 1744 Great Lakes map by the Jesuit  explorer, Jacques Bellin.  It is especially interesting to me, being from this area,  by the fact there are no cities or towns, just rivers, lakes and Indian lands.  Big changes in just a short amount of time.There are many other interesting maps, for instance, the 1585 map of Virginia by John White.  The colonies at Roanoke predates the Puritans arrival at Plymouth Rock by decades.There is also plenty of text explaining details of the maps, but mainly the maps speak for themselves.  I enjoyed perusing its pages.  The author attempts an intellectual approach to exploring.  And how the explorers and their patrons understood their expanding world and their place in  it.  Many of these ancient maps were highly inaccurate by our current standards, yet it was the world as they knew it.

In today's world of fast food and highly processed foods, vitamin content is lacking.  Kirkland adult 50+ vitamins provide what our foods are lacking,These vitamins have enough essential vitamins and minerals to fill the gaps and keep us healthy.  They are small enough not to gag on them, while providing the good nutrition we need.I believe they are superior to the One a Day brand.

I have used this filler on several projects.  It fills holes beautifully.  Sometimes it's difficult to get out of the tube but I left it in the garage over the winter and you're not supposed to let it freeze.  So maybe this was the problem.You can stain it, however, it will not take a stain coloring in precisely the same shade.  You can see where the patch was made.  It dries fast and can be sanded almost right away.  Overall, I am happy with this product and have ordered another tube.

This is a beautiful  10 X 12 coffee table book.  It is a DK book which are noted for their stunning photographs.  Although the book has a dust jacket, the cover of the book is identical to the jacket and not a plain color as is the case with many other books in this class.The maps themselves are both informative and beautiful.  Many of them were created for nobility, the clergy and the wealthy upper class rather than for seamen or merchant travelers who would put them to good and practical use.  Thus, many of them are more art than science.The maps begin with classical period maps from the forth century to the seventh century BCE.  They saw the world, or parts of it, quite differently than we see it today.  The Ptolemy world map is one such.  Some, like the Babylonian World map are made of clay and are difficult  to decipher.Maps from many countries of origin in both the Western and Eastern worlds have been included.  I especially liked the Mercator world map of 1569.  I would like to have a full size copy of it for my wall.  The original is four feet by almost seven feet in length.  In America, nothing west of the Great Lakes is noted.In addition to maps of the land masses there are maps of the sea floor and even a map of the lunar surface.This is a marvelous book that one can spend hours looking over.  There is some explanatory text but mostly the maps speak for themselves.  Since man first learned how to make graphic marks on rock 40,000 years ago, humans have created maps as a way of conceptualizing themselves in relation to their enviornment.  So maps are as much about our existence as they are about the orientation of lands.Anyone who loves and enjoys maps would be enthralled  with this beautiful volume of 256 pages.

Although bromelain is a digestive aid, I have been using it for its anti-inflammatory properties.  I'm old and my joints ache with arthritis.I take between 4 and 6 daily and it helps with inflammation and pain.  If I skip a few days, I can really feel the difference.  As it's a natural product made from the stalk of pineapples, it's safer to take than prescription or OTC synthetic drugs.I have had good effects from this brand.

This is good strong braided wire suitable for hanging large pictures or paintings.  I used it on some paintings weighing about ten pounds.  No problems.  I was able to easily wrap this wire around the supporting screw eyes and it held firmly in place.  I did not test the tensile strength but I think it could hold at least three times this weight without breaking.You will need wire cutters or small pliers with wire cutting capability, like electricians pliers to cut the lengths needed.If you are going to use this heavy gauge wire to hang items up, I would also suggest you invest in some heavy duty wall hangers, preferably ones that use two nails.  Otherwise, it might all come crashing down.I'm glad I bought this wire for security purposes and using it is much better than string or cheap dollar store wire.  I would buy again.

The Big Bang by Simon Sing is a guide to explaining why cosmologists believe that the Big Bang is an accurate description of the origin  and evolution of the universe.  It tells the story of the brilliant and eccentric scientists who fought against established ideas of an eternal and unchanging static universe.From the early Greek cosmologists like Anaximander to recent satellite measurements taken from deep space, the book is full of anecdotes and personal histories.  The author tells of mankind's centuries long attempt to understand how the universe came to be some 14 billion years ago.  This is an easy to understand book that anyone can read and enjoy.I detracted one star because the author did not provide any thought as to what the universe was like prior to the Big Bang or any speculation as to  what might have occurred, even though there has been research and investigation  in this area.

This is an excellent book about atheism.  The author, a professor of philosophy at California State University-Sacramento specializes in atheism.His logic is impeccable.  He addresses the reasons why we believe in Jesus and God and then shatters them like broken glass on the floor.The reason why most Christians believe comes from the pages of the Judeo-Christian Bible.  It is a collection of stories and verse assembled by the early Christians in the first centuries after Christ.  Before the Bible or any of its books were written down, stories  were passed along by word of mouth for decades.  Human tendencies exaggerated , changed, embellished and added to these stories before they were ever written down.  Add to that, the gospels we have are not the originals.  They are copies of copies of copies of the originals  that have been changed since being first written.  And of the many gospels or books written about Christ, only a few were actually chosen to be canonized into the Bible.  Even after that there were changes made until the final result was a book quite unlike the original story.If there had been any information contrary to the view that Jesus was God, it would have long ago been scrubbed from Christian doctrine and the Bible.  The Bible that we now know today has been coalesced over the centuries through a process that deliberately tried to minimize contradictions that did not fit with core Christian doctrines.McCormick states that Iron Age people of the Bible would have seen the world full of mysterious forces, magical events and spiritual  entities; stories about supernatural happenings would have been common for them.  The possibility that someone who could come back from the dead  would have seemed like common sense to them.  Basically, they were an uneducated, illiterate lot who believed in magic and the supernatural.Paul's first Christians were the Romans.  The Romans believed in a whole pantheon of gods.  They were expected to believe in all of them.  To accept one more, the Christian God was no big deal.  They just added him on.  The Romans thought that these gods controlled the weather and natural forces on the Earth.  To disrespect a god, any god, would invoke their wrath.McCormick says, what if there was never an empty tomb at all?  What if Jesus was buried and remained there in the tomb for two thousand years?  (McCormick does not mention it in the book but the Talpiot tomb discovered in 1990 in Israel is thought to be the Jesus family tomb ).Next, the author tackles miracles.  He says that if God has the goal to proving his existence through miracles, he would need to make them evident to a great many well educated skeptical people who do not already believe, instead of the superstitious illiterate followers who already do believe.  To those people from the Iron Age, a toaster or a flush toilet  would have seemed a "miracle".The author says religious people often use circular reasoning to support their faith.Believer:  I believe that God is real.Critic:  But why would you believe this?Believer:  Because the Bible says he is.Critic:  Why believe what the Bible says?Believer:  Because God wrote it.An atheist is just somebody who feels about Yahweh the way any decent Christian feels about Thor or Baal or the Golden Calf.  But the believer says that those gods aren't real, that only his god is real although he doesn't have a single shred of proof to back up his supposition.McCormick says that faith in one religion is as good as faith in another.  It has to be because faith is believing despite the evidence.  The believer can't have it both ways.  A number of studies have shown that people will go on believing something even after their reasons have been shown to be faulty.And finally the author says that some believers aren't actually believers. they are faking it due to social pressures.  They go to church, sing the songs and hymns and say the prayers, yet don't believe in a single word of it.  This even goes for some of the preachers.  In Dennetts study, many in the clergy no longer believe.  They, after really reading the Bible cannot rationalize it as being true, yet they still need work so they play act or pretend to their congregations.  And there are probably many more to whom the study has not reached.  Bart Erhman, who provided much of the information in this book, is one such biblical scholar.I enjoyed reading this book.  There is plenty here for the theist to think about and some interesting ideas for the atheist as well.

Lots of fine old paintings by the European masters.  A great value considering I only paid one cent for the volume.It begins with Titan, Bruegel, Rubens, Rembrandt and Goya.  Then the Impressionists, Pissarro, Manet, Whistler, Degas, Cezanne, Monet, Renoir, Gaugan, Van Gogh and Lautrec are covered.Several paintings of each artist are discussed as well as some notes about the artist, and his painting methods.  A timeline chart of each artist's life follows each artist throughout his career and life.This is a very thick, heavy volume containing over 700 pages.  The lithographs depicting the artist's work are excellent.  The details in the paintings are enlarged for finer inspection and the paintings are NOT  spread across the spine of the book spoiling the image, as has been done in other works of this nature.This is an excellent art book, however, many of the masters, think da Vinci, have been omitted.

These are very sturdy hangers, much better than the ordinary single nail hangers I had been using.I have several very large and heavy pictures which I felt deserved a stronger anchor point than ordinary hangers provide.  I did not want them to come crashing to the floor so I bought these double anchor point hangers.  The backs are padded so they won't mar the paint or wall.  The nails provided are adequate for wood or plaster board.  The metal itself is much thicker too.  The nails are driven in at exact angles for greatest strength.I would buy more of these if needed for security and peace of mind they will hold up much heavier stuff without failure.

These canvasses are excellent.  They come individually wrapped in plastic and are very well made.  The canvas has been pulled taunt and well stapled into place.  There are center struts for added strength and wooden corner shims to drive in for additional stretch.  The corners are well formed.  I could not have done a better job stretching it myself.I have not yet painted on them but the fabric weave is fine and smooth.  The surface has been precoated with gesso.  I will buy these canvasses again.

I  bought this for my wife who suffers from dementia and is in a home for her disabilities.  She has been taking it for about a month and she now says it helps with her memory and thought processes.  I will continue to supply her with this product and see what happens.She takes a dosage according to the label directions.  I will update if her condition continues to improve.

This is a shorter version of the hard cover edition of What Great Paintings Say.  It contains only 200 pages, as opposed to 500 pages of the later.It begins not with a painting, but a tapestry or embroidered cloth dating to 1066 when the Normans invaded England.  The artisan is unknown.  It depicts  battle scenes of the Norman king, William the Conqueror's victory over king Harold at the battle of Hastings.  The tapestry is over 70 meters long.The rest of the book contains mostly European paintings by the masters thru 1938.  Many of the artists were unknown to me as were their works.The text gives an explanation of both artist and the work presented, giving details of the artists life and what is known about the paintings and of the era in which they were created.Several insets of each painting are enlarged so that the viewer can observe particular details of the works.Not all of the most famous masters are represented in this volume.  For instance, Leonardo da Vinci has been completely omitted.While this is a fine volume of art, I would pass on it and buy the much longer expanded hard cover edition of the book.  Many, though not all, of the works are included in the expanded edition.One very irritating thing about this book is that the works are spread across the spine of the book, thereby making part of the paintings hidden within it and difficult to see.

This author believes that many health problems could be caused by a fungus/yeast infection in the digestive track.  These infections can cause:1. Headaches.2. Depression.3. Cancer.4. AIDS.5. Other immune related disorders.6. Skin rashes.7. Low sex drive.8. Food allergies.9. Joint and muscle pain.10.Menstrual irregularities.11.Digestive problems.The Body Ecology diet will show you how to restore and maintain the inner ecology your body needs to function properly and eliminate or control the symptoms.  The author tells how to cleanse the system of these parasites and infections and restore your system's harmony.  There are many great recipes.This is the 2002 edition.  There are newer editions that contain improvements on these methods.  Thus I took off one star for being out of date.

Coconut oil has amazing properties I'm just finding out about.  Not only is coconut oil a healthy food, it also has many health benefits as well.  If taken on a regular basis, the oil has been found to:1. Promote weight loss.2. Help protect against heart disease, cancer, diabetes, arthritis, and many other degenerative diseases.3. Prevent premature aging of the skin.4. Strengthen the immune system.5. Improve digestion.One of the things coconut oil does is promote good oral health.  In primitive societies where modern fast foods are not yet available, the natives have very healthy dentition, few cavities and no gingivitis even though they do not brush  or floss their teeth.  The oil destroys the harmful bacteria that causes the problem.This book explains the health benefits of coconut oil and how it is much more healthy than the other saturated oils.

I have read quite a few of the Edgar Cayce books written by other people.  He was quite an amazing person, not so much in his waking condition, but while in a self induced trance state during which he was able to cure many people of difficult conditions.  Many wealthy and important men sought his advice.  His sessions were free and he never charged money.Apparently, everyone has the ability to see an aura but some of us are more gifted and seeing them comes naturally.This book, however, was written by himself and explains auras or the colors surrounding both human and animal bodies.  The colors he explains can detect both the condition of the body and the type of person he or she is.  This was the last thing he wrote and it encompasses a lifetime of experience  seeing and interpreting auras.The book is very brief, and is more of a pamphlet, containing barely 20 pages.  But there is a lot of information therein.  If you want to know something about auras, this book will tell you.

In this brief book, the author Richard Carrier gives us his reasons why he is not a Christian and does not believe in God.He says, "If God wants something from me, he would tell me."  But God does doesn't say or do anything.  And if God wants man to know something, he would tell everyone; Christians, Muslims, Hindus, everyone and make it perfectly clear in their own languages, but he doesn't.  He says, "the fact that God does nothing is a decisive refutation of the Christian hypothesis."Carrier says "Christianity quite clearly makes extraordinary claims that there is a disembodied, universally present being with magical powers; that this superbeing actually conjured the present universe from nothing; that we have souls that survive the death of our bodies (or that our bodies will be rebuilt in the distant future by this invisible superbeing); and that this being possessed the body of Jesus two thousand years ago, who then preformed many supernatural deeds before miraculously rising from the grave to chat with his friends, and then flew up into outer space."  "Not a single one of these claims has any general proven proposition to support it."Carrier says that those who claim to have "seen" of "spoken" to God are either lying, insane or are only imagining what they saw or heard.  He says even believers admit this because they must in order to explain all the non-Christian visions and divine communications from other cultures.Carrier says that the nature of the universe is not as the early first Christians tried to explain it.  In other words, a geocentric universe with seven planets governed by God's law.  It is instead a universe best explained by the atheist's version of reality in which the Earth and mankind play a small, almost insignificant part.This is a short, easily to read and understand book which gives the many reasons for the falseness of the Christian (and other) faiths.  It will of course not appeal to the faithful, but his reasoning is clear and flawless.

Viva Labs organic extra virgin coconut oil tastes great.  It came in an almost liquid state, so I put in the refrigerator to solidify.Coconut oil has great health benefits.  I intend to use it for "pulling" and for general health.  I haven't put it on cereal or other foods because it tastes great right from the spoon.Probably the biggest benefit I hope to achieve is better oral health, as the oil is able to pull even unnoticed bacteria from inside the teeth and is superior to (but doesn't replace) flossing.

These batteries seem to be good quality batteries.  They have plenty of power for my Maglite.Other reviewers seem to have had a problem with leakage in these batteries.  I have used Duracell batteries that lasted for years without any leakage that would ruin my gear.  I will check my lite often to see if any leakage does occur.  If so, I will revert back to Duracell.Otherwise, there is no problem with Rayovac batteries.  And they were cheaper.

Good grease.  It's slippery and it works well with gear boxes that don't have a gear oil seal.  It should work better in winter than plain heavy grease.It comes in a squirt bottle with nozzle that can be applied to smaller places that are hard to access,

What you will hear on this CD is 60 minutes of peaceful healing sounds.The restless nature of the sea and ocean waves dominate the album.  Mixed in are the baleful sounds of whales and other sea creatures.  The orchestra sweeps each track along with the soft musings of flutes and harp.This is a great album for quiet meditations or a soothing massage.

Despite being some of their best work in 1973, I did not like this album as much as some of their others.  I was hoping for more sounds like appear in Another Brick in the Wall and Comfortably numb.  But there isn't.They were, however, a great group that I loved to listen to.

The New Arthritis Cure provides a seven step plan to reduce or eliminate the pain and swelling of arthritis.  The steps are as follows:Step 1. Oral health.Step 2. Fight systemic infection.Step 3. Anti-arthritis diet.Step 4. Joint rejuvenation.Step 5. Exercise.Step 6. Weight management.Step 7. Calm inflammation.Each of these steps is thoroughly discussed, explaining how to achieve your goal in reducing pain and inflammation.  Also discussed is the arthritis forming diet wherein certain foods actually cause inflammation and pain.  Foods like processed meats, frozen dinners and alcohol, the typical American diet (SAD) cause inflammation and are to be avoided.The main ingredient in Dr. Fife's program is coconut oil.  Coconut oil kills many of the organisms that cause joint paint.  For some people, the author states, that just taking 3 or 4 tablespoons of the oil completely rids them of joint pain.  He encourages us to use a technique called "pulling".  Pulling, or swishing the oil in the mouth for 15-20 minutes a day, rids the mouth and teeth of bacteria and infection thought to be a source for the  arthritis pain.The book is an interesting and easy read.  It can be read in about an hour's time.  There is, however, much information about good health and there is every reason to believe that following the instructions and advice  contained in the book, will lead to a significant reduction or elimination of arthritis pain.Coconut oil is safe, easy to use, does not spoil, does not interfere with other medications and is economical to take.  Why not give it a try.  There's absolutely nothing to lose.I did not see any bad information in the book.  Much of what the author says was already known to me.  As I had already been doing some of the recommendations with some success.  (At age 73, I ran a 5K road race with no knee pain during the race) But I would like to get rid of all the inflammation and pain in my body, so I will begin to use the coconut oil and see if it improves my condition.

This is really a wonderful set of acrylic colors.  It reminds me of the giant box of Crayolas I had as a kid.  The tube size is generous and even though this is a student set, the colors are quite good.The big box contains four trays of paints with 12 colors in each tray.  The tubes are plastic which means the color will easily squish out if you're not careful.  The tubes are NOT sealed with a tin seal, just the plastic cap which might allow some of the lesser used colors to dry out if not used regularly.This is a good set for experimentation with various hues without mixing them yourself.  And included are colors which can't be mixed (like unbleached titanium) with a basic set.Some painting books I have read call for buying the best paint you can afford. But I think the quality is good enough for most, if not all, beginners and at  less than a dollar a tube for all of them, it's really a bargain.

I love this book.  Of the many books I purchased on acrylics and painting in general, this one is the best.  About half the book  is based upon setting up; how acrylics work, brushwork, making supports (the painting surface) and the artists studio.  The second part focuses on the paintings themselves.Sample or demonstrational paintings are colorful landscapes, seascapes, still lifes and animal scenes.  Portraiture has been excluded.  Each painting is broken down into a half dozen or so steps so that the reader can easily see how the painting is created.I especially liked this book because it gave me tips and information (300 tips, techniques and trade secrets)  I had not previously seen in other beginning acrylic painting books.

These are small tubes but the colors are fine.  You will run out of color quickly using them.  The white tube, at least, should be larger or perhaps two of them could be included since this is the color you will use the most.All things considered, it's a good set for making one ore two small experimental paintings and the price is right.  It might be a good addition to an already expanding set of paints.

The Art of Portrait Drawing by Joy Thomas is an excellent book for aspiring artists interested in improving their skills.  The author has been a professional artist for 20 years and who works from a home studio with her husband doing commissioned work for various clients. She states she cannot possibly teach anyone everything they need to know on the subject and recommends they attend classes and lectures to further improve their skills.The author presents various studies done by her that represent the methods used by the old masters.  Included are the canons and divine proportion.  She further uses sketches illustrating the effects of various angles of lighting.Not only does the artist work in pencil, she also uses charcoal and conte crayons giving the work an illusion of color.  She prefers to work from life rather than photographs, as this can reveal the mood of the subject better.  But if photographs are to be used, she prefers taking them herself.This book will be better utilized by more advanced rather than beginning artists, as the more basic skills of drawing and anatomy are not covered.

A really nice figure drawing book.  There are many sketches, all are done in pencil or charcoal.  Nothing in color. Lots of drawing techniques are discussed. Figures include men and women of all ages and ethnicities.  Special attention to facial parts; eyes, ears, noses, etc. are depicted.A very interesting part I found most helpful  was the section on capturing a likeness in a portrait.  It's a good teaching book and I liked it.

Liquitex BASICS acrylic white mixes well with other acrylics  paints, however, it is thin and watery and doesn't cover well by itself.  On the plus side, mixing it with other colors delays drying times and you can work with it for longer on your palate.Considering the price, it's a good deal, as the tube is very large and will last a long time.I haven't tries other Liquitex BASICS  colors, so I don't know if titanium white is the only color with these thin watery properties.

The Stanley TR45K staple gun is a light duty stapler suitable for a wide variety of home projects.  Besides being economical, it comes with staples and in a nice case.  The unit has a smooth chrome finish and has a side window that allows the user to see when the stapler is running out of staples.I have used it for many jobs including stapling books and magazines together, and just lately for stapling canvas to frames.  The stapler sinks staples into wood but if hard wood is used, some downward pressure might be necessary.Stanley has always made good products and this one is no exception.

This is one of the best, if not the very best, books of oil painting techniques I own.  The book is superbly illustrated with numerous  paintings using a wide variety of techniques.  Each technique is explained in detail on how it was achieved.  Painters used brushes, sponges and even fingers to achieve desired results. The paintings were done by a wide assortment of successful artists.Techniques include impasto, knife painting, sgraffito and pointillism.  Subject matter includes still life, landscapes, seascapes and portraits.  Specific topics like clouds and weather are also covered.I learned a lot from reading and studying the material in this volume.  And my work has improved because of it.

I find Monet's paintings, along with those of Renoir, to be the most appealing of all the Impressionists.  His use of color and subject matter are truly awesome.So I bought this book to try to emulate some of his work (they say that imitation is the sincerest  form of flattery).  Because I liked the composition and theme, I chose to do the Bridge at Argenteuil.  I did not use the tracing paper, but instead did my composition freehand with 8B pencil.  I skipped a few steps but tried to duplicate the master's brushstrokes.  Overall, the painting came out good and I framed it.  My clouds came out especially good.The book itself gives a brief description of Monet, how he worked and lived his life.  Then the author lists the tools, paints  and brushes needed to complete each work.  Five individual paintings are used.  This book is probably not for absolute beginners, as many basic techniques are not explained.Monet worked primarily in oil and this book suggests working in acrylic which presents its own problems.  Acrylic paint is beautiful to work with, but it dries very fast so must be done rather quickly.  It also dries darker. Still, there is absolutely no reason why an artist duplicating Monet's work cannot use oil paints for the job.  I chose to use the acrylic paints.Overall, this is a nice, but rather brief book that gives us a look over the shoulder of the master's work.

In this book, Andrew Loomis teaches the basics of drawing the figure in action.  The author explains a series of drawing techniques and how to develop a sketch or ink drawing.  The text is brief and although the format of the book is large, it contains less than 30 pages of actual instruction.Human proportions are illustrated as well as basic shapes of facial features like noses and and eyes.  The figures are mostly female in what one might call glamour poses.The figures are well constructed but the book is too short and incomplete for any serious study.

Product is too expensive for vegans to take needed amounts. All the algal DHA and EPA supplements cost about $100 a month to meet the levels suggested by health studies to keep good brain function and prevent depression. We need 1200 mg EPA and 800mg DHA daily! The amounts the vegan supplements recommend for daily dose are too low to be realistic. (Read Fighting Depression and Improving Cognition with Omega-3 Fatty Acids) I need about 3 bottles a month of this brand, 5 bottles a month of other vegan Omegas. We need to do something about this so vegans can stay healthy and pay a reasonable price for making non-violent dietary choices. I want companies to earn fair profits, but this is never going to work best for most people. Who can afford $100 a month on one essential supplement, on top of other essential supplements and food?

The cut of these reminds me of the original Levi's corduroy jeans from when they only made men's styles, but women wore them too. The fabric is a very narrow corduroy and looks almost like a velvet or cotton suede. I love the colors! I bought the Black Orchid, Green Pine and Dark Choco, they are all very subtle and attractive shades. These are true 5 pocket style, including the slot-pocket over the right front pocket, for something small. There is a lovely detail in the style of double belt loops, so they may be worn with an 1"- 1.5" belt or with a skinny, quarter-inch style belt, this is not bulky or noticeable, it just adds a great, unique feature to these corduroy jeans.The fabric says 98% cotton, 2% elastic, but they are really stretchy. The waist and tops of the back pockets give  2 to 3 inches when I stick a fist in the waistband or pocket. I was a bit worried they might stretch out too much during a day's wear and the back pockets might be too loose for a wallet, but so far they do't become out-of-shape. The stretchy fabric is quite comfortable for sitting, bending and moving about. The fabric feels like cotton corduroy to the touch; it is only when stretching them the elastic "give" can be felt in it's effect. There is no slippery, synthetic feel, I'm surprised to say it might be better than 100% cotton because the "give" makes it so comfortable!.The fit on me (5'6", 137 lbs) is just a bit large in size 12 (they can be pulled down and off without un-buttoning or un-zipping, I wouldn't wear these without a belt), but 10 seems slightly tight in the seat and waistband. The length is long on me, by about 3 inches (I never wear heels, as the pictures show, with this type of pants). After washing in warm and drying completely on high heat, there was no shrinking. The rise is low, but not super low (safe to bend forward with no exposure); they sit above the hips but not up near the natural waist.I'd say these will be most ideal for women 5"9 to 5'11. The inseams on all sizes seems to be 33" (I tried sizes 8, 10 and 12, and measured each of them); women under 5"9", who don't wear heels with jeans, will need to hem these. I bought the odd colors and sizes for under $27.00. Check the different sizes and colors for the deals. I don't think I would pay more than $40 for these, so they loose one star for a high price point with some of them going for $69.. Good luck!

Well sewn. Leg cuffs at bottoms are very wide, only useful with giant boots on. Snow will come up the cuffs! There are no belt loops and the waist cinching elastic is an odd design. It can be fitted to the waist only with an awkward velcro tabbed elastic at the back of the waist. It will likely be hard to keep these from slipping down at the waist because of the bad cinching design. Pockets are not at side seams but straight over each thigh in front, not suitable for keeping hands warm, but flat and with zips for keeping ID or small objects. Waterproof outer fabric is a bit shinny and cheap looking, but these will do in a pinch.

The cut of this is odd. It is  narrow at the bust, tight on my 36 B frame, it will be very tight on larger busted women, unless worn without zipping-up past the waist. Moreover, it a has strange, unflattering pattern, with the arm holes cutting in at the front causing a backwards "racerback" sort of t shape to the front. The top seamof the shoulders comes foward again to the front and the overall length is long. It fits like a long, narrow "wife-beater" t shirt on backwards! It is designed to fit a figure I can't understand, long and narrow like a pole. The sewing is good, no skips or snags. The black on I bought has no logo or non-matching trim like another reviewer wrote about, mine is all black.It is warm but so strangely fitted that I would never buy it again and probably will give it to charity. I have come across many imported garments like this, the patterns are made as though never tried out on actual women for fit.

This tea has a strong flavor. It can be slightly bitter but some will not mind, or it may be brewed fpr shorter time for a lighter flavor. Another method is to add sugar for a rich, sweet tea. I like it plain, but not steeped too long.The box it comes in is strange. It is a box of the shipping box type of brown, corrugated cardboard. It is about twice as tall as an idividually wrapped tea bag, so by the time I recieved it, the wrapped tea bags were every which way, jumbled in this too large, inelegant box. It is not suitable for easy use in a cupboard as most tea I buy, there are no thin cardboard containers, which allow one to open top to stack and take one bag at a time from.
Happy to have this large upply on hand for any job needing some hand protection.

Very useful, the clip makes this more easily used than the ones that plug the lamp flex neck directly into the usb port. Will last longer because of the clip base the other style stresses the usb ports from adjusting the lights.

Best vegan liquid meal replacement yet! Tastes creamy and true to banana flavor. I really like the nutrition contents as it is well balanced and complete. Has good amount of calcium, for example. Orgain vegan drinks taste chalky and gritty compared to this and have zero calcium. Great heated in the microwave, like hot coco in the morning!

Yes, it's a beret. This is what I expected, a type of hat that is sold at street fairs and surplus shops. Not a high-end beret, no edging or trim around the band where it goes against the head. I'd like it to be a little more roomy, to give the right fold with a droop to one side, but it is what it is for this price. Material seems like real wool felt, color is even and true dark black.

The cross over headband part bunches-up and doesn't wash well. Too many seems in the headpiece make bumps and bulk on forehead. Requires fussy, gentle care, maybe hang to dry. Fabric tends to pill, doesn't last in good shape. The neck length needs to be longer to make this easier to tuck into collars for no gaps between neck and clothes, and for ease of movement without un-tucking. I want garments like this, but with better pattern and better fabric.

This developed some sort of loose connection or short at the mini usb connection aperture or between the phone and the charge "puck". It works, but erratically rather than reliably. Exactly as several other reviewers report, when the phone is placed on the charger, it turns on and off over and over again. Instead of a steady charge, messages display showing it continuously flipping between "charging" and "not charging". (There is no extra case on my phone and it is a correct model for this charger).Carefully placing the phone on the puck seems to make little difference. Trying many possible positions and placements of the phone on the puck sometimes results with a steady charging, but it works very inconsistently. It is difficult to tell which position might work or why it only sometimes gives a steady charge. This defeats the point of an easy to use place-and-go charger because it must be fiddled with to prevent the rapid winking off and on glitch. Worth the money only if you like to gamble or enjoy a weird challenge.
