I love Kalso Earth shoes and buy them specifically for the "duck foot" shape. I need lots of room at the toes and ball of my foot and have narrow heels. this is a common problem for many women. Sadly this style does not fit as well as other Kalso Earth shoes I've purchased. They seem to be changing the "duck foot" or "clown shoe" shape to be more and more conventionally "fashionable". Anyway, these are too wide at the heels and the shoes slip partway off with every step. The elastic at the sides of the heel does not fit tightly enough to keep my feet in the shoes. Also the shoes are not wide enough at the balls of the feet, just below the toes, the widest parts of my feet. I think they are altering the old Earth shoe footprint without understanding why it was so useful in the first place.  Very disappointing.

The ear bud pieces are supposed to stay in the cradle ends when not in one's ears, but the magnets are too weak and the buds fall out at the slightest touch, stressing the fragile cords. I do not expect this to last long, the wires eill probably break at the buds because of the too weak magnets

The chain was not as shown, it is grey metal, not black, and I suspect may have a high lead content (toxic).  The medallion itself was as pictured but in the one I received the enamel was not applied properly so there was a gap in the black background that was surely not intentional. Bad quality control for someone to send one that had a clear fault in the execution of the design. A waste of money and unwearable for me.

The lovely fabric is light and airy but not see-through. This machine washes easily on gentle and hangs dry in only minutes with almost no wrinkles, touch-up if necessary with light iron or steamer. The color is beautiful and does not easily fade. The pieces are well cut and sewn with high quality, nothing crooked, seams all very straight and flat. The stitching is even, there are no loose threads.The pattern is new to me as it is three separate pieces. I prefer the three layered, one  piece Saudi style because it is more simple to put on/ easier to wear than this, that is the only reason I do not give 5 stars. This design requires a bit more time and pins to secure well. There is a rectangle hijab (over hair/head) piece, a headband/tie piece which goes on the forehead and the face veil, niqab piece, all three are separate. I suppose I could sew them all together to make them a bit easier. Those familiar with this style will probably love it. One advantage to the separate pieces is the face, niqab, may be worn with other top pieces for a mix-and-match set of hijab one color, niqab another color. I recommend this product, it is beautiful and elegant.

The fringe part is tied in such a way that after a single hand washing in cold water it shrank and ripped in-between half a dozen of the knotted points. I have had other sarongs from this company which were fine but this was ruined before I could wear it one time. The fabric needs to be pre-wshed or the fringe knots need to be tied in another way. The tears while small will rip through the entire length of the fabric wit he slightest pull. Very disappointed

This is a good sack for shopping but it has a design flaw which can cause expensive damage to nice garments. There is a padded part of the shoulder strap made to store the bag when not in use. This little pouch + shoulder pad combination has a  has a velcro closure. When wearing anything sheer or fine (like nylon or knit) the hook side of the velcro in the shoulder strap can catch and snag a nice shirt, blouse, dress or scarf. This could be avoided if the hook-side of the velcro were not about 4 times the size of the catch-side of the velcro. Because there is always unavoidable exposed hook-side velcro (as the catch-side does not fully cover it) snags happen and ruin nice garments being worn when using the sacks. They could either make both sides of the velcro equal so there could be no hook-side exposed or have the smaller section be the hook-side so the exposed, uncovered part would be the smooth catch-side.I will need to use tape or do some sewing or seem ripping to make my bag safe to use. The price of this bag is great but this design flaw ended up being very expensive because of the nice clothes it wrecked before I figured out the problem.

This fits my fine and would be great if the ruffles were more generous. I suspect the quality suffers from an attempt to save money by using the minimum amount of fabric possible to still sew this style. If they made each line of ruffles about an inch wider and overlapped the layers so there would be no gaps without ruffle coverage, it would be much better. The ruffles should also be longer in overall length so they could be gathered more, giving volume to the rows of ruffle. Each strip probably lays out flat about 12" before sewing but would be much better if the strips were about 6" longer then gathered (a sewing term for being puckered before sewing on the base) more fully. As it is it is a good idea but not well excuted in terms of design, The sewing is well enough done, but sewing well if the design is flawed, doesn't improve a garment.I will probably buy more because of lack of market choice. If a competitor offered one made as I describe, it would be much higher value for money. I suspect that this company makes man more first time sales and not a many repeat sales because people really want this garment but are disappointed with it when it comes. As it is the price is too high for the value. If they were made wit more fabric in he ways I suggest, I would feel much better about a $26 price point! I hope anyone wearing this due to chemo/illness will have a full recovery. (Maybe one of you will get well then go into business against the company and be a big success making a nicer cap!)It isn't a bad cap, it is just sad to me that it could be made so much better.

The three I received were each slightly different shades of white. The fabric is cheap, too-thin (a little see-through), synthetic jersey. The white looks slightly grey or slightly dirty. I also do not like the pattern because of the seam placement under the chin and down the front center of the neck; this seam should be out-of-sight, in back.I also do not want the hair knot or bun room to be at the back top crown angled as it is about 90 degrees from vertical. This dictates a hairstyle that many women will not , as I, want to wear. I am not fond of the weird, pointy-head look putting one's hair up like this gives, but worse, it is a very uncomfortable hairstyle for me, causing my scalp to ache after an hour or so.  Not stuffing the hair into this bulge means the piece has an empty area and doesn't fit as it would without the "hair sack". The bottom of the neck all the way around is also too short, making it hard to have coverage because it does not reach and tuck into many collar designs. It should be at least 5 inches longer at the bottom, all the way around.Because this is about the only pattern and fabric available in a ninja underscarf, I must settle for this  not very satisfactory garment. It is better than nothing, but not pleasing. The price is also too high as this is a garment one must have many of, changing them every day, sometimes twice a day. It is flimsy, not strong enough to hold up to constant washing. It is like underwear, it should be affordable, durable and well-made so a woman may have enough of these to be well covered every day. Disappointing.There certainly seems room for a better product to take over the market in selling this garment.

The neck is a slight v-neck, not a crew collar as I'd prefer. The crew neck version of the same brand is, for some reason, $6 more. The garment is well made. I'd rather the logo on the sleeve were not there, it is ugly and makes the garment worth much less to me than if it had no logo.

This was a good deal and it looks great. I was worried the satin finish might not be right because the illustrations/pictures seem to make the finish look shiny. But it has a nice, brushed finish everywhere except the small, pointed end pieces of the bullet-shaped light holders (about 1.6 inch "caps"), which add visual interest. The bullet-shaped light holders have 2 little "rocket fins" each, also adding to the cool factor with a retro-pop look. The included halogen lamps worked fine and it is well made, smooth and even in all joints.I put this up myself in about an hour. I have no formal training, but do know how to wire an electrical socket or a hard-wired phone jack. The instructions were easy to understand. Anyone who reads well and is not downright afraid of doing electrical work could manage, I imagine. Do understand what a ground wire is, and, of course, turn off the main power breaker in your home (not just the wall switch!) before working. Wear safety glasses too (looking up at a hole in the ceiling things can easily fall into eyes). It would be be easier to have a second person help hold the fixture in place as the first screws are tightened, but if determined and a bit clever, one can manage.

I have only used one of the three of these because it smells like unscented laundry soap. It has a clean, soapy smell, and covers bad smells, but it does not smell like cedar at all. There was a slight smell of cedar when I first opened it, but that went away in less than a minute! Now it just smells like a strong old-fashioned laundry soap, which is OK, but is not what I was looking for in a cedar scented deodorizer.I like this brand and Citrus Magic makes great air sprays with orange, grapefruit and other citrus scents. I would like to say nice things about this solid, cedar air freshener, but it just isn't very good.

These paper towels are very stiff and not at all absorbent. They fall apart before they soak up much of anything. They are thin and they tear apart when trying to take a sheet off the roll. Every piece tears in places not perforated when trying to tear it off the roll. I haven't been able to take any complete section off an entire roll. These are just bad paper towels, too thin and they do not soak up anything. It's like trying to wipe up with newspaper, only it tears and falls apart more easily than newspaper. I use Green Forest Bathroom tissue (toilet paper), Green Forest Facial Tissues and Green Forest Napkins, and all those products are good. It would stand to reason the same company could make a good paper towel, but that just isn't the case. I love that these are safer for the environment and use no chlorine. I truly want to like these, but I just can't stand them! I care about the environment, but environmentally safe products can't be so hard to use or of such bad quality that they are a waste of money.I am looking forward to using up the case and buying something else. I want to buy environmentally sound products, but it is unreasonable to spend more money than for "regular" paper towels for a product that is much worse than "regular" paper towels.

I bought 2 of these red recycled glass vases from My Eco Glass, this one, the 7-3/4"  Munich and the 6-3/4" glass ball vase. They were each a different shade of red so could not be used as a set. This one is a good shape, with reasonably thick, not too fragile glass and a nice enough shade or slightly orange-ish red. The others where more purple-ish-red. You may  like this just fine if you buy one and do not try to match it to others.

This arrived 13 days after ordering, but the long shipping time was as stated in the ordering process. They send these one at a time from China, which seems inefficient, but that is not a deal breaker for me. This skin is somewhat opaque, being a rather milky, whitish color of silicone and less clear than other keyboard skins, this makes the keys unnecessarily harder to read.The big problem is the skin does not fit exactly. I have a correct model PC and this skin was clearly made for it, but it is slightly stretched in the gaps between some keys. Everything is in the right place and the key shapes are the correct size, there is small warping in the spaces between keys. Very small distance errors make a big difference on something like this which needs to fit almost perfectly. It bulges and ripples in spots and does not lay flat. This interferes with typing and causes increased errors. If I had to guess what the problem is, I'd say the skin was unevenly pulled off the mold when hot, thereby slightly stretched/deformed during the manufacturing process, before it cooled.I have used other keyboard skins before of much better quality, This cost way too much to be so badly made. I suppose it is better than no protection, but maybe not, because it is causing slowed typing, mistakes and the keys are much harder to read, I will ask for a refund. Maybe I just received a bad one, but you might not want to gamble with your time and money on one of these.

This is a well made brush with a strong, plastic handle which will not bend or break from vigorous use. The black bristles are slightly softer than a scrub brush's bristles. Great for jobs that require the extra length.Pay attention to the listed measurements, this is long and large, not the size of a small dish brush. This is a tool for for washing out pint beer glasses in a deep (bartender's) sink, The brush head fills a standard pint glass perfectly, The long handle keeps sleeves/arms out of deep water. Good product.

The positives: it is a nice shape, like a fishbowl, about the size of a large cantaloupe. It has a good color, a purplish red.  It is a good weight, not too light, won't knock over too easily.The negatives: It is made in two pieces and pressed together leaving raised glass lines up 2 sides. A globe-vase looks better when made of one piece, without seams.Also, I bought two other vases by the same maker/seller also of the red, recycled glass. I assumed the vases would all match, but the colors do not match. Each of the 3 vases is a different shade of red; one is more purple, one more orange, one in the middle-red range.This isn't a bad vase, some will like it. The price ($17.50) seems slightly high for this quality. If you are trying to make a set with others in this "group", the colors are not the same from vase to vase. I am returning this because of the inconsistent colors and the obvious seams bother me.

What a bunch of cups! It will be hard to ever run out with so many. They are shinny and clean and sturdy, exactly as expected. I only subtract one point because I worry about  plastic ending up in landfills, but otherwise,  good deal!

This is an OK deal for the price, but it makes only a very course (big pieces) grind of pepper. The small size is comfortable to grip with smaller hands, but it must be refilled frequently as it hold little. For someone who uses a pepper at almost every meal, it will need filling.After about 2 months of light use this is very hard to turn. Something seems very wrong with the grinder.

I bought the Basil All purpose cleaner with the Lemon Verbena Glass Cleaner. The all purpose goes a long way. 1/4 cup mixes with  1 gallon (64 ounces) of water to make cleaner for most household surfaces. Put it in an empty spray bottle from whatever cleaner you used to use. It does nice work with out feeling harsh or toxic. The glass cleaner also does a nice job on windows, mirrors, etc..The basil scent is not very true to what I think basil should be. It smells more vanilla-ish than it should, to me. The scent stays in the room and I like that aspect. Nothing overpowering like pine-sol, but a nice, light scent to make the room seem freshly cleaned. I prefer the geranium to the basil, but everyone will have their own taste in which scent is best. These cleaners is a great alternative to the harsh, strong, chemical, commercial stuff with names like "Zoom" and "Pow". I recommend the Mrs Meyer's line.

UPDATE (October, 2015):  These were higher priced when released, but currently the prices for 2400 mah AA batteries and 2000 mAh AA batteries can be very close, depending on when you buy.  If that's the case when you're buying, for many people it probably makes sense to go with these higher capacity batteries.These batteries have been great to use over the past year and a half.  We don't use them intensively, and don't usually fully discharge them.  So the reduced life (in terms of the number of charge cycles) isn't a big factor for us.  500 full charge cycles is several years of use for us, or anyone else who uses them even a couple times per week, on average.If you can get a great deal on some of the other AA  options, you may want to consider them.  Also consider your needs, in terms of how often you charge them and whether you will use them often enough to get the benefit of a higher number of cycles.  The newer Eneloop batteries claim a life of up to 2100 charge cycles.  If you recharge them very often, batteries with a higher number of cycles in their life may be a better fit for you.(For us, we'd probably never get the benefit of 1000-2000 cycles on a set of batteries because that's 10-20 years worth of use for most of our applications.  By that time, it seems likely the basic chemistry of the battery will deteriorate, or much better batteries will come along, or we'll lose them or damage them.)Finally, my review is for the AA batteries.  Note that the additional benefit to the high capacity option for AAA batteries is much smaller - a difference of 50-100 mAh (850 vs. 750 or 800).  So again, the regular capacity batteries may be a good option for you.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -THE QUICK TAKE:  The AmazonBasics High Capacity AA Rechargeable batteries are a nice product, but that comes at a higher price (at current pricing).  Unless you need the extra capacity of a 2400 mAh battery, you may want to get the regular 2000 mAh Eneloop or AmazonBasics batteries at a lower price.  Similarly, if you don't need to store them before using them, conventional rechargeables will do the job.The product description on the Amazon product page has a good summary, if you're not familiar with the advantages of "pre-charged" or "low-self discharge" batteries.  This is a somewhat new technology, available in the last 10 years or so;  the batteries are slow to lose their charge, so they can be sold charged and ready to use; and will hold a charge for some time.  It's only relatively recently that higher-capacity versions have been available.If cost isn't important, and you don't want to have to figure out which battery is which - then sure, stock up on these.  But given the cost, most people will want to use these where they are needed.DO YOU NEED THE CAPACITY?  You're paying more for an extra 25% capacity; unless you have a high-drain device that will use that charge, you may be able to use the regular capacity version - such as the AmazonBasics 8 Pack AA Ni-MH Pre-Charged Rechargeable Batteries, 1000 Cycle (Typical 2000mAh, Minimum 1900mAh) or eneloop AA 1800 cycle,  Ni-MH Pre-Charged Rechargeable Batteries, 8 Pack.  Cameras are a good example of a use where the extra capacity could be important.  Slower-draining children's toys, on the other, may not need these batteries.DO YOU NEED LOW SELF DISCHARGE?  If you're looking for a high-capacity battery and you don't plan to store the batteries before using them - for example, you're able to charge your camera batteries each night - there's no need to pay extra for the LSD feature.CYCLES:  Note that these high capacity batteries also state a life of 500 cycles, versus 1000 cycles or more on the regular capacity batteries.  Many people overstate the importance of this - if you use even 500 cycles, you're getting your money's worth; and honestly, if you're recharging them within a few days of use, you don't need LSD batteries - regular rechargeables will do.  Still, it's another example of how you may want to use these batteries selectively.USE A SMART CHARGER:  You'll want to use a charger that charges each battery individually, often referred to as a smart charger.The ones I received have a black top, and are made in Japan.

The design of these mugs is very attractive.  The edge and walls are thin, making it more elegant than chunky.However, after a year and half we've noticed that the coffee stain is building up inside.  They also stain more easily from spoons (stirring inside the cup).  Something about the finish, I assume, that isn't as stain resistant as most other porcelain.By the way, we also had one mug shattered upon arrival.  Obviously Amazon makes it easy to deal with that, other than the time wasted unnecessarily and the disappointment.  It's a shame they weren't boxed and packed properly.

Traveler2014, J. Lalor and persona non grata provide very helpful info.And yes, it's a fair amount of effort to get this working with good rates.  If you just plan to use it for one trip, you may want to consider other alternatives.  If you plan to visit the UK more than once, some additional info:TOP-UPS: As others have noted, when I tried this in 2013, I also found it was more or less impossible to top this up from the US.  But shops in the airport sell top-ups, so you can get this SIM and your phone number before you go, and get the phone working quickly.UNLOCK YOUR PHONE:  Even though you can't top it up, having the SIM before you go lets you make sure your phone is really unlocked.  That's critical.When you get to the UK (or online if you want to set that up) -- You will be on a Starter plan until you pick an Animal plan, which you can do by calling 343.  You may also be able to create an account online to do this.- CHOOSE A PLAN BEFORE YOU TOP UP: If you haven't chosen an "Animal Plan," do so BEFORE YOU TOP UP, as there are bonuses applied when you top up if you select a plan first.  I like the Dolphin plan for the data; a £10 top-up currently gets you 400 free texts and 1GB of data as a bonus; if you're planning to call the US, you may want the Camel plan (though it's no longer showing as available online).  In either case, you get a bonus and you can still use the top-up credit to buy minutes. Search on Orange Animal Plans Pay As You Go, and Pay As You Go Price Guide on the EE site.- BUY AN EXTRA: Buy an "Extra" to get the cheapest rates.  For example, ¬£7.50 gets you 100 UK minutes good for 1 month; ¬£5.00 buys 30 minutes for calls from Western Europe good for 1 month.  You lose any unused minutes, but having a working phone with voice, text and data for your trip is well worth the ¬£10-15 or so it will cost you.Buy an Extra online, or by sending text to 6620 (after you have a balance of credit on the phone):¬£7.50 -  100 UK minutes - 1 month - ¬£0.08/min - Text this: MINS 7.5¬£5.00 - 30 minutes from Western Europe - 1 month - ¬£0.17/min - Text this:  W EURO MINS 5You can also do this online, once you set up an online account and have credit on the account.There are lots of other options - do a web search on Orange Pay As You Go Priceguide to find the current PDFA few other comments:- In the UK, it's the person placing the call who pays the charge for the call.- The SIMs shipping now seem to be a micro-SIM with a holder to fit around the micro SIM so it fits inside a full size slot if needed.  That will fit an iPhone through 4S, but not an iPhone 5 which uses a nano-SIM.  See the Apple page entitled, "Understanding which SIM card your iPhone or iPad uses."- If you have an AT&T iphone, or a Verizon iPhone 4S or later, contact AT&T or Verizon to get it unlocked well before you go.  (More generally, make sure you have an unlocked phone, with the right frequency bands.)- Keep the PIN number you get in the second message, it's needed if you want to contact Orange or create an online account.

The NVidia GTX 750 series cards are a new line from NVidia, using a new chip design called Maxwell.  They're a big jump forward in efficiency, in terms power per watt, which allows you to install them in most desktops without upgrading the power supply or enhancing the cooling and still get much-improved performance.  The new Maxwell graphics processing unit (GPU), along with 1GB of GDDR5 memory, allows you to get the most performance out of one PCI bus-powered card.This card perfectly fit what I needed to upgrade my system to allow me to do video encoding effectively.  While I'd have no problem replacing my power supply, I just don't have the time or feel the need to do it, given my computing needs.Depending on your needs and current card prices, consider two other cards:- The "Superclocked" version of the card this review is posted for, EVGA GTX 750 Superclock w/ 1GB GDDR5, which has a faster clock speed and will perform a little better when you're maxing out the card.  If the price difference is small, go with that card.- The EVGA GTX 750Ti Superclock w/ 2GB GDDR5 will give you the maximum performance for a card powered by only the PCI-e slot.LOW POWER NEEDS:  This GTX 750 card is a good bet if you're looking to keep power and cooling needs down.  According to the NVidia site, this card needs a minimum of a 300 Watt power supply, with a current rating of 20 amps on the +12 volt rail.  A standard Dell 350W power supply has 25 amps on the +12V rail.  Total power draw is just 55 watts, well under the 75 watts the PCI-e slot delivers.  So you can put this card into many desktop systems without the hassle of upgrading the power supply or concerns about cooling.If you're considering one of the other 750 or 750 Ti cards, check the NVidia site for power needs.  Most of them are designed to use just the power from the PCI-e slot.But some overclocked cards with more complex cooling systems (like the Asus) have a 6-pin power supply connector. That's probably not necessary as all GTX 750 boards have on-board power limiting circuitry that keeps it from drawing more than 75W.  Just check to see if the card uses it, and if your power supply has that connector.NEW KING OF LOW POWER HTPC CARDS:  The nvidia GTX 750 / 750 Ti is the new king of home theater PC (HTPC) cards for lower-powered systems, for those willing to have a small and quiet fan (like the one on this 01G-P4-2751-KR card).  The Radeon HD 7750 (such as this XFX AMD Radeon HD 7750 Card) has generally been considered the card with the best performance among quiet cards, until now.750 IS A LIMITED VERSION OF THE 750 TI:  The 750 has most of the same features as the 750 Ti, as it's an identical graphics chip with fewer components. Anandtech has a nice article detailing the differences between the 750 and the 750 Ti, search for it.TWO SLOTS:  Note that while these cards use only one slot for power, all of the current GTX 750 cards use two slots worth of space, and some with more complex cooling are notably longer than this card.LOTS OF VARIATIONS:  There are a lot of GTX 750 cards out already, and more are coming.  The GPU sections are the same, so differences will primarily be the parts of the card designed by the manufacturer:1) Clock Speed:  There are overclock / superclock versions as well.  They're very stable, so if you're looking to max out performance, consider those.2) Ports:  Port configurations vary as well across cards and manufacturers.  I like the way this card is set up with the ports along one slot, to allow air from outside the case to get pulled in through the second slot location.  If you want to run two DVI monitors, it's easy to convert the HDMI port to DVI using an adapter, or an HDMI to DVI Adapter Cable.3) Graphics memory:  If you're running multiple monitors, you may want to go with the 2GB versions.4) Cooling:  The cooling differences are the most obvious, it's where the manufacturers get creative and try to differentiate their products.  There's a wide range of cooling systems, with single fan and dual fan, heat sinks and pipes.  If you have to ask, you probably don't need it.5) Form factor:  Low profile cards have been announced but aren't generally available for sale as of now (March 2014).EVGA IS A GOOD CHOICE:  Several manufacturers make versions of the GTX 750 cards.  Different people have their favorite companies, but many like the EVGA customer service and 3 year warranty.COOLING MATTERS:  Keep in mind that all a fancy cooling system does is draw the heat from the card and put it into your case.  Unless you're willing to upgrade the cooling on your case, you may want to be careful how many watts of heat you add.A GREAT VALUE FOR MANY USERS:  Some have criticized the card because, for the money, it's not the highest performing card.  That's a narrow view, and not a useful view for everyone.  If raw performance is all that matters to you, and you already have plenty of spare power supply capacity and good cooling, then another card would likely be a better choice.But if you're looking to sharply upgrade your graphics card and video connectivity, without the effort of replacing your power supply or worries about cooling - the GTX 750 is unbeatable at the moment, and likely will be for some time to come.

The refurbished Acer Chromebook C720-2802 is a good value at one hundred fifty dollars if you primarily plan to use it for web applications such as browsing, email, media, and so on, and aren't getting it for an intensive user who likes to keep 30 tabs open (think about more memory for them).  It's a good match for children or other basic users, or as a second device.  It's designed to be easy to setup, use and maintain.The hardware is limited but adequate for the uses above, and better than most other Chromebooks.  The upside of the hardware limitations is the long 8 hour battery life (as a laptop, or for displaying video about 6.5 hours).This is a newer model (the C720 series was introduced in fall 2013) with a number of improvements from the older C710 series, including longer battery life and smaller size.Other than being dinged for the bland design, it has gotten very positive reviews in late 2013 and early 2014.  Look for the Endgadget C720 review page for links to a number of reviews.  People like the trackpad.PORTABLE AND SMALL:  The compact size and light weight make it very portable.  However, the screen size and keyboard size may be too small for some users, depending on their hand size and their eyesight.  It's a 11.6" HD Widescreen LCD display (1366 x 768 resolution) with a matte coating.  The keyboard is smaller and has less "travel" (up and down range of motion) than larger computers, but I found it easy to get used to and have no trouble typing on it.This laptop measures 11.3" by 8" x 0.8" and weighs 2.76 pounds.CHROMEBOOK:  In case you don't know, a Chromebook is not a Windows or Mac computer.  It's based on the Google Chrome suite, and the operating system is Chrome OS.  This works fine if *all* the applications you need are on the web.  But note that it will not run Skype (a Microsoft product), or let you install any other software (including drivers for mice or printers).  So printing is somewhat cumbersome (depending on your setup) and not all USB drives and devices will work.However, the Chrome OS and Chromebooks have some substantial advantages, besides the price:  you don't have to buy any software or hardware; you don't have mess around with Windows for software updates, dealing with problems, etc.; virus protection is built in; and if you have issues with software you can easily re-load all the software with a "PowerWash."FAST BOOT:  Because this uses Chrome OS and a Solid State Drive, it boots very quickly - less than 10 seconds usually.ACER:  Acer is the fourth largest computer company in the world, after Lenovo, HP and Dell, and ahead of Asus.  They also sell computers under the Gateway and Packard Bell brand names.REFURBISHED:  Computers sold as refurbished aren't new.  Sometimes they've been repaired, sometimes they are just returns.  Some may have cosmetic damage - but they should not have any functional issues. You do need to be prepared to return the item if there's a problem, so it may not be for everyone.  But for most people, it's a way to get a great value on a laptop that will work as well as a new one.  You'll forget it's refurbished.90 DAY WARRANTY:  As a refurbished computer, the warranty is only 90 days.  Typically problems appear early on, and there aren't many moving parts in this computer.  But the shorter coverage is one reason why this costs less.2GB OF RAM, MAXIMUM:  The maximum amount of memory that can be installed is the 2 GB that this ships with.  That's enough for most web applications, but not enough for intensive applications like complex photo or video editing.  It is fairly fast PC3-12800 DDR3 memory, though.MODEST PROCESSOR: The Intel¬Æ Celeron¬Æ 2955U dual-core processor runs at 1.4GHz and has a CPU benchmark score of 1533.  It's fine for the uses described above, but only comparable in processing power to the netbooks that were so popular a few years ago.  However, it is a newer processor (released Fall 2013), so the Intel¬Æ HD graphics are improved and the newer Ultra Low Voltage processors extend the battery life.  It's also a more capable processor than some other Chromebooks, which use tablet-quality processors.LIMITED STORAGE SO USE THE CLOUD: The 16GB solid state drive won't hold many files; about 10GB of the space is free for your files.  So plan on using the cloud and/or flash drives for your storage needs.  There is a built in SD card reader as well.USB 3.0: You may not think this matters to you, but it does.  If you want to use flash drives, external hard drives or a memory card reader, USB 3.0 is far faster than USB 2.0. There's one USB 3.0 port and one USB 2.0 port on this laptop.SOME NICE FEATURES:  The C720-2802 includes the essential features -  wifi, stereo speakers, a basic webcam - as well as as well as some nice features not found on all low price computers - Bluetooth 4.0 for wireless connections to a phone or speakers; and  HDMI to connect video devices, displays or a TV.  However, as with all of these tiny laptops, there is no optical drive (DVD).

If you're considering The Interior Design Reference Manual, it's probably because you're considering getting an NCIDQ certification.  It's carefully designed to map to the test, so for that end it's an indispensable tool.But if you're considering certification, you're probably thinking about the value that will bring to you.  Certainly preparing for the exam will give you something important - an understanding of the various domains of knowledge needed to be effective in interior design.  It's important to have some working knowledge of a wide range of areas, as the work of a designer builds on and relies on the work of other specialties.  The Interior Design Reference Manual gives you a good basic survey of a number of design and building areas, as well as areas more specific to interior design (such as lighting, finishes, woodworking).  It's very useful to have a comprehensive presentation of the things you need to know.The challenge will be to use that knowledge, so that you reinforce it and add to it.  Otherwise, like so many other things you've learned in your life, you'll know it just long enough to take the test.You might also be considering whether to seek certification in terms of the career impact and value it will bring.  It's worth doing a little work to evaluate which of the certifications in Interior Design to pursue, if any, and what value they bring to your career.  Be sure to talk to some practicing designers, and ask them what makes a good designer, and what they look for when they hire new designers or assistants.

This Belkin Clear Screen Protector is the most complete kit I've seen, with the best instructions.  (Though I do have a few additions, see below.)  The kit includes 2 screen protectors, a cleaning cloth, and a dust pick-up sticker (used after you clean the screen).  The screen protectors have black or white tabs so you know which side to peel first.You definitely do want a screen protector for your iPad and iPhone, it's easy to end up with a scratch.  The protectors to do not affect the use - your iPad still works well with a screen protector.The instructions inside the cover of the packaging go through how to install.  It is a little challenging with the size of the iPad.  A few additional comments:- Clean the screen with a damp, soft, lint free, cotton cloth. (Cotton is a softer fiber than paper or synthetic fabrics.)  An old cotton dishtowel or t-shirt is a good bet. (Old fabric has less lint.) Let it dry.  Then clean it again with the Belkin cloth.- Look at the screen carefully to remove all the lint before starting. Use the included sticker.- Before removing the adhesive covering sheet, line up the screen protector and get a sense for how it fits. Make a plan to align it with an edge and the main button. Note how much space you have on either long side, so you know where the protector needs to be to fit properly on the main button.- After removing the adhesive covering on the screen protector, apply it to one edge - as the instructions suggest, use a long edge to get it on straight, checking the main button location - and work your way to the other side.- Squeeze out the bubbles from the center outward, in each direction.If it's not perfect, don't obsess.  Try using it, I find I don't notice a few small bubbles when I'm using it.

This Newhouse Lighting LED lamp is the perfect dorm or kids' room light.  Unfortunately, I don't entirely mean that as a compliment.  Let me explain ...Pros:+ The lamp gets the light right.  The light is smooth, thanks to the diffuser over the LEDs.+ The 3000K light is a nice color - "bright warm light" as it says on the box.+ It's about the right brightness for a close-up lamp - 300 lumens which is about the equivalent of 30 watts of incandescent.  And as an LED, it doesn't get hot, and doesn't warm you up.+ The clamp holds very well.+ The neck of the light is strong enough to stay in any position you bend it.  So it can be used in almost any configuration.Issues:- The switch for the lamp is on the cord, about 6" down.  So depending on where you have it, you may be fishing around behind or beside the furniture it's attached to, trying to find the switch.- The clamp seems to work well, but it's such a prominent feature (4.5" D x 3" W) they should have given some thought to making it more attractive.Also, to me it would have been nice if the neck were a color other than silver - say, the same color as the head of the lamp.  But that's a matter of personal taste.Overall, it could be easier to use the switch and the lamp could be more attractive.  The lamp head itself looks good, the neck less so, the clamp not so much.  So, it's the perfect dorm room light, but a little less perfect in another setting.Luckily, you can decide for yourself about the looks, and think about whether having the switch on the cord will work for you.  The light functions well and works better in a number of respects than other similar lights.The clamp is about 1" deep and 3" wide, if you're trying to judge whether it will attach where you want the lamp to attach.UPDATE November 2015:  I'd still assess the lamp just as I described.  I still don't love the clamp (though it is very strong).  But for the right use, it's a great lamp - so I'm raising the rating from 4 to 5 stars. I want to emphasize two things:1) The light from this lamp is very nice, especially compared to other LED lights.  They really got the light right.  It's a nice, bright, warm color.  It's very smooth.  The bulb is a single, glowing, lit surface - not an annoying row of bright, distracting LEDs like so many other lamps.2) The neck is very good at bending into many useful shapes, and holding in place.I liked this enough that I bought another one for our kids room.

This is just what I needed, and luckily I remembered to order it from Amazon before the snow fell so it would be in stock.The steel blade gives it enough sturdiness to survive the mix of snow we get in New England, including some ice; and to clean the surface well.Obviously with a steel tool, you want to be a little careful with uneven surfaces or anything that might get damaged.  You're not quite swinging an axe, but it's kind of the same idea.I will say that while I read the comments that it's a heavy shovel, I somewhat downplayed those.  However, it is noticeably heavy and does add some effort to the overall work of shoveling the snow.  It's a good and necessary trade off for me, and I can use the exercise.  But have no doubt it's a heavyish shovel, even for a manly man.If you have space for more than one shovel, this shovel and a lighter one would be a great set.

It should be obvious that the Defender series is a chunkier case, for those looking for more protection for their iPhone.  (If you're looking for a slimmer case that still offers good protection, try the OtterBox Commuter Series.)I'm a big fan of the OtterBox cases.  (I've tried a number of others, and they don't really stack up.)- OtterBoxes are well designed - they include the features I want, and some I didn't know I needed.- They fit well, and more generally match the features of the phone carefully.  OtterBox gets something that apparently isn't obvious to other case makers - you not only want to use all the features of the phone, but you want to use them in an easy and enjoyable way. - The materials are well chosen to provide strength, grip and durability.  (That said, some of my Defender cases developed splits in the skinnier bits, like near the connector.)The screen protector is well made and reasonably easy to apply.  Be sure to put it on.  A few tips for applying the screen protector: - Clean it with a damp, soft, lint free, cotton cloth.  (Cotton is a softer fiber than paper or synthetic fabrics.)  An old cotton dishtowel or t-shirt is a good bet.  (The old part means it has less lint.)  Let it dry.- Look at the screen carefully to remove all the lint before starting.- Before removing the adhesive covering sheet, line up the screen protector and get a sense for how it fits.  Make a plan to align it with an edge and the main button.  Note how much space you have on either long side, so you know where it needs to be to fit properly on the main button.- After removing the adhesive covering on the screen protector, apply it to one edge - I use a long edge to get it on straight, checking the main button location - and work your way to the other side.- Squeeze out the bubbles from the center outward, in each direction.I get a year or two out of the screen protectors, so it's worth some effort to get it on right.I like the fact that the headphone jack has a cover, as I don't use it a lot I prefer to keep out the fuzz and goo.  However, when I do try to use it, not every plug wants to fit into the available space.
